sentence: Mr. President, did President Putin indicate any willingness for Assad to step down? And did you make progress with him or President Hu in stopping the bloodshed in Syria? [SEP] These were major topics in both meetings. The violence in Syria is out of control, civilians are being targeted, and Assad has lost legitimacy. Massacring citizens makes an orderly transition with Assad in power impossible. This transition isn't easy. Russia and China have been more resistant to applying pressure. We had a candid conversation. The U.S. isn't aligned with Russia and China, but they recognize the dangers of civil war and don't condone the massacres. They believe everyone would be better served if Syria had a mechanism for ceasing violence and creating a legitimate government. I've said we should work with the UN and Kofi Annan on a political transition. I hope we can present a pathway for resolving this conflict. Russia and China aren't signed on yet, but they recognize the situation is grave and doesn't serve their interests. We agree that helping the Syrian people find a resolution would benefit everyone. I don't see a scenario where Assad stays and violence is reduced. He didn't fulfill his side of the Annan plan. The international monitors had to leave. The opposition has engaged in violence, but the images from places like Homs were the direct result of the Syrian Government's decisions, and Assad is responsible.
label: Implicit

sentence: Can you comment on the Al Qaida intelligence report? [SEP] Say what?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, while we appreciate the progress on COVID-19, many Americans are concerned about your other campaign promises: immigration, gun control, voting rights, climate change. Given Republican opposition, how far will you go to deliver on these promises? [SEP] Look, when I took office, my priority was clear: address the urgent crises facing the American people, namely COVID-19 and the economic fallout. That's where I focused my energy. The other issues you mentioned are long-term challenges. We'll tackle them one by one, as we're able. But the immediate need is to provide stability and security for families who are struggling. We'll work with anyone who's willing to work with us, but we won't be deterred by partisan obstructionism.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Mr. President, on the wall, are you going to insist that you must have wall funding before you can sign something for the DREAMers or for spending for the rest of the year? [SEP] Our country needs a wall. Mexico, you see what's happening there. You see what just happened yesterday with one of their big political leaders. Mexico is not doing particularly well when it comes to the kind of thing that we have great interest in. Drugs are pouring across our border. We're stopping it, but we need a wall to really stop it. We need a wall in this country. You know it. I know it. Everybody knows it. We have to have a wall, so that's going to be part of it.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, just to be clear, will they receive the $600 a week on top of existing benefits? [SEP] Let's just say we're exploring all options. Details will be released when the time is right. Rest assured, we have the resources.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. They are, at this point, some would say, a nuclear power. Do you accept North Korea as a nuclear-armed state, at least for the time being? And are you thinking about reimposing the military exercises with South Korea, or will you keep it a freeze-for-freeze? [SEP] Well, you know, the military exercises, I gave that up quite a while ago because it costs us a hundred million dollars every time we do it. We fly these massive bombers in from Guam. And when I first started, a certain general said: Oh, yes, sir, we fly them in from Guam. It's right next door. Well, right next door is 7 hours away. And then, they come, and they drop millions of dollars of bombs, and then they go back and—but we would spend—I mean, we spent hundreds of millions of dollars on those exercises, and I hated to see it.I thought it was unfair. And frankly, I was, sort of, of the opinion that should help us with that. You know, we're protecting . I think they should help us with that. So those exercises are very expensive. And I was telling the generals—I said: Look, you know, exercising is fun, and it's nice, and I play—they play the war games. And I'm not saying it's not necessary, because at some levels it is, but at other levels, it's not. But it's a very, very expensive thing. And you know, we do have to think about that too.But when they spend hundreds of millions of dollars on those exercises—and we don't get reimbursed—we're spending a tremendous amount of money on many countries, protecting countries that are very rich that can certainly afford to pay us and then some.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, concerning Afghanistan, what is your anticipated timeframe for withdrawing troops, mirroring the 16-month plan for Iraq? Furthermore, will you lift the Pentagon's prohibition on media coverage of the return of fallen soldiers at Dover Air Force Base, a policy once condemned by Senator Biden? [SEP] First, I want to acknowledge the tragic loss of four American service members in Iraq today. My heart goes out to their families. It's a constant reminder of the burdens of this office. Regarding media access at Dover, we're currently reviewing the policy in consultation with the Department of Defense, and I'll provide an answer after a careful assessment. Afghanistan presents a unique challenge. While Iraq has shown progress with a functioning political system, Afghanistan's government appears disconnected. The Taliban and Al Qaeda operate freely in the border regions. We're undertaking a comprehensive review, engaging General Petraeus and Ambassador Holbrooke, to formulate a regional strategy. We require improved coordination among military, diplomatic, and development initiatives. However, let's not forget our purpose: 9/11. We cannot permit Al Qaeda to operate unchecked. I don't have a precise timeline yet, but I won't allow them to plot attacks on our soil.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: So, no hints whatsoever regarding the region or countries? [SEP] Let's just say the details will be revealed in due course. Stay tuned.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. I just wanted to follow up, before I ask a coronavirus question, on Lebanon. You called this an attack. Are you confident that this was an attack and not an accident? [SEP] Well, it would seem like it, based on the explosion. I've met with some of our great generals, and they just seem to feel that it was. This was not a—some kind of a manufacturing explosion type of event. This was a—seems to be, according to them—they would know better than I would, but they seem to think it was a attack. It was a bomb of some kind, yes.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, are you still committed to signing that Executive Order regarding birthright citizenship, as you previously stated? [SEP] That's a question for another day. Let's move on.

sentence: Sir, with all due respect, Americans are struggling with rising costs. When can they expect relief? And given the limitations of your administration's policies, are you truly able to address the root causes of inflation? [SEP] The problem is the supply chain. That's what's driving up prices. We're working on it. The chip shortage is a big issue, especially for cars. We're trying to fix that. Energy prices are more complex. We got countries to release oil reserves, which helped some. But it's going to be tough. We need more competition in the meat industry, too. And Build Back Better would actually reduce inflation, according to the experts.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, with all due respect, shouldn't the American people know if their leaders acted unethically, regardless of legal technicalities? [SEP] The past is the past. My focus is on the future.

sentence: President Obama, TPP is stalled in Congress. Will you alter your strategy, especially with Boeing and GE deals? Should it address currency manipulation? Also, your reaction to Mullah Mansur's death, Pakistan's concerns, a potential new Afghan offensive, and a more radical Taliban leader? [SEP] Regarding TPP, every trade agreement presents difficulties. Parties always seek a better deal. With multiple participants, scrutiny is intense. In an election year, some will try to gain political advantage.Nevertheless, I remain confident we will succeed because it is the right course of action. It benefits America, the region, and the world.This is the fastest-growing area globally. It represents a substantial market for the U.S. Most nations already sell to us with low tariffs. Conversely, tariffs are higher for U.S. products sold there. A deal eliminating 18,000 taxes on U.S. goods in these markets is advantageous for American businesses and workers.Historically, trade agreements have been criticized for exposing our markets to nations with lower wages, inadequate labor practices, and lax environmental regulations. TPP mandates enforceable commitments to improve labor standards, empower workers, and address environmental concerns. This enables us to engage with countries like Vietnam and collaborate on these issues.I have yet to encounter a compelling argument that TPP will worsen our situation. We will demonstrably benefit. American workers and businesses will gain from TPP's passage. I am confident it will pass.The politics will be turbulent. This was true for the Korean, Colombian, and Panamanian free trade agreements I inherited. But we achieved their passage. I am confident we will do so again, despite the challenges.Regarding currency manipulation, TPP incorporates transparency and reporting mechanisms to monitor it. Some advocate for enforceable provisions allowing us to impose tariffs if currency is significantly devalued. However, determining if devaluation is manipulation is difficult. Binding other nations on monetary policy would necessitate binding our Federal Reserve, which we will not do. We have strengthened provisions to address competitive devaluations.Finally, Mullah Mansur's death is confirmed. As Taliban leader, he targeted U.S. personnel in Afghanistan, who were there to maintain a counterterrorism presence and train Afghan forces. This does not alter our strategy. We are not re-engaging in combat operations. Our role is to assist Afghanistan in securing itself.However, when a prominent leader consistently plans to harm U.S. personnel and resists peace negotiations, I must act to protect our people. That is the message we have conveyed.President Quang, allow me to address the Trans-Pacific Partnership. We view TPP as a significant economic connection, driving economic growth in our country and the Asia-Pacific region. Vietnam's participation is a step in our international integration.President Ob. Mr. President, sorry to interrupt. We're not getting translation. Testing one, two, three.President Ob. For you? Can you hear, Mr. President?President Ob. Okay. Testing one, two, three.President Ob. It's just, I'm sure that he was saying something very wise and important, and we wanted to make sure that we all heard it.President ung. So I would like to add that Vietnam, together with other TPP countries, have been making efforts to narrow differences, to promote cooperation in the spirit of mutual understanding and mutual respect. And we will try to reduce differences in the spirit of constructiveness and understanding and paying attention to one another's legitimate interests. And the finalization of TPP is also the successful outcomes of all 12 members of the TPP, rather than any individual effort. And we are prepared to ratify TPP, and we stand ready to implement all the commitments under TPP.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, what can you tell us about the accident off the coast of California involving the Marines and the Navy corpsman? [SEP] I'm about to get a full briefing on that situation.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, on the topic of the oil price cap: Can we expect it to alleviate the high gasoline prices for American drivers, and what's the estimated timeframe for Americans to continue paying a premium as a result of the war? sentence: Mr. President, regarding voting access, are you concerned about potential limitations impacting citizens' ability to cast their ballots? It's really up to them, you know? Next question, please.

sentence: Mr. President, critics argue that your administration's approach to Iraq lacks clarity, failing to establish clear objectives for the U.S. military presence and neglecting the potential of domestic oil production to address energy security concerns. How do you respond to these criticisms? [SEP] We're working on a strategic framework with the Iraqi government, covering diplomacy, economics, justice. It includes a security agreement. They want a timeline for transitioning to overwatch, where we're training, providing logistics, and conducting special ops. For our troops to be there, we need an agreement with the government, authorities to operate, and protections for our troops. We're negotiating that now. It needs to be done before the end of the year, unless the UN mandate is extended. So there are two parts to the agreement, and we're working on both.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, with respect, the timeline for troop withdrawal from Syria remains unclear. Can you provide a specific date or at least a target range for the completion of this withdrawal? [SEP] We're bringing our troops home. That's the important thing. We're not going to telegraph our moves to the enemy, but you can be sure it's happening, and it's happening soon.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Could I follow up on a couple of points, please? [SEP] Okay.

sentence: Mr. President, after all these years and sacrifices in Afghanistan, can you honestly say it was worth it, given the ongoing problems with corruption and instability? And President Karzai, do you still think most of the corruption is due to foreign influence, and are you really going to step down after the next election? [SEP] Let's remember why we went to Afghanistan in the first place. We were attacked. We had to strike back. We took out Al Qaeda. That was the mission. We did it. Now, building a nation is a different story. Did we get everything we wanted? No. But we gave them a chance for a more stable Afghanistan. That's progress. As for corruption, it's everywhere. We're helping the Afghan government fight it. They have to take charge. We're not staying there forever. It's up to the Afghan people.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Sir, to be absolutely clear, are we including the NHS in these talks? [SEP] I'm sorry, I didn't hear you correctly. Could you speak up?

sentence: Q. Mr. President, representing Chinese media, I'm curious: Do you foresee a future where U.S.-North Korea relations mirror the current U.S.-Vietnam dynamic? [SEP] Come again? I didn't quite catch that.

sentence: Q. Isn't it time to think about doing more?And on another issue, would you support a summer moratorium on the Federal gas tax? [SEP] First of all, the money is just now making it into people's bank accounts. And I applaud the Speaker and the leader of the Senate and minority leaders there to—for working together to get this done. And now, after a period of time, the money is beginning to arrive, and we'll see what the effects are.And we'll look at any idea in terms of energy, except I will tell you this: that if Congress is truly interested in solving the problem, they can send the right signal by saying, we're going to explore for oil and gas in the U.S. territories, starting with ANWR. We can do so in an environmentally friendly way. They ought to say, why don't we—I proposed, you might remember, taking some abandoned military bases and providing regulatory relief so we can build new refineries. I mean, if we're generally interested in moving forward with an energy policy that sends a signal to the world that we're not—we're going to try to become less reliant upon foreign oil, we can explore at home as well as continue on with an alternative fuels program.Yes, sir./Oil Supply
label: Implicit

sentence: Given the current trajectory, Mr. President, what specific metrics will you be using to determine whether the 'new normal' is a success, and what contingency plans are in place if vaccination rates remain stagnant or new variants emerge? [SEP] Look, the key is getting more people vaccinated. That's number one. Number two, these new pills are a game-changer. They'll help people stay out of the hospital. And number three, we gotta get the rest of the world vaccinated. Can't build a wall high enough to keep the variants out. So, we're working on all of that. We're looking at how to get the world vaccinated, and that's what we're focused on.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, with the UK experiencing a surge in coronavirus cases, their exemption from the travel ban seems questionable. What's the rationale behind this, and are you prepared to reverse course if necessary? [SEP] Well, I rely on the advice of my team. We're looking at the new numbers coming out of the UK. It's possible we'll have to include them on the list. We might even remove some others. It's a dynamic situation.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. What part did Japan play? And did the abduction issue come up? [SEP] Yes.

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. Two questions for you. One on Judge Kavanaugh and also one on trade. On Judge Kavanaugh, yesterday you said, We want to go through a full process. You said, We want to make sure everything is perfect, everything is just right. To that end, what would be the problem with the FBI reopening their background investigation into Judge Kavanaugh? Would you support such a thing? [SEP] It wouldn't bother me, other than the FBI, Jon, said that they really don't do that; that's not what they do. Now, they have done, supposedly, six background checks over the years, as Judge Kavanaugh has gone beautifully up a ladder. He's an incredible individual. Great intellect, great judge. Impeccable history in every way—in every way.I feel so badly for him that he's going through this, to be honest with you. I feel so badly for him. This is not a man that deserves this. This should have been brought to the fore. It should have been brought up long ago. And that's what you have hearings for. You don't wait until the hearing is over and then, all of a sudden, bring it up.When Senator Feinstein sat with Judge Kavanaugh for a long period of time—a long, long meeting—she had this letter. Why didn't she bring it up? Why didn't she bring it up then? Why didn't the Democrats bring it up then? Because they obstruct and because they resist. That's the name of their campaign against me. They just resist, and they just obstruct. And frankly, I think they're lousy on policy, and in many ways, they're lousy politicians. But they're very good on obstruction. And it's a shame, because this is a great gentleman.With all of that, I feel that the Republicans—and I can speak for myself—we should go through a process, because there shouldn't even be a little doubt. There shouldn't be a doubt. Again, they knew what they were doing. They should have done this a long time ago—3 months ago—not now. But they did it now. So I don't want to play into their hands.Hopefully, the woman will come forward, state her case. He will state his case before representatives of the United States Senate. And then, they will vote. They will look at his career. They will look at what she had to say from 36 years ago. And we will see what happens.But I just think he is at a level that we rarely see not only in government, anywhere in life. And honestly, I feel terribly for him, for his wife, who is an incredible, lovely woman, and for his beautiful young daughters. I feel terribly for them.
label: Explicit

sentence: Sir, regarding the mosque near Ground Zero, while they have the legal right, wouldn't it be wiser to build elsewhere? And doesn't this Koran burning threat put our troops in harm's way? [SEP] Let's be clear, inflaming a billion Muslims while our troops are deployed in Muslim nations is problematic. It complicates things for our service members. As for the mosque, this nation champions equality and religious freedom. If churches, synagogues, and temples are permitted, so should mosques. I appreciate the sensitivities surrounding 9/11, but we're not at war with Islam, only with terrorists who misrepresent it. We need allies, and most Muslims share our aspirations: jobs, education, security. They reject violent extremism. Millions of Muslim Americans are our neighbors, friends, and colleagues, some serving in our armed forces. We must treat them as equals.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, regarding ISIL, do you see 'destroying' and 'degrading' them as the same objective? Is the ultimate goal annihilation? And can the Free Syrian Army realistically destroy ISIL in Syria, given that airstrikes alone won't suffice? [SEP] You can't contain an organization that is causing so much destruction and displacement. The goal has to be to dismantle them. Like with Al Qaida, you push them back, degrade their capabilities, narrow their scope, shrink their territory, and take out their leadership. Over time, they can't conduct the same attacks. There may be remnants, but we'll hunt them down. We can dismantle this network so they can't harm us. I'm pleased that our allies agree. We won't be placing U.S. ground troops in Syria. We need effective partners on the ground. The moderate coalition is one we can work with. They've been outgunned, so we need to support them more effectively. When U.S. forces put ISIL on the defensive, ground forces can do remarkable things. This is a developing strategy we're consulting on. We'll do what's necessary to ensure ISIL doesn't threaten the U.S. or our partners.
label: Implicit

sentence: I noticed you omitted mentioning that your own supporters were also in Portland this weekend, engaging in activities such as firing paintball guns and deploying some form of pepper spray against others. Would you now like to take this moment to condemn the actions of your supporters in Portland? And let's be clear, paint is not inherently dangerous; it's a means of defense, not a lethal projectile.

sentence: Given your warnings about chemical weapons, do you have concrete intelligence suggesting Putin is actively deploying or considering their use? And what would be the U.S. or NATO's military response? [SEP] With respect to the first part of your inquiry, I am unable to divulge classified intelligence matters. As for the second, any response would be contingent upon the specific circumstances of such an event.

sentence: Mr. President, regarding Kenya, what specific steps will the U.S. undertake to assist in combating al-Shabaab? Do you still view Somalia as a viable counterterrorism model? Are you concerned about potential human rights violations by Kenyan authorities under the guise of counterterrorism? And for President Kenyatta, what additional assistance do you require from the U.S. to fight al-Shabaab, and are you satisfied with the current support level? Furthermore, could you both address the criticism surrounding the treatment of LGBTQ+ individuals in Kenya? [SEP] Well, this has been a subject of extensive discussion and concrete action that we're now implementing. There has been extensive and effective counterterrorism cooperation between the United States and Kenya, primarily addressing threats from al-Shabaab. Partly due to actions we've taken not only with Kenya, but also with AFRICOM, and the collective efforts of countries working together—Uganda, Ethiopia, and others—we have systematically reduced the territory controlled by al-Shabaab. We have been able to decrease their effective control within Somalia and weaken those networks operating here in East Africa. However, the problem is not solved. As is true globally, we find that while we can significantly degrade the capabilities of these terrorist organizations, they can still inflict damage. The number of individuals involved in Garissa or Westgate Mall was not large, but their willingness to target soft targets and civilians, and their readiness to die, allows them to cause significant harm. Therefore, we discussed the importance of continuing the effort to eradicate al-Shabaab's capacity inside Somalia, working jointly. Currently, Kenya is collaborating with Ethiopia and the United States, among others, to further degrade al-Shabaab's operational space within Somalia. We must maintain this pressure while strengthening the Somalian Government. A key reason al-Shabaab emerged as a significant threat to the region was the non-functioning government, effectively a failed state in Somalia for so long. Now there is a credible government and cabinet working with the international community in Mogadishu. Even as we exert military pressure on al-Shabaab, we must also ensure we are establishing an effective governance structure inside Somalia, where we have made progress. Additionally, we must continue to improve intelligence-sharing to identify and prevent threats before they occur in Kenya and elsewhere in the region. Our announcement today includes additional funding and assistance for Kenyan security forces to address these specific counterterrorism threats, as well as additional training and assistance to ensure that the approach taken to root out potential terrorist threats does not create more problems than it solves. This relates to another aspect of your question. We have learned, sometimes through hard experience—and I shared this with —that if you paint any particular community with too broad a brush, if in reaction to terrorism you restrict legitimate organizations, reducing the scope of peaceful organization, it can inadvertently increase the pool of recruits for terrorism and resentment in marginalized communities. I shared with him that one of the strengths in the United States, a reason why we haven't seen systematic networks and cells developing in many of our Muslim or immigrant communities, despite potential lone wolf attacks, is that we have been very conscious to ensure law enforcement reaches out, cooperates, and works with them, because they are our partners in this process. The only way to combat the poison being fed to their young people through social media is to ensure they are our eyes and ears, advising us on how to more effectively build trust and increase cooperation. This has proven successful and will be true in Kenya as well. I made it clear to : Ultimately, the Kenyan Government is accountable to the Kenyan people and will navigate this process in cooperation with us. However, our experience and best practices tell us that rule of law, respecting civil society—indeed, embracing civil society, particularly in communities that may be targeted for recruitment by organizations like al-Shabaab—becomes more important as the threat becomes more significant. This is not only practical advice but also the right thing to do, consistent with the Kenyan Constitution and the values you heard espoused. Similarly, regarding the rights of gays and lesbians, I have been consistent across Africa. I believe in treating people equally under the law, that they deserve equal protection under the law, and that the state should not discriminate against people based on their sexual orientation. I say this recognizing that some may have different religious or cultural beliefs. However, the issue is how the state operates in relation to people. Looking at the history of countries worldwide, when you start treating people differently—not because they are harming anyone, but because they are different—that is the path where freedoms begin to erode and bad things happen. When a government gets into the habit of treating people differently, those habits can spread. As an African American in the United States, I am acutely aware of the history of what happens when people are treated differently under the law. There were all sorts of rationalizations provided by the power structure for decades in the United States for segregation, Jim Crow, and slavery, and they were wrong. So I am unequivocal on this. If someone is a law-abiding citizen, going about their business, working, obeying traffic laws, and doing all the things good citizens should do without harming anyone, the idea that they would be treated differently or abused because of who they love is wrong. Full stop. The state does not need to weigh in on religious doctrine; it simply needs to say we will treat everyone equally under the law. Everyone else can have their own opinions. All right?
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. How persuasive did you find the Europeans and Canadians when they made the case to you that you shouldn't use national security as a justification for tariffs? [SEP] They virtually didn't even make that case. I mean, my case is the fact that it is national security; it's our balance sheet; it's our strength. It's absolutely national security. And, you know, if you look at our—just take a look at our balance sheet. We're going to have a very strong balance sheet very soon because of what I'm doing. We have the strongest economy that we've ever had in the United States—in the history of the United States. We have the best unemployment numbers: Black unemployment, the lowest in history; Hispanic unemployment, the lowest in history. I don't mean the lowest in the last 10 years or 20 years. The lowest in the history of this country. Black unemployment is doing the best it's ever done. Hispanic doing the best. Women are now up to 21 years. Soon it's going to be the best ever in its history—in the country's history.We have to have deals that are fair, and we have to have deals that are economic. Otherwise, that does, in fact, affect our military. Okay?
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. Yes, but—okay.Russia's Interference in 2016 Presidential Election/Former President Jimmy Carter  Q. Thank you, Mr. President. Yesterday former President Jimmy Carter suggested that your Presidency is illegitimate and that you only got the White House with help from Russia. Your reaction to that, sir? [SEP] Russia. Russia. Russia. Isn't it crazy?Okay Jimmy Carter—look he was a nice man. He was a terrible President. He's a Democrat. And it's a typical talking point. He's loyal to the Democrats and I guess you should be.But as everybody now understands I won not because of Russia not because of anybody but myself. I went out—I campaigned better smarter harder than Hillary Clinton. I went to Wisconsin. I went to Michigan the night of the vote. I had 32000 people at 1 o'clock in the morning on election day. I won Michigan. I won Wisconsin. I won Pennsylvania. I won States that traditionally haven't been won by a Republican for many years haven't been won by a Republican.And this had nothing to do with anybody but the fact that I worked harder and much smarter than Hillary Clinton did.Now I'll say this: Jimmy Carter—I was surprised that he would make a statement. I saw it. It was not a big thing but I saw the statement. And it's—you know a lot of Democrats like to make that statement. He's been trashed within his own party. He's been badly trashed. I felt badly for him because if you look over the years his party has virtually—he's like the forgotten President. And I understand why they say that. He was not a good President. Look at what happened with . That was a disaster. What did to him they tied him up in knots. The reason Ronald Reagan probably because President. So you know it's a Democrat talking point.Yes please. Go ahead. Jim [Jim Acosta CNN].
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, the deadline is approaching. Have you made a decision on who will chair the Federal Reserve Board? What are your priorities as you consider your choice, particularly given the tight timeline if you decide to replace Jay Powell? [SEP] I'm not going to discuss the Fed Chair nomination with you today. The process is ongoing, and we'll be making announcements in the coming weeks. We're confident we'll have all the necessary nominees confirmed in time. I've been working closely with my economic advisors to identify the best candidates. We have a number of qualified individuals under consideration, but I won't speculate further at this time.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: President Bush, considering Prime Minister Howard's emphasis on climate change at APEC, hasn't your separate meeting in Washington weakened his position? Furthermore, what is your assessment of the Kyoto Protocol's relevance in combating climate change? [SEP] Let's tackle Kyoto first. Remind me again of the first part, will you? Getting on in years, you know. Kyoto might work for some nations, but it simply wasn't the right fit for the United States. I was upfront about that. And before I even arrived in Washington, the Senate resoundingly rejected it, 95 to nothing. So, it wasn't merely my personal opinion. We pursued a different path, prioritizing energy efficiency and cutting-edge technologies. And the result? We reduced greenhouse gas emissions while simultaneously growing our economy. Not many nations can boast that. We also aim to reduce our reliance on foreign oil. That might unsettle some exporters, but we have a plan to decrease gasoline consumption by 20% within a decade, utilizing ethanol and other innovative technologies. Battery technology is also advancing rapidly. The crucial question is how to accelerate the deployment of these technologies. Kyoto didn't achieve that for us. If you examine which nations are actually meeting the Kyoto targets, you might conclude that our approach is more effective. We rejected it because we wanted to foster economic growth, achieve energy independence, and safeguard the environment. John and I concur on the importance of addressing climate change. I also emphasized to the G-8 that we need universal participation, including China and India. If they feel coerced, they'll disengage, and we can't solve this issue without them. The Prime Minister is wise to reduce tariffs on clean coal technology for China. We fully support that. The key questions are: How quickly can we deploy these technologies, and can we assist developing nations in acquiring them? Otherwise, our efforts will be futile. I believe our strategy is the most effective way to address this issue seriously. And I commend John for prioritizing this issue and promoting energy efficiency. He's demonstrating leadership, and I'm pleased to be here discussing it. Thank you.
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Mr. President, may I ask you about Syria a practical question and a moral one? Morally, how is it possible that for the last 2 years, tens of thousands of innocent civilians are being massacred and no one—the world, the United States, and you—are doing anything to stop it immediately? On a practical level, you have said today and also in the past that the use of chemical weapons would be a crossing of a red line. It seems like this line was crossed yesterday. What specifically do you intend to do about it? [SEP] I'll answer the question in reverse order, if you don't mind I'll talk about the chemical weapons first and then the larger questionWith respect to chemical weapons, we intend to investigate thoroughly exactly what happened Obviously, in right now you've got a war zone You have information that's filtered out, but we have to make sure that we know exactly what happened: what was the nature of the incident, what can we document, what can we prove So I've instructed my teams to work closely with all other countries in the region and international organizations and institutions to find out precisely whether or not this red line was crossedI will note, without at this point having all the facts before me, that we know the n Government has the capacity to carry out chemical weapon attacks We know that there are those in the n Government who have expressed a willingness to use chemical weapons, if necessary, to protect themselves I am deeply skeptical of any claim that, in fact, it was the opposition that used chemical weapons Everybody who knows the facts of the chemical weapon stockpiles inside as well as the n Government's capabilities, I think, would question those claims But I know that they're floating out there right nowThe broader point is, is that once we establish the facts, I have made clear that the use of chemical weapons is a game changer And I won't make an announcement today about next steps because I think we have to gather the facts But I do think that when you start seeing weapons that can cause potential devastation and mass casualties and you let that genie out of the bottle, then you are looking potentially at even more horrific scenes than we've already seen in And the international community has to act on that additional informationBut I—as is always the case when it comes to issues of war and peace, I think having the facts before you act is very importantMore broadly, as I said in my opening statement, I believe that the Asad regime has lost all credibility and legitimacy And I think Asad must go, and I believe he will go It is incorrect for you to say that we have done nothing We have helped to mobilize the isolation of the Asad regime internationally We have supported and recognized the opposition We have provided hundreds of millions of dollars in support for humanitarian aid We have worked diligently with other countries in the region to provide additional tools to move towards a political transition within If your suggestion is, is that I have not acted unilaterally militarily inside of , well, the response has been—or my response would be that, to the extent possible, I want to make sure that we're working as an international community to deal with this problem because I think it's a world problem, not simply a United States problem or an Israel problem or a Turkish problem It's a world problem when tens of thousands of people are being sed, including innocent women and childrenAnd so we will continue to work in an international framework to try to bring about the kind of change that's necessary in Secretary Kerry has been working nonstop since he came into his current position to try to help mobilize and organize our overall efforts, and we will continue to push every lever that we have to try to bring about a resolution inside of that respects the rights and the safety and security of all people, regardless of whatever sectarian lines currently divide Last point I'll make, which is probably obvious, is this is not easy When you start seeing a civil war that has sectarian elements to it, and you've got a repressive Government that is intent on maintaining power, and you have mistrust that has broken out along sectarian lines, and you have an opposition that has not had the opportunity or time to organize itself both politically as well as militarily, then you end up seeing some of the devastation that you've been seeing And we're going to do everything we can to continue to prevent it And I know that the vast majority of our international partners feel the same wayWhite House Press Secretary James F Jay Carney From the White House press corps, Matt Spetalnick of Reuters
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. I have a question for both of you. Mr. President, during your meetings today, did you discuss the possibility of Canada stepping up its stimulus plans? And secondly, for both of you, what do you think the Canada-U.S. relationship will look like in 4 years? What will the auto sector look like? Will the border be thicker or thinner? And will you have a carbon market? [SEP] See, you stuffed about six questions in there. [] Were you talking to Jonathan? Is that--[].
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, concerning the vaccination campaign, you've consistently encouraged vaccination, even addressing Republican hesitancy. However, the lack of vaccine access for young children persists. Could you elaborate on the reasons for this delay and provide some reassurance to anxious parents regarding a potential timeline? [SEP] The scientific community is still in the process of gathering sufficient data to ensure its safety for children under five. As you may recall, we faced similar questions regarding children between the ages of seven and twelve. After rigorous testing and analysis, they reached a point where they were confident in its safety. This same process is underway now. It will happen, but I am not a scientist, and I cannot provide a specific date. However, I want to assure you that we are working diligently to address this issue.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Mr. President, you came into office pledging to work for peace between Israel and the Palestinians. How realistic do you think those hopes are now, given the likelihood of a Prime Minister who's not fully signed up to a two-state solution and a Foreign Minister who has been accused of insulting Arabs? [SEP] It's not easier than it was, but I think it's just as necessary. We don't yet know what the Israeli Government is going to look like, and we don't yet know what the future shape of Palestinian leadership is going to be comprised of. What we do know is this: That the status quo is unsustainable; that it is critical for us to advance a two-state solution where Israelis and Palestinians can live side by side in their own states with peace and security.And by assigning George Mitchell the task of working as Special Envoy, what we've signaled is that we're going to be serious from day one in trying to move the parties in a direction that acknowledges that reality. How effective these negotiations may be, I think we're going to have to wait and see. But, you know, we were here for St. Patrick's Day, and you'll recall that we had what had been previously sworn enemies celebrating here in this very room, you know, leaders from the two sides in Northern Ireland that, you know, a couple of decades ago or even a decade ago, people would have said could never achieve peace. And here they were, jointly appearing and talking about their commitment even in the face of violent provocation. And what that tells me is that if you stick to it, if you are persistent, then these problems can be dealt with.That whole philosophy of persistence, by the way, is one that I'm going to be emphasizing again and again in the months and years to come, as long as I'm in this office. I'm a big believer in persistence. I think that when it comes to domestic affairs, if we keep on working at it, if we acknowledge that we make mistakes sometimes and that we don't always have the right answer and we're inheriting very knotty problems, that we can pass health care, we can find better solutions to our energy challenges, we can teach our children more effectively, we can deal with a very real budget crisis that is not fully dealt with in my budget at this point but makes progress.I think when it comes to the banking system, you know, it was just a few days ago or weeks ago where people were certain that Secretary Geithner couldn't deliver a plan. Today the headlines all look like, well, all right, there's a plan. And I'm sure there will be more criticism, and we'll have to make more adjustments, but we're moving in the right direction.When it comes to Iran, you know, we did a video sending a message to the Iranian people and the leadership of the Islamic Republic of Iran. And some people said, Well, they did not immediately say that we're eliminating nuclear weapons and stop funding terrorism. Well, we didn't expect that. We expect that we're going to make steady progress on this front. We haven't immediately eliminated the influence of lobbyists in Washington. We have not immediately eliminated wasteful pork projects. And we're not immediately going to get Middle East peace. We've been in office now a little over 60 days.What I am confident about is that we're moving in the right direction and that the decisions we're making are based on how are we going to get this economy moving, how are we going to put Americans back to work, how are we going to make sure that our people are safe, and how are we going to create not just prosperity here but work with other countries for global peace and prosperity. And we are going to stay with it as long as I'm in this office, and I think that you look back 4 years from now, I think, hopefully, people will judge that body of work and say, this is a big ocean liner--it's not a speedboat, it doesn't turn around immediately--but we're in a better place because of the decisions that we make.All right. Thank you, everybody.
label: General

sentence: Q. Mr. President, also back home, the Supreme Court ruled that Guantanamo detainees have rights under the Constitution to challenge their detention in U.S. civilian courts. Doesn't this rebuke of your policy on detainees validate the criticism that Gitmo has gotten all over the world, especially here in Europe? [SEP] Yes.
label: Explicit

sentence: Sir, concerning Iraq, will troop reductions halt at pre-surge levels as Petraeus and Gates suggest, or will further drawdowns occur before your term ends? Furthermore, does Iraq's invitation to Ahmadi-nejad weaken efforts to isolate Iran? [SEP] Regarding Iran, they are a neighbor. The message to Iran is clear: stop providing equipment used to kill Americans. Our long-term security agreement with Iraq aims to provide space for their democracy to grow. My message to Ahmadi-nejad is: cease exporting terror. The international community is committed to isolating Iran until they are transparent about their nuclear ambitions. We will see action at the UN next week. On troop levels, speculation is inevitable. My decision will be guided by Gates, Petraeus, and the Joint Chiefs. My priority is success. Failure in Iraq would be disastrous. Therefore, the question is: what is required for success? Politics will not dictate my decision. I increased troop levels because the situation demanded it, and we are now seeing progress. Crocker and Petraeus will provide their assessment, and decisions will follow.
label: Implicit

sentence: Sir, with all due respect, the photos from the guards are still under wraps. Can you explain why? [SEP] Whoa there, hold your horses. That's a different kettle of fish altogether. The key thing is letting the Iranian people know we're keeping an eye on things, that they're not on their own. But the main event is what happens in Iran. We've all been struck by their bravery. As I've said before, and some of you covering my campaigns know, I'm a big fan of Dr. King's line: 'The arc of the moral universe is long, but it bends towards justice.' We gotta believe that justice will come out on top.
label: Deflection

sentence: Sir, you've been discussing state sovereignty as a foundational element of international order on this trip. Could you clarify how that aligns with the concept of 'responsibility to protect,' which was previously a guiding principle for assisting victims? [SEP] Pardon me, how do I reconcile that with the 'responsibility to protect,' which used to be... could you rephrase that?
label: Clarification

sentence: Sir, can you detail any promises made to President Erdogan concerning Turkey's request for F-16 jets? [SEP] My position, as I made clear back in December, remains unchanged: selling them the F-16s and upgrading their existing jets is beneficial for us. There were no conditions attached; it's simply the right course of action. Naturally, we need Congress to sign off on it, and I'm optimistic we can get their support.
label: Implicit

sentence: President Trump, critics argue that demanding a payment to the Treasury after a deal is already in place could be perceived as extortion or a violation of international norms. How do you respond to these concerns, and what assurances can you give that your administration is adhering to ethical and legal standards in its business dealings? [SEP] Extortion? That's ridiculous. We're not extorting anyone. We're just asking for what's fair. We made this deal possible, we should get a piece of the action. It's just good business. And as for ethical and legal standards, we're following them to the letter. We have the best lawyers in the country, they're making sure everything is done right. We're not doing anything wrong. We're just trying to get the best deal for the American people. And if that means pushing the envelope a little bit, so be it. We're not afraid to be tough. We're not afraid to stand up for what we believe in. And we believe that America deserves its fair share.
label: General

sentence: Q. Is that something you wish all the Governors would do? Is that something you would encourage? The President. Well, a lot of the Governors, they have different requirements. Some of the Governors are very strong on masks; others aren't. I think it's really going to ultimately be up to them.We've given them the facts. We've given them everything we know. They have their own facts. Some are strong on masks, and, as you know, some aren't in the same ballpark. But I think—— Q. Shouldn't they all be? [SEP] Well, I think all are suggesting if you want to wear a mask, you wear it. I bring one. I have one. I've worn it. And I think when I'm in certain settings, like hospitals and various—or when I'm close—when, you know, when you can't socially distance, I believe in it. Let's see: Do I? I do. I have it.And if—you know, in certain—in certain instances, I think you really—I think you want to travel with a mask. There are instances where you really can use it. I would believe it would be a good thing.Yes, please.
label: General

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. Trey Yingst with One America News Network. I'd like to ask you: Do you support the plan by people who previously served in your administration, such as the Steve Bannon, to primary Republican candidates in the 2018 elections who do not support your agenda? [SEP] Well, I have a very good relationship, as you know, with Steve Bannon. Steve has been a friend of mine for a long time. I like Steve a lot. Steve is doing what Steve thinks is the right thing. Some of the people that he may be looking at, I'm going to see if we talk him out of that, because, frankly, they're great people.What Mitch will tell you is that maybe, with the exception of a few—and that is a very small few—I have a fantastic relationship with the people in the Senate and with the people in Congress. I mean, I have a—with our House of Representatives. I have a great relationship with political people. If you read the papers, you think, I'm, like, on one island and they're, like, on the other. Well, it's not the way it is.We have a fantastic relationship. I'm friends with most of them, I can say. And I don't think anybody could have much of a higher percentage. But I'm friends with most of them. I like and respect most of them, and I think they like and respect me.Just so you understand, the Republican Party is very, very unified. When we get things approved, we have to go through hell because we have no Democrat support, we have nobody. We don't have a vote from the Democrats. As an example, massive tax cuts, we may not get any Democrat votes. Now, we also may get three of four, but we may get no—for massive tax cuts. We're the highest taxed country in the world, and yet we may get no Democrat support. And that's because they're obstructionists, and they just basically want us to do badly, but that's not going to happen.Yes, go ahead.Office of National Drug Control Policy Director-Designate Thomas A. Marino/
label: General

sentence: Beyond general statements, what are your specific, measurable goals for the G-7 during your time leading the group? [SEP] We're looking to achieve something truly remarkable, something that takes what we've already built and makes it even better. We've created a fantastic base, and we're going to move forward with incredible cohesion. Actually, cohesion was the defining characteristic of our recent gathering of these seven vital nations. Most importantly, we had a fantastic time together.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, with the situation escalating in South Korea and Italy, many are questioning the delay in implementing travel restrictions. Can you provide a specific timeline for when these measures might be considered, or are you waiting for a more drastic turn of events? [SEP] Look, we're on top of it, okay? We're watching everything, every single number, every single case. We're talking to the best people, the smartest people, and they're advising us. We're not going to jump the gun, we're not going to panic. We're going to do what's right, at the right time. We're checking people, we're screening people, we're being very, very careful. And we're working with other countries, we're sharing information. We're going to make a decision when we're ready, and it'll be the best decision, believe me.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, regarding China's perspective on your alliances in Asia, how do you respond to the accusation that these actions are driven by a desire to contain China's growing influence? [SEP] Containment is not our goal. Our goal is to promote economic growth and stability throughout the region. We're working with our partners to create opportunities for trade and investment, and to ensure that all countries have a fair chance to succeed. This is not about isolating China; it's about creating a level playing field for everyone.
label: Deflection

sentence: Are you declining to elaborate further? [SEP] Excuse me?
label: Clarification

sentence: When can people expect to find hand sanitizer on store shelves again? And Mr. President, are you still considering a bailout for the cruise lines, and if so, what's the ballpark figure? [SEP] Look, I never said it was a done deal, but the cruise industry is hurting, big time. It's a great industry, and we're going to help them, just like we'll help the airlines if they need it. As for the hand sanitizer, let's hear from the expert.
label: General

sentence: Q. Mr. President, do you believe the Saudi government bears responsibility for Mr. Khashoggi's death, and if so, what repercussions should they face? [SEP] Look, we're evaluating all the evidence. I've got my best people on it. We're talking to everyone – the Saudis, the Turks, you name it. I'll have a definitive statement for you next week. We're leaving no stone unturned. Okay? Next question.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, could you elaborate on the economic case for autos? [SEP] It's all about the economics, pure and simple. A strong military needs a strong economy. The balance sheet is key.
label: Implicit

sentence: What is your stance on the NRA, Mr. President? [SEP] The NRA comprises members who are also parents. I trust this issue has affected them profoundly, prompting introspection. No single gun law can resolve everything. We need to address mental health, schools, and a range of factors Joe's team will examine. Gun safety is part of it. For 15-20 years, gun control was seen as a Second Amendment infringement. We seek a balanced approach: protect the Second Amendment, allow responsible gun owners their rights, and prioritize safety to prevent tragedies like Newtown or Aurora. There's ample room between the Second Amendment and zero regulation. Joe will explore that space for common ground. I'll take one last question.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, Nigeria is facing significant challenges and desperately needs the Tucano aircraft. Could we expect at least a couple of those planes to arrive before 2020 to help stabilize the situation? Also, any plans to visit Nigeria soon? [SEP] Nigeria, a fantastic country, I hear. Tremendous beauty, they say. I'd love to visit. But what was the first part of your question again? I missed it.
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Thank you, sir. My question is about Syria. Did President Putin of Russia indicate any desire on Russia's part for Asad to step down or to leave power? And did you make any tangible progress in your meetings with him or with Chinese President Hu in finding a way to stop the bloodshed there? [SEP] Right. Well, these were major topics of conversation in both meetings. And anybody who's seen scenes of what's happening in Syria I think recognizes that the violence is completely out of hand, that civilians are being targeted, and that Asad has lost legitimacy. And when you massacre your own citizens in the ways that we've seen, it is impossible to conceive of a orderly political transition that leaves Asad in power.Now, that doesn't mean that that process of political transition is easy. And there's no doubt that Russia, which historically has had a relationship with Syria, as well as China, which is generally wary of commenting on what it considers to be the internal affairs of other countries, are and have been more resistant to applying the kind of pressure that's necessary to achieve that political transition.We had a very candid conversation. I wouldn't suggest that at this point the United States and the rest of the international community are aligned with Russia and China in their positions, but I do think they recognize the grave dangers of all-out civil war. I do not think they condone the massacres that we've witnessed. And I think they believe that everybody would be better served if Syria had a mechanism for ceasing the violence and creating a legitimate government.What I've said to them is that it's important for the world community to work with the United Nations and Kofi Annan on what a political transition would look like. And my hope is, is that we can have those conversations in the coming week or two and that we can present to the world, but most importantly, to the Syrian people, a pathway whereby this conflict can be resolved.But I don't think it would be fair to say that the Russians and the Chinese are signed on at this point. I think what is fair to say is that they recognize that the current situation is grave; it does not serve their interests; it certainly does not serve the interests of the Syrian people. And where we agree is that if we can help the Syrian people find a path to a resolution, all of us would be better off.But it's my personal belief--and I shared this with them--that I don't see a scenario in which Asad stays and violence is reduced. He had an opportunity with the Annan plan. They did not fulfill their side of the deal. Instead we saw escalation and murder of innocent women and children. And at this point, we have the international monitors that were sent in having to leave because of this violence that's being perpetrated. And although you'll hear sometimes from some commentators that the opposition has engaged in violence as well, and obviously, there's evidence of that, I think it's also fair to say that those haunting images that we saw in places like Hom were the direct result of decisions made by the Syrian Government and ultimately Mr. Asad is responsible.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, to be blunt: are you comfortable with the precedent set by seizing journalists' phone records? Does this administration value a free press, or does it prioritize secrecy above all else? [SEP] We value both national security and a free press. Finding the right balance is the challenge.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the potential boycott, could you elaborate on what form it might take? [SEP] Well, that's really up to the individuals involved, isn't it? I wouldn't presume to dictate their actions. But honestly, I wouldn't advise it. If these companies want to silence voices, whether it's someone wearing a MAGA hat or supporting our brave police officers with a 'Blue Lives Matter' message – and let's be clear, that's about respecting law enforcement – then people have a right to choose where they spend their money. These companies are abusing their power, plain and simple. And you know what? If people choose to shop elsewhere, they'll find plenty of opportunities. We've created more jobs than ever before, the best numbers in history. So, they'll land on their feet. It's a disgrace what these companies are doing. Next question, please.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, with respect to Hong Kong and the Build Back Better agenda, could you clarify the specific reasons behind the business advisory for Hong Kong, considering China's commitments? Furthermore, can you detail the discussions with Senators Manchin and Sinema regarding the $3.5 trillion framework, and how you plan to maintain progressive support if compromises are necessary? [SEP] Hong Kong is a situation that requires our attention. China's actions speak louder than words. The advisory is a reflection of that. Now, regarding the Build Back Better plan, I'm having ongoing discussions with Senators Manchin and Sinema. We're working to find common ground. We have a shared goal of investing in our country and our people. We'll get there.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, given the Republican opposition to your immigration policies, how can you justify using executive authority when many believe it circumvents the will of the people as expressed in the election? [SEP] I believe I have a responsibility to address the challenges facing our immigration system, and I will use the tools available to me to do so. Executive action is not a substitute for legislation, but it can provide immediate relief and address critical issues. I remain committed to working with Congress on a comprehensive solution, but I won't wait for them to act if I can make progress on my own.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, your perspective on the NRA? [SEP] The NRA is made up of moms and dads, everyday Americans. I'm sure they're as shaken up by recent events as we all are. Hopefully, they're reflecting on their role. Let's be clear: no single gun law can fix everything. We need to tackle mental health, schools, the whole shebang. Joe's team will be on it. Gun safety is definitely part of the equation. For too long, any mention of gun control has been shouted down as a violation of the Second Amendment. We need a more thoughtful approach. We can protect the Second Amendment, respect responsible gun owners, and still prioritize safety. There's a huge middle ground between the Second Amendment and total anarchy. That's what Joe's going to be working on. I'll take one more question.
label: General

sentence: Q. I'm sorry. Do you plan to meet with Barbara Lagoa in Washington? And is she still on your shortlist? [SEP] She is on my list. I don't have a meeting planned, but she is on my list.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, the intelligence community has assessed that Russia interfered in the 2020 election. Do you concur with their findings? Furthermore, what message would you convey to Vladimir Putin regarding potential interference, irrespective of the candidate they might favor? [SEP] Look, folks, here's the deal. They went to Bernie, told him something about wanting him to win. Never told me. My people here can vouch for that. It was strange they went to Bernie. Now, I'm reading it's all exaggerated, disgraceful even. Leaks from Schiff, probably. Terrible. But Bernie's got momentum, they don't want him, so they say Russia's backing him. Same old game. I know it better than anyone. They didn't say it about me, though. Nobody told me anything. Ambassador O'Brien can confirm. Stop the leaks! Or else.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. So, are we seeing a shift towards eliminating the filibuster, Mr. President? [SEP] I've already given you my answer./Tax Code Reform/Deficit Spending/The President's Agenda
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Given your experience, Mr. President, and acknowledging the press's eagerness for bipartisan agreement, why haven't you proactively engaged Republicans in budget negotiations during your third year? Beyond rhetoric, what concrete actions are you undertaking to cultivate the spirit of cooperation? And finally, can the markets sustain their current performance for another two years amidst this political gridlock? [SEP] That's quite the multifaceted question! Could you perhaps reiterate the core of your inquiry?
label: Clarification

sentence: Can you provide a specific timeline for action? Are we looking at days, weeks, or months? [SEP] Well, let's just say that we anticipate swift action. My team, and Steve here can attest, is working diligently, and we expect developments within a reasonable timeframe, certainly within the foreseeable future.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. [Inaudible]—letters, I mean, what actions can be taken to ensure that does not happen? [SEP] Well, you have a lot of actions we can take, including the—including the increase. You know, right now people don't know: China is paying a lot of tariffs. We made a China deal, and they bought just—I think the third highest amount of corn ever in our—in world history. They just bought from us the highest amount, which is great for our farmers. But I view it differently than I did before I made the deal. When I made the deal, I thought this was a great deal. After what happened to us—what happened to the world, coming from China—I view it much differently. But we can impose massive tariffs on China if we want—and other countries, if we want. And we'll see. We just want to be treated fairly. We want a level playing field. Our farmers were never treated properly by anybody, and they were targeted by China.You know, I paid our farmers $28 billion over a 2-year period because they were targeted to that amount of money—to that exact amount of money: $28 [billion]*. It was $16 billion, and it was $12 billion—$28 [billion]* over a 2-year period. And we gave $28 billion to our farmers. That's why they're all here.And now they're doing very well. Our farmers are doing very well because we made really great trade deals. USMCA just kicked in. The China deal, they're buying a lot. They are buying a lot. I will say that: They're buying a lot. A lot of people ask, How are they doing on the trade deal? They're buying a lot.So I want to thank everybody, and we'll be having these conferences again.I—we're going to be signing an immigration act very soon; it's going to be based on merit. It's going to be very strong. We're going to work on DACA because we want to make people happy. And I'll tell you, even conservative Republicans want to see something happen with DACA.The Democrats had their chance for 3 years to do something with DACA, and they always turned it down. They always turned it down. They used it as politics. I'm using it to get something done.But we'll be signing a very powerful immigration act. It will be great. It will be merit-based. The country has tried to get it for 25 or 30 years. It will be strong on the border, but you'll come in legally, and you'll be able to come in legally.And very importantly, we'll be taking care of people from DACA in a very Republican way. A Republicans—I've spoken to many Republicans, and some would like to leave it out, but, really, they understand that it's the right thing to do.So we're going to be taking care of DACA. We will be doing for DACA what the Democrats had a chance to do and they never did it. Okay?Thank you all very much.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. ——on the issue of Federal busing—federally mandated busing. Biden thought that was a bad policy. He tried to stop it. Kamala Harris said it was an important part of desegregation, including in her own experience.Where do you stand on that issue of federally mandated busing? [SEP] Well first of all before I get into that I thought that she was given too much credit. He didn't do well certainly and maybe the facts weren't necessarily on his side. I think she was given too much credit for what she did. It wasn't that outstanding. And I think probably he was hit harder than he should've been hit Biden. I thought he was hit actually harder.And as far as that I will tell you in about 4 weeks because we're coming out with certain policy that's going to be very interesting and very surprising I think to a lot of people.Jennifer [Jennifer Jacobs Bloomberg News] do you have a question?
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Sir, what's your stance on armed citizens intervening in active shooter situations? [SEP] Ideally, law enforcement should handle everything. That's the ideal scenario. But we need to restore respect for our police. They're under immense pressure, making split-second decisions. Sometimes they make mistakes, and those mistakes are amplified by the media. We need to support them, not demonize them. The left-wing ideology that's poisoning our country is the real problem. Republicans understand this; that's why our cities are safe.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, regarding your extensive international business holdings prior to your presidency, wouldn't a blind trust have been the most ethical course of action? Or do you believe a president's personal financial interests should be intertwined with foreign policy? [SEP] That's a hypothetical, and frankly, a loaded one. I'm not going to engage in hypotheticals.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, with so much public uncertainty surrounding coronavirus protocols and a corresponding drop in your poll numbers, why haven't you made personnel changes at the CDC or other involved agencies? [SEP] The evolving nature of the virus is the root cause of any confusion. Scientists are continually learning, and guidelines are updated as new information becomes available. The CDC's communication strategies have been a priority, and we are actively addressing them. It's important to remember the unprecedented speed with which a vaccine was developed.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, regarding North Korea's commitment to denuclearization, how can you be certain they will follow through, given past instances of broken promises? What specific mechanisms are in place to ensure compliance, and not just empty rhetoric? [SEP] Look, can anyone *guarantee* anything in life? Can you guarantee the sun will rise tomorrow? All I can say is, I have a gut feeling. I'm a dealmaker. It's what I do. They *want* a deal. And frankly, past administrations were too weak to get it done. I have a knack for this sort of thing. We'll see what happens, folks. We'll see.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: President Bush, do you remember your opinion on Israel's bombing of the Iraqi nuclear reactor in 1981? [SEP] That's ancient history, isn't it? I was just trying to make a living back then. I honestly can't recall giving it much thought. I'm sure folks were talking about it, but I don't have a specific memory of my reaction.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Mr. President, as the G-7 host next year, you were allowed to invite other countries to come—guest countries—even though they're not necessarily part of the overall group. Would you consider inviting Vladimir Putin under those circumstances? [SEP] Well, I don't know that he'd accept. And those are tough circumstances. He was a part of G-8, and all of a sudden, he's not out—or he's not in. So I think, John, actually, that's a pretty tough thing for him. You know, he's a proud person. Would I invite him? I would certainly invite him. Whether or not he could come, psychologically, I think that's a tough thing for him to do.You have a G-8, now it's a G-7, and you invite the person that was thrown out, really by President Obama and really because he got outsmarted. President Obama, pure and simple. And don't forget: It was not just Crimea; it was the redline in the sand. And Obama said, Never violate the redline in the sand. And then they went ahead, and they killed many children with gas. It was terrible. And he did nothing about it.I did, but I was there years later. I did something about it, but I was there late.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, the Democrats are very concerned about Social Security, particularly the idea of partial privatization, which you have discussed. In the spirit of bipartisanship, are there any aspects of your agenda that you are willing to reconsider or compromise on, given the importance of this issue to the Democratic Party? [SEP] Look, I've told Ken Paulson to tell the Members that we'll sit down and we'll listen to everybody's ideas. I put out my ideas, as you recall, I think in the State of the Union last time. And we want to hear their ideas. And hopefully, out of this concept of folks sitting around a table sharing ways forward, that we will come up with commonality, that we are able to then say to the American people, We've helped solve this problem.But this is a tough issue. Look, I fully understand how hard it is. Social Security is—people are generally risk-adverse when it comes time to Social Security. My problem with that is, is that the longer you wait, the more difficult the issue is going to become. And some will keep pushing it, and hopefully, we can get something done.Richard [Richard Wolffe, Newsweek].
label: General

sentence: President Bush, in light of the ongoing challenges in Africa, what specific actions and leadership qualities are essential for the continent's progress, and what role will the U.S. play in supporting this? Also, what are your specific goals for this five-nation tour, and how will you guarantee the continuation of your efforts? [SEP] Thanks. I visited Africa early in my presidency as well. This is my second trip, and I'm here to remind everyone that it's in our interest to help African nations combat diseases, promote trade, and invest in education. Ghana is a great place to see these efforts firsthand. It's one thing to give speeches in America, it's another to see the progress on the ground. Africa has changed positively since I became president, thanks to African leaders. We've seen conflict resolution, like in Liberia, where we helped install the first democratically elected female president. We're a partner, not an imposer. Democracy is also advancing, thanks to leaders like John Kufuor. Our aid program now demands accountability, like fighting corruption and investing in education. I believe in setting high standards for African leaders. The leaders I'm meeting are committed to their people and honest government. They prioritize education. That's why I'm here, and I'm glad I am. It's been a great trip. John McKinnon from the Wall Street Journal.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, on Vladimir Putin: Do you believe Putin personally ordered the hack? And did he do it to help Trump? Also, Trump mentions Saddam and WMDs that weren't found. Can you say for sure it wasn't China or a '400-pound guy,' as Trump says? Do Trump's tweets embolden Russia? [SEP] The report coming out before I leave office will tie everything together. I don't want to get ahead of that. But the intelligence I've seen makes me very confident that Russia did the hack.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. I am—[inaudible]—Daily. Now, the Korean Peninsula trust-building process has been the basis of the Korean Government efforts to improve inter-Korean relations. But despite these efforts, North Korea has really not changed its attitude towards developing nuclear missile capabilities. Now, in the second half of your term in office, how do you plan on steering inter-Korean ties?And one more. Now, from your visit to China in September, we have been seeing you say that you want to see unification of the Koreas. Do you really think that this will be possible during your term in office?And I have a question for both of you, actually, finally. In Korea, they say that you see each other often and you start to grow fond of each other. Now, this is your fourth time meeting as a summit meeting, and you also see each other a lot at multilateral talks. So I just want to ask, have you grown closer? [SEP] Now, let me ask the lastanswer the last question first. Then, yes. The answer is yes for me. So let me continue with my answers to your question.Now, the Korean Peninsula trust-building process, basically, we have this principle: Now, we will be very sternly and decisively dealing with any provocations, but we're also leaving the door open for a dialogue, and we'll continue to make efforts to build trust. So this is the basic principle, and this is the basic underlying foundation of all our North Korean policies.In August, there was a North Korean provocation in the demilitarized zone, and we stuck to this principle and applied it to the situation. And we were very firmly responding to the situation, and as a result, we were able to reach the August 25 agreement between the two Koreas.So we had this vicious cycle where North Korea kept on provoking us, and then we just rewarded it, and it went on and on. And we want to stop this. And we are very clear that our North Korean policy line will not change just because North Korea continues to provoke and threaten us. Now, the Korean Government will try to smoothly implement the August 25 agreement. And we seek to put into place concrete measures for reconciliation and cooperation in an effort to maintain this momentum for improved inter-Korean ties.Now, in the past, some peopleyou might have thought that, well, if you just let thingssome things slide, won't you get along better? But if you look at the results of that attitude, they really weren't very good. We need a principled approach, and this principled approach might make it difficult for the time beingthe immediate time beingbut that is where improved relationships will actually start. That is my belief.Now, reunification is something that no one can really predict. Now, in the summit earlier too, we talked about Germany and how the Chancellor Kohl said that German reunification would happen in 10 years' time, but then 3 days later, the Berlin Wall came falling down. So it's really something that's very unpredictable. But no matter when it happens, for us, we need to be prepared. I think that is the most important point for us. So for any circumstances, we need to be prepared. And we are making efforts in this regard.Now, we do have reunification preparation committee that are looking into the practical aspects of reunification, how we prepare for it. But reunification is actually not just between South and North Korea, it also affects the greater international community. So we need to also look at our neighboring countries, and we need to create an environment throughout the world where there is consensus that people agree that, yes, reunification is needed and this will be good for the region, for peace and prosperity. And we need to be able to tell our neighbors and the greater world that reunification is a good thing for the region and the world. And we will continue to make efforts in this regard as well. . I was impressed the first time I met with President Park and just have become more and more impressed with her leadership, the clarity of her vision. And she has not only been a great partner to us, but I think has helped to continue Korea's broader role in global affairs.
