And are you concerned that the kind of involvement that we saw in this year's campaign will be the new normal going forward in future U.S. elections? [SEP] Good. Well, what I have said to world leaders is the same thing that I've said in a number of press conferences, which is the President-elect now has to put together a team and put forward specifics about how he intends to govern. And he hasn't had a full opportunity to do that yet. And so people should take a wait-and-see approach in how much his policy proposals once in the White House, once he is sworn in, matches up with some of the rhetoric of his campaign.My simple point is, is that you can't assume that the language of campaigning matches up with the specifics of governing, legislation, regulations, and foreign policy.I can't be sure of anything. I think, like everyone else, we'll have to wait and see. But as I've said before, once you're in the Oval Office, once you begin interacting with world leaders, once you see the complexities of the issues, that has a way of shaping your thinking and, in some cases, modifying your thinking, because you recognize this solemn responsibility not only to the American people, but the solemn responsibility that America has as the largest, most powerful country in the world.And I can't guarantee that the President-elect won't pursue some of the positions that he's taken. But what I can guarantee is, is that reality will force him to adjust how he approaches many of these issues. That's just the way this office works.And I've said before, if these issues were easy—if ensuring prosperity, jobs, security, good foreign relations with other countries—if all that was simple, then it would have been done by every previous President. And I'm a pretty good Presidential historian. I've looked at my 43 predecessors, and it seems like for all of them—even the best ones—that you end up confronting realities that you didn't anticipate. I think the same will happen here. And that's a good thing. That's an important thing. With respect to President Putin, I didn't have a meeting. We talked briefly while we were in between sessions. And the conversation that I had with him was consistent with the conversations I've had with him over the previous several months, indicating to him that we are still deeply concerned about the bloodshed and chaos that's being sown by constant bombing attacks by Asad and the Russian military against populations in Aleppo and the need for us to arrive first at some sort of humanitarian cease-fire and begin moving towards a political transition of some sort.And I talked to him about Ukraine and the need for us to get Minsk done. I urged him to instruct his negotiators to work with ourselves, with France, with Germany, with Ukraine to see if we can get that done before my term is up. As usual, it was a candid and courteous meeting, but very clear about the strong differences that we have on policy.The issue of the elections did not come up because that's behind us and I was focused in this brief discussion on moving forward. I had already made very clear to him our concerns around cyber attacks, generally, as well as specific concerns we had surrounding the DNC hack.I don't think this will be the norm, but as I've said before, the concern I have has less to do with any particular misinformation or propaganda that's being put out by any particular party, and a greater concern about the general misinformation from all kinds of sources—both domestic, foreign, on social media—that make it very difficult to voters—for voters to figure out what's true and what's not. And let me put it this way. I think if we have a strong, accurate, and responsible press, and we have a strong, civic culture and an engaged citizenry, then various attempts to meddle in our elections won't mean much.If, generally, we've got elections that aren't focused on issues and are full of fake news and false information and distractions, then the issue is not going to be what's happening from the outside. The issue is going to be what are we doing to ourselves from the inside. The good news is that's something that we have control over. All right?Gardiner Harris [New York Times].'s Personal Finances/Government Ethics/President-Elect Donald J. Trump/National Security Agency/Cybersecurity
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. And just a follow-up, if I may, sir. On North Korea, you said you believe in complete denuclearization. What does that mean exactly? [SEP] It means they get rid of their nukes. [] Very simple. They get rid of their nukes, and nobody else would say it. It would be very easy for me to make a simple deal and claim victory. I don't want to do that. I want them to get rid of their nukes. Okay?
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, regarding Ukraine, must Zelenskyy concede territory for a ceasefire with Russia, or is that non-negotiable? Also, should Russia be excluded from the G-20? [SEP] On the G-20 matter, a firm yes. The specifics depend on the group's consensus, of course. I suggested that if a consensus can't be reached with Indonesia and others, we should explore allowing both parties to attend as observers. Now, remind me of your initial question?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, concerning the Hadley memo leak prior to your meeting with Prime Minister al-Maliki, did you or your Chief of Staff initiate an inquiry? Furthermore, if the leak was unauthorized, do you suspect internal elements are attempting to undermine your Iraq strategy or sabotage your meeting with Prime Minister al-Maliki? [SEP] Mark, I am attempting to recall whether I issued such an order. I do not have a specific recollection of initiating an investigation. I do, however, recall expressing concern regarding the persistent leaks. You all dedicate yourselves to uncovering information and disseminating it to the public, which I understand. However, I disapprove of individuals who leak classified documents. This is a recurring issue, not only for this administration but for any administration endeavoring to implement policies that impact the nation's future. We have experienced numerous leaks, some originating from—well, I am uncertain of their provenance, and therefore I shall refrain from speculation. It is often challenging to ascertain the identity of the leaker. It is an advantage inherent in your profession. We may lament it, but it is difficult to identify those within the government who are willing to provide, in this instance, Hadley's document to newspapers. There may be an ongoing investigation; I am simply not cognizant of it. If such an investigation exists, and I were aware of it, it is not presently at the forefront of my mind. However, I believe it would be advantageous to identify individuals within our government who are leaking materials, which is patently illegal, and hold them accountable. Perhaps the most efficacious means of deterring leaks of classified documents is to ensure that there are consequences for such actions. Jim, Los Angeles Times, as I recall.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: President Trump, can you elaborate on the practical implications of this 'enduring presence' for the average Polish citizen? Will they see a noticeable increase in U.S. military activity, and what assurances can you give them regarding potential disruptions or security concerns? [SEP] The people of Poland, they love America, they love our troops. They're great people, very appreciative. This enduring presence, it's about peace of mind, it's about knowing that America has their back. Will they see more activity? Maybe, maybe not. What they'll see is strength, they'll see security. We're not talking about disruptions, we're talking about protection. We're talking about keeping Poland safe, keeping Europe safe. And we're working with President Duda, a tremendous leader, to make sure everything is done right, everything is done smoothly. It's going to be a beautiful thing, a very, very beautiful thing. The best, really.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, with all due respect, your answer seems to avoid directly addressing the question of Israel's nuclear program. Can you clarify whether you believe Israel should declare its nuclear capabilities and sign the NPT, yes or no? [SEP] Look, the situation in the Middle East is incredibly complex. We have to consider the security concerns of all our allies in the region. Our policy is to encourage all countries to join the NPT, and that includes Israel. But I'm not going to get into hypotheticals or speculate about what Israel may or may not do. My focus is on working with all parties to achieve a lasting peace and security in the region. And that's what I'm going to continue to do. Let's move on.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, you haven't mentioned oil companies. Are you confident that American oil producers are fully utilizing all available resources, including offshore drilling? And regarding Iraq, will you sign an interim agreement with Prime Minister Maliki on American operations, leaving a more permanent agreement to your successor? [SEP] Let's begin with Iraq. We're developing a strategic framework agreement with the Iraqi government covering diplomacy, economics, and justice. This includes a security agreement outlining the transition to an overwatch role, involving training, logistical support, and special operations. For our troops to operate in Iraq, we need an understanding with the government, including operational authorities and troop protections. This needs to be finalized before the end of the year, unless the UN mandate is extended. These are two separate aspects of the agreement, and we're working on both simultaneously. Now, let's see...
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Beyond the technical glitches, Mr. President, what specific measures are being implemented to simplify the healthcare enrollment process and ensure that consumers can easily understand their options and access affordable coverage? [SEP] Look, we know this process can be confusing. That's why we're working to make it simpler and easier to understand. We're streamlining the application process, we're providing more assistance to consumers, and we're making sure people have the information they need to make informed choices. We're committed to making healthcare accessible to everyone, and that's what we're going to do.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, while you claim the US has lower death rates, Johns Hopkins data indicates otherwise, placing the US among the highest in deaths per capita. How do you reconcile this discrepancy? [SEP] Well, you have to look at the individual states. New York was a disaster, a real mess. If you take New York out of the equation, our numbers are fantastic, some of the best in the world. Florida, for example, is doing great. So, it's all about perspective, really. But I'll double-check those numbers for you.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. We all appreciate it. It's always good to have a chance to ask questions of you directly. Can you tell us a little more about how this China deal may work going forward? Because Chinese officials have told Fox News that they will not make any concessions until all of the tariffs have been lifted. They also want relief on Huawei. They want it taken off the blacklist. They might want you to stop pursuing extradition of Meng Wanzhou. Can you tell us how you see all of this unfolding?And if you do meet Kim Jong Un at the DMZ tomorrow, would you step across the border into North Korea? [SEP] Sure I would. I would. I'd feel very comfortable doing that. I would have no problem.With respect to China basically we agreed today that we were going to continue the negotiation—which I ended a while back—and we're going to continue the negotiation. We agreed that I would not be putting tariffs on the $325 billion that I would have the ability to put on if I wanted; that—where you know we're fairly advanced depending on where you want to look at and where you want to start. Pretty advanced.We discussed—we did discuss numerous other things. We mentioned Huawei. I said: We'll have to save that until the very end. We'll have to see.One of the things I will allow however is—a lot of people are surprised—we send and we sell to Huawei a tremendous amount of product that goes into the various things that they make. And I said that that's okay that we will keep selling that product. These are American companies John that make product. And that's very complex by the way. Highly scientific.And in some cases we're the ones that do it and we're the only ones that do it. We're the only ones with the technology. What we've done in Silicon Valley is incredible actually. And nobody has been able to compete with it. And I've agreed—and pretty easily—I've agreed to allow them to continue to sell that product so American companies will continue. And they were having a problem. The companies were not exactly happy that they couldn't sell because they had nothing to do with whatever was potentially happening with respect to Huawei. So I did do that. We talked about education and students. Somebody was saying it was harder for a Chinese students to come in. And that's something that if it were—if somebody viewed it that way I don't. We want to have Chinese students come and use our great schools our great universities. They've been great students and tremendous assets. But we did discuss it. It was brought up as a point and I said that will be just like anybody else just like any other nation.And we're actually going to a point where you know we're looking that if you graduate from a college because our great companies—we talk about Silicon Valley and other places—we have a problem in this—in our country that you graduate number one in your class from the best school in the country and you—they say you have to leave; we can't keep them. And we're going to make it—we're going to call it the smart person's waiver. But we're going to make it so that they can not only stay but maybe they have access to green cards. We want to keep these people here. We have to keep—yes go ahead John.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, as the war in Afghanistan draws to a close, can you confidently assert that the immense sacrifices, both human and financial, have been justified, especially considering the current state of Afghanistan, which appears to fall short of the initial goals of reconstruction and democracy? And President Karzai, numerous independent reports have highlighted corruption and governance issues in Afghanistan. Do you stand by your claim that foreign influence is largely to blame, and are you fully committed to stepping down after next year's elections? [SEP] Look, we went into Afghanistan because we were attacked. Al-Qaeda, they hit us, and we had to respond. We decimated them. That was the mission, and we accomplished it. Now, could things be better in Afghanistan? Sure. But we achieved our objective, and that's what matters. As for corruption, that's a problem everywhere, not just in Afghanistan. But we're working with them to build a better future.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Why haven't you attended any of the impeachment hearings? [SEP] Oh, I'd love to be there, right in the front row, just to watch those corrupt politicians squirm. It would be a real spectacle.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, given the intelligence community's assessment of foreign interference in the upcoming election, what specific measures are being taken to safeguard the integrity of the voting process and ensure that the election results accurately reflect the will of the American people? [SEP] We're watching it very closely. Very closely. Russia, China, they'd all love to see me lose. But they know I'm the only one who can stand up to them. We're taking all necessary steps to protect the election.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, in light of the UK's exemption from the travel ban despite having higher coronavirus cases than numerous Schengen countries, why are they being given special consideration, especially given their recent surge in infections? Are you contemplating adding them to the restricted list? [SEP] Well, that was suggested to me by a team of experts, and we're constantly reevaluating the situation with the latest data. The numbers out of the UK have been rising sharply, so we might have to include them on the list. We might even add a few other countries, and frankly, we're also considering removing some.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, a question from the Japanese press? [SEP] Yes, from the Japanese press. Naturally, we're all concerned about the circumstances in Japan.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the intelligence reports suggesting Russian and Chinese interference in the upcoming election to sway it against you and in favor of Mr. Biden, do you find these reports credible? And what specific countermeasures are you prepared to implement? [SEP] Look, the intelligence community has a spotty record, to put it mildly. But let me be clear: nobody has been tougher on Russia than I have. If they're meddling, it's because they know I won't let them get away with it. As for China, they understand that I'm the only one who can hold them accountable on trade. So, sure, maybe they're trying something. But we're watching them very, very closely.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Sir, regarding the NHS, should it be part of the trade discussions? [SEP] Could you repeat that? I'm having trouble hearing you.
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, about Roxham Road, why the hold-up on finalizing the agreement? It's been ready for a year. And for the 15,000 migrants Canada's taking, why so few? What did you give the U.S. in return? Prime Minister Trudeau, your thoughts? [SEP] Look, I'm not disappointed. Haiti's a mess, with gangs basically running the show. The Prime Minister's got a good plan. The best thing we can do, but it'll take time, is to help the Haitian police get their act together. We're also looking at the UN playing a bigger role. It's a real concern, because Haiti's got millions of people, and the diaspora could cause problems in the Western Hemisphere. So, we're helping the police get better training, and talking to other countries in the region who are willing to help. It's a work in progress.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, the Jacksonville event got smaller because of rising COVID-19 cases. Doesn't that show that reopening too fast can backfire? How do you square that with your push to reopen schools and start up Major League Baseball again, especially with the chance of outbreaks? [SEP] We're learning as we go. We're making changes as needed. Baseball is important. It's part of who we are. We want things back to normal. We're working with the teams, the players, the doctors to do it safely. We'll watch the situation closely. We'll make sure we're keeping Americans safe. We have to get back to work. We have to get the economy going again. We can't let the cure be worse than the disease. I know a lot of baseball players. Great people. They want to play. We'll figure it out.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. But you're a plan-ahead kind of guy. Why not have a plan B? [SEP] Well, you know, I want to just make sure that everybody understands that you have a model that—where all the pieces connect. And, I mean, there are a whole bunch of scenarios not just in relation to health care, but all kinds of stuff that I do, where if somebody does something that doesn't make any sense, then it's hard to fix. And this would be hard to fix. Fortunately, there's no reason to have to do it. It doesn't need fixing. All right?Thank you very much. Thank you to the people of Germany and Bavaria. You guys were wonderful hosts.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, the recent attack on the Inter-Continental Hotel raises serious questions. Are you concerned that Afghan forces are not yet capable of securing even high-profile targets in Kabul? [SEP] Well, let's remember the withdrawal hasn't even started yet. We knew this was a risky situation, that the Taliban is still a threat, and these kinds of incidents are bound to happen. The real question is, are the Afghans getting better overall? Look at Kabul, where a huge chunk of the population lives. Afghan forces have been policing it for a while now, and they've done a pretty good job. It's much safer than it used to be, and they're much more capable. That doesn't mean these attacks won't happen, probably for a while. We're not done yet. But as I said, the tide is turning. We're in a transition. Like in Iraq, where we pulled out our troops, and they're maintaining a democracy and keeping the violence down, we think this is the right approach. Even in Iraq, you still see attacks. These countries are still recovering from a lot of war. They're dangerous places. They won't be perfectly safe, even if we stayed. But we can help the Afghan people defend themselves. Jim?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, concerning the wiretapping program, a former Justice Department official testified to a potentially illegal incident involving your staff and Attorney General Ashcroft. Can you confirm or deny these events and comment on the appropriateness of such actions? [SEP] Look, there are always whispers and accusations in Washington, especially regarding sensitive national security matters. I won't dignify those specific claims with a direct response. What I will say is that the program in question was – and remains – absolutely vital to protecting American lives. It operated under legal counsel and congressional oversight, and its necessity is beyond dispute. So, while others may speculate, my focus is, and always will be, the safety and security of this nation.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: President Bush, given the protectionist sentiments within your administration, how much flexibility can Uruguay expect in securing a trade agreement? What specific agreements have been reached today? President Vazquez, did you request President Bush to intervene in the ongoing dispute between Uruguay and Argentina regarding the pulp mill projects? [SEP] President Bush: We dedicated considerable time to addressing Uruguay's concerns regarding market access for specific products. The President raised various trade-related issues, expressing his belief that quotas on items such as cows and sheep were unfair. I assured him that I would give his requests due consideration. You may have thought I was joking about blueberries, but I wasn't. It turns out that Uruguay produces exceptional blueberries. The fundamental question is whether Uruguayan blueberry growers will be able to sell their products in the United States. We discussed a range of produce, and I emphasized that problems can only be resolved if they are brought to the table. I pledged to provide assistance where possible and to explain the reasons why if assistance was not feasible. I am concerned about protectionist tendencies, both within our own country and globally. I believe that a world characterized by free and fair trade is more likely to address poverty. Therefore, I strongly support the completion of the Doha round of the WTO. I shared our strategies for advancing the Doha round with the President. I spent considerable time with President Lula, who was highly interested in our discussions, and I shared our conversations with him. I did not betray any confidences, of course, but I discussed the need to advance the Doha round. The United States is fully prepared to reduce agricultural subsidies, as I explained to the President. We simply want to ensure market access for our products. That is what I told President Lula, the Europeans, and the President. I am optimistic that we can reach an agreement. Our trade minister, Susan Schwab, has remained in Sao Paulo to continue discussions with her Brazilian counterpart, all with the aim of making progress toward a complex but necessary deal. President Vazquez: In response to the first question, I fully agree with President Bush's remarks. We have established a framework, starting with this meeting, where our experts and ministers will discuss and make progress on bilateral relationship issues. Regarding the general multilateral situation, Uruguay has consistently advocated for free trade and the reduction of tariffs and subsidies that impede the sale of our significant cultural products. We have also explored the possibility of advancing the GSP, particularly on certain issues that will be considered in the coming weeks. As for the second part of your question, I have not discussed the issues we have with Argentina with President Bush, primarily because we will be engaging in dialogue between the two governments in a few weeks, thanks to the conciliation efforts of His Majesty, the King of Spain, to find an amicable resolution. We will strive to reach an understanding and resolve the unfortunate differences we have with our Argentine brethren.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, just to confirm, was a deal contingent upon Israel's agreement to a temporary suspension of annexation? [SEP] Pardon? I didn't quite catch that. Could you speak up a bit?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Did the recent leaks revealing that the U.S. was spying on South Korea come up at all in your discussions? And did President Biden provide you any assurances? [SEP] Concerning that, we're talking, sharing what we need to. The U.S. is looking into it, and it's complicated. Let's see what they find. We'll keep in touch. Last question.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: President, regarding North Korea, you've expressed optimism. Could you elaborate on specific diplomatic wins? And is direct engagement still, in your view, a waste? [SEP] I'm not going to telegraph our strategy, you understand? We keep things close. But I will say this: it's in everyone's interest for North Korea to do the right thing. There's a lot at stake. We're showing strength, believe me. They know we have strength like nobody's ever seen. We have carriers, submarines... things they understand. We hope we never have to use them. But I think they'll come to the table, make a deal that works for everyone. I see movement, but we'll see.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, some argue that focusing on past administrations is unproductive. What is your administration's current policy regarding Crimea and Russia's actions in the region? [SEP] We're taking a tough stance on Russia's aggression and working with our allies to hold them accountable. We're committed to upholding international law and defending the sovereignty of Ukraine.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, regarding Yemen, you pledged to end the war. Now, the UAE wants the Houthis back on the terror list. Will you do it, and how will you end the war? [SEP] It's under consideration. And ending the war requires both parties to be involved. It's going to be very difficult. Yes.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, given your commitment to the U.S.-Japan alliance and a free Indo-Pacific region, how do you reconcile this with your upcoming visit to China, a nation that doesn't share those values? And Prime Minister, did the President express concern over Japan's failure to intercept the North Korean missile, and what's your plan for Japan's defense? [SEP] The Prime Minister will be buying a lot of military equipment from the U.S., and then he'll be able to shoot those missiles down. We shot one down in Saudi Arabia with no problem. Japan will be purchasing massive amounts of equipment from us, the best in the world, creating jobs here and ensuring Japan's security. My relationship with President Xi is excellent. I consider him a friend, but he represents China, and I represent the United States. We have different views, but we're aligned on trade. China's been taking advantage of us for years, resulting in a massive trade deficit. We're addressing it. It's about reciprocal trade. If they charge us a tariff, we'll charge them the same. Some countries charge us outrageous taxes, while we charge them nothing. That's ending. We're taking action, but it takes time due to legal requirements. The legal groundwork is laid. You'll see strong action against those who treat us unfairly. I view companies as extensions of the American worker. Regarding Japan's defense, we purchase much from the U.S. The North Korean situation is serious, so we're enhancing our defense capabilities. We'll buy more from the U.S. We tracked the North Korean missiles. Missile defense is a joint effort. We'll intercept if needed, in close coordination.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, the American intelligence community has presented compelling evidence of Russian interference in the 2016 election. Why should the American people, and President Trump, accept your assurances to the contrary? Furthermore, will you commit to extraditing the twelve Russian officials recently indicted by a U.S. grand jury? [SEP] With all due respect, the premise of your question is flawed. The narrative of Russian interference conveniently emerged as a post-election justification for the Democratic Party's defeat, despite the inherent advantage the Electoral College affords them. Our campaign's success was a result of its own merits. As for the matter of trust, I would suggest that skepticism is a prudent approach in all matters of international relations. President Trump is responsible for safeguarding the interests of the United States, just as I am responsible for safeguarding the interests of the Russian Federation. While we may share certain common objectives, we also have areas of divergence. Our focus should be on identifying and addressing these differences in a constructive manner. Rather than being swayed by transient political considerations, we must adhere to factual evidence. I challenge you to provide a single, verifiable fact that substantiates the allegation of collusion. Such claims are, quite simply, unfounded. With respect to the Concord matter, the company in question has retained American legal representation, and the accusations against them are unlikely to withstand scrutiny in U.S. courts. Therefore, we must be guided by facts, not by conjecture. Regarding the twelve alleged Russian intelligence officers, I will undertake a thorough review of the matter. The United States and Russia have a treaty dating back to 1999, the Mutual Assistance on Criminal Cases. This treaty is fully operational and effective. We can offer that the appropriate commission headed by Special Attorney Mueller—he can use this treaty as a solid foundation, and send a formal, an official request to us so that we would interrogate—we would hold the questioning of these individuals who he believes are privy to some crimes And our law enforcement are perfectly able to do this questioning and send the appropriate materials to the United States
label: Implicit

sentence: Critics contend that your emphasis on raising taxes on the wealthy is a politically motivated strategy that will ultimately harm the economy and discourage investment. How do you respond to those concerns, and what evidence can you provide to demonstrate that your tax policies will promote economic growth and prosperity for all Americans? [SEP] We believe that asking the wealthiest Americans to pay a little bit more is not only fair but also necessary for our economic future. We're not going to punish success, but we need to ensure that everyone is paying their fair share. We're confident that our tax policies will promote economic growth by investing in education, infrastructure, and innovation.
label: Implicit

sentence: You recently met with Prime Minister Najib, who is under scrutiny for corruption and human rights abuses. You mentioned you would address these concerns. What specifically did you say to Najib regarding the investment fund scandal and the imprisonment of his political rivals? [SEP] Let's talk about the refugee program first. The Paris attacks, which occurred just a week prior, are still fresh in everyone's minds. Given the speed at which news travels these days, it's easy to lose sight of events. However, the recent attacks in Paris, coupled with the similarities between Paris and many American cities, have understandably heightened concerns, leading to the swift passage of legislation in the House. I hope that, with some time to reflect, people will recognize that refugees seeking entry into the United States undergo the most rigorous vetting process imaginable. This process, developed over several administrations on a bipartisan basis, is exceptionally thorough and typically takes between 18 and 24 months for approval. While the House legislation may appear straightforward, its practical effect could be to paralyze the system and prevent refugees from being admitted. Adding layers of bureaucracy that don't enhance safety but simply make processing nearly impossible would effectively shut down the refugee program for those who desperately need it. My reference to a betrayal of our values was specifically directed at commentary suggesting preferential treatment for Christians over Muslims or expressing fear that a four-year-old orphan might pose a threat. Those of you who visited the refugee center with me saw these children firsthand. If you are a parent and you saw what they had endured, you would agree that we must find a place for them in the United States. To deny them refuge would be a violation of our core principles. Fortunately, the vast majority of people, aware of the extensive screening measures already in place, would agree that we must do right by these children. As for Prime Minister Najib, I refrain from commenting on ongoing investigations, whether in the United States or in foreign countries. However, I did emphasize to Prime Minister Najib, as I have to many other leaders, the importance of transparency, accountability, and combating corruption, all of which are essential for development. I also stressed the importance of civil society and a free press. While countries are at different stages of development, certain fundamental principles are universal. Myanmar's recent historic election is a testament to the potential for progress. While Myanmar may not immediately mirror Sweden's democratic practices, a significant transformation is underway, and we must encourage and support it. Our efforts through initiatives like the Open Government Partnership and the inclusion of transparency provisions in trade agreements like the TPP are designed to raise the bar and promote higher standards. Progress may be uneven, but the overall trajectory is towards a world where individuals are treated fairly, the rule of law is upheld, governments are accountable, and all voices are heard. These are not only American values but also universal ones. Thank you.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, Mitch McConnell's office just released a statement regarding the phase four relief package, CARES II, describing it as precisely tailored for this phase of the crisis. However, it excludes your proposed payroll tax cut. Do you still believe the package is perfectly tailored? [SEP] Well, I'd love to see a payroll tax cut. It's fantastic for the workers. But the Democrats would never go for it. They don't seem to care about the working class. So, I told the Republicans last night – they've been working incredibly hard on this, and they want what's best for the country – that I think a payroll tax cut would be great, but the Democrats won't support it. We need their votes, you know. We have a majority, but it's not enough. That's why we have an election coming up. So, we need Democrat votes, and we're not getting them on this. I think it would be very beneficial for the workers. But if we can't get their support, we have to move on. A payroll tax cut would have been a real boost. Maybe something will happen down the line.
label: Implicit

sentence: President Bush, concerning the detained medical personnel, can you pledge to advocate before Congress for the allocation of resources from your HIV/AIDS initiative to assist children affected by AIDS and their families? And President Parvanov, what are your thoughts on the situation in Libya, and would you care to comment on the suggestion from the Bulgarian media to seek contributions from prominent business figures to establish a cutting-edge medical facility for individuals living with HIV/AIDS? [SEP] There is a fund to which we are making contributions. It is more important to focus on whether the United States, along with the EU, is committing funds, which we are. Furthermore, we are conveying to the Libyan government that we expect the release of the nurses. We are working in close collaboration with your government on this matter, as it is something we care deeply about. We also agree that there should be compensation for the Libyan children. I have personally visited Libya, the hospital, and spoken with the parents and children. I am well aware of the suffering and the need to invest in the hospital. This is a commitment of the entire democratic public, not just a temporary effort to release the nurses. It is a long-term commitment to those suffering in Benghazi and all AIDS sufferers in Africa. The G-8 allocated $60 billion to this cause. I have appealed to businesses to donate more. I support the Bulgarian media's appeal, as their voice is often heard more clearly than politicians'.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Can you confirm whether the assailant was male or female, and what type of weapon was employed? [SEP] I'm afraid I'm not privy to that information at this juncture.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Considering the recurring provocations following U.S. overtures, what's your take on Fidel Castro's role in the negotiations? Was he a topic with Raul? And will you directly engage Congress to safeguard embassy funding? [SEP] I believe we've covered this sufficiently. I'd prefer to address other matters.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, despite the surge's military gains, a unity government hasn't materialized, refugees remain displaced, and polls show Iraqis blaming the U.S. What specific benchmarks must the Iraqi government meet to change this? [SEP] Well, I disagree with your assertion that there's no political progress in Iraq. There's a functioning government. They passed a budget last year, and they're working on this year's. And there have been two readings of a de-Ba'athification law. Bill, if you're judging the Iraqi parliament against our own Congress's efficiency, I'd be cautious. Our Congress often waits until the last minute. The legislative process isn't always smooth. They have work to do, no question. We'll keep pressing them. But there is a functioning government. You said security didn't allow a government to function. That's not true. We'll keep pushing them on de-Ba'athification, elections, power sharing, and oil law. They are distributing oil revenues to the provinces. There's revenue sharing and local reconciliation. Local politics often drive national politics. Are we satisfied with Baghdad's progress? No. But to say nothing is happening is simply false.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. To be clear, are we looking at what is commonly referred to as a 'hard' Brexit? [SEP] Are we suggesting it's a 'harmful' Brexit?
label: Clarification

sentence: Considering the potential inclusion of aid for struggling homeowners in the bailout, what safeguards are in place to guarantee responsible allocation of funds and prevent the creation of moral hazard, discouraging future reckless behavior in the housing sector? [SEP] We're collaborating with Congress to finalize a bill swiftly. This is a critical issue, and we require a substantial solution. I'm a proponent of free markets, but this transcends that. This concerns systemic risk. The downfall of one component of the system could affect everyone. Therefore, we must act decisively. It will be expensive, but the risk of inaction is far greater. We'll recoup a considerable amount of the money in time. But currently, we must send a clear message that we won't permit the system to collapse.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, concerning the legal discussions around preemptive pardons for your staff regarding interrogation methods or U.S. Attorney dismissals, have you given this any thought, and are you planning to issue such pardons? [SEP] Pardons are not a topic for discussion at this press conference.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Given the setbacks this past year, especially the healthcare situation, what single decision do you most regret? [SEP] Are you asking about healthcare specifically, or across the board?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. I wanted to ask: Are you now, or are you considering, separating some more with Vice President Pence as a precautionary measure? [SEP] Well, first of all, the job he's done on Task Force, the job he's done, frankly, as the Vice President of the United States has been outstanding. And he's a warrior too, just like doctors and nurses. I mean, he is working so hard, and he meets—he's coming into contact with a lot of people. But again, he tested negative, so we have to understand that. But he comes into contact with a lot of people.It's something probably, during this quarantine period, we'll probably talk about. I have not seen him since then. But I would say that he will—he and I will be talking about that. Yes, we could talk on the phone.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, there have been rumors of tension between you and Secretary Blinken. Are you considering replacing him, and if so, when can we expect a decision? [SEP] He's working hard, and we appreciate his service. We're constantly assessing our team, but right now, he's doing a good job. We'll revisit this in the near future.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, intelligence reports suggest Russia is interfering in the upcoming election to undermine Joe Biden, while China may act against you. Do you trust these assessments, and what measures will you implement to counter these threats? [SEP] Well, it's certainly a possibility. Let me be clear: nobody has been tougher on Russia than this administration. They know that. And frankly, I suspect they'd prefer someone else in the Oval Office. But we're watching everything very closely.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: So, to be clear, you're not prepared to say whether she was fired or not? [SEP] Honestly, I just learned about this situation this morning. I don't have all the details at my fingertips. Ken Salazar has been occupied with testimony on the Hill. The fundamental point is that reforms at MMS were not progressing at an adequate pace. However, even with faster reforms, this incident might still have occurred. The Commission is tasked with determining whether this was a systemic breakdown or an exceptionally rare occurrence. What are the precise risks involved? Let's consider the broader context. The fact that oil companies must now drill a mile underwater and then an additional three miles below that to access oil underscores a critical shift in the industry. Extraction is becoming more costly and inherently more dangerous. That's why I never championed the 'Drill, baby, drill' approach. We cannot simply drill our way out of this challenge. Oil can serve as a transitional bridge to new technologies and energy sources, but we must acknowledge that the easily accessible oil has already been extracted. As technology becomes more complex and oil sources become more remote, the risks will likely escalate. As a society, we must make difficult choices about the level of risk we are willing to accept. That's a key area for the Commission to investigate. We will continue to require oil for our industries and our daily lives, but we must begin the transition to new energy sources. That's why I addressed the Republican caucus this week, urging them to collaborate. Senators Lieberman and Kerry, along with Lindsey Graham in the past, have developed a framework that could achieve bipartisan support. We will still need oil production, but we must recognize the challenges ahead and adapt our approach accordingly. Next question, please.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, in light of the Republican Party's loss of Congressional majority a year ago, you expressed a commitment to bipartisan collaboration. However, your comments today seemed to offer a rather harsh evaluation of the Democratic Party. How would you personally evaluate your own efforts to engage with Democrats during this past year? To what extent have you been successful in achieving collaboration on key legislative matters, and do you believe you have adequately fostered a spirit of common ground? [SEP] On the matter of Iraq, we are finding common ground. While certain members of Congress maintain that our initial involvement was a mistake, the prevailing sentiment has shifted. The testimony of David Petraeus and Ryan Crocker has had a significant impact on many members. I hope that we will continue to find common ground by ensuring that our troops receive the necessary funding. We have found common ground on FISA. I question the rationale for altering a law that has proven effective. The current legislation serves the security interests of the nation. The American people expect us to enact laws that benefit them, and this law enables our intelligence professionals to ascertain the intentions of Al Qaida. However, the law should be enhanced by providing liability protection to the telecommunications companies that assisted us. Therefore, we have found common ground in this area. It is my hope that we can find further common ground as Congress begins to advance pieces of legislation. The reason I made the aforementioned remarks is that there remains a considerable amount of work to be done. As you are aware, I am not a member of the legislative branch, and I would likely not be a particularly effective legislator. However, as the head of the executive branch, it is incumbent upon me to urge Congress to demonstrate progress and achieve results. It is difficult to find common ground when important bills are not being advanced. Indeed, they are not even being considered. Not a single appropriations bill has reached my desk. How can we find common ground in the absence of an appropriations process? We have found common ground on trade bills, which are, in my view, extremely important pieces of legislation. One of the reasons for this is that exports helped us to overcome the weakness in the housing market during the last quarter. Given this fact, it would seem prudent to continue to open up markets to goods and services. However, no bills pertaining to trade have been advanced. Veterans Affairs is another area in which we can find common ground. I have appointed Bob Dole and Donna Shalala to lead an important Commission tasked with ensuring that our veterans receive the benefits to which they are entitled. I was concerned about bureaucratic delays and a system that has been in place for many years but does not adequately recognize the unique nature of the war we are currently fighting. I am troubled when I encounter wives sitting by their husbands' beds in Walter Reed who are not receiving adequate support from the government. I am concerned about PTSD and wish to encourage greater focus on this issue. We have submitted a bill, and I hope that it will be acted upon expeditiously. This is an area in which we can find common ground, Sheryl.
label: Implicit

sentence: Regarding the executive action, how will you ensure its effectiveness against Republican opposition, particularly concerning funding? Also, are you now considering a figure of two million or more? [SEP] The devil's in the details, Jeff, and those details will be abundantly clear when we unveil the executive action. It will be a very detailed plan. And I'm sure you'll all have plenty to say about it afterwards.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Anything sanctions on Russia, sir? Q. Why no sanctions on Russia, sir? Q. Mr. President, why did you delay the sanctions on Russia? [SEP] Yes, we'll do sanctions. As soon as they very much deserve it, we will have—that is a question. There has been nobody tougher on Russia than President Donald Trump. Between building up the military, between creating tremendous vast amounts of oil. We raised billions and billions of dollars extra in NATO. We had a very, very severe—we were talking about it a little while—fight in Syria recently, a month ago, between our troops and Russian troops, and that's very sad. But many people died in that fight. There has been nobody tougher than me. With the media, no matter what I did, it's never tough enough, because that's their narrative. But Russia will tell you, there has been nobody tougher than Donald Trump. And then, the other night, we had a strike in Syria, which was absolute precision.I leave it with this, with all of that said: If we can get along with China, and if we can get along with Russia, and if we can get along with Japan and other nations, that's a good thing, not a bad thing. Just remember that. If we got along with other nations, that's good, not bad.Thank you very much, everybody.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. How many people? Q. How many? [SEP] I don't know. We can have a report to you if you feel it's necessary.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: But Mr. President, isn't it your responsibility to ensure that every American has access to the ballot box, regardless of their voting method? [SEP] Of course. And that's why we have absentee voting. That's why we have in-person voting. But universal mail-in voting is not a safe or reliable way to conduct an election. It's too easy to cheat. It's too easy to lose ballots. It's too easy to manipulate the results. We need to protect the integrity of our elections, and that means opposing universal mail-in voting.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Specifically, the people are—Kim Jong Un is saying he's wanting a brighter future with prosperity for his people, yet we know they've lived under oppression. You showed him this video of what the future can be like. But do you have an idea specifically of the model that he would like to go towards? Economically, is he open to more economic freedom? [SEP] Yes, it's a good question. So you saw a tape today, and that, I think, was done really well. But that was done at the highest level of future development. I told him, you may not want this. You may want to do a much smaller version of this. I mean, you're going to do something. But you may want to do a smaller version. You may not want that with the trains and the everything. You know, it's super—everything the top. And maybe you won't want that. It's going to be up to them. It's going to be up to them. It's going to be up to the people what they want. They may not want that. I can understand that too.But that was a version of what could happen, what could take place. As an example, they have great beaches. You see that whenever they're exploding their cannons into the ocean, right? I said: Boy, look at the view. Wouldn't that make a great condo behind? [] And I explained, I said, You know, instead of doing that, you could have the best hotels in the world right there. Think of it from a real estate perspective. You have South Korea, you have China, and they own the land in the middle. How bad is that, right? It's great. But I told him, I said, you may not want to do what's there. You may want to do a smaller version of it or—you know. And that could be.Although, I tell you what—he looked at that tape, he looked at that iPad, and I'm telling you they really enjoyed it, I believe. Okay?Yes. Go ahead. Mr. President, a couple more questions. The President. A couple more. Okay. We'll do three more. Yes. Go ahead. Go./
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, the scientific community overwhelmingly agrees that climate change is a serious threat. What specific actions will your administration take to mitigate its effects? [SEP] I'm an environmentalist. I want clean air and clean water. But we're not going to destroy our economy to appease the radical left. We're going to have a strong economy and a healthy environment.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, given your emphasis on the interconnectedness of Afghanistan and Pakistan, why has Pakistan's role in ending the war received so little attention at this summit? Did your discussions with President Zardari yield any progress on reopening supply lines? And if these larger tensions remain unresolved, will it jeopardize NATO's progress in Afghanistan? [SEP] Well, my discussion with President Zardari was brief, but I reiterated our public and private stance: Pakistan is part of the solution in Afghanistan. A democratic, prosperous, and stable Pakistan is in our national interest. We share a common enemy in extremists in both countries, and we must address the tensions arising from our decade-long military presence. President Zardari believes these issues can be resolved. We didn't expect the supply line issue to be resolved here, but we're making progress. Everyone in the alliance and Afghanistan understands that security, stability, and prosperity require resolving these issues and joining the international community to prevent extremism. There are real challenges and tensions between ISAF, the US, and Pakistan, but they are being addressed through military and diplomatic channels. Ultimately, a successful, stable Pakistan is in our interest, and it's in Pakistan's interest to work with us to prevent extremism. We're committed to this, and every NATO/ISAF member is too.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, despite the sanctions and aid, Maduro remains in power. Are you concerned about losing momentum, and what's the estimated timeframe for a resolution? [SEP] There's no set timeline. This situation has been ongoing for a while. Eventually, things will change. We haven't fully implemented the toughest sanctions yet, but all options are on the table. We're deeply concerned about the suffering of the Venezuelan people. It's a tragedy to see such a wealthy country in such dire straits.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. And for the Prime Minister, sir, who do you want to come see you as the next U.S. President? [SEP] First of all, it's the Supreme Court decision. We'll abide by the Court's decision. That doesn't mean I have to agree with it. It's a deeply divided Court, and I strongly agree with those who dissented that. And their dissent was based upon their serious concerns about U.S. national security.Congress and the administration worked very carefully on a piece of legislation that set the appropriate procedures in place as to how to deal with the detainees. And we'll study this opinion, and we'll do so with this in mind, to determine whether or not additional legislation might be appropriate so that we can safely say—or truly say to the American people, we're doing everything we can to protect you. As far as my question is concerned, well, of course, I cannot express any preference with regard to an electoral campaign going on in another country. However, I suppose I could express my own personal preference for one of the candidates, the Republican candidate. And this is for a very selfish reason, and that is that I would no longer be the oldest person at the upcoming G-8, because McCain is a month older than me, 29th of August, 1936—29th of September, which is when I was born. There you go. []The second question now from the American journalist, please. Let's see. [Inaudible] Yes, Jeff Stinson [USA Today].
label: General

sentence: What do you believe was the primary message sent by American voters last week? And is there still time for the 'course correction' you spoke of before our European counterparts finalize their decisions? [SEP] Look, I think the American people get it: the world's a smaller place, we're all connected. You can't just stuff that back in the box. They know their jobs, or their kids' jobs, might be changing, not just one gig for 30 years, but maybe switching careers, getting more schooling, learning new skills. And I think they're ready for that. They just want a fair shake. Most Americans still like trade, but they're worried about fairness, about getting the same access to other countries' markets. Is it just a race to see who can pay people the least? I tried to explain, but didn't get very far, that TPP would fix this, making sure workers and the environment are protected, making things fair, and helping American workers and businesses. But it's hard to convince people when they remember factories closing and jobs moving overseas. So, the election showed people wanted things to change. Talk about stopping immigration and unfair trade deals worked. Now that we're governing, we need a smarter approach. We need immigration that's done right, that follows the rules, because it's good for our economy, keeps us young and full of energy. We get people who start businesses and take risks. That's why America's been so successful. When it comes to trade, just cutting off deals like the one with Mexico isn't easy. We have supply chains that go all over the world. Parts from Mexico are keeping auto plants open and running extra shifts. So, we need to listen to people's worries, their fears, and offer real solutions: better pay, stronger protections for workers, tougher rules for banks, trade that's fair and doesn't use child labor, and paying attention to inequality. That's how we win. And I think we can do it. The world's still watching us. What we do matters. The way to make everyone feel like they're part of the global economy isn't to shut ourselves off, but to work together better.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. And, if I can, your Press Secretary had said that the U.S. Government has continued to follow up on that significant offer, but also had proposed alternative potential ways forward with the Russians. Can you tell us what those alternative ways forward are and how Russia has responded to those? [SEP] Yes, I can, but I won't. [] Okay, I can't—I mean, you know, it would not be a wise thing to do in order to see if they would move forward.But it is my—I'm telling you, I am determined to get her home and get her home safely—along with others, I might add.April Ryan.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Sir, do you think Hillary Clinton is the nominee? [SEP] Pardon me?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Mr. President, can you confirm that the individual was carrying a weapon? [SEP] That's my understanding, but I can't say for certain. You'll have to get confirmation from the people who were there.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: In light of Rick Ledgett's remarks regarding Edward Snowden, what are your thoughts on his suggestion of amnesty? Under what circumstances would you entertain the possibility of a plea agreement or amnesty for Snowden? And how do you respond to Americans who believe that Snowden's actions were justified? [SEP] Given that Mr. Snowden is currently under indictment, I must exercise caution in my response. The matter is now in the hands of the Attorney General and the courts. While I cannot comment on the specifics of the case, I believe that the debate surrounding surveillance and privacy is an important one. However, it is also important to acknowledge the damage that these disclosures have caused to U.S. intelligence capabilities and diplomatic efforts. Ultimately, the decision regarding Mr. Snowden's fate rests with the courts.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Mr. President, the Paris attacks cast a shadow over the upcoming climate talks. How might these attacks influence the discussions? Also, regarding concerns about convincing poorer nations to adopt climate measures, especially given Republican opposition, what's your response? Finally, what about the reports of intelligence officials altering ISIL assessments? [SEP] Let's start with the intelligence issue. From day one, I've insisted on unvarnished intelligence, free from political spin. Accurate intelligence is crucial for sound policy. I trust that our intelligence agencies understand this. As for CENTCOM, we'll investigate any wrongdoing. I've told the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs and Secretary Carter to get to the bottom of it. There will always be disagreements on interpreting facts, but I expect fidelity to the truth. That said, I haven't seen rosy pictures of Iraq and Syria. Regarding Paris, we must show that terror won't stop us. Paris won't be cowered. We won't succumb to fear. Terrorists can't defeat us, but they can make us fearful. We fight them by not being afraid. They're just killers. We've faced bigger threats before. On Paris, the G-20, APEC, and ASEAN all emphasized a strong deal. I'm optimistic. 160 countries have targets, covering 90% of emissions. The key is differentiation, accountability, transparency, and review. Climate finance is also vital. We need to help poorer countries develop cleanly. We're on track to meet our $100 billion target. Critics say we shouldn't act if others don't, but China's commitment changed that. Helping countries like India is crucial. Finally, the Paris attacks highlight the need for unity. We must not let fear dictate our actions.
label: General

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. I want to ask a couple questions. On the economy, could you discuss your efforts at reviewing history as it relates to the poverty agenda, meaning LBJ and Dr. King?And also, since Senate Republicans are holding up the issue of Cobell and Pigford too, can you make any assurances before you leave office that you will make sure that those awards are funded? [SEP] Let me take the second question first. For those who aren't familiar, Cobell and Pigford relate to settlements surrounding historic discrimination against minority farmers who weren't oftentimes provided the same benefits as everybody else under the USDA.It is a fair settlement. It is a just settlement. We think it's important for Congress to fund that settlement. We're going to continue to make it a priority.With respect to the history of fighting poverty, I got my start in public service as a community organizer working in the shadow of steel plants that had been closed in some of the poorest neighborhoods on the south side of Chicago. That's what led me to want to serve. And so I am constantly thinking about how do we create ladders for communities and individuals to climb into the middle class.Now, I think the history of antipoverty efforts is, is that the most important antipoverty effort is growing the economy and making sure there are enough jobs out there--single most important thing we can do. It's more important than any program we could set up. It's more important than any transfer payment that we could have. If we can grow the economy faster and create more jobs, then everybody is swept up into that virtuous cycle. And if the economy is shrinking and things are going badly, then the folks who are most vulnerable are going to be those poorest communities.So what we want to focus on right now is broad-based job growth and broad-based economic expansion. And we're doing so against some tough headwinds, because as I said, we are coming out of a very difficult time. We've started to turn the corner, but we're not there yet.And so that is going to be my central focus: How do I grow the economy? How do I make sure that there's more job growth?That doesn't mean that there aren't some targeted things we can do to help communities that are especially in need. And probably the most important thing we can do, after growing the economy generally, is, how can we improve school systems in low-income communities? And I am very proud of the efforts that we've made on education reform, which have received praise from Democrats and Republicans. This is one area where actually we've seen some good bipartisan cooperation.And the idea is very simple: If we can make sure that we have the very best teachers in the classroom, if we can reward excellence instead of mediocrity and the status quo, if we can make sure that we're tracking progress in real, serious ways, and we're willing to make investments in what goes on in the classroom and not the school bureaucracy, and reward innovation, then schools can improve. There are models out there of schools in the toughest inner-city neighborhood that are now graduating kids, 90 percent of whom are going to college. And the key is, how do we duplicate those?And so what our Race to the Top program has done is, it's said to every State around the country, instead of just getting money based on a formula, we want you to compete. Show us how you are reforming your school systems to promote excellence, based on proven ideas out there. And if you do that, we're going to reward you with some extra money. And just the competition alone has actually spurred 46 States so far to initiate legislation designed to reform the school system.So we're very proud of that. And that, I think, is going to be one of the most important things we can do. It's not just, by the way, K through 12. It's also higher education. And as a consequence of a battle that we had--and it was a contentious battle--in Congress, we've been able to take tens of billions of dollars that were going to banks and financial intermediaries in the student loan program and said, we're going to give that money directly to students so that they get more help going to college. And obviously, poor kids are the ones who are going to benefit most from those programs.Helene Cooper [New York Times].U.S. Military Operations in Afghanistan/
label: Implicit

sentence: So, if I understand correctly, you see federal contracting as a useful tool, as demonstrated by your actions on gay rights and contraception. Is it reasonable to assume you'd consider applying this approach to federal contractors in this case as well? [SEP] I appreciate the question, but I'm not prepared to discuss specific policy details piecemeal. Once we've completed a comprehensive review and fully understand our legal options, we'll make our intentions known.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. ——discourage mail-in voting? Are you trying to discourage? [SEP] No, not at all. The steps that he is taking are trying to stop the tremendous losses that have taken place for many, many years. He's trying to streamline the Post Office and make it great again. Okay?
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, regarding Prime Minister Netanyahu's recent statements on Palestinian statehood, what specific actions can he take to demonstrate his commitment to peace? And is there any truth to the allegations that Israel spied on the Iran talks? [SEP] I don't comment on intelligence matters. As for an agreement with Iran, we brief Congress, the Israelis, and our partners. If we reach a deal that prevents Iran from getting a nuclear weapon, it will be transparent. People will be able to see what's in it. I'm confident that if there's an agreement, it will be a good one for American, Israeli, and regional security. If not, there won't be an agreement. On Israel and the Palestinians, the issue is what the parties believe is possible. Prime Minister Netanyahu said a Palestinian state wouldn't happen while he was Prime Minister. I took him at his word. He later added conditions that would be impossible to meet soon. So, there doesn't seem to be a prospect of a meaningful framework for a Palestinian state. The question is, do we create a process that gives Palestinians hope for a secure state alongside Israel? It's hard to envision that happening based on the Prime Minister's statements. We're evaluating our approach. This isn't about our commitment to Israel's security or our cooperation. That continues. But I have to honestly evaluate how we manage Israeli-Palestinian relations. The possibility of two states seems dim, which could lead to a downward spiral. Our military and intelligence cooperation with Israel will continue. The evaluation is specific to Israeli-Palestinian relations. We'll engage both sides. We can't pretend something is possible when it's not. This isn't a personal issue between me and Prime Minister Netanyahu. It's a policy difference. We believe two states is the best path forward. He has a different approach.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, you've spent the last two days emphasizing the U.S.-Japan alliance and outlining a vision for a free and open Indo-Pacific. However, in two days, you're traveling to China, a country that is neither free nor open. How can the U.S. promote freedom and openness in the region without inevitably clashing with China? And Prime Minister, the President has often expressed a desire for Japan to take a stronger role in its own defense. He's keen to sell Japan military equipment, and reports suggest he was disappointed that Japan didn't intercept the North Korean missile that flew over Hokkaido. Did this topic arise, and what message did you convey to the President regarding Japan's role in its defense? [SEP] Let me jump in on the Prime Minister's answer. He'll be shooting those missiles down once he finishes buying all that great military equipment from us. He'll easily shoot them down, just like we did in Saudi Arabia the other day. Amazing shot. Now, the Prime Minister is going to be purchasing massive amounts of military equipment from the United States, and he should. We make the best, by far. Whether it's the F-35, the greatest fighter in the world, total stealth, or missiles of all kinds, it's jobs for us and safety for Japan and other countries buying from us, countries that weren't buying a year or two ago. As for China, my relationship with President Xi is excellent. I like him a lot. He's a friend. But he represents China, and I represent the United States. We have different views on some things, but we're pretty aligned on trade. The problem with China is that for decades, it's been a very unfair trade situation. I'm being kind to previous administrations here. Our trade deficit is massive, hundreds of billions a year, not even including intellectual property. We've started discussions with China because it has to come down. It has to come down to free, fair, or reciprocal trade. I prefer reciprocal. When you explain that you're going to charge tariffs to equalize things, some people don't get it. But when you say it's reciprocal, that we'll charge the same as they charge us, they understand. It's much more understandable. Reciprocal trade is very important to me. We have countries charging us a hundred-percent tax while we charge them nothing. I've been against that for a long time, and you'll see us do something about it. It takes time, with statutory limitations and notices. But you'll see strong action against countries that have been treating the United States, the American worker, and our companies unfairly. It's already started, but the legal foundation is done. You're going to see a big difference, very soon. The United States has been treated very unfairly when it comes to trade. Thank you very much.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, what assurances can you give to the markets that the U.S. is prepared for a potential Greek exit from the Eurozone and its impact on the global economy? [SEP] The Eurozone situation was a key topic at Camp David. We all want to see it resolved. I'm not going to get into hypotheticals about Greece leaving, especially with their election. The G-8 wants them to stay, if they can honor their commitments. It's up to the Greek people. But what happens there matters here. Uncertainty in Europe hurts investment. We need to protect countries doing the right thing. We need strong banks. We need growth. There's agreement on this approach. They're working on it. We're offering help. Europe needs to get its act together. It's tough with so many countries involved. But there's more urgency now. We acted decisively in 2008, and that worked. It's better to be bold.
label: General

sentence: Are you unwilling to even acknowledge drone strikes in Yemen? [SEP] I cannot comment on ongoing military operations. Ed Henry.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Sir, with all due respect, isn't it your responsibility to be informed about groups like QAnon, especially given their influence? [SEP] Look, I'm focused on the big picture: making America great again. I can't be expected to know every detail about every group out there. What I do know is that many people are frustrated with the direction our country is headed, and I'm fighting to change that. If these QAnon people are part of that, then so be it.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: To confirm, you're asking if a direct meeting with Iranian leaders is on the horizon? [SEP] The essence of your question is: Am I contemplating a direct engagement with the Iranians?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, considering your extensive international business interests prior to assuming office, would it have been wiser to liquidate them and establish a blind trust? Furthermore, what are your reservations concerning the operations of the NSA and Cyber Command? [SEP] That opening question was a thinly veiled attempt to criticize me, correct?
label: Dodging

sentence: Is there a record, perhaps a transcript, of your conversation? Can the American people see it? [SEP] Does anyone have a copy of that? Maybe a draft? If you find one, let us know.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Under what specific conditions would you be willing to meet with President Castro in Havana? Furthermore, are you considering additional sanctions against North Korea, including military or cyber options? [SEP] With respect to Cuba, we are always open to dialogue, but there needs to be demonstrable progress on human rights and democratic reforms. As for North Korea, all options remain on the table. We will respond in a manner that is proportionate and effective.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Mr. President, considering Netanyahu's remarks, can you confirm or deny the U.S. role, if any, in the Israeli strike in Syria, and what are the potential ramifications for regional stability? [SEP] That's a matter of ongoing intelligence, and I'm not at liberty to discuss ongoing intelligence matters. Next question.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Mr. President, that was a long question, could you tell me what part you want me to answer? [SEP] Which part are you referring to?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. If I may ask one last question: Have you had any talks with Senate Republicans who are threatening this administration with not considering the immigration legislation that was passed in the House until the situation at the border has been resolved? [SEP] No, because I know they have to posture for a while. They sort of got to get it out of their system. This is a—but I'm ready to work with any Republican who wants to help solve the problem and make the situation better.But, folks, I'm going. Thank you very, very much. I appreciate it. Thank you.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, concerning Estonia's request for visa-free travel, when will you formally submit the necessary legislation to Congress? And what specific measures can Estonia take to facilitate a swifter resolution to this issue? [SEP] We're focused on the 3% defense commitment and assuring Congress that visa waiver changes won't compromise our security. This initiative begins shortly. Estonia has consistently raised this matter. We've made significant progress since discussions began. We'll implement security requirements in our passports once clarified. It's a technical matter, but solvable.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, how can the American people be confident that North Korea will truly denuclearize, and not just repeat past patterns of deception? [SEP] Look, you can't guarantee anything. Can I guarantee that you'll write a fair article? No. But I've got a good instinct for these things. I know when someone's serious, and I believe they are. We'll see.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Mr. President, regarding Crimea, what concrete actions will your administration pursue to address the situation and potentially remove Russian influence? [SEP] That's a matter of ongoing deliberation, and frankly, revealing our strategy would be strategically unwise. We're considering various avenues, diplomatic and otherwise. Let's just say we're not sitting idly by.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, concerning the TPP's uncertain future in Congress, are you planning any changes to your strategy for its approval, especially given the recent agreements with Boeing and GE during your Vietnam visit? Should the agreement be revised to address currency manipulation? Additionally, what are your thoughts on the killing of Mullah Mansur and Pakistan's concerns? Does this indicate a new offensive in Afghanistan, and are you worried about a more radical successor? [SEP] On TPP, trade deals are always tough. Everyone wants a better deal, especially with many parties involved. And in an election year, some will play politics. But I'm confident we'll get it done because it's the right thing to do for America and the world. This is a fast-growing region, a big market for us. They sell to us with low tariffs, but our goods face higher tariffs. This deal eliminates 18,000 taxes on U.S. goods. TPP also requires higher labor and environmental standards. I haven't seen a good reason why TPP will hurt us. American workers and businesses benefit from it. The politics will be messy, like with past trade deals. But we got those done, and we'll get this done too. Regarding currency manipulation, we have transparency provisions in TPP. Some want stronger measures, but it's hard to know why a currency is falling and if it's being manipulated. Binding other countries' monetary policy would mean binding our own Federal Reserve, which we won't do. But we've improved provisions to address competitive devaluations. Finally, Mullah Mansur is dead. He targeted U.S. personnel in Afghanistan. This doesn't change our approach. We're not re-entering combat. We're helping Afghanistan secure itself. But when a leader targets U.S. personnel and resists peace, I must protect our people. That's the message. President Quang.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, do you think Senator Obama's comments on Iraq are a bit green, considering he's still battling it out with Senator Clinton for the nomination? [SEP] Look, the guy's gotta win the primary first, right? Then we can talk about who's got the better ideas on Iraq. Right now, it's all just talk. Let's see who's standing at the end of the day. Next!
label: Dodging

sentence: Can you give me your definition of torture? [SEP] Of what are you asking?
label: Clarification

sentence: President Biden, your administration has faced challenges in addressing inflation and rising prices. What specific measures are you taking to combat inflation, and how do you respond to concerns that your policies are contributing to the problem?
