[SEP] We're focused on bringing down costs for American families. We're working to address supply chain bottlenecks, lower prescription drug prices, and promote competition in the economy. We're also committed to fiscal responsibility and reducing the national debt. We believe that these policies will help to ease inflationary pressures and create a stronger economy for everyone.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, the Roxham Road agreement has been finalized for a year. What accounts for the protracted delay in its implementation? Additionally, the 15,000 migrant quota appears restrictive. What compromises were made with the U.S. to reach this agreement? [SEP] The Prime Minister has explained the complexities involved. A hasty closure of Roxham Road would have been a band-aid solution, potentially exacerbating the problem. The modernization of the Safe Third Country Agreement provides a more comprehensive and equitable framework. This required careful planning and execution. We are preserving the integrity of our asylum system while meeting our obligations. To balance the closure, we are committed to increasing asylum seeker admissions from the Western Hemisphere.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Sir, following the Inter-Continental Hotel attack, are you worried about the readiness of Afghan forces to assume security responsibilities, given their inability to prevent such a high-profile incident? [SEP] Look, the drawdown hasn't even begun. We knew Afghanistan was a dangerous place, the Taliban is still active, and these things will occur. The key is whether Afghan capacity is improving. Kabul, with a large percentage of the population, has been largely policed by Afghan forces for some time, and they've done a reasonable job. It's safer than it was, and they're more capable. That doesn't mean these events won't happen, potentially for a while. Our work isn't finished. But as I said, the war is receding. We've shifted to transition. Like Iraq, where we withdrew troops, and they've maintained a democratic government and reduced violence, we think a similar approach makes sense here. Even in Iraq, attacks still happen. These countries are digging out of war. They're dangerous places, and won't be perfectly safe even with us there. But we can improve the chances for Afghans to defend themselves. Next question.
label: Clarification

sentence: Sir, regarding the incident with the Marines and Navy corpsman, can you share any preliminary information about the cause of the accident or the status of the investigation? [SEP] I'm awaiting a comprehensive briefing on the matter. I'll have more to say once I've received all the relevant details.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: So that was recorded? [SEP] No, they didn't record it. I don't think they recorded it. Were there any recordings of it? I wish there were. Because it is interesting stuff.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Given your advocacy for state sovereignty, how does that align with the 'responsibility to protect' doctrine? [SEP] Reconcile with 'responsibility to protect,' which used to be... I'm sorry?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Can you comment on the bribery allegations against you, President Biden? [SEP] But wait, wait, wait, wait, wait.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. And will the U.S. negotiate in the same manner? [SEP] Yes.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Thank you, sir. There's a bill that could come before the lameduck session of Congress that would extend voting rights to the District of Columbia, in Congress, and also give an extra seat to Utah. You've been passionate about democracy in Iraq. Why not here in DC, and would you support this bill? [SEP] Yes, I haven't—it's the first I've heard of it. I didn't know that's going to come up from the lameduck.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: President Trump, can you clarify the status of North Korea's nuclear program? Are they continuing to develop their program? [SEP] He told me there would be no more testing. He assured me, no rockets, no missiles, nothing nuclear. That's what he said, folks. We'll see what happens. Believe me.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Thanks, Mr. President. I wanted to ask about two things that were on the agenda at the G-7 this weekend. The first was the Islamic State. You said yesterday, ahead of your meeting with Prime Minister Cameron, that you'd assess what was working and what wasn't. So I'm wondering, bluntly, what is not working in the fight against the Islamic State. And in today's bilateral with Prime Minister Abadi, you pledged to step up assistance to Iraq. I'm wondering if that includes additional U.S. military personnel.Separately, on trade, Chancellor Merkel said today that she was pleased you would get fast track authority. I'm wondering if that means that you gave her or other leaders here assurance that it would go through the House. And if it doesn't, what does it say about your ability to achieve meaningful agreements with Congress for the remainder of your time in office? [SEP] Well, on the latter question, I'm not going to hypothesize about not getting it done. I intend to get it done. And, hopefully, we're going to get a vote soon, because I think it's the right thing to do.With respect to ISIL, we have made significant progress in pushing back ISIL from areas in which they had occupied or disrupted local populations, but we've also seen areas like in Ramadi where they're displaced in one place and then they come back in, in another. And they're nimble, and they're aggressive, and they're opportunistic. So one of the areas where we're going to have to improve is the speed at which we're training Iraqi forces. Where we've trained Iraqi forces directly and equipped them and we have a train-and-assist posture, they operate effectively. Where we haven't, morale, lack of equipment, et cetera, may undermine the effectiveness of Iraqi security forces. So we want to get more Iraqi security forces trained, fresh, well equipped, and focused. And President Abadi wants the same thing.So we're reviewing a range of plans for how we might do that, essentially accelerating the number of Iraqi forces that are properly trained and equipped and have a focused strategy and good leadership. And when a finalized plan is presented to me by the Pentagon, then I will share it with the American people. It's not—I—we don't yet have a complete strategy because it requires commitments on the part of the Iraqis as well about how recruitment takes place, how that training takes place. And so the details of that are not yet worked out.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, regarding Syria, you've said Assad must go. Can you give us a timeline, and should we expect the Syrian crisis to continue into next year? [SEP] We would have liked to see Assad gone yesterday. Our position has been consistent: he lost legitimacy when he attacked his own people. As for how, there's no easy fix. We need sustained international pressure and a stronger opposition. Talks in Geneva might offer a path forward, but we'll keep supporting the opposition and addressing the humanitarian crisis in close coordination with Turkey.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. So, if Republicans block funding, will the executive action still have teeth? And are we talking about 2 million people, or more? [SEP] We're working on all the angles. The final plan will be comprehensive. I'll have more to say soon.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. Those of us who remember covering your campaign remember you saying that militarily, when the United States acts, it's not just important what it does, but how it goes about doing it; and that even when America sets its course, it's important to engage the international community and listen to different ideas even as it's pursuing that action. I wonder if you leave here and return to Washington, seeing the skepticism there, hearing it here, with any different ideas that might delay military action. For example, some in Congress have suggested giving the Syrian regime 45 days to sign the Chemical Weapons Convention, get rid of its chemical stockpiles, do something that would enhance international sense of accountability for Syria, but delay military action. Are you, Mr. President, looking at any of these ideas? Or are we on a fast track to military action as soon as Congress renders its judgment one way or the other? [SEP] I am listening to all these ideas. And some of them are constructive. And I'm listening to ideas in Congress, and I'm listening to ideas here. Look, I want to repeat here: My goal is to maintain the international norm on banning chemical weapons. I want that enforcement to be real. I want it to be serious. I want people to understand that gassing innocent people, delivering chemical weapons against children is not something we do. It's prohibited in active wars between countries. We certainly don't do it against kids. And we've got to stand up for that principle.If there are tools that we can use to ensure that, obviously my preference would be, again, to act internationally in a serious way and to make sure that Mr. Asad gets the message.I'm not itching for military action. Recall, Major, that I have been criticized for the last couple of years by some of the folks who are now saying they would oppose these strikes for not striking. And I think that I have a well-deserved reputation for taking very seriously and soberly the idea of military engagement.So we will look at these ideas. So far, at least, I have not seen ideas presented that, as a practical matter, I think would do the job. But this is a situation where part of the reason I wanted to foster debate was to make sure that everybody thought about both the ramifications of action and inaction.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, critics argue your response lacks specifics. What tangible actions will Japan undertake to deter China's expansionism and support Ukraine's defense? [SEP] We're coordinating our efforts with Japan on a daily basis. We're sharing intelligence, conducting joint military exercises, and working together to promote economic prosperity in the region. We're confident that Japan will continue to play a leading role in addressing these challenges.
label: Dodging

sentence: Has President Biden reassured you regarding his climate change and Russia policies? Are you concerned about the EU's stance on Russia collapsing after Trump's election? Would you announce your candidacy as a gesture of civility? [SEP] It's not my place to comment on other nations' internal affairs. Merkel was a great partner. Regarding Russia, I've always sought cooperation while standing firm on values. I hope the next president does the same. As for my candidacy, time will tell.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the NHS: Is the National Health Service a topic for discussion in these trade talks? [SEP] I'm sorry, what was that? I couldn't quite hear you.
label: Clarification

sentence: So, Mr. President, can you give us any indication of when this meeting might actually happen? [SEP] Honestly, I'm in the dark on that one. It's all up in the air. Could be tomorrow, could be next year. Who knows? I'm hoping for the best, but preparing for anything.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. I ask you because your attorneys say it's not. Alan Dershowitz says the Framers of the Constitution did not permit impeachment on grounds like abuse of power or obstruction. They objected, open-ended, vague criteria.So for future Presidents, is abuse of power an impeachable offense? [SEP] Well, it depends. But if you take a look at this, and from what everybody tells me, all I do is, I'm honest. I make great deals. I've made great deals for our country. Now we're working with the WTO. You're probably surprised by that, but this has been a long-term, abusive situation to the U.S. I make great deals for our country, and they're honest deals.And when you read that transcription—and, by the way, it wasn't one call; it was two calls. Nobody likes to talk about that. There was one call, which was perfect, and then there was a second call—I guess, a couple of months later—which was perfect.The President of Ukraine said it was perfect. The Foreign Minister of Ukraine said it was perfect. So if we have a transcription, we have the call, and we have the person on the other side of the call saying it was good—now, here's the other thing: They got their money long before schedule. They got all their money. What nobody says—this is very important to me: Why isn't Germany paying? Why isn't U.K. paying? Why isn't France paying? Why aren't the European nations paying? Why is it always the sucker—United States? That's one.And the other thing I wanted to check very carefully—and it's very important—is corruption. And we do that too. This was a perfect call, and I think we're doing very well.
label: General

sentence: After five years of war, what lessons will you take into the final two years of your Presidency? [SEP] It's important to analyze what went wrong. Clearly, the sectarian violence inside Baghdad has been a major problem. It's a troubling aspect of trying to help the Iraqi Government succeed. Our planners are focused on how to deal with that and how to help the Iraqis stop the violence. There are different war theaters inside Iraq. Baghdad, where the sectarian violence is brutal, and the battle against Sunni extremists. We're making good progress against them. There are also issues in the south, mainly Shi'a-on-Shi'a tensions. But the toughest fight is inside of Baghdad. We haven't made as much progress as we'd hoped in helping the government defend and govern itself. The attack on the Samarra mosque was Zarqawi's attempt to foment sectarian violence. Success in Iraq will require military, political, and reconstruction efforts working together. We need a parallel political process and a reconstruction process going along with a new military strategy. We're looking at where things went wrong, where expectations were dashed.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Do you have a plan to put something on the table? [SEP] We want to get money to people. It wasn't their fault. And we want to get money to people, and it has to be substantial. It's not their fault what happened.The fact is, people don't like saying it—they know it's true—it's China's fault. Okay? It's not their fault. It's not the worker who lost his job; it's China's fault. And that's the way it is.OAN, please.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Mr. President, can you at least acknowledge the existence of drone strikes conducted by the U.S. in Yemen? [SEP] With all due respect, Ed, I'm not at liberty to delve into the specifics of ongoing military operations. National security considerations preclude such disclosures.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. So, no further comment on that particular point? [SEP] Excuse me?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, given President Trump's aversion to foreign entanglements, what specific arguments did you employ to secure his commitment to a continued U.S. military presence in your country? What was his reaction? [SEP] The situation is more nuanced than a simple 'military presence.' We have a specialized training team working alongside our officers, sharing best practices and strengthening our defense capabilities. This is a strategic partnership, not an occupation.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. Just to follow up, just quickly: Does that mean you disagree with her characterization, Mr. President? [SEP] Go ahead, please.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, many are questioning your absence from the impeachment hearings. Why not directly address the accusations and defend yourself in person? [SEP] Frankly, I'd relish the opportunity to sit face-to-face with those characters and watch them try to make their case. What a show that would be!
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: President Obama, regarding human rights violations and drug trafficking in Mexico, will you certify Mexico? How will the Merida Initiative proceed given threats against President Calderon and visa concerns? Your comments? [SEP] I'm afraid the translation was a bit garbled. It sounded like an excellent query, though. Perhaps we can try that again?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Mr. President, what does it say about the status of American system of justice when so many of those who are thought to be plotters for September 11th or accused or suspected terrorists are still awaiting any kind of trial? Are you--why are you still convinced that a civilian trial is correct for Sheikh--Khalid Sheikh Mohammed? And why has that stalled? And will Guantanamo remain open for another year? [SEP] Well, we have succeeded on delivering a lot of campaign promises that we made. One where we've fallen short is closing Guantanamo. I wanted to close it sooner. We have missed that deadline. It's not for lack of trying. It's because the politics of it are difficult.Now, I am absolutely convinced that the American justice system is strong enough that we should be able to convict people who murdered innocent Americans, who carried out terrorist attacks against us. We should be able to lock them up and make sure that they don't see the light of day. We can do that. We've done it before. We've got people who engaged in terrorist attacks who are in our prisons--maximum security prisons all across the country.But this is an issue that has generated a lot of political rhetoric, and people, understandably, are fearful. But one of the things that I think is worth reflecting on after 9/11 is, this country is so resilient, we are so tough, we can't be frightened by a handful of people who are trying to do us harm, especially when we've captured them and we've got the goods on them.So I've also said that there are going to be circumstances where a military tribunal may be appropriate, and the reason for that is--and I'll just give a specific example. There may be situations in which somebody was captured in theater, is now in Guantanamo. It's very hard to piece together a chain of evidence that would meet some of the evidentiary standards that would be required in an Article III court. But we know that this person is guilty; there's sufficient evidence to bring about a conviction. So what I have said is, the military commission system that we set up--where appropriate for certain individuals that would make it--it would be difficult to try in Article III courts for a range of reasons--we can reform that system so that it meets the highest standards of due process and prosecute them there.And so I'm prepared to work with Democrats and Republicans. And we, over the course of the last year, have been in constant conversations with them about setting up a sensible system in which we are prosecuting, where appropriate, those in Article III courts. We are prosecuting others, where appropriate, through a military tribunal. And in either case, let's put them in prisons where our track record is they've never escaped. And by the way, just from a purely fiscal point of view, the costs of holding folks in Guantanamo is massively higher than it is holding them in a super-maximum security prison here in the United States.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Why does that matter? Why is this a global competition to you if, every day, Americans are still losing their lives and we're still seeing more cases every day? [SEP] Well, they're losing their lives everywhere in the world. And maybe that's a question you should ask China. Don't ask me; ask China that question, okay? When you ask them that question, you may get a very unusual answer.Yes. Behind you, please.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the Syrian situation, many are concerned about Russia's involvement. Following your meeting with President Putin, do you believe he was forthright about his Syrian objectives? If Russian forces target groups aligned with the U.S. alongside ISIS, will the U.S. military intervene to protect them? Furthermore, considering the setbacks in the U.S. train-and-equip program, can it be salvaged, or should alternative strategies be considered? Specifically, would you entertain the idea of a no-fly zone, as advocated by several presidential hopefuls, including your former Secretary of State? [SEP] Well, let's get one thing straight: Syria's a mess, and it didn't start yesterday. What began as peaceful protests against Assad morphed into a full-blown civil war because of his brutal response. This isn't about the U.S. versus anyone in Syria; it's about the Syrian people versus a ruthless dictator. Assad's still in power because Russia and Iran have been propping him up. Putin's actions now aren't new; he's just being more blatant about it. He's backing a regime that the Syrian people overwhelmingly reject because Assad's willing to bomb his own people to stay in power. I told Putin that the only way to fix Syria is through a political transition that includes everyone, keeps the state and military intact, but gets rid of Assad. He's too toxic for Syrians to accept. I offered to work with Putin if he can convince Assad and Iran to agree to this transition. A military solution won't work; it'll just get them stuck in a quagmire. We all want to destroy ISIS, but Putin doesn't see the difference between ISIS and the moderate Sunni opposition. He thinks they're all terrorists, which is wrong. We're talking to Russia to avoid accidental clashes. We still believe Assad's the problem and his brutality must end. We're ready to work with anyone to achieve that, but we won't help Russia crush Assad's opposition. The moderate opposition is key to Syria's future. Russia's actions are weakening them and strengthening ISIS. Our train-and-equip program hasn't worked as planned, partly because the opposition is too busy fighting Assad to focus on ISIS. We're looking at what's worked, like our work with the Kurds, and building on that. We'll also keep working with the opposition because without a change in government, the civil war will continue, fueling ISIS. Putin went into Syria because Assad was failing. Sending arms and money wasn't enough; he had to send in his own forces. Nobody's buying his plan. Iran and Assad are his only allies. We have a coalition of 60 nations. Putin might realize it's in his interest to broker a political settlement. We're ready to work with Russia and Iran on that. It won't be easy, but it's possible. We need to talk, but only if there's a recognition that Assad has to go. We can't go back to the way things were. Russia's attacks on the moderate opposition are making things worse.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, with the shifting power structures in Russia, particularly concerning Medvedev and Putin, and considering past criticisms about your assessment of Putin, what counsel would you offer your successor on navigating this intricate relationship? [SEP] Honestly, I couldn't tell you much about Medvedev's current influence. The key indicator will be who represents Russia at international forums like the G-8. That will offer insights into Russia's foreign policy direction post-Putin. I can't provide a complete answer at this moment. However, maintaining relations with Russia remains crucial, especially regarding non-proliferation and Iran. Putin's past collaboration on Iran's nuclear program was a positive step. Furthermore, we must collaborate with Russia to address shared security challenges, such as missile defense in Europe. It's essential to ensure they grasp that the system isn't targeted at them, but at genuine threats. Ultimately, my successor must have the latitude to engage with whoever is leading Russia, even amidst disagreements, because it serves our national interests.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. You have said that core Al Qaida has been decimated, that its leaders are on the run. Now that we've seen this terror threat that has resulted in Embassies closed throughout the Arab world, much of Africa, do you still believe that Al Qaida has been decimated? And if I can ask in the interest of transparency, can you tell us about these drone strikes that we've seen over the last couple of weeks in Yemen? [SEP] What I said in the same National Defense University speech back in May that I referred to earlier is that core Al aida is on its heels, has been decimated. But what I also said was that Al aida and other extremists have metastasized into regional groups that can pose significant dangers.And I'd refer you back to that speech just back in May, where I said specifically that although they are less likely to be able to carry out spectacular homeland attacks like 9/11, they have the capacity to go after our Embassies. They have the capacity, potentially, to go after our businesses. They have the capacity to be destabilizing and disruptive in countries where the security apparatus is weak. And that's exactly what we are seeing right now.So it's entirely consistent to say that this tightly organized and relatively centralized Al aida that attacked us on 9/11 has been broken apart and is very weak and does not have a lot of operational capacity and to say we still have these regional organizations like AAP that can pose a threat, that can drive potentially a truck bomb into an Embassy wall and can kill some people.And so that requires us then to make sure that we have a strategy that is strengthening those partners so that they've got their own capacity to deal with what are potentially manageable regional threats if these countries are a little bit stronger and have more effective CT and so forth. It means that we've got to continue to be vigilant and go after known terrorists who are potentially carrying out plots or are going to strengthen their capacity over time, because they're always testing the boundaries of, well, maybe we can try this, maybe we can do that.But this is a ongoing process. We are not going to completely eliminate terrorism. What we can do is to weaken it and to strengthen our partnerships in such a way that it does not pose the kind of horrible threat that we saw on 9/11.And I'm not going to discuss specific operations that have taken place. Again, in my speech in May, I was very specific about how we make these determinations about potential lethal strikes, so I would refer you to that speech.
label: Explicit

sentence: So, Mr. President, just to finalize this point, are you prepared to give your full endorsement to that proposal as it is currently written? [SEP] Well, not that particular proposal, but we're getting closer, folks. We're getting closer. What I *do* support is getting funds to the people who were really, really hurt unnecessarily by something that, frankly, could have been prevented. They could have stopped it from leaving their country. They could have stopped it from coming here, to Europe, and to the rest of the world – 188 different countries from all over the world. Please.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the situation with Iran, you mentioned potential discussions. Could you elaborate on the specific actions Iran needs to take to de-escalate tensions? Furthermore, considering your meetings with leaders from North Korea and Russia, would you be open to a meeting with President Rouhani? What preconditions, if any, would be necessary for such a meeting? [SEP] Look, I'm open to talking to anyone if it serves American interests. As someone very smart once said, dialogue is key, especially when dealing with matters of war, peace, and prosperity. We've seen positive results from engaging with Chairman Kim – no missile launches in months, our hostages returned. My meeting with President Putin, despite what the fake news says, was productive for global security and economic cooperation. NATO is now stronger financially because of our efforts. So, yes, I'd meet with Iran if they're serious. The previous deal was a disaster, a complete waste. They're struggling right now, but I believe they'll eventually want to talk. I'm ready when they are, not from a position of strength or weakness, but from a position of common sense. If we can negotiate a meaningful agreement, unlike that previous joke, I'm all in.
label: Implicit

sentence: Following up on human rights, you spoke with great conviction on this during the State of the Union. Given that, will you call on Israel to declare its nuclear program and sign the Non-Proliferation Treaty? If not, why wouldn't other countries see that as an incentive not to sign on to the treaty? [SEP] Well, Scott, you started by talking about U.S. behavior, and now we're talking about Israel. Let's focus on the United States. I do think that as part of the NPT, our obligation as the largest nuclear power is to take steps to reduce our nuclear stockpile. That's what the START Treaty was about. As for Israel, I'm not going to comment on their program. I'm going to point out that we have consistently urged all countries to become members of the NPT. So there's no contradiction there. We think it is important that we have an international approach that is universal and that rests on three pillars: that those of us who have nuclear weapons are making serious efforts to reduce those stockpiles; that we are all working against the proliferation of nuclear weapons, and those countries that don't currently have nuclear weapons make the decision not to pursue nuclear weapons; and that all countries have access to peaceful nuclear energy. So whether we're talking about Israel or any other country, we think that becoming part of the NPT is important. And that's not a new position. That's been a consistent position of the United States Government even prior to my administration.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, regarding Russia and Ukraine, you mentioned assessing Putin's intentions. Has your administration determined whether President Putin plans to invade or move further into Ukraine? [SEP] Let me be clear: Putin is calling the shots here, period. Nobody else's opinion matters. What he decides to do is entirely up to him. Frankly, it probably depends on what kind of mood he's in that day. He might want to discuss strategic doctrine and force structures, but who knows? I don't think even his own people know what he's going to do. We've had meetings, but they haven't yielded much. As for an invasion, he'll need the ground to freeze if he wants to move in from the north. We're providing defense assistance to Ukraine and monitoring the situation in the Baltic and Black Seas. He's weighing his options, considering the short-term and long-term consequences for Russia. But ultimately, it's his decision, and I don't think he's made up his mind yet.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Well, how many cigarettes a day do you now smoke? Do you smoke alone or in the presence of other people? And do you believe the new law would help you to quit? If so, why? [SEP] Well, the--first of all, the new law that was put in place is not about me; it's about the next generation of kids coming up. So I think it's fair, Margaret, to just say that you just think it's neat to ask me about my smoking, as opposed to it being relevant to my new law. [] But that's fine.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. Mr. President, after the mistakes that have been made in this war, when you do as you did yesterday, where you raised 2-year-old intelligence, talking about the threat posed by Al Qaida, it's met with increasing skepticism. The majority in the public, a growing number of Republicans appear not to trust you any longer to be able to carry out this policy successfully. Can you explain why you believe you're still a credible messenger on the war? [SEP] I'm credible because I read the intelligence, David, and make it abundantly clear in plain terms that if we let up, we'll be attacked. And I firmly believe that.Look, this has been a long, difficult experience for the American people. I can assure you, Al Qaida, who would like to attack us again, have got plenty of patience and persistence. And the question is, will we?Yes, I talked about intelligence yesterday. I wanted to make sure the intelligence I laid out was credible, so we took our time. Somebody said, well, he's trying to politicize the thing. If I was trying to politicize it, I'd have dropped it out before the 2006 elections. I believe I have an obligation to tell the truth to the American people as to the nature of the enemy. And it's unpleasant for some. I fully recognize that after 9/11, in the calm here at home, relatively speaking, caused some to say, well, maybe we're not at war. I know that's a comfortable position to be in, but that's not the truth.Failure in Iraq will cause generations to suffer, in my judgment. Al Qaida will be emboldened. They will say, yes, once again, we've driven the great, soft America out of a part of the region. It will cause them to be able to recruit more. It will give them safe haven. They are a direct threat to the United States.And I'm going to keep talking about it. That's my job as the President, is to tell people the threats we face and what we're doing about it. And what we've done about it is, we've strengthened our homeland defenses. We've got new techniques that we use that enable us to better determine their in—their motives and their plans and plots. We're working with nations around the world to deal with these radicals and extremists. But they're dangerous, and I can't put it any more plainly: They're dangerous. And we will, and I can't put it any more plainly to the American people and to them: We will stay on the offense.It's better to fight them there than here. And this concept about, well, maybe let us kind of just leave them alone, and maybe they'll be all right is naive. These people attacked us before we were in Iraq. They viciously attacked us before we were in Iraq, and they've been attacking ever since. They are a threat to your children, David, and whoever is in that Oval Office better understand it and take measures necessary to protect the American people.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, you've mentioned the potential for Kim Jong Un to 'surprise on the upside.' Can you elaborate on what specific actions or concessions from North Korea would constitute such a surprise, and what would be your immediate response? [SEP] Well, I don't want to give away my negotiating strategy, you understand? But let's just say that if Kim Jong Un came to the table with a serious offer, a real commitment to denuclearization, that would be a big surprise, a very big surprise. And my response would be to listen, to negotiate, to try to make a deal. I'm a dealmaker, that's what I do. And I think we can make a deal with North Korea, a deal that benefits everyone. But it's going to take courage, it's going to take trust, and it's going to take a willingness to compromise. And I'm willing to do all of those things. Are they? We'll see. We'll see what happens.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, can you clarify if this person is simply a follower or if there's more to the story? [SEP] Look, lots of folks follow me on Twitter, okay? We got a call, so I guess he does. People are always reaching out. They wanna see if they can 'do something,' whatever that means. It's not a big deal, just a 'hello.' I get along with everyone, even you guys. Remember when I said I'd be a 'sleeper' on foreign policy? Well, look what's happening. We're working on things, maybe a deal. They'd be smart to make one. I'm good either way. They're not doing so hot, were getting pushed around before I got here. But now, we're not getting played anymore. These countries were taking advantage of us on defense and trade. It's all changing. They know it. I even asked Abe, 'How'd you get away with this for so long?' He said nobody complained! Same with China. I said, 'You charge us nothing, we charge you 45%! What gives?' They just kept raising it, and nobody said anything. But I'm saying something. Next question.
label: Implicit

sentence: President Bush, what specific steps should Africa take to improve its leadership, and how will the U.S. support this transformation? [SEP] Well, I've been to Africa twice as President, and I've seen positive changes. It's about African leaders taking ownership, like President Kufuor in Ghana. We need to support conflict resolution, promote democracy, and ensure aid is tied to good governance and education. That's the key.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the peaceful transfer of power, while you've expressed support, numerous Democrats are boycotting the incoming President's Inauguration. Do you endorse their actions? What message would you convey to encourage a smoother transition? Furthermore, could you share insights from your conversations with the President-elect, specifically whether you attempted to persuade him on key issues like the Affordable Care Act or the DREAMers program, and how successful were those attempts? [SEP] Well, I'm not at liberty to divulge the specifics of my discussions with President-elect Trump. Suffice it to say, they've been civil, sometimes lengthy, and always substantive. Whether I've swayed him is a question best posed to him directly. I've offered my counsel on various matters, both domestic and international. However, given that he won an election opposing many of my initiatives, it's only fitting that he pursues his own vision. I don't anticipate complete alignment. Perhaps, upon assuming office and grappling with the complexities of healthcare or job creation, he might arrive at similar conclusions as I did. But we won't know until he's settled in. His advisors will undoubtedly shape his views, hence the importance of these confirmation hearings. I've emphasized to him the immense responsibility of the job, one that demands a strong team providing sound information and diverse perspectives. Regarding the Inauguration, I'll refrain from commenting on others' decisions. Michelle and I will be there, and thankfully, the weather forecast looks milder than my first Inauguration – that was a real chiller!
label: Deflection

sentence: What's your take on David Cameron? [SEP] I've never actually met the man. And look, it's not really my place to advise the leader of the Conservative Party, or any other party for that matter. It's up to them what they do, and up to him whether he decides to come here or not. But I will say this: let's forget about these two individuals for a moment and focus on the two countries. Even if people strongly disagree with the Iraq situation, for example, at least they understand that we're fighting a battle around the world today. And it's a battle about the values that will shape the 21st century. You don't win those battles by being a fair-weather friend. You don't win by hesitating or withdrawing support when things get tough. You don't win by losing the will to fight when your enemy is determined. Our two countries share values, and that's what's important. The fact that we can both stand here and face tough questions from the press is a testament to that. It's about democracy, freedom of expression, and holding politicians accountable. So, sure, it's easy to attack America and get applause in Europe. But when the dust settles, what matters is that we're fighting for those values. We can debate the mistakes and the issues, but our enemy is watching. They're asking if we're standing up for what we believe in, or if we'll give up when things get difficult. That's a decision for leadership. And it's not just for me and him; it's for everyone in politics. People may criticize politics, but when it's done right, it's about public service. We made a difficult decision, and I still believe it was the right one. History will judge us. But what we represent here today is a better way of life than brutal dictatorship or religious extremism. It's a way of life that people choose when given the chance. And our two nations should be proud to offer that choice to the world. The world needs courage, and this man is a courageous man. Thank you.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, with the UK exempted from the travel ban despite higher COVID numbers than many Schengen nations, and a recent case surge, what justifies this exception? Will you reconsider adding them to the ban list? [SEP] Look, the experts advised me on that one, and we're watching the numbers like hawks. They spiked recently, so yeah, we might have to add them. We might even take some others off the list, who knows? We're keeping a close eye on it.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, to address Mr. Romney's statement, he posits that your greatest foreign policy misstep lies with Iran, suggesting that their acquisition of nuclear weapons is contingent upon your reelection. Your response? [SEP] I shall refrain from directly addressing the assertions made during the Republican debates until such a time as they have formally designated their nominee. However, as I previously stated, an examination of our endeavors to unite the international community against Iran over the past three years reveals consistent, resolute progress in isolating the Iranian regime. This sends an unequivocal message that the global consensus deems their possession of nuclear weaponry as perilous. Is this a facile matter? Certainly not. Any assertion to the contrary is either politically motivated or indicative of a lack of comprehension. Nevertheless, I am confident that both the global community and the Iranian regime are acutely aware of our unwavering commitment to preventing not only nuclear proliferation but also a nuclear arms race in the region, as well as violations of nonproliferation standards that would reverberate worldwide, including in the Asia-Pacific region, where we face analogous challenges with North Korea.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, if you were to choose the second option of the 2 trillion dollar package, would that need to include some form of stimulus, such as a payroll tax extension or the extension of unemployment insurance, for you to sign it? [SEP] Those are both good for the economy. A payroll tax cut put money in the pockets of the average American family and offset some of the rising costs in gasoline and food. American consumers and businesses would benefit from a continuation of that tax cut next year. Unemployment insurance is important because unemployment is still too high. Many people are doing everything they can to find a job, but the market is still tight. We need to make sure that they are able to stay in their homes and support their families, which is important and contributes to the overall economy. We can take a little over a trillion dollars in serious discretionary cuts, meaningful discretionary cuts, and then start building on top of that some cuts in non-health-care mandatory payments, ethanol programs, or how we calculate various subsidies to various industries. That could potentially be layered on. And we could still do something like a tax cut for ordinary families that would end up benefiting the economy as a whole. That is not my preferable option, though. I think about this like a layer cake. You can do the bare minimum, and then you can make some progressively harder decisions to solve the problem more and more. If we're serious about this and everybody is willing to compromise, we can fix this thing for a decade or more. That would be good for the overall business climate and would encourage the American people that Washington actually is willing to take care of its business.
label: General

sentence: Concerning the scandal linking politicians to drug trafficking and paramilitary groups, what is your opinion on the government's handling of the matter? How strong is your support for President Uribe, given the alleged connections between paramilitary leaders and drug trafficking? Will the U.S. demand the extradition of those implicated? [SEP] Our focus is on supporting Colombia's efforts to strengthen its institutions and combat drug trafficking. We believe in a strong, independent judiciary that can investigate these allegations and hold those responsible accountable. President Uribe has committed to that process, and we stand by him in that effort. Justice must be served, and it must be seen to be served fairly and impartially.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Mr. President, and to you Mr. Prime Minister, did you discuss Canada increasing its stimulus? And what will the Canada-U.S. relationship look like in four years regarding the auto sector, the border, and carbon markets? [SEP] Wow, that's a whole laundry list of questions. [] Were you consulting with someone else? Is that--[].
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, what specific benefits will economic security bring to the Korean people? And given your focus on universal values, would the U.S. consider imposing export controls on nations that don't share them? [SEP] Economic security is fundamentally about the well-being of our people. It directly impacts their daily lives. Take, for example, the manufacturing of cars, which relies on semiconductors. Recent water challenges also highlight the critical need for essential materials in both daily life and industrial production. Ensuring a stable supply chain is essential for our citizens and national economy, linking to national and military security. While the WTO once facilitated free trade, the pandemic and the formation of market blocs have introduced risks to the supply chain. The U.S. and Korea, united by democratic values and human rights, must work with like-minded nations to strengthen the supply chain. Our National Security Councils are responsible for addressing this. We aim for closer collaboration to resolve any issues. Moreover, we're prepared to assist each other in the event of financial or foreign exchange market instability, extending to military and economic security. We also plan to negotiate defense item exports to promote cooperation in specific areas. This isn't just words; it's an alliance in action. We're committed to deepening our alliance. While advocating democracy, human rights, and freedom, we seek to include nations with varying values in the pursuit of global peace, encouraging them to embrace these universal principles. Our focus is on building strong solidarity and cooperation among nations that share our values.
label: General

sentence: Q. So did you expect that that would work with Senators Manchin or Sinema—that argument? [SEP] No, here's the thing: There's certain things that are so consequential you have to speak from your heart as well as your head. I was speaking out forcefully on what I think to be at stake. That's what it is.And by the way, no one—no one—forgets who was on the side of King or—versus on—or Bull Connor. No one not—does not. The history books will note it. And what—I was making the case: Don't think this is a freebie. You don't get to vote this way, and then somehow it goes away. This will be—stick with you the rest of your career and long after you're gone.
label: Explicit

sentence: So, to be clear, a deal involving tax cuts for the wealthiest is off the table for now? [SEP] My focus is on the priorities of the American people. We need to ensure that families have the resources they need to thrive. That's where our energy should be directed.
label: General

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. I wonder if I can get you to weigh in on the wisdom of building a mosque a couple of blocks from Ground Zero. We know that the organizers have the constitutional right. What would it say about this country if they were somehow talked out of doing that? And hasn't the Florida minister's threat to burn a couple hundred copies of the Koran, hasn't the threat itself put American lives in danger, sir? [SEP] Well, on the second--on your second question, there's no doubt that when someone goes out of their way to be provocative in ways that we know can inflame the passions of over a billion Muslims around the world, at a time when we've got our troops in a lot of Muslim countries, that's a problem. And it has made life a lot more difficult for our men and women in uniform who already have a very difficult job.With respect to the mosque in New York, I think I've been pretty clear on my position here, and that is, is that this country stands for the proposition that all men and women are created equal, that they have certain inalienable rights--one of those inalienable rights is to practice their religion freely. And what that means is that if you could build a church on a site, you could build a synagogue on a site, if you could build a Hindu temple on a site, then you should be able to build a mosque on the site.Now, I recognize the extraordinary sensitivities around 9/11. I've met with families of 9/11 victims in the past. I can only imagine the continuing pain and anguish and sense of loss that they may go through. And tomorrow we as Americans are going to be joining them in prayer and remembrance. But I go back to what I said earlier: We are not at war against Islam. We are at war against terrorist organizations that have distorted Islam or falsely used the banner of Islam to engage in their destructive acts.And we've got to be clear about that. We've got to be clear about that because if we're going to deal with the problems that Ed Henry was talking about, if we're going to successfully reduce the terrorist threat, then we need all the allies we can get. The folks who are most interested in a war between the United States or the West and Islam are Al Qaida. That's what they've been banking on.And fortunately, the overwhelming majority of Muslims around the world are peace loving, are interested in the same things that you and I are interested in: How do I make sure I can get a good job? How can I make sure that my kids get a decent education? How can I make sure I'm safe? How can I improve my lot in life? And so they have rejected this violent ideology for the most part--overwhelmingly.And so from a national security interest, we want to be clear about who the enemy is here. It's a handful, a tiny minority of people who are engaging in horrific acts and have killed Muslims more than anybody else.The other reason it's important for us to remember that is because we've got millions of Muslim Americans, our fellow citizens, in this country. They're going to school with our kids. They're our neighbors. They're our friends. They're our coworkers. And when we start acting as if their religion is somehow offensive, what are we saying to them?I've got Muslims who are fighting in Afghanistan in the uniform of the United States Armed Services. They're out there putting their lives on the line for us. And we've got to make sure that we are crystal clear, for our sakes and their sakes, they are Americans and we honor their service. And part of honoring their service is making sure that they understand that we don't differentiate between them and us. It's just us.And that is a principle that I think is going to be very important for us to sustain. And I think tomorrow is an excellent time for us to reflect on that.Thank you very much, everybody.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, following up on the MoveOn.org ad, do you believe that such attacks on military leaders undermine public trust in the armed forces, and what steps can be taken to ensure that political discourse remains respectful of those who serve? [SEP] Absolutely, attacks like that erode public trust. It's crucial to remember that these are dedicated individuals putting their lives on the line for our country. While debate on policy is healthy, personal attacks on their character are unacceptable. We need leaders from both parties to set a better example and foster a climate of respect for those who serve. It's about honoring their sacrifice, regardless of political differences.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, the Attorney General's chief of staff has testified that Gonzales knew more about the U.S. attorney firings than he admitted. How can the American people trust an Attorney General who isn't being completely honest? How long does he have to fix this, and can it even be fixed? [SEP] Al Gonzales is a man of integrity and honesty, and he has my complete support. He's cooperating with Congress to uncover the truth. He will testify before Congress and provide truthful testimony. The U.S. attorneys serve at the President's discretion. I appointed them to 4-year terms, and they served those terms. I appreciate their service. It's unfortunate that these hearings have tarnished their reputations. That was not the intention of anyone in my administration. I want to emphasize that there is no credible evidence of any wrongdoing.
label: Deflection

sentence: President, Putin has expressed satisfaction with your response regarding the 'killer' remark. Can you elaborate on your communication with him on this topic? [SEP] He said he's satisfied. End of story.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: President Obama, considering the lingering questions about US involvement in Chile during the 1970s, will your administration pledge complete transparency and provide all relevant documentation to assist ongoing investigations, potentially including an apology for any past wrongdoings? [SEP] The past is complex, and relationships between nations evolve. We're committed to a strong, forward-looking relationship with Chile. We'll consider any requests for information through the appropriate channels, but our primary focus is on strengthening our partnership for the future. We believe in learning from the past, but not being defined by it.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Right here, sir. In your opening remarks, sir, you were--you said about Iran that you were appalled and outraged. What took you so long to say those words? [SEP] Well, I don't think that's accurate. Track what I've been saying. Right after the election, I said that we had profound concerns about the nature of the election, but that it was not up to us to determine what the outcome was. As soon as violence broke out--in fact, in anticipation of potential violence--we were very clear in saying that violence was unacceptable, that that was not how governments operate with respect to their people.So we've been entirely consistent, Major, in terms of how we've approached this. My role has been to say, the United States is not going to be a foil for the ian Government to try to blame what's happening on the streets of Tehran on the CIA or on the White House, that this is an issue that is led by and given voice to the frustrations of the ian people. And so we've been very consistent the first day, and we're going to continue to be consistent in saying, this is not an issue about the United States; this is about an issue of the ian people.What we've also been consistent about is saying that there are some universal principles, including freedom of assembly and freedom of speech, making sure that governments are not using coercion and violence and repression in terms of how they interact with peaceful demonstrators. And we have been speaking out very clearly about that fact.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. Thank you. You said earlier that people in Iraq are sick and tired of the violence. To what extent has the recent Blackwater incident frayed your relations with Prime Minister Maliki and his Government? And why are outfits like Blackwater above the law in Iraq? [SEP] First of all, I have yet to speak to the Prime Minister about this subject. I'll see him in New York next week at the U.N.; I'm confident he'll bring it up. I also appreciate the fact that he's willing to work with the U.S. Government to set up a commission to find out what actually happened. The folks like Blackwater who provide security for the State Department are under rules of engagement. In other words, they have certain rules. And this commission will determine whether or not they violated those rules. And I'm looking forward to finding out what the results are.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. And if I could, on the election, sir—can I——TikTok/Microsoft Corporation  Q. President Trump, on the sale of TikTok, you're basically arguing that the U.S. Government is going to collect a cut from a—of a transaction including two companies, in which it doesn't hold a stake in.That's unprecedented. That's never happened in U.S. history before, and the administration has offered very little explanation about how that's going to work. Can you back your statement up and provide specifics about how that would work? [SEP] Did you say, That's impressive? Did you actually use that term?

sentence: Mr. President, concerning North Korea and the United States, could their relationship evolve similarly to that of the U.S. and Vietnam? [SEP] Pardon?

sentence: Mr. President Bush, regarding trade with Uruguay, what specific flexibilities can your administration offer to advance a trade agreement, and what progress has been achieved today? Also, President Vazquez, did you request President Bush's intervention in the mill plant dispute with Argentina? [SEP] We dedicated considerable time to addressing Uruguay's concerns about market access for certain products. The President raised various trade issues, expressing concerns about quotas on items like cows and sheep. I assured him that I would seriously consider his requests. You might have thought I was joking about blueberries, but I wasn't. Uruguay produces excellent blueberries, and the key question is whether their growers can sell them in the United States. We discussed various produce items, and I emphasized that problems must be put on the table to be solved. We'll help where we can, and if we can't, I'll explain why. I'm also concerned about protectionist tendencies worldwide. Free and fair trade is essential for poverty reduction, so I strongly support completing the Doha round of the WTO. I shared our strategies for advancing the Doha round with President Lula, without betraying any confidences. The United States is prepared to reduce agricultural subsidies, but we need market access for our products. I'm optimistic about reaching a deal. Our trade minister, Susan Schwab, is in Sao Paulo discussing this with her Brazilian counterpart. Regarding your first question, I fully agree with President Bush. We've created a space for experts and ministers to discuss bilateral issues. Uruguay advocates for free trade and lower tariffs and subsidies. We're also exploring progress with the GSP. As for your second question, I haven't discussed the Argentina dispute with President Bush, as we'll be engaging in dialogue with Argentina soon, thanks to the King of Spain's conciliation, to find a friendly resolution to our differences.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, just to be clear, are you saying the National Health Service should be part of trade negotiations? [SEP] Come again? I didn't quite catch that.
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, to clarify, concerning North Korea, are we talking about weeks, months, or years before a decision is made, and what specific intelligence led to the confirmation of North Korea's involvement? On Cuba, what are the primary obstacles preventing a visit, and what steps are being taken to address them? [SEP] We're working expeditiously, but I won't put a specific timeframe on it. As for Cuba, the conditions aren't right for a visit, but I'm hopeful for the future. We're focused on the present, but I anticipate future engagement.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: So, was Syria part of these discussions, or not? [SEP] The discussions involved the broader issue of proliferation.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Mr. President, the conservative newspaper columnist, Robert Novak, recently wrote that in 50 years of covering Washington, he's never seen a President more isolated than you are right now. What do you say to critics like Novak who say that you are more isolated now than Richard Nixon was during Watergate? [SEP] How did he define isolated?

sentence: Q. Why aren't your doctors not with you here today? Where's Dr. Fauci, Dr. Birx? [SEP] Well, Dr. Birx is right outside.Yes, please.

sentence: Q. Do you believe with Dr. Robert Redfield who, earlier this week, said if America doesn't follow public health guidelines, we could be in store for one of the worst falls we've ever faced, from a public health perspective? [SEP] No, I mean, you can't compare it to 1917. That was incredible. That was—that was the worst ever by far. That was—you look at—they lost possibly 100 million people. No, I don't agree with that.But if you look at these numbers, they're coming down very substantially. And I do believe that Americans—many are wearing masks, which is a good thing. Again, some people thought that you shouldn't wear a mask. You know, when this whole thing started, Dr. Fauci, who I like and respect, said don't wear masks, okay? And so did Dr. Redfield. And then, all of a sudden, it was like everybody should wear masks. And that's okay. People can change their mind.But wash your hands, good hygiene—all of those things—I think people are really doing it to a level that they've never done before.And when you look at the numbers, the way the numbers are coming out, I mean, it's very impressive when you see what's happening.By the way, Florida doing well. You see that. And hospitalizations and all—you know, normally you would have had to build more—like we did for the first surge. We've done it right. We closed it up. We had the greatest economy in history. We closed it up. We understand the disease now. Nobody knew. Nobody knew what was hitting us, right? Nobody knew that old people would be very, very susceptible, especially if they have heart and diabetes problems and other problems; that old people would be very susceptible and young people would be extremely good with it. If you look at the percentages, there are a tiny percentage that have problems, especially the big problem.So, no, I think that we're doing very well. We're on our way. And we're also opening up our economy, and our economy is going to set records. And if stupid people aren't elected next year, we're going to have one of the greatest years that we've ever had.Jennifer [Jennifer Jacobs, Bloomberg News], go ahead, please.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Mr. President, in light of the Paris attacks, how will this impact the climate talks? Furthermore, how do you address concerns about convincing developing nations to commit to climate goals, considering Republican resistance? Lastly, can you comment on allegations of intelligence manipulation regarding the ISIL campaign? [SEP] First, on intelligence, I've always demanded unbiased assessments. We need accurate intelligence to make good decisions. I believe our agencies understand this. We'll investigate the CENTCOM allegations thoroughly. I've instructed the relevant officials to get to the truth. Disagreements on interpretation are inevitable, but honesty is paramount. I haven't received overly optimistic reports about Iraq and Syria. As for Paris, we must show resilience. We won't be intimidated. Terrorists can't win if we don't let them. They're simply murderers. We've overcome greater challenges. The G-20, APEC, and ASEAN all stressed the importance of a strong Paris agreement. I'm hopeful. 160 nations have set targets, representing 90% of global emissions. Key elements include differentiation, accountability, transparency, and periodic review. Climate finance is essential to assist developing nations in pursuing clean development. We're progressing towards our $100 billion commitment. Critics argue against unilateral action, but China's commitment has altered the landscape. Supporting countries like India is crucial. Finally, the Paris attacks underscore the need for solidarity. We must not allow fear to dictate our response.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, regarding Israel and Iran, why haven't you visited Israel in three years, despite your pledge to 'have their back'? Furthermore, critics suggest your concern over war-related gas prices is a ploy to push Americans towards renewable fuels. How do you respond? [SEP] Look, does anyone seriously think a President facing reelection wants higher gas prices? It's absurd. My priority is lowering gas prices because they hurt working families. We're pursuing an all-of-the-above energy strategy: increased production, conservation, and clean energy development. We've made progress, reducing oil imports. As for Israel, my commitment isn't measured by a single visit. My actions speak louder than words. I've consistently supported Israel's security.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, reflecting back to 1981, what was your stance regarding Israel's action against the Iraqi nuclear facility? [SEP] Well, that's going back a ways. I must confess, I don't have a precise recollection of my views on that particular incident. My attention was directed towards other pressing issues at that point in time.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. By game changer, you mean U.S. military action? [SEP] By game changer, I mean that we would have to rethink the range of options that are available to us.Now, we're already, as I've said, invested in trying to bring about a solution inside of . Obviously, there are options that are available to me that are on the shelf right now that we have not deployed. And that's a spectrum of options. As early as last year, I asked the Pentagon, our military, our intelligence officials to prepare for me what options might be available. And I won't go into the details of what those options might be, but clearly, that would be an escalation, in our view, of the threat to the security of the international community, our allies, and the United States, and that means that there are some options that we might not otherwise exercise that we would strongly consider.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, before we move onto the border, a quick question about busing. Do you believe it's a feasible method for integrating schools? And how does this relate to the policy you're planning to announce? [SEP] Well, it's been a practice employed for quite some time. I mean, there aren't many alternatives for transporting students to schools. So, it's a practice that's been utilized. In some instances, it's been implemented rather forcefully. And that's part of the equation. But it's certainly a primary means of getting students to schools. I believe if Vice President Biden had answered the question differently, the outcome would have been different. He faced significant criticism on that issue. So, it is certainly a primary method of transporting students to schools.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, just to clarify, is it your position that these unaccompanied minors should be allowed to stay, or will they eventually be deported? [SEP] The decision hinges on individual factors. This young man has a mother waiting for him. It's hard to argue against reuniting him with his family.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, with Mr. Netanyahu openly discussing the Israeli strike in Syria, can you confirm the target? Did the U.S. support the action? And how might this affect the already volatile regional dynamic? [SEP] That's a matter of ongoing intelligence, and I'm not at liberty to discuss it at this time. Next question, please.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: So, this is good for business and the climate, but not something you'd mandate with your signature, correct? [SEP] I'm not sure I followed that. Can you rephrase?
label: Clarification

sentence: President Bush, concerning Colombia, how do you assess the government's response to the allegations of drug trafficking involving politicians and paramilitary groups? Given that many paramilitary leaders are also drug lords, how strong is your support for President Uribe? And will the U.S. push for their extradition? [SEP] I believe in a system where justice is blind, and an independent judiciary investigates all allegations thoroughly. President Uribe shares this commitment. If someone is guilty, they must be held accountable, regardless of their political connections. He assured me that Colombia has an independent court system and strong laws to ensure fair justice. Colombia has faced significant challenges, and the best path to healing is through a fair and impartial justice system.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. I'm from Financial News. My name is Kim—[inaudible]. My question goes to both of you. My first one goes to President Yoon first.During the state visit, you've said that the alliance has strengthened to cutting-edge industries, to cutting-edge science. And also investments in businesses have been some of the outcomes. These are some positives. However, to each individual of the public, how will this have a long-term impact? What will be the direct benefits felt?And to President Biden: In celebration of the 70th anniversary of the R.O.K.-U.S. alliance, I know that the atmosphere is really positive. However, Korean businesses, especially because of the CHIPS Act and the IRA, are on edge.What message can you send to the Korean companies to really make sure and tell them that this is not something to worry about? [SEP] The technology cooperation between the R.O.K. and the U.S., and also in partnerships in cutting-edge industries, in science and technology, was your first question. So that is about really strengthening the competitiveness of our two countries. And it will enhance the productivity and create added value—high added value. These are the types of products that are going to be produced.And from the perspective of the public, for each individual: In that process, they will reap the benefits wide and comprehensive that will stem from these industries and investments in these industries—for example, from job creation, as well.And above all, the future generations will be given the determination and will to take on new challenges and embrace opportunities in our industry so that they can continue to prosper and grow and become more abundant in the future. The reassurance is that it's overwhelmingly in our interests for Korea to do well. No, it is. It's very much in America's interest that Korea do well in the Pacific—very well—because they are one of our most valued partners.And so I think the combination of growing democracies and the democratic institutions, as well as their economies, is overwhelmingly in the benefit of the United States, whether it is in South Korea or it's in Australia, in the deep South Pacific.And so I think that there's a reason—overwhelming reason.Plus, in addition to that, we're increasing the number of student exchanges, access to more information between our folks, educating our people, as well as we're going to be cooperating on everything from space to technology to medicine. And so there's so many opportunities we have.And I don't think we—at least we don't—and I don't think, so far, most of the South Korean companies believe that there's somehow a U.S. effort to slow them down, prevent their growth, or anything like that. We'd like to see them grow. And I mean that sincerely.It's overwhelmingly in the U.S. interest for South Korea to do very well economically. It's overwhelmingly in our interest because it has——And lastly, you know, I think we underestimate the example that South Korea sets. Here you have a nation that is significant, but is not a nation of 2-, 3-, 400,000 people, making the kind of changes it's making.It gives other smaller nations hope to believe that if they have democratic institutions and commitment and impact on industries that in fact are the cutting-edge industries—new sciences and technology, including AI and other things—that there's a future for them. And I think that's what this is about.And so we view South Korea's economic growth as a benefit to the United States, as well as freedom around the world.Thank you all so very much. Appreciate it.
label: Explicit

sentence: Prime Minister, regarding Syria, what's your assessment of the impact of reduced U.S. involvement, and what's your plan following the Reyhanli bombing? [SEP] First, Eric Holder has my full support. He's doing a great job. Now, Syria. Instead of focusing on potential negatives, let's look at the opportunities. We're working to raise international awareness and action. Turkey is committed to this, and we believe the U.S. is too. Our goal is a rapid democratic transition to prevent further loss of life. This requires a collective effort from all who value democracy, and we'll continue to pursue it.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, with all due respect, Mr. Ledgett's suggestion regarding amnesty for Edward Snowden has sparked considerable debate. Considering his position within the NSA, his comments carry weight. Could you elaborate on your administration's stance on this matter, and under what specific conditions, if any, would you entertain the possibility of a plea agreement or amnesty? Furthermore, how do you reconcile the concerns of those who believe Snowden's actions were justified in light of potential government overreach? [SEP] Well, I appreciate the question, but as you know, Mr. Snowden's case is currently before the courts, and he faces serious charges. It wouldn't be appropriate for me to comment directly on the specifics of his situation at this time. However, I can say that the issues raised by the Snowden disclosures are incredibly important. We need to strike a balance between protecting our national security and safeguarding civil liberties. The way these disclosures were handled, however, caused significant damage to our intelligence capabilities and diplomatic efforts. While it's vital to have this conversation, it's equally important to acknowledge the harm that has been done. Ultimately, the courts will decide Mr. Snowden's fate, and we will respect their decision.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. What is he recommending to you in terms of dealing with the latest strikes on Saudi Arabia and the response?And then, secondly, you announced new sanctions on Iran. Secretary Mnuchin said that this affects the last available funds for that regime. Have we now exhausted sanctions in regards to Iran? [SEP] Well these are the strongest sanctions ever put on a country. We are at a level of sanction that is far greater than ever before with respect to Iran. Today we did Central Bank as you know. And we'll see. We'll see.They're having a lot of problems not only with us; they're having problems within their own country. And I think they have a lot of self-made problems.We are by far the strongest military in the world. Going into Iran would be a very easy decision. As I said before it'd be very easy. The easiest thing. Most people thought I would go in within 2 seconds but plenty of time. Plenty of time.In the meantime they have a lot of problems within Iran. Iran could be a great country could be a rich country. But they are choosing to go a different way. There'll be a point at which they'll be very sorry for that choice. But I think I'm showing great restraint. A lot of people respect it; some people don't. Some people say Oh you should go in immediately. And other people are so thrilled at what I'm doing. And I don't do it for anybody; I do it for what's good for the United States what's good for our allies. And it's working out really very well.As far as Robert is concerned he's—Robert maybe you could stand up? Robert O'Brien is done a fantastic job for us with hostage negotiations. I think we can say that there has never been anybody that has done better than you and I as a combination. We've brought many people home and we brought them home quickly. Speed is a very important thing I find with hostages. It's really something.I had dinner the other night with the Warmbier family an incredible family—the whole family and some of Otto's friends in addition to the family. We had 25 people over on Saturday night. And we did that dinner in Otto—really in Otto's honor. And it was a beautiful thing. It was a beautiful thing.The First Lady and I it was very—you know it was very touching and really very beautiful. We talked about Otto. And I will tell you that people should have moved faster. And Robert and I were talking about that. Should have moved faster. He was there for a long time.You've got to move fast. With hostages you have to move fast. All of a sudden it gets very hard for the other side to do anything. And sometimes it's just too late. In the case of Otto it was very late. We got him home but he was in horrible horrible condition. What happened to him was actually incredible and just horrible.But you have to move fast. Robert and I have been really successful. And the reason I know him so well—I actually work hard on hostages I think he would say. I think most Presidents wouldn't do that but I do. These are great—I guess in almost all cases—American lives. And we help other people also. We've also helped other countries with their hostage situation where we have some strength that they don't.But these are great people. And we get them home. We got them home from North Korea as you know. And we got them home from a lot of different locations. Egypt—we got them home. We got them home from many different locations. Turkey. President Erdogan was very good. And we got a hostage home who—our great pastor who everyone in this room knows and loves.But we've had tremendous success. And what's surprised me I didn't know too many people knew Robert. And when it came time to pick somebody for the position—it's a very critical time—I had so many people—I shouldn't say this in front of Robert he'll be embarrassed but I had so many people that called me and they recommended Robert O'Brien. So I think he's going to do a great job.And he was here—I can tell you this—he started about 12 minutes after he was chosen. He sat in with us. And he's very much involved now on what we're doing.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. But specifically, do you believe Secretary Azar is doing a good job? [SEP] He's working hard, I know that. Everyone in my administration is working tirelessly for the American people. We're a team.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. What about the previous phone call you had with Kim Jong Un? Have you had phone calls—[inaudible]? [SEP] Yes, but I don't want to discuss it. But we did is we've had numerous discussions. We've had very important relationships established at Mike's level and other levels. In fact, a couple of people are here from, as you know, from North Korea. They're in the room. We have a few people in the back also, in the room.So when we went into this final agreement, very importantly, we really didn't go in cold. We went in with tremendous relationship and tremendous knowledge. And I think that's why we got it done.So I'm going to head back. I don't know about you folks, but it's been a long time since I've taken it easy. So now we can take it a little bit easy, and then the work begins again. And I appreciate everybody being here. I hope we've answered your questions. And thank you very much. And, sort of, congratulations to everybody, because this is, really—to me it's a very important event in world history.
