And to be really true to myself, I have to add, I want to get it completed. So Mike, our whole team has to get to work and get it completed. Because otherwise, we've done a good job. But if you don't the ball over the goal line, it doesn't mean enough. Okay?So thank you, and, sort of, congratulations to everybody in the room. Thank you very much. Appreciate it. Thank you.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. But what about in the White House? What about in the White House, sir? You've got a lot White House staff. Some have been talking about leaving. General Kelly has been rumored to be leaving. Is he? [SEP] Well, that's okay. But no, people leave. People leave.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, concerning the Kodak pharmaceutical initiative, the SEC's investigation is raising questions. Can you assure the American people that there was no impropriety in the arrangements made? [SEP] Honestly, I'm not privy to all the details. It's a complex deal, but the goal is to bring manufacturing back to America. We're looking into the concerns, and we'll have more to say when we have all the facts.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Mr. President, thank you. Since General Pace made his comments that got a lot of attention about homosexuality, we haven't heard from you on that issue. Do you, sir, believe that homosexuality is immoral? [SEP] I will not be rendering judgment about individual orientation. I do believe the don't ask, don't tell policy is good policy.Sammon [Bill Sammon, Washington Times], yes.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Mr. President, concerning the allegations against Postmaster General DeJoy regarding campaign finance, would you say you are fully informed about the situation and its potential implications? [SEP] Honestly, I'm not deeply versed in the matter. I caught a headline this morning, but beyond that, I'd need more information. He's a respected figure, apparently enjoyed bipartisan backing. I'll get up to speed soon enough. I just saw it this morning, like you folks.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. You've just spoken about some of the deals that you've sealed here, about the importance of exports--your own goal of doubling exports to your job strategy. At the same time, you said there needs to be further adjustment in the exchange rate and the RMB is undervalued. To what extent does China's depressing of its currency affect your ability to grow jobs in this country and lower the unemployment rate? [SEP] Well, I think that it is important for us to look at the entire economic relationship, and the currency issue is one part of it.The first time I met President Hu was in April of 2009. And this was the first G-20 summit that I attended, when we were in the midst of the worst financial crisis that we had experienced since the 1930s. And even as we were trying to stabilize the financial system, what was absolutely clear was that we couldn't go back to a system in which the United States was borrowing massively, consuming massively, but not producing and selling to the rest of the world, creating these huge imbalances that helped contribute to the crisis. And that's why we pushed and why the G-20 adopted a framework that called for rebalancing the world economy.Now, that gives us some responsibilities. We've got to save more in this country. We've got to cut back on these huge levels of debt both in the private sector, but also in the public sector. It also means that there are structural reforms that we have to undergo to make ourselves more competitive in the world economy. So making sure that we have the best education system in the world, that we're producing more engineers than lawyers; making sure that we have a handle on our fiscal problems; making sure that we've got a world-class infrastructure: Those are all important parts of us being competitive and being able to export.It does also mean, though, that we have a level playing field when it comes to our trading partners. And so with respect to China, what President Hu and myself and our delegations have discussed is how do we make sure that, in fact, our trading relationship is fair and a win-win situation as opposed to a win-lose situation.Some of that has to do with issues completely unrelated to currency. For example, we're making progress on making sure that the Government procurement process in China is open and fair to American businesses. And we've made progress as a consequence of this state visit.Some of it has to do with intellectual property protection. So we were just in a meeting with business leaders, and Steve Ballmer of Microsoft pointed out that their estimate is that only 1 customer in every 10 of their products is actually paying for it in China. And so can we get better enforcement, since that is an area where America excels--intellectual property and high-value-added products and services.And the Chinese Government has, to its credit, taken steps to better enforce intellectual property. We've got further agreement as a consequence of this state visit. And I think President Hu would acknowledge that more needs to be done.But the currency issue is a part of the problem. The RMB is undervalued. The Chinese Government has intervened very forcefully in the currency markets. They've spent $200 billion just recently, and that's an indication of the degree to which it's still undervalued. President Hu has indicated he's committed to moving towards a market-based system. And there has been movement, but it's not as fast as we want. And what I've said to President Hu--and I firmly believe this--is not only will U.S. businesses be able to export more to China if we have a market-based currency, but it will also be good for China and President Hu's agenda of expanding domestic demand. Because if the RMB is worth more, that means they can buy more products and services, and that will contribute to China having greater purchasing power and a higher standard of living.So this is something that can be a win-win. President Hu's concerned understandably about how rapid this transition takes and the disruptions that may occur in its export sector. But I'm confident that it's the right thing to do, and my hope and expectation is, is that President Hu's resolve will lead to a fully market-based currency program that will allow more effective trade between our two countries.Spokesman for [inaudible]--from the Xinhua News Agency.
label: Deflection

sentence: President Bachelet's leadership in Chile is commendable, but how can the US effectively support democratic values and human rights in Latin America, especially in countries with less democratic governance? [SEP] We believe in leading by example. Our relationship with Chile, a strong democracy with a robust economy, demonstrates the benefits of partnership and shared values. We'll continue to support democratic institutions and civil society organizations throughout the region, encouraging reforms and promoting good governance.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. And my final question: Because you're heading to Poland tomorrow, do you think that getting a firsthand look at the effects of this war on these millions of Ukrainians who have fled their country could change the way that you might respond? [SEP] I don't think so, because I've been to many, many war zones. I've been in refugee camps. I've been in war zones for the last 15 years. And it's devastating. And what—the thing you look at the most is you see these young children, you see children without parents that are in those camps or in—or refugees. You see women and husbands—men and women who are completely lost and have no—you see the look—that blank look on their face, that absolute feeling of: My God, where am I? What's going to happen to me?And so it—what it will do, it will reinforce my commitment to have the United States make sure we are a major piece of dealing with the relocation of all those folks, as well as humanitarian assistance needed both inside and outside .For example, this is not something that Poland or Romania or Germany should carry on their own. This is an international responsibility. And the United States, as the leader—one of the leaders in the international community, has an obligation to be engaged—to be engaged and do all we can to ease the suffering and pain of innocent women and children, and men, for that matter, throughout and those who have made it across the border.I plan on attempting to see those folks, as well as I hope I'm going to be able to see—I guess I'm not supposed to say where I'm going, am I? [] But anyway, I hope I get to see a lot of people. []Markus [Markus Becker] with Der Spiegel.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, after so many years and so much sacrifice in Afghanistan, can you honestly say that the outcome justifies the cost, considering the persistent challenges of corruption and instability? And President Karzai, do you still attribute much of the corruption to foreign influence, and are you fully committed to stepping down after the next election? [SEP] Let's be clear about why we went into Afghanistan in the first place. We were attacked. We had to respond. We decimated Al Qaeda. That was the mission. We achieved it. Now, nation-building is a different story. Did we get everything we wanted? No. But we created an opportunity for a more stable Afghanistan. And that's progress. As for corruption, it's a problem everywhere. We're working with the Afghan government to address it. They have to take responsibility. We are not going to stay there forever. It is up to the Afghan people.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President—[inaudible]—Valentinovna, Sputnik News Agency. Have you discussed the issue of possible inspections to North Korea's nuclear sites during your negotiations? [SEP] I'm having trouble hearing you. Where exactly are you reporting from?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. Larry Kudlow, earlier today, said that the V-shaped recovery is showing signs of moderating. Do you think, given what we're seeing with the increase in cases, that the recovery could be in jeopardy at all, the economic recovery? [SEP] I don't think so. I think the recovery has been very strong. We've set record job numbers. We've set record numbers. Whether it's a pure V or a little bit less than that, I think it's going to be very good.If, therapeutically, we come up with some answers very quickly, which I think we will, then you're going to have a tremendous recovery. Likewise, with the vaccines, if you do that by the end of the year, that's ahead of schedule—substantially ahead of schedule. And it's ahead of anything that's ever taken place, in terms of vaccines, before.So I think if those things happen—if just one of those events happen, you'll go right back into that V, and I think you're probably in the V anyway.I really do believe a lot of the Governors should be opening up States that they're not opening, and we'll see what happens with them. But a lot will have to do with the fact that, therapeutically, I think you're going to have some great answers, vaccine-wise, likewise.Yes, please. Go ahead, in the back.
label: Explicit

sentence: President Bush, what steps will the U.S. take to ensure accountability for Colombian politicians implicated in drug trafficking and paramilitary activity, and to what extent do you still support President Uribe? [SEP] We support a system where accusations are thoroughly investigated by an independent judiciary, and those found guilty are held accountable. That's the system President Uribe supports, and that's the kind of justice we believe in.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, just to be absolutely certain, concerning the Senkaku Islands, are you saying unequivocally that the U.S. military would defend them against Chinese aggression? And isn't this just another 'red line' scenario, potentially undermining U.S. credibility if not enforced, as we saw with Syria? Also, regarding North Korea, is your mention of them a direct warning against further nuclear tests? And Prime Minister Abe, in light of the West's failure to deter Russia in Ukraine, do you still have faith in President Obama's assurances about your security? Thank you, Mr. President. [SEP] Remind me, what was the specific question about North Korea again?
label: Clarification

sentence: President Bush, given the protectionist forces at play in your government, how adaptable can your administration be in forging a trade agreement with Uruguay? What outcomes have been achieved today? President Vazquez, did you request President Bush's involvement in the disagreements between Uruguay and Argentina concerning the paper mill projects? [SEP] President Bush: We dedicated considerable time to addressing Uruguay's concerns regarding market access for specific products. The President raised various trade-related issues, expressing his belief that quotas on items such as cows and sheep were unfair. I assured him that I would give his requests due consideration. You may have thought I was joking about blueberries, but I wasn't. It turns out that Uruguay produces exceptional blueberries. The fundamental question is whether Uruguayan blueberry growers will be able to sell their products in the United States. We discussed a range of produce, and I emphasized that problems can only be resolved if they are brought to the table. I pledged to provide assistance where possible and to explain the reasons why if assistance was not feasible. I am concerned about protectionist tendencies, both within our own country and globally. I believe that a world characterized by free and fair trade is more likely to address poverty. Therefore, I strongly support the completion of the Doha round of the WTO. I shared our strategies for advancing the Doha round with the President. I spent considerable time with President Lula, who was highly interested in our discussions, and I shared our conversations with him. I did not betray any confidences, of course, but I discussed the need to advance the Doha round. The United States is fully prepared to reduce agricultural subsidies, as I explained to the President. We simply want to ensure market access for our products. That is what I told President Lula, the Europeans, and the President. I am optimistic that we can reach an agreement. Our trade minister, Susan Schwab, has remained in Sao Paulo to continue discussions with her Brazilian counterpart, all with the aim of making progress toward a complex but necessary deal. President Vazquez: In response to the first question, I fully agree with President Bush's remarks. We have established a framework, starting with this meeting, where our experts and ministers will discuss and make progress on bilateral relationship issues. Regarding the general multilateral situation, Uruguay has consistently advocated for free trade and the reduction of tariffs and subsidies that impede the sale of our significant cultural products. We have also explored the possibility of advancing the GSP, particularly on certain issues that will be considered in the coming weeks. As for the second part of your question, I have not discussed the issues we have with Argentina with President Bush, primarily because we will be engaging in dialogue between the two governments in a few weeks, thanks to the conciliation efforts of His Majesty, the King of Spain, to find an amicable resolution. We will strive to reach an understanding and resolve the unfortunate differences we have with our Argentine brethren.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Would you concede that a mistake was made? [SEP] I'll let the pundits debate that. What I will say is, being in the sixth year, you learn to roll with the punches. I've had my time in the spotlight, times when everyone wanted a piece of me, and times when things were tough. It all evens out. The key is to stay focused on the real goal: getting things done. Next question, please.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, critics argue that engaging in negotiations with Republicans on spending caps is a dangerous game, potentially leading to a recession. Are you willing to risk the economic stability of the country for the sake of a deal, especially considering the potential impact on social programs? [SEP] Let me be clear: I am not going to let Republicans hold the American economy hostage. We are willing to negotiate, but we will not compromise on our values. We will protect Social Security, Medicare, and other essential programs that working families rely on. We are also committed to fiscal responsibility, and we believe we can find common ground with Republicans on ways to cut wasteful spending. However, we will not agree to any cuts that harm the middle class or undermine our economic recovery. We are confident that we can reach a bipartisan agreement that is fair, responsible, and protects the interests of all Americans.
label: Implicit

sentence: Sir, after all that's come out, can Paul Wolfowitz still lead the World Bank effectively? [SEP] First off, I think everyone acted in good faith here. I hate that it's come to this. I admire Paul Wolfowitz, his heart, and how much he cares about helping the poor. The board's meeting right now. All I can tell you is, Paul Wolfowitz wants what's best for the Bank and making sure it focuses on things that matter: human suffering. I applaud his vision; I respect him a lot. And like I said, I hate that it's come to this.
label: Deflection

sentence: So, when's that announcement coming? And what's your take on how Asian countries are doing? [SEP] Well, some are doing good, some aren't, you know how it is. But some are making headway. And when they get to the number we all agree on – they know it, we know it – we'll open things up. And some are really moving fast. We're hoping to open things up as soon as we can. Next question.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: With respect to the crisis in Ukraine, is Germany pulling its weight, especially regarding military support and the Nord Stream 2 pipeline? [SEP] Germany is a totally reliable ally. They're one of our most important partners in the world. They've been a leading financial supporter of Ukraine. The United States and Germany are united. We are the country that contributes a great share of financial support to Ukraine.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Regarding Afghanistan, could you elaborate on the specific requests you made to him concerning the situation and the presence of U.S. troops? [SEP] Actually, he inquired about Afghanistan, expressing his hope that we can maintain peace and security. I responded that it significantly depends on him. He indicated his willingness to assist on Afghanistan, though I won't delve into specifics now, as well as on Iran and other matters. In return, we outlined our objectives for bringing stability and economic or physical security to the people of Syria and Libya. These discussions took place.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Following up on Vice President Biden's remarks about a 30% failure rate, can you provide some clarity on the topic of that discussion and whether you share his perspective on the likelihood of success? [SEP] Honestly, I don't recall the specifics of that particular conversation. But the broader point is this: we're facing unprecedented challenges. We're going to try a lot of things, and not everything is going to work perfectly. That's just the reality of the situation.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, given the inherent volatility of presidential approval ratings, how can the world be confident that your vision for American leadership will persist beyond your current term in office? [SEP] I'm not worried about the next election. I'm worried about making this country great again. We're laying the foundation for long-term success. The American people will see the results, and they'll know we're on the right track.
label: Dodging

sentence: Do you agree with Mr. Clapper's statement that Qadhafi will likely win, and should he be reprimanded for saying that publicly? [SEP] He was just giving a realistic view of the military situation. It's obvious Qadhafi has more weapons. That's not policy. Let me be clear: my policy, as President, is that Qadhafi is wrong. Libyans want to be free, and we will work with the opposition and other countries to get rid of Qadhafi.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. Yes, I just wanted to ask you about the WTO's recent ruling against the United States over $200 billion in tariffs on China. Should the U.S. remain part of the WTO? [SEP] Well, I have real questions about it. Look, the U.S.—we just won a seven-and-a-half-billion-dollar lawsuit, which—nobody used to sue before I came along, you know—or they used to lose them every single time. Now they haven't been losing them.But we're getting reports on the WTO. It's not good. Never been good to us. The WTO, as far as I'm concerned, was created to suck money and jobs out of the United States to the benefit of and other countries—that's what my opinion is—whether it was created or it just turned out to be that way.But the World Trade Organization has been not good for the United States. It's been good for everybody else, but it's not been good. It was a method, in my opinion, of taking advantage of the United States. So we're looking into what happened, and we'll let—we'll get back to you fast.
label: General

sentence: Sir, shouldn't all governors be encouraging mask use? Is that something you would push for? [SEP] Well, each governor has their own approach, you know? Some are big on masks, some aren't. I think it's up to them. We've given them the data, the facts, everything we know. They have their own information too. But look, if you want to wear a mask, wear it. I carry one, I've worn one. When I'm in a hospital, or close to people, I believe in it. It's a good idea.
label: General

sentence: Q. ——or at least other leaders within the Church? [SEP] We're in the process of doing that. I think it's horrible what they're doing. I mean, they're playing the religious card. And it's frankly—you're talking about Catholics. That's a very major religion in our country.I don't know—Chris, do you have anything to say about it? I think it's obvious what they're doing. So, you know, she'll be strong, she'll be tough, and she'll stand up for what she believes in. . And she went through—just like I did, 4 years ago, in terms of litigation of different things—she went through it before and did very well.Rudy, what do you think? I think the article in the New York Times today reveals a very strong anti-Catholic bias. I mean, it says in the article that Catholicism and the American ethos can't be—contradict each other.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, you promised a new tone in Washington. Yet, you recently accused Democrats of supporting terrorists. What's different now? [SEP] The election is over, and the Democrats won; that's what's changed. We'll work together for the next two years to accomplish great things for the country. The Democrats need to decide how they'll conduct themselves. I haven't spoken with the leadership yet, but we'll begin consultations with them shortly.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. So currently, the only way to enforce this international norm is militarily and even giving us—the Asad regime extra time would not achieve your goals? [SEP] What I'm saying, Major, is that so far, what we've seen is a escalation by the Asad regime of chemical weapons use.You'll recall that several months ago, I said we now say with some confidence that at a small level Asad has used chemical weapons. We not only sent warnings to Asad, but we demarched, meaning we sent a strong message through countries that have relationships with Asad, that he should not be doing this. And rather than hold the line, we ended up with what we saw on August 21. So this is not as if we haven't tested the proposition that the guy—or at least generals under his charge—can show restraint when it comes to this stuff. And they've got one of the largest stockpiles in the world.But I want to emphasize that we continue to consult with our international partners. I'm listening to Congress. I'm not just doing the talking. And if there are good ideas that are worth pursuing then I'm going to be open to it.I will take last question. Tangi, AFP [Tangi uemener, Agence France-Presse].
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, a final question for the road? [SEP] As long as it's not another one of your typical zingers, I suppose. []
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, Iran has stated they'll rejoin nuclear talks by November's end. How will you gauge their sincerity? Furthermore, what repercussions await Iran if they persist in attacking U.S. forces, such as the recent drone strikes in Syria? [SEP] Those are, in effect, two distinct considerations. Firstly, the question of rejoining the JCPOA. That hinges on – hence my discussions with our allies in Rome, who were original signatories – reversing the demonstrably poor decision made by President Trump when he withdrew. That's one facet. Its resolution will depend on their actions and the resolve of our allies to enforce economic consequences should they fail to return to the agreement. Secondly, regarding responses to actions against U.S. interests, be they drone strikes or otherwise, we will respond, and we will continue to do so. Cecilia Vega, ABC. Apologies, it's difficult to recognize you with the mask. Climate Change…
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: What are the precise preconditions for a potential meeting with the North Korean leader, and do you have confidence in his ability to satisfy them? [SEP] I never jump to conclusions about what someone will or won't do based on their public statements. Time will tell. If he makes a solid commitment to discuss his nuclear arsenal, then I would consider a meeting. That commitment must include a serious discussion about denuclearization and reducing tensions in the region. My Secretary of State and other advisors would negotiate a framework for the meeting beforehand. I'm not going to repeat the errors of the past by giving him international legitimacy without seeing tangible progress. I need to see concrete details. I'm not ruling out a meeting with North Korea entirely, but my team would need to engage with their counterparts first to establish clear objectives and expectations.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, could you elaborate on the underlying principles that make this strategy effective, in your opinion? [SEP] Look, the story is simple. People keep saying, 'Just cut a deal!' But they lack the courage and the foresight to understand that we can't keep hemorrhaging half a trillion dollars annually. It's unsustainable! Someone had to step up. Obama should've done it. Biden, Sleepy Joe, should've done it. Bush, Clinton, the whole lot of them! They all should've acted. But I'm the one doing it. And let me tell you something else: North Korea? That mess should've been resolved ages ago. I'm tackling it all. I'm handling things that should've been dealt with long before I arrived.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Sir, could you repeat the question? I did not hear it well. [SEP] Come again?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Is the Republican Party in the desperate straits that Arlen Specter seems to think it is? [SEP] You know, politics in America changes very quick, and I'm a big believer that things are never as good as they seem and never as bad as they seem. You're talking to a guy who was 30 points down in the polls during a primary in Iowa, so I never--I don't believe in crystal balls. I do think that our administration has taken some steps that have restored confidence in the American people that we're moving in the right direction, and that simply opposing our approach on every front is probably not a good political strategy.Ed Henry [Cable News Network].
label: General

sentence: Q. You've had some differences with your Defense Secretary, Mark Esper. Do you have confidence in his leadership there? [SEP] Mark Yesper? Did you call him Yesper?
label: Dodging

sentence: Do you foresee any possibility of working together? [SEP] Check back with me in approximately eight years. That's one plus seven, for clarity. Ideally, yes, because bipartisanship is appealing. However, their current strategy is pure obstruction. They're against tax cuts that would benefit our nation. That's a difficult position to defend, and I anticipate some Democrats will ultimately support the tax cuts.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. To be clear, are you advocating for a hard Brexit? [SEP] Is it causing heartbreak, perhaps?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, with all due respect, isn't this just a way to deflect from the real issue? You're talking about differences when people are worried about similarities – the potential for widespread harm. Why not address those concerns directly instead of focusing on distinctions? [SEP] Look, I understand the anxiety. People are scared, and that's understandable. But fear shouldn't drive policy. We need to be rational, informed, and strategic. We're not downplaying the seriousness of the situation, but we're also not going to engage in fear-mongering. We're focused on solutions, on protecting the American people, and on getting the economy back on track. That's what matters.
label: General

sentence: Q. I'm sorry.[At this point, the reporter asked a question in Portuguese, which was translated by an interpreter as follows.]Madam President, Brazil views itself as a global player and leader in the world scene, and the U.S. sees Brazil as a regional player. How do you reconcile or strike a balance between those two visions? [SEP] Well, I'm actually going to answer in part the question you just asked the President. We view Brazil not as a regional power, but as a global power. If you think about the preeminent economic forum for coordinating between major economies, the G-20, Brazil is a major voice in that. The negotiations that are going to be taking place in Paris around climate change can only succeed with Brazil as a key leader. And the announcements that have been made today about their goals on renewable energy are—is indicative of Brazil's leadership.Brazil is a major global player. And I told President Dilma last night that the United States, as powerful as we are and as interested as we are in solving a whole range of international issues, recognizes, we can't do it alone. On issues like global health, we're not going to succeed unless we're working with Brazil and other major countries so that we can identify where there might be the outbreak of a disease, how we prevent it from turning into a pandemic. If we want to be successful on climate change, on countering terrorism, on making sure that we are reducing extreme poverty around the world, all the major countries have to be involved in that process. And Brazil we consider to be an absolutely indispensable partner in these efforts.With respect to trust, I will say that and I have had an excellent relationship since she took office. I trust her completely. She's always been very candid and frank with me about the interests of the Brazilian people and how we can work together. She's delivered on what she's promised. When we met in Panama, we discussed, for example, the defense cooperation agreements that were just mentioned. She got those through Congress. As somebody who knows something about Congresses—[]—that—I know that's never easy. So for her to use political capital in order to get that done, I think, is indicative of the kind of reliable partner that she is.And so we believe that this meeting that we've had this week builds on a series of steps that have continued to deepen cooperation between our two countries. There are still going to be differences occasionally, but that's true with every one of our close friends and allies. No country is going to have identical interests. There will always be some frictions. But our common values, the strong people-to-people relations that we have, the fact that we are the largest countries in the hemisphere with similar histories—I think all that means that we should be very strong partners for years to come. Well, I believe that part of my answer was given by , and I'd like to thank him for that. But I'd like to still make the following remark. Countries do go through crises and difficulties. It's just natural. And the fact that countries experience difficulties and/or crises should not entail a lesser role for any country, especially because a country can only be said to be a great country if it is able to successfully overcome difficulties. That applies to countries, to people. It applies to everything in life: one's braveness to overcome difficulties, challenges, and face up to them and still sustain and uphold the commitment towards one's people and country.It also applies to relations with countries such as the U.S. and the rest of the world. These are essential relations. I think Brazil and the U.S. have a great deal in common. We are two countries that have a hallmark in our history, something that we actually had to fight to overcome. I'm talking about the blemish of slavery. We have large Black populations in our two countries. We are countries marked by a very significant ethnic and multicultural variety in our population makeup. And that is a major asset, the wonderful heritage in our population. The same is true for the U.S.We are also two strong democracies. Brazil, just as is the case of the United States—and I even congratulated for having overcome the crisis that struck this country back in 2008 and 2009, and likewise, Brazil will overcome the effects of the current crisis that strikes Brazil. And we will do so very surefootedly, very decisively, with great—a great sense of commitment.More than that, we will not only resume growth, but we will uphold and ensure continuity of all of the gains and achievements that we have established in the past 12 years—in the course of the past 12 years. And we will make sure that these gains multiply into the future. We truly want to build a predominantly middle class country. I think the efforts to reduce inequality are a major gain, and we must fight to preserve those gains.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, regarding your previous statement about potentially collaborating with Governor Romney, could you provide a concrete timeline for when this meeting might occur, and perhaps elaborate on specific policy areas where you envision common ground? [SEP] Well, things move quickly, you know? A week feels like a month in politics. We haven't nailed down the specifics just yet. The Governor's entitled to some downtime, and frankly, so am I. But I fully expect we'll connect before the year's out. He's got some ideas, some experience, that could be useful. We'll see. It's all about what's best for the country.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, would you be willing to sign an immigration deal that doesn't include funding for the border wall? Or is that a red line for you? President Trump. No. No. Q. No? [SEP] The wall is a must. We need it for security. We need it for safety. We need it for stopping the drugs. I believe that the people in the room, both Democrat and Republican, will come up with a solution to the DACA problem and maybe, beyond that, immigration as a whole. But any solution has to include the wall, because without the wall, it all doesn't work. Look at Israel. They put up the wall; they solved the problem. We need the wall. We have to have the wall for security purposes. Security is number one. And so the answer is, have to have the wall.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Going into these talks with Kim Jong Un, do you have a clear objective of what you want to get out of them? [SEP] I have a clear objective. But I have to say, Eliana, that it's going to be something that will always be spur of the moment. You don't know. You know, this has not been done before at this level. This is a leader who really is an unknown personality. People don't know much about him. I think that he's going to surprise on the upside, very much on the upside. We'll see. But never been done. Never been tested. Many people—world leaders—I'm talking about world leaders that have been right next to him have never met him.So we're going in with a very positive spirit, I think, very well prepared. I think—and by the way, we have worked very well with their people. They have many people right now in Shanghai; our people have been—in Singapore. Our people have been working very, very well with the representatives of .So we're going in with a very positive attitude, and I think we're going to come out fine. But I've said it many times: Who knows? Who knows? May not. May not work out. It's a good chance it won't work out. There's probably an even better chance that it will take a period of time. It will be a process.
label: General

sentence: Sir, could you elaborate on the nature of the threats you've made to Pakistan if they don't cooperate in apprehending him? [SEP] I'm not at liberty to divulge the precise details of our private conversations. Suffice it to say, we've made our expectations abundantly clear. Moving on.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Mr. Prime Minister, you are the only major world leader not to have a sitdown or a planned sitdown with Kim Jong Un. You hinted in your address today that you would be willing to do so on the matter of abductees. Do you have any plans currently to do so? And would it be focused solely on abductees, or would you be willing to have a separate denuclearization discussion with Kim Jong Un directly without the United States? Thank you.Prime Minister Abe. Of course, on the issue of abduction, we have to resolve this problem. With Abe administration, this is of the highest priority. And if anything contributes to that resolution, if the talk leads to the solution of the problem between U.S. and North Korea or between Japan and North Korea, the meetings we wish to have on the issue of abduction in the final analysis, Chairman Kim Jong Un and between me—between Japan and North Korea, problem has to be solved. Of course, for Japan, missile issue and nuclear issue—very important.Nuclear issue, missile issue, regarding these issues, at the U.S. and North Korea summit meeting, first and foremost, I'm hopeful for the progress. And then, on the issue of abduction, we will liaise—we will collaborate with the U.S. and international community. And Japan, ourselves, must talk directly with North Korea in the final analysis. I am determined about that.Mr. Hayashi?Abduction of Japanese Citizens by North Korea/Release of U.S. Citizens Detained in North Korea  Q. Thank you, Prime Minister Abe. I have question to Prime Minister as well as President Trump. Starting with Prime Minister, you have already mentioned to a certain degree on the abduction issue. In order to hold Japan-North Korea summit, the premise is that you need to obtain results for the abduction issue. What kind of concrete pathway are you envisaging to hold the summit meeting?In your meeting with President Trump today, have you asked President Trump to raise the question of abduction at the U.S.-North Korea summit meeting in Singapore?Next is my question to President Trump. You have—Kim Jong Un has maintained this position that the abduction issue is something that already had been resolved. So what kind of explanation has been given to the United States on the abduction issue in the North Korea to U.S. via consultations? And how should we approach the North Korea in order to seek solution for the abduction? And what did you convey to Prime Minister Abe today in this regard? [SEP] You know, I can speak first because I will tell you, on the Prime Minister's behalf, that he very much talked about abduction. It was preeminent in our conversations. He talked about it long and hard and passionately. And I will follow his wishes, and we will be discussing that with , absolutely. Absolutely.Prime Minister, go ahead. Now, at our Japan-U.S. summit meeting we had in Mar-a-Lago in the February, today, once again, as President Trump has mentioned already, I have explained on the abduction issue once again, and I have conveyed to him the earnest wish of the families of the abductees. And President Trump once again has stated that the abduction issue will be raised at the upcoming U.S.- summit.Now, at the U.S.- summit meeting, as to the concrete matters to be discussed, I would like to refrain from mentioning this at this juncture. But in any case, Japan's fulsome position were explained at length, and President Trump has given his understanding, and he has promised that the issue will be brought up at the summit meeting in Singapore. And I am delighted of this. President Trump and the international community—I would like to closely work with President Trump as well as the international community to seek solution to the issue. In solving the abduction issue, Japan itself needs to have direct consultation with . I have not changed my resolve in doing so.And under this decision and resolve, what will be conducive to solve the abduction issue—of course, I will have to think about the summit meeting for Japan- summit meeting. If we are to have the summit meeting, the nuclear, the missile, and what is more important, the abduction issue—the solution to all these issues must be the result. And I hope that we will be able to realize a summit meeting which would lead to solution of the problems.But first and foremost, we need to seek advancement for the abduction, nuclear and missile programs. Japan and U.S. should closely cooperate with each other so that we will be able to see great success for the historic U.S.- summit meeting. And Japan would like to give our all-out efforts in support.Thank you. I'd like to just close by paying my highest respect and regards and love, frankly—I've gotten to know them very well—to the Warmbier family, the incredible family of Otto Warmbier, who was a brilliant, beautiful, terrific young man. And he has not died in vain, I can tell you that. He has not died in vain. So to the Warmbier family, our love and our respect.Also, I'd like to say that we were tremendously successful in getting our three hostages back. And I'm very thankful to the cooperation that we received from . And the three United States citizens are now very happily ensconced in their homes with their families. They're very happy. And they didn't think this was going to happen. And frankly, it would never have happened, but it has.So I just want to wish them well also. They had a tough journey, but I really respect the fact that we were able to work with the n folks and get them out. They're very, very well ingrained already. They're back into—they were telling me they're now going to movies and they're going out to dinner and they're back. They're back in our country, and it's a terrific thing.I believe we're going to have a terrific success or a modified success. But in one form or another, if it all goes—and things can happen between now and then—but I know many of you are going. And I look forward to seeing you there. I look forward to traveling with you. It's a long way. But I really believe that we have the potential to do something incredible for the world. And it's my honor to be involved.Thank you very much. Thank you. Thank you.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Mr. President, you've expressed frustration with Congress, obviously, over the economic—wanting them to do more on the economy. They've blocked you on Colombia. They've blocked you on the FISA issue. Are you frustrated? Are you angry? And do you have any real hope of being able to work with this Congress this year? [SEP] Yes. I am—I believe that they're letting the American people down, is what I believe. The—on the FISA issue, it is hard to believe that it's okay to pass the Protect America Act in August of 2007, and that act—and that people in Congress can't—don't believe that act is relevant in 2008. I mean, the act was set to expire; it did. And yet this threat hasn't gone away. And I can only—it's either lack of leadership or a lack of understanding of the issue. And either way, it's not good for the country. We need to make sure our professionals have the tools to protect the American people from attack.The Colombia free trade agreement— this economy is—as I mentioned to you, it's a sour time. It's tough for the American people. And yet the Colombia free trade agreement would benefit our economy. And the reason why is, is that many goods from Colombia come into our country duty free. And yet our goods going to Colombia are taxed through tariff. And the American people expect the President and the Congress to at least insist that a foreign country treat us the way we treat them. And in this case, the benefits will be more exports, more midsized and small businesses exporting into Colombia. About 9,000 exporters into Colombia today; 8,000 are midsized and small businesses. And when you can export more, it helps the economy. And one of the bright lights of the economy has been the amount of exports going overseas.So rather than playing politics or whatever rationale that they have made for Colombia, they ought to be saying, this is good for our economy, it's good for workers, it's good for small businesses.And so I'm perplexed, I guess is the best way to describe it, about why there's no action, inactivity on big issues. And because the two issues you mentioned—FISA, protecting America, and Colombia, protecting America's economy by encouraging growth—are important to people whether they be Republicans, Democrats, or Independents.Sheryl [Sheryl Gay Stolberg, New York Times].
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, the U.K.'s travel ban exemption expires tonight. Considering that 17 Schengen countries have fewer coronavirus cases than the U.K., and the U.K. added 208 cases in the last day, why the special treatment for the U.K.? Will you consider adding them to the travel ban? [SEP] That was a professional recommendation, and we're reassessing it based on the latest figures. We may have to include them on the list of countries we're, let's say, restricting travel from during this period. Their numbers have increased quite rapidly in the last 24 hours, so we may add them, and perhaps a few others. We might also start thinking about removing some countries from the list.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, are you suggesting that you're putting aside the use of that specific term for now, while still holding the same underlying view? [SEP] My focus right now is on encouraging President Gul to continue these very productive discussions. The last thing I want is for the United States to do anything that might inadvertently tip the scales in one direction or another. We need to let these negotiations play out, and I'm confident they will reach a positive outcome.
label: General

sentence: Sir, regarding the Federal Reserve Chair, have you made a decision on your nominee? If not, what factors are influencing your choice for both the Chair and other vacant positions? Given the lateness of the hour, are you worried about a tight schedule, particularly if you opt not to reappoint Jay Powell? [SEP] The answer to all your questions is no. I won't be discussing it with you at this time. The process is ongoing, and we'll be making announcements in due course. It's been underway for some time now. Secondly, I'm confident that we'll have sufficient time to ensure all key nominees are confirmed before their terms conclude. And thirdly, I've given this matter a great deal of thought and consulted with my economic advisors to determine the best candidates. We have a number of excellent options. However, I won't be speculating at this juncture.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. And the masks are making my glasses fog up, so I apologize too.Thank you, sir. On climate change: You just mentioned the incentives you have on renewable energy in your Build Back Better plan. You do have a number of incentives, but as it stands right now, there are no punitive measures in this plan to hold these companies accountable. And many experts firmly believe that you've got to have the stick along with the carrot in order to get to your goal to reduce emissions by 2030 by 50 percent. So can you stand here today and say to the world that you definitively will still meet that goal? [SEP] Yes, I can. Because what we're proposing and what we've initiated is everything from getting the automobile makers to commit to going all electric, number one. Getting the unions to agree to do that as well. Making sure we have the investment in battery technology that requires us to have the ability to generate electric vehicles, electric buses, electric transportation grids. Making sure that we are dealing with everything from—let me go through some of these: that we have tax credits for—of $320 billion for dealing with alternatives by people getting a tax credit for moving on solar panels, on wind, and a whole range of other things, and winterizing their properties.I don't think you're going to need any punitive action to get people to step up and do those things. There's been no indication that's the case at all. With regard to, you know, the—there's a total of $555 billion in climate and—I'm just checking the numbers; make sure I'm right—and climate investment, in terms of resilience.We're now—it's very much in the interest of—of the industry to see to it that we move to making sure that we have the resilience to be able to, when those towers come down and the lines end up hitting the ground and burning down large swaths of the West, to bury this underground.There's a whole range of things. I don't think we're going to have to—everybody knows which direction it's going. And there's no indication that there has to be a punitive effort to get people to react the way in which we have to do, at least I don't believe so.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Are you saying it's not so warm? [SEP] Well, I don't know yet. What I'm about to tell you is, is that I'm looking forward to getting President Putin's readout from the meeting. I think one of the—the thing I'm interested in is whether or not he continues to harbor the same concerns that I do. And I say continues because when we were in Australia, he reconfirmed to me that it is—he recognized it's not in the world's interest for to have the capacity to make a nuclear weapon. And they have been very supportive in the United Nations, and we're working with them on a potential third resolution.So that's where my concerns—I don't worry about the pictures. I understand why they meet. I am—will continue to work with Russia, as well as other nations, to keep a focused effort on sending a message that—You will remain isolated if you continue your nuclear weapons ambitions.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: President Niinistö, considering Finland's border with Russia, are there any recent developments causing concern, and what further actions would you advocate to deter Putin? [SEP] Of course, we have been thinking about all kinds of scenarios. We have to be prepared. We are very careful. The situation is stable, we hope it stays that way. The Finnish people are feeling safer, and we are ready to defend our allies.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, in light of the recent court ruling questioning the effectiveness of NSA's bulk data collection, what alternative strategies are being considered to achieve the same national security objectives while addressing concerns about privacy and civil liberties? [SEP] Well, we're looking at all the options. The independent panel made a lot of good recommendations. We're reviewing those very carefully. We need to make sure we're protecting the country, but we also need to respect people's privacy. It's a balance. And we're going to find the right balance. We are currently evaluating these recommendations. In January, I will provide a definitive statement outlining which recommendations we will implement, which require further refinement, and how they relate to our work both internally and with international partners.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, what specific commitments can the U.S. make to ensure equitable vaccine distribution and realistically achieve the goal of ending the pandemic by 2022? [SEP] It might take a little longer than 2022, globally. The U.S. will continue to provide. We might be able to provide another billion doses in 2022 or 2023. But that's not finalized. I'm being careful to only say what I know and what I think we can do. I don't want to overpromise. There was consensus at the G-7 that we'll keep at it until the whole world is covered. It's not just the right thing to do morally, but it's also for our own health and security. You can't build a wall high enough to keep out new strains. This will be a constant project. We need a system to detect future pandemics early. We're helping other countries manufacture their own vaccines. It's a huge logistical effort. Last question.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Sir, considering the diverse perspectives on gun ownership and the complexities of addressing gun violence, what strategies are you employing to bridge the divide and foster a constructive dialogue on this critical issue? [SEP] We are actively engaging with stakeholders from across the political spectrum to foster a productive dialogue on gun violence. Our approach is rooted in a commitment to finding common ground and exploring evidence-based solutions that can help reduce gun violence while respecting the rights and concerns of all Americans.
label: Implicit

sentence: In light of the NSA surveillance disclosures, can you cite concrete examples where the bulk metadata program directly thwarted imminent terrorist attacks, and do you still believe the program's benefits outweigh the privacy concerns it raises? [SEP] Let me address the broader picture first. The independent panel I commissioned provided 46 recommendations. I had a detailed meeting with them to review them. They did an excellent job. I tasked them with examining all our activities and assessing whether they adequately address our security needs and prevent terrorist attacks, proliferation, and other threats. And are we also ensuring we uphold the rule of law and respect privacy? We're currently evaluating all the recommendations. In January, I'll make a comprehensive statement outlining which recommendations are sensible, which require further refinement, and how they relate to our internal and international collaborations. I'm treating this with utmost seriousness because this is a necessary debate. The 215 program, involving the bulk collection of phone data, has garnered significant attention. The NSA believed it was crucial to track calls from known foreign terrorists to the U.S. to investigate threats. There have been no allegations of misuse of this data. However, public concern exists regarding potential abuse. We must determine if we can achieve the same objectives while enhancing public trust. I'm confident the NSA isn't snooping, but we may need adjustments to boost public confidence. We must also reassure the international community. We have extensive laws to prevent the NSA from spying on Americans, but fewer international constraints. In a virtual world, borders are blurred, and just because we can do something doesn't mean we should. Our values must extend beyond our borders.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Mr. President, considering the consistent provocations following U.S. attempts at diplomacy, and the Republican resistance to your Cuba initiatives, can you detail Fidel Castro's involvement in the negotiations? Did you discuss him with Raul? Also, will you directly engage with Congress to thwart efforts to defund the embassy? [SEP] Lesley, with all due respect, I believe we need to move on. This is consuming too much of our allotted time.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. [inaudible]--marriage is a civil right? [SEP] And so I think it is important for us to work through these issues, because each community is going to be different and each State is going to be different--to work through them. In the meantime, we filed a--we filed briefs before the Supreme Court that say we think that any discrimination against gays, lesbians, transgenders is subject to heightened scrutiny, and we don't think that DOMA is unconstitutional [constitutional]*. And so I think the combination of what States are doing, what the courts are doing, the actions that we're taking administratively, all are how the process should work.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, you've spoken about addressing racial disparities. How does criminal justice reform figure into that? What specific gaps are you hoping to bridge before you leave office? What does your trip to Kenya signify? And, if I may, what's your position on Bill Cosby keeping his Medal of Freedom? [SEP] You've certainly given me a lot to unpack there, April. I'll just say...
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, given the urgency of the Iranian nuclear threat, how confident are you that international sanctions will be implemented within the timeframe you've outlined? Furthermore, regarding Pakistan, can you assure the American public that Pakistan's nuclear arsenal is secure from potential terrorist acquisition? [SEP] Well, let me address the Pakistan question first. We're working closely with Pakistan to ensure the security of its nuclear weapons program. We have confidence in their ability to safeguard these materials, but we're always looking for ways to improve security measures. As for Iran, we're committed to imposing strong sanctions that will have consequences for their nuclear program. We're working with our international partners to achieve this goal, and I'm confident that we'll be able to reach an agreement on sanctions in the near future. However, these negotiations can be complex, and we're prepared to take whatever steps are necessary to prevent Iran from acquiring nuclear weapons.
label: General

sentence: President Obama, with the benefit of hindsight, what specific changes would you make to the White House's internal processes to prevent similar technology failures in the future, and what steps are being taken to hold those responsible accountable? [SEP] Well, let's be honest, this has been a learning experience. We're taking a hard look at what went wrong and why. The truth is, this is a complicated system, and the government isn't always the best at IT procurement. But that's not an excuse. We need to do better, and we will. We're making changes to our processes, and we're holding people accountable. The bottom line is, we're going to get this fixed.
label: Deflection

sentence: Regarding the investigation into your handling of classified documents, can you assure the American public that no sensitive information was compromised, and what is your explanation for why these documents were found outside of secure government facilities? [SEP] I'm not going to comment on ongoing investigations. What I will say is that the world is looking at us. They want to know if the United States is stable, if we know what we're about. They want to know if we're the same democracy we've always been. That's what's really at stake here.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, given your emphasis on face-to-face talks, and considering the ongoing investigation into the origins of COVID-19, would you ever consider calling President Xi – man-to-man – and asking him to open up China to the WHO investigators so they can get to the bottom of this? [SEP] We have lines of communication with China, and we're using them. Look, the relationship is complex, and we're dealing with a lot of stuff. Right now, the focus is on getting a real, independent investigation. We're making our position crystal clear. We expect them to cooperate, and we'll see what happens next.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. Mr. President, in recent days, there's been a fair amount of discussion in legal circles about whether or not you might give preemptive pardons, pardons in advance, to officials of your administration who engaged in anything from harsh interrogation tactics to perhaps dismissing U.S. Attorneys. And I'd like to know, have you given any consideration to this? And are you planning on it? [SEP] I won't be discussing pardons here at this press conference.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, critics argue your approach is too simplistic. What specific policies will you implement to address the root causes of crime and ensure justice for all? [SEP] We're going to create jobs, we're going to improve education, and we're going to strengthen our communities. We're going to give people hope and opportunity, and we're going to make sure that everyone has a chance to succeed.
label: Dodging

sentence: So, is it your belief that Vladimir Putin authorized the hack? [SEP] I've said all I'm going to say on that matter. Next question.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Following the election of President Trump, do you believe that your concerns about climate change and Russia have been adequately addressed by President Biden? Furthermore, are you worried about the potential disintegration of the common European policy towards Russia, and would you consider announcing your candidacy as a gesture of goodwill? [SEP] I prefer to refrain from commenting on the political landscape of other countries. Chancellor Merkel has been an exceptional ally. My approach to Russia has consistently emphasized cooperation while upholding our core values. I hope that the incoming president will adopt a similar stance. As for my own political aspirations, I will make a decision at the appropriate time.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Considering Rick Ledgett's recent statements about Edward Snowden, what is your perspective on the possibility of granting him amnesty? What conditions would need to be met for you to consider a plea agreement or amnesty? And what is your message to those Americans who believe that Snowden's actions were justified and served the public interest? [SEP] As Mr. Snowden is currently facing criminal charges, I must be careful not to prejudice the legal proceedings. The Attorney General and the courts will ultimately determine the outcome of his case. While I recognize the importance of the debate surrounding surveillance and privacy, I also believe that the unauthorized disclosure of classified information has had a detrimental impact on U.S. national security. I will defer to the courts to resolve the matter in accordance with the law.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Do you support backpay for furloughed Federal workers? [SEP] Absolutely. I mean, that's how we've always done it.Roberta Rampton [Reuters].
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, given the economic slowdown and its potential to destabilize the global economy, particularly concerning China and Taiwan, and considering the Putin-Kim meeting's impact on the war in Ukraine, what are your thoughts on these interconnected challenges? [SEP] Look, China's facing some serious economic headwinds, stemming from a mix of global factors and their own policy choices. I don't anticipate this leading to an invasion of Taiwan; in fact, it might weaken their capacity. We're not looking to harm China; a prosperous China that plays by international rules benefits everyone. However, they're grappling with real estate issues and are currently weighing their options. We're not aiming to decouple, but we won't provide them with materials that could enhance their nuclear or defense capabilities, which would destabilize the region. Is that clear? Next question, please.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. And on the Benghazi question, I know pieces of this story have been litigated, and you've been asked about it. But there are people in your own State Department saying they've been blocked from coming forward, that they survived the terror attack, and they want to tell their story. Will you help them come forward and just say it once and for all? [SEP] Ed, I'm not familiar with this notion that anybody has been blocked from testifying. So what I'll do is I will find out what exactly you're referring to. What I've been very clear about from the start is that our job with respect to Benghazi has been to find out exactly what happened, to make sure that U.S. Embassies not just in the Middle East, but around the world are safe and secure, and to bring those who carried it out to justice.But I'll find out what exactly you're referring to.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: In terms of the economic environment, what are your predictions for the future? Do you regard this trend as favorable or unfavorable? [SEP] I hope we move away from protectionism. I was disappointed we couldn't get the trade bills for Colombia, Panama, and South Korea through Congress. I was hopeful, but they didn't pass the House. I worry about protectionism. In tough times, there's a temptation to protect our own and not compete. That sentiment was there even in good times. We barely got CAFTA through Congress. It would be a mistake to become protectionist. The Bush Center at SMU could remind people about the benefits of free trade: for our workers, overseas workers, development, and lifting people out of poverty in third world countries. Trade is the best way to enhance economic growth and give people a better future. I hope the country doesn't become protectionist. April, your turn.
label: General

sentence: Q. ----the idea that your policies are taking the country in reverse. You just reject that idea altogether that your policies could be going in reverse? [SEP] Yes. And I think--look, here's the bottom line. When I came into office, this economy was in a freefall, and the economy has stabilized. The economy is growing. We've seen 9 months of private sector job growth. So I think it would be hard to argue that we're going backwards. I think what you can argue is we're stuck in neutral. We are not moving the way we need to, to make sure that folks have the jobs, have the opportunity, are seeing economic growth in their communities the way they need to. And that's going to require Democrats and Republicans to come together and look for the best ideas to move things forward.It will not be easy, not just because Democrats and Republicans may have different priorities, as we were just discussing when it came to how we structure tax cuts, but because these issues are hard.The Republicans throughout the campaign said they're very concerned about debt and deficits. Well, one of the most important things we can do for debt and deficits is economic growth. So what other proposals do they have to grow the economy? If, in fact, they're rejecting some of the proposals I've made, I want to hear from them what affirmative policies can make a difference in terms of encouraging job growth and promoting the economy, because I don't think that tax cuts alone would--are going to be a recipe for the kind of expansion that we need.From 2001 to 2009, we cut taxes pretty significantly, and we just didn't see the kind of expansion that is going to be necessary in terms of driving the unemployment rate down significantly.So I think what we're going to need to do and what the American people want is for us to mix and match ideas, figure out those areas where we can agree on, move forward on those, disagree without being disagreeable on those areas that we can't agree on. If we accomplish that, then there will be time for politics later, but over the next year I think we can solidify this recovery and give people a little more confidence out there.Hans Nichols [Bloomberg News].
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Did you raise the border issue with him today? [SEP] I—we talked about it today, but I guess what I'm saying, Jeff, is this has been an ongoing conversation. We've recognized that this is a central part of our anti-ISIL strategy. We've got to choke them off. We have to choke off how they make money. We've got to choke off their ability to bring in new fighters. Because we've taken tens of thousands of their fighters off the battlefield, but if new ones are still coming in, then they continue to maintain a stranglehold over certain population centers inside of Iraq or Syria. So we've got to cut off their source of new fighters.That's also part of the great danger for Europe, and ultimately the United States as well, and countries as far flung as Australia or Singapore. If you've got foreign fighters coming in that are getting not only ideologically hardened, but battle hardened, and then they're returning to their home countries, they're likely candidates for engaging in the kind of terrorist attacks that we saw here in Paris.So this has been an ongoing concern, and we're going to continue to push hard among all our allies to cut off the financing, cut off the foreign fighters, improve our intelligence gathering, which has allowed us to accelerate the strikes that we're taking against ISIL.A lot of the discussion over the last couple of weeks was the pace of airstrikes. The pace of airstrikes is not constrained by the amount of planes or missiles that we have, the pace has been dictated by how many effective targets do we have. And our intelligence continues to improve. And the better we get at that, the better we're going to be at going after them.Scott Horsley [NPR].
label: Explicit

sentence: So, just to confirm, are you in agreement with that precise proposal? [SEP] That exact proposal? Not quite, but we're advancing. We're approaching a resolution. I'm a strong advocate for providing significant relief to those who were needlessly impacted because they possessed the means to prevent it. They could have halted its arrival in their country, our country, Europe, and its dissemination to 188 countries across the globe. It's a matter of responsibility.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Are you saying it's possible a recording exists without your knowledge? [SEP] Look, I'm not saying anything definitively. To the best of my knowledge, no such recording exists. But who knows what others might have done?
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Mr. President, concerning the Senate proceedings, do you want a quick end or a detailed investigation? What did you think of the Cipollone-Nadler clash? And are you absolutely against Bolton testifying? [SEP] Wow, you're throwing a lot at me at once.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Obama, on Mexico: human rights, drugs, Calderon's safety, visas – your thoughts? [SEP] The translation didn't quite make it through. Can we try that one more time?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, you said Joe Biden has hurt God; he's against God. The Vice President is a man of deep Catholic faith, and he credits it for helping him endure immense personal tragedy. What did you mean by your statement? [SEP] Well, look at their manifesto, their stance on religion and faith. A man of deep religion wouldn't agree to the Bernie Sanders plan. You can't reconcile that with religious values. That's why, if you look at polls—though I don't trust them—our numbers are rising, and Joe's are falling. He'll have to leave his basement soon. But no, look at their manifesto. It's further left than Bernie ever was. It's a terrible thing for our country. It will destroy us, cause a depression, double and triple taxes, and ruin healthcare. 180 million people will lose their healthcare. It's terrible.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, with deportations ongoing, can Guatemalans expect a halt to these actions while you pursue immigration reform? [SEP] We'll treat everyone with respect, but we must uphold our laws. Hiring undocumented workers is illegal, and we are a nation of laws. The best way to address Guatemalan concerns about their relatives in the U.S. is for me to work with Congress on a comprehensive bill. I'm optimistic we can achieve this, though it will be challenging.
label: General

sentence: Sir, with respect to the Libby matter, can you assure the American people that the White House is not attempting to influence the proceedings in any way, and that you are committed to transparency and accountability in this matter? [SEP] Look, it's a legal matter, plain and simple. I'm aware of the news reports, of course. However, I'm not going to offer any further commentary on a case that is currently before the courts. That would be inappropriate.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: With two years passed since you pledged to close Guantanamo, what specific obstacles have prevented its closure, and what is your revised timeline for fulfilling this promise? [SEP] Well, the main thing is keeping Americans safe. Guantanamo, it's a problem, a symbol. It gives Al Qaeda something to use, a way to get people to join them. We're going after these terrorists hard, my administration is doing a great job. We're making progress, Al Qaeda is weaker. But we also need to think about our values, what we stand for. That's why I want to close Guantanamo, not because the people there are doing a bad job, but because it's become a symbol. We can keep these people somewhere else. We're trying to find a way to deal with these dangerous people, give them lawyers, but also make sure they can't hurt us. It's a tough balance, security and our values, but we need to get it right. It's what makes America special.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, how will you regain public trust after the healthcare website debacle, especially regarding other complex policy proposals? [SEP] We are committed to transparency and accountability. We are taking steps to fix the problems with the healthcare website, and we are holding those responsible accountable. We are also engaging with the public to provide accurate information and address their concerns. We believe that by being open and honest, and by demonstrating our commitment to delivering results, we can rebuild public trust and move forward on our other important policy initiatives.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. ——also really quickly about Putin's invitation to join a video summit with Iran and other world powers. Would you accept that invitation? [SEP] I haven't been told of it yet. I heard there's something, but I haven't been told of it yet.Please, go ahead.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. The point I was going to make is, as leader of the free world, the people of Sydney don't see their city looking all that free at the moment. And how's that going? We thought that we weren't going to allow terrorists to do this to our free society. And so your very positive view on Iraq and progress towards reconciliation there is of interest to us if you're meeting the opposition leader tomorrow, and his view is that there should be a staged withdrawal of troops from Iraq next year. How would that affect the positive view you put today? And what will you say to disavow him of that decision? [SEP] First of all, in terms of whether Sydney is going to return to normal after I leave—or after we leave, I suspect it might, don't you? I don't think this is a permanent condition. I think the great freedom of the city of Sydney is going to return quite rapidly, which is different from other societies in the world.First of all, I'm looking forward to meeting with the opposition leader. I believe I did that on my last trip here to Australia, if I'm not mistaken. And I hope we have an honest exchange of views. You just heard my opinion about Iraq and whether or not, one, we can win, and two, if it's necessary to win. I believe it's necessary, and I believe we can. And I'm looking forward to hearing his opinion.I'm also wise enough not to prejudge the election results here in Australia. Yours is a slightly loaded question in trying to get me to comment about what it would be like to work with somebody who hasn't even been elected. And therefore, I'm going to let the Australian people express their opinion. My own judgment is, I wouldn't count the man out. As I recall, he's kind of like me; we both have run from behind and won. So that's going to be part of my—I can tell you, relations are great right now. And I also, as I told you earlier, and I believe this, that our relationship is bigger than any individual in office. It's a relationship based upon values, common values, and it's also a relationship—it's enforced during tough times. When we fought fascism, we learned a lot about each other. And the American people have got great respect for Australians. Anyway, thank you.Suzanne [Suzanne Malveaux, Cable News Network].
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, critics suggest your actions set a poor example for the nation. How do you respond? [SEP] With all due respect, that's simply incorrect. These are permitted political activities, plain and simple. There are clearly defined exceptions.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Critics fear this could lead to a witch hunt against career civil servants. Can you guarantee that these reviews will be based solely on performance and not on political affiliation or personal loyalty? [SEP] We're not looking for a witch hunt. We're looking for people that are doing their jobs. We want people that are competent, that are dedicated, that are putting America first.
label: Deflection

sentence: Concerning energy policy, you've engaged with consumers regarding supply. What measures are you contemplating if OPEC Plus declines to boost output? And do you acknowledge any inherent conflict in urging greater oil production while simultaneously promoting emissions reductions at COP26? [SEP] While it might appear contradictory, the notion that we can transition to renewable energy instantaneously and abandon oil, gas, or hydrogen is simply not feasible. We must prioritize eliminating methane and addressing other pressing issues. Although it may seem inconsistent to advocate for increased oil production while simultaneously championing emissions reductions, it's not, because we cannot eliminate fossil fuels overnight. We're going to stop subsidizing those fossil fuels. This situation only underscores the urgency of accelerating our transition to renewable energy. We're going to COP to deal with renewable energy, and I'm saying, Why are you guys cutting off oil and raising the price just to make it harder for us? By 2030, half the vehicles in America will be electric, but we'll still need gasoline. By 2050, we'll have zero emissions. Jim?
label: Deflection

sentence: Regarding TikTok, the Commerce Department's actions suggest a potential delay in finalizing a deal until after the election. What's your timeline for resolving this issue? [SEP] We're evaluating all possibilities to safeguard American data. We're talking to some great companies. We'll make a decision soon.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, with regard to energy policy, many are wondering why you consistently avoid mentioning the oil industry. Are you confident that American oil producers are maximizing all available resources, including offshore opportunities?
