And shifting to Iraq, will you finalize an interim agreement with Prime Minister Maliki regarding American military operations, or will you defer a more permanent agreement to your successor? [SEP] Regarding Iraq, we are actively working on a strategic framework agreement with the Iraqi government. This agreement will encompass cooperation in various sectors: diplomacy, economics, and justice. A key component is a security agreement. They are, understandably, interested in a clear timeline for the transition to what we call 'overwatch.' 'Overwatch' signifies that the U.S. will maintain a training mission, logistical support, and special operations capabilities. It is imperative that our troops operating in a foreign nation have a clear understanding with that government, including the authority to operate and protections. We are negotiating these details, aiming to finalize them before the end of the year, unless the UN mandate is extended. So, there are two distinct aspects to this agreement – often conflated, it seems – and we're tackling them concurrently. Let me see, what was the first question?
label: Dodging

sentence: President Obama, acknowledging Hillary Clinton's concerns about the FBI's role in the election, what steps can be taken to ensure the integrity and impartiality of law enforcement agencies, particularly in politically sensitive investigations, and to prevent future interference in the democratic process? [SEP] The transition is always a bit bumpy, right? Everyone's got their feelings. But the important thing is that Donald Trump is now President-elect, and he's got a whole new set of responsibilities. I've had some cordial conversations with him, offered some advice on how to maintain the integrity of the office. As for the FBI, they're good people, they work hard. It's always tough when law enforcement and politics intersect. I've always tried to stay out of their decisions, and I'm not about to start now.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, with the ban on food imports and the troop build-up, some critics are saying your administration's response is too tepid. What's your message to those who feel you're not doing enough to stand up to Russia? [SEP] Let me be clear: we are taking this situation very seriously. We are working closely with our allies to present a united front against Russian aggression. The sanctions are having an impact, and we are prepared to take further action if necessary. But we must also be mindful of the potential consequences of our actions, and we must proceed strategically and deliberately. This is not a time for rash decisions or empty gestures. It is a time for steady resolve and a commitment to finding a peaceful resolution to this crisis.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Mr. President, considering the setbacks with the healthcare rollout, will this affect your ability to tackle other key policy initiatives, like immigration reform? [SEP] Let me be clear, there's no valid reason to delay or abandon immigration reform. We've already secured bipartisan backing in the Senate. I've engaged with traditionally conservative clergy who are deeply committed to this cause. And the business community is wholeheartedly supportive. So, we have a diverse coalition, including many who typically align with the Republican party. If individuals are seeking a pretext to avoid doing the right thing on immigration reform, they will always find one. However, I firmly believe that people inherently want to do what's just. This would fortify our borders, enhance the legal immigration system, penalize employers who exploit undocumented workers, and offer a path for those here illegally to rectify their status – pay a fine, learn English, and wait their turn. It's a sensible and practical solution, and we shouldn't be searching for reasons to avoid it. I will continue to advocate tirelessly for its passage. Will I need to work to rebuild trust in some of our endeavors? Undoubtedly. But that's an inherent part of this role. Positive outcomes often go unacknowledged, while negative ones garner significant attention. That's simply the reality. I'm prepared for the challenge. We're going to achieve our goals.
label: General

sentence: Is an Executive Order the right way to address this issue, Mr. President? [SEP] The option is available to me, certainly. We're not there yet, but we're exploring all avenues. We're also pursuing legal action in Nevada. By the way, we're about to unveil a fantastic new healthcare plan, hopefully before the end of the month. And next month, we'll be tackling immigration. So, stay tuned for some very impressive developments.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, with casualties mounting and public support waning, why are you so steadfast in your commitment to the current strategy in Iraq, despite widespread calls for a change of course? [SEP] Well, look, the American people, they're understandably weary. This is a tough war, a war against an enemy that has no regard for human life. They'll kill anyone, anytime, anywhere. So, yeah, people are concerned. But we have to stay the course. We have to give General Petraeus the time he needs to assess the situation. He's the expert. I trust his judgment. And we're seeing progress, real progress, in places like Anbar Province. So, we're not going to back down now.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. I wonder if there's a big, urgent problem facing the country, coming down the road, that you worry your successor will neglect or postpone. That is, when the politics are done, after the war on terror, what do you think should be at the top of the list of the person who moves into that office? [SEP] Yes. I don't think John McCain is going to neglect the war on terror, and I do think he'll be the President. Here I am interjecting myself in the '08 campaign, just like I told you I wouldn't. That's unfair, isn't it?He—it's very important for the President to understand that America is still in danger of attack and that we're dealing in—with an ideological struggle that can only be solved with the spread of liberty. And a concern of mine, as you've heard me say, is that the Nation has had the tendency in the past to become isolationist and correspondingly protectionist. And I would hope whoever the President is—and I do believe it will be John—will be willing to resist the impulse, the temptation to say, well, it's not worth it anymore to confront an enemy; it's not worth it to try to do the hard work of helping democracies thrive and succeed. Because not only is it worth it; we will succeed in laying the foundation for peace if we have faith in the capacity of liberty to be transformative.I'm also concerned about protectionism. This lad right here asked me about Congress's intransigence on Colombia. I think it reflects the fact that there is a strong protectionist sentiment in the United States. People—good people—believe it is not in our interest to be opening up markets. You might remember the CAFTA trade vote. We won by one vote, and it was a tough vote to get. And now the Speaker pulled a unique maneuver to stop the Colombia from moving forward. And it's a sign of—that the country is losing its confidence to a certain extent, that protectionist policy is better than confidently trading and treating unfairness in the marketplace.And so my worry—not worry—my hope is, is that whoever the President is understands that America is a force for good in the world, that we're—that in the spread of liberty, we're adhering to a universal value. It's not an American value, it's a universal value, the notion of liberty. And you've heard me say it a lot. I do believe it's a gift from the Almighty to every man, woman, and child. And if you believe in that and act on that, you're really acting on a platform of peace, because ultimately, liberty yields the peace you want. It's trans-formative and powerful. And I believe that people will be making a mistake if they say, we can't compete economically, and therefore, let's throw up walls. And yet the tendencies here in America are pretty strong right now.There's a lot of concern around the world, by the way, about America's retreat. They're wondering whether or not America is going to remain a leader. They're wondering whether or not, for example, will capital be welcomed back into our country. And so it's the isms that bother me— isolationism and protectionism.April [April Ryan, American Urban Radio Networks].
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, it seems you're hesitant to proceed with the proposed sanctions. Is that a fair assessment? [SEP] Let me tell you, I love this country, but President Erdogan, he's the one who got Pastor Brunson back to us. Nobody else could do it. Obama couldn't get him back. He was going to be locked up for decades. Pastor Brunson was an innocent man. I called Erdogan, and very quickly, Pastor Brunson was right here in the Oval Office with me. So, from my perspective, he's a tough guy. Real tough. But I get along with him. I think he was treated unfairly. He was told he couldn't have something, and then after he went and bought a different system, we said, 'Okay, we'll sell it to you now.' But he couldn't use it at that point. He'd already bought the plane. So, it's a complex situation. We're working on it. We'll see what happens.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, with legislative options seemingly exhausted, what concrete steps are you prepared to take, through executive action or other means, to protect voting rights, as you indicated was possible at your earlier press conference? [SEP] I'm not going to unveil our entire strategy at this time. But we're actively pursuing all available options. We've significantly enhanced the Justice Department's capacity to challenge these unconstitutional Republican efforts to manipulate elections. We're engaging communities, raising awareness about the potential for subversion. The idea that electors could be changed after the fact? It's a shocking development. But we're ready to confront it. And I'm confident that we can still achieve meaningful progress on voting rights legislation, even if it's not everything we initially hoped for.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, regarding Russia's leadership, how do you view the dynamic between Putin and Medvedev? And what's the most important thing your successor should keep in mind when dealing with Russia? [SEP] The power structure there is something we're all trying to understand. The G-8 will offer some clues. Regardless, we need to engage with Russia on issues like nuclear security and Iran. We won't always see eye-to-eye, but dialogue is essential. My advice is to pursue a pragmatic relationship.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, considering the Kuwaiti Ambassador's statement to the IAEA regarding Iran and the JCPOA, and with the U.S. seeking to extend sanctions at the U.N., could you outline your administration's specific strategy to address Kuwait's concerns, as discussed in your meeting today? [SEP] The Kuwaitis, great people, they came to see me, and we had a fantastic meeting. They're seeing what's happening, the deals we're making, nobody thought it was possible. They're excited, very excited. Iran, well, that's part of the puzzle, a big part, but we're putting it all together. We're talking to everyone about the Middle East, it's a mess, but we're cleaning it up. We're getting our troops back home, and we're guarding our interests. The previous administration made a terrible deal with Iran, the worst deal ever, but we're making it better. Everyone is tired of fighting. They want security, and they want to be part of the deal.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Mr. President, following yesterday's attack on the Inter-Continental Hotel, are you concerned that Afghan security forces might not be ready to handle security challenges if they can't even protect a high-profile target in Kabul? [SEP] Well, let's remember the drawdown hasn't even started yet. We knew Afghanistan was a dangerous place, that the Taliban remains a threat, and that incidents like this would happen. The real question is, are the Afghans improving their capabilities overall? Kabul, which houses a large part of the Afghan population, has been largely policed by Afghan forces for some time now, and they've done a pretty good job. Kabul is safer than it used to be, and Afghan forces there are more capable. That doesn't mean these attacks won't happen, and they probably will for a while. Our work isn't finished. But as I said before, the tide of war is receding. We've moved to a transition phase. And just like in Iraq, where we reduced our troop presence and will withdraw the rest by the end of the year, but Iraq has been able to maintain a democratic government and reduce violence, we believe a similar approach makes sense in Afghanistan. Even in Iraq, you still see occasional attacks. These countries are still recovering from a lot of war and conflict. They're dangerous places, and they won't be perfectly safe, even with us there. But we can improve the Afghan people's ability to defend themselves.
label: Clarification

sentence: Are you able to confirm whether Chen Guangcheng is currently under U.S. protection in Beijing, and would the United States consider granting him asylum should he seek it? [SEP] I've seen the news reports, but I won't comment on the specifics. I will say that human rights are always a topic of discussion when we engage with .
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, given the current political climate, many are skeptical that the U.S. will uphold its commitments to the Paris Agreement after your term. What assurances can you offer that future administrations, particularly Republican ones, will continue to prioritize climate action? [SEP] Let me be clear, climate change is not a partisan issue, it's a global crisis that demands urgent action. While I can't predict the future, I'm confident that any future president, regardless of party affiliation, will recognize the importance of addressing climate change. The science is undeniable, the economic opportunities are immense, and the American people overwhelmingly support climate action. We've already seen significant progress in reducing emissions and investing in clean energy, and I believe that momentum will continue. The world is watching, and we must continue to lead by example.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, what concrete steps were discussed with Chairman Kim to achieve denuclearization? [SEP] We discussed many ways. And the denuclearization is a very important—it's a very important word. Become a very well used word. And a lot of people don't know what it means, but to me it's pretty obvious: We have to get rid of the nukes.I think he's got a chance to have one of the most successful countries—rapidly, too—on Earth. Incredible country, incredible location. You're right between—if you think of it, you have, on one side, Russia and , and on the other, you have , and you're surrounded by water and among the most beautiful shorelines in the world.There is tremendous potential in North Korea, and I think he's going to lead it to a very important thing, economically. I think it's going to be an absolute economic power.Yes. Go ahead. Please. Go ahead. Yes.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. You hear criticism on the Hill that you and your White House team are too insular. Is that how this mess came to be? [SEP] Well, I think there is going to be a lot of evaluation of how we got to this point. And I'm sure—I assure you that I've been asking a lot of questions about that. The truth is that this is, number one, very complicated. The web site itself is doing a lot of stuff. There aren't a lot of web sites out there that have to help people compare their possible insurance options, verify income to find out what kind of tax credits they might get, communicate with those insurance companies so that they can purchase, make sure that all of it's verified. Right? So there's just a bunch of pieces to it that made it challenging.And you combine that with the fact that the Federal Government does a lot of things really well. One of the things it does not do well is information technology procurement. This is kind of a systematic problem that we have across the board. And it is not surprising then that there were going to be some problems.Now, I think we have to ask ourselves some hard questions inside the White House as opposed to why we didn't see more of these problems coming earlier on: A, so we could set expectations; B, so that we could look for different ways for people to end up applying.So ultimately, you're right. This is something that's really important to me, and it's really important to millions of Americans who have been waiting for a really long time to try to get health care, because they don't have it. And I am very frustrated, but I'm also somebody who, if I fumbled the ball, I'm going to wait until I get the next play, and then I'm going to try to run as hard as I can and do right by the team. So ultimately, I'm the head of this team. We did fumble the ball on it, and what I'm going to do is make sure that we get it fixed.In terms of what happens on November 30 or December 1, I think it's fair to say that the improvement will be marked and noticeable. The web site will work much better on November 30, December 1 than it worked certainly on October 1, but that's a pretty low bar. It will be working a lot better than it is—it was last week, and it will be working better than it was this week, which means that the majority of people who go to the web site will see a web site that is working the way it's supposed to.I think it is not possible for me to guarantee that a hundred percent of the people a hundred percent of the time going on this web site will have a perfectly seamless, smooth experience. We're going to have to continue to improve it even after November 30, December 1. But the majority of people who use it will be able to see it operate the way it was supposed to.One thing that we've discovered, though, that I think is worth noting: A lot of focus has been on the web site and the technology, and that's partly because that's how we initially identified it; these are glitches. What we're discovering is that part of the problem has been technology—hardware and software—and that's being upgraded. But even if we get the hardware and software working exactly the way it's supposed to, with relatively minor glitches, what we're also discovering is that insurance is complicated to buy.And another mistake that we made, I think, was underestimating the difficulties of people purchasing insurance online and shopping for a lot of options with a lot of costs and a lot of different benefits and plans and somehow expecting that that would be very smooth. And then they've also got to try to apply for tax credits on the web site.So what we're doing even as we're trying to solve the technical problems is also, what can we do to make the application a little bit simpler? What can we do to make it in English as opposed to bureaucratese? Are there steps that we can skip while still getting the core information that people need?And part of what we're realizing is that they are going to be a certain portion of people who are just going to need more help and more handholding in the application process. And so I guess part of the continuous improvement that I'm looking at is not just a technical issue. It's also, can we streamline the application process? What are we doing to give people more assistance in the application process? How do the call centers and the people who are helping folks in-person? How are they trained so that things can go more smoothly?Because the bottom line ultimately is, I just want people to know what their options are in a clear way. And buying health insurance is never going to be like buying a song on iTunes. It's just a much more complicated transaction. But I think we can continue to make it better. All of which is to say that on December 1, November 30, it will be a lot better, but there will still be some problems. Some of those will not be because of technological problems, although I'm sure that there will still be some glitches that have to be smoothed out. Some of it's going to be, how are we making this application process more user friendly for folks?And one good example of this, by the way, just to use an analogy: When we came into office, we heard a lot of complaints about the financial aid forms that families have to fill out to get Federal financial aid. And I actually remember applying for some of that stuff and remember how difficult and confusing it was. And Arne Duncan over at Education worked with a team to see what we could do to simplify it, and it made a big difference.And that's part of the process that we've got to go through. And in fact, if we can get some focus groups and we sit down with actual users and see how well is this working, what would improve it, what part of it didn't you understand, that all I think is part of what we're going to be working on in the weeks ahead.
label: Deflection

sentence: President Bush, from an outside perspective, Africa may seem to be in a difficult position. However, there is hope for a brighter future. What actions do you believe Africa needs to take, what type of leadership do you envision, and how will the U.S. assist in transforming the continent? Additionally, what are your objectives for this five-nation tour, why are you visiting Africa near the end of your term, and how will you ensure the continuation of your goals? [SEP] Thank you. I visited Africa early in my presidency as well. This second trip underscores the importance of assisting African nations in combating diseases like malaria and HIV/AIDS, promoting trade, and investing in education. Ghana provides a firsthand look at these efforts. It's different than just giving speeches in America. Africa has changed positively during my time, thanks to African leaders. We've helped resolve conflicts, like in Liberia, and supported democratic transitions. The U.S. has been a helpful partner, not an imposing force. Democracy is growing, exemplified by leaders like John Kufuor. Our aid program now emphasizes accountability, requiring good governance and investment in education. I have confidence in the leaders I've met, who are dedicated to their people and honest government. This trip highlights these points. Thank you, Ghana. John McKinnon, from the Wall Street Journal.
label: General

sentence: Sir, the intelligence community reports Russian meddling against Biden and potential Chinese meddling against you. Do you accept this assessment, and how will you respond? [SEP] Could be true, could be. But frankly, Russia wouldn't want me in office. I've been tougher on Russia than anyone, believe me. The toughest.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. If USMCA doesn't pass through Congress, is that it for NAFTA? [SEP] Well, that would be a shame. Well, I don't want to answer that question, but you know how I feel about NAFTA. I think NAFTA is the worst trade deal ever made, although I also happen to think World Trade Organization was not one of the greats. Not one of the greats. That was the creation of China, which went like a rocket ship from the day they signed. It was—it was terrible.But no, we're going to find out. That's going to be a very interesting question, with Nancy and Chuck and all of these people focusing on the witch hunt because they can't beat us at the ballot. They can't beat us at the ballot. And they're not going to win the President. We're having great polls. We have internal polls that are—Ohio, Iowa. Pennsylvania is looking good. North Carolina.We just won two races that a lot of people—we thought we were going to lose both of those races. One was down 17 points 3 weeks before the race, and he ended up winning by a substantial margin—by a substantial margin. And—Dan Bishop. And then, we had a second race, as you know, and he was up one or two points and ended up winning by—what was it? Twenty-five points or some incredible—I'll ask you folks, because I don't want to be inaccurate. Otherwise, I'll have a front-page story: We have breaking news. Trump exaggerated.But he won by many, many points. And he was leading by maybe two, maybe three, but he won by—in the twenties. So it's—it's been—so we're looking great in North Carolina, looking great in Florida.And you had one or two Congressmen, Democrats, say, Listen, we can't beat them at the election, so let's impeach him. Right? Didn't you hear—Al Green. That's a beauty. He's a real beauty, that guy. But he said, very distinctively, it's all—it was all over the place. I don't know—they're trying to lose that tape, I guess. But he said, We can't . . . Essentially, he said: We can't beat him. Let's impeach him. That's pretty dangerous stuff.Steve [Steve A. Holland, Reuters], go ahead.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, did you or your Chief of Staff order an investigation into the Hadley memo leak before your meeting with Prime Minister al-Maliki? If the leak was unauthorized, do you suspect someone in your administration is trying to undermine your Iraq policy or sabotage your meeting? [SEP] I don't recall ordering a specific investigation. I expressed concern about the leaks. I understand you all work hard to get information out, but I don't appreciate classified document leaks. It's a problem for every administration. We've had many leaks, and it's hard to find the leakers. There may be an ongoing investigation; I'm not sure. It would be helpful to hold leakers accountable to deter future leaks.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, you've previously voted against raising the debt ceiling as a Senator. Now, you insist on no negotiations, a departure from past presidential practices involving deficit reduction deals tied to debt ceiling increases. Doesn't this inflexibility risk a default, given the lack of dialogue? [SEP] We're committed to responsible fiscal management, but we won't allow the debt ceiling to be used as a political weapon. We're willing to have a conversation about reducing our deficits, but we won't negotiate under the threat of default. It's time for Congress to act responsibly and raise the debt ceiling without preconditions.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, despite your advocacy for a peaceful transition, numerous Democrats are boycotting the upcoming Inauguration. What are your thoughts on this? What message would you send to encourage a more unified transfer of power? Furthermore, could you elaborate on your discussions with the President-elect, specifically whether you attempted to influence his stance on critical issues such as the Affordable Care Act and the DREAMers program, and to what extent were you successful? [SEP] I'm not at liberty to disclose the specifics of my conversations with President-elect Trump. I will say that they have been cordial, at times quite extensive, and always substantive. Whether I have been persuasive is a question best directed to him. I have offered my best counsel on a range of issues, both foreign and domestic. However, given that he won an election in opposition to many of my initiatives, it is appropriate for him to proceed with his own vision. I do not anticipate complete alignment. It is possible that on certain issues, once he assumes office and confronts the complexities of providing healthcare for all or fostering job creation, he may arrive at similar conclusions to my own. However, we will not know until he has the opportunity to be sworn in and occupy that office. His views will undoubtedly be shaped by his advisors, hence the importance of these confirmation hearings. I have emphasized to him that this is a role of such magnitude that it cannot be undertaken alone. One is heavily reliant on a team: one's Cabinet, senior White House staff, and even more junior staff who execute significant responsibilities. Therefore, assembling a team that provides the best information and presents a range of options is the most valuable advice I can offer. Regarding the Inauguration, I will refrain from commenting on others' decisions. Michelle and I will be in attendance, and I am relieved that the weather forecast indicates it will not be as cold as my first Inauguration.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Yes. I know you said the last thing was an add-on and it wasn't in the agreement, but that he gave you his word. If he doesn't follow through on these things, what are you prepared to do in response? And will you lose faith in this process? [SEP] No. I think he'll do it. I really believe that. Otherwise, I wouldn't be doing this. I really believe it. And it was really the engine testing site, in addition to all of the other things that they've agreed to do. It was the—they have a very powerful engine testing site that, again, we're able to see because of the heat that they—that it emits. And yes, I'm able to—I'm very happy. I'll tell you what—I'm very happy with those two points—the two points you mentioned.But I think you might be referring to the thing that's not in, which is the engine testing site. I think he's—I think—honestly, I think he's going to do these things. I may be wrong. I mean, I may stand before you in 6 months and say, Hey, I was wrong. I don't know that I'll ever admit that, but I'll find a—I'll find some kind of an excuse. []Okay, one or two. One more. Come on.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. You believe it's all politics? [SEP] No, I said some. But what I have also said is, is that the American people have gone through a lot when it comes to the military over the last decade or so. And so I understand that. And when you starting talking about chemical weapons and their proliferation, those images of those bodies can sometimes be forgotten pretty quickly. The news cycle moves on.Frankly, if we weren't talking about the need for an international response right now, this wouldn't be what everybody would be asking about. There would be some resolutions that were being proffered in the United Nations and the usual hocus-pocus, but the world and the country would have moved on.So trying to impart a sense of urgency about this—why we can't have an environment in which, over time, people start thinking, we can get away with chemical weapons use—it's a hard sell, but it's something I believe in. And as I explained to Brianna, in this context, me making sure that the American people understand it, I think, is important before I take action.Jon Karl [ABC News].
label: Explicit

sentence: Do we know if the suspect was male or female? [SEP] I honestly couldn't say. The authorities handling the case will be providing a detailed briefing shortly, I understand.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: President Obama, concerning Chile, while you commend its economic progress and democratic shift, the legacy of Pinochet's dictatorship lingers. Critics argue the U.S. shares blame. Will the U.S. assist investigations into Allende and Frei Montalva, and will you offer an apology for the U.S.'s actions in the 70s? [SEP] Regarding collaboration with the Chilean government, we will carefully consider any requests for information concerning the past. Understanding our history is crucial, and U.S.-Latin America relations have, at times, been challenging.However, while acknowledging our history is vital, we must not be confined by it. Chile has made remarkable progress in the last two decades, with the full support of the U.S.I cannot comment on all past policies, but I can address the present and future. As President, I affirm our commitment to democracy, poverty eradication, inclusive development, and open markets in Chile. We strongly support the efforts of [Pinera] and [Bachelet].Once again, we must learn from our history without being shackled by it. We face numerous challenges now and in the future.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Sir, the message to young men? Sir? [SEP] Thank you. Thank you very much. Thank you very much.
label: Dodging

sentence: Do you still have confidence in Secretary Azar? [SEP] I wish him well, whoever that is. Is that the right name?
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Just to put a bow on this, will you officially endorse the proposed legislation? [SEP] Not that specific proposal, no. But let me tell you, we're getting closer to something great. We're talking about sending much-needed funds to people who were unfairly impacted by something that could have been prevented. It's a shame, a real shame, that it wasn't stopped at the source. Now, we're dealing with the fallout worldwide. Sad!
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: In essence, you're saying the annexation suspension was a non-negotiable condition for the deal? [SEP] Could you say that again, please?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. ——those are his words. Are you perhaps facing an ultimatum on the war this fall with Congress? [SEP] You know, I—first of all, I appreciate the Members coming down to the White House. We had a good exchange. It gave me a chance to share with them my feelings about the Iraqi issue. I spent time talking to them about what it meant to fail and what it means when we succeed. They expressed their opinions. They're obviously concerned about the Iraq war, but so are a lot of other people.I remind people—I reminded them that last fall, late fall, I had been one of these people that get endlessly polled. You know, these surveys and the pollsters constantly calling people all the time, it looks like— and had asked my opinion; I'd have said, I disapprove of what was going on in Iraq. You could have put me down as part of the disapproval process—and, therefore, had put a plan in place that would more likely cause me to approve of what's going on in Iraq. That's why I made the decision I made.I explained to them why I made the decision I made. And I said, look, David Petraeus has got a plan, and Members of Congress—some Members of Congress won't let him implement the plan. That doesn't make any sense, on the one hand, for us to send him out with the unanimous confirmation by the Senate, and then to deny him the troops and/or the funds necessary to get the job done. And I reminded them that we ought to give David Petraeus a chance.I did explain to them that General Petraeus has said he's going to come back and report to the Secretary and the Joint Chiefs and the White House and the Congress about whether or not the strategy that he thinks could work is working. And at that point in time, we will respond accordingly.As I have told people, that decisions about the posture in Iraq need to be based upon conditions on the ground. And no better person to report about the conditions on the ground than somebody who was there, and that would be General Petraeus. And at that point in time, upon the recommendation of the Secretary and the Joint Chiefs and General Petraeus, we will respond to what he says. And so I said, why don't we wait and see what happens? Let's give this plan a chance to work. Let's stop playing politics. It's one thing to have a good, honest debate about the way forward in Iraq, it's another thing to put our troops right in the middle of that debate.These troops deserve the money necessary to do the job. And our commanders need the flexibility necessary to do the job. And I believe this cause is necessary and it's noble. That's why I put those young men and women out there in the first place. It's necessary for the peace and security of our country. It's noble to have such amazing citizens volunteer to go into harm's way. And our Congress needs to support them. It's one thing to have a political debate or a debate about strategies, it's another thing to make sure that money gets sent to them on a timely basis. I repeat: This idea of funding our troops every 2 months is not adequate, and I frankly don't think it's right. They need to give the— these troops what they—what the military has asked for them.And we can debate Iraq and should. But there should be no debate about making sure that money gets there on a timely basis so our kids can do the job we've asked them to do.I want to thank you all for your time.
label: General

sentence: Considering Mr. Hensarling's remarks, will you veto any attempt to change the sequester? And can you elaborate on your conversation with President Sarkozy about Prime Minister Netanyahu? [SEP] Let's focus on the bigger picture. The supercommittee needs to act responsibly. As for private conversations with world leaders, I'm not going to get into the specifics.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, following up on North Korea and Cuba, could you provide a clearer timeline for when these options will be presented, and what specific criteria will guide your decision-making process? Furthermore, what specific benchmarks need to be met before a visit to Cuba becomes a realistic possibility? [SEP] We're moving deliberately, ensuring all angles are covered. The options are being refined, and I'll review them when they're ready. As for Cuba, the conditions aren't right for a visit, but I'm hopeful for the future. We're focused on the present, but I anticipate future engagement.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: When might you consider easing travel restrictions concerning China, given the coronavirus outbreak? [SEP] We'll ease them when the problem is resolved. Those restrictions saved us. If I hadn't acted decisively early on, we'd be facing a far worse situation. I faced criticism, even accusations of racism, for making that decision. It was a bold move, and it proved to be the right one. We need to work together, not criticize, especially when we have the best team in the world handling this.
label: General

sentence: Sir, is it your belief that a successful agreement could have been forged without Israel's commitment to a temporary suspension of annexation efforts? [SEP] I'm sorry, could you articulate that once more?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, regarding climate change, some say you've called it a hoax in the past. What's your current position? [SEP] Well, I wouldn't say it's a hoax entirely. Parts of it, maybe. Some people are exaggerating the problem. We all want clean air and water, and my administration has made tremendous progress. Our numbers are the best they've ever been. But other countries are the real problem. They're polluting the planet while we're cleaning it up. Greta should focus her attention on them. And don't forget the garbage they dump in our oceans. So, it's not a hoax, but it's also not entirely our fault.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, Donald Trump has repeatedly claimed the upcoming election will be rigged. This strikes at the heart of our democratic process. Can you assure the American people that the election will be fair? And are you concerned his rhetoric will undermine faith in the results? Furthermore, if he wins, despite your assessment of him, what will your message be to the nation? [SEP] Look, ultimately, the power rests with the American people. I have one vote, just like everyone else. I've voiced my concerns, but the decision is theirs. If someone wins the presidency, my constitutional duty is a peaceful transfer of power and to support their success. As for the election being rigged, that's absurd. The federal government doesn't control elections. States and local communities do. Trump's conspiracy theories are baseless, even in states like Texas. We take election integrity seriously, monitoring for vulnerabilities and addressing any violations of federal law. But this election will be like any other. Sometimes, losers complain about being cheated, but I've never seen someone complain before the game is even over. My advice to Mr. Trump is to focus on winning. If he loses by a landslide, then maybe he can raise questions. But that's not the case right now.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. And if they do, sir, you will have to make that choice? [SEP] We'll see what happens. We've got a couple of months.
label: General

sentence: Sir, with all due respect, 'immediately' is vague. Can you give us a target date, even a rough estimate, for public availability? [SEP] Look, we're working day and night. It will be available as soon as possible. It's going to be a beautiful thing to see.
label: General

sentence: Sir, is the 'fire and fury' rhetoric a thing of the past? [SEP] At that time, 'fire and fury' may have been required. We simply could not permit that particular capability to materialize, not for the United States, and definitely not for Japan, which is right next door.
label: General

sentence: So, Mr. President, it doesn't sound like you're too keen on moving forward with those sanctions? [SEP] Look, I love our country, but I gotta tell you, President Erdogan – he got our pastor back, Pastor Brunson. Nobody else could do that. Remember? Obama couldn't get him back. He was in jail for 35 years! He was gonna be in jail forever. Pastor Brunson, he was an innocent man. I called him, and after a short period of time, Pastor Brunson was standing in the Oval Office with me. So, you know, from my standpoint, he's a tough guy. Okay? When you talk about tough, he's tough. But I get along with him. I think he was unfairly treated. They told him he couldn't have something, and then after he bought another system, we said, 'We'll sell it to you. We'll give it to you right away.' But he couldn't use it then. By that time, he had already bought the plane. So, it's a complicated deal. We're working on it. We'll see what we can do.
label: Implicit

sentence: Sir, given Netanyahu's legal troubles and the need for Israeli concessions, do you believe he's the right partner for peace? [SEP] Netanyahu's been a terrific Prime Minister. The situation is what it is. I'm not going to get into the details of his personal affairs. We'll see what happens.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, further to that point, are you certain Speaker Boehner can guarantee the votes needed for any deal, given the rifts within his caucus? Is he truly in control of his members? [SEP] That's a question for the Speaker to answer, not me. My interactions with John Boehner have been good. I think he's a good person who wants to do what's right for the country. However, the political winds that swept him into the Speakership are making governing difficult. The Republican caucus needs to understand that American democracy works when people listen to each other, assume good intentions, and find reasonable compromises. Sadly, some members of that caucus haven't fully understood that yet.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Mr. President, a couple of financial questions, if I could. Larry Kudlow said this morning that, at the current run rate, the Paycheck Protection money will run out very soon. The plan to re- up it is stalled in Congress. What can you do, as President, to try to move that forward? [SEP] Well, we're trying to get it done. The problem is the Democrats want to put all sorts of things. Last time, they put Kennedy Center, and I hated putting Kennedy Center. And I've great respect for Kennedy Center, but I hated putting it in the bill because it's just not appropriate. Right?And—but they wanted it in for whatever reason. They had their own political reason. And, John, I said, Watch the way that blows up. And it blew up. I think it blew up in their face. We want to take care of our workers. We'll worry about other things and other pet projects of Democrats—and also Republicans—later.But it's been a tremendously successful program. I think you see it. The banks have stepped up. Hundreds of thousands of loan applications approved. Money is going out. It's been a tremendous program. Really, it's been—and obviously, it was at a point where we're almost—you know, we're almost—the money will be expired, and we could use a refill for the workers. We want to be able to make sure that small businesses stay open, John. And I think that'll happen.Yes, go ahead. Please./California
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Mr. President, considering the Vatican's potential move to recognize a Palestinian state, and its implications for the prospect of a two-state solution with Israel, could you share your perspective on whether this action would be constructive or detrimental, and how it might affect the two-state solution you've advocated for? [SEP] Well, first off, let me just say how pleased I am with the Senate's progress on granting me the authority to negotiate trade deals that are not only smart but also promote growth, both in the Asia-Pacific region and potentially in Europe. This also empowers us to enforce these agreements, which hasn't always been the case. I want to express my gratitude to the Senators who voted in favor of this, or at least to initiate the debate. For those who didn't, I'll continue to make my case, providing them with the necessary information to understand that despite past issues with trade deals, our approach is the right one, not just for large corporations, but for small and medium-sized businesses, and most importantly, for American workers. I wouldn't support any agreement that I didn't believe would create jobs and opportunities for Americans to climb the ladder of success, with higher incomes and wages. That's been my primary focus since day one. The issue between myself and Elizabeth is not personal. The press likes to sensationalize disagreements between allies, but many of my closest friends in the Senate and House disagree with me on this issue. I understand their concerns about plants closing and jobs being shipped overseas. They worry about the enforcement of labor and environmental agreements and whether trade is truly fair. They share my deep concern about rising inequality and the impact of automation and globalization on the middle class. These are people whose values align with mine. They even released a progressive statement of principles that mirrored my agenda, except for trade. This is a policy difference, a disagreement on what's best for our constituents. I firmly believe that despite past problems, we're better off writing high-standard rules with strong enforcement on issues like child labor, deforestation, and intellectual property. If we don't, China and other countries will, disadvantaging our businesses and workers. As for outsourcing fears, companies seeking low-cost labor can already do so. Our opportunity lies in attracting companies back to manufacture here. Nike's potential return of 10,000 jobs due to new technologies is an example of this. But we need to be able to sell overseas to fully capitalize on these opportunities. That's why I argue with my progressive friends that we need to focus on shared objectives like a strong minimum wage, job training programs, infrastructure investments, stronger collective bargaining laws, and enforcement of overtime pay and paid sick leave. We need an honest conversation about our budgets and stop preserving loopholes for corporations that provide no economic benefit. These are the things that will address their concerns. Blocking a trade deal won't, especially since they acknowledge the existing rules are bad for U.S. workers. How does clinging to the status quo help them? It doesn't make sense. I support enforcement and the signed provisions. I have concerns about the currency language in the bill, but I need to discuss with Senators Schumer and Brown how to ensure it doesn't negatively impact our monetary policy. Remind me again of the original question?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the shooting incident you mentioned took place 'outside,' could you elaborate on how far that was from the White House? [SEP] Details will be shared with you in an upcoming briefing.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Sir, may I, as a representative of the international media, pose a question? [SEP] And you represent?
label: Clarification

sentence: Sir, concerning immigration, if you receive an E-Verify bill without a legalization component, will you veto it? And regarding Fast and Furious, with Congress and Mexico still awaiting answers, will there be changes in ATF leadership? When can we expect the investigation's findings? [SEP] Regarding the second point, my Attorney General has stated unequivocally that he would not have approved gun running into Mexico. The investigation is still underway, and I will refrain from commenting on it. Once the investigation concludes, appropriate measures will be taken. As for E-Verify, we require comprehensive immigration reform. We must uphold our heritage as a nation of laws and immigrants. This necessitates robust border security, targeting employers who illegally hire and exploit workers, and providing a pathway to legal status for those living in the shadows. While we may not achieve everything we desire in a single package, a balanced approach is crucial. E-Verify can be a valuable enforcement tool if it is accurate and protects U.S. citizens. We must prevent errors that harm qualified candidates. Our aim is to refine E-Verify and implement safeguards. Furthermore, we must address the situation of DREAM Act children, who deserve the opportunity to contribute to our nation. A verification system alone is inadequate.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Are you saying that you have made a decision to apply further sanctions, but you just have to wait for a technical process to play out? Or are you saying you have not made the decision yet to levy those sanctions? [SEP] What I'm saying is, is that we have prepared for the possibility of applying additional sanctions, that there are a whole bunch of technical issues behind that; that there's always the possibility that Russia, tomorrow or the next day, reverses course and takes a different approach, which, by the way, would simply involve them stating clearly that they actually believe in what they said in Geneva, that they actually call on those who are holding buildings in the south and the east of Ukraine to get out of those buildings, that they are encouraged by the willingness of the Kiev Government to follow through on amnesty, that they allow OSCE monitors in, and that they support an election process where Ukrainians are able to make their own decisions. So it wouldn't require a radical shift. It would require the kinds of steps that, on paper at least, they already agreed to as recently as last week.Do I think they're going to do that? So far, the evidence doesn't make me hopeful. And I think it's fair to say that, as we've said earlier this week, this is a matter of days and not weeks. Assuming that they do not follow through, we will follow through on what we said, which is that there will be additional consequences on the Russians. First of all, my basic recognition of history is such that politicians have to have a sense of humility when it comes to history. Japan, 70 years ago in the war—when the war ended, to many persons, especially persons in Asia, we had inflicted tremendous damage and pain. And we are—have reflected on this, and we started our work after the war. For 70 years, as a peace-loving nation, we have steadily tread the path, and that is Japan, and that is the Japanese public.We—ever since we were poor, we tried to contribute to Asia. We made our maximum efforts, even when we were poor. And many nations in Asia have evaluated highly Japan's work. In the Abe Government, there is no change in stance compared to previous Governments. Last year's end, I visited Yasukuni, and to those that have fought for the country and that have been wounded, that have passed away, I have prayed and prayed for the souls of such persons. That was the purpose of my visit to the shrine.And many leaders of the world share this common attitude, I believe. And at the same time, in Yasukuni Shrine, there is a remembrance memorial called Chinreisha, and I visited this memorial. This has not been reported much, but in this memorial, those who have passed away as a result of the war—not only Japanese, but those from all over the world—are honored there. So I have visited this memorial so that never again people would suffer in wars. I renewed my resolve to create such a society and such a world, and I have renewed my pledge not to engage in war. And I have released a statement to that effect.To my—with regard to my basic thinking, I will continue to explain and make efforts so that people will understand. I should like to accumulate such efforts. After the war, in order to create a democratic and free nation, we have made tremendous efforts, and we have respected persons—human rights, and we have valued the rule of law not only in Japan, but in the world. We want to increase regions of this kind.And so we would like to accumulate efforts toward this end: peace and a prosperous world. In order to build such a world, we would like to contribute. And by so doing, I hope that many countries of the world would understand.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, critics argue that your actions set a poor example for the nation. How do you respond to this criticism? [SEP] That's just wrong. It's a political activity. There are exceptions for political activity. You're misinformed.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Thank you. Mr. President, Mr. Prime Minister, the war in Iraq—if we could stay on that subject for just a minute—I mean, it's been going on for almost 5 years. Is there anything you would have done differently, Mr. President, if you had known back then in 2003 what you know today? [SEP] That's an interesting question. One thing I wouldn't do differently is leave Saddam Hussein in power. It was the right decision then; it's the right decision today; and it will be viewed as the right decision when history is finally written.You know, I—look, I mean, there's going to be ample time to second-guess decisions, and I'll let the historians do that. A war is constantly changing, and what appears to have been an easy decision today might have been a lot difficult when you take it—put it in historical context. And so my focus, sir, is moving forward and making sure this progress that we're watching continues.And there's been some ups and downs, obviously. I mean, the great moments were, of course, the writing of a modern Constitution for the Middle East and votes for a President and a Parliament. And then 2006 came along, and an enemy was able to stir up unbelievable sectarian hatred and violence. And so I had a choice to make, you know, accept it and allow for failure, or do something about it. And obviously, I chose the latter, which was—I wouldn't call that exactly a popular decision. But if you follow popularity as your guide, then you sacrifice principle and vision.And so, look, this is a—this will be an important chapter of my Presidency, and they'll be analyzing these decisions for a long time. And I just got to tell you, I've got great faith in the capacity of democracy to be transformative, not only for the people of Iraq but for the region. And that's why we're discussing with the Iraqis a long-term security agreement, to have a—have the kind of effect that will enable people to be confident to make hard decisions when it comes to reconciliation and political progress.But the historians, I'm sure, will find ample—well, there's some short-term historians already trying to find some ample opportunity to figure out what went right or what went wrong, what we could have done differently. But there's no such thing as accurate short-term history, as far as I'm concerned. There needs to be time for people to be able to see and put things in proper perspective.Michael [Mike Emanuel, FOX News].
label: Deflection

sentence: Sir, concerning the chemical weapons threat, do we have concrete intel indicating Putin's readiness to use them? And if he does, what's our military play? [SEP] Look, I can't get into the nitty-gritty of intelligence. That's just not how it works. But let me tell you this: if he uses those weapons, we will react. How we react depends on what he does, plain and simple.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, has the conflict in Afghanistan reached its conclusion? Is the Taliban now in control? Furthermore, what is the rationale behind the renomination of Congressman John Ratcliffe? [SEP] Well, he's a terrific man. He's been fantastic at everything he's done. He's highly respected. He wanted to wait until after the IG report came in, as you saw originally. I don't think he was officially or formally nominated. His name was thrown out. But he wanted to wait until after the IG report. The IG report has now come, and we've learned a lot of very bad things from the IG report, as you know very well.And I think he'll go through a process, and it will go fairly quickly. He's a very respected man, somebody that I've gotten that like; somebody who really has—he's someone who's really distinguished himself and, I think, over the last year and a half, 2 years, in particular. So we're very happy with that.As far as the Taliban is concerned, everybody wanted this to happen. The Taliban wanted it to happen. President Ghani was very much involved in this, as you know. And he's now dealing with the Taliban.But we're talking about 19 years we've been there. Nineteen years. And other Presidents have tried to do this. The Taliban has given a pledge—and a very strong pledge—and we'll see how that all works out. We hope it's going to work out very well. I think they have big incentives to do it, but they have to take care of the terrorists and kill the terrorists. We'll be working in a different kind of a fashion toward that end.But the job we've done has been fantastic—a fantastic one in terms of terrorists and terrorism, and it's time for our people to start coming home.
label: Deflection

sentence: Given the concerns about election integrity, do you believe the 2022 midterms accurately reflected the will of the American people, and what specific steps are you advocating to prevent future irregularities? [SEP] Look, the vast majority of Republicans I know are good, decent people. We may disagree on policy, but they're not trying to undermine democracy. The world is watching us, wondering if we're still the stable democracy we've always been. Remember the G7 meeting? They asked me, 'How long will America be back?' That's the real question. Are we going to accept the decisions made by our courts, by Congress, by the government?
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, can you confirm or deny the Washington Post's report that the White House is holding up the coronavirus bill to include funding for a new FBI building? [SEP] I'm not sure if it's in this particular bill, but a new FBI building is definitely on the table. The current one is ancient, frankly, and not up to par. It's a safety hazard with panels falling off and concrete crumbling. They're considering building on the existing site, which I support because it needs to be near the Justice Department. Some suggested locations in Maryland and Virginia, but those were too remote. I've been pushing for a new building, a state-of-the-art facility that will last for a century. We could even put a running track on top for the agents. Whether it's in this bill or another, the FBI needs a new headquarters, and we're going to make it happen.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: President Trump, considering the election outcome, do you acknowledge any need to re-evaluate your administration's approach to engaging with diverse communities across America, particularly those who may feel marginalized or underserved? [SEP] Well, the facts are clear. Employment numbers for African Americans, Asian Americans, and Hispanic Americans are at a historic high. A recent poll indicated that my approval ratings among Hispanics and African Americans are the highest they've ever been. That poll was released just a few days ago. Median income is up, and all the employment numbers are excellent. It's all reflected in the polls. Yes, go ahead.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, given the Republican nominee's recent remarks about the Khan family and his suggestion of potentially recognizing Russia's annexation of Crimea, do you question his qualifications to be President? And secondly, sir, on Libya. You've previously indicated that your biggest regret might have been the failure to plan for the aftermath of the 2011 NATO intervention. Is your recent decision to bomb ISIS there a direct result of that? [SEP] Well, I've already expressed my concerns about the Republican nominee's suitability for the presidency, and frankly, he continues to reinforce those concerns. Attacking a Gold Star family who have made extraordinary sacrifices for our country is simply unacceptable. His apparent lack of understanding of critical issues in Europe, the Middle East, and Asia suggests a profound lack of preparation for this role. And this isn't just my assessment; leading Republicans, including the Speaker of the House, the Senate Majority Leader, and prominent figures like John McCain, have repeatedly denounced his statements. The question they must ask themselves is this: If you consistently and vehemently condemn his words, why do you continue to endorse him? What message does it send about your party that he is your standard-bearer? This isn't a matter of occasional gaffes; it's a recurring pattern where they distance themselves from his pronouncements. There must come a point where they say, 'This is not someone I can support for President,' even if he identifies as a member of my party. Their failure to do so renders their condemnations somewhat hollow. I don't doubt their sincerity, but there must be a point where they acknowledge that someone who makes such statements lacks the judgment, temperament, and understanding necessary for the most powerful position in the world. Many people depend on the White House to make sound decisions, and this transcends mere policy disagreements. I understand that they profoundly disagree with me or Hillary Clinton on tax policy or foreign policy, but I never questioned the competence of previous Republican Presidents. I disagreed with Mitt Romney and John McCain on certain issues, but I never doubted their ability to perform the job. Had they won, I would have been disappointed, but I would have assured Americans that they would uphold norms, rules, common sense, decency, and possess sufficient knowledge of economic policy, foreign policy, and our constitutional traditions to govern effectively. This situation is different, and it's not just my opinion. Many prominent Republicans share this view. There must come a point where they say, 'Enough.' Otherwise, the entire Republican Party effectively endorses and validates Mr. Trump's positions, which I believe do not represent the views of many Republicans. Regarding Libya, I've consistently stated that we did the right thing in preventing a potential massacre under a U.N. mandate. However, we collectively failed to adequately plan for the aftermath to ensure security and peace. The positive development is that we now have the beginnings of a Government of National Accord committed to uniting factions and establishing security. At their request, and after significant progress against ISIS, we are working in partnership to prevent ISIS from gaining a foothold in Libya. They recognize ISIS as a threat to their national interests, and we hope that after defeating ISIS, they can unite the country. The Europeans and other nations also have a vested interest in Libyan stability, which is crucial for addressing migration crises and humanitarian tragedies.
label: Implicit

sentence: Secretary of Homeland Security says he has a 'gut feeling' of an imminent threat this summer, despite a lack of credible intelligence. How comfortable are you with that statement, and what does your gut tell you? [SEP] Look, I take the threat seriously. My gut tells me we gotta be ready. We gotta have good intel, quick response, and keep the pressure on these guys overseas. They want to hurt us, and we gotta stop them. This is a long fight, a battle of ideas. They want to control the world, and we want to spread freedom. That's why we gotta stay strong and defend ourselves.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the recently passed energy legislation co-sponsored with Speaker Pelosi and Senator Reid, which aims to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, your administration simultaneously restricted California's ability to enforce stricter tailpipe emission standards. Could you clarify the importance you place on combating greenhouse gases, why states are being prevented from exceeding national standards, and if you've discussed climate change with Vice President Gore recently? [SEP] Let's be clear: the objective is an *effective* strategy. The question isn't *if* we act, but *how*. Is a patchwork of state regulations more effective than a unified national approach? Director Johnson's decision reflects the fact that the new legislation provides a national framework, specifically increased CAFE standards and alternative fuel mandates. This offers a coherent, nationwide solution. My conversation with Vice President Gore was about the seriousness with which I take this issue. We are crafting a strategy, and yesterday's bill is a component. Replacing gasoline with alternative fuels will significantly reduce greenhouse gases. While I favored a stronger bill, I was pleased to sign it. A key element is investment in cellulosic ethanol research; we can't rely solely on corn. This is a comprehensive national plan. Furthermore, global participation is essential. My opposition to Kyoto stemmed from China's exclusion. We need major emitters at the table. Our approach, outlined at the G-8 and Bali, seeks a consensus-based goal. I take this seriously, but we must act effectively without crippling our economy. Technological innovation is key, and prosperity is necessary for investment. Nuclear power, a carbon-free energy source, should be strongly supported. Combining CAFE standards, alternative fuels, and nuclear power creates a robust strategy. We also possess vast coal reserves, and we must develop environmentally sound technologies to utilize them. In short, we have a strategy: engaging others, developing a national plan, and pursuing international goals. You've heard some of the key elements.
label: General

sentence: President Trump, with the understanding that the JCPOA has been abandoned, what specific alternative strategies are being pursued to contain Iran's regional influence and prevent further destabilization of the Middle East? [SEP] The whole Middle East equation, if you look at what's happened, if you've looked at the stupidity of decisions that were made, including the deal that was made—I mean, take a look at what happened with Iran. Had that deal stayed and had I not broken that deal, you could have never done the deal that I'm doing now where all the countries are pouring in. I had two calls this morning with countries; they want to know, When can we go into the deal? They want security, they want peace, and they're really tired of fighting. It's incredible. They're tired of fighting. They've been fighting for so many years. They're tired of fighting.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, could you elaborate on the timeline for achieving comfort in your role, considering the economic crisis you inherited? [SEP] Time for ease? There was none. We were hemorrhaging jobs. My experience was, let's say, atypical. FDR had a Depression already in progress. We were in a free fall, banks failing, the auto industry on the brink, housing collapsed. I was simply too occupied to ponder my comfort level. We had to act. The next administration inherits a nation with problems, but also with strengths: low unemployment, rising incomes, stable markets. They have the luxury of time, a testament to my team's efforts.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, Senator McConnell's office has characterized the CARES II relief package as precisely tailored for this phase of the crisis, yet it conspicuously lacks your proposed payroll tax cut. Given this omission, do you still maintain that the package is perfectly tailored to meet the needs of the American people during this challenging time? [SEP] Well, let me be clear, I am a strong advocate for a payroll tax cut. I believe it would provide significant relief to the hardworking men and women of this country. However, the Democrats have made it abundantly clear that they are unwilling to support such a measure. They appear to be out of touch with the needs of the working class. Therefore, I informed the Republicans last night – who have been diligently working on this package and are committed to serving the best interests of the nation – that while I believe a payroll tax cut would be highly beneficial, it is unlikely to garner Democratic support. As you are aware, we require their votes to enact this legislation. While we hold a majority, it is insufficient to overcome their opposition. That is precisely why we have an election on the horizon. So, we must secure Democratic votes, and it is evident that we will not obtain them on this particular issue. I firmly believe it would provide a substantial boost to the American worker. But if we are unable to secure their support, we must proceed with the understanding that a payroll tax cut is not currently feasible. It would have been a transformative measure. Perhaps circumstances will change in the future.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Mr. President——The President's Upcoming Meeting With President Vladimir Vladimirovich Putin of Russia  Q. Kreeta Karvala from Finland. What would be the best deal with Putin when you come to Helsinki? And don't you think that your harsh diplomacy—that you are playing in the same goal—to the same goal that Putin, with your harsh diplomacy towards EU and NATO? [SEP] Well, I can't tell you what would be the ultimate. What would be the ultimate? Well, let's see: No more nuclear weapons anywhere in the world would be the ultimate, okay? No more wars, no more problems, no more conflict. Let's find a cure to every disease known to mankind or womankind. [] That would be my ultimate, okay? And we'll start from there.Okay. Yes, go ahead.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, with your term ending, who specifically will sign the agreement? Who has the power now? [SEP] Look, we have a very talented group of people representing us. They're fully briefed, fully prepared, and they have the authority to act. The framework is in place, and they'll handle the final steps. Believe me, they will.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, with the Democrats already eyeing 2020, can we expect to see Vice President Pence on the ticket with you again? [SEP] I haven't formally extended the invitation, but I certainly hope he accepts! Mike, will you be my running mate? Please rise! Raise your right hand! Just a bit of humor! Will you? Excellent! The answer is affirmative!
label: Dodging

sentence: Sir, given the detrimental impact and financial burden, why not just terminate it outright? [SEP] Let's move on. I've already given my answer.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. What happened with the peace process between Israel and Palestine? [SEP] Go ahead. Please. Please.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. Are you worried this might dampen enthusiasm for you? [SEP] Look, we've done a great job. We built the greatest economy in the world. Nobody close, not China, not anybody. We had to close it, we saved millions of lives, then we opened it. But we had the best numbers in history for African Americans, Hispanic Americans, Asian Americans, every group you want to name: young people without a diploma, young people with a high school diploma, with a college diploma. Anything you want to name, we had the best numbers. Women doing incredibly. Never been a time like that.And we had to turn it off because of what China did. We had to turn it off. And then, all of the sudden, now we turn it back on, and we're doing very well. But it was very bad.China—speaking about China—the trade deal means less to me now than it did when I made it. When I made it, it was a great deal. But they're setting records. Yesterday was a record corn day. They purchased more corn than any order ever, and that went on for 2 or 3 days. And soy beans and all. But it just means much less to me. Can you understand that? It just means much less to me.Please, go ahead.
label: General

sentence: Q. Given your impending departure, Mr. President, who is now empowered to sign this agreement on behalf of the United States? [SEP] We have a capable team of negotiators here. While I may not be the leader present at the final moment, they are fully authorized to sign off, especially given that the vast majority of the text has been finalized.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, regarding General Neller's statement to marines in Norway about a potential 'big-ass fight,' how soon do you foresee this war, and in what location? [SEP] You mentioned 'the big war' - what exactly are you referring to? Please clarify.
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, concerning Benghazi, despite all the investigations, some State Department officials allege they've been blocked from telling their stories. Will you help them come forward and finally set the record straight? [SEP] Ed, I'm not aware of anyone being blocked from testifying. I'll check into what you're talking about. My focus on Benghazi has been to find out what happened, make sure our embassies are safe, and bring the bad guys to justice. But I'll look into those claims.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Regarding President Carter's discussions with Hamas, did they yield any positive outcomes? Furthermore, did your administration discourage him from engaging in these talks, and will they influence your upcoming visit to the Middle East? [SEP] With all due respect, I haven't personally spoken with President Carter on this matter, and therefore, I lack specific knowledge of the conversations that transpired. I remain skeptical about Hamas's willingness to change, as their actions often contradict their words. This pattern has been evident throughout my administration. While I supported the initial elections that brought them to power, their failure to deliver for the people of Gaza is deeply concerning. My focus during my upcoming trip is to collaborate with both Israelis and President Abbas to foster a shared vision and empower Palestinians in the West Bank through security and economic initiatives. While I remain hopeful for an agreement by the end of my presidency, the persistent rocket attacks by Hamas, aimed at destabilizing the region, pose a significant challenge. Ultimately, the effectiveness of any dialogue with Hamas will be judged by their future behavior.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. All right. Let me go back to immigration. Moments before you walked out here, sir, Mitch McConnell said, and I quote, that if you in fact use your executive authority to legalize a certain number of millions of undocumented workers, it would poison the well—direct quote—and it would be like waving a red flag in front of a bull. Do you not believe that is the considered opinion of the new Republican majority in the House and Senate? And do you also not believe what they have said in the aftermath of last night's results, that the verdict rendered by voters should stop you or should prevent you from taking this action because it was a subtext in many of the campaigns? [SEP] Yes.
label: General

sentence: Q. Mr. Bush, how can you say nothing has changed when you may see it this way, but the rest of the world is going to see the lead as the fact that the nuclear weapons program was halted in 2003? [SEP] Right.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, just to clarify, are you actively considering ways to remove the current President as part of this political transition? [SEP] I'm relying on Mitch McConnell's assurance that the government won't shut down. There's no reason for it. We've been down that road before. It hurt the country and every elected official in Washington. Ultimately, it was resolved the same way it would have been without the shutdown. So, it's unproductive, and I believe Leader McConnell and Speaker Boehner understand that. This brings up a broader point I've made before: Disagreement is inherent in democracy. Our system, unlike a parliamentary one, allows for a Congress of one party and a President of another, leading to fundamental disagreements. The question is, how do we manage that? The sensible approach is to identify areas of disagreement, fight hard for our positions, and then collaborate on areas of agreement. That's how it's always been, even with Ronald Reagan and a Democratic Congress. Democrats didn't refuse to work with Reagan on Social Security or tax reform just because they disagreed on other issues. They fought on those issues, collaborated on others, and the country progressed. I expect the same attitude now. I understand that some Republicans strongly disagree with me, law enforcement, the evangelical community, and even other Republicans on immigration reform. They've made their views clear, and they have the right to argue their position and oppose legislation. But shutting down the government over it makes as little sense as me shutting down the government if they vote to repeal healthcare reform for the umpteenth time. I understand there's a difference, but let's focus on doing the people's work.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. You're inclined to pull the troops out? [SEP] I want to get out. I want to bring our troops back home. I want to start rebuilding our Nation. We will have, as of 3 months ago, $7 trillion in the Middle East over the last 17 years. We get nothing—nothing—out of it. Nothing. And as you remember in civilian life, for years I said, Keep the oil. I was always saying, Keep the oil. We didn't keep the oil. Who got the oil? It was ISIS got the oil, a lot of it. That's what funded their campaigns. They took a lot of the oil, and it was largely responsible for funding. We should have kept the oil then. We didn't keep the oil.So I want to get back. I want to rebuild our Nation. Think of it: $7 trillion over a 17-year period; we have nothing—nothing—except death and destruction. It's a horrible thing. So it's time. It's time. We were very successful against ISIS. We'll be successful against anybody militarily. But sometimes, it's time to come back home, and we're thinking about that very seriously. Okay? Thank you.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, Americans are hurting from rising prices. How long will this last? And given the constraints on your administration, can you truly make a difference in tackling inflation? [SEP] The issue is the supply chain. That's what's causing inflation. We're making progress on that. The chip shortage is a major problem, especially for cars. We're working to become self-sufficient in chip production. Energy prices are more complex. We convinced countries to release oil reserves, which helped a little. But it's going to be difficult.
