We need more competition in the meat industry, too. And Build Back Better would actually lower inflation, according to experts.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, considering the ongoing crisis in Haiti, critics argue that the current approach is inadequate and lacks the urgency needed to address the dire situation. What specific benchmarks will you use to measure the effectiveness of the police training program, and what contingency plans are in place if the situation continues to deteriorate despite these efforts? [SEP] Well, we're taking a multifaceted approach to Haiti. The situation there is incredibly complex, as you know, with gangs essentially controlling the country. Our focus right now is on strengthening the Haitian National Police, giving them the resources and training they need to restore order. We're also working with international partners to explore other options, including a potential role for the United Nations. This is a long-term project, and there are no easy solutions. But we are committed to working with the Haitian people to build a more stable and secure future.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: President Bush, regarding visa-free travel for Estonians, when will you propose this change to Congress? And what steps should Estonia take to expedite this process? [SEP] We're working on the 3-percent requirement while assuring Congress that visa waiver changes won't compromise our security. This process is starting soon. Estonia constantly raises this question. I had a long discussion back when I was a delegate in European Parliament. We've come a long way from 2 years ago with Nick Burns. Once security requirements are clarified, we'll implement them in our passports. It's a technical problem, but resolvable.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. And are you—do you fear that this could be your Herbert Hoover moment if you do not reach a deal with Congress to set up a new CARES Act? [SEP] No, we are not allowing that to happen. We're stopping evictions. We are stopping evictions. We're not going to let that happen.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, many analysts and some former members of your administration believe that the kind of negotiated political settlement that you say is necessary in Syria will require working directly with Iran and giving Iran an important role. Do you agree? And is that a dialogue you'll be actively seeking? And what about the fight against ISIS? What would it take for there to be explicit cooperation between the U.S. and Iran? [SEP] Well, let's be clear, solving the mess in Syria requires everyone at the table: Russians, Iranians, Turks, and our Gulf partners. It's a chaotic situation with too many factions, too much money, and too many weapons flooding in. It's a mix of sectarian conflict and geopolitical maneuvering. To fix it, the major powers interested in Syria need to agree that it can't be won on the battlefield. Iran's a key player, and they need to be part of the conversation. Now, let me reiterate, we haven't restored normal diplomatic relations with Iran, and I don't see that happening anytime soon. So, I don't foresee formal agreements with Iran on our counter-ISIS campaign. However, Iran has influence in Iraq, which has a majority Shia population. They have relationships, some natural, with Iran. We expect Prime Minister Abadi to work with Iran as a neighbor. But some relationships are less legitimate, like Iran funding Shia militias that have killed American soldiers and might commit atrocities in Sunni areas. Our diplomats and military teams are assessing where we can deconflict and work with Abadi on an overall strategy for Iraq to regain its sovereignty. We're also telling Abadi when Iran's actions are a problem and we can't cooperate unless those folks are removed. These conversations are ongoing. You can count on any U.S. government or military work in Iraq with other partners being based on the idea that they report to the Iraqi government and security forces. If we don't trust that Abadi is directing those soldiers, it's tough to have any direct relationship. Got it?
label: General

sentence: Q. To be clear, this is positive for business and the environment, but doesn't require your signature - is that right? [SEP] I'm sorry, I'm not quite following. Could you please rephrase your question?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Mr. President—— Q. To follow on that, if he tries to dodge the questions or doesn't address them head on, are you prepared with the facts and information to answer that for the American people? [SEP] Well, I have all the information. It just came out. I mean, I didn't know about Moscow: $3½ million from the mayor's wife. I didn't know about that. And he's a very influential, powerful man in Russia, as you know. And it wasn't me; I didn't have anything to do with Russia. That came out loud and clear.What also came out is they should have never gone into this fake Mueller investigation. And it also came out that the 31 phones that were wiped clean shouldn't have been wiped clean. And that's a criminal act.And Bloomberg likewise shouldn't be paying for prisoners to go—in Florida—go and vote, because he's basically paying—which is totally illegal—going and paying prisoners. I hope he hasn't done it yet. But he's down in writing as doing it. This is what he wants to do so that he can ingratiate himself to the Democrats after they made him look like a total fool in the debate.I mean, what they did to him is incredible. And that he goes out and spends money, it shows you the problems that he's got. Mini Mike.But for him to go out and buy votes, because that's—I don't know, you're very good lawyer. I am. . Are you allowed to go tell people that: Go vote. I'm going to pay off your tab? You certainly can't buy votes, that's for sure. . Yes, because that's what it is. I mean, it's a very serious—a very serious charge.Yes, please go ahead.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Thank you, sir. A two-part question: The New Yorker reports that the Red Cross has found the interrogation program in the CIA detention facilities used interrogation techniques that were tantamount to torture. I'm wondering if you have read that report and what your reaction to it is. And the second part of the question is, more than a year ago, you said that you wanted to close the detention facility at Guantanamo, and a year later, nothing has actually happened in that regard. Your Vice President, Attorney General, and Homeland Security Secretary are reported to be resisting such a move. I wonder if you could tell us who's really in charge on this issue. Are you doing anything about it? Do you expect Guantanamo to be open or closed when you leave office? [SEP] I did say it should be a goal of the Nation to shut down Guantanamo. I also made it clear that part of the delay was the reluctance of some nations to take back some of the people being held there. In other words, in order to make it work, we've got to have a place for these people to go. I don't know if you noticed a resolution of the Senate the other day, where all but three Senators said we don't want these prisoners in the country. I don't know if it was a 97-3 vote, but it was something-to-3 vote. In other words, part of the issue, Peter, is the practical issue of what do we do with the people?And you say nothing has taken place. I strongly disagree with that. First of all, we are working with other nations to send folks back. Again, it's a fairly steep order. A lot of people don't want killers in their midst, and a lot of these people are killers. Secondly, of course, we want to make sure that when we do send them back, they're treated as humanely as possible.The other issue was whether or not we can get people to be tried. One of the things I'm anxious about, want to see happen, is that there to be trials. Courts have been involved with deciding how to do this, and Defense is trying to work out mechanisms to get the trials up and running. And the sooner we can get that up and running, the better it is, as far as I'm concerned. I don't want to make any predictions about whether Guantanamo will be available or not. I'm just telling you it's a very complicated subject.And I laid out an aspiration. Whether or not we can achieve that or not, we'll try to. But it is not as easy a subject as some may think on the surface. Again, I refer to you to the Senate vote. When asked whether or not you want to shut down Guantanamo and, therefore, receive some of those prisoners in your home State, there didn't seem to be a lot of support for it. Like, three people said, It's okay by me, in the Senate.Your other question, sir?
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Mr. President, with all due respect, why did you single me out regarding the China question? [SEP] I'm not singling anyone out. I'm responding to the question. If you ask a question that seems to imply something negative, expect a direct answer.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, considering the current political climate, are you concerned that your legacy will be tarnished by the actions of your successor? Do you feel a responsibility to speak out against policies that you believe are harmful to the country? [SEP] My legacy will be judged by history. I'm confident that the American people will remember the progress we made together and the challenges we overcame. I will continue to speak out on issues that I care about, but I believe it's important to respect the outcome of the election and give my successor the opportunity to lead.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Ghislaine Maxwell is in prison. Do you think she will implicate powerful individuals? You've previously commented on Prince Andrew and Bill Clinton. [SEP] I haven't been following that too closely. I just wish her well. I've met her a few times, especially when I lived in Palm Beach. I don't know the situation with Prince Andrew; I'm not aware of it. Next question.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: In your opinion, would a resolution involving Putin's departure be considered a win for the United States? [SEP] The essential element is his removal from directing armed conflict against the people. He must vacate his office. That's the necessary condition.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Regarding Build Back Better, you mentioned passing 'big chunks' this year. Does this imply a shift towards breaking the package into smaller, individual bills? Also, following the Supreme Court's decision on the vaccination-or-test rule, are you considering mandating vaccines for domestic flights to increase vaccination rates? [SEP] Let's address the latter point first. The Supreme Court's ruling was, in my opinion, misguided. However, many corporations are still implementing testing requirements. As for Build Back Better, what aspect of it are you most concerned with?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, to be blunt, are you prepared to sacrifice legalization in favor of a mandatory E-Verify bill? And what specific steps are you taking to ensure transparency and accountability in the Fast and Furious investigation? [SEP] My position is well-documented. We need a comprehensive solution to immigration. The Attorney General is handling the ATF investigation, and I trust him to deliver a thorough and impartial report.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. And what about your own family, Mr. President? [SEP] Pardon?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. So it's up to lawmakers? [SEP] So it's up to lawmakers. But my hope and intention is, when we resolve this problem, I'd find a rationale to take it to the courts to see whether or not the 14th Amendment is, in fact, something that would be able to stop it.Thank you. Okay, the press conference has concluded. Thanks, everybody. Thank you, everyone.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. So will you keep that going through September even if there isn't? [SEP] Martha, as I mentioned in my opening remarks, we have felt all along that the security situation needed to change in order for there to be political progress. It's very hard for a young democracy to function with the violence that was raging. Secondly, there's a lot of the past that needs to be worked through the system. I mean, there's—living under the brutal tyrant Saddam Hussein created a lot of anxiety and a lot of tensions and a lot of rivalry, and it's just—it's going to take a while to work it through. But they couldn't work through those tensions and rivalries in the midst of serious violence.And so the strategy was, move in more troops to cause the violence to abate. And that's what David Petraeus will be reporting on.Yes, Jim [Jim Axelrod, CBS News].
label: Implicit

sentence: President Obama, many feel that by commuting Chelsea Manning's sentence, you are essentially giving a green light to future leakers of classified information, particularly those who may collaborate with entities hostile to the United States, such as WikiLeaks. Can you assure the American public that this decision will not compromise national security or embolden further acts of espionage? [SEP] With all due respect, the premise of your question is flawed. Chelsea Manning served a substantial sentence, and that fact alone should deter anyone contemplating similar actions. My decision was based on the specific circumstances of her case, including the length of her sentence relative to others and her acceptance of responsibility. It was not a blanket endorsement of leaking classified information. We must protect national security, but we also need to ensure that justice is served fairly. Regarding WikiLeaks, the intelligence community's findings on Russian hacking were not conclusive about their role in the DNC email leak. I don't base my decisions on Julian Assange's pronouncements. The Justice Department will handle any legal issues related to him. We must find the right balance between transparency and security in the digital age. I believe my decision in Manning's case was the right one, given all the factors involved.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, concerning Kimberly and Don Jr.'s outreach to the Indian American community, will they and Ivanka Trump campaign on your behalf, sharing your perspectives on the India-U.S. relationship? [SEP] I must confess, I didn't grasp everything you said. However, I'm familiar with India, and I understand those young individuals you mentioned are quite capable. Their connection to India is strong, as is mine. Prime Minister Modi is a friend, and he's performing admirably, despite the challenges. Speaking of which, China and India are currently engaged in a significant border dispute, which is quite unpleasant. We stand ready to assist in any way we can, and we're in communication with both countries regarding this matter. I appreciate your kind sentiments. They hold India in high regard, as do I. And I have great respect for your Prime Minister. Thank you.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. How about will my Korean friends allow me to ask a question on your behalf? Yes or no? [SEP] Well, it depends on whether there's a Korean reporter who would rather have the question. No, no takers?
label: Deflection

sentence: President Trump, critics argue that your public criticism of Prime Minister May's Brexit plan undermined the special relationship between the U.S. and the U.K. How do you respond to those criticisms, and what steps are you taking to repair any potential damage? [SEP] The relationship is fantastic, the best it's ever been. I have tremendous respect for the Prime Minister. We just want to make sure we can trade, that's all. Some people try to make a big deal out of nothing, you know, fake news. But we're working together, and we're going to have a great trade deal. Believe me.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, during your meetings today, did you discuss the possibility of Canada increasing its stimulus plans? And for both of you, what do you think the Canada-U.S. relationship will look like in 4 years? What will the auto sector look like? Will the border be thicker or thinner? And will you have a carbon market? [SEP] Wow, you really packed a lot in there, didn't you? [] Did you get that from Jonathan? []
label: Clarification

sentence: President Uribe, amidst all the talk surrounding Chavez, would you offer your perspective on whether his regional influence is, in your estimation, being overstated? [SEP] Remind me, what is it you're asking my opinion about?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Just to be clear, do you believe the atomic bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki were justified? [SEP] Hold on, let's rewind. You're asking about the bombings, and...?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Hi, I'm Kristin Brown with Fox News. On your upcoming summit with President Putin, did any of your allies here express any specific concerns or talk to you about any messages that they'd like you to take with you when you go to the summit? [SEP] Yes. Just the opposite of concern. They actually—and they'll probably come out with a little bit of an edict—but they actually thanked me for meeting with President Putin. I look forward to the meeting. They thanked me. They thought it was a great thing that I was doing it. And they gave us our best wishes, or their best wishes.Now, with that being said, we'll see that happens. Just a loose meeting. It's not going to be big schedule. I don't think it should take a very long period of time. And we'll see where it leads. But it could lead to productive—something very productive. And maybe it's not.But I think meeting with people is great. We had a great meeting with Chairman Kim. And I'll tell you, Mike Pompeo did a fantastic job. I might ask you to say a few words, Mike, while you're here.Just 1 second. Mike, go ahead. I'm done. Yes, sir. Thank you, Mr. President. So, I did. I returned—I actually came straight from with a couple of stops here to Brussels. We had a productive conversation. There remains a great deal of work to do, but I think, most importantly, my counterpart, Kim Yong Chol, made a commitment consistent with what President Trump was able to achieve with Chairman Kim, which was: They intend to denuclearize. They're going to accomplish it. And now the task is to get it implemented.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Mr. President, thank you very much. Since your philosophy is so different from President-elect Obama's, what concerns you the most about what he may attempt to do? [SEP] You know, Michael, I'm not going to speculate about what he's going to do. It's going to be—you know, he's going to get in the Oval Office, he's going to analyze each situation, and he's going to make the decisions that he think is necessary.And the other thing is, when I get out of here, I'm getting off the stage. I believe there ought to be, you know, one person in the klieg lights at a time. And I've had my time in the klieg lights. You know, I'm confident, you know, you'll catch me opining on occasion, but I wish him all the best.And people say, Oh, you just—that's just a throwaway line. No, it's not a throwaway line. The stakes are high. There is an enemy that still is out there. You know, people can maybe try to write that off as, you know, he's trying to set something up. I'm telling you there's an enemy that would like to attack America, Americans again. There just is. That's the reality of the world. And I wish him all the very best.And of course, he's going to have his hands full with the economy. I understand. It's tough for a lot of working people out there. People are concerned about their economic future. You know, one of the very difficult parts of the decision I made on the financial crisis was to use hard-working people's money to help prevent there to be a crisis, and in so doing, some of that money went into Wall Street firms that caused the crisis in the first place. I wasn't kidding when I said Wall Street got drunk and we got the hangover. And—but nevertheless, President-elect Obama will find the problems and the situations surrounding problems sometimes cause people to have to make decisions that they, you know, weren't initially comfortable with. And there was such a decision when it came to Wall Street.I mean, I had a lot of people—when I went out to Midland that time—say, What the heck are you doing, boy? Those people up East caused the problem. I said, I know, but if we hadn't worked to fix the problem, your situation would be worse. And anyway, I really do wish him all the best.Sheryl [Sheryl Gay Stolberg, New York Times].
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, with respect to the library's funding, you've presented several questions about the $200 million target, donor transparency, and contribution limits. Could you please specify which facet you'd like me to elaborate on? [SEP] Easy there, partner! That's a loaded question with multiple parts. [] No, yes, undecided, and it depends. [] I'm still reviewing the budget. My foundation will handle the donor disclosures. Some donors prefer privacy, you understand. So, we'll take that into account. What else did you want to know?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Asked about the drive to take action in light of what happened in Oregon, he said: Look, stuff happens. There's always a crisis. And the impulse is always to do something, and it's not always the right thing to do. How would you react to Governor Bush? [SEP] I don't even think I have to react to that one [] I think the American people should hear that and make their own judgments, based on the fact that every couple of months, we have a mass shooting, and in terms of—and they can decide whether they consider that stuff happeningIn terms of what I can do, I've asked my team—as I have in the past—to scrub what kinds of authorities do we have to enforce the laws that we have in place more effectively to keep guns out of the hands of criminals Are there additional actions that we can take that might prevent even a handful of these tragic deaths from taking place? But as I said last night, this will not change until the politics changes and the behavior of elected officials changesAnd so the main thing I'm going to do is, I'm going to talk about this on a regular basis, and I will politicize it because our inaction is a political decision that we are makingThe reason that Congress does not support even the modest gun safety laws that we proposed after Sandy Hook is not because the majority of the American people don't support it I mean, normally, politicians are responsive to the views of the electorate Here you've got the majority of the American people think it's the right thing to do Background checks, other commonsense steps that would maybe save some lives couldn't even get a full vote And why is that? It's because of politics It's because interest groups fund campaigns, feed people fear And in fairness, it's not just in the Republican Party, although the Republican Party is just uniformly opposed to all gun safety laws And unless we change that political dynamic, we're not going to be able to make a big dent in this problemFor example, you'll hear people talk about, The problem is not guns, it's mental illness Well, if you talk to people who study this problem, it is true that the majority of these mass shooters are angry young men, but there are hundreds of millions of angry young men around the world—tens of millions of angry young men Most of them don't shoot It doesn't help us just to identify—and the majority of people who have mental illnesses are not shooters So we can't sort through and identify ahead of time who might take actions like this The only thing we can do is make sure that they can't have an entire arsenal when something snaps in themAnd if we're going to do something about that, the politics has to change The politics has to change And the people who are troubled by this have to be as intense and as organized and as adamant about this issue as folks on the other side who are absolutists and think that any gun safety measures are somehow an assault on freedom or communistic or a plot by me to take over and stay in power forever or something [] I mean, there are all kinds of crackpot conspiracy theories that float around there, some of which, by the way, are ratified by elected officials in the other party on occasionSo we've got to change the politics of this And that requires people to feel—not just feel deeply—because I get a lot of letters after this happens: Do something! Well, okay, here's what we—here's what you need to do You have to make sure that anybody who you are voting for is on the right side of this issue And if they're not, even if they're great on other stuff, for a couple of election cycles, you've got to vote against them and let them know precisely why you're voting against them And you just have to, for a while, be a single-issue voter because that's what is happening on the other sideAnd that's going to take some time I mean, the NRA has had a good start They've been at this a long time; they perfected what they do You've got to give them credit They're very effective Because they don't represent the majority of the American people, but they know how to stir up fear, they know how to stir up their base, they know how to raise money, they know how to scare politicians, they know how to organize campaigns And the American people are going to have to match them in their sense of urgency if we're actually going to stop thisWhich isn't to say stopping all violence We're not going to stop all violence Violence exists around the world, sadly Part of original sin But our homicide rates are just a lot higher than other places that, by the way, have the same levels of violence It's just, they—you can't kill as many people when you don't have easy access to these kinds of weaponsAnd I'm deeply saddened about what happened yesterday But Arne is going back to Chicago; let's not forget, this is happening every single day in forgotten neighborhoods around the country Every single day Kids are just running for their lives, trying to get to school Broderick, when we were down in New Orleans, sitting down with a group of young men, when we were talking about Katrina, and I've got two young men next to me, both of them had been shot multiple times They were barely 20So we've got to make a decision If we think that's normal, then we have to own it I don't think it's normal I think it's abnormal I think we should change it But I can't do it by myselfSo main thing I'm going to do, Jon, is talk about it And hope that over time I'm changing enough minds, along with other leaders around the country, that we start finally seeing some action I don't think it's going to happen overnightCheryl Bolen [Bloomberg BNA]
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. ——if Republicans take control of the House? [SEP] Yes, because it's going to be much closer if they take control.If they take—look, the predictions were—and again, I'm not being critical of anybody who made the predictions. I got it, okay? This was supposed to be a red wave. You guys—you were talking about us losing 30 to 50 seats and this was going to—we're nowhere near—that's not going to happen. And so there's always enough people in the—on the other team, whether it's Democrat or Republican, that the opposite party can make an appeal to and maybe pick them off to get the help. And so it remains to be seen.But look, I doubt whether or not—for example, all the talk—I'd ask the rhetorical—I don't expect you to answer, but the rhetorical question: Do you think that, you know, Senator Johnson is going to move to cut Medicare and Social Security? And if he does, how many Republicans do you think are going to vote for it?So it depends.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, could you share your perspective on the current economic trajectory and whether you view it as favorable or unfavorable? [SEP] I trust that we are moving away from protectionist policies. The failure to secure passage of the trade bills concerning Colombia, Panama, and South Korea was a disappointment, though not a mistake. I genuinely believed we had an opportunity there. Protectionism is a significant concern. In challenging economic times, the inclination is to erect barriers and prioritize domestic interests, even at the expense of competition. This sentiment was present even during periods of economic prosperity. After all, CAFTA barely passed. It would be a grave error for us to embrace protectionism. Perhaps the Bush Center at SMU could serve as a reminder of the advantages of free and fair trade, which benefit our workers, workers abroad, and promote development, particularly in developing nations. Trade is the most effective means of fostering economic growth and providing individuals with opportunities for a better future. This is a proven fact. I remain hopeful that the country will not succumb to protectionist policies.
label: General

sentence: President Obama, regarding the long-term strategic partnership between Afghanistan and the United States, how do you reconcile this with the deadlines for troop withdrawal after 2017? [SEP] Our expectations were for enhanced cooperation and a clear vision for enduring cooperation with the United States. This has occurred, and the U.S. Government considers Afghanistan a reliable partner. The commitments made are considerable, including the $4.1 billion funding proposal for Afghan security forces by 2017. The new framework for economic cooperation, with $800 million committed, will be spent through the Afghan budget. The flexibility shown in security cooperation provides confidence to our security forces and sends a strong message that this cooperation is long term. Our strategic partnership is based on enabling the Afghan people, through their security forces, to provide for their own security. We aim to be a strong partner in building and sustaining effective Afghan security forces.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. How long do you expect people like Senator Charles Schumer and American manufacturers who've lost so many jobs so quickly--how long do you expect them to wait? [SEP] Well, Hans, we're not going to have a colloquy here, but my expectation is, is that they're going to be serious about the policy that they themselves have announced.Now, what I'm going to do is I'm going to work with people like Senator Schumer, manufacturers, workers who are affected by these trade imbalances. And I think we all have the same interest, and that is, the United States can compete with anybody as long as we've got an even playing field.And as I indicated in my opening remarks, we're prepared to enter into trade agreements with Korea. One of the things that we discussed here was, is there a way to reinvigorate the Doha round, which has been stuck for a very long time? So I agree with the statement in the communique that trade can be a source of prosperity for everybody, but it's got to be a fair deal.And it's not just currency, by the way. I mean, we've had discussions with our Chinese partners about what are they doing on nontariff barriers; what are they doing with respect to intellectual property protection; what are they doing with respect to state-owned enterprises or stated-owned banks that are subsidizing industry. So there are a whole host of issues.Now, undoubtedly, they've got some issues with us. And I think we can manage these trade frictions, but it's going to be important, I think, for to take seriously not just what we're saying, but what a number of countries, including countries like Canada, are saying.All right? Jackie [Jackie Calmes, New York Times]. Where are you at?
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, with respect, the deadline for naming your pick for Federal Reserve Chair is looming. Can you give us any hints about your thinking or potential candidates? The markets are jittery, and frankly, so are we. Are you worried about the impact of this delay, especially if you pass on re-upping Chairman Powell? [SEP] Look, the process is humming along. We're looking at some top-notch folks, and I promise you, we'll announce something soon. We're not going to let some made-up deadline rush us. We're focused on what's best for the American economy long-term. I've got the best people on it, and we'll get it done, you can bet on it.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, with the ongoing threat of terrorism, how can you assure Americans that your administration is doing everything possible to prevent future attacks, even those carried out by lone wolves? [SEP] Well, Roberta, you're absolutely right that it is very difficult for us to detect lone-wolf plotsor plots involving a husband and wife, in this casebecause despite the incredible vigilance thatand professionalism of all our law enforcement, homeland security, et cetera, it's not that different from us trying to detect the next mass shooter. You don't always see it. They're not always communicating publicly, and if you're not catching what they say publicly, then it becomes a challenge.
label: General

sentence: Q. A quick follow-up. Did you discuss the election with her? [SEP] No, I didn't. I didn't.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Will there be a signing ceremony for this agreement? [SEP] Well, since it's not legally binding, I'm not sure about the protocol. But it's a strong commitment from the United States. We believe it's very important. So, we're treating it with the utmost seriousness. Thank you.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Mr. President, regarding the oil price cap, are you certain it will lower prices for American drivers, and how long should they expect to pay a premium due to the war? [SEP] Could you repeat the second part of your question? The one about price reduction, was it?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, regarding Jacksonville, critics suggest you're acting prematurely, especially with schools and baseball. Doesn't Jacksonville highlight the dangers of moving too fast? [SEP] Consider baseball – we were just on that topic. You'll be seeing an empty stadium. Randy Levine, a Yankee friend, invited me to throw out the first pitch on August 15th at Yankee Stadium. I inquired about the crowd, and he said there won't be one. It'll be a new experience for Mariano; he's accustomed to the crowd's energy. I think it'd be just as good without it. Some people are naturally gifted.And speaking of baseball, I've never witnessed a pitcher break as many bats as Mariano. He holds the record. I asked him his secret, and he replied, 'Parents.' It all boils down to great parents. Right? How do you do that? It's called parents.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: President Lee, regarding North Korea's potential missile launch, beyond stating it's a violation, what specific countermeasures are being considered? What economic or diplomatic levers will South Korea pull, and can you provide an update on the missile range negotiations with the United States? [SEP] If they proceed, it's a clear violation, plain and simple. They've made pledges to the international community. They will face the consequences. The people of North Korea will understand the true nature of their leadership. We urge them to act responsibly. The US and South Korea are aligned on this. Regarding missile range, that wasn't part of our discussion today, but it's being addressed at the working level.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: So, to be clear, will you be delivering your acceptance speech in Charlotte, where the Republican convention is being held, or will it be at a different location? [SEP] The details are still being finalized, but we're planning a fantastic event. The convention will be a great success, and I'm looking forward to addressing the American people.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: You've stated your surprise at the Republican's obstructionist tactics. Yet, wasn't this the same strategy they employed against President Obama during your time as Vice President? What rationale did you have for anticipating a different approach from them now? [SEP] The degree of obstruction we're seeing now is unprecedented. We were able to collaborate with Republicans like John McCain and even Lindsey Graham in the past. The fundamental question is, what is their agenda today? They had a defined agenda during our administration. Now, it's completely unclear. The American public is outraged by the current tax system. What are they proposing to do about it? Nothing. They deny the existence of climate change. What's their solution? I'm honestly baffled by the Republican platform. What are their positions on taxes, human rights, or the exorbitant cost of prescription drugs? I truly don't know. Furthermore, how can they simply disregard the events of January 6th as if they didn't happen?
label: Deflection

sentence: So, how are we planning to address this disparity? Will the United States commit to further international aid in the form of vaccine doses? And realistically, given the current situation, is ending the pandemic by 2022 a feasible goal? [SEP] It's conceivable that it'll take a little longer on a global scale. The United States remains dedicated. There's a chance, perhaps between 2022 and 2023, that we could provide another billion doses. However, that's not yet finalized. I've been careful to share what I know and what I believe is achievable. I don't want to make promises I can't keep. The G-7 members were in agreement: we're committed until we can meet the needs of the entire world. It's not only the ethical thing to do, but also crucial for our own health and security. Walls can't stop new variants. This will be a continuous undertaking, and future pandemics are possible. We need a system to identify potential threats early on. Therefore, as long as nations require vaccinations, we will continue to assist. Furthermore, we're supporting countries in developing their own vaccine production capabilities. India has the potential to do so, but currently lacks the necessary resources. We're working to provide not only vaccines, but also the means for countries to produce their own. Last question. The President. I'm just kidding, last question. Peter Alexander, NBC News.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: You mean, to engage with Iranian officials directly? [SEP] Am I going to meet with the Iranians directly, is that the question?
label: Clarification

sentence: Sir, with all due respect, are you deliberately avoiding giving us a straight answer? [SEP] I assure you, I'm giving this matter serious consideration. It's a decision that requires careful thought. I want to choose a location that reflects the importance of the event.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, you mentioned several key areas of potential collaboration with Canada. Could you prioritize which of these areas – stimulus, auto sector, border policy, or carbon market – you see as most critical in the next four years? [SEP] Whoa, hold on a second. Did you just try to sneak in four questions disguised as one? Remind me who you're with again?
label: Clarification

sentence: While you've stated these commutations were for minor drug offenses, a significant portion also involved firearms. Can you explain how that aligns with your stance on gun control? [SEP] Each case was assessed independently, considering all factors.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, can you share any details regarding the intelligence you've gathered on Putin's potential use of chemical weapons? Furthermore, what specific actions would the U.S. or NATO take in response? [SEP] I cannot provide any information that could compromise our intelligence operations. However, I want to assure you that we are closely monitoring the situation and are prepared to respond decisively to any threats.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, what is the United States' position regarding Chen Guangcheng and the possibility of asylum? And what is your administration's strategy for dealing with North Korea's nuclear ambitions? [SEP] As a matter of policy, I don't comment on specific asylum cases. However, human rights are always a priority in our discussions with . Regarding North Korea, we are committed to working with our allies to denuclearize the Korean Peninsula through diplomatic pressure and sanctions.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, what is your message for President Moon, who has reached the limit of inter-Korean cooperation due to sanctions? And what's the future of U.S.-R.O.K. military drills? [SEP] I like President Moon very much. We have a great relationship. I have a great relationship with almost every leader. Some take advantage of our country. When they know I know it, it freezes them up a bit. But we have good relationships. We'll call President Moon soon, as soon as I get on the plane. He'll be one of the first calls. I'll call Prime Minister Abe of Japan, telling him about where we are and what we're doing. He's working very hard. President Moon is working very hard. He'd love to see a deal, and he's been very helpful.
label: General

sentence: Can you give us any geographical indication as to where this announcement will take place? [SEP] The specifics are still being finalized, and any premature disclosure would be, shall we say, suboptimal. Patience, my friend, all will be revealed in due course.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, concerning Ukraine, should the cease-fire prove durable, will the United States and its European allies consider a rollback of the sanctions regime? Or do you deem it imperative to maintain these sanctions irrespective of the cease-fire's success? Furthermore, could you elaborate on the specific contributions the U.S. will make to the Rapid Response Force, in terms of troop deployments and equipment provisions, beyond the commitments articulated in Warsaw? [SEP] While we remain optimistic regarding the cease-fire agreement, past experiences with separatist factions and the Russian Federation necessitate a degree of skepticism. The agreement's efficacy must be rigorously assessed. Our European counterparts are currently deliberating the final configuration of their sanctions measures. In my estimation, the implementation of President Poroshenko's plan will require a sustained period. Consequently, maintaining the existing sanctions framework, while signaling a willingness to rescind them upon demonstrable adherence to the plan's tenets, represents the most prudent course of action to ensure compliance. It is crucial to acknowledge that the current cease-fire is attributable, in no small part, to the sanctions already imposed and the threat of further sanctions, which are exerting a tangible impact on the Russian economy and fostering its isolation on the global stage. The opportunity remains for Russia to reintegrate into the community of nations that uphold international law, and we urge President Putin to seize it. The unity and resolve exhibited by the transatlantic alliance in supporting Ukraine and implementing sanctions underscore the gravity with which we view the fundamental principle that larger nations cannot simply subjugate smaller ones or compel them to relinquish their sovereignty. I am highly gratified by the collaborative efforts undertaken throughout this crisis in Ukraine, and I believe that U.S. leadership has been indispensable throughout this process. Regarding the Rapid Response Forces, I announced a $1 billion initiative in Warsaw. A substantial portion of these funds will be allocated to implementing various facets of the readiness action plan. We have already augmented personnel rotations in the Baltic States, for instance, and we maintain air policing operations and other activities in the Baltic and Black Seas. This initiative serves to complement, coordinate, and integrate these efforts further, with additional contributions from our partners. It signifies NATO's unwavering commitment to Article 5, particularly in light of recent Russian actions and rhetoric. An enhanced presence serves as the most effective deterrent against any potential Russian aggression.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Okay. And another question on the big picture of U.S.-China relations: What do you think the U.S. and China should see each other? Are we strategic partners? Are we competitors? Are we enemies? What are we? [SEP] No. I think we're going to be strategic partners.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Do you approve of the Israeli conduct in this? [SEP] I think Israel has a right to defend herself. Obviously, in any of these kinds of situations, I would hope that she would continue to be mindful of innocent folks, and that they help, you know, expedite the delivery of humanitarian aid.And third, why haven't we achieved peace?
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. On Iran, I would like to ask you, Mr. President, there is—seems to be an emerging debate in Israel about a military option against the nuclear installations in Iran. How do you see that debate?And, Prime Minister Jansa, I would like to ask you on climate change, how do you rate the chances that in the following years there will be an agreement with the U.S. on this issue? [SEP] First of all, if you were living in Israel, you'd be a little nervous too if a leader in your neighborhood announced that they—he'd like to destroy you. And one sure way of achieving that means is through the development of a nuclear weapon. Therefore, now is the time for all of us to work together to stop them. There's a lot of urgencies when it comes to dealing with , and the Israeli political folks—and if you go to Israel and listen carefully, you'll hear that urgency in their voice—one of many urgencies. And I'm hopeful we can get it done.And by the way—I don't want to preclude the Prime Minister's answer—I think we can actually get an agreement on global climate change during my Presidency, just so you know. I believe in a global agreement for a joint fight against climate change. This is, as a matter of fact, the only solution. An agreement or a self-commitment of the most developed or industrial countries to reduce greenhouse gas emissions is not enough, especially because some developing countries are developing really fast. China will, in a few years, become the first in terms of the greenhouse gas emissions. And a global agreement without the developing countries would be a short-term solution.So, as a matter of fact, we really need that everybody who is a key stakeholder sits at the table. And I have mentioned already in my introduction, those who are most developed should take the leading role. And therefore, this alliance, these agreements, these discussions on bringing closer the standpoints is of such significance.As President Bush has mentioned, the commitment of the most developed economies—which is mandatory to reduce emissions by a certain deadline—this is a key commitment: how individual economies this reach is less important. However, the goals must be set, and we must have mandatory goals, and this is of key importance. And in this way, we will reduce the threat of climate change.And of course, we should also attract to this task the other countries. Without the leading role of the European Union and the United States of America and without close cooperation, it is not possible to reach a global agreement in short term. Therefore, this discussion is of extreme importance. And the G-8 summit in Japan in next month should represent an important step forward if we wish, in time, before the U.N. conference in Copenhagen, reach this agreement. There is not much time left. The time is running out. All right, we'll take the last one from John McKinnon of the Wall Street Journal. It's called technology. []
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, inflation is a major concern, especially for Black voters according to recent surveys. What specific, tangible actions can you guarantee in the next two years to improve their financial situation, while also preventing a recession? [SEP] Look, we're doing a lot. Black unemployment is way down since I took office. More Black businesses are starting up than ever before. We're even helping folks buy homes through the Small Business Administration, because that's how most middle-class families build wealth. I can't promise to get rid of inflation completely, but we're working on it. Gas prices are already down a good bit. But these oil companies are making a killing. They made over $100 billion in profits last quarter! They should be investing in more refineries or passing those savings on to the gas stations, but they're not. We're also tackling the everyday costs that families face, like prescription drugs. We're bringing those prices down, starting next year. Insulin, for example, will cost no more than $35 a month. We're going after all those things that eat into people's budgets – housing, food, gas, healthcare. We've already passed laws to lower those costs, and they're starting to kick in. I'm optimistic because we're still growing, and we're not in a recession. I think we can bring down prices without a major economic downturn.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, intelligence agencies claim Russia is meddling in the election to harm Joe Biden, and China is considering meddling to hurt you. Do you believe this intelligence, and what will you do about it? [SEP] Well, it's certainly a possibility. Russia likely doesn't want me in office, considering I've been tougher on them than anyone else.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Thanks. The first one is on Turkey. What assurances, if any, did you make to President Erdogan about his request for new F-16 jets for his military? [SEP] What I said was—I said back in December, as you'll recall, we should sell them the F-16 jets and modernize those jets as well. It's not in our interest not to do that. And I indicated to them that I've not changed my position at all since December.And there was no quid pro quo with that; it was just that we should sell. But I need congressional approval to be able to do that, and I think we can get that.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, given Rick Ledgett's comments on Snowden and potential amnesty, what are your thoughts? Would you ever consider a plea deal or amnesty for him? And what's your message to those who feel Snowden acted rightly in revealing surveillance practices? [SEP] Look, Snowden's been charged with serious crimes, and it's up to the courts to decide his fate. I can't comment directly on the case. But I will say this: the debate he sparked was important, but the way he did it caused real damage to our intelligence. We could have had this discussion without compromising our security. The fact is, we're a nation of laws, and we respect privacy. But because of Snowden, countries that actually abuse their citizens are now pointing fingers at us. So, while the debate was necessary, it came at a cost. I'll leave the specifics of his case to the legal system.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Mr. President, you're meeting today with Chilean President Michelle Bachelet. You're meeting next week with Alvaro Uribe from Colombia. Two months ago in Trinidad, at the Summit of the Americas, you said that--you called on Latin American countries to help you with deeds, not words, particularly towards less democratic countries. Have you noticed any particular progress in these 2 months, and can you give us examples if so? [SEP] Well, first of all, I'm very much looking forward to seeing President Bachelet. I think she's one of the finest leaders in Latin America, a very capable person. If you look at how Chile has handled the recession, they've handled it very well, in part because the surpluses that they got when copper prices were very high they set aside. And so they had a--the resources to deal with the downturn. It's a good lesson for the United States. When we had surpluses, they got dissipated.We think that there's enormous possibilities of making progress in Latin America generally. One of the things that I'll be talking about with President Bachelet is the coordination and cooperation between the United State and Chile on clean energy. We'll have an announcement when we do our press conference after my bilateral meeting on some important clean energy partnerships. We're making important progress when it comes to exchanges on cancer research. We continue to have a robust trade regime with Chile. So--and by the way, Chile has actually entered into some very interesting partnerships, not just with the Federal Government but also with State governments like California.So I think the relationship that we have with Chile--which, by the way, does not fall in line with U.S. foreign policy on every single issue--but it's a respectful policy. Chile is an important partner. I think that's the model that we want: partnership. The United States doesn't dictate how Chile should view its own interests, but in fact, we've achieved great cooperation. And I will be looking at President Bachelet giving us further advice in terms of how we can take the kind of relationship we have with Chile and expand that to our relationships throughout Latin America. Okay?
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, how likely is it that the international community will agree on sanctions against Iran in the coming weeks? And is the United States certain that Pakistan's nuclear weapons are safe from terrorists? [SEP] The security of Pakistan's nuclear arsenal is a top priority, and we work closely with them to ensure its safety. We have confidence in their security measures, but we remain vigilant. Regarding Iran, we are working diligently to secure strong international sanctions. These negotiations are complex, but we are committed to preventing Iran from acquiring nuclear weapons. We are hopeful that we can reach an agreement soon, but we will not compromise on the strength of the sanctions.
label: General

sentence: President, are you contemplating withholding federal funds from them? [SEP] That's not my preferred course of action. I'm confident we can find common ground. They rely on the federal government for various forms of assistance, not just monetary. We have a wealth of expertise and resources to share. When I took office, the situation was dire, but we've turned things around. I anticipate a respectful relationship with the Governors. The ideal scenario is for the States to operate independently, with federal support available when necessary.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: So, are you leaning towards a troop withdrawal? [SEP] Come again?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, in relation to the G-7 discussions, what specific weaknesses have you identified in the campaign against the Islamic State, and will the intensified support for Iraq entail the deployment of additional U.S. military personnel? Moreover, did you provide Chancellor Merkel with assurances that fast track authority would be approved by the House, and what are the ramifications if it fails to secure passage? [SEP] I'm not going to speculate about failing to get trade done. We're going to get it done. With respect to ISIL, we've made progress, but they're adaptable. We need to train Iraqi forces faster. When we train them and equip them, they do well. When we don't, they struggle. So, we're looking at ways to accelerate training and equipping Iraqi forces. President Abadi wants the same thing. The Pentagon is working on a plan, and I'll share it when it's ready. But it requires commitments from the Iraqis as well. The details are still being worked out.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, could you share your thoughts on the recently released Al Qaida intelligence report? [SEP] I didn't hear you.
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. And you are coming back to Singapore? [SEP] I would come back gladly. Your Prime Minister was fantastic. We were with him yesterday. He's done a great job. It was very welcoming. It really, probably had—it probably made a difference, actually. It's a great place.Thank you very much.
label: General

sentence: Sir, concerning the impeachment trial in the Senate, do you favor a quick conclusion or a comprehensive investigation? What's your take on the clash between Pat Cipollone and Jerrold Nadler yesterday? And are you completely against John Bolton's testimony? [SEP] Well, you're asking a lot of questions.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the Prime Minister's Brexit plan, your earlier statements seemed to suggest it would hinder a trade deal with the U.S. Given our 'special relationship,' wasn't your public criticism of her policy, and indeed her personally, rather uncharacteristic of a friend? And Prime Minister, how did you feel about the President's critique of your Brexit strategy, particularly concerning its potential impact on future trade agreements? [SEP] Well, let me clarify. I have immense respect for the Prime Minister. The press, as usual, took things out of context. They conveniently omitted my positive remarks. Luckily, we record these interviews now – a handy tool against, shall we say, 'fake news.' The Prime Minister will ultimately decide her course. My only request is that it doesn't impede trade. We want to trade with the U.K., and vice versa. We're their biggest partner, and we can easily expand that. If they choose a different path – and they desire independence, of course – I simply hope trade with the U.S. remains possible. Some reports suggest it won't be, but after discussions with her team, I'm confident it will. So, based on that, and our overall relationship – which will be fine – trade is the key. We both want it. And I think she's doing a fantastic job, frankly.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Quick follow-up: Can I ask you, do you agree with your top intelligence official, James Clapper, who said before Congress yesterday that it is likely that the Qadhafi regime will prevail in the long run? And did he err by saying that in public? And if so, is this something he needs to be taken to the woodshed for? [SEP] He was making a hardheaded assessment about military capability. And I don't think anybody disputes that Qadhafi has more firepower than the opposition. He wasn't stating policy.So let me be clear again about what our policy as determined by me, the President of the United States, is towards the situation there. I believe that Qadhafi is on the wrong side of history. I believe that the Libyan people are anxious for freedom and the removal of somebody who has suppressed them for decades now. And we are going to be in contact with the opposition, as well as in consultation with the international community, to try to achieve the goal of Mr. Qadhafi being removed from power.Zachary Goldfarb [Washington Post].
label: Deflection

sentence: Has the American President reassured you regarding the policies of his successor on climate change and Russia, thereby alleviating your concerns? Are you worried that the common European policy towards Russia might fall apart? And following Mr. Trump's election, wouldn't you be obligated to announce your candidacy again as a gesture of civility? [SEP] I generally try to avoid getting involved in other countries' internal affairs. All I can say is that Chancellor Merkel has been an outstanding partner. She's perhaps the only leader among our closest allies who was there when I first arrived, making us veterans of many challenges over the past 8 years. While we haven't always agreed on every issue, her core values, integrity, truthfulness, thoughtfulness, diligence, knowledge, and commitment to the interests of the German people, while recognizing the importance of global engagement and multilateral institutions, have been outstanding. It's her decision whether to run again, and ultimately, the German people will decide. If I were German, I might support her. As for Russia, my approach has been consistent since I took office. Russia is an important country, a military superpower with global influence. Cooperation with Russia is in our interest to solve many global problems. We should hope for a successful Russia with a growing economy and good relations with its neighbors. I've sought a constructive relationship with Russia, but I'm realistic about our differences. We can't set aside our values of democracy, free speech, international norms, and the rule of law. We've had significant differences on issues like Ukraine and Syria. I hope the President-elect will take a similar approach, finding areas for cooperation while standing up to Russia when it deviates from our values. I'm encouraged by the President-elect's commitment to NATO. Regarding my conversations with President Putin, they occurred before the election. There's clear proof of their cyber attacks, which isn't new. We've delivered a clear message that meddling with elections or targeting private organizations is unacceptable, and we'll respond appropriately. We need international frameworks to prevent a cyber arms race. We've started working on principles at the G-20, G-7, and U.N. levels, but more work is needed. The transition period in the United States is proceeding smoothly, with the outgoing administration sharing its knowledge with the incoming one. This encourages us to continue the good cooperation between the United States and Germany. I'll approach this with an open mind and a deep conviction with President-elect Donald Trump. On Russia, it's about respecting certain principles. From a European perspective, peace depends on respecting territorial integrity and sovereignty. The reverse would be a dangerous path. We're pinning our hopes on political efforts like the Normandy process. Russia is our neighbor, and we have an interest in a good relationship. We must raise our differences with political means and work for political settlements. I'll continue to work on this with all my heart. I'll decide on my candidacy at the appropriate time.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the benchmarks for cooperation between the U.S. and Iraq, some observers noted Prime Minister Maliki's absence from yesterday's press conference with General Casey and Ambassador Khalilzad. Can you shed any light on why he wasn't present, and whether it reflects any underlying issues in the relationship? [SEP] Honestly, Elaine, your guess is as good as mine. I wasn't involved in the scheduling.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Will all the sanctions that are currently in existence remain, sir? [SEP] They're in place. You know, I was watching as a lot of you folks over the weeks have said, Oh, we've given up—we haven't given up anything. And frankly, I think we'll end up being very good friends with Chairman Kim and with North Korea, and I think they have tremendous potential. I've been telling everybody: They have tremendous potential. Unbelievable potential. But we're going to see.But it was about sanctions. I mean, they wanted sanctions lifted, but they weren't willing to do an area that we wanted. They were willing to give us areas, but not the ones we wanted.John [John Roberts, Fox News].
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Well, I'm going to ask a very Bloomberg question to begin, which is: Have you decided who you will nominate to chair the Federal Reserve Board? And if not, can you speak a little bit about what you're thinking about as you consider your choice for Fed Chair and the other seats that are open?This is the latest that a President has gone without nominating somebody the year before a nominee needs to be selected. And are you concerned about potentially having a short timeline, especially if you're not going to renominate Jay Powell? [SEP] No, no, and no. No, I'm not going to discuss it with you, because that's in train now. We'll be making those announcements fairly quickly. It's been in train for some time, number one.Number two, I also would indicate that I think we're going to have plenty of time to make sure all the major nominees are able to be cleared in time that—where their terms would expire.And number three, I've given a lot of thought to it, and I've been meeting with my economic advisers on what the best choices are, and we've got a lot of good choices. But I'm not going to speculate now.Nancy [Nancy Cordes, CBS News], CBS. I think you had your hand up. I'm sorry. Did you?
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. He follows you on Twitter? [SEP] I guess so because we got a call very quickly. [] A lot of people follow it. But you know they've contacted us and they'd like to see if they can do something. And we're not talking about for you know extended. Just a quick hello.And we get along. I get along with him and I get along with other people. Like you know for instance on Jim's question it's a fair question but I really have great relationships with everybody.I think—you know I said a long time ago that maybe I'll be a sleeper on foreign policy. And if you look at what's happened on foreign policy—now we are working on and we'll see what happens. I think they'd like to make a deal. I think they'd be very smart to want to make a deal but we're going to see what happens. I'm okay. I have all the time in the world.They're doing very poorly. They were doing—they were very brutal when I first came in. Eighteen sites of confliction meaning where they were behind. But I think on foreign policy if you look at what's happening—and the other thing that's happening is we're not being taken for suckers anymore.I mean we have countries where we'd lose on defending them because we defend a tremendous percentage of the world. And they don't pay us for it. And then on top of it we lose money with that same country on trade. And it's all changing. And they understand it's changing. And they expect it to change. They can't believe.Honestly like I'd ask Prime Minister Abe—I said How did this happen where you send us billions and billions of dollars' worth of cars and other things and we send you practically nothing? He said Nobody ever complained. Same thing with China. I said: You know you send a car to us. We charge you essentially nothing. It's 2½ percent but basically you don't have to—there are ways around that. So you send a car to us and you pay nothing. We send a car to you made in the United States and we have to pay 45-percent tariff. How did that happen? He said We just kept lifting it lifting it lifting it. I mean they're being honest with me. We just kept lifting it and nobody called. But I call. I call.Go ahead Jon.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. So there was a negotiation on Huawei, welcoming students, holding off on tariffs. So it sounds like China has agreed to buy more ag, but is this a lopsided agreement or what more did China agree to? [SEP] No we agreed—on China this is actually a good question. I did agree to allow our companies—you know it's jobs—I like our companies selling things to other people. So I allowed that to happen. Very complex things. Not easy. This is not things that are easy to make. Very few companies are able to do it. But a tremendous amount of money. Our companies were very upset. You know these companies are great companies. You know all of them. But they weren't exactly happy with it. But we're allowing that because that was a national security; we're allowing them to sell.But we agreed to leave that till the end. Huawei is a complicated situation. We agreed to leave that—we're leaving Huawei toward the end. We're going to see. We'll see where we go with the trade agreement.Yes please.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. President Trump said you would be making military purchases of military equipment. What does that signal? And is it a change? [SEP] I'm not entirely sure which direction your question was, but I can say one thing: When it comes to the state of our reconnaissance assets and the strategic assets—on acquisition of these U.S. strategic assets—we have agreed to begin the consultations for acquisition—Korea's acquisition of such assets. And that is to enhance Korea's defense capabilities and also the combined defense posture of Korea and the United States. I think it is essential. . Margaret, if I may add to that, that the President and I have agreed they'll be buying a tremendous—which they want, and which they need, and everybody thinks it makes a lot of sense. We make the greatest military equipment in the world, whether it's planes, whether it's missiles. No matter what it is, we have the greatest military equipment in the world. And South Korea will be ordering billions of dollars of that equipment, which, frankly, for them makes a lot of sense. And for us, it means jobs; it means reducing our trade deficit with South Korea.But they'll be ordering billions of dollars' worth of equipment, and we've already approved some of those orders. Okay? Thank you.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Can I ask a quick follow-up question? [SEP] [] The third one, yes. Go ahead.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. Clearly, there was some sort of dispute between you and the European leaders about how to fund this bailout. And you, in your remarks, emphasized the fact that TARP was done with U.S. funds, that there wasn't any international involvement here. Are you confident now that the European leaders are going to fund this firewall or bailout fund themselves, not looking for handouts from other countries, and that they will do what they have to do?And the second part of my question is, how hard was it to convince these folks to do stimulus measures when your own stimulus measure--you've mentioned it twice now--is not going anywhere right now on Capitol Hill? [SEP] Well, first of all, we didn't have a long conversation about stimulus measures, so that was maybe two or three G-20s ago. We had a discussion about what steps could be taken to continue to spur economic growth. And that may not always involve government spending. For example, the rebalancing agenda that I talked about is one way in which we can make a big difference in spurring on global demand. It requires some adjustments, some changes in behavior on the part of countries. But it doesn't necessarily involve classic fiscal stimulus.There wasn't a dispute with the Europeans. I think the Europeans agree with us that it is important to send a clear signal that the European project is alive and well, and that they are committed to the euro and that they are committed to resolving this crisis. And I think if you talk to European leaders, they are the first ones to say that that begins with European leaders arriving at a common course of action.So essentially, what we've seen is all the elements for dealing with the crisis put in place, and we think those are the right elements. The first is having a solution to the specific problem of Greece. And although the actions of Papandreou and the referendum issue over the last couple of days I think got a lot of people nervous, the truth is, is that the general approach, which involved a voluntary reduction on the part of those who hold the Greeks' debt, reducing the obligations of the Greek Government, Greece continuing with reforms and structural change, that's the right recipe. It just has to be carried out. And I was encouraged by the fact that despite all the turmoil in Greece, even the opposition leader in Greece indicated that it's important to move forward on the proposal.The second component is recapitalization of Europe's banks. And they have identified that need and they are resourcing that need. And that I think is going to be critical to further instill confidence in the markets.And the third part of it is creating this firewall, essentially sending a signal to the markets that Europe is going to stand behind the euro. And all the details, the structure, how it operates, are still being worked out among the European leaders. What we were able to do was to give them some ideas, some options in terms of how they would put that together.And what we've said is--and I'm speaking now for the whole of the G-20--what we've said is the international community is going to stand ready to assist and make sure that the overall global economy is cushioned by the gyrations in the market and the shocks that arise as Europe is working these issues through. And so they're going to have a strong partner in us. But European leaders understand that ultimately what the markets are looking for is a strong signal from Europe that they're standing behind the euro.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, are you deliberately avoiding this hearing, and if so, why? [SEP] Honestly, I'm not entirely sure why I haven't gone. It's not like I wouldn't enjoy watching the show. I'd love to see it, but, you know, things happen.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, regarding Russia's posture towards NATO, specifically concerning missile defense and the potential membership of Ukraine and Georgia, do you perceive their actions as exerting undue pressure or veiled threats? [SEP] Look, those Soviet-era flags you saw yesterday? Don't read too much into it. It's an interesting debate. Every nation assures me Russia won't have a veto over Bucharest's decisions, and I trust them. That's the right approach. I'm committed to Ukraine and Georgia joining MAP. It's in our, NATO's, and their best interests. On missile defense, I've clearly told President Putin it's not aimed at Russia. They could easily overwhelm it. It's for threats from the Middle East, like our Far East systems protect us from single or dual launches. We need to ease suspicions, but we're making progress. Ukraine's NATO membership is about national interest, not targeting anyone. Our history shows collective defense is vital for sovereignty and integrity. Joining MAP is the best response for Ukraine's future. Debates in Europe shouldn't create obstacles. We're on the right track, acting within our sovereignty. The open-door policy shouldn't be replaced by a veto from a non-member. The discussion is overheated, lacking respect. Wisdom should prevail. I want calmness, stability, and security for Ukraine. We want to discuss Ukraine's presence in the world and internally. Those are my motives. Some political forces disagree, which is natural. The red flags represent a tragic past, famine, oppression, and deaths. We might need another Moses. I want to show my vision and ideology.
label: Deflection

sentence: How does the principle of state sovereignty fit with the idea of 'responsibility to protect'? [SEP] Responsibility to protect what, now?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, in light of General Neller's comments to marines in Norway regarding an upcoming 'big-ass fight,' how imminent is this conflict, and where do you expect it to take place? [SEP] When you say 'the big war,' what are you implying? Could you elaborate?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Mr. President, if you don't mind, could you restate the question? [SEP] Come again?
label: Clarification

sentence: About these 'provocations' every time we try to engage, what do you know about Fidel Castro's role in the talks? Did you ask Raul about him? How is he? And with Republicans opposing your Cuba moves, will you personally fight to keep funding from being blocked? [SEP] Okay, Lesley, I'm going to have to stop you right there. We're out of time.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, critics argue that your rhetoric is emboldening white nationalists. How do you respond to the claim that the Republican Party is now perceived as supporting such groups because of your words? [SEP] That's a ridiculous assertion. I condemn all forms of hate and bigotry. My policies are designed to benefit all Americans, regardless of race or background. Look at the economic progress we've made – that benefits everyone.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: If North Korea is unwilling to negotiate, will the US increase sanctions? [SEP] I'm not going to comment on that. We have strong sanctions in place. I don't want to talk about increasing sanctions. I care about the people of North Korea. Getting to know Chairman Kim has changed my attitude. Hopefully, for the sake of South Korea and Japan, this situation will resolve itself.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Thank you. I have a question for the Chancellor but I'd like to start with a question on Iran for you, Mr. President.After a long day of talks with you, President Macron went to Congress, warned of a new war in the Middle East, and asked the world and the United States to respect the sovereignty of all countries, including Iran. In the absence of a new agreement, are you prepared to use military force to rein in the nuclear program in Iran? Or do you have another plan B that is not an agreement and not military force? [SEP] I don't talk about whether or not I'd use military force. That's not appropriate to be talking about. But I can tell you this: They will not be doing nuclear weapons. That I can tell you. Okay? They're not going to be doing nuclear weapons. You can bank on it.Okay. Please.[.]
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, given the lack of progress with North Korea, are you ruling out the possibility of tightening sanctions in the near future? [SEP] Our sanctions are very strong. I don't want to discuss future actions. We have to remember the people of North Korea. I have a good relationship with Chairman Kim. I've discussed this with President Xi. I'm now heading back to Washington. Thank you.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. And a quick follow-up for President Duda: Do you consider Russia a friend or foe? [SEP] Are you addressing that question to me?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, concerning Mr. Ledgett's suggestion of amnesty for Edward Snowden, what was your reaction to his public statement? Under what circumstances would you consider a plea agreement or amnesty for Mr. Snowden? And what is your response to Americans who believe Mr. Snowden's actions were justified in exposing surveillance practices? [SEP] Well, let's be clear, I must be cautious here. Mr. Snowden faces serious charges, and it's up to the Attorney General and the judiciary to handle the matter. I can't offer specific commentary. However, I do believe the conversation he initiated was vital. That being said, the manner of these disclosures caused significant harm to our intelligence operations. There could have been a less damaging way to proceed. The United States, despite its imperfections, upholds the rule of law and deeply values privacy. Now, nations that truly engage in the activities Mr. Snowden accused us of are exploiting this situation to deflect criticism. So, while the discussion was essential, the leaks inflicted damage. The courts will determine Mr. Snowden's fate.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Mr. Karzai, can I ask my question in Dari first? [SEP] Please, yes.[]
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, you've spoken with economists who agree on the need for a deal regarding the debt ceiling. Have you engaged with U.S. business leaders to advocate for raising the debt ceiling in Congress? If so, with whom have you been in contact? [SEP] I've had extensive conversations with business leaders. They generally agree that a resolution is needed. However, they're often hesitant to publicly support a solution due to their business interests before Congress. It's a political problem, and business leaders, like everyone else, want to protect their own interests.
