Some, like Warren Buffett, have been vocal, but many are hesitant to be as straightforward as I'd like about the need for spending cuts and increased revenue.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. Thank you—— Q. A quick follow-up. Can I ask you a quick follow-up? [SEP] Go ahead, please.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, concerning North Korea, you've stated a belief in a positive outcome. Can you detail any successes in your diplomatic approach? And do you still regard direct talks as unproductive? [SEP] Well, I'm not going to get into the specifics of our strategy. We like to keep those things close to the chest. But I will say that it's in everyone's interest for North Korea to act responsibly. There's a lot of good reason behind it. We're showing strength, tremendous strength. They understand we have unparalleled strength. We have carriers, submarines... the best in the world. We hope we never have to use them. But I believe they'll come to the table, make a deal that benefits everyone. I see some movement, yes. But let's see what happens.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: What specific conditions must be met before you would consider meeting with the North Korean leader, and do you think he's likely to meet those conditions? [SEP] I don't make assumptions about what people will do based solely on what they say. We'll have to wait and see. If he makes a genuine commitment to discuss his nuclear weapons program, then I'd be willing to meet. That commitment has to include serious discussions about denuclearization and reducing tensions. My Secretary of State and other officials would negotiate an agenda beforehand. I won't repeat the mistakes of the past by giving him international recognition without seeing real progress. I need to see concrete proposals. I'm not ruling out a meeting with North Korea altogether, but my team would need to meet with their counterparts first to establish clear objectives.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, with the location for your Presidential library secured, fundraising becomes the next hurdle. Rumors are swirling about a $200 million target. Is that the ballpark figure? Do you think the American people deserve transparency regarding who's contributing such significant amounts to their President? Will you disclose donations as they come in? And will you set any limits on donor eligibility or contribution size? [SEP] Not sure yet, probably, we'll figure it out. I haven't seen the final budget, and as Donnie Evans has stated, we'll adhere to the disclosure guidelines. Some donors prefer to remain anonymous, and we'll respect that. What else did you want to know?
label: Clarification

sentence: Given the fluid circumstances in Libya, what specific metrics will dictate the transfer of command, and why is NATO the preferred entity to oversee this transition? [SEP] As you know, the situation on the ground is constantly evolving. The timing of this transfer is dependent on the recommendations of our commanding officers, specifically when they determine that the initial phase of the mission, focused on neutralizing Libyan air defenses, has been successfully completed. This is essential for the effective operation of the no-fly zone and the safety of our coalition pilots. Humanitarian aspects are also a crucial consideration. I anticipate this transition occurring in a matter of days, not weeks. The Pentagon will provide further details. NATO's coordinating function is invaluable due to its unique capabilities. Regarding this partnership, it's a two-way street. Chile has much to offer, particularly in clean energy. We're exploring collaborations in education and security, addressing issues like narcotrafficking. This isn't about a developed nation aiding a less developed one; it's a collaboration among equals. Regarding Latin American integration, we lag behind Europe. While the idea of a free trade area from Alaska to Tierra del Fuego was once floated, it never materialized. Latin America needs to fulfill its potential, drawing on shared values and principles with the U.S. We seek a partnership that encompasses democracy, free trade, education, and innovation. We must also address energy and water challenges, as well as transnational threats. The time is ripe for a new international order, one that adapts to the needs of the 21st century. Latin America cannot afford to be late to the knowledge and information revolution.
label: General

sentence: President Trump, can you address the report in the Washington Post about the FBI building and its potential inclusion in the coronavirus relief package? [SEP] I'm not certain about its inclusion in this specific bill, but let me tell you, that FBI building is in terrible shape. It's old, it's dangerous, pieces are falling off. They considered locations outside of Washington, but I believe it's crucial to keep it near the Justice Department. Building a new facility is the best option, ensuring its longevity. Renovation simply won't suffice. They could even add a running track on top for the agents. So, whether it's in this bill or another, a new FBI building is a priority, and we'll make it happen. Thank you.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. Can you assure the American people that there have been no breaches of national security or classified information in the scandal involving Generals Petraeus and Allen? And do you think that you as Commander in Chief and the American people should have been told that the CIA chief was under investigation before the election? [SEP] Well, I have no evidence at this point from what I've seen that classified information was disclosed that in any way would have had a negative impact on our national security.Obviously, there's an ongoing investigation. I don't want to comment on the specifics of the investigation. The FBI has its own protocols in terms of how they proceed, and I'm going to let Director Mueller and others examine those protocols and make some statements to the public generally.I do want to emphasize what I've said before: General Petraeus had an extraordinary career. He served this country with great distinction in Iraq, in Afghanistan, and as head of the CIA. By his own assessment, he did not meet the standards that he felt were necessary as the Director of CIA with respect to this personal matter that he is now dealing with with his family and with his wife. And it's on that basis that he tendered his resignation, and it's on that basis that I accepted it.But I want to emphasize that, from my perspective at least, he has provided this country an extraordinary service. We are safer because of the work that Dave Petraeus has done. And my main hope right now is, is that he and his family are able to move on and that this ends up being a single side note on what has otherwise been an extraordinary career.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, in the current debt negotiations, would you consider supporting tax incentives aimed at boosting the economy, despite their potential impact on the deficit? Also, following up on your earlier remarks about same-sex marriage, given the growing acceptance in states like New York, has your personal stance evolved to support same-sex marriage, irrespective of state-level decisions? [SEP] I won't be making any announcements on that today. You almost got me there!
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Sir, could you clarify your position on including the NHS in any potential trade deals? [SEP] Pardon? I'm having trouble hearing you.
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, in light of the recent election outcomes, which suggest voter dissatisfaction with your administration, do you feel compelled to revise your agenda for the remainder of your term? What concrete steps will you take to restructure your White House operations and improve relations with Republicans to address the concerns voiced by voters? [SEP] The American people have spoken. They want Washington to function more effectively. As President, I'm committed to making that happen. We'll seek areas of bipartisan agreement, such as infrastructure and export promotion. We'll continue to champion policies that strengthen the middle class. It's about finding common ground and delivering tangible results.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, regarding Afghanistan, what is your assessment of the reported talks brokered by Pakistan between the Taliban and President Karzai? Do they offer hope, or do they raise concerns? Furthermore, do you concur with Prime Minister David Cameron's assertion that a complete withdrawal from Afghanistan is feasible by 2015? [SEP] I am uncertain about the accuracy of that quote from David Cameron, but let me address the latter question first. Our presence in Afghanistan has now extended for nine years, and next year will mark a decade. This represents America's longest war. Consequently, we all share an interest not in occupying Afghanistan, but in ensuring its stability, its ability to independently manage its security, and its prevention from becoming a base for terrorist activities directed against the United States. We will need to provide ongoing assistance to Afghanistan, aiding in the development of a national government, courts, effective police forces, and a transparent and fair political system. However, this differs from maintaining troops on the ground. Our policy, announced last November, involves deploying additional troops to provide the Afghan government with the necessary space and time to strengthen its security forces, counter the Taliban's momentum, and improve governance. General Petraeus is continuing this policy, with the endorsement of our allies and President Karzai. It is a formidable challenge, given Afghanistan's poverty, illiteracy, and history of conflict. We anticipate progress by the end of this year, followed by a comprehensive review and adjustments as needed. Ultimately, as in Iraq, a political solution is essential. Regarding the negotiations, it is premature to draw conclusions. We must approach them with skepticism but also openness. The Taliban comprises diverse elements, and President Karzai's peace jirga and the Kabul conference are constructive steps, as are talks between Afghanistan and Pakistan. Regional players must recognize the shared interest in a stable Afghanistan-Pakistan region. Next question, please.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, many states have used mail-in voting for years without widespread fraud. What specific measures do you believe are necessary to ensure the security of mail-in ballots, and why do you believe those measures are not currently in place in states like Nevada? [SEP] We need to have voter ID, signature verification, and a lot of other things. And we need to make sure that people can't just send in ballots for dead people or people who have moved away. It's a very complicated process, and it's easy to cheat. That's why I'm concerned about mail-in voting.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, and to you as well, Prime Minister, during your discussions today, did you consider Canada increasing its stimulus efforts? And for both of you, what is your vision for the Canada-US relationship in the next four years? What will the automotive industry look like? Will border controls be tighter or looser? And will there be a carbon market? [SEP] Wow, you managed to cram about half a dozen questions in there. Were you talking to Jonathan? Is that--?
label: Clarification

sentence: President Obama, on the topic of Mexico, regarding human rights abuses and the fight against drug cartels, will you certify their compliance? What's your plan for the Merida Initiative? And what about concerns for President Calderon's safety, visa complications, and the overall security challenges? [SEP] I'm afraid I didn't fully understand the translation. It sounded like a very pertinent question, however. Could you please rephrase it?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. But sir, are they currently under investigation? [SEP] Peter, I'm not prepared to discuss ongoing investigations at this time. Thank you.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, regarding Europe's handling of the economic crisis, why do you believe your recommendations weren't adopted? And what specific measures will you take in the coming months to aid Greece and address the Cyprus issue, particularly the Turkish occupation? [SEP] On Cyprus, it's fundamentally a negotiation between Cypriots. We're encouraged by the leaders' commitment to compromise. If they reach an agreement, we'll support it internationally, including Turkey and Greece. Vice President Biden has been deeply involved, and we see a window for resolution. As for Europe, my situation was simpler with congressional majorities. Europe faces multiple parliaments, commissions, and unions, making consensus difficult. I've offered our best thinking on resolving bank problems and stimulating growth through infrastructure spending. Our deficits decreased due to growth and increased tax revenue, lessons applicable to all countries. Prime Minister Tsipras is right, it's an international problem going on for 42 years, and it is a problem of illegal invasion and occupation of the northern part of Cyprus.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. It's me? It's me? [SEP] Yes, you. [] The guy looks—the guy looks like he's shocked. That's not—this is going to be not good. []
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, concerning the Senate proceedings, would you prefer a quick conclusion or a comprehensive review of the evidence? What's your take on the clash between White House Counsel Pat Cipollone and Jerrold Nadler last night? And are you absolutely against John Bolton testifying? [SEP] That's quite a few questions you're throwing at me.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Can you give us any geographic indication whatsoever about where these announcements will be made? A continent, perhaps? [SEP] You know, it's going to be revealed very, very soon. I don't want to spoil the surprise. Just stay tuned, okay?
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Was the perpetrator a man or a woman? [SEP] That information is not currently available to me.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, given the constitutional questions surrounding some of your decisions, do you believe the War Powers Act is constitutional? What about the debt limit? And is marriage a civil right? [SEP] Chuck, you're throwing me a curveball with all these legal questions. You should be on the Supreme Court! I'm not a judge. Let's stick to Libya. All this talk about process misses the point. Qadhafi, a major threat, was about to massacre his people. We joined a U.N.-backed coalition to neutralize his air defenses, protecting civilians. I promised no ground troops and that our allies would lead. We've kept our word. No U.S. troops, and our allies have carried their weight. We've protected thousands in Benghazi, with no U.S. casualties and no escalation. It's a limited mission. We've consulted with Congress throughout. This controversy is mostly political theater. We acted under a U.N. mandate and saved lives. Qadhafi is now cornered. The War Powers Resolution arose after Vietnam, aiming to prevent unchecked military actions. Consultation is vital. But did we violate the War Powers Resolution? Absolutely not. So, the constitutional question is moot.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Given the contrasting views of Brazil as a global versus regional power, how do you, Madam President, navigate this dynamic to ensure a strong and equitable partnership with the United States? [SEP] Brazil is a nation with global reach and influence, and our partnership with the U.S. reflects that reality. We are committed to working together to tackle the world's most pressing challenges.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, concerning the situation with Russia and Ukraine, if Russia engages in what you termed a 'minor incursion,' will the sanctions you've threatened still be implemented? Are you inadvertently authorizing Putin to conduct a limited invasion? [SEP] That's a very good question.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Will you consider taking away their Federal funding? [SEP] I don't want to say that. They'll listen. They'll be fine. I think we're going to have a good relationship. They need the Federal Government not only for funding—and I'm not saying take it away—but they need it for advice. They'll need, maybe, equipment that we have. We have a tremendous stockpile that we're in the process of completing. We're in a very good position.Again, the cupboard was bare when I got here. Nobody ever thought a thing—in all fairness to previous administrations, nobody ever thought anything like this was going to happen, but it did happen.No, the Governors will be very, very respectful of the Presidency. Again, this isn't me; this is the Presidency. The Presidency has such a great importance, in terms of what we're doing. And you can talk about Constitution, you can talk about federalism, you can talk about whatever you want, but the best way—I'm talking now from a managerial standpoint—is to let individual Governors run individual States and come to us if they have difficulty and we will help them.Yes, John []./
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, regarding Kosovo, what specific deadline are you proposing for U.N. action? Are you worried about escalating tensions with Russia as a result? And what are your thoughts on the Russian missile defense proposal? [SEP] Well, I don't believe I explicitly stated a deadline. I believe I emphasized the importance of time. The fundamental question is whether we will engage in endless discussions on a matter that we have already resolved. We firmly believe that Kosovo should be independent. The G-8 discussions were focused on finding a way to make this outcome acceptable to Russia. Ideally, Russia would acknowledge and accept our conclusion. However, they have not yet reached that point. Therefore, I stressed the need for progress to prevent unmet expectations in Kosovo. That was my intention. We will actively pursue the process. President Putin presented an interesting proposal regarding missile defense for Europe. I also proposed a missile defense system for Europe, designed to protect Europe, not to threaten Russia. The primary threats we face originate from rogue nations that may possess deliverable weapons. It is in the interest of peace to have the capacity to intercept such missiles. President Putin suggested the joint use of radar in Azerbaijan. I agreed to consider it. However, it became clear that he also had reservations about my proposal. Therefore, I proposed that we assemble a group to transparently discuss our respective ideas, sharing technologies and radar positioning to ensure effective coverage. His statement was significant, as it acknowledged the potential for cooperation. Russia is not our enemy. The Cold War has ended. We are now confronting 21st-century threats. I appreciated his recognition of the potential for collaboration. I view it as a positive gesture and look forward to further discussions in July when he visits Maine.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Mr. President, regarding the Indian American outreach during the conventions, specifically the 'Four More Years' video, and the potential for Kimberly, Don Jr., and Ivanka to campaign on your behalf within that community, could you elaborate on your views on the India-U.S. relationship? [SEP] Well, I didn't catch every word of that, but I know India, and I know those young people. Fine young people. Their connection to India is strong, as is mine. Modi is a friend, doing a great job. Not easy, but great. Speaking of which, China and India are having a bit of a go at it on the border, very nasty. We're ready to help if we can, talking to both sides. But I appreciate the kind words. They think highly of India, and so do I. And your Prime Minister. Thank you.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, at the NATO summit in Chicago, do you expect an agreement on a strategy for transitioning in Afghanistan? And are you concerned that the Koran burning and the events that followed might undermine negotiations with our partners? [SEP] The transition policy, established in Lisbon, remains our guiding principle. We're committed to transferring increasing responsibility to the Afghans, with a full transition and the end of our combat role by the end of 2014. Our coalition partners are sticking to the plan. At the NATO meeting, we'll focus on ensuring a smooth transition, avoiding a 'cliff' effect. Like our drawdown in Iraq, this will be a gradual process, building Afghan capacity and strengthening partnerships with Afghan security forces. We'll also establish the necessary support structures for the overall strategy to succeed. The Koran burning incident is concerning and highlights the challenges in Afghanistan, underscoring the need for transition. While violence against our people is unacceptable, President Karzai is eager for greater Afghan responsibility. We'll find a way to respect Afghan sovereignty while empowering them to take greater control of their security. This is in the best interest of both Afghans and ourselves. While I'm confident we can execute the plan, there will be bumps along the road, just as there were in Iraq.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Mr. President, a simple yes or no: Will you encourage federal properties to follow the DC order? [SEP] The matter is under review. We'll provide an update as soon as a decision has been reached.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Given the UK's rising coronavirus cases, why are they exempt from the travel ban, especially when other nations with fewer cases are not? Will you reconsider their inclusion on the ban list? [SEP] Well, let me tell you, that was a recommendation from some very smart people, top professionals. We're keeping a close eye on the numbers, believe me. If they keep going up, we might just have to add them to the list, you know, the ban, or whatever you want to call it. But we're also looking at taking some countries off the list, so it's all very fluid, very dynamic.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: How do you respond to the criticism that your administration is not doing enough to address the violence and corruption in Mexico, particularly given the impact on US citizens and businesses? [SEP] We're deeply concerned about the situation in Mexico and are working closely with the Mexican government to address these challenges. We're providing assistance to strengthen law enforcement, combat drug trafficking, and promote good governance.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. [Inaudible]—Sankei Newspaper Company. I have a question to President Trump. You met with the family members of abductees, and you met with Hitomi Soga, actual abductee. How can you comment on your meeting with them? To North Korea, is there a possibility of U.S. military action? Suppose that the U.S. decides to go on it, the abductees' rescue, how do you think about it once the military action is to be imminent? [SEP] Well, I think it's very sad. I look at what's happened, and it's a very, very sad thing. Who has ever heard of anything like this? Abducted by a hostile country for purposes of language, for purposes of—could be any number of another reasons. We'll see what happens in terms of the ultimate conclusion.But I did put it in my speech at the United Nations, and many people in Japan were really thrilled that I did because a lot of people thought that the folks we're talking about were forgotten about. Like I say, the forgotten people—where they were, maybe they're forgotten people—but I can tell you, your great Prime Minister did not forget. He didn't forget at all.So we'll work together and see if we can do something. Now the spotlight is on and perhaps we can have some very good luck, and perhaps the regime itself would send them back. I think it would be a tremendous signal if Kim Jong Un would send them back. If he would send them back, that would be the start of something—I think, would be just something very special if they would do that.But I spoke with people who were devastated, and they've been devastated for many years. They think they're alive, but they don't know. Probably makes it even tougher that way. But we'll see what happens. Thank you. Thank you. The second question from the United States, Mark Landler, New York Times.
label: Dodging

sentence: President Bolsonaro, would you consider allowing a U.S. military base or presence in Brazil to support your border with Venezuela? Did you discuss this with President Trump? [SEP] Yes, we discussed Brazil potentially becoming a major non-NATO ally. We recently requested U.S. assistance in delivering food through Boa Vista to provide humanitarian aid. That's where we are now. Brazil is willing to do whatever it can to resolve the Venezuelan dictatorship issue and bring freedom and democracy to that country, which was once wealthy but is now suffering from starvation and violence. We need to end this pervasive issue. Mr. President?
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, concerning the Chinese government's expulsion of Wall Street Journal reporters, what retaliatory measures is your administration considering, such as restricting access for Chinese journalists in the U.S.? [SEP] I haven't received a full briefing yet, but we're looking into it. I don't like it; it's unfair. We provide excellent access, maybe too much, some might say. But I believe in open access. We'll make a decision relatively soon. Okay? Good question. Next question, please.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, on Build Back Better and the pandemic: You're optimistic about passing substantial parts of Build Back Better this year. Does that indicate you're considering splitting the package into individual pieces? And on the pandemic, given the Supreme Court's block of the vaccine-or-test rule for large businesses, are you reconsidering vaccine mandates for domestic flights to improve vaccination rates? [SEP] Right, let's start with the last part: The Supreme Court's decision, I believe, was a misstep. However, many individuals working for major corporations are still being tested because of corporate decisions, not my standards. I expect that number to increase, not decrease. Now, remind me, what was the first part of your question?
label: Clarification

sentence: President, what assurances can you provide to concerned employees who are being asked to return to work amidst ongoing health concerns? [SEP] Well, that's really a state-by-state issue. The governors are in charge, and they'll ensure safety. Businesses have options – testing, temperature checks, and so on. This isn't permanent, of course. We all want to return to normalcy, to crowded ballparks and restaurants. This current setup, with reporters so far apart, isn't ideal. We'll get back to normal. Handshakes might be less common, but they'll return. I even took up handshaking when I entered politics. So, the governors have it covered; they're doing a fantastic job.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, about the U.S.-Japan alliance and your Indo-Pacific strategy, you're heading to China, which isn't exactly known for being free or open. How do you balance promoting freedom in the region without a showdown with China? And Prime Minister, the President has talked about Japan stepping up its defense game. He wants to sell you weapons, and there's been talk he was disappointed you didn't take out that North Korean missile. Did that come up, and what's your take on Japan's defense? [SEP] Let me just jump in here on the Prime Minister's point. He'll be knocking those missiles out of the sky as soon as he wraps up buying all that extra military stuff from us. Just like we did in Saudi Arabia, quick and clean. So, Japan's gonna be buying a lot of our top-notch gear, like the F-35, the stealthiest thing out there, and all sorts of missiles. That means jobs for us, and safety for Japan. Now, China, I get along great with President Xi. We're friends. But he's China, I'm the U.S. We see things differently, especially on trade. The problem is, they've been taking advantage of us for years. Our trade deficit is massive, hundreds of billions a year, not even counting intellectual property. We're talking to China about it, and it's gotta change. It's gotta be fair, or reciprocal. I like reciprocal. People understand it. If you charge me this, I charge you the same. Makes sense. We're gonna start doing that. Some countries charge us a hundred percent, and we charge them nothing. That's ending. It takes time, legal stuff, but it's coming. You're gonna see the U.S. take strong action against countries that have been unfair to us. It's already started, and the legal groundwork is done. Big changes are on the way. On Japan's defense, we buy a lot from the U.S. The North Korean situation is serious, so we need to boost our defense. F-35A, SM-3 Block IIA, Aegis vessels, all from the U.S. We'll shoot down missiles if necessary, working closely with the U.S.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, Russia has announced a ban on food imports. Defense Secretary Hagel says troops massing on Ukraine's border increases the chance of invasion. Are sanctions failing? [SEP] It's too early to say if sanctions are failing. They're designed to put pressure on the Russian economy. Look at the markets, capital flight, and growth projections. The Russian economy has stalled. Capital flight is huge. Investors are staying away. Putin has a choice: diplomacy or hurting his economy and people. We're doing what we should. Our allies agree. But the issue isn't resolved. Fighting continues. Civilians are dying. The Malaysian Airlines disaster is a consequence. We need serious talks to ensure all Ukrainians are heard, that they can work through the political process, that reforms are implemented to protect Russian speakers. Putin needs to recognize Ukraine's independence. Sanctions are working as intended.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: So, you are not confirming that she was fired? [SEP] Honestly, I do not know. I only found out about this this morning. I do not yet know the details. Regarding your initial question, Ken Salazar was already implementing changes at MMS. But the truth is, they were not happening fast enough. If they had been, this might have been prevented. Then again, it is possible it still would not have been. We could have had a completely new environmental review process, and they still might have said, this meets industry standards. That is what this commission needs to determine. Was this a systemic failure? Or a one-in-a-million occurrence? What are the inherent risks? The fact that oil companies now have to drill a mile underwater and then another 3 miles below that tells us something about the oil industry. Extraction is becoming more expensive and inherently more risky. That is precisely why you never heard me say, Drill, baby, drill, because we cannot simply drill our way out of this predicament. We are going to have to begin transitioning.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Would you disagree with P.J. Crowley's assessment? [SEP] I believe I have already answered the question.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, the election results suggest a significant disconnect between your agenda and the concerns of voters. Do you acknowledge a need to adjust your policies, and what specific changes will you implement in your White House and your approach to working with Republicans? [SEP] Well, the American people have made it clear that they believe Washington isn't working for them. As President, I'm responsible for addressing that. My job is to find common ground, break through the gridlock, and deliver results. Now, on specific agenda items, like the minimum wage, voters have shown support when given the chance. The key is to identify areas where my proposals align with Republican ideas. There won't be perfect agreement, of course. But I'm committed to reaching out to Republicans, listening to their ideas, and finding areas where we can work together, even if we only agree on 70, 80, or 90 percent of the details. Building trust and improving the way Washington functions is essential.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: So, is this individual facing any real consequences? [SEP] Look, this person is doing a fantastic job, a truly great job. We're evaluating the situation very carefully, very strongly. We'll have a better idea, probably the best idea, in about a week.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: What are your concrete goals for the G-7 summit under your leadership, Mr. President? [SEP] The goal is simple: to do something special, something that builds upon the progress we've already made. We're aiming for a unified front, a display of solidarity among these important nations. And most importantly, we want to foster a spirit of cooperation and understanding.
label: General

sentence: President, Romney claims your Iran strategy is a bust and they'll be nuclear if you win again. What's your take? [SEP] Look, I'm not going to get into a back-and-forth with the other side while they're still figuring out who their guy is. But let's be real: we've spent the last three years building a worldwide team to take on Iran. We've been steady, we've been focused, and we've made it clear that a nuke is a no-go. Is it a walk in the park? No way. Anyone who says it is is either playing games or doesn't know what they're talking about. But I think the whole world, including Iran, knows we're serious about stopping them from getting a nuke. It's not just about Iran; it's about stopping a nuclear arms race and making sure everyone plays by the rules, even in places like Asia where we have problems with North Korea.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. What is your response to Speaker Pelosi who said earlier today you don't know what you're talking about, about the coronavirus? I'm also wondering if you want to address critics who say you can't be trusted about what your administration is saying? [SEP] Well I think—yes, sure. Sure. I think Speaker Pelosi is incompetent. She lost the Congress once. I think she's going to lose it again. She lifted my poll numbers up 10 points. I never thought that I would see that so quickly and so easily.I'm leading everybody. We're doing great. I don't want to do it that way. It's almost unfair if you think about it. But I think she's incompetent, and I think she's not thinking about the country. And instead of making a statement like that, where I've been beating her routinely at everything—instead of making a statement like that, she should be saying we have to work together, because we have a big problem, potentially. And maybe it's going to be a very little problem. I hope that it's going to be a very little problem. But we have to work together.Instead, she wants to do that—same thing with Cryin' Chuck Schumer. He goes out, and he says: The President only asked for $2½ billion. He should have 8½. This is the first time I've ever been told that we should take more. Usually, it's we have to take less.And we should be working together. He shouldn't be making statements like that, because it's so bad for the country. And Nancy Pelosi—I mean, she should go back to her district and clean it up, because it's the number one—if you look at percentage down, that was one of the finest in the world, and now you look at what's happening.And I'm just saying, we should all be working together. She's trying to create a panic, and there's no reason to panic, because we have done so good. These professionals behind me and over here and over there and back here, and in some conference rooms—I just left a group of 45 people that are the most talented people in the world. Parts of the world are asking us, in a very nice way, can they partake and help them.So Nancy Pelosi shouldn't—and she knows it's not true. She knows it—all they're trying to do is get a political advantage. This isn't about political advantage. We're all trying to do the right thing. They shouldn't be saying: This is terrible. President Trump isn't asking for enough money. How stupid a thing to say. If they want to give us more money, that's okay; we'll take more money. Some Republicans think we should have more money too. That's okay. We'll take more money. But they shouldn't demean the people that are on the stage, who are the finest in the world. They're not demeaning me. They're demeaning the greatest health care professionals in the world and people that do exactly what we're talking about.Yes.
label: Explicit

sentence: What proportion of asylum seekers, in your estimation, warrant asylum in the United States? [SEP] I won't speculate on percentages. We are a nation governed by laws, and borders are essential. A nation without borders is no nation at all. I have observed the caravan's advance. Mexico's immigration laws are exceedingly stringent. It began with over a thousand individuals, now reduced to approximately one hundred. Mexico is a vast nation. We are contending with the most inadequate laws imaginable. Congressional action is urgently needed. A wall is paramount. While not impenetrable, it will serve as a deterrent. Border security is imperative. We are deploying National Guard personnel to the border. We require legal reform. Catch-and-release is absurd.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. [Inaudible]—man or a woman? Q. With what type of weapon? [SEP] I don't know that, no.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Regarding the China negotiations: you welcomed students, held off on tariffs, and China agreed to buy more agricultural products. Is this a lopsided agreement, and what more did China concede? [SEP] No, this wasn't lopsided. I did agree to allow our companies to sell to Huawei – it's about jobs, and I want our companies selling things. It's very complex, not easy to manufacture. Tremendous amount of money involved. Our companies weren't exactly happy, but we're allowing it because of national security concerns. Huawei is complicated, and we're leaving it to the end. We'll see where we go with the overall trade agreement.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, doesn't commuting Chelsea Manning's sentence risk encouraging leaks of classified information, particularly given WikiLeaks' connection to Russian interference? And what about Julian Assange's offer to come to the US – are you seeking his extradition and would he be prosecuted? [SEP] Let's be clear, Chelsea Manning served a significant prison sentence. It's not as if leaking classified information goes unpunished. The sentence she received was very disproportionate to what other leakers have received. She went to trial, due process was carried out, and she took responsibility for her crime. I felt it made sense to commute her sentence, not pardon it. Justice has been served, and a message has been sent that national security is paramount. People with concerns about government actions should use established channels and whistleblower protections. I recognize some think these aren't enough, but we need to balance accountability with the safety of those in the field. With respect to WikiLeaks, I don't see a contradiction. I haven't commented on WikiLeaks generally. The intelligence community's conclusions on Russian hacking and WikiLeaks were not conclusive. I don't pay attention to Assange's tweets. I'd refer you to the Justice Department for any criminal investigations. In this cyber age, we need to balance accountability, openness, and transparency with national security. We need to protect our democracy while allowing our agencies to function effectively. I looked at the particulars of this case and felt commuting her sentence was appropriate.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: President Bush, many critics argue that U.S. involvement in Africa is often driven by self-interest, such as access to resources. How do you respond to those criticisms, and what is your vision for a truly equitable partnership between the U.S. and African nations? [SEP] That's just not the way I see it. We're in Africa because we care about the people. We want to help them build better lives, fight disease, and create opportunities. Of course, there are mutual benefits to trade and investment, but our primary focus is on supporting African nations in achieving their own goals. We want to be a good partner, a reliable friend, and that's what I've tried to do during my time as President.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Considering the American interest, would you view a political resolution as positive, even if he were to retain some level of influence? [SEP] The only acceptable resolution is his departure. He needs to step down from his position and halt the violence against the population. He has to go. That's what we're aiming for.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, on the subject of voting rights, Republican legislatures across the nation are enacting laws to restrict voting, particularly impacting minority and young voters who were instrumental in your election. Are you concerned that failure to pass voting rights legislation will cost your party seats in the 2022 elections? [SEP] My concern lies with the fundamentally un-American character of these initiatives. It is, frankly, sickening. The notion that states would prohibit providing water to individuals waiting in line to vote, or that voting would cease at 5 PM, coinciding with the end of the workday for many, or that absentee ballots would be severely restricted. This is all by design. My efforts will be concentrated on three key areas: first, securing passage of the legislation approved by the House; second, educating the American public; and third, mobilizing Republican voters who find these actions reprehensible. These are not the elected officials, but the voters outside this White House. I am confident that we can defeat this because it is a most egregious assault on our democracy. It dwarfs Jim Crow in its scope and intent. I will dedicate all my resources, in collaboration with my colleagues in the House and Senate, to prevent this from becoming law.
label: Deflection

sentence: Which factions within the Republican Party most urgently need to embrace a more inclusive approach? [SEP] The post-defeat inclination is to become insular and impose rigid ideological tests. While this party will recover, its message must be one of inclusivity and acceptance of diverse perspectives. Consider the immigration debate, for instance. The initial discourse fostered the perception that Republicans harbor animosity towards immigrants. If that is the prevailing image, others may feel similarly alienated. Our party must be characterized by compassion and broadmindedness. I recall the 1964 elections, during which my father's Senate campaign was overwhelmed by the Johnson landslide. The Republican Party suffered a significant setback at that time, but experienced a resurgence in '66. A similar recovery is possible now, provided we ensure that our message is inclusive and compassionate, demonstrating our concern for people's lives and our commitment to improving them.
label: General

sentence: President Karzai of Afghanistan has accused Pakistani intelligence of orchestrating a recent terrorist attack in his country. Reports also suggest that Al Qaeda has regained pre-9/11 strength along the Afghanistan-Pakistan border. Is President Karzai's assessment accurate? And do you believe the new Pakistani government is both willing and capable of combating terrorism? [SEP] Let's start by stating that we're taking his allegations seriously and will collaborate with his team to investigate thoroughly. Undeniably, there's a flow of extremists originating from parts of Pakistan into Afghanistan. This is a concern for us, for Afghanistan, and should be equally concerning for Pakistan. We share a common adversary: extremists who resort to violence to disrupt or undermine democratic processes. Al Qaeda remains a presence. We've dealt them significant blows globally, including within Pakistan, and we'll maintain pressure alongside our Pakistani counterparts. I trust that the Pakistani government recognizes the inherent dangers of extremists operating within their borders. Indeed, I believe they do. We'll have the opportunity to delve deeper into this matter during discussions with the Prime Minister of Pakistan on Monday. Pakistan is an ally, a friend. And I reiterate: the United States, Pakistan, and Afghanistan are united by a shared enemy. I recall vividly a meeting at the White House with Presidents Musharraf and Karzai, where we emphasized the imperative of cross-border cooperation to prevent the infiltration of dangerous elements for training purposes into Afghanistan, and their subsequent return with skills that could be leveraged against the government. While some progress was achieved, the struggle persists. We were encouraged by the Provincial elections in that region. We'll continue to support the government in countering extremists and implementing an effective counterinsurgency strategy that leverages aid to foster economic development. It's a formidable challenge, but one we can address more effectively through collaboration than in isolation.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, regarding Cuba, many argue that the U.S. sanctions have historically stifled their progress. Given your administration's shift in policy, will you commit to a complete removal of these sanctions, and in return, what specific democratic reforms do you expect from the Cuban government? Furthermore, considering the current political climate, do you believe Vice President Harris is adequately prepared to assume the presidency if necessary, and what steps are being taken to ensure a smooth transition of power should that become a reality? [SEP] I'm not going to speculate on future elections or potential successors. That's for the political commentators to discuss. Regarding Cuba, our priority is to empower the Cuban people through engagement, not regime change. We want to create an environment where they can decide their own future. The Cold War is over, and we need to move beyond the old ways of thinking. While we have concerns about human rights and regional issues, we also see opportunities for cooperation, such as healthcare. Our approach is to lead by example and advocate for our values through persuasion. Cuba isn't a direct threat to our national security, but we will continue to address our differences constructively. Our priority is to work with the region to promote opportunity and security, and we believe that engagement, not isolation, is the best way forward. We've learned from history that intervention often backfires, and we want to avoid giving Cuba excuses for its own failures.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: What happens if Republicans gain control of the House? [SEP] If Republicans take control, things will be much closer. The predictions were wrong; this wasn't a red wave. We weren't going to lose 30 to 50 seats. There are always enough people on the other team that the opposite party can appeal to. It remains to be seen. Do you think Senator Johnson is going to cut Medicare and Social Security? If he does, how many Republicans do you think are going to vote for it? So it depends.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. Republicans say, more than anything else, what this election was about was spending. And they say it will be when hell freezes over that they will accept anything remotely like a stimulus bill or any kind of the proposals you have out there to stimulate job growth through spending. Do you accept the fact that any kind of spending to create jobs is dead at this point? And if so, what else can Government do to create jobs, which is the number-one issue? [SEP] Well, I think this is going to be an important question for Democrats and Republicans. I think the American people are absolutely concerned about spending and debt and deficits. And I'm going to have a deficit commission that is putting forward its ideas. It's a bipartisan group that includes Republican and Democratic Members of Congress. Hopefully, they were able to arrive at some consensus on some areas where we can eliminate programs that don't work, cut back on Government spending that is inefficient, can streamline Government, but isn't cutting into the core investments that are going to make sure that we are a competitive economy that is growing and providing opportunity for years to come.So the question I think that my Republican friends and me and Democratic leaders are going to have answer is, what are our priorities? What do we care about? And that's going to be a tough debate, because there are some tough choices here.We already had a big deficit that I inherited, and that has been made worse because of the recession. As we bring it down, I want to make sure that we're not cutting into education that is going to help define whether or not we can compete around the world. I don't think we should be cutting back on research and development, because if we can develop new technologies, in areas like clean energy, that could make all the difference in terms of job creation here at home.I think the proposal that I put forward with respect to infrastructure is one that, historically, we've had bipartisan agreement about. And we should be able to agree now that it makes no sense for China to have better rail systems than us and Singapore having better airports than us. And we just learned that China now has the fastest supercomputer on Earth; that used to be us. They're making investments because they know those investments will pay off over the long term.And so in these budget discussions, the key is to be able to distinguish between stuff that isn't adding to our growth, isn't an investment in our future, and those things that are absolutely necessary for us to be able to increase job growth in the future as well.Now, the single most important thing I think we need to do economically--and this is something that has to be done during the lame duck session--is making sure that taxes don't go up on middle class families next year. And so we've got some work to do on that front to make sure that families not only aren't seeing a higher tax burden, which will automatically happen if Congress doesn't act, but also making sure that business provisions that, historically, we have extended each year--that, for example, provide tax breaks for companies that are investing here in the United States in research and development--that those are extended. I think it makes sense for us to extend unemployment insurance because there are still a lot of folks out there hurting.So there are some things that we can do right now that will help sustain the recovery and advance it, even as we're also sitting down and figuring out, okay, over the next several years what kinds of budget cuts can we make that are intelligent, that are smart, that won't be undermining our recovery, but, in fact, will be encouraging job growth.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. I asked about Holder as well.And for the Prime Minister, I wanted to ask you, sir, if the United States does not step up its involvement in Syria, in your view, how will that affect the war? And what plans do you have to react to the bombing of the border town that the President mentioned of Reyhanli? [SEP] Mr. Prime Minister, just excuse me, you're right, I have complete confidence in Eric Holder as Attorney General. He's an outstanding Attorney General and does his job with integrity, and I expect he will continue to do so. Okay?. You are talking about the part of the glass which is empty. I like to look at things with the glass half full instead of half empty. We are—what we would like to see is the sensitivity on the part of the international community with respect to what's going on in . And this is what we, as Turkey, are striving for, and I do believe that the United States is doing the same. And other countries, the United Nations Security Council, the Arab League. And other countries—though not part of these structures—are still sensitive to what is going on in .Our aim is to accelerate this process, and I will be visiting other countries—my Foreign Minister will be visiting other countries—just to see how we can speed things up in a way which will prevent the death of more people and in a way which will ensure a transition to a democratic system in . Our goal is to see the tyranny, the dictatorship, go away in and to be replaced with democracy. And I think this is a collective responsibility on the part of all countries that believe in democracy. And this is what we will all continue to do.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. How did it go down? [SEP] And no subsidies. I even said no tariffs. In other words, let's say Canada—where we have tremendous tariffs—the United States pays tremendous tariffs on dairy. As an example, 270 percent. Nobody knows that. We pay nothing. We don't want to pay anything. Why should we pay?We have to—ultimately, that's what you want. You want a tariff-free, you want no barriers, and you want no subsidies, because you have some cases where countries are subsidizing industries, and that's not fair. So you go tariff-free, you go barrier-free, you go subsidy-free. That's the way you learned at the Wharton School of Finance. I mean, that would be the ultimate thing. Now, whether or not that works—but I did suggest it, and people were—I guess, they're going to go back to the drawing and check it out, right?But we can't have—an example—where we're paying—the United States is paying 270 percent. Just can't have it. And when they send things into us, you don't have that. I will say, it was not contentious. What was strong was the language that this cannot go on. But the relationships are very good, whether it be President Macron or with Justin. We had—Justin did a really good job. I think the relationships were outstanding.But because of the fact that the United States leaders of the past didn't do a good job on trade—and again, I'm not blaming countries, I'm blaming our people that represented our past. It's got to change. It's going to change. I mean, it's not a question of I hope it changes. It's going to change, a hundred percent. And tariffs are going to come way down, because we—people cannot continue to do that. We're like the piggybank that everybody is robbing. And that ends.In fact, Larry Kudlow is a great expert on this, and he's a total free trader. But even Larry has seen the ravages of what they've done with their tariffs. Would you like to say something on that, Larry, very quickly? It might be interesting. One interesting point, in terms of the G-7 group meeting—I don't know if they were surprised with President Trump's free-trade proclamation, but they certainly listened to it and we had lengthy discussions about that. As the President said, all—reduce these barriers. In fact, go to zero: zero tariffs, zero nontariff barriers, zero subsidies.And along the way, we're going to have to clean up the international trading system about which there was virtual consensus of agreement on that. And that will be a target. And these are the best ways to promote economic growth, and we'll all be better at it, and we'll all be stronger at it. So, I myself was particularly gratified to hear my President talk about free trade. Thank you, sir. . Thank you.And it's very unfair to our farmers. Our farmers are, essentially—whether it's through a barrier, nonmonetary barrier, or whether it's through very high tariffs that make it impossible—and this is all over the world. This isn't just G-7. I mean, we have India, where some of the tariffs are a hundred percent. A hundred percent. And we charge nothing. We can't do that. And so we are talking to many countries. We're talking to all countries. And it's going to stop. Or we'll stop trading with them. And that's a very profitable answer, if we have to do it.Yes, sir.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, can you outline the specific actions you are taking to promote your pro-life agenda? [SEP] We're moving forward. I've been pushing consistently, and we've achieved some success. But it's a challenging issue with passionate advocates on both sides.
label: General

sentence: What specific measures are you taking to ensure the safety of journalists and human rights defenders in Mexico, who are facing increasing threats and violence? [SEP] We believe that a free and independent press is essential for a healthy democracy. We're working with the Mexican government to strengthen protections for journalists and human rights defenders and to ensure that those who commit violence against them are held accountable.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, on Afghanistan, what's the endgame? When can we expect our troops to come home? And will you lift the ban on media coverage of returning coffins, something Senator Biden himself criticized? [SEP] The sacrifices of our service members are never forgotten. We're looking at the media policy. On Afghanistan, we're undertaking a comprehensive review. Our priority is to prevent future attacks on American soil. A timeline will be established after the review.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. And on direct talks, sir? [SEP] I don't want to say that.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: So, Mr. President, can you guarantee passage of your legislative priorities in the next 12 months? [SEP] We're giving it our best shot. We're working with everyone, even the people who don't like us. We'll see what happens, okay?
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Yes, I will. Okay. With regards to the CEOs, can you please tell us when you expect to see items like hand sanitizer that have been going out of stock very quickly back on the shelves? There have been a lot of reports about that.And, for you, Mr. President, could you talk about a potential bailout for the cruise industry? You had suggested that could happen. Is that something you're still looking at? And how much would that be? [SEP] Well, I didn't suggest that it could happen, but I can tell you it's an industry that was very badly impacted by what's going on with the virus. And it's a great industry. It's a very important industry, and we will be helping them. And we will be helping the airline industry, if we have to—assuming we have to.So far, people haven't been asking. But if they should be asking, we'll—we want to make sure our airlines are very strong. And then, one day—and one day, all of a sudden, it wasn't looking so good.Interestingly, we were just talking—I was talking to Doug, and the numbers they're doing from the retailing standpoint—I guess, because of this, your business is like the opposite. All of you have done—you've been selling a lot of stuff. Do you want to answer the question, as to the hand sanitizers? Sure. Yes, specifically the areas where we're seeing pressure in the supply chain are surface cleaners, cleaning supplies, paper goods, in particular. Hand sanitizer is going to be very difficult to have a hundred percent in stock on for some time. We're still replenishing it and shipping it, but as soon as it hits the stores, it's going. The same thing is true for the categories I just mentioned. So all of the retailers will be working hand in hand with the suppliers to bring that to the market as fast as we can.
label: Explicit

sentence: Considering Russia's recent actions, including the food import ban and troop deployments near Ukraine, are the sanctions proving ineffective? [SEP] It's too early to definitively say whether the sanctions are working. They are intended to apply considerable pressure to the Russian economy, and indicators suggest they are succeeding in that regard. We're observing significant capital flight and downward revisions in Russian economic growth forecasts. President Putin faces a critical decision: to pursue a diplomatic solution that respects Ukraine's sovereignty or to persist in his current course, which will ultimately harm his own economy and citizens. We are taking appropriate action, with the support of our international partners. However, the situation remains unresolved. Conflict persists, and civilians continue to suffer. We need serious negotiations to guarantee the rights of all Ukrainians and the implementation of necessary reforms. President Putin must recognize Ukraine's independence. Until that occurs, the problem will persist, although the sanctions are functioning as intended.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Sir, can you provide specific details about the denuclearization strategies discussed with Chairman Kim? [SEP] We discussed many ways. And the denuclearization is a very important—it's a very important word. Become a very well used word. And a lot of people don't know what it means, but to me it's pretty obvious: We have to get rid of the nukes.I think he's got a chance to have one of the most successful countries—rapidly, too—on Earth. Incredible country, incredible location. You're right between—if you think of it, you have, on one side, Russia and , and on the other, you have , and you're surrounded by water and among the most beautiful shorelines in the world.There is tremendous potential in North Korea, and I think he's going to lead it to a very important thing, economically. I think it's going to be an absolute economic power.Yes. Go ahead. Please. Go ahead. Yes.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, concerning the violence in Delhi, what did Prime Minister Modi convey about the citizenship law, and what are your concerns about religious violence in India? [SEP] We discussed religious freedom. The Prime Minister was incredible. He strongly supports religious freedom. India has worked hard to have great and open religious freedom. I asked about it in front of many people. We talked about it at length. I believe he means it. As for the individual attack, I heard about it, but didn't discuss it. That's up to India. As for Harvey Weinstein, I'm not a fan.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. The question to President Bush: Were you able to persuade France and Germany to give positive answer on the Ukrainian issue? And how your visit is remarkable to deciding—to having that decision? [SEP] Thank you very much. We have been working with all nations in NATO for a positive outcome, because I strongly believe NATO membership is in— for Ukraine and Georgia is in the interest of our organization. And so I have personally talked to quite a few leaders. Secretary Rice has been talking to her counterparts. Mr. Hadley has been talking to his counterparts. And there's a lot of discussions going on. And I wouldn't prejudge the outcome yet. The vote will be taken in Bucharest.And my stop here is—should be a clear signal to everybody that I mean what I say, and that is, I mean that it's in our interest for Ukraine to join. I mean, that's—and so therefore, one should—but you ought to take more than my stop— more from my stop than just a—trying to send a signal on NATO. I firmly—well, first of all, I was impressed, like most Americans, by the Orange Revolution. You probably don't know this, but a lot of Americans were really, really touched and pleased to see what took place here.And I told the President that Ukraine is—you know, has caught the imagination of a lot of our fellow citizens over the last decade or so, and that you'll have good friends. The key, of course, is to have government that's open, government that's transparent, government that's noncorrupt, government that actually listens to the voices of the people as it makes laws, which is what's happening.But no, this is a good trip, and I'm really thrilled to be here. As the President said, It took you too long to get here, and I admit it. But nevertheless, better late than never, as they say. And I'm thrilled to be here, and I want to thank you for your hospitality.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, concerning Cuba, what role did Fidel Castro play in the negotiations, and how will you address Republican concerns about lifting the embargo? [SEP] I think we've spent enough time on this topic. Next question, please.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: President Obama, acknowledging the ongoing challenges, what specific metrics will you use to measure the success of the website's improvements, and what alternative enrollment pathways are being prioritized to ensure that all eligible Americans can obtain health insurance? [SEP] We're tracking the number of people who are able to enroll successfully, and we're monitoring the website's performance to make sure it's working properly. We're also providing alternative enrollment pathways, such as phone and in-person assistance, to make sure everyone has access to coverage. The goal is to get as many people covered as possible, and that's what we're focused on.
label: Deflection

sentence: Will you consider taking away their Federal funding? [SEP] I'm not going to threaten anyone. I believe we can work together constructively. They need our support, not just financially, but also in terms of guidance and resources. We have a lot to offer. When I came into office, we were in a difficult position, but we've made great progress. I expect the Governors to respect the office of the President, and I believe they will. Ultimately, the best approach is to let the States manage their own affairs and provide assistance when needed.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Thank you so much, sir. Good evening. You mentioned your sitdown with Vladimir Putin and Russian aggression that came up in your conversations today. I'd like to ask you two questions, if I may, on that front. Is it your sense, walking into this meeting, that Americans back home shouldn't expect much in terms of an outcome? Could you provide some specifics on what a successful meeting would look like to you? Are there going to be specific concessions you want Putin to make?And then, I'll just give you my follow-up right now. You've met Vladimir Putin before. What have you learned about him that informs how you approach this sitdown with him? And what's your mindset walking into a meeting with a former KGB agent who you've said has no soul? [SEP] I'll tell you all that when it's over.Look, I've been doing this a long time. The last thing anyone would do is negotiate in front of the world press as to how he's going to approach a critical meeting with another adversary and/or someone who could be an adversary. It's the last thing I'm going to do.But I will tell you this: I'm going to make clear to President Putin that there are areas where we can cooperate, if he chooses. And if he chooses not to cooperate and acts in a way that he has in the past, relative to cybersecurity and some other activities, then we will respond. We will respond in kind.There need not be—we should decide where it's in our mutual interest, in the interest of the world, to cooperate, and see if we can do that. And the areas where we don't agree, make it clear what the red lines are.I have met with him. He's bright. He's tough. And I have found that he is a—as they say, when you used to play ball, a worthy adversary.But the fact is that I will be happy to talk with you when it's over, and not before, about what the discussion will entail.Nancy Cordes, CBS.The President's Meeting With /Detention of Russian Opposition Leader Alexei Navalny
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Do you plan on speaking with him before? [SEP] ——but we have a very good working relationship. We're setting up a meeting. Things have changed very radically from a few months ago, you know, the name-calling and a lot of other things. We get a kick every once and a while out of the fact that I'll be watching people that failed so badly over the last 25 years explaining to me how to make a deal with . I get a big, big kick out of that.But we are doing very well. I think that something very dramatic could happen. They're treating us with great respect. And you know, what's going on with South Korea—and I think President Moon of South Korea was very generous in saying that we helped make the Olympics a great success, because of the fact that, as you know, there was a tremendous animosity, there was a tremendous problem going on. And all of a sudden, people started buying tickets because—whole different feeling when North said, We'd love to go to the Olympics.So a lot of good things are happening with respect to . President Obama told me—when I had the one meeting with him—he said: That's your biggest problem. That's going to be the most difficult thing you have. And honestly, I wish it was handled earlier. I wish it were handled by another administration years ago. I'm not just talking about President Obama. I go back to any administration you want. But over the last 25 years, this should have been handled a long time ago, not now. This should not have been left for me to handle.But we will handle it. We're handling it well. And hopefully, there will peace for , South Korea, Germany—I mean, everything is included—Japan. The Chancellor has been very helpful in the maximum pressure campaign, as I said. Really, very helpful. So have many other nations. President Xi of China has been really good at the border. Everyone is surprised at how tight he clamped down. Everyone said that he'd just talk about it, he wouldn't do it. Well, he did it, and he did it out a relationship that we have and also out of the fact that we're negotiating trade deals, and I think that's also very important to him. Hopefully, we'll come up with something that's good for both countries.So I think some very good things can happen with respect to . We're setting up meetings now. We're down to two countries, as to a site, and we'll let you know what that site is.Do you have a question for the Chancellor?
label: General

sentence: Q. Given the election of these two Muslim women to the House, breaking new ground, do you interpret this as a direct contradiction of your stated views? [SEP] I'm sorry, I didn't quite understand the question. Could you elaborate?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. President Trump, regarding the military intervention, do you think about this possibility of fighting Venezuela to remove Maduro from power? [SEP] So, as I said, all options are open. I think of all possibilities. All options are open. We'll see what happens.And by the way, I see in the audience the son of the President who has been fantastic. Would you please stand up? The job you've done during a very tough period of time is just fantastic. And I know your father appreciates it, that I can tell you. Okay? Thank you very much. Fantastic job.Saagar Enjeti, from Daily Caller. Saagar.
label: General

sentence: Q. President Obama, regarding Chile, while you commend its economic progress and democratic transition, the legacy of the Pinochet dictatorship remains a sensitive issue. Critics point to the U.S.'s role in those dark years. Will your administration support ongoing investigations into the deaths of Allende and Frei Montalva, and consider an apology for past U.S. actions in Chile? [SEP] We will certainly consider any requests from the Chilean government for information about the past, and we would like to cooperate. Understanding our history is crucial. The U.S.-Latin America relationship has had its difficult moments. However, while we learn from the past, we must not be defined by it. Chile's progress in the last two decades has been remarkable, and the U.S. has fully supported it. I can't speak for all past policies, but I can speak for the present and future. The U.S. is committed to democracy, poverty eradication, and inclusive development. We support Chile's open markets and the economic transformation led by and President Bachelet. So, let's learn from history, but not be trapped by it. We have present and future challenges to address.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Mr. President, will you reinstate the Houthi rebels on the terror list, as the UAE is urging? And can you offer any concrete steps you're taking to bring an end to the devastating war in Yemen? [SEP] The situation in Yemen is complex, and we're evaluating all options, including the Houthi designation. Ending the conflict requires a commitment from all sides, and we're working to facilitate that.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, you've called for Assad to step down for quite some time now. When can the American people expect to see a resolution to the conflict in Syria? [SEP] Well, the situation in Syria is a tough one. There's no simple solution, and I can't give you an exact date. We're working with our allies, putting pressure on the regime, and trying to find a way forward. But predicting the future? That's above my pay grade.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Mr. President, can you explain the Hong Kong business advisory? And on Build Back Better, are Senators Manchin and Sinema supporting the $3.5 trillion plan? If cuts are needed, can you keep progressives on board? Chancellor Merkel, do you feel President Biden now understands your perspective on China? Is the U.S. doing enough on global vaccinations, or should American children wait until adults in other countries are vaccinated? [SEP] That's it? I thought I said two questions, but I guess that means two or more from each person called on. Let me talk about the business advisory. The situation in Hong Kong is deteriorating. And the Chinese Government is not keeping its commitment that it made how it would deal with Hong Kong. And so it is more of an advisory as to what may happen in—on Hong Kong. It's as simple as that and as complicated as that. With regard to am I confident?—I'm supremely confident that everything is going to work out perfectly in terms—[]. Look, I understand why the press, among others, is skeptical that I can actually get this deal done on infrastructure and on human infrastructure. And I've watched and listened, and the press declared my initiative dead at least 10 times so far. I don't think it's dead. I think it's still alive. I still have confidence we're going to be able to get what I proposed and what I've agreed to in the bipartisan agreement on infrastructure. I've gotten—we've each committed—I trust the members of—the Republican Senators who have made the commitments relative to how we should proceed and what would be included in the package for infrastructure. And they're men and women of honor, and I expect they would keep their commitment. With regard to the further issue of what's going on and what will confuse the listening audience—but reconciliation—that is the mechanism by which you have to get every single Democrat to agree to proceed on matters like what I announced today. Today—I don't know whether you have any children; it's none of my business whether you do, but if you do, you're going to get—if you're making less than $150,000—you're going to get a significant stipend that is a tax cut. If you have a child under the age of 7 years old, you're going to get—in your bank account today, you're going to get a payment of one-sixth—12 months divided—$3,600—$3,700 for that child divided by 12 every month, just like a Social Security check. It's expected to reduce poverty—child poverty by over 40 percent. And it could be a significant, significant game changer. We have mechanisms to pay for both these mechanisms. And there may be some last-minute discussion as to who—what mechanism is used to pay for each of these items, both the infrastructure package and the human infrastructure package. But I believe we will get it done. Thank you. We talked about China, and there is a lot of common understanding that China, in many areas, is our competitor; that trade with China needs to rest on the assumption that we have a level playing field so that we all play by the same rules, have the same standards. That, incidentally, was also the driving force behind the EU-China agreement on trade that they abide by the core labor norms of ILO. And we are convinced of ours—needing to be technological leaders for our two countries in many, many areas. Obviously, it's legitimate for China wishing to do this as well, but, forexample, we will cooperate in many technological state-of-the-art technologies, for example, CHIPS. I think the act that the President launched is fundamental in this respect and crucial. And we want to trade together at a time of digitalization where security issues loom very large in our agendas. We ought to have an exchange on this; we ought to talk about this; we ought to talk about norms, standards that govern the internet; whether we can agree on common norms. I think, particularly as regards to the relationship of us with China, we ought to coordinate our efforts. We do that in the European Union, and we should do it with the United States. And then, there are interests, obviously: sometimes divergent interests, but sometimes common interests. But we also have, obviously, areas where American companies compete with European companies, and we have to accept that. But I think, basically, the rules as to how we deal with China ought to rest and do rest on our shared values. And I think, on the pandemic, we are obviously of the opinion that the pandemic—we can only master the pandemic if each and every one is vaccinated. We are trying to boost production. We are trying also to get as many people in our country vaccinated as possible—which obviously opens us up to criticism of those countries who as yet have not had the chance, which is why we invested a lot of money in COVAX, which is why we encourage our companies to increase their production of vaccines. And, in Africa, we are trying to help Africans to upskill people so that they, too, can have their own production sites. We're going to do this, but, de facto, there is an imbalance, I agree. And—but we're overcoming. We're putting our all into that and also together in overcoming that imbalance.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Thank you very much, Mr. President. Given the conditions that were just laid out at the migrant facilities at the U.S. border, will you commit to allowing journalists to have access to the facilities that are overcrowded moving forward? [SEP] I will commit when my plan, very shortly, is underway to let you have access to not just them, but to other facilities as well.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, with the resurgence of Al Qaeda in the region, are you considering any changes to our strategy in Afghanistan? [SEP] We're constantly reviewing our strategy to ensure that it's aligned with the current threat environment. We're committed to working with our Afghan partners to build their capacity to defend themselves. We're also focused on promoting economic development and good governance to create a more stable and secure Afghanistan.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, she claims your refusal to ramp up testing, your inconsistent stance on social distancing and masks, and your overconfidence are why one American is dying of COVID-19 every minute.
