What's your take? [SEP] Well, that's probably why she failed so miserably as a candidate and had to drop out – she's just plain wrong on the facts. She's notoriously bad with facts. Let's be clear: We've done more testing than any other country, by far. More than India with its 1.5 billion people, more than China, more than anyone. Our testing is the best in the world. Other countries are calling us, asking how we do it. But here's the thing: when you test as much as we do – 65 million people and counting – you're going to find more cases. If you went to Mexico or other countries, you'd see they barely test at all. They only test people who are already sick. We've done the most testing, and we've done the best job overall. We even became the 'ventilator king,' supplying the whole world with these complex and vital machines. And when you look at the numbers, we were impacted less than many other countries. Now, some of those countries are seeing explosions of cases, even though they had advantages. So, we've done a great job. She's just wrong on the facts. I think she's going to be a big failure, and I'm looking forward to the debate between her and Mike Pence. He'll wipe the floor with her, just like he did with Senator Kaine.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, could you clarify your current stance on the Attorney General and Deputy Attorney General following the midterm elections? Can they expect to remain in their positions long-term? [SEP] That's something we're actively evaluating as part of a broader review. We're considering various options across the administration, as is typical after a midterm. I didn't want to make any changes before the election, but I can say that I'm generally pleased with the performance of my Cabinet. Secretary Pompeo, in particular, has exceeded expectations.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, regarding Afghanistan, with the ongoing summit aiming to prevent its return to being a terrorist haven, the recent massacre of soldiers in Yemen raises concerns. Are you worried that despite U.S. efforts, Yemen is descending into anarchy? What further actions can the U.S. take to mitigate this? [SEP] Well, the situation in Yemen is certainly concerning, and we're monitoring it closely. We've been working with the Yemeni government on counterterrorism efforts, and we'll continue to do so. However, it's a complex situation with many factors at play. We're exploring all options to promote stability and prevent further escalation, but a military solution alone won't suffice. We need a comprehensive approach that addresses the underlying political and economic issues.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, concerning your upcoming meeting with Kim Jong Un, considering that your CIA Director's recent visit to Pyongyang failed to secure the release of detained Americans or any visible concessions from North Korea, are you still willing to meet with Kim Jong Un if Americans remain imprisoned? Will you demand concrete concessions from North Korea in exchange for gestures like sending a potential future Secretary of State? [SEP] Look, the situation is this: they *do* have three prisoners, and we're in talks about them. We're negotiating, doing our best. They've been there a long time, and it's not a pleasant situation. We fought hard to get Otto Warmbier back, but he was in terrible shape. It was a very sad thing. We're working hard to get the three American citizens back. I think there's a good chance we'll get them out. We're having good conversations. We'll keep you in the loop. We're in there, working hard on it. We've come a long way with North Korea. For years, people have been talking and nothing's happened. Past administrations should have dealt with this when they weren't so far along. But we've put on some very tough sanctions, and other things too. I want to thank President Xi of China, who's done more for us than any other administration has seen. He's really tightened up the border, and he's done it powerfully. He didn't think he'd go this far, and I appreciate that. It's put a lot of pressure on them. 93 percent of the goods going into North Korea come from China. President Xi understands that these next few months are very important. He doesn't want a Korea with nuclear weapons. He's also fighting for China's interests. He's been terrific. Could he be better? Always. But he's been very good, and it's made a big difference. We've never been in this position with that regime before. I'm hoping for a very successful meeting. If we don't think it's going to be successful, we won't have it. If the meeting isn't going well, I'll respectfully leave, and we'll continue doing what we're doing. Something's going to happen. I like to stay flexible. I've gotten us to this point. President Moon of South Korea said that if it wasn't for Donald Trump, the Olympics would have been a disaster. It was my involvement that made them a success. If you look at the ticket sales before, it was going to be a mess. We've gotten to this point, and I think we'll be successful. But if I don't think we will be, we're done. Okay?
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, given the outcome of the recent elections, which many interpret as a referendum on your policies, do you feel compelled to reassess your agenda? What concrete steps will you take to modify your policies and improve your relationship with Republicans to address the concerns expressed by voters? [SEP] The American people have spoken: they want Washington to be more responsive to their needs. As President, I bear the responsibility for achieving that. I must work to bridge divides, overcome gridlock, and deliver results. Regarding specific policies, like the minimum wage, voters have demonstrated their support. The key is to identify areas where my proposals align with Republican priorities. While disagreements are inevitable, I'm dedicated to engaging with Republicans, listening to their ideas, and finding common ground. Even if we only agree on 70, 80, or 90 percent of the details, we can begin there. Building trust and improving the way Washington operates is paramount.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Which other Chinese tech companies are you considering banning from operating in the United States? [SEP] Well, Huawei is the main concern, isn't it? Huawei isn't here, and I'm keeping it that way. I've advised European nations and others—Australia's been great—that Huawei isn't coming here. And we've told countries considering Huawei that we won't share intelligence if they use it. They've all backed off. Look at the U.K.; they seemed to be going that way, but now they've changed their minds.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Sir, with all due respect, how do you feel about Democrats skipping the Inauguration after you've been such a strong advocate for a peaceful transition? And did you try to get the President-elect to rethink things like Obamacare or the DREAMers during your talks? [SEP] I'm not going to get into the details of my talks with the President-elect. They were good, productive. Whether I changed his mind? You'd have to ask him. I gave him my best advice, but he won on a different platform. He's going to do his thing. Maybe he'll see things my way on healthcare or jobs once he's in the hot seat. We'll find out. He'll listen to his people. You need a good team to do this job. If you're in a bubble, you're going to screw up. As for the Inauguration, I'm going. Michelle's going. And it won't be as freezing as my first one!
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. How does it help struggling and persecuted Christians in the Middle East, the deal today? [SEP] Well, I think it's going to. I think it's a big start. And you're right about that: Christians have been persecuted by some countries in particular in the Middle East. And I think this is a big start. It's going to be a very strong start, very powerful start, and it's something that I will tell you—I've told David, and I've told every one of our negotiators: If you look at the way Christians have been treated in some countries, it's beyond disgraceful. It's—if I had information and if I had absolute proof—some of the stories that we've heard, which are not easy, which is not easy to get—I would go in and do a number to those countries like you wouldn't believe. What they do to Christians in the Middle East—and it's disgraceful. It's disgraceful. You're right.It's a very big part of the overall negotiation. And as countries come in—for instance, U.A.E. has agreed very strongly to represent us; I think they will very well with respect to Christianity, because in the Middle East, it's not treated well. It's not treated well at all. It's treated horribly and very unfairly, and it's criminal what's happened, and that's for many, many years.I think it's a great question and very—it's a very unfair situation.Please, go ahead.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, now that Mr. Netanyahu has publicly confirmed Israel's strike in Syria, can you clarify the target, confirm your support, and comment on how this action impacts regional stability and potential U.S. involvement? [SEP] I'm going to refrain from commenting on that specific operation. Next question, please.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Do you feel your foreign policy in the Middle East has been undermined by Jimmy Carter's meeting with Hamas leaders? What harm does it do for him to have met with Hamas leaders? [SEP] No. Foreign policy and peace is undermined by Hamas in the Middle East. They're the ones who are undermining peace. They're the ones whose foreign policy objective is the destruction of Israel. They're the ones who are trying to create enough violence to stop the advance of the two-party state solution. They are a significant problem to world peace—or Middle Eastern peace.And that's the reason I'm not talking to them. And that's the reason why—it's just important for people to understand that this is a—we're in a—we're witnessing a struggle between those who understand liberty and believe in the advance of liberty and those who want to stop the advance of liberty. And Hamas has made their position very clear.Unfortunately, they're getting help. In Syria, they get help. There's rumors about Iranian help. And these countries that I just named are—take, for example, Lebanon. I talked to Prime Minister Siniora today. Here's a struggling democracy in the heart of the Middle East that is—whose internal politics are being influenced by Syria, Hizballah—as a result of Iranian influence with Hizballah, all aiming to destabilize the country, which should be a clear signal about the intents of—the intentions of groups like Hizballah and Hamas.And so when you want to talk about peace being difficult in the Middle East, it's going to be difficult. But it's even made more difficult by entities like Hamas, who insist upon lobbing rockets into Israel, trying to provoke response and trying to destabilize—even destabilize the region more.And anybody can talk to who they want, but I just want the people to understand that the problem is Hamas. And until Hamas changes or until there's a competing vision in the Middle East for President Abbas, Prime Minister Fayyad to offer to the Palestinian people, that's all the more reason to try to define a state. And that's why I'm going to the Middle East, besides going to the 60th anniversary of Israel.Yes, Ann [Ann Compton, ABC News].
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Apparently, Lamar Alexander has said he's made a deal with Senator Patty Murray to stabilize Obamacare. Has the White House been involved in those negotiations? And will you support that deal? [SEP] Yes, we have been involved And this is a short-term deal, because we think, ultimately, block grants going to the States is going to be the answer That's a very good solution We think it's going to not only save money, but give people much better health care with a very, very much smaller premium spike—and you look at what has gone on with that—also, much lower deductibles so they can use itLamar has been working very, very hard with the Democratic—his colleagues on the other side, and Patty Murray is one of them, in particular And they're coming up, and they're fairly close to a short-term solution The solution will be for about a year or 2 years, and it will get us over this intermediate hump, because we have—as you probably know, we have—we either have the votes or we are very close to having the votes And we will get the votes for having, really, the potential of having great health care in our countrySo they are indeed working, but it is a short-term solution so that we don't have this very dangerous little period—including dangerous period for insurance companies, by the way For a period of 1 year, 2 years, we will have a very good solution But we're going to have a great solution, ultimately, for health care Okay?
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, shouldn't there be a unified message on mask-wearing from the federal government? Would you advocate for a nationwide mask mandate? [SEP] Look, governors have different situations, different needs. Some are strong on masks, others, not so much. We've provided them with the facts, the science. Ultimately, it's their call. But I've said it before, if you feel more comfortable wearing a mask, go for it. I have one, I've worn it. In certain settings, it makes sense.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, a quick follow-up on busing before we discuss the border. Do you see busing as a practical way to integrate schools? How does this relate to your upcoming policy announcement? [SEP] Well, it's been a method employed for quite some time. I mean, there aren't many alternatives for transporting students to schools. So, it's a practice that's been utilized. In some instances, it's been implemented rather forcefully. And that's part of the equation. But it's certainly a primary means of getting students to schools. I believe if Vice President Biden had answered the question differently, the outcome would have been different. He faced significant criticism on that issue. So, it is certainly a primary method of transporting students to schools.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, while you acknowledge some environmental concerns, your past statements have often downplayed the severity of climate change. What specific, measurable steps is your administration taking to reduce carbon emissions and transition to renewable energy sources? [SEP] No, no hoax. I think aspects of it are. Some people exaggerate. We want the cleanest water, the cleanest air. Our numbers are great, the best ever. But other continents, other countries, they're polluting like crazy. Greta should focus on them. We're doing better than ever. And we have garbage flowing into our oceans from other countries. So Greta needs to work on those countries.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Given your previous statements, Mr. President, regarding the UK's Brexit plan and its potential impact on trade with the US, some perceive a shift in your stance. Critics suggest you've publicly undermined Prime Minister May's position. How do you reconcile these perceptions with the notion of a 'special relationship' between our nations? And Prime Minister, how do you respond to the President's earlier criticisms regarding the limitations of your Brexit plan on future trade deals? [SEP] Let me clarify. There's been no criticism, only concern. I deeply respect the Prime Minister, and any suggestion otherwise is, frankly, fake news. We're recording this, right? The Prime Minister is navigating a complex situation, and my only desire is to ensure that trade between our nations remains unfettered. The UK is a vital partner, and we want to see that partnership flourish. The Prime Minister will make her decisions, and I trust they will align with the best interests of both our countries. As long as we can trade freely, that's what matters. I've been assured by her team that this will be the case. So, let's move forward and focus on the immense opportunities that lie ahead.
label: General

sentence: Q. So, Mr. President, will Georgia be on the agenda when you meet with Mr. Putin? [SEP] They came to see us, and frankly, they impressed us. It's a difficult situation in Georgia, a very tough one. But they made a good case, a really good case. We'll see what happens, okay? Next question, please.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. The theory posits you're secretly saving the world from a Satanic cabal of pedophiles and cannibals. Your thoughts? [SEP] That's not something I'm familiar with. However, I am committed to protecting our nation from all threats, both foreign and domestic. We are working tirelessly to ensure the safety and security of every American.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Mr. President, regarding the issues of rockets and settlements that you mentioned before, what should—what could Israel do regarding the ever-growing threat from Gaza? And regarding the settlements, did you get any new assurances from the Prime Minister regarding the removal of illegal outposts? Do you believe that this time it will be implemented? Do you care about it? [SEP] Yes.[]
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. You've agreed to talk to Syria in the context of the international conferences on Iraq. What's so different or wrong about Speaker Pelosi having her own meetings there? And are you worried that she might be preempting your own efforts? [SEP] We have made it clear to high-ranking officials, whether they be Republicans or Democrats, that going to sends mixed signals—signals in the region and, of course, mixed signals to President Asad. And by that, I mean, photo opportunities and/or meetings with President Asad lead the Asad Government to believe they're part of the mainstream of the international community, when, in fact, they're a state sponsor of terror; when, in fact, they're helping expedite—or at least not stopping the movement of foreign fighters from into Iraq; when, in fact, they have done little to nothing to rein in militant Hamas and Hizballah; and when, in fact, they destabilize the Lebanese democracy.There have been a lot of people who have gone to see President Asad—some Americans, but a lot of European leaders, high-ranking officials. And yet we haven't seen action; in other words, he hasn't responded. It's one thing to send a message, it's another thing to have the person receiving the message actually do something. So the position of this administration is that the best way to meet with a leader like Asad or people from is in the larger context of trying to get the global community to help change his behavior. But sending delegations hasn't worked. It's just simply been counterproductive.Steve [Steve Holland, Reuters].
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Red Cross report? [SEP] I haven't seen it. We don't torture.Yes, Jim [Jim Rutenberg, New York Times].
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Well, I appreciate that, sir. Thank you very much. Mr. President, Vladimir Putin——[At this point, a microphone was brought to Mr. Lemire.] Q. ——thank you. Vladimir Putin, who you'll be seeing in a few days in Geneva, said just a couple of days ago that he believed that U.S.-Russia relations were at a low point. In what concrete ways could your summit change that?And then, secondly, on the same topic: You have said previously, and in the runup to the summit, that you would be unafraid to call out Russia's disruptive actions—like cyber hacks, Ukraine, election interference—but you're not having a joint press conference with Putin. Why not take the chance to stand side by side with him and say those things to him with the world watching? [SEP] [] Well, let me make it clear: I think he's right it's a low point, and it depends on how he responds to acting consistent with international norms, which, in many cases, he has not.As I told him when I was running and when I got elected, before it was—I was sworn in, that I was going to find out whether or not he, in fact, did engage in trying to interfere in our election; that I was going to take a look at whether he was involved in the—a cybersecurity breach that occurred, et cetera; and if I did, I was going to respond.I did; I checked it out. So I had access to all the intelligence. He was engaged in those activities. I did respond and made it clear that I'd respond again.With regard to—I always found—and I don't mean to suggest that the press should not know—but this is not a contest about who can do better in front of a press conference or try to embarrass each other. It's about making myself very clear what the conditions are to get a better relationship are—with Russia.We're not looking for conflict. We are looking to resolve those actions which we think are inconsistent with international norms, number one. Number two, where we can work together, we may be able to do that in terms of some strategic doctrine that may be able to be worked together. We're ready to do it. And there may be other areas. There's even talk there may be the ability to work together on climate.So the bottom line is that I think the best way to deal with this is for he and I to meet, he and I to have our discussion. I know you don't doubt that I'll be very straightforward—[]—with him about our concerns. And I will make clear my view of how that meeting turned out, and he'll make clear how—from his perspective, how it turned out.But I don't want to get into being diverted by: Did they shake hands? How far did they—who talked the most, and the rest. Now, he can say what he said the meeting was about, and I will say what I think the meeting was about.That's how I'm going to handle it.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, if this situation is indeed detrimental to the nation and results in substantial financial losses, why not simply put an end to it? [SEP] Let him speak into the microphone, please. I believe I've already addressed that inquiry.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, regarding Rick Ledgett's suggestion of amnesty for Edward Snowden: To what extent were you pleased that he raised this possibility? Under what conditions might you consider a plea agreement or amnesty for Mr. Snowden? And what is your message to Americans who, after recent developments, believe that Mr. Snowden's actions were justified in exposing the extent of government surveillance and should not be considered criminal by this government? [SEP] I must exercise caution here, Major, as Mr. Snowden is currently under indictment and facing criminal charges. This matter falls within the purview of the Attorney General and, ultimately, a judge and a jury. Therefore, I cannot offer specific commentary on this case at this time. However, I will attempt to address the underlying sentiment of the question, even if I cannot delve into the specifics. I have previously stated, and I maintain, that this was an important conversation that needed to occur. I have also stated that the manner in which these disclosures were made has been detrimental to the United States and damaging to our intelligence capabilities. I believe that there was a way to have this conversation without causing such harm. To provide a specific example, the United States, despite its imperfections, is a nation that adheres to the rule of law, deeply values privacy, civil liberties, and our Constitution. As a result of these disclosures, countries that actively engage in the very activities that Mr. Snowden claims to be concerned about—such as surveillance of their own citizens, targeting political dissidents, and suppressing the press—are now able to stand on the sidelines and portray the United States as having problems with surveillance and intelligence operations. This is a distorted view of the situation. While this debate has been important and necessary, it is also crucial to remember that it has caused unnecessary damage to U.S. intelligence capabilities and U.S. diplomacy. However, I will leave it to the courts and the Attorney General to publicly weigh in on the specifics of Mr. Snowden's case.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, the intelligence community is reporting that Russia is actively working to damage Joe Biden's campaign, and that China is contemplating similar actions against you. How do you assess the veracity of these reports, and what measures are you prepared to implement? [SEP] It's conceivable. Entirely conceivable. But let me be clear: Russia has no desire to see me in office, because no one has been more resolute in confronting them than I have, period.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Mr. President, have you discussed the issue of possible inspections to North Korea's nuclear sites during your negotiations? [SEP] Could you repeat that, louder? And which organization do you represent?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. Your budget relies on revenue from tax increases to multinational corporations that ship jobs overseas and on increases on oil and gas industry. You've been calling on this for years. And if you couldn't get it through a Democratic Congress, why do you think you'll be able to get it through now? And also, doesn't it blunt your push for deficit-neutral corporate tax reform? [SEP] Well, I continue to believe I'm right. [] So we're going to try again. I think what's different is everybody says now that they're really serious about the deficit. Well, if you're really serious about the deficit--not just spending, but you're serious about the deficit overall--then part of what you have to look at is unjustifiable spending through the Tax Code, through tax breaks that do not make us more competitive, do not create jobs here in the United States of America.And the two examples you cite, I think, most economists would look at and they'd say these aren't contributing to our long-term economic growth. And if they're not, why are we letting some folks pay lower taxes than other folks who are creating jobs here in the United States and are investing? Why are we not investing in the energy sources of the future, just the ones in the past, particularly if the energy sources of the past are highly profitable right now and don't need a tax break?So I think what may have changed is, if we are going to get serious about deficit reduction and debt reduction, then we've got to look at all the sources of deficit and debt. We can't be just trying to pick and choose and getting a hundred percent of our way.The same is true, by the way, for Democrats. I mean, there are some provisions in this budget that are hard for me to take. You've got cities around the country and States around the country that are having a tremendously difficult time trying to balance their own budgets because of fallen revenue. They've got greater demands because folks have lost their jobs; the housing market is still in a tough way in a lot of these places. And yet part of what this budget says is we're going to reduce community development block grants by 10 percent. That's not something I'd like to do. But--and if it had come up a year ago or 2 years ago, I would have said no. Under these new circumstances, I'm saying yes to that. And so my expectation is, is that everybody is going to have to make those same sorts of compromises.Now, with respect to corporate tax reform, the whole concept of corporate tax reform is to simplify, eliminate loopholes, treat everybody fairly. That is entirely consistent with saying, for example, that we shouldn't provide special treatment to the oil industry when they've been making huge profits and can afford to further invest in their companies without special tax breaks that are different from what somebody else gets.
label: Explicit

sentence: Concerning the shortages, when can the public expect hand sanitizers to be readily available? And Mr. President, could you elaborate on the possibility of a bailout for the cruise industry? Is it still under consideration, and what's the projected amount? [SEP] The cruise industry is a very important industry. We will be helping them. As for hand sanitizer, I will let the experts answer that.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, the question from my colleague from China is, could relations between North Korea and the United States mirror those between the U.S. and Vietnam? [SEP] Could you repeat that, please?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, could you elaborate on the recent intelligence report concerning Al-Qaeda? [SEP] Pardon?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Jonathan Karl, ABC News. Madam President, thank you. Mr. President, thank you. It wasn't that long ago you were talking about a reset with Russia and were optimistic that relations with Vladimir Putin could be dramatically improved. Did you misjudge him, or did he mislead you? And at this point, isn't it clear that sanctions simply are not going to change his behavior? And just a personal relations question: I'm sure you saw, President Putin was asked that if he were drowning, would you save him? And he said he thought you would save him. So I'm just wondering, was he correct on that? And do you think that Putin would save you? [Laughter]And to President Park, in light of the fact that, as President Obama points out, North Korea is already the most isolated country on the planet, the most sanctioned country, what do you think should be done specifically if they go through with another nuclear test? [SEP] First of all, I absolutely would save Mr. Putin if he were drowning. I'd like to think that if anybody is out there drowning, I'm going to save them. I used to be a pretty good swimmer. I grew up in Hawaii. [] A little out of practice.Keep in mind that, when I came into office, the idea of reset was a recognition that there were a range of issues in which U.S. and Russian interests converged. It was in our national security interests to try to foster cooperation with the Russians so that, for example, we could have alternative supply lines to our troops in Afghanistan; so that we could obtain cooperation from Russia in applying sanctions to Iran and forcing them to the table to see if we could resolve that issue peacefully. And in fact, during the first term of my administration, the approach we took resulted in concrete benefits to the national security posture of the United States. We were able to reduce weapons of mass destruction. We were able to make sure that our troops were adequately supplied in Afghanistan at times, as you'll recall, when there were some tensions within Pakistan after we conducted the raid against bin Laden in Abbottabad. We were able to bring Iran to the table, and we now have what so far, at least, have been constructive discussions about resolving the nuclear problem there.So those were all things that were good for us, and I believe they were actually good for the Russians as well. Mr. Putin, in my second term, has had an increasing tendency to view the world through a cold war prism and to see Russia's interests as invariably in conflict with the West's. I disagree with him in my assessment of what's in Russia's interests, but he's the President of that country. There are still areas that we should be cooperating—on counterterrorism, for example. But his decisions recently—first, with respect to supporting the horrendous bloodshed carried out by the Asad regime in Syria, and then, most clearly, with respect to the situation in Ukraine—makes it much more difficult for us to cooperate. And I suspect that that's going to linger for some time to come.We'll continue to look for areas where, if it's in our national security interests, and they think it's in their interests, that we'll try to find areas where we can work together. But the violations of sovereignty and territorial integrity in Ukraine is a principle that the United States has to stand up to.Now, with respect to the impact of sanctions, Russia has a deep interest in what happens in Ukraine, and I think they're going about meeting those interests in entirely the wrong way. But what's clear is—you're right—Mr. Putin is going to make decisions based on what he thinks is best for Russia, and he views Ukraine as absolutely central, critical to his foreign policy and the long-term strategic interests of Russia.That doesn't mean that he doesn't take into account other long-term interests of Russia. Tens of billions of dollars of capital fleeing Russia poses a problem for Russia's long-term interests. Russia being isolated so that no business man or woman with any sense are going to want to invest there. That's a problem for Russia's long-term interests. And President Putin is not a stupid man and, I think, recently acknowledged that this has already had an impact. And certainly if the situation gets worse and sanctions are broadened to an entire sector, that will have a more severe impact on the Russian people and the Russian economy.And so there's going to come a point at which he's got to make a fundamental decision. Is he willing to see the Russian economy that was already weakened, that was already faltering, weaken further because he's unwilling to deal with Ukraine in a diplomatic fashion that respects their sovereignty, but still meets any legitimate interest that Russia may have? Or is he going to use military force and the kind of destabilizing activities that we've seen so far? That's a choice that he's going to have to make. But we shouldn't make the choice easy for him. He should recognize that the international community as a whole is not going to encourage the kinds of actions that he's taken so far.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, in light of the recent election outcomes, do you believe it's necessary to re-evaluate your policy priorities for the remainder of your term? What specific modifications will you implement within the White House and in your interactions with Republicans to address the concerns expressed by voters? [SEP] The core message from the American people is that Washington is failing to address their needs. As President, I bear the responsibility to rectify this. They expect me to overcome divisions and achieve tangible results. Therefore, my focus is on delivering outcomes and facilitating Congressional action. Regarding policy matters, such as raising the minimum wage, there's clear voter support. The challenge lies in identifying areas of alignment between my agenda and Republican proposals, even if the overlap isn't complete. I intend to engage with Republicans, listen to their perspectives, and seek common ground on issues like infrastructure and exports. We can initiate progress in areas where we share significant agreement, such as 70, 80, or 90 percent, fostering trust and improving the functionality of Washington.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Given the consensus among U.S. intelligence agencies regarding Russian interference in the 2016 election, and President Putin's denial, with whom does your allegiance lie, and are you prepared to publicly condemn Russia's actions? [SEP] Look, there are a lot of people asking questions about that server. Why didn't the FBI ever get their hands on it? It's a legitimate question. My people, top guys, they're telling me it's Russia. Putin says it isn't. All I'm saying is, where's the server? Let's find the server, then we'll talk. I have faith in our intelligence, but Putin was very strong in his denial. He even offered to let our people work with his. It's an incredible offer. And what about Hillary's emails? 33,000 gone. You think that would happen in Russia? Not a chance.
label: Deflection

sentence: Given your remarks about a shift in decency, does this election signal a true departure from the divisiveness of recent years? [SEP] Look, those super-mega-MAGA Republicans? I doubt we'll change their minds. But they're a minority. Most Republicans, we disagree, sure, but they're decent folks. We have different opinions, but I worked with these people in the Senate and House for years. They're honest, straightforward. Different from me, but decent. The world's watching us, you know? At the first G-7, the big democracies, I said, 'America's back.' And someone said, 'For how long?' Serious question. Then someone else said, 'What if you woke up and Parliament was stormed, cops died, and they tried to stop the election confirmation?' Not the same, but what would you think? You'd think England was in trouble. Democracy on the edge. That's how they saw us. 'When will this stop?' Nothing like it since the Civil War. They want to know: Are we stable? Do we know what we're doing? Are we still a democracy? The world looks to us, not that we're always right, but if we pulled out, things would change. They're worried we're still a democracy with rules and institutions that matter. They're asking: Will we accept decisions from the Court, Congress, the government?
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Looking ahead, how will your engagement strategy with Iran be influenced by the outcome of their upcoming elections? [SEP] During the campaign, I emphasized Iran's rich culture and history, while also noting their problematic actions in promoting peace and prosperity. Their support for terrorist groups, their belligerent rhetoric towards Israel, and their pursuit of nuclear weapons are destabilizing. We need a comprehensive approach, including diplomacy. My national security team is reviewing our policy to identify opportunities for constructive dialogue. We'll be seeking openings for face-to-face discussions to shift our policy. Mistrust has built up over time, so progress will be gradual. We'll be clear about our concerns regarding terrorism funding and nuclear proliferation. We aim for a relationship of mutual respect and progress, as demonstrated by my approach to the Middle East and my appointment of George Mitchell. Now, Iran needs to signal a willingness to act differently and embrace its responsibilities.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Mr. President, are you concerned about—[inaudible]? Q. Mr. President, do you have an opinion on the Manhattan grand jury probably indicting your predecessor?Iran  Q. Mr. President, Iran keeps targeting Americans. Does there need to be a higher cost, sir? [SEP] We are not going to stop.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. A lot of our allies in Europe do a lot of business with Iran, so I wonder what your thoughts are about how you further tighten the financial pressure on Iran, in particular, if it also means economic pain for a lot of our allies? [SEP] Yes. It's an interesting question. One of the problems—not specifically on this issue, just in general—that— let's put it this way: Money trumps peace, sometimes. In other words, commercial interests are very powerful interests throughout the world. And part of the issue in convincing people to put sanctions on a specific country is to convince them that it's in the world's interest that they forgo their own financial interest.And, John, that's why sometimes it's tough to get tough economic sanctions on countries. And I'm not making any comment about any particular country, but you touched on a very interesting point.And so therefore, we're constantly working with nations to convince them that what really matters in the long run is to have the environment so peace can flourish. In the ian case, I firmly believe that if they were to have a weapon, it would make it difficult for peace to flourish. And therefore, I'm working with people to make sure that that concern trumps whatever commercial interests may be preventing governments from acting. I make no specific accusation with that statement. It's a broad statement. But it's an accurate assessment of what sometimes can halt multilateral diplomacy from working.Let's see here. Ann [Ann Compton, ABC Radio].
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. ----and bled to death. Have you seen this video? [SEP] I have.
label: Explicit

sentence: So, if I understand correctly, the climate aspect wasn't a deal-breaker for you? [SEP] Could you run that by me one more time? I didn't quite catch the gist of it.
label: Clarification

sentence: Given the concerns about Russian aggression, are you, Mr. President, perhaps emboldening Putin by questioning established alliances? [SEP] That's just the fake news media trying to stir up trouble, probably CNN. They're always twisting things. It's all about ratings, not about the truth.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. So is that a yes that you are running for reelection? [SEP] Look, I don't know where you guys come from, man. I've never been able to travel. I'm a great respecter of fate. I've never been able to plan 4½, 3½ years ahead for certain.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Thank you, sir. Just to follow up on Jennifer's question: The communiqué cited a variety of fronts on China, everything from human rights, the origin of the COVID virus, Taiwan. What do you think China needs to do to ease tensions? [SEP] I think China has to start to act more responsibly in terms of international norms on human rights and transparency.Transparency matters across the board. And I think the idea that—for example, one of the things I raised and others raised—I wasn't the only one who raised this at the G-7—is that we don't know—we haven't had access to the laboratories to determine whether or not—and I have not reached a conclusion because our intelligence community is not certain yet whether or not this was a consequence of a—from the marketplace of a bat, you know, interfacing with animals in the environment that caused this COVID-19 or whether it was an experiment gone awry in a laboratory.It's important to know the answer to that because we have to have access—we have to build a system whereby we can know what—when we see another transparent—lack of transparency that might produce another pandemic. We have to have access. The world has to have access.So we're trying to figure out, the G-7, whether we could put together an international basis upon which we could have a bottom line with what the transparency accounted for.
label: Explicit

sentence: President Biden, concerning the influx of migrants and fentanyl, what specific actions are being taken? President Obrador, how will Mexico accommodate those turned away at the U.S. border? And did you discuss the USMCA energy disputes? [SEP] We're committed to a comprehensive approach to migration, including addressing the root causes and ensuring safe and orderly processing. We're also working with Mexico to combat fentanyl trafficking. We had a productive discussion on a range of issues.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, critics contend that the Roxham Road agreement merely shifts the problem of irregular border crossings rather than solving it. How do you respond to concerns that this agreement will simply lead to increased crossings in other, less regulated areas, potentially exacerbating the challenges faced by border security and asylum seekers? [SEP] Well, that's always a risk, isn't it? But we believe that this agreement is the best way to manage the situation. It allows us to process asylum claims in a more orderly and efficient manner, and it sends a clear message that people can't just cross the border illegally and expect to be welcomed with open arms. We're going to continue to monitor the situation closely, and we're prepared to make adjustments as needed. But we're confident that this agreement is a step in the right direction.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Just to follow up, Secretary Yellen recently stated that some of the tariffs on Chinese imports are more detrimental to consumers and businesses and lack strategic value. Do you agree with this assessment? And are you contemplating removing any of these tariffs? [SEP] I'll be discussing that with the Secretary when I get back. It's under consideration. Keep in mind, these tariffs weren't initiated by us; they were implemented by the previous administration, and they're currently being reviewed.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, concerning potential short-term funding bills from Congress, if these measures are passed, will you still be open to negotiating on broader issues such as healthcare and deficit reduction, or will you view these short-term fixes as a sign of bad faith? [SEP] Let me be clear, I'm always willing to negotiate. I'm a negotiator, that's what I do. But these short-term bills, they're not a solution. They're just kicking the can down the road. We need to address the real problems, the big problems. Healthcare, the deficit, these are serious issues, very serious issues. And I'm willing to work with anyone, anyone, who's willing to come to the table and have a serious conversation.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, I have two questions: one concerning the Ahmaud Arbery case and another on the coronavirus pandemic. On the coronavirus front, given reports of the Vice President's self-isolation, what reassurance can you offer to Americans worried about their safety and the government's reopening strategy? Also, why hasn't testing capacity reached a point where every American who desires a test can obtain one? [SEP] Well, the Vice President has been tested, and he's negative – tested yesterday, tested again today, negative. He's doing great, so that's not an issue. As for Americans getting tested, everybody who wants a test should be able to get one right now. That's the problem with these kinds of questions. We just announced that we're number one in the world, by far, in testing – two, three, even four times more than other countries – and then I'm asked, 'When will everyone be able to get tested?' If someone wants a test, they can get one. Regarding the incident, it's a terrible thing, and many people are looking into it. I've spoken to several people about it. I saw the picture of him in his tuxedo; he looked so handsome. A wonderful young man, with a bright future. It's just awful. They're investigating the case thoroughly, interviewing everyone involved, and we'll see what happens. It's a very sad situation. I've spoken to people closely involved, and I'm following it closely. It's heartbreaking. The video was just terrible. But many people are looking at it, and hopefully, we'll have answers soon. It's truly heartbreaking.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Given the complex history between the US and Chile, particularly regarding the Pinochet regime, will your administration declassify any remaining documents related to that period and offer a formal apology for past US involvement? [SEP] We understand the sensitivities surrounding this period and the importance of transparency. We're committed to working with the Chilean government to address any outstanding concerns and provide as much information as possible, while also focusing on building a strong and forward-looking relationship.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. One quick follow-up on that, in regards to Iran. If sanctions don't work and they continue their malign activity, is there any other measures outside of a military option that can be taken, that you're considering? [SEP] Well I don't want to talk about that but I will say I think the sanctions work. And the military would work but that's a very severe form of winning. But we win. Nobody can beat us militarily. Nobody can even come close. What we've done for our military in the last 3 years is incredible. All made in the U.S.A. by the way. And it's really incredible. Our nuclear was getting very tired. They hadn't spent the money on it. And now we have it have it in as we would say tippy-top shape. Tippy-top. It's—we have new and we have renovated and it's incredible. And we all should pray that we never have to use it. We should never have to use it. And our military itself is in phenomenal shape.And we have a great gentleman as you know going to be taking over Joint Chiefs of Staff. Joe Dunford has been fantastic. He's a great great man and a friend of mine. But General Milley is going to be taking over. And it's going to be—we're going to have a little bit of a celebration both for Joe and for Mark—for everybody.And you know—as you know our Secretary of Defense has just come in Mark Esper. And he's been here for a short period of time but he's got tremendous energy. He's got it. He knows it. That's what he's been doing for a long period of time from the day he graduated or maybe I should say from the day he started at West Point where he was a top top scholar et cetera.So we have a—we have an incredible people. And Steve Mnuchin is here. We did the sanctions today and I think they're probably Steve the strongest that have ever been put on a country. We will certainly never do that to Australia I promise you. [] Pleased to hear it.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, what's the timeline for the Khalid Sheikh Mohammed trial? Will it ever actually happen? [SEP] It needs to happen. We're working with Congress, on a bipartisan basis, to move forward in a way that upholds due process, respects our Constitution, and reflects our commitment to the rule of law. Guantanamo is still used by Al Qaeda as a justification for attacks. We can prosecute these individuals through our justice system and ensure they never harm us again. That's the goal.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, given the Red Cross report detailing the CIA's interrogation methods as torture, and the lack of progress on closing Guantanamo, despite your promises, what specific impediments are preventing its closure? Are you facing internal resistance from your administration? What concrete steps are you taking to overcome these obstacles, and when can the American people expect Guantanamo to finally be closed? [SEP] The Guantanamo situation is, shall we say, a bit of a pickle. We're trying to find places for these folks to go, but nobody wants them. It's like trying to give away a free puppy that bites. We are working with other countries, but it's a slow process. The Senate vote showed that there's not a lot of enthusiasm for bringing these detainees to the US. We're also trying to figure out how to try them, but the courts are involved, and it's taking time. So, we're working on it, but it's not as easy as just flipping a switch. As for the Red Cross report, we are reviewing it carefully. Now, about the internal resistance...
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Thank you for this opportunity to pose a question. My name is Han Ji-hoon, Yonhap News Agency.First, regarding the concept of economic security, a number of Koreans find the concept pretty unfamiliar. So what are the benefits the Korean economy can gain from the economic security cooperation? What are the real benefits that can be experienced by the Korean people?And in addition to that, you talked about universal values—solidarity and alliance—and you very much underscored that point. But if there are, for example, countries that cannot share those values—for example, strong export regulations or controls that the United States is imposing on other countries—do you think you can take—resort to those measures as well? [SEP] As you may be very well aware, economic security is probably something that you have already heard and seen through various newspaper channels.Let's say, for example, this is directly related to the livelihoods of our people. And important industrial goods, for them to be produced—for example, let's say that we're trying to produce and manufacture a car, the unique system of semiconductors. And, for example, we had—[inaudible]—water issues recently. And so these are materials that are critically needed for our daily lives as well as our industrial production.And to secure stability in the supply chain is very much and directly related to the lives of the people as well as the national economy. And this is, in turn, related to the national security as well as military security.And in the past, we had the WTO system that brought countries together to form a free and universal trading order, but due to the COVID-19 pandemic and the formation of the blocks in the market, we see permanent risks when it comes to the supply chain. So it is very important to stabilize the supply chain.And especially our two countries, the United States and Korea, we share the values of democracy and human rights. And among the likeminded countries, they share the values that would be important to stabilize the supply chain. That is why we need to deal with the issue of economic security.The NSCs of the offices of the President are given that authority to deal with this issue. And, for example, if there are any difficult issues to be resolved, then the two countries will be engaged in closer cooperation for economic security. And we decided to pursue this goal going forward.In addition, if you look at the financial market or the foreign exchange market, there could be possible shocks. And when that happens, the two countries can step in to help with each other, and also related to the military security and also economic security. Especially in relation to the export of defense items, what the two countries hope to do is to initiate the negotiations in this area so that we can pave the way for promoting our cooperation in the specific fields.This is not just cooperation in terms of words or empty words—empty promises. It is going to be an alliance that takes action together. And we decided to evolve our alliance even further.And the United States and Korea, we advocate democracy, human rights, and freedom. And even those countries that are not sharing those specific values, for the world peace, of course, we're not trying to exclude them in the process, but we want these countries to be embraced in these universal values.So, especially, we want to start this close solidarity and cooperation among the likeminded countries and countries that share the values.
label: Explicit

sentence: Can you give us any estimate as to how long this will take? [SEP] It's difficult to provide a precise timeframe, but we're working towards a prompt conclusion. Yes, you in the back.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, concerning the objectives set for Prime Minister Maliki, is there a specific timeframe for achieving them? Furthermore, your focus remains on the U.S. combating Al Qaeda. Does this indicate that the responsibility for curbing sectarian violence rests solely with the Iraqis, without U.S. military intervention? And Prime Minister Maliki, could you elaborate on the reason for the cancellation of last night's meeting? [SEP] I apologize, but could you please reiterate the very first component of your rather lengthy question?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. Before I ask my question, I'm wondering if you could actually answer David's. Is the public plan nonnegotiable? [SEP] Well, that's your question. []
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. Mr. President, Mr. ElBaradei of the IAEA said today that Iran's progress in developing uranium enrichment is slow, and that its centrifuges are older models. So how do you reconcile that with the U.S. view that Iran is a major nuclear threat? [SEP] Yes.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President Obama, many felt the recovery after the 2008 financial crisis was too slow. What could have been done differently to accelerate economic growth and provide more immediate relief to struggling families? [SEP] Well, look, we inherited a complete mess. The economy was on the verge of collapse. We took decisive action to prevent a second Great Depression. We passed the Recovery Act, which saved millions of jobs. Could we have done more? Maybe. But we did what we could with the hand we were dealt.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. So, the individual in question was armed, Mr. President? [SEP] That's the information I've received. However, I can't confirm it definitively. You'd need to direct that question to the relevant authorities.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Mr. President, are you comfortable with Postmaster General DeJoy allegedly soliciting GOP donations from his former employees and then reimbursing them? Is that something you condone? [SEP] Look, I've only just heard whispers of this this morning. DeJoy is a highly respected individual, garnered bipartisan support, I'm told. I need to delve deeper into the specifics. I'll have a clearer picture shortly, just like everyone else who caught wind of it today.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Regarding Secretary Azar, do you still support him? [SEP] Good luck to him. In who?
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Then why not devote your energy now to a campaign to have all Americans wear a mask, something that if more effective than a vaccine, would also help schools and the economy? [SEP] Okay, number one, it's not more effective, by any means, than a vaccine. And I called him about that. Those were the two things I discussed with him. And I believe that if you ask him, he would probably say that he didn't understand the question. Because I said to him—I asked him those two questions: the one question which we covered and the mask question.And I was inaccurately covered, because I was on with George last night—George Stephanopoulos. And I enjoyed it. I think people enjoyed it. I got—you know, a lot of people said very good things about the show. I hope they did well. But they said a lot of good things about the show, but they always cut my sentences off. You know, they cut it off.On masks, the masks have problems too. And I talked about the masks about to be handled very gently, very carefully. I see that, in restaurants, they have people with masks, and they're playing around with their mask, and they have it—their fingers are in their mask, and then they're serving with plates. I mean, I think there's a lot of problems with masks.No, vaccine is much more effective than the masks. And if we get the vaccine, we have—added to the fact that our numbers are going way down. You know, you see the numbers. I'm just reading you statistics that are from wherever they get them. But they're very highly qualified statistics.But no, the mask is not as important as the vaccine. The mask, perhaps, helps. Don't forget: A lot of people didn't like the concept of masks initially. Dr. Fauci didn't like them, and a lot of people didn't. And I'm not knocking anybody, because I understand both sides of the argument.But when I called up Robert today, I said to him, What's with the masks? He said, I think I answered that question incorrectly. I think maybe he misunderstood it. I mean, you know, you have two questions; maybe he misunderstood both of them. But the answer to the one is, it's going to be a much faster distribution than he said. Maybe he's not aware of the distribution process. It's not really his thing as much as it would be, let's say, mine. But the distribution is going to be much faster.As far as the mask is concerned, I hope that the vaccine is going to be a lot more beneficial than the masks, because people have used the masks. But when I looked at that chart that we put up, if you look, you know, we write—if you do the good job—they had, I guess, 240,000. But if you do the good—if it worked out well—now, look, one death is too much. One death is too much; should have never happened. But the lower level was at that 240,000—between a hundred and something and 240,000.As far as the mask is concerned, he made a mistake.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. If this drug proves effective, would you expedite its approval in the U.S.? [SEP] It's too early to say. I need more information. I don't have enough data to form an opinion on that yet.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, thank you. Yesterday's energy bill signing with Speaker Pelosi and Senator Reid highlighted efforts to curb greenhouse gases. Yet, your administration is blocking California's stricter tailpipe emission plan. How high a priority is fighting greenhouse gases? Why prevent states from exceeding federal standards? And could you share any insights from your recent climate change discussion with Vice President Gore? [SEP] Let's circle back to that last part. Remind me. Look, the core issue is crafting an effective strategy. Is it more effective to let each state decide on curbing greenhouse gases, or to have a national approach? Director Johnson decided based on the new legislation, which enables a national strategy, raising CAFE standards to 35 miles per gallon by 2020 and boosting alternative fuels to 36 billion gallons by 2022. The Director believes this law provides a national plan.I told Vice President Gore I'm serious about this. We're developing an effective strategy. Yesterday's bill is part of that. Replacing gasoline on a mandatory basis will significantly reduce greenhouse gases. The bill wasn't as strong as I wanted, but I signed it.A key to reformulated fuel standards is investing in cellulosic ethanol research. We can't only rely on corn. Many farmers are concerned, especially those feeding cattle or hogs, as costs rise. We're investing taxpayer money in using wood chips or switchgrass for ethanol. This is a real national plan.Globally, countries emitting greenhouse gases must be involved. I opposed Kyoto because China wasn't included. Our efforts alone won't solve the problem unless countries like China participate.At the Bali Conference, we agreed to a 2-year process. We're also working to ensure major emitters agree on a common goal. This strategy was presented at the G-8 in Germany and Bali.I take this seriously. But we must be effective and not wreck our economy. Developing technologies to maintain our living standards and address greenhouse gases requires prosperity.We also need nuclear power. It generates electricity without greenhouse gas emissions. I'm surprised our country isn't more supportive of nuclear power. I applaud Congress's efforts to incentivize new plants.If you're serious about greenhouse gases, you should support nuclear power. It's the best solution for economic growth and environmental stewardship.Combining increased CAFE standards with alternative fuels and a good electricity strategy creates a comprehensive approach. We also have 250 years of coal reserves, and I believe we can develop environmentally friendly technologies to use it.We have a strategy: bringing others to the table and developing our own plan to meet national and international goals. You've heard some of the components. Yes, sir.
label: General

sentence: Putin, Mr. President? Zelenskyy's demands? [SEP] Putin out is the key, but unlikely. I'll talk if he wants peace, with allies. Support Ukraine's plan. Nuclear safety talks continue.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, the IAEA reports a significant acceleration in Iran's uranium enrichment. President Ahmadinejad vows to proceed. Coupled with the detention of Iranian-American citizens, where is this heading? Is it time for stringent UN sanctions, and are you confident of Russian and Chinese support? [SEP] As we frequently discuss at these briefings, Iran remains a persistent topic due to their defiance of international demands regarding nuclear weapons. The world has spoken against such programs, yet they consistently disregard these calls. I believe we must strengthen sanctions. I've spoken with Condoleezza Rice, and we'll collaborate with European partners on further sanctions. I'll also discuss this with Presidents Putin and Hu Jintao. These leaders must understand that a nuclear-armed Iran is profoundly destabilizing. It's in their interest to collaborate in isolating the regime. I sympathize with the Iranian people, burdened by a government pursuing a condemned program, hindering economic opportunities. Iran has a rich history and hardworking citizens who deserve a more open society. The government's actions lead to further isolation. Therefore, we'll work with partners to maintain pressure. Secondly, the detention of innocent Americans is unacceptable, and we've clearly stated that such behavior is intolerable.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, General Neller told marines in Norway to prepare for a 'big-ass fight.' Can you clarify the nature and timeline of this potential conflict? [SEP] You're saying 'big war'? What does that mean to you?
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, with the speculation intensifying, are you prepared to comment on the possibility of issuing preemptive pardons to members of your administration? A simple yes or no would suffice. [SEP] That subject is off-limits at this press conference.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Are you suggesting both options are viable? [SEP] Maybe both, maybe neither. Are you two a team? Go ahead, ask your question.
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. In his endorsement of you a few weeks ago, Mayor Bloomberg said he was motivated by the belief that you would do more to confront the threat of climate change than your opponent. Tomorrow you're going up to New York City, where you're going to, I assume, see people who are still suffering the effects of Hurricane Sandy, which many people say is further evidence of how a warming globe is changing our weather. What specifically do you plan to do in a second term to tackle the issue of climate change? And do you think the political will exists in Washington to pass legislation that could include some kind of a tax on carbon? [SEP] As you know, Mark, we can't attribute any particular weather event to climate change. What we do know is the temperature around the globe is increasing, faster than was predicted even 10 years ago. We do know that the Arctic ice cap is melting, faster than was predicted even 5 years ago. We do know that there have been extraordinarily—there have been an extraordinarily large number of severe weather events here in North America, but also around the globe.And I am a firm believer that climate change is real, that it is impacted by human behavior and carbon emissions. And as a consequence, I think we've got an obligation to future generations to do something about it.Now, in my first term, we doubled fuel efficiency standards on cars and trucks. That will have an impact. That will take a lot of carbon out of the atmosphere. We doubled the production of clean energy, which promises to reduce the utilization of fossil fuels for power generation. And we continue to invest in potential breakthrough technologies that could further remove carbon from our atmosphere. But we haven't done as much as we need to.So what I'm going to be doing over the next several weeks, next several months, is having a conversation, a wide-ranging conversation with scientists, engineers, and elected officials to find out what can—what more can we do to make in—short-term progress in reducing carbons and then working through an education process that I think is necessary—a discussion, a conversation across the country—about what realistically can we do long term to make sure that this is not something we're passing on to future generations that's going to be very expensive and very painful to deal with.I don't know what either Democrats or Republicans are prepared to do at this point, because this is one of those issues that's not just a partisan issue, I also think there are regional differences. There's no doubt that for us to take on climate change in a serious way would involve making some tough political choices. And understandably, I think the American people right now have been so focused, and will continue to be focused on our economy and jobs and growth, that if the message is somehow we're going to ignore jobs and growth simply to address climate change, I don't think anybody is going to go for that. I won't go for that.If, on the other hand, we can shape an agenda that says we can create jobs, advance growth, and make a serious dent in climate change and be an international leader, I think that's something that the American people would support.So you can expect that you'll hear more from me in the coming months and years about how we can shape an agenda that garners bipartisan support and helps move this agenda forward.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, about those reports of the U.S. spying on South Korea - did you bring that up with President Biden? Did he give you any guarantees? [SEP] We're talking to the U.S. about it, sharing what we need to. They're looking into it, and there's a lot going on. We need to wait and see what they find. We'll keep talking about it.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Sir, with the next election cycle looming, can you definitively state your intentions regarding a potential reelection campaign? [SEP] With all due respect, my focus remains squarely on the duties of this office. I've always been a pragmatist, dealing with the challenges before me. I'm a great believer in fate.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Can you confirm the suspect's gender and the type of weapon used? [SEP] That information is not known to me at this time.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. But can you address why it is the correct time to do this now in the middle of a pandemic? [SEP] Well, we're going to be dealing with countries, and we're going to be dealing with leaders of different parts of the world. We spend $500 million a year. We have for many years—more, far more, than anybody else, including China.And I mean, look, I read off a long list of problems that we have. And we've had problems with them for years. It doesn't matter—we're looking at a term of 60 to 90 days. We're doing a very thorough investigation right now as we speak. But this should have been done by previous administrations a long time ago. And when you look at the mistakes that were made—all of the mistakes that were made—it's just something we have to look at.And it is very China-centric. I told that to President Xi. I said, The is very China-centric. Meaning, whatever it is, China was always right. You can't do that. You can't do that. Not right. And we spend—and again, it's not a question of money. But when we're spending $500 million and China is spending $38 million, $34 million, $40 million—$42 million, in a case. It's—again, not money, but it's not right.So we'll see. This is an evaluation period. But in the meantime, we're putting a hold on all funds going to World Health. We will be able to take that money and channel it to the areas that most need it. And that's another way of doing it, but we have not been treated properly.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. And a quick question on the USMCA. Now that it's been concluded, have you repaired your relationship with Prime Minister Trudeau? [SEP] Yes, I have. We have a very good relationship.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, with the election just around the corner, do you believe that universal mail-in voting is a secure and reliable method, especially considering the potential strain on the Postal Service and the recent changes in New Jersey's voting procedures? [SEP] Well, wait a minute. You just threw—look, I just read last night that now New Jersey is going to try the universal mail-in voting. Well, they didn't know this. So now, all of a sudden, New Jersey is going to be hit with millions of ballots to be sent out. They didn't know anything about this.So how does a Post Office—how does a Postal Service that doesn't know about it, now all of a sudden, New Jersey is supposed to take out, and millions of ballots are going to be sent all over New Jersey?And if you look at some of the things they say, like in—take the State of Nevada, take that little scam that's going on over there with the clubhouse politician Governor. Take that, where the votes don't even have to be in until 7—they get counted 7 days after November 3. That means if—Nevada is a very important State. I think we have a great chance of winning that State. If the votes don't have to be in for 7—and they're not counting the votes—7 days later, that means how are they going to predict a winner on November 3?
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, what's your view on Russia's announcement that it will scale back military operations near Kyiv? Is this the war ending, or is Russia buying time? [SEP] We'll see. I don't read anything into it until I see their actions. We'll see if they follow through. Negotiations have continued today. I met with the heads of state of France, Germany, the UK, and the US. There's a consensus to see what they offer. We'll keep the sanctions strong and provide the Ukrainian military with the capacity to defend themselves. We'll keep a close eye on things. Thank you.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Given the anniversary of the Newtown tragedy and the renewed pushback against an assault weapons ban, how hard are you willing to fight for it? And if Congress blocks it, what other steps are absolutely necessary in a larger plan to tackle gun violence? [SEP] Well, the VP and my folks went deep on this, talked to everyone, even the NRA, and gave me some smart ideas to stop another Newtown. I'm meetin' with the VP today, and I'll tell you more later this week. I'm not worried 'bout the politics, I'm worried 'bout what works to keep our kids safe and stop gun violence, and do it without messin' with the Second Amendment. Congress needs to think hard and vote their conscience, forget the games and do what's right. I still think we need better background checks, less of those big magazines, and a real assault weapons ban. Will it all pass? I dunno. But I'm gonna tell it straight what I think will work. If we can do somethin' that saves even one kid from what happened in Newtown, we gotta do it.
label: Deflection

sentence: Sir, about the NHS: Should the National Health Service be part of the trade negotiations? [SEP] Pardon? I didn't catch that.
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. One quick follow-up, and then I want to ask you about Iran. I just want to make sure I understood what you said. Can you envision any scenario in which we do go off the fiscal cliff at the end of the year?And on Iran, are you preparing a final diplomatic push here to resolve the nuclear program issue? And are we headed toward one-on-one talks? [SEP] Well, obviously, we can all imagine a scenario where we go off the fiscal cliff. If despite the election, if despite the dangers of going over the fiscal cliff and what that means for our economy, that there's too much stubbornness in Congress that we can't even agree on giving middle class families a tax cut, then middle class families are all going to end up having a big tax hike. And that's going to be a pretty rude shock for them and, I suspect, will have a big impact on the holiday shopping season, which, in turn, will have an impact on business planning and hiring, and we can go back into a recession.It would be a bad thing. It is not necessary. So I want to repeat: Step number one that we can take in the next couple of weeks, provide certainty to middle class families—98 percent of families who make less than $250,000 a year, 97 percent of small businesses—that their taxes will not go up a single dime next year. Give them that certainty right now. We can get that done.We can then set up a structure whereby we are dealing with tax reform, closing deductions, closing loopholes, simplifying, dealing with entitlements. And I'm ready to and willing to make big commitments to make sure that we're locking in the kind of deficit reductions that stabilize our deficit, start bringing it down, start bringing down our debt. I'm confident we can do it.It's—and look, I've been living with this for a couple of years now. I know the math pretty well. And it really is arithmetic, it's not calculus. There are some tough things that have to be done, but there is a way of doing this that does not hurt middle class families, that does not hurt our seniors, doesn't hurt families with disabled kids, allows us to continue to invest in those things that make us grow, like basic research and education, helping young people afford going to college. As we've already heard from some Republican commentators, a modest tax increase on the wealthy is not going to break their backs; they'll still be wealthy. And it will not impinge on business investment.So we know how to do this. This is just a matter of whether or not we come together and go ahead and say, Democrats and Republicans, we're both going to hold hands and do what's right for the American people. And I hope that's what happens.With respect to Iran, I very much want to see a diplomatic resolution to the problem. I was very clear before the campaign, I was clear during the campaign, and I'm now clear after the campaign: We're not going to let Iran get a nuclear weapon. But I think there is still a window of time for us to resolve this diplomatically. We've imposed the toughest sanctions in history. It is having an impact on Iran's economy.There should be a way in which they can enjoy peaceful nuclear power while still meeting their international obligations and providing clear assurances to the international community that they're not pursuing a nuclear weapon.And so yes, I will try to make a push in the coming months to see if we can open up a dialogue between Iran and not just us, but the international community, to see if we can get this thing resolved. I can't promise that Iran will walk through the door that they need to walk through, but that would be very much the preferable option.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, given the recent controversies surrounding Paul Wolfowitz, can he still effectively lead the World Bank? [SEP] First off, I believe everyone involved here acted with good intentions. I'm sorry it's come to this. I have a lot of respect for Paul Wolfowitz, especially his dedication to helping the poor. There's a board meeting happening right now. All I can say is, I know Paul Wolfowitz is focused on what's best for the Bank, just like he's always been focused on addressing human suffering and improving the human condition. I admire his vision and respect him greatly. As I said, I regret that it's reached this point. Next question.

sentence: Mr. President, given Baker's comments, could there be any flexibility on preconditions for talks with Iran regarding Iraq? Once they do that, the door to dialogue opens.

sentence: Sir, about the $400, are the states going to have to pick up some of the tab? Which governors have told you they're on board? [SEP] If they don't, they don't. It's their call. sentence: Q. Would you still do it if the room was empty? [SEP] Well, the room won't be empty. The room will have different people there and representatives of countries. But I can understand how it's, you know—it's very difficult for countries to be there. They won't be there only for that reason. They'd love to be there. I've already had people call. In fact, say—a couple of them—I'd love to be there. If you want, I'll be there. I said, Don't be there. You don't have to be there.No, the room would be—I think the room will not be—although, there may be a spacing requirement like you have in this room. This room was always packed. This room would be packed again if we had the seats open. But you have a spacing requirement, so I understand that the United Nations, they may have that too.Yes, please.

I'll have a strong opinion shortly.
