sentence: President Trump, after reaffirming the U.S.-Japan alliance and outlining a vision for a free and open Indo-Pacific, how can the U.S. promote freedom and openness in the region without conflicting with China? Prime Minister, did the President express disappointment about Japan not shooting down the North Korean missile, and what message did you convey about Japan's defense role? [SEP] Mark, on the Prime Minister's answer, he'll shoot them down after buying more U.S. military equipment. Like we did in Saudi Arabia, a needle in the sky hit immediately. The Prime Minister will buy massive amounts of military equipment, the best in the world, from the U.S., like the F-35 fighter, creating jobs and safety. My relationship with President Xi is excellent, I like him, he's a friend, but he represents China, I represent the U.S. Our views differ, but we're similar on trade. For decades, the trade situation has been unfair, a massive deficit, $350-$504 billion, not including intellectual property. We've started discussions with China to lower it, through free, fair, or reciprocal trade. I prefer reciprocal. People understand it better. We'll charge the same as they charge us. Some countries charge us a hundred-percent tax, but we charge them nothing. I've been against that for a long time, and we'll do something about it. It takes time due to statutory limitations. But you'll see strong action against countries treating the U.S. unfairly. It's already started, the legal foundation is done. You'll see a big difference soon. The U.S. has been treated unfairly on trade. Thank you. Regarding Japan's defense equipment, we buy a lot from the U.S. The North Korean situation is tough, Asia-Pacific security is tough, we must enhance our defense capability. F-35A and SM-3 Block IIA are examples. Aegis vessels must be enhanced. We'll buy more from the U.S. We traced the North Korean missiles. Missile defense is a U.S.-Japan cooperation. If necessary, we'll intercept, but we'll coordinate with the U.S.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, concerning Libya, when do you foresee the transfer of command occurring, and is NATO the intended recipient? Also, what are the tangible goals you hope to achieve with your 'alliance among equals' initiative in the Americas? [SEP] Well, with respect to Libya, obviously the situation is evolving on the ground. And how quickly this transfer takes place will be determined by the recommendations of our commanding officers that the mission has been completed--the first phase of the mission has been completed. NATO will be involved in a coordinating function because of the extraordinary capacity of that alliance. But I will leave it to Admiral Mullen and those who are directly involved in the operation to describe to you how exactly that transfer might be--might take place. With respect to this new partnership, I don't want to give you all my best lines from my speech; otherwise, no one will come. But the thing that I'm most excited about is the fact that in a country like Chile, it's not just a matter of what we can give to Chile, it's also a matter of what Chile can offer us.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, if it's so harmful and expensive, why not just stop it? [SEP] I've answered that question. Next!

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. You're aware that Senators Kerry and McCain have a proposal on the Senate floor to give you the leeway to continue operations in Libya for a further year. You've just said that this, from the beginning, has been an operation limited in time and scope. Initially, you said days, not weeks. Are you prepared, are the American people prepared for this operation, with American support, to continue for a further year? And is there any other definition of success than Qadhafi being removed from power? [SEP] Well, first of all, Jim, just a slight correction. What I told the American people was that the initial phase where Americans were in the lead would take days, perhaps weeks. And that's exactly what happened, right? I mean, after around 2 weeks, a little less than 2 weeks, we had transitioned where NATO had taken full control of the operation. So promise made, promise kept.Second, I think when you have the former Republican nominee for President, John McCain, and the former nominee for President on the Democratic side, John Kerry, coming together to support what we're doing in , that should tell the American people that this is important. And I very much appreciate their efforts in that regard.Third, when it comes to our definitions of success, the U.N. mandate has said that we are there to make sure that you do not see a massacre directed against n civilians by the n regime. The n regime's capacity has been greatly reduced as a consequence of our operation. That's already been successful. What we've seen both in the east and in the west is that opposition forces have been able to mobilize themselves and start getting organized, and people are starting to see the possibility of a more peaceful future on the horizon.What is also true is, as long as Qadhafi is still presenting himself as the head of the n Government and as long as he still controls large numbers of troops, the n people are going to be in danger of counteroffensives and of retribution. So there is no doubt that Qadhafi stepping down from power is--from the international community's perspective--going to be the primary way that we can assure that the overall mission of 's people being protected is accomplished.And I just want to point out--I know it's something you know--the International Criminal Court identified Qadhafi as having violated international law, having committed war crimes. What we've seen is reports of troops engaging in horrible acts, including potentially using rape as a weapon of war. And so when you have somebody like that in charge of large numbers of troops, I think it'd be hard for us to feel confident that the n people are going to be protected unless he steps down.Now, what that means, whether there's the possibility of ns arriving at some sort of political settlement, that, I think, is something that ultimately the n people are going to have to make a decision about, because the international community is there in service of that broader goal, of a peaceful .
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, there's growing anxiety about the health of our banks. Doesn't the rescue of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac send the wrong message, suggesting that some institutions are immune to failure and encouraging irresponsible behavior? [SEP] Let's clarify the situation with Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac. It's essential to understand their significance to the mortgage markets. Maintaining confidence and stability in these markets is paramount. Secretary Paulson's plan, which requires congressional approval for a line of credit and potential capital investment, is designed to achieve this. The objective is to reassure the public about the importance of these institutions and to ease anxieties. By presenting this plan, we reduce the likelihood of needing to implement this temporary authority. Now, concerning commercial banks, it's crucial to remember that deposits are insured by the Federal Government up to $100,000. If there are concerns about a bank's stability, depositors should be aware that the FDIC guarantees their deposits up to $100,000. As a depositor, you are protected by the Federal Government. I remember a bank run in Midland, Texas, where someone attempted to reassure people about their insured deposits, but fear overwhelmed reason. I hope people will step back and recognize that their deposits are secure under our Government's protection. So, we're dealing with two distinct issues: the mortgage market and the banking system.
label: General

sentence: Q. And your advice to both of them? [SEP] My advice is, support reasonable people and reject extremists. Understand that most people want to live in peace and harmony and security. It's very important for the American people to understand that most Muslim mothers want their children to grow up in peace, and they're interested in peace. And it's in our interest to help liberty prevail in the Middle East, starting with Iraq.And that's why this business about graceful exit just simply has no realism to it at all. We're going to help this Government. And I'm able to say that it is—that we have a government that wants our help and is becoming more capable about taking the lead in the fight to protect their own country. The only way that Iraq is going to be able to succeed is when the Iraqis, led by a capable person, says, We're tired of it. We don't want violence; we want the peace that our 12 million people voted for. And it's in the world's interest that Iraq succeed.Mr. Prime Minister, you want to answer some more questions? [] Go ahead. Hold on for a minute. Wait, wait, wait. We said six question; now this is the seventh—this is the eighth—eight questions. Mr. President? Yes, this guy?
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, you promised more troops to Afghanistan and a withdrawal from Iraq in 16 months. What's your timeline for withdrawing from Afghanistan? Also, will you overturn the Pentagon policy banning media coverage of flag-draped coffins, given then-Senator Biden's criticism of it? [SEP] Your question is timely. We just received reports of four American servicemembers killed in Iraq. Our thoughts are with their families. People ask me when I realized I was President, and it was signing letters to the families of fallen heroes. It reminds you of the responsibilities and consequences. Regarding media access to loved ones being brought home, we're reviewing those policies with the Department of Defense. I don't want to answer before evaluating the review. Afghanistan is a big challenge. Our troops' work and Ambassador Crocker's diplomacy led to a relatively peaceful election in Iraq. The political system seems to be functioning. We don't see that in Afghanistan. The national government seems detached. The Taliban and Al Qaida operate in the FATA region. We haven't seen a concerted effort to root out those safe havens. We're undergoing a thorough review. General Petraeus and Richard Holbrooke are evaluating a regional approach. We need better coordination of military, diplomatic, and development efforts. This is difficult, but Afghanistan was the base for the 9/11 attacks. I met with 9/11 families, a reminder of the cost of those safe havens. We can't allow Al Qaida to operate there. We need to work smartly and consistently to ensure those safe havens don't exist. I don't have a timeline yet. I won't allow Al Qaida or bin Laden to operate with impunity.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, could you clarify the timeline for accepting migrants from Venezuela, Haiti, Cuba, and Nicaragua, and whether you plan to include other countries in this program? Also, what specific steps are being taken to combat fentanyl, and what impact has the arrest of Ovidio Guzmán had on the Cartel of the Pacific's fentanyl production? [SEP] Well, we're working with Mexico on migration, and we're trying to protect migrants from the dangers they face. People don't leave their homes for fun. They do it because they have to. We need to address the root causes of migration. We're investing in development in these countries. We're not building any migration centers in Mexico. We're just helping with shelters and healthcare. The Venezuelan program is working, and we're looking at expanding it. We're also fighting violence by giving young people opportunities. And we're committed to fighting corruption. It's a big problem, but we're working on it.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President—[inaudible]—Valentinovna, Sputnik News Agency. Have you discussed the issue of possible inspections to North Korea's nuclear sites during your negotiations? [SEP] Speak up, please. And where are you reporting from again?

sentence: Q. They'll still get $600 a week, in addition? [SEP] I won't say that yet. You'll see that when it happens, but we have the money.

sentence: Mr. President, your earlier comments suggested Brexit would hinder a U.S.-U.K. trade deal. Given the 'special relationship,' was criticizing the Prime Minister's policy and her personally appropriate? Prime Minister, is Mr. Trump right about Brexit limiting future trade deals, and how did you feel about his criticism? [SEP] Well, let me just say, I have tremendous respect for the Prime Minister. There was a story, a fake news story, that didn't include all the great things I said about her. We record these things, you know, so we have the truth. Now, she's going to make her own decisions about Brexit. All I ask is that we can trade. We want to trade with the U.K., and they want to trade with us. We're their biggest trading partner. We have a tremendous opportunity to make it even bigger. So, if they go a different route, I just hope we can still trade. I've been told it might not be possible, but I believe it will be. So, we'll see. And I think she's doing a terrific job. Thank you. And just to confirm what the President said, there will be no limit to our trade deals after Brexit. We'll be able to trade with the U.S. and everyone else. We're taking back control of our borders, our laws, and our money. We'll be able to make our own trade deals. And the U.S. is keen to work with us.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, just to be absolutely certain, concerning the Senkaku Islands, are you saying unequivocally that the U.S. military would defend them against Chinese aggression? And isn't this just another 'red line' scenario, potentially undermining U.S. credibility if not enforced, as we saw with Syria? sentence: Q. Looking back, is there anything you believe you could have handled differently? [SEP] Regarding which specific situation are you referring to?

sentence: Mr. President, with the Fed Chair's term ending soon, the financial world is eager to know: have you made a decision regarding the nomination? If not, could you share your key considerations in selecting the next leader of the Federal Reserve? Given the approaching deadline, are you concerned about the potential for a rushed confirmation process, especially if you choose not to reappoint Mr. Powell? [SEP] Look, I understand the interest, I really do. But this is a process, a delicate one. We're moving forward deliberately. I won't telegraph my moves on this. We're well aware of the timeline and are proceeding accordingly. Rest assured, we're considering all the best options, consulting with top economic minds. But I won't be drawn into premature speculation. Next question.

sentence: Q. Sir, could you rephrase that question? [SEP] What exactly are you asking?

sentence: Q. Has it been a painful time? [SEP] The most painful aspect of my Presidency has been knowing that good men and women have died in combat. I read about it every night. My heart breaks for a mother or father, or husband or wife, or son and daughter; it just does. And so when you ask about pain, that's pain. I reach out to a lot of the families. I spend time with them. I am always inspired by their spirit. Most people have asked me to do one thing, and that is to make sure that their child didn't die in vain—and I agree with that—that the sacrifice has been worth it.We'll accomplish our objective; we've got to constantly adjust our tactics to do so. We've got to insist that the Iraqis take more responsibility more quickly in order to do so.But I—look, my heart breaks for them; it just does, on a regular basis.

sentence: Mr. President, given the impending indictment of Prime Minister Netanyahu on corruption allegations, and the ongoing challenges in the Israeli-Palestinian peace process, what specific assurances can you offer that your administration's peace plan will address the core concerns of both sides and lead to a lasting resolution? [SEP] Well, I just think he's been a great Prime Minister. I don't know about his difficulties, but you're telling me something that people have been hearing about. I can say he's done a great job as Prime Minister. He's tough, he's smart, he's strong. He is very defensive. His military has been built up a lot. They buy a lot of equipment from the United States, and they pay for it. Of course, we give them a tremendous subsidy, four billion dollars a year. But they've been very good, incredible in many ways. There is a chance for peace between Israel and the Palestinians. All my life, I've heard that the toughest of all deals would be peace between Israel and Palestinians. They say it's the impossible deal. I'd love to be able to produce it. We'll see what happens. We were paying the Palestinians a lot of money, and I ended that about two years ago because they weren't saying the right things. Why would we pay somebody that's not saying nice things about us and not really wanting to go to the peace table? They've been much better. We'll see what happens.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. ——but the question—but you didn't answer my question. Just very simply, the question is, why are you pitting Americans against one another, sir? [SEP] I'm not.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. Two of the key players in the insurance industry, America's Health Insurance Plans and BlueCross BlueShield, sent a letter to the Senate this morning saying that a government health insurance plan would, quote, dismantle, end quote, private insurers. Why are they wrong? And secondly, this public plan, is this nonnegotiable? Would you sign a health care bill without it? [SEP] Well, let's talk first of all about health care reform more broadly. I think in this debate, there's been some notion that if we just stand pat, we're okay. And that's just not true. You know, there are polls out that show that 70 or 80 percent of Americans are satisfied with the health insurance that they currently have. The only problem is that premiums have been doubling every 9 years, going up three times faster than wages. The U.S. Government is not going to be able to afford Medicare and Medicaid on its current trajectory. Businesses are having to make very tough decisions about whether we drop coverage or we further restrict coverage.So the notion that somehow we can just keep on doing what we're doing and that's okay, that's just not true. We have a longstanding critical problem in our health care system that is pulling down our economy, it's burdening families, it's burdening businesses, and it is the primary driver of our Federal deficits. All right?So if we start from the premise that the status quo is unacceptable, then that means we're going to have to bring about some serious changes. Now, what I've said is, our top priority has to be to control costs. And that means not just tinkering around the edges. It doesn't mean just lopping off reimbursements for doctors in any given year because we're trying to fix our budget. It means that we look at the kinds of incentives that exist, what our delivery system is like, why it is that some communities are spending 30 percent less than other communities but getting better health care outcomes, and figuring out how can we make sure that everybody is benefiting from lower costs and better quality by improving practices. It means health IT. It means prevention.So all these things are the starting point, I think, for reform. And I've said very clearly, if any bill arrives from Congress that is not controlling costs, that's not a bill I can support. It's going to have to control costs. It's going to have to be paid for. All right? So there's been a lot of talk about, well, a trillion-dollar price tag. What I've said is, if we're going to spend that much money, then it's going to be largely funded through reallocating dollars that are already in the health care system but aren't being spent well. If we're spending $177 billion over 10 years to subsidize insurance companies under Medicare Advantage, when there's no showing that people are healthier using that program than the regular Medicare program, well, that's not a good deal for taxpayers. And we're going to take that money, and we're going to use it to provide better care at a cheaper cost to the American people. So that's point number one.Number two, while we are in the process of dealing with the cost issue, I think it's also wise policy and the right thing to do to start providing coverage for people who don't have health insurance or are underinsured, are paying a lot of money for high deductibles. I get letters--two, three letters a day--that I read of families who don't have health insurance, are going bankrupt, are on the brink of losing their insurance, have deductibles that are so high that even with insurance they end up with fifty, a hundred thousand dollars worth of debt, are at risk of losing their homes.And that has to be part of reform, making sure that even if you've got health insurance now, you are not worried that when you lose your job or your employer decides to change policies that somehow you're going to be out of luck. I think about the woman who was in Wisconsin that I was with, who introduced me up in Green Bay--36 years old, double mastectomy; breast cancer has now moved to her bones, and she's got two little kids, a husband with a job. They had health insurance, but they're still $50,000 in debt, and she's thinking, my main legacy, if I don't survive this thing, is going to be leaving $100,000 worth of debt. So those are the things that I'm prioritizing.Now, the public plan, I think, is a important tool to discipline insurance companies. What we've said is, under our proposal, let's have a system the same way that Federal employees do, same way that Members of Congress do, where--we call it an exchange, but you can call it a marketplace--where essentially you've got a whole bunch of different plans. If you like your plan and you like your doctor, you won't have to do a thing. You keep your plan; you keep your doctor. If your employer is providing you good health insurance, terrific; we're not going to mess with it.But if you're a small-business person, if the insurance that's being offered is something you can't afford, if you want to shop for a better price, then you can go to this exchange, this marketplace, and you can look: Okay, this is how much this plan costs; this is how much that plan costs; this is what the coverage is like; this is what fits for my family. As one of those options, for us to be able to say, here's a public option that's not profit-driven, that can keep down administrative costs, and that provides you good, quality care for a reasonable price--as one of the options for you to choose, I think that makes sense.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, with the American people having witnessed massive spending and the economy still struggling, what key indicators should they monitor to assess the effectiveness of your economic programs, beyond simply avoiding a catastrophe? Should they focus on the stock market, foreclosures, or unemployment rates, and when can they expect to see tangible results, or will a 'Plan B' be necessary? [SEP] Look, the most important thing we're doing is getting folks back to work; plain and simple. If we can create jobs, people will have the confidence to spend money, which will help businesses grow and hire more people. Secondly, we need to fix the credit markets. Too many businesses can't get loans, even if they're successful. Finally, we need to stabilize the housing market. The government can't do it alone, but we can work with the Federal Reserve and the FDIC to reduce foreclosures and stabilize housing values. If we can stop the bleeding and start growing again, that's how we'll know we're on the right track. It's going to be a tough year, but I'm hopeful we'll see real improvement next year. Now, who's next?
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, there's a bill in Congress concerning DC voting rights and an additional seat for Utah. Given your advocacy for democracy abroad, would you support extending these rights domestically? [SEP] That's news to me. I wasn't aware of that particular bill being considered.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, concerning the Bidens and Ukraine, what specific allegations did you want investigated? [SEP] The Bidens are a disaster, a total mess. The son made millions doing nothing. It's obvious. Ask something else.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. So, as you raise these broader issues on—of human rights and democracy, what is your message to those—including some members of your own party—who believe that your administration is overlooking the targeting of religious minorities and a crackdown on dissent in India? [SEP] Well, look, the Prime Minister and I had a good discussion about democratic values. And there is a—there is the—that's the nature of our relationship: We're straightforward with each other, and we respect each other.One of the fundamental reasons that I believe the U.S.-China relationship is not in the space it is with the U.S.- Indian relationship is that there's an overwhelming respect for each other because we're both democracies. And it's a common democratic character of both our countries that—and our people—our diversity; our culture; our open, tolerant, robust debate.And I believe that we believe in the dignity of every citizen. And it is in America's DNA and, I believe, in India's DNA that the whole world—the whole world—has a stake in our success, both of us, in maintaining our democracies. It makes us appealing partners and enables us to expand democratic institutions across—around the world. And I believe this, and I still believe this.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, following the Brexit vote and its potential impact on the global economy, what measures will you take to stabilize the markets and encourage a swift resolution? Do you still believe the UK should be at the back of the queue for a US trade deal? And will you actively promote the TPP while campaigning for Secretary Clinton? [SEP] Roberta, excellent questions. I'll even help my friends out a bit on that last one. When I visit other countries, it's not my place to comment on candidates in the middle of a race. Governments tend to transcend whoever is in power. With respect to Brexit, the markets seem to have settled down a bit. We're monitoring for any systemic strains. Central banks and our Treasury Secretary have prepared well. There are longer-term concerns about global growth if Brexit freezes investment in Great Britain or Europe. We need to boost global demand. Whether it's the US improving infrastructure, or Germany spending more, or China shifting to domestic-based growth. With respect to Brexit negotiations, my message is: everyone should catch their breath, come up with an orderly, transparent plan. Both sides have a stake in getting this right. Leadership issues in Great Britain will need to be resolved quickly. Chancellor Merkel's interest is in making sure the process works. We'll help in any way we can. As for the UK and a trade agreement, they'll be the least of their problems right now. Their first order of business is Europe. But the special relationship with Great Britain doesn't change. The ties are deep and long-lasting. Our relationship with the UK fundamentally doesn't change. Their absence from the EU makes it harder to solve other challenges. Our relationship goes far deeper than any individual leaders. Canada, the US, and Mexico will continue to have close relationships. I look forward to working with whomever the American people elect as their President. I know we will always be able to find shared priorities. My Government will respect fully the domestic electoral process in the United States. We are facing a global reality. We have a populist world, an interconnected world with its own challenges. In the world we're living, in different places, we have political leaders, political stakeholders that use demagoguery and have the populistic slogans that want to eliminate and destroy what has been built, what has taken decades to build to go back to problems of the past. And yes, it is true, all the benefits have not reached society as we whole. That is true. But those leaderships, those political actors, by using populism and demagoguery, they choose the easiest way to solve the challenges of today's world. And things are not that simplistic. It's not as easy as that. To lead a country, to take on a responsibility to rule a country, it goes beyond giving the easiest answer. It is complex and it is difficult to lead a country.We have reached so far—the level of development, the level of well-being that we have in the world—without a doubt makes contrast with what the situation that we lived 30 years back. Never before a global society—or the societies, at least, of our three countries—had lived the level of development and well-being that we enjoy today. Never before had our countries had a high life expectancy as we have today. Never before had we had the opportunity to have access to the knowledge of the world as fast and as easy as we do today. Never before were in such a level of connection between society and the possibility of having access to any product from any corner of the world as we do today. And that was built throughout the years by using the model based on openness, free trade, trade agreements.And the biggest challenge today is to make sure that those benefits reach out to every single citizen. But the solution proposed by some is not by destroying what we have been built, it is not taking a different route to choose the road towards isolationism and destruction. What we need to do is to keep up the pace towards development. And when I said that, I mentioned that most of what some people say, it is very similar that in the past—and President Obama already said it, even years back—but in the past, some leaders addressed their societies in those terms. Hitler and Mussolini did that. And the outcome, it's clear to everyone: It resulted in devastation, and it turned out to be a tragedy for mankind.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, can you clarify your definition of 'minor incursion'? Is there a specific threshold of territorial gain or casualties that would trigger the promised sanctions? [SEP] My administration is monitoring the situation closely and will respond appropriately.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Are you prepared to assure the American people that a government shutdown will not occur during the lame-duck period? [SEP] I'd like to say yes, but I can't. It's not entirely up to me. It requires cooperation from the other side. So, we'll see what happens. I'm optimistic, but I can't guarantee anything.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Mr. President, the Washington Post reports the White House is holding up the GOP coronavirus bill over language about the FBI building. Can you confirm this? [SEP] I'm not sure if it's in *this* bill, but everyone agrees the FBI needs a new building. The current one is ancient and frankly, poorly constructed. Panels are falling off, concrete is crumbling – it's dangerous! They considered sites far from D.C., but I insisted they stay near the Justice Department. The current location is ideal. So, I've been pushing for a new building. Renovation won't cut it; we need a state-of-the-art facility for the next century, maybe even with a rooftop track for the agents! It's a huge site, perfect for a new building. Whether it's in this bill or another, the FBI will get its new building. Thank you all!
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Thank you for those comments, Mr. President. Here's a question. I'm wondering if you plan to ask Congress for the remaining $350 billion in bail money. And in terms of the timing, if you do that before you leave office, sir, are you motivated in part to make life a little easier for President-elect Obama? [SEP] I have talked to the President-elect about this subject. And I told him that if he felt that he needed the 350 billion, I would be willing to ask for it, in other words, if he felt like it needed to happen on my watch.The best course of action, of course, is to convince enough Members of the Senate to vote positively for the request. And, you know, that's all I can share with you, because that's all I know.
label: Explicit

sentence: Given the internal divisions within the House Republican caucus, particularly the influence of factions less inclined to cooperate with your administration, how optimistic are you about Speaker Boehner's ability to deliver on any comprehensive deal you might reach? [SEP] Look, Speaker Boehner's got a tough job. He's got a lot of folks in his caucus who aren't exactly fans of mine. They're more worried about getting primaried than doing what's right for the country. But the American people are tired of gridlock. They want solutions. And I believe Speaker Boehner knows that. So, while it won't be easy, I'm hopeful that we can find common ground and get something done.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, concerning the situation in Syria, many are focused on Russia's involvement. Following your discussion with President Putin, do you believe he was honest about his intentions in Syria? If Russian forces target groups aligned with the U.S. alongside ISIS, will the U.S. military intervene to protect them? Furthermore, considering the failures in the U.S. train-and-equip program, can it be salvaged, or should alternative strategies be considered? Specifically, would you consider a no-fly zone, as advocated by several presidential hopefuls, including your former Secretary of State? [SEP] Look, the situation in Syria is complex, and it's important to understand how we got here. What started as peaceful protests against Assad devolved into a civil war because of his brutal response. This isn't a conflict between the U.S. and any party in Syria; it's a conflict between the Syrian people and a ruthless dictator. Assad remains in power because Russia and Iran have supported him throughout this process. Putin's actions now aren't particularly different from what they've been doing in the past; they're just more overt about it. They're propping up a regime that's rejected by the Syrian population because Assad has been willing to bomb his own people to stay in power. I told Putin that the only way to solve the problem in Syria is through a political transition that's inclusive, keeps the state and military intact, but gets rid of Assad. He's too toxic for Syrians to accept. I offered to work with Putin if he can convince Assad and Iran to agree to this transition. A military solution won't work; it'll just get them stuck in a quagmire. We all want to destroy ISIS, but Putin doesn't distinguish between ISIS and the moderate Sunni opposition. He thinks they're all terrorists, which is wrong. We're talking to Russia to avoid accidental clashes. We still believe Assad's the problem and his brutality must end. We're ready to work with anyone to achieve that, but we won't help Russia crush Assad's opposition. The moderate opposition is key to Syria's future. Russia's actions are weakening them and strengthening ISIS. Our train-and-equip program hasn't worked as planned, partly because the opposition is too busy fighting Assad to focus on ISIS. We're looking at what's worked, like our work with the Kurds, and building on that. We'll also keep working with the opposition because without a change in government, the civil war will continue, fueling ISIS. Putin went into Syria because Assad was crumbling. Sending arms and money wasn't enough; he had to send in his own forces. Nobody's buying his plan. Iran and Assad are his only allies. We have a coalition of 60 nations. Putin might realize it's in his interest to broker a political settlement. We're ready to work with Russia and Iran on that. It won't be easy, but it's possible. We need to talk, but only if there's a recognition that Assad has to go. We can't go back to the way things were. Russia's attacks on the moderate opposition are making things worse.
label: General

sentence: Considering Rick Ledgett's remarks on Edward Snowden, what are your thoughts on granting him amnesty or a plea deal? And how do you respond to Americans who feel Snowden's actions were justified in revealing surveillance practices? [SEP] Snowden is under indictment, so I need to be cautious. This is a matter for the Attorney General and the courts. I've stated before that this discussion was crucial. However, the manner in which it occurred harmed U.S. intelligence capabilities. We uphold the rule of law. These revelations have enabled countries that actively conduct surveillance to criticize us. It's caused unnecessary harm. I'll defer to the courts.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, intelligence agencies are reporting that both Russia and China are meddling in the election, with Russia targeting Biden and China potentially targeting you. How do you view these reports, and what actions will you take to address this interference? [SEP] Well, let me tell you, nobody's been tougher on Russia than me. And China, they respect me. So, if they're meddling, it's probably because they're afraid of what I'll do. We'll see what happens.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Thank you very much, Mr. President. On Venezuela, you did the tough sanctions, and you sent the aid, but it seems like Maduro is no closer to leaving. And I'm wondering if you're getting worried about losing momentum. And how long are you being told that this going to take? [SEP] No one's giving me a specific timeline. They've been in power a long time, both him and his predecessor. Eventually, I expect things will change. But we haven't really implemented the toughest sanctions yet. We have that option. All options are on the table. We've only done sanctions that are right down the middle. We can get much tougher if necessary. It's a tragedy, and we're only trying to help people who are starving and dying in the streets. What's happening there is a disgrace. It used to be one of the wealthiest countries in the world, and now it's grief-stricken, poverty-stricken, with no food, water, air conditioning, or power. The power went out for a long time last week and will likely fail again because it's barely holding together. It's very sad, Roberta. Very sad to see.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, the UN has warned of potential food supply disruptions due to the pandemic. What specific measures are you taking to ensure that Americans have access to adequate food supplies during this crisis? [SEP] We're working closely with our farmers and food producers to maintain a stable supply chain. We're also providing assistance to food banks and other organizations that are helping to feed those in need. We're confident that we can weather this storm and ensure that all Americans have access to the food they need.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. So you could be going to Charlotte? [SEP] Anybody have any ideas? We'll be announcing it very soon.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: President Obama, can you confidently say that Speaker Boehner has the authority and influence to deliver on any agreements made, considering the divisions within his party? [SEP] That's a question for the Speaker himself, not for me. My experience with John Boehner has been good. I believe he's a good man who wants to do what's right for the country. But, as has been alluded to, the politics that swept him into the Speakership are challenging for governing. The Republican caucus needs to recognize that American democracy works when people listen to each other, assume good intentions, and are willing to compromise to solve big problems. Some members of that caucus haven't fully come to that realization yet.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: What preconditions must be met before you would consider a meeting with President Castro in Havana? And regarding North Korea, are you contemplating further economic sanctions, military action, or a cyber response? [SEP] Regarding Cuba, we are not actively pursuing a meeting at this time. We want to see real change on the island. On North Korea, we are assessing all available options and will respond appropriately to their actions.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: President Bush, given the growing economic anxieties, what is your prognosis for the severity and length of the anticipated recession, and what specific strategies are being implemented to cushion the economic impact on Mexico, considering its close economic ties with the United States? [SEP] Let me be clear, we're experiencing a slowdown, not a recession. We're implementing pro-growth policies, like tax rebates, to boost the economy. President Calderon is a strong leader, and I'm confident he will navigate Mexico through these challenges. And on the subject of Colombia, we must support President Uribe and pass the free trade agreement. It's vital for security and prosperity.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Are you considering, at any point, issuing an Executive order addressing mail-in ballots? And why do you think some people are pushing it so hard? [SEP] Well, there's never been a push like this for mail-in ballots. And if you look at the New York Congressional race, which is a disaster—Carolyn—it's been a total disaster. They have—they're 6 weeks into it now. They have no clue what's going on. And, I mean, I think I can say right here and now, I think you have to rerun that race, because it's a mess.Nobody knows what's happening with the ballots and the lost ballots and the fraudulent ballots, I guess. I think you'd probably have to take the Carolyn Maloney race and run it over again. How can you do this? And this is a small race with literally thousands of people—small thousands—and it's all messed up.You look at Paterson, New Jersey, it's all messed up. Almost every one of these—and these are small, easy to control. They should be able to do this easy.Now you're talking about, like, Nevada, where last—2 nights ago, they went out and in the darkness of night without people, without having any meetings of the public, without having anything, they approved a ridiculous—you don't have to look at signatures. You don't have to approve anything. You can have double mailings. You can have all sorts of things. Nobody has ever seen anything like it. It's a disgrace. I mean, honestly, it's a disgrace.So it's a very good question. I mean, the mail-in ballots, if you look at just some of the small places, the small races—congressional race in New York, it should be very easy. Normally, that would have been announced at 7 o'clock, and it would have been down to the wire and everybody would have loved it. If it was at all complex, it would have taken an extra 45 minutes or an hour, and they would have announced it a little bit later. They have no clue. This was about 6 weeks ago, and they have no clue what's going on.They've lost ballots. There's fraudulent ballots. It's—how are you going to do that for an entire nation? They're using COVID to try and get the mail-in ballots.Now, absentee ballots are great. Absentee ballots, they have to request them. They go through a process. They get them. But the universal mail-in ballots have turned out to be a disaster.And what Nevada has been doing—if you look, over the last few days, you have to look at what they've done. You can have two ballots, you can harvest—it's harvesting, so you can take thousands of ballots, put them together and just dump them down on somebody's desk after a certain period of time.They have something where, if you vote, the vote can count up to 7 days later. Well, if the vote is going to count 7 days later, that means you—you know, if it depends on the one State like Nevada, that would mean simply that you can't have—supposing it's down to that one State—it could be—it's a great State. But supposing it's down to that one State, that means you have to wait 7 days.But they won't have it there. This is something that's so messed up. And by the way, I have to say, the Post Office, for many, many years, has been, you know, run in a fashion that hasn't been great. Great workers and everything, but they have old equipment—very old equipment. And I don't think the Post Office is prepared for a thing like this. You'll have to ask the people at the Post Office. But how can the Post Office be expected to handle? They have regular mailing, and then now, on top of that, they have the internet, where you have Amazon and these companies doing, you know, all the buying—instead of going to a department store, they go buy through mail. So you have massive numbers of purchases now going through the Post Office, purchases of items and gifts, and that's a tremendous strain on the Post Office. The Post Office loses a fortune, and it has been for many, many years, for decades.So now, on top of it, it has this, and the Amazons of the world and the others, they pay very, very little money. They lose money on every—the Post Office loses money, which is ridiculous, on every package it delivers. But now, on top of that—and I'm not just referring to Amazon, I'm talking about all of the competitors, if there is such a thing, to Amazon. There will be. But if there is such a thing.But now, on top of that, you'll have somebody like the Governor of Nevada come out with this massive plan, out of nowhere, to take millions of ballots and send them all over the place. You'll never know who won that State. It will get messed up just like New York and just like Paterson, New Jersey and just like many other places.In West Virginia, they indicted a postman for doing something very bad. You know that. And—but there are many cases all over the country. If you look, you'll be able to find—there's a list of them all over the country. And that has to do with universal mail-in.Again, absentee is great. It works. Like in Florida, they'll do absentee. It really works. But universal mail-in ballots is going to be a great embarrassment to our country.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. To follow up on Jackie's question, you talked about providing assistance in Afghanistan for some time to come. But given the challenges there and the history in Afghanistan, what makes you think that after declaring victory in Afghanistan, that it won't slide back into becoming a haven for terrorists? [SEP] Well, I don't have a crystal ball. I think that right now the debate surrounding Afghanistan is presented as either we get up and leave immediately because there's no chance at a positive outcome, or we stay, basically, indefinitely and do, quote, unquote, whatever it takes for as long as it takes. And what I said last year, I will repeat, which is, we have a vital national interest in making sure that Afghanistan is not used as a base to launch terrorist attacks.It is true that Al Qaida right now is in Pakistan. And you'll often hear, Why are we in Afghanistan when the terrorists are in Pakistan? Well, Al Qaida is pinned down and has been weakened in part because they don't have the run of the territory. We would be less secure if you returned to a situation that existed prior to 9/11, in which they had a Government that was friendly to them and willing to house their operations. And I don't think anybody would dispute that.So A, we've got a vital interest in the region; B, we do not expect, because of our involvement in Afghanistan, that the country is going to completely transform itself in a year or 2 years or 5 years. President Karzai does not expect that; the Afghan people don't expect that. Afghanistan has its own culture. It is a very proud culture. It has a lot of work to do with respect to development, and it's going to have to find its own path.But I reject the notion that the Afghan people don't want some of the basic things that everybody wants: basic rule of law, a voice in governance, economic opportunity, basic physical security, electricity, roads, an ability to get a harvest to market and get a fair price for it without having to pay too many bribes in between. And I think we can make a difference and the coalition can make a difference in them meeting those aspirations, even as we are meeting our security interests. Those two things are tied together.Now, there has been a lot of obsession around this whole issue of when do we leave. My focus right now is how do we make sure that what we're doing there is successful, given the incredible sacrifices that our young men and women are putting in. And we have set up a mechanism whereby we are going to do a review--and I've signaled very clearly that we're not going to just keep on doing things if they're not working--and that by next year, we will begin a process of transition.That doesn't mean that we suddenly turn off the lights and let the door close behind us. And if you look at what's happening in Iraq right now, we have met every deadline. By the way, there was a timetable in place, and we are--we have--by the end of August, will have removed all of our combat troops from Iraq. We will maintain a military presence there, we will maintain military-to-military cooperation, and we are providing them assistance, but we're meeting this deadline.And I think it is worth the extraordinary sacrifices that we are making--and when I say we, not just the United States, but all coalition members--to try to see a positive outcome in Afghanistan as well.All right? Last question, Scott Horsley [National Public Radio]. Where's Scott?
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. President Obama, with TPP facing congressional hurdles, will you adjust your approach, particularly regarding currency manipulation? And your reaction to the Taliban leader's death and Pakistan's concerns? [SEP] Look, TPP is a complex issue, and there's always going to be political noise, especially during an election. But the bottom line is, this is a good deal for American businesses and workers. We're getting rid of thousands of taxes on our goods. As for currency manipulation, we've strengthened the provisions to address it. And on the Taliban leader, he was targeting our troops, so we took action. It doesn't signal a change in our overall strategy. President Quang, your thoughts?
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Yes. Mr. President, you've said that the arrest of Jimmy Lai in Hong Kong is, quote, a terrible thing. Do you have a message for Jimmy Lai? Has your administration spoken directly with him? Is your State Department working for his release? [SEP] Well, I send him best wishes. I hear he's a wonderful gentleman. He's certainly a brave man. And I send him best wishes.With that being said, because of that and obviously what happened in Hong Kong, we've taken all of the vast amounts of money that we use to subsidize Hong Kong. We essentially subsidized Hong Kong by giving them all sorts of incentives. And that's what made Hong Kong—the exchange and business in Hong Kong—successful. I've taken it all back. That means that the United States is going to do a lot more business. You know, we really gave them tremendous incentive and subsidy in order that they be successful for freedom.But now that the freedom obviously seems to have been taken away, we will keep all of the incentives that we were giving them, which is billions and billions of dollars. And all of that business will come into our country, including the New York Stock Exchange and NASDA
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, as you contemplate the end of this war, can you justify the enormous human and financial costs, given that Afghanistan is somewhat less developed than initially hoped? President Karzai, do you still believe that foreign influence is largely to blame for Afghanistan's corruption and poor governance, and are you fully committed to stepping down as President after the elections next year? [SEP] We must remember why we went into Afghanistan. 3,000 Americans were brutally murdered by terrorists who were operating openly there. It was absolutely the right thing to do to go after that organization and the government that let them do it. Our troops and our Afghan friends have done a great job in achieving our main goal: to weaken Al Qaida so they can't attack us again. Everything we've done has been focused on that. We'll be able to say that the sacrifices made by our service members have achieved that goal. We also wanted a stable, sovereign Afghanistan, a responsible partner. That meant Afghanistan needed its own security and a path to prosperity and peace. Afghanistan still has work to do, but the chance of peace and prosperity is better now than before we went in. That's partly because of the sacrifices Americans have made. Did we achieve everything we imagined? Probably not. It's a human thing, you fall short sometimes. Did we achieve our main goal? Have we built a strong relationship with a responsible Afghan government that will work with us to prevent future attacks? We're getting there. We thank our military, intelligence, and diplomatic teams, and the Afghan government and people. On corruption, there is corruption in Afghanistan. We're fighting it. We've made progress, but we're not satisfied. On foreign corruption in Afghanistan, I've said that Afghanistan needs cooperation from international partners to fix how assistance is delivered. On elections, my greatest achievement will be a fair, interference-free election where Afghans can choose their next president. I'll be a happy retired president.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, can you provide any insights into the nature of these alternative proposals or the specific strategies being employed? [SEP] I understand the desire for more information, but I must refrain from discussing sensitive matters that could compromise ongoing negotiations. It is imperative that we maintain a strategic advantage and avoid providing our adversaries with any leverage.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Does their election refute your message? [SEP] I'm sorry, I didn't quite understand. What was that?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, would you like to retract your previous praise of China's transparency regarding the coronavirus outbreak back in January? [SEP] I maintain a respectful stance towards China.
label: General

sentence: Q. Has the American President calmed you in the sense that, on the policy of his successor on climate change and Russia, he has allayed your fears? And how—are you concerned that the common European policy towards Russia will collapse? And after the election of Mr. Trump, would you—as a sign of civility, wouldn't you actually have to declare that you are going to be a candidate again? [SEP] Well, I try to make it a rule not to meddle in other people's politics. All I can say is that Chancellor Merkel has been an outstanding partner. And Chancellor Merkel is perhaps the only leader left among our closest allies that was there when I arrived, so in some ways, we are now the veterans of many challenges over the last 8 years. And although we have not always been in sync on every issue, in terms of our core values, in terms of her integrity, her truthfulness, her thoughtfulness, her doing her homework, knowing her facts, her commitment to looking out for the interests of the German people first, but recognizing that part of good leadership on behalf of the nation requires engaging the world as a whole and participating effectively in multilateral institutions, I think she's been outstanding.So it's up to her whether she wants to stand again, and then ultimately, it will be up to the German people to decide what the future holds. If I were here and I were German and I had a vote, I might support her. [] But it's—I don't know whether that hurts or helps. []With respect to Russia, my principal approach to Russia has been constant since I first came into office. Russia is an important country. It is a military superpower. It has influence in the region, and it has influence around the world. And in order for us to solve many big problems around the world, it is in our interest to work with Russia and obtain their cooperation.I think we should all hope for a Russia that is successful, where its people are employed and the economy is growing and they are having good relationships with their neighbors and participating constructively on big issues like climate change.So I've sought a constructive relationship with Russia, but what I have also been is realistic in recognizing that there are some significant differences in how Russia views the world and how we view the world.The values that we talked about—the values of democracy and free speech and international norms and rule of law, respecting the ability of other countries to determine their own destiny and preserve their sovereignty and territorial integrity—those things are not something that we can set aside. And so in—on issues like Ukraine, on issues like Syria, we've had very significant differences. And my hope is that the President-elect coming in takes a similarly constructive approach, finding areas where we can cooperate with Russia where our values and interests align, but that the President-elect also is willing to stand up to Russia where they are deviating from our values and international norms.And I don't expect that the President-elect will follow exactly our blueprint or our approach, but my hope is, is that he does not simply take a realpolitik approach and suggest that if we just cut some deals with Russia, even if it hurts people or even if it violates international norms or even if it leaves smaller countries vulnerable or creates long-term problems in regions like Syria—that we just do whatever is convenient at the time. And that will be something that I think we'll learn more about as the President-elect puts his team together.I am encouraged by the President-elect's insistence that NATO is a commitment that does not change. And his full commitment to NATO as the foundation for our international security, I think, is very important.And finally, in terms of my conversations with President Putin, these are conversations that took place before the election. As I indicated, there has been very clear proof that they have engaged in cyber attacks. This isn't new. It's not unique to Russia. There are a number of states where we've seen low-level cyber attacks and industrial espionage and other behavior that we think should be out of bounds. And I delivered a clear and forceful message that, although we recognize Russia's intelligence gathering will sometimes take place even if we don't like it, there's a difference between that and them either meddling with elections or going after private organizations or commercial entities, and that we're monitoring it carefully and we will respond appropriately if and when we see this happening.I do think that this whole area of cyber is something that, at an international level, we have to work on and develop frameworks and international norms so that we don't see a cyber arms race. A lot of countries have advanced capabilities, and given the vulnerabilities of our infrastructure and our economies to digital platforms, we have to be careful in making sure that this doesn't become a lawless, low-level battlefield.And we've started trying to put together some principles that were adopted in the G-20, the G-7, and at the U.N. levels, but a lot more work remains to be done on that front. Well, allow me if I may to underline, first of all, that I'm very much impressed that, in spite of a very tough election campaign, this transition period in the United States of America, because it is—it follows democratic principles, is working smoothly. Because this is all about the American people, it's about the destiny of the American people, the outgoing administration is sharing its knowledge, its expertise with the incoming administration. And this to us is a sign of encouragement to continue the good cooperation that we have built between the United States of America and the Federal Republic of Germany. And that is in our mutual interest.So we will continue this. I will continue this with—I approach this with an open mind, and I'll do it on the basis of a deep conviction with President-elect Donald Trump.Secondly, on Russia, I can only repeat what the President said previously. This is all about respecting certain principles. And I'm saying this from a European vantage point, from a European—from a German vantage point, sorry. The fact that for over 70 years, we have been able to enjoy peace, to live in peace very much depends on territorial integrity and sovereignty of each and every European country being respected. In view of the European history, the reverse would be the start of a very bitter road down a slippery slope, and we have to nip this in the bud. We have to stand up resolutely against any such attempts.But we are pinning our hopes on political efforts. This is why we launched the Normandy process, in close coordination with the United States of America. And particularly from a German perspective—from the European perspective—I can only say again, Russia is our neighbor. And just look at Poland—the sort of European perspective this has. So we have an interest in seeing this relationship be a good one. We have a lot of historical ties, of course, a history that we share. But this mustn't keep us from, wherever we feel there are very grave differences of opinion, to raise them with them, but again, with political means and always trying to work for political settlements.And this is what I'm going to continue to work on with all my heart. So on the question whether I will put up a candidacy, I will do this at the appropriate time, and this is not today.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, did Speaker Pelosi offer any assurances regarding impeachment during your conversation? [SEP] Impeachment? The whole thing is a joke. They're obsessed with impeachment. They can't stand the fact that I won. They can't stand the fact that we're making America great again. So they resort to these ridiculous witch hunts, these phony investigations. It's a disgrace.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, the war in Yemen has been described as a humanitarian catastrophe. Given your initial commitment to ending it, and the current push to re-designate the Houthis, what concrete steps are you taking to alleviate the suffering of the Yemeni people and bring this conflict to a close? [SEP] Look, we're aware of the situation. We're exploring various avenues, engaging with regional partners. Ending the war requires cooperation, and that's what we're working towards. It's a process.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. So you're inclined to pull the troops out? [SEP] Say it?
label: Clarification

sentence: And with respect to American oil producers, what is your inquiry? [SEP] I'm sorry, could you clarify the question you're posing?
label: Clarification

sentence: So, you're uncertain about the warming trend? [SEP] I'm looking forward to hearing President Putin's account of the meeting. What interests me most is whether he still holds the same concerns as I do. He confirmed in Australia that he recognizes it's not in the world's best interest for Iran to have the capacity to develop nuclear weapons. They've been supportive at the United Nations, and we're collaborating on a possible third resolution. That's my primary concern. I'm not worried about the images. I understand the context of their meeting. I will continue to work with Russia, as well as other nations, to maintain a focused effort on conveying the message that Iran will remain isolated if it continues its nuclear weapons ambitions.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Sir, regarding the $400, will the states be covering some of the costs? Which governors have committed to this? [SEP] Look, if they don't want to, that's their choice. It's their problem, not mine. Their constituents won't be happy, though. They have the funds available. So, if they refuse, it's on them. The states have the money, it's just sitting there.
label: Implicit

sentence: So, you're dismissing the intelligence community's assessment and trusting Kim Jong-un's assurances? Isn't that a risky approach to national security? [SEP] I have the best instincts, okay? I know how to deal with these people. We're talking, we're negotiating. That's better than war, right? We're making tremendous progress. You'll see. Just wait.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. And did he call you? [SEP] I don't think we have time set aside for that meeting.Now, with that being said, we're very shortly meeting again at the G-20, where he'll be there, and I'll be there. And that's where we're actually looking forward to meeting.
label: Dodging

sentence: President Bush, considering the Baghdad regional conference, what specific accomplishments can you point to, and what are your expectations for future rounds? Moreover, do you truly believe Iran and Syria are sincere in their pledges to stabilize Iraq, and could this potentially open avenues for more formal dialogue with these countries? [SEP] I'm a results-oriented person. I like to see actions, not just hear words. If they truly want to help stabilize Iraq, they know what they need to do: stop the flow of weapons and suicide bombers. The conference was a positive step, bringing regional players together to support Iraq's democracy. It boosted the Iraqi government's confidence, which is crucial for reconciliation. As for future meetings, Secretary Rice will be there, continuing the work we started. We're watching closely to see if Iran and Syria back up their words with concrete actions.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. And my second question is on your trip to Saudi Arabia, which is coming up next month. As we just discussed, Americans are paying almost $5 a gallon nationally, on average, for gas. So do you expect to ask the Crown Prince or the King to increase oil production? And if so, how will you balance that with your desire to hold them accountable for their human rights abuses? [SEP] Well, first of all, that's not the purpose of the trip. The purpose of the trip—my—first of all, I'm starting off on that trip in Israel. And the Israelis are—believe it's really important that I make the trip. And in addition to that, what we're trying to do is that the G-7—it's the Gulf States plus three. And so I'm sure the—it's in Saudi Arabia, but it's not about Saudi Arabia. It's in Saudi Arabia.And so there's no commitment that is being made or—I'm not even sure; I guess I will see the King and the Crown Prince, but that's not the meeting I'm going to. They'll be part of a much larger meeting.And what we're talking about in dealing with that trip is that, before I go, I'm, as I said, going to Israel to meet with Israeli leaders to affirm the unbreakable bond Israel and the United States have. And part of the purpose is—the trip to the Middle East—is to deepen Israel's integration in the region, which I think we're going to be able to do and which is a good—good for peace and good for Israeli security. And that's why Israel leaders have come out so strongly for my going to Saudi.But the overall piece here is, we're also going to try to reduce the deaths and—in the war that's occurring in Yemen. There's a whole range of things that go well beyond anything having to do with Saudi, in particular.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, considering the US already spends significantly more on defense as a percentage of GDP, what specific concessions have you offered to incentivize these NATO allies to increase their spending? [SEP] We're not talking about concessions, we're talking about fairness. It's about everyone paying their fair share. We're protecting them, and they need to contribute. It's a simple equation. And frankly, with our economy booming like never before, we can afford to do our part, but everyone else needs to step up too.
label: General

sentence: Q. ——you in a position to talk to him about those subjects? [SEP] Yes. I won the travel ban, as you probably know. A lot of people said I lost it. No, I won the travel ban, and we use the travel ban where we think there's—not based on religion, but where we think there's going to be trouble, where we're looking at certain countries. As you know, we added a few countries onto it.But we won the travel ban, and we won it in the Supreme Court. So the travel ban is not a thing against Muslims, it's a thing against areas where we don't want people coming into our country that are going to cause problems, cause harm, cause death, hurt our people. And I feel very strongly about that.Okay. Please go ahead.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. When did you show that to Kim? What was the goal there? [SEP] Today. Yes, we had it made up by some—I hope you liked it. I thought it was good. I thought it was interesting enough to show, one in English and one in Korean. And we had it made up. I showed it to him today. Actually, during the meeting—toward the end of the meeting. And I think he loved it. He—they were giving—we didn't have a big screen like you have the luxury of having. We didn't need it because we had it on a cassette and—an iPad. And they played it. And about eight of their representatives were watching it, and I thought they were fascinated.But I thought it was well done. I showed it to you, because that's the future. I mean, that could very well be the future. And the other alternative is just not a very good alternative. It's just not good. But I showed it because I really want him to do something. Now, I don't think I had to show it because I really believe he wants to—I think he wants to get it done.Yes. Go ahead. How's Staten Island Ferry doing? Okay?
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. I'd like to take you back to not this summit, but the one you hosted at Camp David a couple of days ago and whether you feel that you can ensure--assure investors there are contingency plans in place to cope, if Greece leaves the euro, to prevent a Lehman-like shock to the U.S. and the global economy? [SEP] We had an extensive discussion of the situation in the euro zone, and obviously, everybody is keenly interested in getting that issue resolved.I'm not going to speculate on what happens if the Greek choose to exit because they've got an election and this is going to be an important debate inside of Greece. Everybody who was involved in the G-8 summit indicated their desire to see Greece stay in the euro zone in a way that's consistent with the commitments that it's already--that have already been made. And I think it's important for Greece, which is a democracy, to work through what their options are at a time of great difficulty.I think we all understand, though, what's at stake. What happens in Greece has an impact here in the United States. Businesses are more hesitant to invest if they see a lot of uncertainty looming across the Atlantic because they're not sure whether that's going to mean a further global slowdown. And we're already seeing very slow growth rates and in fact contraction in a lot of countries in Europe. So we had an extensive discussion about how do we strengthen the European project, generally, in a way that does not harm world economic growth, but instead moves it forward.And I've been clear, I think, in--not just this week, but over the last 2 years about what I think needs to be done. We've got to put in place firewalls that ensure that countries outside of Greece that are doing the right thing aren't harmed just because markets are skittish and nervous.We've got to make sure that banks are recapitalized in Europe so that investors have confidence. And we've got to make sure that there is a growth strategy to go alongside the need for fiscal discipline, as well as a monetary policy that is promoting the capacity of countries--like a Spain or an Italy--that have put in place some very tough targets and some very tough policies to also offer their constituencies a prospect for the economy improving, job growth increasing, incomes expanding, even if it may take a little bit of time.And the good news was, you saw a consensus across the board, from newly elected President Hollande to Chancellor Merkel, to other members of the European community, that that balanced approach is what's needed right now. They're going to be meeting this week to try to advance those discussions further. We've offered to be there for consultation to provide any technical assistance and work through some of these ideas in terms of how we can stabilize the markets there.Ultimately, what I think is most important is that Europe recognizes this euro project involves more than just a currency. It means that there's got to be some more effective coordination on the fiscal and the monetary side and on the growth agenda. And I think that there was strong intent there to move in that direction. Of course, they've got 17 countries that have to agree to every step they take. So I think about my one Congress, then I start thinking about 17 congresses, and I start getting a little bit of a headache. It's going to be challenging for them.The last point I'll make is, I do sense greater urgency now than perhaps existed 2 years ago or 2 1/2 years ago. And keep in mind, just for folks here in the States, when we look backwards at our response in 2008 and 2009, there was some criticism because we had to make a bunch of tough political decisions.In fact, there's still criticism about some of the decisions we made. But one of the things we were able to do was to act forcefully to solve a lot of these problems early, which is why credit markets that were locked up started loosening up again. That's why businesses started investing again. That's why we've seen job growth of over 4 million jobs over the last 2 years. That's why corporations are making money, and that's why we've seen strong economic growth for a long time.And so acting forcefully, rather than in small, bite-sized pieces and increments, I think, ends up being a better approach, even though obviously we're still going through challenges ourselves. I mean, some of these issues are ones that built up over decades.All right? Stephen Collinson [Agence France-Presse]. Where's Stephen?
label: General

sentence: Sir, just so we're clear, are you aiming to obliterate ISIS, keep them in check, or just force them back a bit? [SEP] What we're shooting for is to make sure ISIL isn't a constant threat to the region. We can get there, but it's going to take some time and a lot of work. Like with Al Qaeda, there's always going to be some stragglers who can cause problems, that's just how terrorism works. A few guys can still pull off an attack. But we can definitely weaken ISIL's widespread aggression – the stuff that's scaring Muslims, Kurds, Iraqis, everyone – so it's not the big problem it is now.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, you maintain your innocence regarding your interactions with the Ukrainian President. However, can you articulate why it's acceptable for an American President to solicit information from a foreign leader concerning a political opponent? What would have been your reaction had President Obama engaged in similar behavior against you? [SEP] Well, wasn't that precisely what he was doing? Consider the origins of this entire witch hunt, and hopefully, the truth will eventually surface. Numerous insightful books are being published that expose what they did to us. They've inflicted significant damage upon this nation. No other President should endure what I've experienced. The Ukrainian President is committed to combating corruption. There was corruption. Senators threatened him with withholding votes and financial aid. That's precisely what they're accusing me of doing, but I didn't. The call was flawless. There was no quid pro quo, unlike Biden and those Senators. We have an honest group of individuals being unfairly maligned. I'm quite pleased. A recent poll showed me at 53. Add 10 points to any poll result for Trump. I'm uncertain if that's a compliment, but it is in a way. That's what transpired in the election: an unprecedented number of people turned out to vote.
label: Deflection

sentence: So, you're not convinced it's getting warmer? [SEP] I'm waiting to hear Putin's perspective after their meeting. I'm interested to know if he still shares my concerns. When we were in Australia, he reaffirmed that it's not in anyone's interest for Iran to have nuclear weapons. They've been supportive at the UN, and we're working on a possible third resolution. My focus is on that. I'm not worried about the pictures. I understand why they meet. I'll keep working with Russia and other nations to send the message that Iran will be isolated if it pursues nuclear weapons.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, with all due respect, the question is about your conduct, not the Bidens. Did you or did you not request the Ukrainian government to investigate a political opponent? [SEP] Let me be perfectly clear. My administration is committed to fighting corruption wherever it exists. We're talking about billions of dollars potentially being siphoned off, and nobody seems to care. The media wants to focus on process, on manufactured outrage, while ignoring the substance. I'm not going to stand by and let corruption fester. I have a duty to the American people to get to the bottom of this.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, given the constitutional questions surrounding some of your decisions, do you believe the War Powers Act is constitutional? What about the debt limit? And is marriage a civil right? [SEP] Whoa, that's quite the legal salad you've tossed there. Chuck, I think you should be on the Supreme Court. I'm not a Supreme Court Justice, so I'm not going to put on my constitutional law professor hat here. Let me focus on the issue of Libya. There's been all kinds of noise about process and congressional consultation and so forth. Let's talk about concretely what's happened. Muammar Qadhafi, who, prior to Usama bin Laden, was responsible for more American deaths than just about anybody on the planet, was threatening to massacre his people. And as part of an international coalition, under a U.N. mandate that is almost unprecedented, we went in and took out air defense systems so that an international coalition could provide a no-fly zone, could protect--provide humanitarian protection to the people on the ground. I spoke to the American people about what we would do. I said there would be no troops on the ground. I said that we would not be carrying the lion's share of this operation, but as members of NATO, we would be supportive of it because it's in our national security interests and also because it's the right thing to do. We have done exactly what I said we would do. We have not put any boots on the ground. And our allies--who, historically, we've complained aren't willing to carry enough of the load when it comes to NATO operations--have carried a big load when it comes to these NATO operations. And as a consequence, we've protected thousands of people in Benghazi; we have not seen a single U.S. casualty; there's no risks of additional escalation. This operation is limited in time and in scope. So I said to the American people, here's our narrow mission. We have carried out that narrow mission in exemplary fashion.
