And throughout this process we consulted with Congress. We've had 10 hearings on it. We've sent reams of information about what the operations are. I've had all the Members of Congress over to talk about it. So a lot of this fuss is politics. And if you look substantively at what we've done, we have done exactly what we said to do, under a U.N. mandate, and we have protected thousands of lives in the process. And as a consequence, a guy who was a state sponsor of terrorist operations against the United States of America is pinned down, and the noose is tightening around him. Now, when you look at the history of the War Powers Resolution, it came up after the Vietnam war in which we had half a million soldiers there, tens of thousands of lives lost, hundreds of billions of dollars spent, and Congress said, you know what, we don't want something like that happening again. So if you're going to start getting us into those kinds of commitments, you've got to consult with Congress beforehand. And I think that such consultation is entirely appropriate. But do I think that our actions in any way violate the War Powers Resolution? The answer is no. So I don't even have to get to the constitutional question.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, given the current tensions, what specific assurances can you offer to our NATO allies in Eastern Europe regarding their security? [SEP] Our commitment to Article 5 is ironclad. We stand shoulder-to-shoulder with our NATO allies. They can rest assured that we will defend every inch of NATO territory. We're constantly reviewing our force posture in the region to ensure we have the necessary capabilities to deter aggression. We're also providing security assistance to Ukraine to help them defend themselves. Our message is clear: we will not tolerate any violation of sovereignty or territorial integrity.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Mr. President, hi. I want to revisit the issue of sacrifice. In 2009, you said that--expect the worst to come; we have not seen the worst yet. And now with these budget cuts looming, you have minorities, the poor, the elderly, as well as people who are scared of losing jobs, fearful. And also, what say you about Congressman Chaka Fattah's bill, the Debt Free America Act? Do you support that bill? Are you supporting the Republican bill that is similar to his, modeled after Congressman Fattah's bill? [SEP] Well, I'm not going to comment on a particular bill right now. Let me speak to the broader point that you're asking about, April.This recession has been hard on everybody, but obviously, it's harder on folks who've got less. And the thing that I am obsessed with, and have been since I came into office, is all those families out there who are doing the right thing every single day, who are looking after their families, who are just struggling to keep up and just feel like they're falling behind, no matter how hard they work.I got a letter this past week from a woman who--her husband had lost his job, had pounded the pavement, finally found a job. They felt like things were stabilizing for a few months. Six months later he lost his second job. Now they're back looking again and trying to figure out how they are going to make ends meet. And there are just hundreds of thousands of folks out there who really have seen as tough of an economy as we've seen in our lifetimes.Now, we took very aggressive steps when I first came into office to yank the economy out of a potential great depression and stabilize it. And we were largely successful in stabilizing it. But we stabilized it at a level where unemployment is still too high, and the economy is not growing fast enough to make up for all the jobs that were lost before I took office and the few months after I took office.So this unemployment rate has been really stubborn. There are a couple of ways that we can solve that. Number one is to make sure that the overall economy is growing. And so we have continued to take a series of steps to make sure that there's money in people's pockets that they can go out there and spend. That's what these payroll tax cuts were about.We've taken a number of steps to make sure that businesses are willing to invest, and that's what the small-business tax cuts and some of the tax breaks for companies that are willing to invest in plants and equipment--and zero capital gains for small businesses--that's what that was all about, was giving businesses more incentive to invest.We have worked to make sure that the training programs that are out there for folks who are having to shift from jobs that may not exist anymore so that they can get the training they need for the jobs that do exist, that those are improved and sharpened.We have put forward a series of proposals to make sure that regulations that may be unnecessary and are hampering some businesses from investing, that we are examining all of those for their costs and their benefits. And if they are not providing the kind of benefits in terms of the public health and clean air and clean water and worker safety that have been promised, then we should get rid of some of those regulations.So we've been looking at the whole menu of steps that can be taken. We are now in a situation where because the economy has moved slower than we wanted, because of the deficits and debt that result from the recession and the crisis, that taking a approach that costs trillions of dollars is not an option. We don't have that kind of money right now.What we can do is to solve this underlying debt and deficit problem for a long period of time so that then we can get back to having a conversation about, all right, since we now have solved this problem, that's not--no longer what's hampering economic growth, that's not feeding business and uncertainty, everybody feels that the ground is stable under our feet, are there some strategies that we could pursue that would really focus on some targeted job growth, infrastructure being a primary example.I mean, the infrastructure bank that we've proposed is relatively small. But could we imagine a project where we're rebuilding roads and bridges and ports and schools and broadband lines and smart grids, and taking all those construction workers and putting them to work right now? I can imagine a very aggressive program like that that I think the American people would rally around and would be good for the economy not just next year or the year after, but for the next 20 or 30 years.But we can't even have that conversation if people feel as if we don't have our fiscal house in order. Right? So the idea here is, let's act now. Let's get this problem off the table. And then with some firm footing, with a solid fiscal situation, we will then be in a position to make the kind of investments that, I think, are going to be necessary to win the future.So this is not a right or left, conservative/liberal situation. This is how do we operate in a smart way, understanding that we've got some short-term challenges and some long-term challenges. If we can solve some of those long-term challenges, that frees up some of our energies to be able to deal with some of these short-term ones as well.All right? Thank you very much, everybody.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, regarding immigration reform, is the 14th Amendment still a viable option, or have you ruled it out? Furthermore, how do you address concerns that your policies and the G-7's actions will exacerbate global instability? And finally, is a congressional agreement the only path forward, or are you still exploring unilateral or executive options? [SEP] The reality is, we haven't identified any unilateral actions that could be implemented successfully within the next few weeks. That's the core issue.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, isn't it a bit of a stretch to say the Republicans are guaranteed a win? And what's your take on some Republicans seemingly avoiding your endorsement? [SEP] Well, let me tell you, I'm not one to hold grudges, even if some Democrats are suddenly using my face on their ads. As for the election, the pundits are already calling it, but they're jumping the gun. There's plenty of time left, and these candidates are working their tails off. My advice? Stick to the basics: security, taxes, and we'll be back in business. Now, who's next?
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, some believe that your willingness to overlook human rights concerns in Vietnam is driven by economic considerations. How do you respond to those who accuse you of putting profits over principles? [SEP] That's simply not true. We're committed to both promoting human rights and expanding economic opportunities. We believe that those two things can go hand in hand.
label: General

sentence: Q. And to Mr. President—to President Buhari: The United States import of crude oil from Nigeria has considerably gone down. Did you discuss the need for the U.S. to increase the import of crude oil from Nigeria? [SEP] No, I can't tell the United States what to do. But luckily for us, we have good market for our crude oil elsewhere. But the progress made by United States in technology is largely—is actually frightening for such a monoeconomy. I hope technology will allow them to use our crude for its quality for petrochemicals—[inaudible]—vis-a-vis the ones they are getting from shale.Thank you. . I think maybe more than anything else, what we discussed today was agricultural products going into Nigeria, which Nigeria wants. But we have certain barriers that don't allow that to happen. So for the good of our farmers—U.S. farmers—and for the good of Nigeria and all of , it's very important that we are able to sell our great agricultural products into Nigeria. And that will happen, and we're going to be working on that right away. Okay?Thank you all very much. Thank you, everybody. Thank you.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Mr. President, is it your understanding that the individual was armed? [SEP] That's what I've been told, but I don't have firsthand knowledge. You should ask the authorities involved for a definitive answer.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: President Bush, why have you remained silent on the treatment of Saddam Hussein after his execution, and can you provide a specific date for the release of your Iraq strategy? [SEP] I'm not going to give you a date for the announcement. As for the other question, I want you to focus on the upcoming speech. I want you to think about what I'm going to say.
label: Implicit

sentence: Do you anticipate any concessions from them on that particular point? [SEP] I'm optimistic that they will ultimately choose the responsible path forward. We're all hoping for a positive resolution.
label: General

sentence: Q. It's obviously emerging as a sticking point on the Hill. And are you concerned that arms to Iran will go to Hizballah or Hamas? And is there anything that you or a future President can do to stop that?And if you don't mind, I mean, I wanted to see if you could step back a little bit, and when you look at this Iran deal and all the other issues and unrest that's happening in the Middle East, what kind of Middle East do you want to leave when you leave the White House in a year and a half? [SEP] Good. So the issue of the arms embargo and ballistic missiles is of real concern to us, has been of real concern to us. And it is in the national security interest of the United States to prevent Iran from sending weapons to Hizballah, for example, or sending weapons to the Houthis in Yemen that accelerate a civil war there.We have a number of mechanisms under international law that gives us authority to interdict arms shipments by Iran. One of those mechanisms is the U.N. security resolution related to Iran's nuclear program. Essentially, Iran was sanctioned because of what had happened at Fordow, its unwillingness to comply with previous U.N. security resolutions about their nuclear program. And as part of the package of sanctions that was slapped on them, the issue of arms and ballistic missiles were included.Now, under the terms of the original U.N. resolution, the fact is that once an agreement was arrived at that gave the international community assurance Iran didn't have a nuclear weapon, you could argue, just looking at the text, that those arms and ballistic missile prohibitions should immediately go away.But what I said to our negotiators was, given that Iran has breached trust and the uncertainty of our allies in the region about Iran's activities, let's press for a longer extension of the arms embargo and the ballistic missile prohibitions. And we got that. We got 5 years in which, under this new agreement, arms coming in and out of Iran are prohibited. And we got 8 years with respect to ballistic missiles.But part of the reason why we were willing to extend it only for 5, let's say, as opposed to a longer period of time, is because we have other U.N. resolutions that prohibit arms sales by Iran to organizations like Hizballah. We have other U.N. resolutions and multilateral agreements that give us authority to interdict arms shipments from Iran throughout the region. And so we've had belts and suspenders and buttons, a whole bunch of different legal authorities. These legal authorities under the nuclear program may lapse after 5 or 8 years, but we'll still be in possession of other legal authorities that allow us to interdict those arms.And truthfully, these prohibitions are not self-enforcing. It's not like the U.N. has the capacity to police what Iran is doing. What it does is, is it gives us authority under international law to prevent arms shipments from happening in concert with our allies and our partners. And the real problem, if you look at how, for example, Hizballah got a lot of missiles that are a grave threat to Israel and many of our friends in the region, it's not because they were legal. It's not because somehow that was authorized under international law. It was because there was insufficient intelligence or capacity to stop those shipments.So the bottom line is, Carol, I share the concerns of Israel, Saudis, Gulf partners about Iran shipping arms and causing conflict and chaos in the region. And that's why I've said to them, let's double down and partner much more effectively to improve our intelligence capacity and our interdiction capacity so that fewer of those arms shipments are getting through the net.But the legal authorities we'll still possess. And obviously, we've got our own unilateral prohibitions and sanctions in place around nonnuclear issues, like support for Hizballah. And those remain in place.Now, in terms of the larger issues of the Middle East, obviously, that's a longer discussion. I think my key goal when I turn over the keys to the President—the next President is that we are on track to defeat ISIL, that they are much more contained, and we're moving in the right direction there; that we have jump-started a process to resolve the civil war in Syria, which is like an open sore in the region and is giving refuge to terrorist organizations who are taking advantage of that chaos; to make sure that in Iraq, not only have we pushed back ISIL, but we've also created an environment in which Sunni, Shia, and Kurd are starting to operate and function more effectively together; and to be in a conversation with all our partners in the region about how we have strengthened our security partnerships so that they feel they can address any potential threats that may come, including threats from Iran. And that includes providing additional security assurances and cooperation to Israel, building on the unprecedented cooperation that we have already put in place and support that we've already put in place. It includes the work that we've done with the GCC up at Camp David, making sure that we execute that.If we've done those things, then the problems in the Middle East will not be solved. And ultimately, it's not the job of the President of the United States to solve every problem in the Middle East. The people of the Middle East are going to have to solve some of these problems themselves. But I think we can provide that next President at least a foundation for continued progress in these various areas.The last thing I would say—and this is a longer term issue—is we have to address the youth in the region with jobs and opportunity and a better vision for the future so that they are not tempted by the nihilistic, violent dead end that organizations like ISIL offer. Again, we can't do that entirely by ourselves, but we can partner with well-intentioned organizations, states, NGOs, religious leaders in the region. We have to do a better job of that than we've been doing so far. Okay?All right. Michael Crowley [Politico].
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. I want to follow on that by asking, under what conditions would you meet with President Castro in Havana? Would you have certain preconditions that you would want to see met before doing that? And on the hack, I know that you said that you're not going to announce your response, but are you—can you say whether you're considering additional economic or financial sanctions on North Korea? Can you rule out the use of military force or some kind of cyber hit of your own? [SEP] I think I'm going to leave it where I left it, which is, we just confirmed that it was North Korea; we have been working up a range of options. They will be presented to me. I will make a decision on those based on what I believe is proportional and appropriate to the nature of this crime.With respect to Cuba, we're not at a stage here where me visiting Cuba or President Castro coming to the United States is in the cards. I don't know how this relationship will develop over the next several years. I'm a fairly young man, so I imagine that at some point in my life I will have the opportunity to visit Cuba and enjoy interacting with the Cuban people. But there's nothing specific where we're trying to target some sort of visit on my part. Okay.Colleen McCain Nelson [Wall Street Journal].
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. Can you tell us who those five Republican Senators are? [SEP] Sure. No. [] Are you kidding me? I maintain confidentiality.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Are we prepared for the possibility of a years-long war of attrition? [SEP] I don't foresee this war dragging on indefinitely. Russia's capacity to sustain a long-term conflict is limited by its resource constraints. Moreover, I anticipate that President Putin will eventually realize that continuing this war is not in Russia's best economic or political interests. I'm hopeful that Ukraine's offensive will gain traction and pave the way for a negotiated resolution.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. Prime Minister, regarding Syria, if the U.S. reduces its involvement, what's the worst-case scenario, and how will Turkey respond to the Reyhanli bombing? [SEP] Look, Eric Holder is doing a fine job, okay? Now, about Syria, whining about what *might* happen isn't helpful. We're focused on the positive: getting the world to care about what's happening there. Turkey's doing its part, and we think the U.S. is too. We're pushing for a quick change to democracy so people stop dying. It's up to all of us who believe in democracy to make that happen.
label: Deflection

sentence: Concerning the question of Kamala Harris's eligibility for the presidency, will you now acknowledge that her birth in Oakland, California, satisfies the requirements? [SEP] I have no involvement in that. I did see something about it. Apparently, a very intelligent lawyer has written about it. I don't know anything about it, but it's not something that's bothering me.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, Tony Blair expressed regret over Iraq, saying he did what he thought was right but apologized if wrong. Do you have similar reflections? Should more focus have been on Afghanistan? Prime Minister, is the Lisbon Treaty dead, and what's next for Europe? [SEP] History will judge the tactics, troop levels, and positioning. Removing Saddam was right for our security, peace, and Iraqis. The key is helping Iraq build a democracy, not a U.S. clone, but a government responsive to its people. Was it worth it? Absolutely, in this ideological war, with Afghanistan and Iraq as key theaters. A free Iraq helps with Iran and inspires Middle East reformers. The West must choose freedom over stability. Zimbabwe shows forms of government matter. Freedom transformed Europe and the Far East. Will we let it transform the Middle East? Some doubt freedom's universality, suggesting only Westerners can self-govern. I reject that elitism. History shows freedom brings peace, unless we isolate, lose confidence, or quit. I'm confident removing Saddam was right. Freedom is universal, and Iraq is democratic because of our actions. We must ensure Iraqis have an economic stake. On Europe, I'll meet Ireland's leader. All 27 members must sign and ratify the treaty. Each decides its process. We'll debate in the Lords and give royal assent this week. Ireland needs time to reflect and propose solutions at the European Council. The EU believes Ireland deserves this time, as David Miliband will say.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, President-elect Trump has suggested potentially lifting sanctions on Russia if they significantly reduce their nuclear arsenal. Given your own efforts in arms control, do you believe this is a viable strategy? Based on your experience in office and your understanding of Mr. Trump, what advice would you offer his advisors to help him navigate his relationship with Vladimir Putin effectively? And considering your recent actions regarding Russia, do you think these sanctions should be considered leverage in future negotiations? [SEP] Well, there are a few things to consider here. First and foremost, a constructive relationship with Russia is in the best interests of both America and the world. That's been my approach throughout my presidency. We've worked together where our interests have aligned. Early on, I tried to encourage Russia to be a constructive member of the international community, helping them diversify and improve their economy, and use the talents of the Russian people in more productive ways. However, it's fair to say that after President Putin returned to the presidency, an escalating anti-American rhetoric and a global approach seemingly based on the idea that anything America does must be bad for Russia, leading them to counteract our efforts, has revived a Cold War-era adversarial spirit, making the relationship more difficult. This was further solidified when Russia intervened in Crimea and parts of Ukraine. The sanctions, as you recall, were not imposed due to nuclear weapons issues. They were a response to the violation of Ukraine's independence and sovereignty through force by Russia. This wasn't just our assessment; it was the consensus of the entire international community. Russia continues to occupy Ukrainian territory, meddle in Ukrainian affairs, and support military proxies who have violated fundamental international law and norms. I've communicated to the Russians that the sanctions will be lifted as soon as they cease these actions. To maintain international norms, it's crucial that we don't conflate the reasons for these sanctions with other unrelated issues. Regarding nuclear matters, we negotiated the START II Treaty during my first term, significantly reducing nuclear stockpiles for both Russia and the United States. I was prepared to go further and conveyed this to President Putin, but they were unwilling to negotiate. If President-elect Trump can restart those talks in a meaningful way, there's still considerable potential for further stockpile reductions. Our success in nonproliferation and nuclear security has been partly due to leading by example. I hope that continues. However, it's essential to remember that the sanctions against Russia are a direct result of their actions in Ukraine. The United States must uphold the fundamental principle that larger countries cannot invade and bully smaller ones. I've stated before that I expect Russia and Ukraine to maintain a strong relationship, given their historical, cultural, and social ties. However, Ukraine is an independent nation. This situation exemplifies the vital role America must continue to play in preserving basic norms and values globally, whether advocating for human rights, women's rights, or freedom of the press. The United States hasn't always been perfect in this regard. At times, we must engage with allies and partners who may not fully meet our desired standards for international rules and norms. However, I can assure you that in every multilateral forum—the United Nations, the G-20, the G-7—the United States has consistently championed these values. It's crucial for us to continue doing so, because if the largest, strongest democracy in the world isn't willing to stand up for these values, then certainly China, Russia, and others will not.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the Senkaku Islands, to be absolutely clear, are you stating that the US would consider military intervention if China were to initiate a military incursion to seize those islands? Doesn't this establish another 'red line' that you'd be compelled to enforce, potentially jeopardizing US credibility, as was the case with Syria and Russia? On another critical security matter, you mentioned North Korea. Are you issuing a warning against further nuclear tests? And Prime Minister Abe, do you have faith in President Obama's security assurances, given the West's inability to prevent Russia's actions in Ukraine? [SEP] And the question was?
label: Clarification

sentence: Regarding potential tax adjustments, could you clarify whether these would primarily affect corporations or individuals? And, to reassure the markets, could you provide a rough estimate of the percentage adjustment you envision on either side? [SEP] I'm not going to give you specifics. I'm just saying I'd be open to a slight adjustment.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: President Bush, what's your take on how the Colombian government is handling the drug trafficking scandal involving politicians and paramilitaries? How much do you support President Uribe, considering the paramilitary leaders are often drug traffickers? Will the U.S. insist on extradition? [SEP] I support a system where an independent judiciary investigates all charges, and those found guilty are punished. That's the plan President Uribe supports. There are no political favorites when it comes to justice. A fair court, independent from politics, is the best way to ensure justice. President Uribe assured me that his government has an independent court and firm laws, and that people will be held accountable regardless of their political affiliations. Colombia has been through difficult times, and fair, independent justice is the best way to heal wounds.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, the debate over federally mandated busing is reignited. Given the historical context and the current political climate, what is your stance on the federal government's role in busing policies? [SEP] That's a complex issue with a lot of history. But I think the focus on that particular debate is a distraction. We're looking at comprehensive solutions to address inequality and opportunity. We'll be unveiling our plans in the coming weeks. It's going to be a bold vision, and I think people will be impressed. So, I'm not going to comment directly on busing at this time.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. With the election of these two Muslim women, one wearing a hijab, into Congress, a historic moment, does this signify a rejection of your message, in your opinion? [SEP] I'm not entirely following your line of reasoning. Could you rephrase that?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the trade imbalance with China, critics argue that your administration's policies haven't significantly altered the situation. How do you respond to concerns that the RMB's undervaluation continues to hinder American job growth? [SEP] Look, it's not just about the RMB. It's about the whole shebang, the whole economic relationship. I remember back in '09, at that G20, we were staring into the abyss. The financial crisis was a real mess. And we knew we couldn't keep going down that road, with the U.S. borrowing and consuming like crazy, not producing, not selling. That's why we pushed for a global rebalancing. Now, that means we gotta save more, cut the debt, both public and private. We gotta get our act together, be more competitive. Best education, more engineers, less lawyers, fix our fiscal problems, build world-class infrastructure. That's all part of it. But, yeah, we need a level playing field. With China, it's about making sure it's a win-win, not a win-lose. Some of it's not even about currency. We're getting somewhere on government procurement, making it fair for American businesses. We're making progress on intellectual property. Steve Ballmer was just telling me, only one in ten of their products are actually paid for in China. Can we get better enforcement? China's taken steps, but more needs to be done. The currency thing is part of it. The RMB is undervalued. They've spent billions to keep it that way. President Hu says he wants a market-based system, but it's not happening fast enough. I told him, it's good for both of us. U.S. businesses can sell more, and China can boost domestic demand. A stronger RMB means they can buy more, raise their standard of living. It's a win-win. He's worried about the transition, the disruptions. But I'm confident he'll do the right thing and move towards a fully market-based currency. It'll be good for everyone.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, the increase in anti-Semitism and hate crimes is deeply troubling. Anti-Semitic incidents have risen by 57 percent since 2016, and hate crimes are on the upswing. What, in your opinion, is driving this trend, and what steps will your administration take to address it? [SEP] It's a very sad situation. I detest seeing it. And, as you know, I've accomplished more for Israel than any other President. Prime Minister Netanyahu himself acknowledged this. Jerusalem, protection, collaboration – numerous things. But the most significant is Jerusalem. Many Presidents have spoken about building the Embassy in Jerusalem, but it never occurred. Designating it as the capital – never happened. But I made it happen, and promptly. And we constructed the Embassy. It would have taken many years and cost billions, but we did it for a minimal amount. It's already complete. Nobody has achieved more for Israel than Donald Trump. And that's not just my opinion; it's also the view of Prime Minister Netanyahu.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. Were you premature in saying that the U.S. economy is not in a recession when food and energy prices are soaring so high?And what more can you do to persuade Saudi Arabia during your upcoming visit to reconsider output levels and cut prices? [SEP] Yes. Look, I mean, you know, the words on how to define the economy don't reflect the anxiety the American people feel. The average person doesn't really care what we call it. The average person wants to know whether or not we know that they're paying higher gasoline prices and that they're worried about staying in their homes. And I do understand that. That's why we've been aggressively helping people refinance their homes. That's why I continue to call upon Congress to pass legislation that will enable people to stay in their homes.These are tough times. People—economists can argue over the terminology. But—and these are difficult times, and the American people know it. And they want to know whether or not Congress knows it. I think an important signal to send on energy, just like I said, is to say, okay, we're going to go find oil here at home.We can—we're transitioning to a new era, by the way, a new era where we're going to have batteries in our cars that will power—enable people to drive 40 miles on electricity. There's going to be more ethanol on the market, more alternative fuels. It would be—our driving habits will change. But in the meantime, we need to be sending a signal to the world markets that we intend to explore here in America. We can also send a clear signal that we understand supply and demand. And then when you don't build a refinery for 30 years, it's going to be a part of restricting supply, and therefore, we ought to expand our refining capacity by permitting new refineries and getting after it quickly.On the electricity front, as you know, I'm a big believer in nuclear power, except we keep getting mixed signals out of Congress, and the regulatory system sends mixed signals.And so—and then to your question on the Saudis, look, I have made the case that the high price of oil injures economies. But I think we better understand that there's not a lot of excess capacity in this world right now. Hopefully, high prices will spur more exploration to bring excess capacity on, but demand is rising faster than supply. And that's why you're seeing global energy prices rise. And that's why it's important for us to try to take the pressure off by saying, we're going to start exploring here at home.John [John Yang, NBC News].
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, the slower withdrawal from Afghanistan means greater peril for our soldiers. What's your justification to them? How do you reassure them of the mission's value and the certainty of its end? [SEP] The timeline for an embassy-centered presence by the end of 2016 remains. Our transition out of a combat role has not changed. Risks exist in Afghanistan, but casualties have decreased substantially since our shift away from combat. Afghan security services are fighting with courage and improving. While some rotations may be extended, we've reduced our presence from 100,000 to under 10,000 troops, who are not in combat roles. This additional time provides essential support during this fighting season, ensuring Afghan forces succeed. It's a worthwhile investment in our freedom and global stability. Furthermore, Congress should adequately fund our troops, including their transition back home.
label: Implicit

sentence: Sir, could you specify the key points of discussion during your meeting with [Person]? [SEP] We touched upon the main topics of the conference, such as stability and ensuring access to change for developing nations in the Southern Hemisphere. It was a friendly exchange. He came up to me and said [inaudible]. Thank you all. The President. Thank you. That concludes the press conference. Thank you, everyone. The President. Thank you. Thank you.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Mr. President, could you repeat that question? [SEP] I didn't hear you, could you repeat that?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Do you have it yourself, Mr. President? [SEP] I don't. We probably have some notes or something. But they have, actually, detailed notes, I would imagine. But we had a great conversation. It was a very heartfelt conversation.
label: Explicit

sentence: The midterm election results have been widely interpreted as a rebuke of your administration's policies. How do you intend to address the concerns of voters who feel left behind or disenfranchised? Will you consider a course correction on key issues, or do you believe your current policies remain the best path forward for the country? [SEP] We understand that many Americans are struggling, and we're committed to addressing their concerns. We're reviewing our policies and listening to feedback from across the country. We're open to new ideas and willing to make adjustments where necessary. Our goal is to create an economy that works for everyone, and we'll continue to pursue policies that promote opportunity and prosperity for all.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. But did you press King Abdallah about it personally? [SEP] I talked to King Abdallah about the Middle Eastern peace. I don't remember if that subject came up.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: With respect to Asian nations, when can we anticipate an announcement about the relaxation of restrictions, and what benchmarks are being used to measure their success? [SEP] As you know, some are advancing, while others are not. However, some are making headway. Once they achieve the desired level, we'll commence reopening. Certain countries are progressing swiftly. We're hoping to lift restrictions at the earliest opportunity. Please proceed.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, questions have arisen regarding the constitutionality of certain decisions you've made. I'd like to ask: Do you believe the War Powers Act is constitutional? What is your opinion on the constitutionality of the debt limit? And do you consider marriage to be a civil right? [SEP] Chuck, that's quite a collection of questions! Perhaps you should be nominated to the Supreme Court! However, I am not a Supreme Court Justice, so I will refrain from donning my constitutional law professor persona. Let us concentrate on the essence of the matter at hand. There has been excessive emphasis on procedural aspects and insufficient attention to the substantive issues. Muammar Qadhafi, who bore responsibility for more American fatalities than nearly anyone preceding Usama bin Laden, was poised to perpetrate a massacre upon his own populace. As part of an international coalition, operating under a United Nations mandate of unprecedented scope, we neutralized his air defense systems, enabling the coalition to enforce a no-fly zone and safeguard the civilians on the ground. I assured the American people that we would not deploy ground troops and that we would not bear the predominant burden of the operation. We have adhered precisely to our commitments. Our allies have assumed a significant portion of the responsibility, and we have successfully protected thousands of individuals in Libya. There have been no American casualties, and there is no risk of further escalation. The operation is circumscribed in both duration and extent. We have maintained ongoing consultations with Congress throughout this process. Therefore, much of the current uproar is politically motivated. Our actions align precisely with our stated objectives, conducted under a United Nations mandate, and have resulted in the preservation of countless lives. Qadhafi is now under siege. The War Powers Resolution emerged in the aftermath of the Vietnam War, during which we had deployed half a million soldiers and suffered tens of thousands of casualties. Congress sought to prevent a recurrence of such events. I believe that consultation is entirely appropriate; however, our actions do not, in any way, contravene the War Powers Resolution. Consequently, I need not address the constitutional question.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, you've spoken eloquently about nonviolence. How does that square with potentially attacking Syria, especially as a Nobel laureate? And how did your talk with the Swedish PM move us forward on climate change? [SEP] My Nobel speech touched on this. It's about balancing peace with a world full of violence. We try to end wars and use diplomacy, but what do we do when faced with true evil? When kids are gassed, we have to act. It's tough, but it's my job. Now, remind me about that second question on climate change.
label: Clarification

sentence: With all due respect Mr. President, if I may, I'd like to shift gears for a moment. You previously stated your commitment to bridging racial divides within the government. How does criminal justice reform align with this goal, and what specific gaps remain for you to address? Furthermore, what significance does your upcoming trip to Kenya hold, and will you consider revoking Bill Cosby's Medal of Freedom? [SEP] April, you've presented a multifaceted query, haven't you? Let's just say...
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, Sputnik News is asking if you discussed possible inspections to North Korea's nuclear sites during your negotiations. Can you confirm? [SEP] Come again? And where are you reporting from?
label: Clarification

sentence: President Obama, given the economic realities and the rising concerns about China's assertiveness, isn't this troop deployment primarily a strategic move to contain China's power in the region, and can you honestly say that the sacrifices in Afghanistan are truly worth the continued loss of life? [SEP] This deployment is about strengthening our alliances and ensuring security in a vital region. The Asia-Pacific is driving global economic growth. We need to modernize our security arrangements. This allows us to respond to various challenges, including humanitarian crises. We welcome China's rise, but they must embrace their responsibilities. They need to play by the rules. In Afghanistan, any loss of life is a tragedy. We're there to protect our security. We're transitioning to Afghan control. We need to finish the job responsibly. And I appreciate Prime Minister Gillard's commitment and her compassion for our troops.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Mr. President, concerning the NHS, should it be included in the discussions? [SEP] I'm afraid I didn't hear you clearly. What did you say?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Alan Greenspan has come out with a book, a recent book, criticizing you for being fiscally irresponsible. And they're not the first former Government officials to come out and be critical of you. And I'm wondering two things. First, do you feel betrayed by some of these people who have served you and then have come out and criticized you? And then, more particularly, can you respond to Greenspan's criticism? [SEP] My feelings are not hurt. You might have been a little selective in quoting Donald Rumsfeld, which I know you didn't mean to be, you know. I respect Secretary Rumsfeld; I believe he did a fine job. And I respect Alan Greenspan. I respectfully disagree with Alan Greenspan when it comes to saying that this administration didn't handle the fiscal issues we faced in good fashion. As a matter of fact, we did.The deficit, as a percent of GDP, is low. It's lower than the 30-year average. We have submitted a plan to balance the budget. We dealt with a recession, a terrorist attack, and corporate scandals. And we did it by cutting taxes. The tax cuts worked. The economy recovered. People are working. Interest rates are low.I'm a supply-sider. I believe supply-side economics, when properly instituted, enables us to achieve certain objectives. One, there's people finding work, and there's hope in the economy. Two, that supply-side economics yields additional tax revenues. And if we're smart about how we manage the fiscal budget, it leads to balance, and that's what we have done. We are fighting a war at the same time that we're headed toward balance. In other words, we're making sure our troops get the money they need and veterans get the benefits they need.The former Chairman Greenspan and I spent a lot of time talking about the unfunded liabilities inherent in Social Security and Medicare. And he's concerned about those unfunded liabilities, as am I. And that's why I went in front of the Congress, in more than one occasion, talking about how to reform Social Security so that young people who are working aren't paying payroll taxes into a system that's going broke.I'm not going to give up on entitlement reform, but it can require part—members of both parties to recognize we have a problem that ought to be solved now. It's time to—I thought it was time to come together a couple of years ago, and that wasn't the political will in Congress. And I'm not so sure we're going to find it now, but I'm going to keep trying because, like the Chairman, I understand that the biggest issue we've got with the deficit are those deficits inherent in these entitlement programs.John [John McKinnon, Wall Street Journal].
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Do you disagree with P.J. Crowley? [SEP] I think I gave you an answer to the substantive issue.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, you've raised concerns about the potential use of chemical weapons. Do you have specific intelligence suggesting that President Putin is actively deploying or considering the use of these weapons? And if he were to use them, would the U.S. or NATO respond with military force? [SEP] I cannot share specific intelligence information. However, let me be clear: we would respond if he uses chemical weapons. The nature of our response would depend on the specific circumstances of their use.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Mr. President, the Iraqis hold their regional conference tomorrow. What are your expectations for it? And are you now willing to talk directly with Iran and Syria at this meeting? [SEP] The expectations are that nations in the neighborhood, plus nations of the world, recognize that democracy can lead to peace, and that when 12 million people vote to live in a free society, it's in all our interests to help them realize the blessings of a free society. That's the expectations—in other words, a commitment to helping this young democracy survive and thrive.Our message to the Syrians and Iranians won't change at that meeting, that I've stated publicly, which is, we expect you to help this young democracy. And we will defend ourselves and the people in from the—from weapons being shipped in to cause harm; that we will protect ourselves and help the i people protect themselves against those who would murder the innocent to achieve political objectives.And it's a positive meeting, Steve [Steve Holland, Reuters], particularly for Prime Minister Maliki and his Government, in that countries will now be coming to a rather formal meeting to express support. And it's positive because I think it's going to be important for the i people who have been suffering a lot to hear from other countries in the world that say: We embrace your courage; we embrace your willingness to take risk for freedom. And we'll see how it goes, but I'm happy to have supported the Prime Minister's request that this meeting take place.Mr. President, thanks. Your press conferences are nice. I appreciate the Brazilian press for coming. Glad the American press behaved okay. [] Be careful, they may spend a lot of time at the bars around here. [] Yes.Okay, thanks.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Concerning Meng Wanzhou, will her case also be deferred until the end, or could the US withdraw the extradition request? [SEP] Sorry, when are you talking about? On what basis?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, oil prices have surged past $118 a barrel, a new record. Are Saudi Arabia and other oil producers adversaries, and have your appeals to them been successful? Furthermore, won't the high gasoline prices negate the benefits of the economic stimulus package? [SEP] Absolutely, rising gasoline prices are a burden on working families. We've neglected domestic hydrocarbon production for too long, and now we're paying the price. We should have been exploring for oil and gas in ANWR, for example. Congress blocked us from opening new areas for environmentally responsible exploration, making us more dependent on foreign oil. Fortunately, Canada and Mexico are major suppliers, and we're grateful for that. But our energy policy hasn't been effective, and we're seeing the consequences. There's also limited excess capacity globally. Unfortunately, many supplies come from politically unstable regions. Again, Canada and Mexico are exceptions. Some countries aren't reinvesting in their reserves, leading to declines. I'm concerned for our consumers. That's why we passed the tax relief. Congress should make it permanent. Some want to tax the rich, but that won't cover their spending. Those schemes always end up taxing the middle class. In times of economic uncertainty, we need tax certainty. With rising gasoline prices, we need to assure Americans we won't raise their taxes.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the Hong Kong business advisory and the Build Back Better plan, could you elaborate on the necessity of the advisory given China's commitments, and also, what assurances can you provide that Senators Manchin and Sinema are aligned with the $3.5 trillion framework, ensuring progressive support? [SEP] Well, let's just say that the situation in Hong Kong speaks for itself. China made promises, and those promises are, shall we say, not being kept. The advisory is a heads-up, plain and simple. As for the Build Back Better plan, I'm confident we'll get there. There will be discussions, of course, but we have mechanisms in place to ensure we can get this done. We're talking about significant tax cuts for families and a reduction in child poverty. It's a game-changer, and we will deliver.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: In light of your earlier commitment to immediate implementation, would you consider a temporary postponement? [SEP] I appreciate the question, but I cannot answer simply because it was shouted. Thank you all for your time.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, can you clarify your current position on DACA and what specific concessions you are seeking from Congress in exchange for a legislative solution? [SEP] DACA is a very complicated issue, a very, very complicated issue. We were very close to a deal, very close. But the Democrats, they walked away. They didn't want to make a deal. Now, we're dealing with the courts, and we'll see what happens. We want to do what's right, what's fair, but it has to be good for the country.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, beyond the summit, what other consequences will Russia face? [SEP] The summit decision wasn't just about Mr. Snowden. It was also about the lack of progress on a range of issues. So, it's not strictly punitive. We're going to assess where the relationship can advance U.S. interests and increase peace and stability and prosperity around the world. Where it can, we're going to keep on working with them. Where we have differences, we're going to say so clearly. And my hope is, is that over time, Mr. Putin will recognize that rather than a zero-sum competition, in fact, if the two countries are working together, we can probably advance the betterment of both peoples.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, some argue that allowing trained citizens to carry firearms could deter mass shootings. What are your thoughts? [SEP] I believe in empowering law enforcement. They're the professionals, and we need to give them the resources and respect they deserve. These officers face impossible situations, making life-or-death decisions in fractions of a second. When they make a mistake, it's national news. We need to stand behind them and reject this radical left-wing agenda that's undermining our country. Look at Republican-led states; they're safe and secure.
label: Implicit

sentence: Regarding the trade deal with China, if they bring up TikTok and WeChat during these routine check-ins, will you instruct your team to engage on that? [SEP] The China deal is proceeding nicely, very nicely. We have a date, a firm deadline. As for TikTok and WeChat, those are separate matters, very important matters of national security. We're looking at all options, believe me. The Treasury will be involved, and we'll ensure America gets a fair deal, a very fair deal. But the trade deal? That's a whole different ballgame, and it's going great, just great. They're buying everything, you know, corn, soybeans, beef, the biggest orders ever. So, it's a complicated situation, but we're on top of it, totally on top of it.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, with regard to Chancellor Merkel, does this award represent a culmination of her past achievements, or does it also signify future expectations? Where do you envision Germany playing a larger role globally? And Madam Chancellor, does Germany's economic prowess necessitate a greater assumption of global responsibilities? [SEP] The Medal of Freedom is a recognition of Chancellor Merkel's remarkable career. She has been an excellent steward of the German economy and the European project. She represents the unification of Europe through her own life story and the capacity to overcome the past and point towards a brighter future. The extraordinary work that she's already done would by itself merit the Medal of Freedom. Fortunately, she's going to be around quite a bit longer. Her leadership will be critical on economic issues of the sort that we just discussed in the euro zone. I compliment her on the courage with which she approaches some of these very difficult political issues, at some significant political costs to herself. On the international stage, there's no issues that we don't coordinate closely with Germany. Our work in Afghanistan, our work together with NATO, the approach that we've taken with respect to the Middle East and the Arab Spring, our approaches to development issues and how we help the poorest countries find their place in the international economy, these are all going to be areas where Angela's leadership will be welcomed and will be absolutely critical for us to be able to achieve the kind of more peaceful and prosperous world that we want to see. She's not finished yet; she's got a lot more work to do. Well, I believe when you see me standing here before you today and receiving this prestigious award of the Medal of Freedom, it will perhaps also be a moment where one needs to look back to 1989 and German unification and what actually happened there. Germany entered into a qualitatively new phase. We were all of a sudden a reunited country, a country with all rights, but also with all the obligations. If I think back to the beginning of the nineties, we were struggling for a decision that would enable us to send ships on the Adria, taking part in reconnaissance missions. And if you compare this to where we are today, you see the road that we have traveled in the direction of assuming more international responsibility. Military missions, participating in military missions are part and parcel of that: on the Balkans, in UNIFIL, in Afghanistan, in combating piracy, and in many other areas. What's also important in this context is that we need to combine military and civil engagement. We share this approach, Barack and I. We live up to our international responsibilities. The world is full of problems that we need to address. You cannot have enough partners that work together with you in a coordinated way, and this is why this cooperation is so extremely important for our common future. I'm saying this also as someone who comes from Europe. The changes in North Africa are changes that happen on our doorstep. Those are our immediate neighbors, and we have a choice. Either this works out well or we have an enormous refugee problem. It's not only out of charity that we help people. There's not only a moral obligation. But we have also a vested interest in seeing to it that this continent, this region, comes on its feet.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. And, President Duda, if I could just throw one your way as well: You said in the Oval Office earlier that democracy in Poland was strong. Not all of your European Union counterparts agree with that. How is forcing Supreme Court justices to retire early consistent with democratic principles? And, President Trump, is that something that you support? [SEP] No. Ladies and gentlemen, this is a very complex issue. And it's hard to answer this question because a lot of people in Western Europe—I think also in the U.S.—do not fully understand this problem because they have not grown up in a country such as mine.I was born in 1972, in a Poland which was in the Russian sphere of influence, in which a career could be made only, actually, when somebody enrolled as member of the Communist Party and who followed these people's power who was the supreme authority. And this is what was happening for many years.Although, as you know, ladies and gentlemen, as Solidarity movement grew, people were imprisoned, people were tortured, people were killed during the martial law, and after as well—be it openly or in a secret way. And this was the reality of Poland until 1989.And now imagine, ladies and gentlemen, that no so long ago—a few years ago—I was surprised to discover that, in the Polish Supreme Court, there was a whole group of justices who were issuing sentencing as judges—members of the Communist Party—before 1990, who were even passing sentences during the martial law, sentencing people to prisons based on the law of the Communist martial law.And when I was asked whether the Supreme Court needs to be reformed, I said yes. If Poland is supposed to be a truly democratic, free, and sovereign country, if it is supposed to be a country we want it to be for our children, for the generation who was born after, in 1989, then for God's sake, those people have to leave. They have to retire. And this is what we did.As a matter of fact, everything that we were doing was aimed at retiring those people. But, as you can see, unfortunately, although 30 years have passed, they have got influence, the influence which they were building after 1989 where they assumed a new identity of an elite of a new state. So this influence is still strong. This is what I can say.And let me assure you of one thing: that freedom of speech is absolutely respected in Poland. Poland absolutely respects all constitutional standards, just as in the United States: the right to assemble; the right to the freedom of speech. There is free media in Poland. There is everything that is functioning in a normal democracy.One can announce what they think, one can demonstrate, one can say what they think. In Poland, people are not attacked during demonstrations as it happens in other Western European countries. Police do not use truncheons or tear gas against people. People can speak their mind. They can express that they're not pleased with something. This is their right in democracy.Please ask Polish journalists, When was the last time—when was the last demonstration in Poland when some kind of tension happened? No, it didn't, because in Poland we respect the right to demonstrate and to express your concern, because we believe that this is one of the foundations of democracy. In Poland, there is absolutely free and just elections. All the standards are respected.So, please, ladies and gentleman, come to Poland and see Poland with your own eyes. Please do not repeat certain stereotypes that are repeated in the West. Poland, today, has got quite a conservative government, that is true. And this government has got certain standards of action. Not everybody subscribes to those standards, especially people of more leftist views. But this is the nature of democracy.So once you have got one side of the political scene in power, and then people make a different choice and another side of the political stage comes to power. There is nothing extraordinary about that. And this is the change that is happening in Poland.But when somebody wins the elections, they then have the right to implement the program which they announced before the elections. Excuse me, however, realizing that implementing the program, which you presented in your election campaign, is not only the right, but I think an obligation resting on a politician. And this is exactly what is happening in Poland.Visa Waiver Program
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, concerning Ukraine and the reported 30,000 Russian troops at the border, what guarantees can you provide to Eastern Ukraine, the Baltic nations, Moldova, and others regarding possible Russian annexation? Also, is Crimea now a 'fait accompli,' or do you think Putin might return it, or is this merely a show of strength to deter further territorial seizures? [SEP] Regarding Crimea, it's not a 'fait accompli' because the global community largely does not recognize the annexation. Russian forces control Crimea, and some locals support it. Removal by force is unlikely. We are exerting legal, diplomatic, political, and economic pressure. A straightforward resolution is improbable. History is unpredictable. The situation's development hinges on international solidarity in condemning Russia's actions. As for Russian troops near Ukraine, they are within Russia. We oppose intimidation, but Russia has the right to station troops on its territory. Russia is still deliberating. These calculations depend on US, European, and international unity in rejecting 21st-century dispute resolution methods. It is crucial to reject claims that Russian speakers in Ukraine are threatened to justify Russian action. There is no evidence of threats. Provocateurs have instigated unrest. Comparisons to Kosovo, where thousands were massacred, are absurd. We must debunk justifications for Russian action. For non-NATO border states, like Ukraine, we are applying international pressure, highlighting the situation, and strengthening their economies. NATO members have Article 5 protection. We are enhancing contingency plans. A NATO ministerial will further develop these plans. NATO members are resolute. For non-NATO nations, we are providing support through diplomatic and economic initiatives.
label: General

sentence: Considering the observations of international bodies, shouldn't there be consequences for the actions that have occurred up to this point? [SEP] The international community is closely monitoring the situation. The ian government should understand that its handling of internal dissent, which originates from the ian population, will significantly affect 's future and its relations with other countries. Since we are discussing , I understand that Nico Pitney from the Huffington Post is in attendance.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, you campaigned on a promise to end partisan gridlock, yet Congress remains deeply divided. Has your approach to leadership failed to bridge the divide, and are you now resorting to executive actions as a tacit admission of that failure? [SEP] I remain committed to working with both parties to find common ground. But when faced with obstruction and inaction, I have a responsibility to act in the best interests of the American people. I won't let partisan politics stand in the way of progress. I will use the authority I have to take action.
label: Dodging

sentence: Sir, two parts: The New Yorker says the Red Cross found CIA torture. Your reaction? And you promised to close Guantanamo a year ago, but nothing's happened. Who's in charge, and will it close before you leave? [SEP] Closing Guantanamo is the aim. It's hard because nobody wants these prisoners. The Senate agrees. We're trying to send them back and have trials. As for the Red Cross report, remind me exactly what you're asking?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Mr. President, what should Americans expect from Congress as it relates to abortion rights after the midterms? [SEP] I don't think they can expect much of anything other than, we're going to maintain our positions.I'm not going to get into more questions. I shouldn't even have answered your question.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the violence in Delhi, what did Prime Minister Modi tell you about the citizenship law, and how concerned are you about religious violence in India? [SEP] We did discuss religious freedom. The Prime Minister was incredible on what he told me. He wants people to have religious freedom, very strongly. He said India has worked very hard to have great and open religious freedom. I asked that question in front of a very large group of people today. He talked about it; we talked about it for a long time. I really believe that's what he wants. As far as the individual attack, I heard about it, but I didn't discuss that with him. That's up to India. As for Harvey Weinstein, I'm not a fan.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Do you trust that they are sincere about this? [SEP] I do. I think they want to make a deal very badly. I think that was elevated last night, very late in the night. I see an alert—or, as you would call it, breaking news. And it was that the Vice Chairman—we're not talking about somebody from China at a low level—the Vice Chairman of China came out that he wants to see a deal made, he wants it to be made under calm conditions, using the word calm. I agree with him on that.And China has taken a very hard hit over the last number of months. You know, they've lost 3 million jobs. It will soon be much more than 3 million jobs. Their chain is breaking. A chain is breaking up like nobody has seen before. And once that happens, it's very hard to put it back together. You understand.I think they want—very much want—to make a deal. And the longer they wait, the harder it is to put it back, if it can be put back at all. So I believe they want to do a deal.The tariffs have hit them very hard in a fairly short period of time. The United States will have collected over $100 billion in tariffs. And I say it again: The reporters failed to—the media failed to acknowledge it. But if you look at the goods coming in from China—we're talking about China, not other countries. If you look at the goods, they have a power that others don't have. But that power is only good for so long.They've manipulated their currency, they've devalued their currency, and they put a lot of cash into the system. And because of that, the prices have not gone up. Or if they've gone up, it's been very little, because they want to keep people working. If the prices go up, they're not going to be able to keep people working; they're not going to be able to compete. It's a brilliant market. It's a brilliant, brilliant market, the world market. A lot of markets are brilliant.And frankly, I think that China cannot—I don't know, maybe they can, maybe they can't. I don't think they can do that. And I think they're very smart. And I think President Xi is a great leader, who happens to be a brilliant man. And he can't lose 3 million jobs in a very short period of time. And that's going to be magnified many times over. And it's going to break down the Chinese system of trade, and he can't do that.So when you say, Do you think they want to? Maybe they want to, and maybe they don't. But I think they want to make a deal. I'm not sure they have a choice. And I don't say that as a threat. I don't think they have a choice. In the meantime, the United States, which has never collected 10 cents from China, will, in a fairly short period of time, be over $100 billion in tariffs. So I think they want to make a deal very badly. Okay?Go ahead. Second question.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Don't your officials vote by mail, sir? People in the White House vote by mail. Are they part of the scam? [SEP] They do, but that's different. That's called solicited. When you solicit, when you go out—it's called absentee or solicit. When you go out and you request a ballot—you want to say, I want to vote because I can't be in Florida or I can't be someplace. You request. So you're sending something in, it's handled professionally, they send it back—it's a whole thing. That's much different than unsolicited, when you get millions of ballots. I heard numbers like 80 million ballots.Now, just this week, they had another one—another one of the disasters that took place—an election. But look at what happened in New Jersey. And they had another one in New Jersey—very, very bad—different than Paterson. Look at what happened in New York with Carolyn—your Congressman—Murphy.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, with regards to the rise of what you've termed a 'crude nationalism,' would you advise protestors to stop demonstrating against the rhetoric of Donald Trump? Also, have you given your successor any advice on choosing staff? Finally, do you think you can stop the bombing of Aleppo? [SEP] Protesting is part of democracy. I've been protested against. I wouldn't tell them to stop. I'd tell them to vote, organize, and stay informed. Don't take our government for granted. Democracy takes work. If people don't vote, democracy suffers. If we can't tell facts from lies, we're in trouble. If people won't compromise, democracy falls apart. Know what makes democracy work and be a citizen. Some forget the Cold War. Sometimes, people equate the U.S. and Russia. We have flaws, but we try to do what's right. The U.S. has been good to Germany. We've helped them. We try to have free speech and fight corruption. Remember that. There's a lot of bad information out there. Don't compare small mistakes to big problems. If we do, we won't know what to protect. Sorry, that was long.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. If he does choose to cooperate, how would you ever trust him? And what is the—your version of trust but verify? [SEP] I'd verify first and then trust. In other words: Everything would have to be shown to be actually occurring. The—it's not about, you know, trusting; it's about agreeing.You know, when we—when you write treaties with your adversaries, you don't say, I trust you. You say, This is what I expect, and if you violate the agreement you made then, we—the, quote, 'The treaty is off. The agreement is off.'And I'm hoping that—that President Putin concludes that there is some interest, in terms of his own interests, in changing the perception that the world has of him, in terms of whether or not he will engage in behavior that's more consistent with what is considered to be appropriate behavior for a head of state.Anne Gearan, the Washington Post.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, Nigeria is in a tough spot and really needs those Tucano aircraft. Is there any chance we could get at least two of them delivered before 2020 to help them out? And, by the way, are you planning a trip to Nigeria anytime soon? [SEP] Nigeria, a beautiful country, I'm told. I'd love to go. But I didn't quite understand the first part of your question. Could you repeat it?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. And for President Niinistö, you've been working on fortifying the fence along the border between Finland and Russia. Is there anything that you're seeing recently that concerns you? And also, as a leader who shares a border with Russia, what more do you want to see done to deter Putin? [SEP] During the beginning of our application process, surely, we had to make sure, first, trying to figure out every possible negative action we might meet and, surely, how we response from that. And we were very careful on that work.So, at the moment, the situation is quite calm. Hope it remains as such.But I just want to tell you that Finnish people do feel more secure. At the moment, we have 80 percent of our population supporting NATO membership and more than 80 percent who say that we will also protect our allies. That's the Finnish position.
label: Dodging

sentence: Sir, the economic deceleration in China – does it pose a risk to global stability, perhaps incentivizing more assertive behavior from Beijing, especially regarding Taiwan? And on a different note, the meeting between Putin and Kim Jong Un – does that worry you in terms of Russia's war effort in Ukraine? [SEP] China's got some real economic challenges at the moment, stemming from international economic conditions and their own policy choices. I don't believe it will lead to an invasion of Taiwan; in fact, it might diminish their capacity to do so. We're not seeking to harm China; we all benefit from a prosperous China that adheres to international norms. However, they're facing difficulties, particularly in their real estate sector. They're currently deciding on the necessary actions. I won't predict the outcome, but we're not aiming to decouple. We won't provide them with materials that enhance their nuclear weapons capabilities or facilitate aggressive military actions. But our goal isn't to hurt China. Next question, please.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Sir, can you confirm whether he was invited? [SEP] I'm not the person to ask about that. I don't handle the logistics of news conferences. What I can say is that they have a very collaborative working relationship, and that's what matters.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Inspections in North Korea – were they discussed? [SEP] I can't hear you very well. And where are you from?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Thank you. Mr. President, you tweeted this morning that it's U.S. foolishness, stupidity, and the Mueller probe that is responsible for the decline in U.S. relations with Russia. Do you hold Russia at all accountable for anything in particular? And if so, what would you consider them—that they are responsible for? [SEP] Yes, I do I hold both countries responsible I think that the United States has been foolish I think we've all been foolish We should have had this dialogue a long time ago—a long time, frankly, before I got to office And I think we're all to blame I think that the United States now has stepped forward, along with Russia And we're getting together And we have a chance to do some great things, whether it's nuclear proliferation, in terms of stopping—because we have to do it Ultimately, that's probably the most important thing that we can be working onBut I do feel that we have both made some mistakes I think that the probe is a disaster for our country I think it's kept us apart It's kept us separated There was no collusion at all Everybody knows it People are being brought out to the foreSo far, that I know, virtually none of it related to the campaign And they're going to have to try really hard to find somebody that did relate to the campaign That was a clean campaign I beat Hillary Clinton easily And frankly, we beat her—and I'm not even saying from the standpoint—we won that race And it's a shame that there can even be a little bit of a cloud over itPeople know that People understand it But the main thing, and we discussed this also, is zero collusion And it has had a negative impact upon the relationship of the two largest nuclear powers in the world We have 90 percent of nuclear power between the two countries It's ridiculous It's ridiculous what's going on with the probe
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, are you confident that Speaker Boehner can control his caucus and deliver the votes needed for any agreements reached? [SEP] Look, that's a question for Speaker Boehner. He's the Speaker. I'm the President. We have different jobs. I think he's doing a fine job, but ultimately, it's up to him to manage his caucus. They're all grown-ups. They can figure it out. I'm focused on the big picture, on what's best for America.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Prime Minister Lee and President Obama, how do you see the U.S. rebalance in Asia evolving? And President Obama, if you could serve another term, what would be your priorities in strengthening the relationship with Singapore? [SEP] Fifty years is a vast expanse of time. We aspire to build upon this relationship. It relies on both countries maintaining stability and prosperity. If America remains a leading economy, and Singapore continues its success, we can find common cause. Concerning a more inward-looking U.S. leader, this isn't the appropriate setting to discuss U.S. politics. We will work with any U.S. administration. Singapore often plays a moderating role, facilitating cooperation and easing tensions. The Asia-Pacific region will continue to grow. The U.S. will maintain a substantial interest in remaining an Asia-Pacific power and fostering strong trade, scientific, and educational connections.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, regarding American oil producers, are you sure they're tapping all sources, including offshore? And on Iraq, interim agreement with Maliki now, or permanent agreement later? [SEP] Iraq's the priority. We're hammering out a strategic framework agreement – diplomacy, economics, justice, the whole shebang. Security's key, aiming for 'overwatch' ASAP – U.S. trainers, support, special forces. Troops need permission, authority, protection. Gotta get it done before the year's out, unless the UN steps in. Two parts to the deal, both cooking at once. Now, about those oil companies, they're doing great, really great. Tremendous!
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the Justice Department, do you believe the recent seizure of phone records from Associated Press journalists constitutes an overreach? Do you still have confidence in your Attorney General? Is the renewed White House interest in a media shield law a direct response? Finally, what are your thoughts on comparisons to the Nixon era scandals? [SEP] I'll leave those historical comparisons to you all. My focus is on resolving any issues within the government. That's my responsibility. Regarding the IRS and ensuring proper law application, and the security of our diplomats, we'll work with Congress for adequate funding. On the Justice Department, I won't comment on pending cases. Leaks endanger national security and those serving abroad. I won't apologize for prioritizing their safety. However, a free press is vital for accountability. The media shield law aimed to balance these concerns. This case prompts a necessary revisit of that legislation. Protecting our personnel is paramount, while also upholding the public's right to know.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, even without revealing your choice, can you describe the kind of leadership you're looking for at the Federal Reserve? [SEP] Look, we're working on it. We'll be announcing something soon. We've got plenty of time to get the right people in place. I've been talking to my economic guys, and we've got a lot of good choices. But I'm not going to give you any hints right now. We'll see what happens.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Looking ahead to your second term, how do you plan to address the bipartisan criticism that you haven't sufficiently engaged with Congress to build strong working relationships? [SEP] Look, I'm always open to self-improvement, and I'll certainly be looking at ways to better communicate my commitment to working with everyone, provided it serves the purpose of strengthening our middle class and improving our economy. I've cultivated good relationships with folks in both the House and the Senate, across the political spectrum. However, that hasn't always resulted in the kind of bipartisan agreements I'd like to see. We all need to take responsibility for finding ways to improve, and I'm no exception. I'll be engaging in some self-reflection to see how I can foster better working relationships. There will inevitably be sharp differences, and as I emphasized during the campaign, some battles are worth fighting. But what the American people don't want is a constant focus on the next election; they want us focused on them. I don't have another election to run. Michelle and I were just talking last night about the immense honor and privilege it is to hold this office. Millions of people across the country worked tirelessly to help us get elected, but millions more, who may not have supported us, are also relying on us.
