sentence: Mr. President, despite your emphasis on European leaders funding their own bailout, your administration's stimulus measures are stalled in Congress. How can you credibly advise Europe on economic recovery when your own policies are facing such resistance at home? [SEP] Well, first of all, our conversations with European leaders weren't solely focused on stimulus measures. We discussed a range of strategies to promote economic growth, including rebalancing global demand. This involves adjustments and changes in behavior by various countries, not just government spending. There wasn't a disagreement with the Europeans. We all agree that it's crucial to demonstrate the strength and viability of the European project and the commitment to the euro. European leaders understand that this starts with a unified approach. We believe the elements for addressing the crisis are in place: a solution for Greece, recapitalization of European banks, and a firewall to protect the euro. We offered ideas and options for structuring the firewall. The international community stands ready to assist, but ultimately, Europe must show the markets that they are committed to the euro.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Mr. President, you're going to California today. And as you said earlier this week, you told the Nation that there's no specific or credible threat of a similar attack. But how is it really possible to know? I mean, aren't similar plots going to be just as hard to detect beforehand? And some lawmakers are saying that your Government should review the social media of all people applying for visas to come to this country. What do you think of that idea? Should that be mandatory? [SEP] Well, Roberta, you're absolutely right that it is very difficult for us to detect lone-wolf plotsor plots involving a husband and wife, in this casebecause despite the incredible vigilance thatand professionalism of all our law enforcement, homeland security, et cetera, it's not that different from us trying to detect the next mass shooter. You don't always see it. They're not always communicating publicly, and if you're not catching what they say publicly, then it becomes a challenge.We are continuing to work at every level to make sure that there's no slip between information sharing among agencies. We're continuing to strengthen our information sharing with foreign countries. And because, in part, of the tragedy in Paris, I think you're seeing much greater cooperation from our European partners on these issues.But this is a different kind of challenge than the sort that we had with an organization like Al aida that involved highly trained operatives who are working as cells or as a network. Here, essentially, you have ISIL trying to encourage or induce somebody who may be prey to this kind of propaganda. And it becomes more difficult to see. It does mean that they're less likely to be able to carry out large, complex attacks. But as we saw in San Bernardino, obviously, you can still do enormous damage.The issue of reviewing social media for those who are obtaining visas, I think, may have gotten garbled a little bit, because there may beit's important to distinguish between posts that are publicsocial media on a Facebook pageversus private communications through various social media or apps. And our law enforcement and intelligence professionals are constantly monitoring public posts, and that is part of the visa review process, that people are investigating what individuals have said publicly and questioned about any statements that they maybe made.But if you have a private communications between two individuals, that's harder to discern, by definition. And one of the things we'll be doing is engaging with the high-tech community to find out how we can, in an appropriate way, do a better job, if we have a lead, to be able to track a suspected terrorist. But we're going to have to recognize that no government is going to have the capacity to read every single person's text or e-mails or social media. If it's not posted publicly, then there are going to be feasibility issues that are probably insurmountable at some level, and it raises questions about our values.I mean, keep in mind it was only a couple of years ago where we were having a major debate about whether the Government was becoming too much like Big Brother. And overall, I think we've struck the right balance in protecting civil liberties and making sure that U.S. citizens' privacy is preserved, that we are making sure that there's oversight to what our intelligence agencies do. But we're going to have to continue to balance our needs for security with people's legitimate concerns about privacy.And because the Internet is global and communication systems are global, the values that we apply here oftentimes are ones that folks who are trying to come into the country are also benefiting from because they're using the same technologies. But this is precisely why we're working very hard to bring law enforcement, intelligence, and high-tech companies together. Because we're going to have to really review what we can do both technically as well as consistent with our laws and our values in order to try to discern more rapidly some of the potential threats that may be out there. Okay?David Jackson [USA Today].
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. You've described the U.S. relationship with China as complex. U.S. military sources are now confirming that Chinese hackers hacked into the computers at the Pentagon in June, hackers linked to the Government in Beijing. And it's being described as a complicated cyber attack. Have you been briefed on this attack? How much more complex does this make the relationship with China? And do you plan to bring it up with President Hu Jintao on Thursday? [SEP] I'm very aware that a lot of our systems are vulnerable to cyber attack from a variety of places. And therefore, the first question should be—not to put questions in your mouth, Bret, but— what are you doing to defend America against cyber attack? Are you aware that we have vulnerabilities, that people can hack into sensitive systems? And are you then providing expertise and technology necessary to defend? And the answer is, yes. We understand that we're vulnerable in some systems, some, by the way, more valuable than others—or less valuable than others, I guess, is the best way to put it.In terms of whether or not I'll bring this up to countries that we suspect may— from which there may have been an attack, I may. In this instance, I don't have the intelligence at my fingertips right now. Whether it be this issue or issues like intellectual property rights, I mean, if you have a relationship with a country, then you've got to respect the country's systems and knowledge base. And that's what we expect from people with whom we trade.Our relationship with China is complex. On the one hand, we appreciate the opportunity to trade goods and services. We certainly hope that China changes from a saving society to a consuming society. Right now, because of the lack of a safety net, many Chinese save for what we call a rainy day. What we want is the Government to provide more of a safety net so they start buying more and Australian products. We want there to be a—the middle class to feel comfortable coming into the marketplace, the global marketplace, so that our producers can see the benefits directly with trade with China.By the way, our exports to China are up, Mr. Prime Minister, which is positive. We still have got a huge trade deficit with China, which then causes us to want to work with them to adjust—to let their currency float. We think that would be helpful in terms of adjusting trade balances.We've got great relations with China from a diplomatic perspective. In other words, we're able to talk with them openly and candidly. But do we agree on every issue? Not at all. I mean, for example, I've spent time talking about dissidents who have been jailed. I'm concerned about the treatment of the Dalai Lama. I want China to be more aggressive when it comes to Iran. I'm interested to hear President Hu Jintao's attitudes toward the humanitarian crisis in Darfur. In other words, there's a lot of issues which we wish they would have a different lean to their policy, so I'm going to discuss these with him. But it's best to be able to discuss these issues in an environment that is frank and open and friendly, as opposed to one in which there's tension and suspicion.And so when I say we've got great relations, I will sit down with the President and have a good, honest, candid discussion. And he's going to tell me what's on his mind, and I'm darned sure going to tell him what's on my mind.One area where we are making good progress is on North Korea. As you may remember, I shifted the whole strategic approach to North Korea. I'm convinced that it's more effective to have five countries to say to North Korea the same thing than just one country, so that if North Korea makes the decision not to honor their word, that there's a better chance that there's consequences that they'll feel. And so as a result of getting China to the table on North Korea, the North Koreans are going to realize there is a lot more than one voice. And China has been instrumental in helping move this process forward. Chris Hill—Ambassador Hill briefed me and Secretary Rice this morning on the fact that North Korea still looks like they're going to honor their agreement to disclose and to shut down their nuclear programs, which will be good for peace.Anyway, a long answer because it's a complex relationship. Australian side. Mark [Mark Riley, Seven Network].
label: Implicit

sentence: Sir, what precisely did you ask him regarding Afghanistan and the role of U.S. troops? [SEP] Well, he actually brought up Afghanistan first, voicing his hope for continued stability. I emphasized that much rested on his actions. He suggested he could potentially assist in Afghanistan—the details of which I'll keep private for now—and also with Iran. We, in turn, communicated our goals for bringing stability, both economic and physical, to Syria and Libya. Those were the main points of our conversation.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Not yet. But just given all the concerns about the economy that people have, do you feel like you could win in a State like Ohio if you were running again for Presidency? [SEP] Landslide, John. [] Look, I am a big believer in free trade. And the reason why is, I firmly believe that free trade is essential to the formation of high-paying, quality jobs. In other words, people who work for industries that export goods to overseas are likely to be paid more than their—other workers.Secondly, if you look at the—our economic growth recently, particularly last year, a major portion of that growth came as a result of exports. It's an essential part of our economic picture.Yes, I heard the talk about NAFTA. One statistic I think people need to know is, I think there's roughly, like, $380 billion worth of goods that we ship to our NAFTA partners on an annual basis. Now, $380 billion worth of goods means there's a lot of farmers and businesses, large and small, who are benefiting from having a market in our neighborhood. And the idea of just unilaterally withdrawing from a trade treaty because of trying to score political points is not good policy. It's not good policy on the merits, and it's not good policy to— as a message to send to our—people who have, in good faith, signed a treaty and worked with us on a treaty.Thirdly, those of us who grew up in Texas remember what the border looked like when we were kids, and it was really poor. And you go down to that border today, it is prosperous on both sides of the river, to the credit of those who proposed NAFTA and to the credit of those who got NAFTA through the Congress. If you're worried about people coming into our country illegally, it makes sense to help a place like Mexico grow its economy. Most folks would rather be finding a job close to home; most folks would rather not try to get in the bottom of an 18-wheeler to come and put food on the table.This agreement has meant prosperity on both sides of our borders, north and south. And I believe it's in the interests to continue to seek markets for our farmers, ranchers, and businesspeople. I also know it's in our interest to insist that when people sell products into our countries, that we get treated fairly. In other words, if we treat a country one way—people in a country one way—we expect to be treated the same way, like Colombia.The Colombia free trade vote's coming up. Many of their products come into our country much easier than our products go into theirs. It makes sense to be treated equally. But on this vote, there's an additional consequence. If the Congress rejects the Colombia free trade agreement, it will sorely affect the national security interests of the United States. It will encourage false populism in our neighborhood. It will undermine the standing of courageous leaders like President Uribe. And I strongly urge the Congress, when they bring this—when the Colombia free trade agreement is brought to a vote, to seriously consider the consequences of rejecting this trade agreement.Mike [Mike Emanuel, FOX News].
label: General

sentence: Q. Would you now consider Kim Jong Un your peer? [SEP] In what context are you asking?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, considering the global implications of surveillance programs, what steps have you taken to ensure that U.S. intelligence activities are conducted in a manner that respects the privacy and civil liberties of individuals both at home and abroad? [SEP] We take these issues very seriously. We have a system of checks and balances in place to ensure that our intelligence activities are conducted within the law and with respect for privacy and civil liberties. We're constantly reviewing our procedures to make sure we're doing everything we can to protect those values.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Yes. And so are you still considering imposing Section 232 tariffs on Japan's auto exports to the United States on national security grounds? [SEP] Not at this moment, no. Not at this moment. Well, it's one of the reasons we made the deal. But no, not at this moment. It's something I could do at a later date if I wanted to, but we're not looking at that. We just want to be treated fairly.You know, Japan has had a tremendous trade surplus with the United States for many, many years—long before I came here. And I'll tell you something: We're transforming our country. We're taking these horrible, one-sided, foolish, very dumb, stupid—if you'd like to use that word, because it's so descriptive. We're taking these trade deals that are so bad, and we we're making good, solid deals out of them. And that's transforming our country. That's—that will be transformative and very exciting, I think, for our country. Very, very exciting.Please, go ahead. Go ahead.
label: Explicit

sentence: So, Mr. President, regarding China, are you concerned that their economic struggles might push them to act more aggressively, particularly concerning Taiwan? And separately, what's your take on the Putin-Kim meeting and its potential impact on the situation in Ukraine? [SEP] China's got some serious economic problems, no doubt about it, stemming from global issues and their own policies. I don't see that leading to an invasion of Taiwan; in fact, it might limit their capabilities. We're not looking to hurt China, a prosperous China that plays by the rules is good for everyone. They're dealing with real estate troubles and figuring out their next steps. We're not trying to decouple, but we won't sell them stuff that helps them build more nukes or engage in defense activities that destabilize the region. Next question, please.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. The question to President Yushchenko: Please, Mr. President, say, if the positive decision is not taken in Bucharest on Ukraine, what are the next steps of Ukraine then? [SEP] If not, the—I'm sure that we will win because the arguments that were just mentioned by Mr. President and the positions that Ukraine is standing with, within the framework of the international debate on this issue—we are every day approaching to the positive final result. This is a colossal international work, and I would like to thank you all— in your presence, I would like to thank President Bush for the work that's been done and that will be done in both public and nonpublic way.And we fully understand the value of the issue and its importance. Of course, we still have a lot of effort forward to receive a positive answer. I have very good belief that the position of our friends in the EU will play a very important role for tomorrow's decision. And I hope that we will be able to convince those states that still have an opportunity—that will have an opportunity to get more information about it and eliminate all the doubts.I—frankly speaking, I don't see any other way for Ukraine, no other alternative maybe—emotionally, I would like to say that for the nation, for the political forces, should be more devoted to this way. And the issue of whether Ukraine joins or not— the MAP—is not the complete target, the final target that we have in the Ukrainian society. And I'm sure that in order to avoid speculations on an international level, when somebody refers to the fact that the Ukrainian nation has not decided yet—I'm sorry, we have decided already. We're not speaking about joining NATO, we are only speaking about MAP.Why Ukraine should be deprived of that sovereign right is—there is a principle of open doors, which is the basic principle for NATO. Why can't we join MAP, and then let's have a meeting in a year or two, when we explain to the nation that—what the NATO mission is and what the collective security mission is and then how important is—a response for Ukraine it is and why there is no alternative answer for us. If any politician is troubled about this nation and is worried about this future, I am sure that Ukrainian nation is very wise, and it will make positive decision in the course of the referendum that we going to have regarding Ukraine to join NATO.I recall when, 3 years ago, we started this discussion, I think, from 17 percent of those who are for and who supported the alliance integration—a year ago, we were supported by 33 percent. During the last live debates, we've seen the analytics that raised up to 40 percent. And we haven't started our work yet—I mean, the profound work. So this is the—quite a situation. I mean, the attention to this issue in the parliament for the last 2 months just made that big progress, and the nation started knowing better what NATO is and what its concept is. So I think everything will be fine.Thank you.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Can you share what you asked him about Afghanistan? What was your particular request for Afghanistan and the U.S. troops? [SEP] No, he asked us about Afghanistan. He said that he hopes that we're able to maintain some peace and security, and I said, That has a lot to do with you. He indicated that he was prepared to, quote, help on Afghanistan—I won't go into detail now; and help on Iran; and help on—and, in return, we told him what we wanted to do relative to bringing some stability and economic security or physical security to the people of Syria and Libya.So we had those discussions.Yamiche [Yamiche Alcindor, PBS News].Ransomware Attacks on U.S. Companies/
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Do you believe that a deal could have been reached without Israel's agreement to temporarily suspend annexation? [SEP] What do you think about that, David? It's interesting. I think you can't do both at the same time. So I think, again, prioritize peace. Sovereignty after peace is given; every opportunity to return to sovereignty. I don't think the two could have been done at the same time.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, how would you characterize Speaker Pelosi's recent criticisms regarding your handling of the coronavirus outbreak and the information disseminated by your administration? [SEP] With all due respect, Speaker Pelosi's comments are, frankly, indicative of her own shortcomings. Her leadership has been demonstrably ineffective, as evidenced by her previous loss of the House. It is my assessment that she is likely to repeat this failure. Ironically, her criticisms have served only to bolster my public approval, a phenomenon I find both unexpected and easily achieved. Rather than engage in such unproductive rhetoric, she would be better served by prioritizing national unity in the face of this potential challenge. While I remain optimistic that its impact will be minimal, collaborative action is paramount. Furthermore, Senator Schumer's assertions regarding the inadequacy of our funding request are particularly disingenuous. It is typically the case that we are urged to reduce spending, not increase it. These individuals are prioritizing political maneuvering over the well-being of the nation. They seek to incite panic where none is warranted. We possess the most capable experts globally, and other nations are soliciting our assistance. Speaker Pelosi should address the issues within her own constituency, which is currently facing significant challenges. This matter transcends political considerations; it is about serving the American people. If additional funding is offered, we will accept it. However, it is unacceptable to denigrate the dedicated healthcare professionals who are working tirelessly on this issue. They are not merely criticizing me; they are disparaging the finest minds in the world.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, regarding North Korea's commitment to denuclearization, how can you guarantee they will follow through this time, and not just offer empty promises? [SEP] Guarantee? Nobody can guarantee anything in life. Can you guarantee the sun will rise tomorrow? What I can tell you is this: I have a feeling, a very strong feeling, that Kim Jong-un wants to make a deal. I'm a dealmaker, the best dealmaker, believe me. I know when someone's serious. And I think he's serious. We'll see what happens. But I have a good feeling about it. It's going to be great, really great.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. But is the election of two Muslim women—one of them is veiled—to the House, which is making history, is this a rebuke of this message, do you think? [SEP] I don't understand what you're saying to me. What?

sentence: Q. So you have no regrets? You have no regrets? [SEP] That's what I intend to do.Jon Karl [ABC News]./President's Policy Agenda

sentence: Mr. President, concerning Russia's announcement about reducing military activities near Kyiv, is this a sign of progress towards peace, or a deceptive tactic to reorganize their forces for a renewed offensive? [SEP] Look, I'm not going to speculate on their motives. We're watching what they *do*, not what they *say*. There are talks happening, and I just met with leaders from France, Germany, and the UK. Everyone's taking a 'wait and see' approach. We're keeping the pressure on with sanctions and making sure Ukraine has what it needs to defend itself. We'll know soon enough if they're serious.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, concerning Cuba, does your new approach signal an end to U.S. efforts at regime change? And regarding Hillary Clinton, do you share Vice President Biden's view that the Democratic nomination is still up for grabs? [SEP] I'm done running for office, and I'm not a political prognosticator. That's your job. Lots of people are eager to offer opinions; I won't be one of them. On Cuba, our focus isn't regime change. It's about giving the Cuban people freedom and the power to control their destiny, supporting civil society. Cuba will change regardless. President Castro mentioned events from before I was born; the Cold War is over. We'll still have disagreements with Cuba, including their government's treatment of its people and regional issues. But we can find common ground. Cuban doctors helped during Ebola; their efforts in Haiti after the earthquake were significant. I told President Castro we'll express our views, but persuasion is the key, especially on issues that don't directly threaten our national security. Cuba isn't a threat. My concerns include ISIL, Iran's nuclear program, Yemen, Libya, Boko Haram, Russian aggression in Ukraine, climate change – a long list. We'll work with the region, be clear about our values, and partner to improve opportunity, prosperity, and security. Overreach often backfires, giving countries excuses for their problems. Let's eliminate that excuse.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, as you approach the end of your term, what are your remaining legislative priorities? And how concerned are you that the immigration bill will be derailed by election-year politics? [SEP] We've got a full agenda. We need to get this energy bill passed, renew No Child Left Behind, and push these trade agreements through Congress. Panama, Peru, Colombia – we need to get those done. And we need to keep building on the progress we've made with the Korean free trade agreement. We're hoping to bring back a successful Doha negotiation for a vote, which means we need to extend TPA. And we need to keep the budget balanced. The deficit's been reduced more than expected, thanks to increased tax revenues and our fiscal policies. But we need Congress to be responsible and not overspend or raise taxes. That would hurt the economy. And of course, we have to keep fighting the war on terror. I'd like to find common ground with Democrats and Republicans on Iraq, but some just want to withdraw. I disagree with that. Most Americans do. Immigration is a tough issue. It's very emotional. I've always supported comprehensive reform. I campaigned on it. I understand the concerns about illegal immigration, which is why we've been working to secure the border. We're doubling the Border Patrol, building fences, and using new technology. I even sent the National Guard down there for a while. This bill addresses those concerns. It sets benchmarks for border security before any other reforms take place. But you can't have real border security without a temporary worker program. People will come here to work, and they'll find a way. That creates an underground industry of smugglers and document forgers. It's inhumane. We need to give people a legal way to come here and work temporarily. And we need a tamper-proof ID card to verify employment. The most difficult part is what to do with the people already here. Some people want to deport them all, but that's not realistic. And we can't just give them automatic citizenship. So we've developed a plan where they have to meet certain requirements to get a Z visa, like background checks and fines. They go to the back of the line for citizenship. If you support the bill, I thank you. If you don't, you can always find something to criticize. It's easy to pick it apart. But I believe it's the right thing to do. I want to get it done because it will solve the problem. I want to take it out of politics. Immigration debates can bring out the worst in people. We're a nation of immigrants. I was touched by the story of the Coast Guard ensign whose grandfather came from Mexico. He's serving America with pride. That's what immigration can mean for America. Welcoming people who want to work and pursue the American Dream renews our spirit. We have an opportunity to pass a good law now. It will be difficult, and politics will play a role. But I hope members of Congress will rise above it. I will.
label: Implicit

sentence: Sir, considering most surge troops were in place during the July report, will you disregard General Petraeus's recommendations and continue the surge if Iraq doesn't achieve political milestones by September? [SEP] I'm not going to jump the gun. I want to get General Petraeus's input in September, and then I'll be in a better position to answer that question.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the COVID-19 booster shots, some are suggesting the definition of 'fully vaccinated' should be updated to include them. Is the White House hesitant to do so because it might make the vaccination rates appear less impressive? [SEP] Look, that's simply not the case. The science is evolving, and we're constantly monitoring the data. My message is clear: if you're vaccinated, get boosted. It's the best protection available. Two shots offer solid defense, especially with Pfizer, but the booster significantly enhances that protection. It's about optimizing public health, not manipulating statistics.

sentence: When can we expect that announcement? And how do you see the overall progress that Asian countries made? [SEP] Well, some are making progress; some are not, as you know. But some are making progress. And as they make progress, as they get down to the number that we all think is right—that they know is right, we know is right—we'll be opening it up. And some are really moving along rapidly. We hope to be able to open things up as quickly as possible.Go ahead, please. Go ahead.

We're monitoring the situation closely and are committed to working with the Mexican government to ensure a stable and mutually beneficial relationship.

sentence: Mr. President, as someone from China, I'm curious: Do you still see a potential future where U.S.-North Korea relations mirror the current U.S.-Vietnam relationship? [SEP] Pardon? Could you repeat that, please?

sentence: Mr. President, regarding President Moon, who's facing limitations on inter-Korean cooperation due to sanctions, what's your message? Also, what's the status of U.S.-R.O.K. military exercises? [SEP] Well, I have a very high regard for President Moon. Our relationship is excellent. In fact, I maintain excellent relationships with nearly every leader. While some may attempt to exploit our nation, they tend to reconsider once they realize I'm aware of their intentions. Nevertheless, we enjoy many positive relationships. I'll be contacting President Moon imminently, as soon as I board the plane. He'll be among the first I call. I'll also be reaching out to Prime Minister Abe of Japan to inform him of our progress. He's diligently working, President Moon is. He's eager to see a resolution, and he's been quite supportive.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, on Cuba, the Cuban government often claims U.S. interference justifies their restrictions on freedoms. Does your new policy truly end U.S. regime change efforts, and should Cuba then respond with free elections and tolerance of dissent? Also, Vice President Biden says the Democratic race is wide open, despite what polls suggest. What's your opinion? [SEP] I'm not running any more elections, and I'm not in the business of predicting them. That's your job. Plenty of people are happy to give their opinions, but I won't be one of them. On Cuba, we're not focused on regime change. We're focused on ensuring the Cuban people have freedom and the ability to shape their own destiny and lives, and on supporting civil society. There will be an evolution in Cuba, regardless of what we do. Partly, it's generational. President Castro's comments earlier referenced actions that took place before I was born, and part of my message is that the Cold War is over. We still face many challenges and issues around the world, and we will still have serious issues with Cuba regarding its government's approach to its own people, as well as regional concerns. There may be areas where we can cooperate. Cuban doctors made a difference during the Ebola crisis, and Cuban activity in Haiti after the earthquake was significant. I told President Castro what I've told leaders throughout the region: we have a point of view, and we won't hesitate to express it. But I believe the best way to promote the values we care about is through persuasion. That will be our primary approach on these issues, mainly because they don't directly threaten our national security. Cuba is not a threat to the United States, although we have differences. Among the threats I'm concerned about, I would list ISIL, Iran's nuclear ambitions, activities in Yemen and Libya, Boko Haram, Russian aggression in Ukraine, and climate change. Our approach must be to work with the region and other countries, clearly stating what we believe in and what works. Often, when we intervene in ways that go beyond persuasion, it's counterproductive and backfires. That's been part of our history, which is why countries use us as an excuse for their own governance failures. Let's remove that excuse and be clear that we're prepared to partner and engage with everyone to promote opportunity, prosperity, and security in the region.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. How hard is it for you to conduct the war without popular support? For you personally, do you ever have trouble balancing the—between doing what you think is the right thing and following the will of the majority of the public, which is really the essence of democracy? [SEP] Yes, it is. And, first of all, I can fully understand why people are tired of the war. The question they have is, can we win it? And of course I'm concerned about whether or not the American people are in this fight. I believe, however, that when they really think about the consequences if we were to precipitously withdraw, they begin to say to themselves, maybe we ought to win this; maybe we ought to have a stable Iraq.Their question, it seems like to me, is, can we succeed? And that's a very important, legitimate question for anybody to ask. I think many people understand we must succeed, and I think a lot of people understand we've got to wait for the generals to make these military decisions. I suspect—I know this, Ed, that if our troops thought that I was taking a poll to decide how to conduct this war, they would be very concerned about the mission. In other words, if our troops said, Well, here we are in combat, and we've got a Commander in Chief who is running a focus group. In other words, politics would be—is more important to him than our safety and/or our strategy, that would dispirit our troops.And there's a lot of constituencies in this fight. Clearly the American people, who are paying for this, is the major constituency. And I repeat to you, Ed, I understand that there—this violence has affected them. And a lot of people don't think we can win. There's a lot of people in Congress who don't think we can win as well, and therefore, their attitude is, get out.My concern with that strategy—something that Mike Hayden also discussed— is that just getting out may sound simple, and it may affect polls, but it would have long-term, serious security consequences for the United States. And so, Ed, sometimes you just have to make the decisions based upon what you think is right. My most important job is to help secure this country, and therefore, the decisions in Iraq are all aimed at helping do that job. And that's what I firmly believe.A second constituency is the military. And I repeat to you: I'm pretty confident our military do not want their Commander in Chief making political decisions about their future.A third constituency that matters to me a lot is the military families. These are good folks who are making huge sacrifices, and they support their loved ones. And I don't think they want their Commander in Chief making decisions based upon popularity.Another constituency group that is important for me to talk to is the Iraqis. Obviously, I want the Iraqi Government to understand that we expect there to be reconciliation top down, that we want to see laws passed. I think they've got that message. They know full well that the American Government and the American people expect to see tangible evidence of working together. That's what the benchmarks are aimed to do.But they also need to know that I am making decisions based upon our security interests, of course, but also helping them succeed, and that a poll is not going to determine the course of action by the United States. What will determine the course of actions is, will the decisions that we have made help secure our country for the long run?And finally, another constituency is the enemy, who are wondering whether or not America has got the resolve and the determination to stay after them. And so that's what I think about, Ed.And, you know, I guess I'm like any other political figure; everybody wants to be loved, just sometimes the decisions you make and the consequences don't enable you to be loved. And so when it's all said and done, Ed, when you've—if you ever come down and visit the old, tired me down there in Crawford, I will be able to say, I looked in the mirror and made decisions based upon principle, not based upon politics. And that's important to me.Thank you all for your time. I loved being here at this new building. Thank you.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, can you at least confirm or deny whether military action in Syria is being considered? [SEP] Elaine, I'm not going to comment on potential military operations. My focus is on de-escalation and finding a diplomatic solution.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. After your election 2 years ago, when you met with Republicans you said that, in discussing what policies might go forward, that elections have consequences and that you pointed out that you had won. I wonder what consequences you think this election should have then, in terms of your policies. Are there areas that you're willing--can you name today areas that you would be willing to compromise on that you might not have been willing to compromise on in the past? [SEP] Well, I think I've been willing to compromise in the past and I'm going to be willing to compromise going forward on a whole range of issues. Let me give you an example, the issue of energy that I just mentioned.I think there are a lot of Republicans that ran against the energy bill that passed in the House last year. And so it's doubtful that you could get the votes to pass that through the House this year or next year or the year after. But that doesn't mean there isn't agreement that we should have a better energy policy. And so let's find those areas where we can agree.We've got, I think, broad agreement that we've got terrific natural gas resources in this country. Are we doing everything we can to develop those? There's a lot of agreement around the need to make sure that electric cars are developed here in the United States, that we don't fall behind other countries. Are there things that we can do to encourage that? And there's already been bipartisan interest on those issues.There's been discussion about how we can restart our nuclear industry as a means of reducing our dependence on foreign oil and reducing greenhouse gases. Is that an area where we can move forward?We were able, over the last 2 years, to increase, for the first time in 30 years, fuel efficiency standards on cars and trucks. We didn't even need legislation. We just needed the cooperation of automakers and autoworkers and investors and other shareholders. And that's going to move us forward in a serious way.So I think when it comes to something like energy, what we're probably going to have to do is say, here are some areas where there's just too much disagreement between Democrats and Republicans. We can't get this done right now, but let's not wait. Let's go ahead and start making some progress on the things that we do agree on, and we can continue to have a strong and healthy debate about those areas where we don't.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, Hillary Clinton suggests the FBI Director's announcement impacted the election. Her campaign chair alleges a lackadaisical early investigation. Your thoughts? [SEP] Well, transitions are always bumpy. Feelings are still raw. But when Trump takes office, he'll have different responsibilities. Walking into the Oval Office is sobering. I've had cordial conversations with the President-elect, offering suggestions on maintaining the office's effectiveness and integrity. He's listened. I don't know if he'll implement them, but the talks have been cordial. I'll always be available to him. As for the FBI, I know Director Comey and many agents. They take their job seriously. It's tough when law enforcement intersects with politics. We want them independent, but investigations sometimes touch on politics. I've been scrupulous about not interfering in investigations. I don't plan to start now.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, with respect, the American people deserve transparency. Can you provide a definitive answer regarding the $200 million target, disclosure of donors, and contribution limits for your Presidential library? [SEP] Well, let's just say the library is a significant undertaking, and fundraising is ongoing. The details are still being worked out, and we'll follow all applicable regulations. It's a process, you know?
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: So, your thoughts on Boris Johnson and Michael Gove? [SEP] Boris, I've met him. Seems like a strong leader. Jeremy, I've heard good things. Michael... I'm not as familiar with him. But if the people support him, then I'm sure he's capable. Okay? Good. Let's move on.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Sir, with the SEC looking into the Kodak situation, do you think there might be something fishy about how that deal went down? [SEP] Look, I wasn't involved in the day-to-day stuff. The idea behind the deal is a good one, but we'll let the investigation run its course and see what they find.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, with all due respect, while you tout GDP growth, many Americans are struggling. How do you reconcile this disconnect, especially when compared to the economic hardships faced by countries like Greece under international financial oversight? [SEP] The United States is not Greece. Period. When I walked into the Oval Office, this economy was on life support, losing jobs at an alarming rate. We implemented a comprehensive plan to stabilize the economy and stimulate growth. It's a multi-faceted approach that includes structural reforms, responsible fiscal management, and strategic investments. A growing economy generates more revenue, which helps to alleviate debt. Cutting spending during an economic downturn is counterproductive. We have the advantage of the dollar being the world's reserve currency, providing us with unique flexibility. Our experience demonstrates that investing in our people, fostering economic activity, and addressing structural deficits are essential for sustainable growth. We are committed to ensuring that the benefits of economic growth are shared by all Americans.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, the public is demanding to see the photos from the guards. What is the justification for withholding them? [SEP] That's a separate question, and I don't want to get sidetracked. The real issue is the Iranian people's struggle for freedom. We need to focus on supporting them and making sure they know that we are watching. As Dr. King said, 'The arc of the moral universe is long, but it bends towards justice.' We must believe that justice will prevail. The photos are a distraction from the main issue.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. And a subsidiary question, what do you think about taking it out of the political realm and giving it to an outside body of experts to take the politics out of Medicare? [SEP] Well, on the second point, that's exactly what our proposal is. It—called the MedPAC program. By the way, it was originally a Republican idea. I want to give credit where credit is due. The Republican Congress passed a bill that created a panel of health care experts to make recommendations to Congress on how we could get better quality, lower cost. The problem is, every year it would just go on a shelf and nobody would act on it.So what we've said is let's give that body some power. Let's require Congress to vote on the proposals that they're making every year. Congress can still reject them, so it's not completely removing it from politics, but they have to reject or accept it as a package. And that, I think, would incentivize and empower important changes.But here's the thing I want to emphasize, Chip. It's not going to reduce benefits. What it's going to do is to change how those benefits are delivered so that they're more efficient. Let me give you a very specific example. You've heard that as a consequence of our efforts at reform, the pharmaceutical industry has already said they're willing to put $80 billion on the table. Now, why is that? Well, the reason is, is because there's probably even more waste than $80 billion, in terms of how the drug plan in is administered. We might be able to get 100 billion out or more, but the pharmaceutical industry voluntarily said here's $80 billion.You know what that translates—what that means? That means that senior citizens who right now have a so-called doughnut hole in their plan, where after spending a certain amount on prescription drugs suddenly they drop off a cliff and they've got to pocket the entire cost, suddenly half of that is filled. That's a hard commitment that we already have. So that's a change in how we are delivering . But you know what? It turns out that it means out-of-pocket savings for seniors. That's why AARP has endorsed us. Okay.Christi Parsons [Chicago Tribune].
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, given the recent economic turmoil, how can you assure the American people that raising the debt ceiling won't lead to further instability? [SEP] I am going to keep on working, and I'm going to keep on trying. And what I'm going to do is to hope that, in part, this debate has focused the American people's attention a little bit more and will subject Congress to scrutiny. And I think increasingly the American people are going to say to themselves, you know what, if a party or a politician is constantly taking the position my way or the high way, constantly being locked into ideologically rigid positions, that we're going to remember at the polls.
label: General

sentence: Q. Sir, in light of the Inter-Continental Hotel attack, does it worry you that Afghan forces might not be up to the task if they can't secure a major target in the capital? [SEP] Look, the drawdown hasn't even begun. We knew Afghanistan was a dangerous place, the Taliban's still active, and things like this would happen. The key question is, are the Afghans getting better? Kabul, where a lot of Afghans live, has been mostly policed by Afghan forces for a while, and they've done a decent job. Kabul's safer now, and the Afghan forces are more capable. That doesn't mean these attacks won't happen, and they probably will for some time. We're not done yet. But as I've said, the war is winding down. We're in a transition phase. And like in Iraq, where we pulled out troops and will have the rest out by the end of the year, but Iraq's been able to keep a democratic government and reduce violence, we think a similar approach makes sense in Afghanistan. Even in Iraq, you still see attacks. These countries are still dealing with a lot of war and conflict. They're dangerous, and they won't be perfectly safe, even if we stay. But we can help the Afghan people defend themselves better.
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Sir, one more time, what are your thoughts on your family's role? [SEP] Excuse me?
label: Clarification

sentence: Considering the complex challenges at the border, what specific, tangible steps are being taken to address the root causes of migration and prevent families from making the dangerous journey to the U.S.? [SEP] We are working with our partners in Central America to address the underlying issues that drive migration, such as poverty, violence, and corruption. This includes investing in economic development, strengthening law enforcement, and promoting good governance. We are also providing humanitarian assistance to those in need. It's a long-term effort, but we are committed to making progress.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, you've spoken about rising nationalism. What advice would you give to protestors demonstrating against Donald Trump's rhetoric? And have you advised your successor to be mindful of worrying trends, especially regarding staff picks? Finally, do you have leverage to stop the bombing of Aleppo? [SEP] Well, protesting is part of democracy. I've been protested myself. I wouldn't tell anyone to be silent. But elections matter, voting matters, being informed matters. Don't take our system for granted. Democracy is hard work. If people don't vote, democracy weakens. If we can't tell truth from propaganda, we have problems. If people are unwilling to compromise, democracy breaks down. Understand the foundations of democracy and engage in citizenship continuously. There's complacency. People forget the Cold War. There's an easy equivalence between the U.S. and Russia. We have flaws, we've made mistakes. But the U.S. has been good for Germany, for Europe. We've provided security. We've tried to apply principles of free speech and civil liberties. Remember that. Because there's so much misinformation. If everything seems the same, we won't know what to protect. We can lose so much. That was a long answer. I don't remember the second part.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, you've often spoken about expanding rights and opportunities for all Americans. However, as you leave office, many worry that the progress made will be undone. Considering your past remarks about closing remaining gaps, what are the most pressing rights issues that still need addressing? How do you plan to contribute to resolving these issues in your post-presidency? And, as the first African American President, what are your thoughts on the likelihood of seeing another Black President in the near future? [SEP] Let me address that last question first. I firmly believe we will continue to see talented individuals from every conceivable background rise to positions of leadership in this country. That's the essence of America's strength – when everyone has a fair chance to succeed. I've often used the analogy of our Olympic teams. Their incredible diversity is a testament to our nation's potential. You see athletes of all shapes, sizes, and colors achieving greatness. This genetic diversity is a tremendous asset. Consider Simone Biles and Michael Phelps – vastly different individuals, yet both champions in their respective fields. And it's worth noting that women consistently win a significant portion of our medals, a direct result of Title IX, which has provided them with unparalleled opportunities in sports.So, if we remain committed to ensuring equal opportunity for all, I have no doubt that we will see a woman President, a Latino President, a Jewish President, a Hindu President – the possibilities are endless. Perhaps even a President of mixed heritage that defies easy categorization. That's perfectly acceptable.Regarding my concerns, I addressed many of these in my Farewell Address, so I won't reiterate them all here. However, inequality remains a significant challenge. If we fail to invest in ensuring that everyone can participate fully in the economy, we risk hindering economic growth and exacerbating divisions among Americans, not just along racial lines. Many individuals voted for the President-elect because they feel marginalized and forgotten, believing that their children will not have the same opportunities they once had.We must avoid a scenario where a small elite thrives while the majority struggles for scraps. This breeds resentment and can amplify racial tensions, as people begin to believe that the only way to advance is by taking something from someone who looks or worships differently. This is not a recipe for a healthy democracy.I am also deeply concerned about the fundamental mechanisms of our democracy. We stand alone among advanced nations in making it more difficult, rather than easier, to vote. This has a long and troubling history that we must confront honestly.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, with all due respect, I asked a direct question. Are you refusing to answer it? [SEP] I am choosing to allocate my time to questions that I deem more relevant to the American public at this time.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, the agreement hinges on voluntary cooperation. Given past disagreements, what's the probability of genuine cooperation, and how will compliance be ensured? [SEP] Take Ukraine, for example. We've been pushing them for ten years to get rid of their highly enriched uranium. Because of this conference, they've agreed to do it. These commitments were already in place before the communique. That shows you how much agreement there is on this issue. We also have a number of international conventions. The U.S. needs to ratify a couple of them dealing with nuclear terrorism. This sets out a bold plan. We're already seeing efforts that have been delayed for years finally coming to fruition here at this summit.
label: Deflection

sentence: So, to be clear, you're not confirming that she was terminated? [SEP] Listen, with all due respect, I'm not going to speculate on personnel matters without all the facts. I learned about this situation just this morning, and frankly, I'm still trying to get my head around it. We need to let the investigation run its course.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, to leave no room for doubt, are you prepared to endorse a budget that maintains government operations, even if it necessitates adhering to the reduced levels dictated by the sequester, regardless of your personal inclinations? [SEP] I'm not going to commit to anything specific right now. However, I believe it's important to honor the agreements we've already made. If the final bill reflects those commitments, then I would be inclined to sign it to ensure the stability of our government. Thank you. Next question.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: So, Mr. President, is Charlotte a possibility? [SEP] We're considering a number of options. An announcement will be made in due course.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Given the allegations of government officials' involvement with drug trafficking and paramilitary organizations, how do you evaluate the government's response to this scandal? How far does your support for President Uribe extend, considering the drug trafficking activities of paramilitary leaders? Will the U.S. pursue extradition of those involved? [SEP] We stand for the rule of law. We believe that everyone, regardless of their position, should be held accountable for their actions. President Uribe has assured me that he is committed to ensuring a fair and transparent investigation, and we support his efforts to do so. The key is an independent judiciary, free from political influence, that can deliver justice to all.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Could you repeat that, sir, regarding your family? [SEP] Come again?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Okay. One more. [Laughter] Very quickly. You saw Governor Ron DeSantis with a resounding victory in Florida last night. Who do you think would be the tougher competitor: Ron DeSantis or former President Trump? And how is that factoring into your decision? [SEP] It will be fun watching them take on each other. []All right. David Sanger [New York Times].
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Mr. President, you, on the other hand, got the request and right away went here to meet him. And do you understand those people who say that you gave him the ultimate present, the legitimacy to a regime who oppress its people without an ongoing process before you, as the U.S. President, as the leader of the free world, meet and shake hands with this leader of North Korea who is perceived to be oppressing brutally his own people? [SEP] Okay. Good. I think we've just answered the question.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, how does this agreement between Israel and the U.A.E. assist Christians in the Middle East? [SEP] Excuse me?
label: Clarification

sentence: Sir, about the Presidential library: are you aiming to raise $200 million as reported? Will you disclose donor names and amounts, and will you limit who can contribute? [SEP] The budget's still in flux. We'll look at disclosure rules. Some donors want to remain anonymous. What was the last part of your question again?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, what's your take on the proposed mosque near Ground Zero? They have a right, but wouldn't it be better if they chose another location? Also, doesn't this Koran burning threat endanger American lives? [SEP] Look, anyone deliberately provoking a billion Muslims while we have troops in Muslim countries is creating a problem. It makes things harder for our soldiers. As for the mosque, this country is built on the principle that everyone is equal and has the right to practice their religion freely. If you can build a church, synagogue, or temple, you should be able to build a mosque. I understand the sensitivities around 9/11, but we're not at war with Islam. We're at war with terrorists who distort Islam. We need allies, and most Muslims want the same things we do: jobs, education, safety. They reject this violent ideology. We have millions of Muslim Americans who are our neighbors, friends, and coworkers. Some are even fighting for us in Afghanistan. We need to treat them as equals.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Mr. President, despite the military success of the surge, there's no evidence that one of its intended benefits, making it easier for the Iraqis to form a unity government, has had any effect. Refugees won't come home from Syria. There was an opinion poll this week which said that most of the Iraqis surveyed blamed us, said things would be better when the U.S. leaves. What benchmarks can the Iraqi Government meet that would change this? What do you want them to do? [SEP] Well, first of all, I don't agree with your premise that there's no politics taking place in Iraq. There is a functioning Government. They did pass a budget last year, and they're in the process of passing their budget this year. I am pleased to report that there's been two readings of a de-Ba'athification law to the Council of Assemblies.Well, Bill, I mean, if your standard is— if you're trying to judge the Iraqi parliament based upon our own Congress's ability to get bills done—is that what you're saying—I'd be a little careful. It took our Congress till the last minute to get things done. I mean, the legislative process is not all that smooth at times. And they've got a lot of work to do; don't get me wrong. I mean, I am not suggesting that we shouldn't, as a Government, continue to press them. What I am suggesting, though, there is a functioning Government. Your statement was, security didn't provide room for a government to stand up and function. Well, it's happening. And so therefore— and therefore, we will continue to press them on de-Ba'ath law, Provincial election laws, power sharing with the central Government and the Provinces, and oil law.But as I've reminded you from this podium, they are distributing oil revenues to the Provinces. There is revenue sharing, and there's local reconciliation taking place. And a lot of times, it's local politics that will drive national politics. Are we satisfied with the progress in Baghdad? No. But to say nothing is happening is just simply not the case.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, regarding your powerful speech on the Rwandan genocide, the perpetrators remain at large, especially in Congo. Given your call for results, what specific actions will the U.S. take to bring these individuals to justice? [SEP] Precisely.
label: Dodging

sentence: Sir, concerning the shooting near the White House, can you provide any details about the distance between the incident and the White House itself? [SEP] The relevant authorities will address those specifics shortly.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, following up on the prior question regarding Russia and Ukraine, are you implying that a small-scale Russian invasion wouldn't warrant the full force of the sanctions you've promised? Are you giving Putin the go-ahead for a limited incursion? [SEP] An interesting point.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: President Obama, given the apparent stagnation of the Trans-Pacific Partnership in Congress, are you considering a revised strategy to secure its approval, particularly in light of the Boeing and GE deals announced during your Vietnam visit? Should the agreement be amended to address currency manipulation? Furthermore, can you comment on the killing of Taliban leader Mullah Mansur and Pakistan's concerns about the strike on its soil? Does this signal a new offensive in Afghanistan, and are you concerned about a more hardline successor? [SEP] Well, on TPP, every trade deal is painful. Folks are always looking for a better deal, especially with multiple parties involved. And in an election year, some will try to score political points. But I'm confident we'll get it done because it's the right thing to do. It's good for America, the region, and the world. This is the fastest-growing part of the world, a huge market for the U.S. Most countries here already sell to us with low tariffs, while our goods face higher tariffs. This deal eliminates 18,000 taxes on U.S. goods. Also, TPP commits countries to higher labor standards and environmental regulations. I haven't seen a credible argument that TPP will make us worse off. American workers and businesses are better off if we pass this deal. The politics will be noisy, like with the Korean, Colombian, and Panamanian free trade agreements. But we got those done, and we'll get this done too. As for currency manipulation, we have provisions in TPP for transparency and reporting. Some want enforceable provisions, but it's hard to determine why a currency is going down and whether it's being manipulated. Binding other countries on monetary policy would mean binding our Federal Reserve, which we won't do. But we've strengthened provisions to address competitive devaluations. Finally, Mullah Mansur is dead. He targeted U.S. personnel in Afghanistan. This doesn't represent a shift in our approach. We're not re-entering combat operations. Our job is to help Afghanistan secure its own country. But when a high-profile leader targets U.S. personnel and resists peace talks, I have a responsibility to protect our people. That's the message we've sent. President Quang.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Mr. President, this week, you and the G-7 allies introduced a plan for an oil price cap for Russian exports in response to high gasoline prices. Do you believe this cap will lower prices for American drivers? And how long should American drivers expect to pay a premium because of this war? [SEP] Could you repeat the second part of the question? Was it about whether it would lower the price?
label: Clarification

sentence: With Mr. Hensarling suggesting changes to the sequester, will you commit to a veto? And can you clarify your 'hot mic' comments to President Sarkozy regarding Prime Minister Netanyahu? [SEP] The key is a balanced approach from the supercommittee. As for private conversations, I'm not going to comment on those.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: So, you're leaning towards a troop withdrawal? [SEP] Come again?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. I want to change the subject a bit. Earlier this year, on the flight to Selma, you said, on matters of race, as President, your job is to close the remaining gaps that are left in State and Federal government. Now, how does criminal justice reform fit into that equation? And what gaps remain for you—in the—towards the end of your Presidency? And also, what does it mean to travel to Kenya, your father's homeland, in the next couple of weeks as President to the United States? And lastly, would you revoke the Medal of Freedom from Bill Cosby? [SEP] You stuffed a lot in there, April. [] You know what?
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, concerning the North Korean situation, while we appreciate the optimism, many remain skeptical. What specific, verifiable benchmarks will be used to assess North Korea's progress towards denuclearization, and what are the consequences if they backslide? [SEP] Look, I'm not going to get into the weeds here. This is about trust. It's about relationships. And I have a very good relationship with Kim Jong-un. He wants to do the right thing. Can I guarantee it? No. But I have a very good feeling about this. And that's more than anyone else has been able to achieve.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. And, Mr. President, on the debt limit, you said already, I've done——  Q. Can you speak to your experience—— Q. I've done my part. Do you think that if there is a breach, nobody is going to blame you? [SEP] Of course, no one would blame me. I know you won't. You'll be saying, Biden did a wonderful job. [] I know you.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, the American people are tired of endless wars and failed interventions. What assurances can you give them that this coalition will be different, and that it will actually achieve its goals without further destabilizing the region? [SEP] We understand the concerns about getting bogged down in another conflict. That's why we are pursuing a comprehensive strategy that includes military action, diplomatic engagement, and humanitarian assistance. We are also working with local partners to empower them to take the lead in the fight against ISIS. We are confident that this approach will be more effective and sustainable than previous interventions.
label: General

sentence: You've mentioned both Gettysburg and the White House as potential locations. Is there a frontrunner in your mind? [SEP] They both have their unique appeal, don't they? Gettysburg represents our nation's history, a place of profound significance. The White House, of course, is the seat of power. It's a tough call. I'll be giving it more thought.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, the possibility of widespread quarantines raises serious concerns about civil liberties and economic disruption. Can you assure the American people that such measures would only be implemented as an absolute last resort, and that all other options would be exhausted first? [SEP] The health and safety of the American people are my top priority. We are taking all necessary steps to contain the virus and prevent its spread. We are working closely with state and local officials to implement the best possible strategies. Quarantines are a serious measure, and we would only consider them if they were absolutely necessary to protect public health. We are committed to transparency and will keep the American people informed every step of the way.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. Thanks so much, Mr. President. Did you—you say that you didn't issue any threats. Were there any ultimatums made when it comes to ransomware? And how will you measure success, especially when it comes to these working groups on Russian meddling and on cybersecurity? [SEP] Well, it's going to be real easy. They either—for example, on cybersecurity, are we going to work out where they take action against ransomware criminals on n territory? They didn't do it. I don't think they planned it, in this case. And they—are they going to act? We'll find out.Will we commit—what can we commit to act in terms of anything affecting violating international norms that negatively affects ? What are we going to agree to do? And so I think we have real opportunities to move.And I think that one of the things that I noticed when we had the larger meeting is that people who are very, very well-informed started thinking, You know, this could be a real problem. What happens if that ransomware outfit were sitting in Florida or Maine and took action, as I said, on their single lifeline to their economy: oil? That would be devastating. And they're, like—you could see them kind of go—not that we would do that—but like, Whoa.So it's in—it's in everybody's interest that these things be acted on. We'll see, though, what happens from these groups we put together.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, considering John Howard's focus on climate change at APEC, hasn't your separate meeting detracted from his goals? And what's your assessment of the Kyoto Protocol's relevance to tackling climate change? [SEP] Allow me to begin with the latter. Given my advancing years, you may need to reiterate the initial part of your question. Kyoto may be suitable for some nations, but it was not for the United States. The Senate voted overwhelmingly against it. We've adopted energy efficiency standards based on innovation. We reduced greenhouse gases while our economy expanded. We seek to lessen our reliance on foreign oil through the 20-in-10 initiative. New technologies are on the horizon, and Kyoto did not foster that. Many nations are not meeting Kyoto's targets. We rejected it to grow our economy, reduce oil dependence, and be environmentally responsible. I supported John's focus on climate change at APEC. I urged our G-8 partners to include nations like China and India. Otherwise, they may reject a solution imposed upon them. The Prime Minister's proposal to reduce tariffs on environmental technologies is wise. We must accelerate the deployment of effective technologies and assist developing nations in acquiring them. Our strategy is the most effective approach. I commend the Prime Minister's leadership on this issue.
label: Clarification

sentence: Sir, to clarify, is the executive order on birthright citizenship still on the table? [SEP] That's not something I'm prepared to discuss at this moment. Go ahead.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, would you mind naming those five Republican Senators? [SEP] You've got to be kidding me. I can't do that. It's a matter of trust.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: President Obama, with cap-and-trade now defunct, will you authorize the EPA to regulate carbon emissions, and in retrospect, do you have any regrets about the deals you made to secure passage of the Affordable Care Act, even if they compromised the bill's original intent? [SEP] Look, ensuring families have access to healthcare is crucial. But the legislative process was difficult, and I wish it had been smoother. Regarding the EPA, we need to find common ground on energy and climate. Cap-and-trade was just one approach. We're exploring all avenues to address this issue without harming our economy.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. May I follow that, sir? [SEP] I know, terrible principle. I'm sorry.
label: Dodging

sentence: The issue of federal busing has resurfaced, dividing opinions. Biden opposed it, Harris supported it. Mr. President, where do you fall on this spectrum? Is federally mandated busing a tool you would consider? [SEP] Look, that whole thing was a sideshow. Frankly, I think Biden got railroaded. But let me tell you, we're working on some big things, some real game-changers. We're going to have a policy announcement in a few weeks that will address these issues in a new and innovative way. So, I'm not going to get into the weeds on busing right now. Just wait and see.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, your administration has repeatedly asserted that the Iran framework agreement is essentially finalized, with only the implementation details subject to further discussion. Given this, how can you address concerns regarding the absence of military site inspections and the insistence on immediate sanctions relief? Additionally, concerning Cuba, did you and President Castro discuss the 45-day waiting period for removing Cuba from the state sponsor of terrorism list, and do you foresee any remaining obstacles to opening embassies once that removal is approved? [SEP] Okay, let me address Iran one more time. We have a political framework established between Iran and the P-5-plus-1. Some aspects, such as centrifuge reductions at Natanz, are highly specific. Others are expressions of intent, but the specifics are crucial. The interpretation of these details will be subject to negotiation. It's inaccurate to suggest that everything is finalized. We have a framework that, if implemented effectively, will achieve our goal of preventing Iran from acquiring a nuclear weapon. However, the details matter significantly, and there will be challenging negotiations. That's what I've maintained from the beginning. Regarding Cuba, we didn't delve into the level of detail you mentioned. The state sponsor of terrorism recommendation is forthcoming. Congress will have an opportunity to review it. The Embassy concerns are likely primarily on the Cuban side. They haven't had an American Embassy in quite some time. We're accustomed to this process, having reopened diplomatic relations with countries like China and Vietnam. We're prepared to move forward and foster improved dialogue, which will ultimately benefit the Cuban people. I extend my gratitude to the Latin American countries and the people of Panama. I'm optimistic about this region because of its people.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, given the upcoming corruption trial of Prime Minister Netanyahu, and your long-standing relationship, do you have any words of support or concern for him at this difficult time? [SEP] Bibi's a strong leader, a survivor. He's been a great friend to the United States, and I have no doubt he'll navigate these challenges. Israel is a vital ally, and our relationship remains rock solid.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, concerning North Korea, can you detail your conversations with President Xi regarding their influence over Pyongyang's nuclear ambitions? What specific repercussions would a North Korean nuclear test have on the Sino-American relationship? [SEP] Well, let's start with the basics. I can't definitively say China controls North Korea, point blank. I've communicated to President Xi Jinping that they have a responsibility to discourage North Korea from conducting these nuclear tests. I've also made it clear that if North Korea proceeds, we'll take defensive measures. These actions aren't directed at China, but to send a clear message to North Korea. We're committed to defending our allies, our territory, and our capabilities. I'm not certain if China has the power to prevent it, but I'm confident they don't want further escalation. I've emphasized that we'll do what's necessary to defend ourselves and our allies, like South Korea and Japan. This isn't about China, but about North Korea's actions. We're collaborating with China to find solutions, but it won't be a walk in the park. I don't believe there's cause for concern about a new Cold War. I want to be clear with everyone, especially Xi Jinping, that my words are my bond. Misunderstandings are the biggest risk. We had a lengthy meeting, and I believe we understand each other, which is crucial.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Under what conditions would these private talks take place? [SEP] I'm not going to get into the nitty-gritty of the negotiations. But I can tell you that we're serious about getting this resolved, and we won't let diplomatic niceties stand in our way. If Iran is serious about a resolution, they'll make it happen.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: President Obama, with all due respect, is August 2nd a hard deadline for a debt ceiling agreement, or is there some flexibility? What specific consequences will the country face if an agreement is not reached by that date? [SEP] Well, let's be clear, August 2nd is a very important date. And I want to be responsible here, I don't want to engage in scare tactics. But the fact is, if we don't reach an agreement by then, we risk serious damage to the economy. We could see interest rates rise, we could see the stock market fall, and we could see our credit rating downgraded. These are not things we want to happen. That's why it's so important that Congress act now. We know what the options are. We've identified areas where we can cut spending, we've identified loopholes in the tax code that we can close. The question is, are we willing to make the tough choices necessary to get this done? That's what leadership is all about.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, what specific actions should Israel take to address the threat from Gaza, and did you receive any firm commitments from the Prime Minister regarding the removal of illegal outposts? [SEP] Yes.
label: General

sentence: So, Mr. President, are you prepared to cut off federal funding to states that defy your administration's directives? [SEP] I'm not going to say that. I have faith in our governors. They'll see the wisdom in our approach. They rely on the federal government for support and guidance. And let's be honest, we've built up a tremendous capacity since I took office. My predecessors, with all due respect, didn't anticipate this. But the governors will respect the Presidency. It's a matter of leadership. We can debate the Constitution and federalism, but ultimately, it's about letting the states govern themselves and offering assistance when they need it. Yes, John.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. I want to follow up on your comments about NAFTA. The Democratic Presidential candidates, in fact, are talking about renegotiating that trade agreement if elected. I'm wondering if you're worried that their comments on the campaign trail are perhaps overshadowing your protrade agenda. In essence, do you worry that you're losing the free trade debate in the courts of public opinion?And to President Calderon and Prime Minister Harper, I'd like to get your thoughts about expanding your trade relationship with the United States. Is there a point at which you shift attention to the people running for the White House and their views and try to reach out to them? [SEP] Actually, my biggest concern on trade right now is with Colombia. NAFTA exists, and NAFTA—when you analyze it in an objective way, it benefits— beneficial to America. It also happens to be beneficial to Mexico and Canada, which makes it a, you know, a very good, comprehensive agreement.It's beneficial to us because when you're able to export to your neighborhood, it helps create jobs. Jobs are created when people find outlets for their goods and services. We have found a lot of outlets for our goods and services with our—in our neighborhood. It also helps consumers when you import. In other words, the more choices consumers have, the more options they have, the more—less likely it is there will be price increases, and it's better for your consumers. This agreement's been beneficial in creating wealth in our neighborhood. Our economies have all grown.I also happen to think it's very important for our citizens. I wish people could remember what the border looked like between Texas and Mexico before NAFTA. I mean, it was poor, really poor, on both sides of the border.
