If you go down there today, there's prosperity on both sides of the border, and that's in our Nation's interests.I mean, one way to increase pressure on the border is to—if you do it—away with NAFTA, there's going to be a lot of Mexicans—more Mexicans out of work. It will make it harder on the border. It will make it harder to deal with. So people who say, Let's get rid of NAFTA, because of a throwaway political line, must understand this has been good for America, and it's also been good for Mexico and Canada, and that's what you want in your neighborhood.Secondly, my biggest concern is to turn our back on our friends in Colombia. The Speaker of the House made a decision, using an extraordinary procedure, to prevent a vote on a trade bill that had been negotiated in good faith between our respective countries. You heard the—President Calderon say, it's in the region's interest to trade freely and fairly. Well, this agreement we have with Colombia right now is not fair for America, it's not fair for our businesses, it's not fair for our farmers. And all I'm asking the Congress is to make it fair.And if they—if the Speaker doesn't bring—give us a date certain on the bill, she's effectively killed it. It's her responsibility, and she's going to have to explain why the voices of false populism have been strengthened, why anti-Americanism could flourish, when America turns its back on a strong leader like President Uribe and a friend for democracy like President Uribe.I'm concerned about protectionism in America. It's not in our interests to become a protectionist nation. And so I'll continue to speak out on it and assure our friends that we will work hard to explain to the people the benefits of why free and fair trade is in our Nation's interest. First of all, what we have to do—all of us who have responsibilities vis-a-vis our citizens—is to objectively study the facts. What's happened with NAFTA in our three countries? Before NAFTA, there were many businesses, Mexican businesses, that were afraid, and they alleged that it was impossible to compete with the sophisticated and modern U.S. companies. And they weren't going to survive. There were also many U.S. companies who thought it was impossible to compete in more open markets. Now, what was the result? The result has been that trade has grown, and that has led to gains for everyone involved.Contrary to what they believe—that one was going to win, the other would lose— it was a win-win situation, and NAFTA has benefited the three countries. Trade has grown in all three, jobs have grown in all three, and even wage levels have gone up in all three. Today, the economies of Canada, Mexico, and the United States are bigger and stronger than they were 14 years ago. Income per capita for all three has also grown compared to 14 years ago. The benefits are visible, and all you need to do is to talk based on demonstrated results.To talk about taking a step backwards, in terms of free trade in the case of Mexico, would effectively provoke considerable damage on the economy. And another factor I was discussing yesterday with President Bush—that he reiterated today, and I will reiterate as well—would be a sudden loss of economic opportunities that would even lead to even greater migratory pressure in the—against—with the United States.We are doing everything we can in order to create job opportunities in Mexico for people so that Mexicans will not need to seek job opportunities outside their country. And the only way to do it is by creating jobs in Mexico, and the only way is, precisely, multiplying our possibilities of trade.In the case of the U.S. economy, if you were to take a step backwards with regard to NAFTA or free trade, you would be condemning Americans to have one of the least competitive economies in the developed world. While other parts of the world are accelerating their growth, their integration—China, Japan, India, Asia—in order to have more competitive economies and more complementary situations—and Europe is already becoming a single trade group, and they're adding more and more countries to that bloc every year—here you see protectionist voices arising. And the only thing they would achieve, if they were to prosper, would be to condemn North America as a region to complete backwardness in today's world. And that is the worst possible solution you can provide to your citizens.It is not my role to talk to the three candidates or precandidates to the Presidency. I'm very respectful of the domestic politics of this country. This is a decision that is solely in the hands of U.S. citizens. And for that reason, I must respect that process completely. It is not my role to talk to any candidates or precandidates. All I would do is speak to the person who will eventually be the President of the United States. And we will speak openly and sincerely about the future of both of our countries or, in this case, our three countries in the trilateral meetings that we hold.But Mexico will have a respectful relationship with the next President of the United States and will always seek the prosperity of our nations, knowing that through free trade, we have a clear, open, and respectful relationship among all our countries that will achieve prosperity.If we want to solve common problems, if we want to solve problems like security, problems like immigration, problems like economic growth in the United States and in Mexico, we need to understand that only to the extent that North America is more competitive as a region, only to that extent will we be able to successfully face our problems. We have been working with the current U.S. administration. We've had a very productive relationship with President Bush and his administration. And I trust that this will continue, that it will continue with any of the Presidential candidates here in the United States.Of course, it's the United States who needs to make a decision about this election. But I think that in the end, Canada really is confident that the next President will also understand the importance of NAFTA and the importance of the commercial relationship between the United States and Canada. And I must emphasize that for energy security, the commercial relationship between our two countries is even more important today than it was 20 years ago. And I think this relationship will be even more important in the future.[]——productive relationship with the current administration, and I anticipate that Canada will have a very productive relationship with the next administration, because I'm confident that when the facts are looked at, any President, just as any Prime Minister of Canada, will quickly conclude how critically important NAFTA and our North American/Canadian-American trade relations are to jobs and prosperity on both sides of our border and, in particular, the importance of energy security that is a particularly critical part of the NAFTA arrangement.Canada is the biggest and most stable supplier of energy to the United States in the world. That energy security is more important now than it was 20 years ago, when NAFTA was negotiated, and will be even more important in the future.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Mr. President, regarding Yemen, are you considering re-designating the Houthi rebels as a terrorist organization, as requested by the UAE? And what's your plan to finally end the war there? [SEP] Well, that's something we're looking at. Ending the war in Yemen requires cooperation from all parties involved, and that's proving to be a real challenge. We are working on it.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. But you don't think the spending cuts themselves will cause a recession? [SEP] I know they won't. I know they won't.Matter of fact, the fact that we were able to cut Government spending by $1.7 trillion, that didn't cause a recession; that caused growth. Look, we have the lowest unemployment rate in over 50 years. We've created 12-point—I think it's—7 million new jobs, including 800,000 manufacturing jobs. We have moved in a direction where we're rebuilding and reconstructing America through the infrastructure act.Look, here's the other thing. I'm sure—I'm not sure; my guess is, I'll get a question about, you know, Well, wait a minute, you know, the American people aren't satisfied. Well, guess what? As I've told you all before, most of this—what we've passed—doesn't kick in—it only kicks in over time. And so the fact is, for example, that if you're in a situation where you were—I'll give you the one example that I've used—everybody understands the easiest—is insulin.Well, I decided that we were going to be in a position where we were not going to continue to pay the highest drug prices in the world. And that's what we do, by the way. Same manufacturer of a drug in the United States, selling it here in Japan, selling it in Tokyo, or selling it in Berlin, or selling it around the world, they pay a lot less than we pay at home.So we said a simple proposition: Let's take a look at how much it costs to make the product. And I'm not going to ask you to—a show of hands like I do in a town meeting, but if—I usually ask, How many people know somebody who has type 1 or type 2 diabetes? And I'm almost—at least half the audience raises their hand.Well, they were paying somewhere between $4- and $700 a month for their insulin that they badly need to stay healthy and alive. Well, guess what? It costs $10—t-e-n—$10 to make. To package, total amount, you could argue maybe as much as $13.Well, guess what? Now they can't charge more for—Medicare can't, because Medicare is paying—taking American tax dollars and paying for the elderly's health care needs. You can't charge more than $35 for that drug. That saves $160 billion. Hear it? A hundred and sixty billion dollars less will be paid out by the Federal—by the American taxpayer to help the elderly people on Medicare with a problem.Well, a lot of this is just kicking in. We're in a situation where next year, for the drug costs, no senior will have to pay—total cost—total cost of all the drugs, from expensive cancer drugs to whatever drugs they're taking, will not have to pay more than $3,500 a year. The following year—we've already passed this. This is the law now. The following year, they won't have to pay more than $2,000. That saves another $200 billion that we're paying out.But the other team won't count this. Even though it's the law—we passed it—they won't count that as reducing the debt.So there's a lot of those kinds of disagreements we have. And my guess is that I'm going to be talking to the Speaker of the House on the way back on the plane, because it will be morning time over—at home. And I'm going to be in that plane in about an hour or so. And my guess is, he's going to want to deal directly with me in making sure we're all on the same page.But it's probably more than you wanted to know.How about Masaru, NHK [Masaru Takagi; NHK World].
label: Explicit

sentence: Sir, now that Netanyahu has publicly acknowledged the Israeli bombing raid in Syria, can you shed any light on the target? Did the U.S. have prior knowledge or offer support? And what are the potential ramifications for regional stability? [SEP] I'm simply not going to comment on covert operations. Let's move on.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Hypothetically speaking, Mr. President, if Pakistan's nuclear arsenal were at risk, would military intervention be on the table? [SEP] Our priority is a peaceful and stable region. We are confident in our ability to address any threats that may arise, but I won't engage in what-if games.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, following the midterms, could you provide some clarity on your current thinking regarding your Attorney General and Deputy Attorney General? Can they expect long-term job security? [SEP] I'd prefer to address that at another time. We're evaluating various aspects, including the Cabinet. I'm generally pleased with my Cabinet. We're considering different individuals for various roles. This is typical after the midterms. I didn't want to make any changes before the midterms. However, I must say that I'm largely very satisfied with my Cabinet. Mike Pompeo, for instance, has integrated seamlessly and has done an outstanding job as...
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, intelligence reports suggest a heightened risk of chemical weapons use. Can you confirm whether you have specific intelligence indicating President Putin is deploying or considering the use of such weapons? Furthermore, what specific actions would trigger a U.S. or NATO military response? [SEP] I can't get into the specifics of intelligence matters. That would be irresponsible. But let me be clear: the use of chemical weapons is a red line. We would respond decisively if he uses them. The nature of that response would depend on the specific circumstances, but it would be significant.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Given your frequent golfing excursions, why haven't you personally engaged with the affected individuals? [SEP] Affirmative.
label: Dodging

sentence: Regarding denuclearization, Mr. President, could you elaborate on the expected process, including treaties and talks? [SEP] It'll be a gradual process. We're not the only nation with nuclear weapons. It must be a simultaneous effort involving us and other countries. When this meeting was arranged, which we both desired, I didn't have high expectations, but exceptional outcomes are possible. Nuclear proliferation is a major global problem. I understand nuclear matters, thanks to my uncle, Dr. John Trump at MIT. If we can significantly reduce or ideally eliminate nuclear weapons, that would be a dream. It's something I'll discuss. It's also costly. We have political issues in the U.S. that complicate relations with Russia. But I want to get along with Russia, China, and other countries. I'll also bring up Syria and Ukraine.
label: General

sentence: Q. Regarding your emphasis on national sovereignty as the basis for global order, how do you square that with the principle of 'responsibility to protect' vulnerable populations, a concept previously central to international action? [SEP] Excuse me, could you repeat the latter part of your question? Specifically, how does sovereignty relate to what, exactly?
label: Clarification

sentence: Given your strong views on the Second Amendment, how do you reconcile granting commutations to individuals convicted of firearms offenses? [SEP] Each case is unique, and we consider many factors.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Mr. President, are you looking at closing further Chinese Embassies in the United States?And did you ask Ambassador Woody Johnson to bring the British Open to your Thurnberry—or Turnberry property in Scotland? [SEP] No, I never spoke to Woody Johnson about that, about Turnberry. Turnberry is a highly respected course, as you know, one of the best in the world. And I read a story about it today. And I had never—I never spoke to Woody Johnson about doing that. No.As far as closing additional Embassies, it's always possible. You see what's going on. We thought there was a fire in the one that we did close. And everybody said: There's a fire. There's a fire. And I guess they were burning documents or burning papers, and I wonder what that's all about.Okay, how about one or two more? Please.
label: Implicit

sentence: Is the election of two Muslim women to the House, one wearing a hijab, a rejection of your policies? [SEP] I'm sorry, I didn't catch that. Could you repeat the question?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. But are you giving people false hope? [SEP] This will go very—if we get sued. Maybe we won't get sued. If we get sued, it's somebody that doesn't want people to get money. Okay? And that's not going to be a very popular thing.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, and to you as well, Prime Minister, did you discuss Canada increasing its stimulus? And what will the Canada-U.S. relationship, the auto sector, the border, and carbon market look like in four years? [SEP] Wow, you managed to cram about ten questions into one. Were you consulting with someone?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, reflecting on five years of war, what lessons will inform your decisions for the remainder of your term? [SEP] Analyzing past failures is essential for future success. The sectarian violence in Baghdad has been a significant setback, resulting in substantial loss of life and displacement. Addressing this violence is a primary focus for our planners. There are two principal theaters in Iraq: Baghdad, characterized by sectarian violence, and the struggle against Sunni extremists. While progress is being made against the latter, Baghdad remains a challenge. The attack on the Samarra mosque exacerbated this sectarian violence. Success requires a combination of military, political, and reconstruction efforts. The moderate coalition represents a positive development. The oil law is vital for unifying the country. We are pursuing a parallel strategy, integrating military action with political and reconstruction processes. Prime Minister Maliki's efforts to reach out to former Saddam-era generals are encouraging. We are also collaborating with Provincial Reconstruction Teams to facilitate rebuilding and reconciliation. We are examining past shortcomings and adapting our strategy accordingly.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, by meeting with the leader of North Korea without preconditions, are you legitimizing a regime accused of human rights abuses? [SEP] We're talking. That's what matters. We're trying to make a deal. We're trying to denuclearize the Korean Peninsula. That's good for everyone.
label: Dodging

sentence: Considering the Iranian elections, what specific adjustments, if any, will you make to your strategy for engaging with Iran? [SEP] I've always acknowledged Iran's rich heritage, but their actions have been detrimental to regional and global stability. Their support for terrorist organizations, their aggressive stance towards Israel, and their nuclear program are deeply concerning. We need a multifaceted approach, including diplomacy. My national security team is reassessing our current policy, looking for areas where we can engage constructively. We expect to find openings for direct dialogue in the near future, allowing us to redirect our policy. Progress will be slow, given the history of mistrust. We will be explicit about our concerns regarding terrorism funding and nuclear proliferation. We aspire to a relationship built on mutual respect, as shown by my approach to the Middle East and my appointment of George Mitchell. Now, Iran must demonstrate a willingness to change its behavior and accept its responsibilities.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. To be clear, sir, you have no information regarding the perpetrator's gender or the weapon used in the attack? [SEP] That's correct. I have no knowledge of those details at this time.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the funding of your future Presidential library, figures as high as $200 million have been mentioned. Can you confirm this target amount? Furthermore, will you commit to full transparency by disclosing the identities of donors and any limitations on contributions? [SEP] Look, the budget's still being finalized. As for disclosure, the foundation chairman, a fine man, will address those requirements. Some folks prefer anonymity, you know? It's their right. And what was the last part of your multi-part question again?
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, with Rick Ledgett raising the possibility of amnesty for Edward Snowden, how do you feel about that? Under what circumstances might you consider a plea agreement or amnesty? And what do you say to those Americans who believe Snowden was right to expose government surveillance? [SEP] I have to be careful here, because Snowden is facing criminal charges, and that's a matter for the courts. I can't really weigh in on the specifics. But I've said before that we needed to have a conversation about surveillance. At the same time, the way Snowden released that information hurt our country and our intelligence capabilities. There was a better way to do it. The US, for all its faults, respects the law and values privacy. Because of what Snowden did, countries that actually spy on their own people are now criticizing us. So, while the debate was important, it also caused damage. I'll let the courts handle the Snowden case.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Given your previous remarks about 'fire and fury,' has your stance on the matter evolved since then? [SEP] Look, back then, a certain level of 'fire and fury' might have seemed necessary. We simply couldn't stand by and allow that kind of capability to develop, especially considering the potential impact on the United States and our allies like Japan, which is, as you know, right next door.
label: General

sentence: Q. You've been clear about saying that you will veto overspending by Congress when they come back next month to do appropriations bills. You've also been clear you don't want to raise taxes. Can you do justice to the kind of programs the Government needs for bridges, for housing, and also continue to spend as much as you do with the war in Iraq? [SEP] One can meet priorities if they set priorities. The problem in Congress is they have trouble actually focusing on priorities. Appropriators take their title seriously, and they all feel like they got to appropriate, which means there's a myriad of priorities. So the role of the President, it seems to me, is to help Congress focus on that which is important. We have a debate over that which is important, of course, but one thing that we shouldn't have a debate over is whether or not it's important to fund our troops in this war against radicals, extremists, the war on terror. And I think we'll be able to get that kind of cooperation. I would hope that they would get the defense bill to my desk as quickly as possible.Part of my concerns, of course, is that there are different sets of priorities in both bodies. And it seems like to me that the Congress needs to come together, solve their differences—solve their differences first, and then bring them to the White House and see if we can find accommodation. I have proven in the past, though, Ann, that one is able to set priorities— keep taxes low, grow the economy—and reduce the deficit. In other words, we have cut taxes, causing economic growth, which caused there to be this year alone 187 billion more tax dollars coming into the Treasury; the deficit is reduced to 1.5 percent of GDP, which on a 40-year historical average is very low, or is low, below the average; and we've proven that you can set priorities and meet obligations. And so the Congress needs to learn to do that itself.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the allegations against Postmaster General DeJoy – specifically, the claims he reimbursed former employees for GOP donations – if these allegations are substantiated, would you consider that behavior acceptable? [SEP] Well, I've only just become aware of these reports this morning. I haven't had the opportunity to fully investigate the matter. My understanding is that Mr. DeJoy enjoys bipartisan support, and I'll need more information before forming a definitive opinion. I'm sure the details will become clearer shortly.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. With respect to the G-7's oil price cap, can you assure Americans that it will alleviate their pain at the pump, and for how long must they endure these war-related costs? [SEP] Remind me, your second point concerned the impact on prices, correct?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the Roxham Road agreement, critics argue the delay in modernization allowed for continued irregular crossings. How do you respond to concerns that this delay exacerbated the situation and what specific assurances can you offer that the new measures will be more effective in managing the border? [SEP] Well, let me be clear. The situation at Roxham Road was complex, not something you could just snap your fingers and fix. Simply shutting it down would have been reckless, pushing people to more dangerous, uncontrolled areas. We needed a comprehensive solution, and that's what the modernized Safe Third Country Agreement provides. It ensures a consistent approach, directing asylum seekers to the appropriate channels. This wasn't a quick fix, it required careful negotiation and planning. But make no mistake, we are protecting the integrity of our system while upholding our obligations to those seeking asylum. And we are committed to increasing the number of asylum seekers from the Western Hemisphere to compensate for closing these irregular crossings.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, the American people deserve a clear answer. If this is so damaging, why the hesitation? Why not end it now? [SEP] I've made my position clear. Let's move on to another topic.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the Senate proceedings, would you prefer a swift resolution or a thorough examination of the facts? What are your thoughts on the exchange between White House Counsel Pat Cipollone and Jerrold Nadler? And are you categorically opposed to John Bolton's testimony? [SEP] That's quite a few questions you're throwing at me.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, could you provide a list of Chinese tech companies, in addition to Huawei, that are currently being reviewed for potential national security threats? [SEP] The primary concern is Huawei. They are not present in the United States, and I am preventing their entry. I have communicated this to various nations, including those in Europe. Australia has been particularly supportive. Huawei will not be operating here. We have informed certain countries considering utilizing Huawei that we will not be sharing intelligence with them. Consequently, they have all reconsidered their positions. Consider the United Kingdom; they initially appeared inclined to proceed with Huawei, but they have since reversed course – Scotland Yard.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, have you received any specific threats that you're aware of? [SEP] I'm not going to comment on specific threats. That's a matter for the authorities to handle. We're taking all necessary precautions to ensure my safety and the safety of my family.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, given the absence of a vaccine for young children, what is your administration doing to support families who are struggling to balance work and childcare, especially those with vulnerable family members? [SEP] We're providing resources and support through various programs, like the Child Tax Credit and childcare subsidies. We're also working with employers to encourage flexible work arrangements. We understand the challenges families are facing, and we're committed to helping them navigate this difficult time. We're all in this together.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Just to be clear, is the Brexit being pursued a 'hard' one? [SEP] Are you suggesting it's heartbreaking?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Mr. President, with respect to the discussions today, did you address the possibility of Canada increasing its economic stimulus? And also, for both of you, how do you see the relationship between our nations evolving in the coming years? What is your outlook on the auto sector, border controls, and carbon emissions policies? [SEP] Whoa there, you've managed to squeeze in a multitude of inquiries. Were you perhaps coordinating with someone beforehand? Is that--?
label: Clarification

sentence: So, you are willing to engage in direct talks with the Iranian government? [SEP] The core of the question is whether I envision direct engagement with Iranian counterparts, correct?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. And earlier today you tweeted that Democrats are moving slowly for political purposes. But why do you believe that their motive is politics rather than public safety? And how do you respond to criticism that you're also motivated by politics to try to grow the economy ahead of the election? [SEP] Well, I think that if you look at Pennsylvania, as an example; if you look at various other States—I won't get into them—the people want to go back. The numbers are getting to a point where they can, and there just seems to be no effort on certain blue States to get back into gear. And the people aren't going to stand for it; they want to get back.They're not going to stand for it. They want our country opened. I want our country opened too. I want it opened safely, but I want it open.Don't forget, people are dying the other route. You can go with the enclosed route: Everything is closed up, you're in your house, you're not allowed to move. People are dying with that too. You look at drug addiction, you look at suicides, you look at some of the things that are taking place, people are dying that way too. You could make the case, it's in even greater numbers.So it's a situation that some people—and I've noticed that some States could be moving more quickly. And also, at the same time, safety. Look, safety is paramount. But people are dying in the lockdown position too. And everybody understands that. They're just starting to find out. And look at what's going on with drugs, and look at what's happening with suicides.Yes, please. Please, go ahead.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, what military repercussions await North Korea if they renege on the commitments you've mentioned? Are we contemplating military action? [SEP] I'm hesitant to discuss that directly, because I don't want to appear threatening. They are aware of the potential consequences. Seoul, a city of 28 million people right on the border, is a stark reminder of what's at stake. The devastation could be catastrophic, potentially resulting in tens of millions of casualties. This is a critical undertaking, and the potential loss of life is staggering.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Mr. President—— Q. Thank you. Thank you. A couple of questions. One of them technical. The woman who passed away, did she travel to South Korea, or is she a case of community spread?Director Redfield. Oops. Yes, the case—again, this is why we're talking about the community cases with no link to travel. So the investigation at this time shows no evidence of link to travel or a known contact. Q. Okay. And also, you said that Americans as a whole are at a low risk. Are Americans on the West Coast of the United States at a low risk? And are you considering restricting travel within the United States?Director Redfield. So I just want to emphasize again that the Americans, independent of where they live in this Nation, are at low risk. All right? And we're going to continue to evaluate aggressively these unlinked cases as we see them. And as we learn, we'll obviously communicate that.Border Security/Mexico's Immigration Enforcement Cooperation With U.S./Coronavirus Containment Efforts  Q. Thank you so much, Mr. President. Why are you considering closing the border with Mexico, since there are so many more cases here than there? And another question: Are you working with the governments from Brazil and Mexico to try to coordinate a response about this? Or did you talk to President Bolsonaro? [SEP] Well, we have a great relationship, as you know, with Mexico. We have 27,000 soldiers—their soldiers—on our border doing a fantastic job. Our numbers are way down of people coming into our country illegally.We have ports of entry that we are keeping open. And we're not talking about it; we're thinking about all borders. We have to think about that border. But right now that is not a border as it pertains to what we're talking about here. This is not a border that seems to be much of a problem right now. We hope we won't have to do that.Yes, please go ahead.
label: Explicit

sentence: Sir, did you or your Chief of Staff direct an investigation into the Hadley memo leak before your meeting with Prime Minister al-Maliki? And if unauthorized, do you suspect someone in your administration is trying to undermine your Iraq policy or sabotage your meeting with Prime Minister al-Maliki? [SEP] Mark, let me see if I recall ordering such an investigation. I don't specifically recall doing so. I do remember expressing concern about the ongoing leaks. You all work diligently to uncover information and disseminate it to the public, which I understand. However, I disapprove of those who leak classified documents. It's a persistent issue, not just for this administration but for any administration attempting to implement policy that affects the country's future. We've experienced numerous leaks, some originating from—well, I'm unsure of their source, so I won't speculate. It's often difficult to identify the leaker. It's an advantage you have in your profession. We can lament it, but it's challenging to find those within the government willing to provide, in this case, Hadley's document to newspapers. There may be an ongoing investigation; I'm simply not aware of it. If there is, and I knew about it, it's not at the forefront of my mind. However, I believe it would be beneficial to identify individuals within our government who are leaking materials, which is clearly against the law, and hold them accountable. Perhaps the most effective way to deter leaks of classified documents is to ensure there are consequences for doing so. Jim, Los Angeles Times.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, concerning the allegations against Postmaster General DeJoy, if proven true, will you take action to remove him from his position? [SEP] I'm not familiar with the specifics. I just saw something about it this morning. He's a very respected man. I believe he was approved by both parties. I'll have to get more information.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Do you think you could have done more? [SEP] On which one?
label: Clarification

sentence: Concerning the situation in Asian countries, when can we expect an announcement regarding the lifting of restrictions, and what criteria are being used to evaluate their advancement? [SEP] As you're aware, some are progressing, while others aren't. But some are indeed making strides. Once they reach the appropriate threshold, we'll begin reopening. Certain countries are advancing rapidly. We're aiming to lift restrictions as soon as we can. Next question.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. You've spoken throughout the trip about the need for comprehensive immigration reform. It's been a big subject here in Guatemala City. Can you provide a little more detail, sir, if you would, about how you intend to overcome congressional opposition? There is opposition in both parties, specifically at the moment. A bill has been expected for some time now. You've been working with Senators, and your staff have been working with Senators. Is there a holdup? How are you tackling the problem at the moment, sir? [SEP] Yes. No, I appreciate that. He's referring to the process at this point in time, about why hadn't a consensus bill in the Senate began to emerge. And it's because this is a complicated issue that requires both parties learning to work together on this issue. I believe it is, first of all, incumbent to find, as best as possible, a coherent Republican position in the Senate. And that's where we're spending a lot of time right now. And then, as I understand it, Senator Kennedy will be carrying the bill on the Democrat side, and then once we can get a coherent Republican position, one that most Republicans are comfortable with, then we'll start working with the Senator.As you know full well that if we don't have enough consensus, nothing is going to move out of the Senate. And if nothing moves out of the Senate, nothing is going to happen in the House. And so therefore, the initial stages of getting a bill that meets objections is time consuming, but it is worth it and necessary in order for us to be able to address the concerns, many of which were expressed during the last debate on immigration reform.Now, I'm optimistic, I really am. I believe we can get something done, and I believe we're beginning to find consensus. I think there is pretty widespread consensus that there ought to be a temporary-worker plan that says, you can come legally to the United States to do a job Americans are not doing, for a period of time. That will help a lot of the Guatemalan citizens. It will mean somebody, first of all, doesn't have to sneak in the country in the first place and pay a or buy forged documents or sleep in some sleazy place hiding from authorities until you're able to make destination. You'll be able to come in, in a rational way.Secondly, that once you're in the United States, if you have to come home to be with your family, you'll be able to do so in a legal way; in other words, you'll be able to come back and forth without fear. Now, you won't be able to—there will be a time limit on the amount of time, and that's part of the negotiations.The hard issue, as the President noted and I just talked about, was what to do with the people who've been in our country for more than a limited period of time. And that's a difficult issue, and it's one that's got a lot of politics in the country. The idea of giving someone automatic citizenship is just not acceptable. It's not acceptable to a lot of people in our country, and, Massimo, you understand that. And yet the fundamental question is, how do you design a system that doesn't raise those fears? And yes, obviously, he didn't like my answer. Oh, you did like it? Well, good. []My dad had been ill, and he kindly brought greetings, for which I am grateful.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, many believe you strategically avoided addressing gun violence during your first term and in 2012, despite supporting the ban on semiautomatic rifles. Given the numerous instances of horrific gun violence during your presidency, where has your focus been? [SEP] Jake, let me assure you, I've been fully engaged as President, navigating the worst economic crisis since the Depression, rescuing the auto industry, and managing two ongoing wars. My days have been far from leisurely. We all must reassess our priorities in Washington. The safety of our children is paramount. It's a wake-up call that demands immediate action. I am committed to ensuring their safety. This involves many facets, including healthcare, education, and job opportunities for parents. These aren't secondary concerns. I'm confident that Vice President Biden will dedicate himself to this issue in the coming months. Thank you.
label: General

sentence: Q. Also, Mitch McConnell's office just put out a statement, a moment ago, about the phase four relief package, CARES II, saying, quote, it's tailored precisely for this phase of the crisis. Yet it does not include your payroll tax cut. So do you believe it's perfectly tailored? [SEP] Yes, I'd like to see a payroll tax cut. I think it's great for the workers. The Democrats would never have gone for it. They don't want it. They're not big into the workers, I guess. And based on that, I told them last night—I told the Republicans, who have been working very hard on this, I'll tell you—and they want what's right for the country—and hopefully, the Democrats ultimately will.But I said, I think a payroll tax will be good, but you're not going to get it from the Democrats. We need their votes, as you know. It's not like—you know, we have a majority, but it's not enough that we—that's why I guess we have an election coming up. So you still need Democrat votes, and we're not going to get the Democrat votes on that.So I'd like to see it. I think it would be very good for the workers. But if we're not going to get their votes, I guess we have to go on to the next thing. A payroll tax cut would have been very good. And maybe something happens.Yes, please.
label: Implicit

sentence: And Boris Johnson and Michael Gove – your assessment? [SEP] Boris? Terrific. A real winner. Jeremy, solid. I've heard good things. Michael... I don't know him. But I'm sure he's a fine person. Next question, please.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, your earlier remarks seemed to contradict your recent criticism of the Prime Minister's Brexit plan. Given the 'special relationship' between our countries, was publicly criticizing her policy and questioning her judgment the behavior of a true ally? [SEP] Well, let me clarify. I wasn't criticizing the Prime Minister. I have tremendous respect for her. There was a story that didn't fully capture my positive comments. Fortunately, we record these things now. It's called fake news, you know. The Prime Minister will make her own decisions. I only ask that we can continue to trade freely. We don't want any restrictions. We're their biggest trading partner, and we can grow that even more. So, if they go a different route, I hope we can still trade. I believe it's possible after speaking with her representatives. Trade is a bit tricky, but I think we'll manage. And she's doing a great job, by the way.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, your administration has stated that the Iran framework agreement is essentially set in stone, with only the implementation details open for negotiation. How do you reconcile this with concerns about the lack of military site inspections and the demand for immediate sanctions relief? Furthermore, concerning Cuba, did your discussions with President Castro address the 45-day waiting period for removing Cuba from the state sponsor of terrorism list, and do you anticipate any remaining obstacles to opening embassies once that removal is approved? [SEP] Alright, let me address Iran one more time. We have a political framework established between Iran and the P-5-plus-1. Some aspects, such as centrifuge reductions at Natanz, are highly specific. Others are expressions of intent, but the specifics are crucial. The interpretation of these details will be subject to negotiation. It's inaccurate to suggest that everything is finalized. We have a framework that, if implemented effectively, will achieve our goal of preventing Iran from acquiring a nuclear weapon. However, the details matter significantly, and there will be challenging negotiations. That's what I've maintained from the beginning. Regarding Cuba, we didn't delve into the level of detail you mentioned. The state sponsor of terrorism recommendation is forthcoming. Congress will have an opportunity to review it. The Embassy concerns are likely primarily on the Cuban side. They haven't had an American Embassy in quite some time. We're accustomed to this process, having reopened diplomatic relations with countries like China and Vietnam. We're prepared to move forward and foster improved dialogue, which will ultimately benefit the Cuban people. I extend my gratitude to the Latin American countries and the people of Panama. I'm optimistic about this region because of its people.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Mr. President, assuming this drug is proven safe and effective, would you support a fast-track approval process? [SEP] I can't comment on that at this stage. I simply don't have enough information or data to offer an informed opinion.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: President Bolsonaro, regarding the possibility of a U.S. military presence in Brazil to support the border with Venezuela, can you provide specific details about the nature of these discussions with President Trump? What specific roles would U.S. personnel play, and what safeguards would be in place to ensure Brazilian sovereignty? [SEP] Indeed, we have explored the potential for Brazil to become a key ally, perhaps even beyond NATO. The humanitarian aid sent via Boa Vista demonstrates our collaborative spirit. Our primary objective is to restore freedom and democracy to Venezuela, and we are prepared to collaborate in any way possible to achieve this noble goal. The suffering of the Venezuelan people is a grave concern, and we are committed to finding a resolution.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Deadline for Kosovo independence? [SEP] Decline?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. What do you intend to say, sir, to President Xi and to President Putin when you meet with them later this month? [SEP] Well, I have a good relationship with both. I know President Xi better. But I think I have a very good relationship with both. I actually had a very good meeting in Russia that you people didn't agree with, but that's okay. It doesn't much matter, obviously. Because here I am.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Sorry. And do you wish that President Prodi will pay a visit to you in Washington in the next months? [SEP] Yes, and yes.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, the election outcome suggests a significant shift in public sentiment. Were you caught off guard? And, if I may ask, do you see any similarities between Nancy Pelosi and Bob Bullock? [SEP] I'm not commenting on the Bob Bullock question. It's an inside joke. I'm an optimist. I knew we'd lose seats, but I didn't expect it to be this many.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, given Rick Ledgett's comments about Edward Snowden, what's your reaction to the idea of amnesty or a plea agreement for him? And what do you say to Americans who believe Snowden acted justly in exposing surveillance programs? [SEP] Well, Major, Snowden is under indictment, so I have to be careful. This is for the Attorney General and the courts. But I've said before that this conversation was important. However, the way it happened damaged U.S. intelligence capabilities. We abide by the rule of law. These disclosures have allowed countries that actually engage in surveillance to criticize us. It's done unnecessary damage. I'll leave it to the courts.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, you and the G-7 introduced an oil price cap for Russian exports to address high gas prices. Do you think this will actually lower prices for American drivers? And for how long should American drivers anticipate paying a premium because of this conflict? [SEP] I'm sorry, could you repeat the second part of the question? Was it regarding whether it would reduce the price?
label: Clarification

sentence: But Mr. President, isn't it true that increased domestic production would take years to impact gas prices, and wouldn't it exacerbate the climate crisis? Are you willing to sacrifice long-term environmental goals for short-term political gains? [SEP] We can walk and chew gum at the same time. We can increase domestic energy production while also investing in renewable energy sources. We need an all-of-the-above energy strategy that protects our environment and strengthens our economy. And we need to hold OPEC accountable for their actions.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Mr. President, are you willing to budge on any of the demands you've made to Congress regarding immigration, specifically in exchange for a DACA fix and amnesty for 1.7 million people? [SEP] DACA is a very important issue, and frankly, we were close to a resolution. But then a judge intervened, and that changed the dynamic. We'll see what happens at the Supreme Court. It's really up to them now.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, with respect, those are long-term goals. What are you doing in the immediate future to prevent a humanitarian crisis at the border and ensure the safety and well-being of these vulnerable families? [SEP] We are working to expand our capacity to process asylum claims, provide shelter and medical care, and reunite families. We are also working to deter illegal immigration by strengthening border security and cracking down on human smuggling. It's a complex challenge, but we are committed to addressing it in a humane and effective way.
label: General

sentence: Q. The Justice Department IG has found out, with the Carter Page foreign application. But we were actually warned in 2013 that the Surveillance Court was, allegedly, a rubber stamp. It was approving surveillance.And I was wondering: I don't think, as President, you've commented on Edward Snowden, but do you think he should be allowed to return without going to prison? [SEP] So as far FISA abuse is concerned, there was tremendous FISA abuse. It's amazing that it's taken this long. And everyone knows that it's been proven very substantially. Not only FISA abuse, changing documents and putting documents in front of the FISA Court and courts that are disgraceful that they could have done it.And the fact is we caught Joe Biden, President Obama, the whole group. You can look at Brennan and Comey and Clapper, the whole group. We caught them spying on our campaign. This was an illegal act like no other illegal act. This was treason. This was at the highest level of treason. And Obama and Biden got caught spying on my campaign, using intelligence agencies of the United States Government to do it, both before and after the election. So before the election and then after I won, they continued. It's totally illegal activity, and now we just have to see what's happening.But as far as Kamala is concerned, she's a big tax raiser, she's a big slasher of funds for our military, and she's got a lot of difficult things that she's going to have to explain. Plus, she was very, very nasty to—one of the reasons it surprised me, she was very—she was probably nastier than even Pocahontas to Joe Biden. She was very disrespectful to Joe Biden. And it's hard to pick somebody that's that disrespectful. When she said things during the debates—during the Democrat primary debates—that were horrible about Sleepy Joe. And I would think that he wouldn't have picked.OAN, please. Please. Thank you very much.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, your perspective on Brexit? Should Britain depart the EU without an agreement by October 31st? And Prime Minister, what are the potential consequences for the U.K. in the absence of a deal? [SEP] Well, I don't like to get involved in things that I don't, you know, really—I understand the issue very well. I foresaw this, you know. Some of you may recall that prediction. It was a strong prediction, made at a certain location, when we were opening a development the day before it happened. And I thought it was going to happen because of immigration mostly, but there are probably a lot of reasons. But I would say, yes, I think it will happen and it probably should happen. This is a great country, and it wants to be its own boss. It wants to control its own borders. It wants to run its own affairs. This is a very, very special place. And I think it deserves a special place. And I thought maybe for that reason—and for others—but that reason, it was going to happen.Yes, I think it will happen, and I believe the Prime Minister has brought it to a good point where something will take place soon. I think she's done a very good job. I believe it would be good for the country, yes. And from my point of view, I believe it is important for us to deliver Brexit. We gave that choice to the British people. Parliament overwhelmingly gave the choice to the British people. We should now deliver on that choice. I continue to believe that, actually, it's in the best interests of the U.K. to leave the European Union in an orderly way with a deal. I think we have a good deal. Sadly, the Labour Party and other MPs have, so far, stopped us from delivering Brexit and that deal.But we will—but obviously, this is an issue that is going to continue here in the U.K. I think the important thing is we deliver Brexit. And once we're out of the European Union, we will be able to do what we've been talking about today and develop not just that free trade agreement, but a broader economic partnership into the future.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Mr. President, on Iraq, you've talked repeatedly about the threat of Al Qaida in Iraq. And we've also heard a lot about the military progress that's been made against that group. Can you tell Americans how close the United States is to declaring victory against that group? And if you're not able to do so, does that suggest that your critics are correct that this war cannot be won militarily? [SEP] The Iraq situation cannot be won by military means alone. There has to be political reconciliation to go with it. There has to be a emergence of a democracy. That's been my position ever since it started.Al Qaida is still dangerous. They're dangerous in Iraq; they're dangerous elsewhere. Al Qaida is not going to go away anytime soon. That's why it's important for us to be finding out what their intentions are and what are their plans, so we can respond to them. This is a—this war against Al Qaida requires actionable intelligence. That's why this FISA bill is important. And they still want to do us harm, Elaine, and they're still active. Yes, we've hurt them bad in Iraq, and we've hurt them bad elsewhere. If you're the number-three person in Al Qaida, you've had some rough goes— you've been captured or killed. And we're keeping the pressure on them all the time.And so yes, we're making progress. But, no, I fully understand those who say you can't win this thing militarily.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Mr. President, was this a threat toward you, sir? [SEP] We don't know yet. We don't know. They're going to find that out.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, what's your take on the anti-LGBTQ laws and violence, and those families thinking of leaving? Prime Minister Sunak, what's the U.S. and U.K. doing on AI disinformation and election security? How's AI regulation different from climate change? [SEP] Gimme that family's number; I'll call 'em. We scrapped the transgender military ban, signed the Respect for Marriage Act, boosted LGBT rights. But we're battling hysteria and prejudice. Firing someone for being gay? Wrong. Violence? Rising. These bills against transgender kids? Cruel. They're our kids. We're launching new protections: safety, rights, mental health. Congress needs the Equality Act. LGBTQ Americans, we got your back. AI's good but risky. Need guardrails, like Sunak and I talked about. Working with other countries, learning from climate change. Gotta move fast.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Four years ago, you stated that the Taliban posed no threat to the Afghan people. Who do you believe has supported the Taliban in threatening security through kidnappings and attacks on government officials, and why? [SEP] Four years ago, I did say that, and I stand by it. The Taliban pose dangers to our innocent people, to children going to school, to our clergy, to our teachers, to our engineers, to international aid workers. They are not posing any threat to the Government of Afghanistan, to the institutions of Afghanistan, or to the buildup of institutions of Afghanistan. It's a force that's defeated, frustrated, and acting in cowardice by killing children going to school. The question of who is supporting them is one we've been working on for a long time. I hope the jirga between us and Pakistan will provide solutions. One thing is certain: we know their vision of how to govern. They've been in power and had the opportunity to show the world what they think and do. It would be instructive to speak to a mother of a young girl about life under the Taliban. These are brutal, cold-blooded killers. That's what they are. The fundamental question for those of us who believe in freedom is whether we confront them and whether it's worth the effort to spread an alternative to their hateful vision. We've concluded that it is. That's why President Karzai is here at Camp David, discussing common concerns and opportunities about how to defeat a vision of darkness. They don't believe in freedom. They don't believe it's possible to live in a society where people are allowed to express themselves freely. It's part of an ongoing challenge that the free world faces. The real question is whether those of us who have the blessings of liberty will continue to pursue policies aimed at protecting our homeland and laying a condition for peace to prevail.
label: General

sentence: Sir, regarding the COVID response, many are saying the buck stops with you. What specific actions did you personally take to ensure the nation was prepared for this pandemic? [SEP] Well, I took very decisive action. I closed the border, something nobody else would have done. And we developed vaccines in record time. Nobody thought that was possible. We saved millions of lives, frankly. The fake news media doesn't want to talk about that, but we did a tremendous job.
label: Dodging

sentence: Sir, but specific statements you've made have been interpreted as sympathetic to white nationalist viewpoints. Can you address those specific instances? [SEP] I'm focused on uniting the country, not dividing it. The media is twisting my words to create division. My record speaks for itself – I've consistently denounced racism and hate.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, what are your thoughts on Medvedev's role in Russia, and what advice would you offer your successor regarding the challenges posed by Russia? [SEP] I'm not entirely sure about Medvedev's position. Observing their representation at the G-8 will be informative. However, it is crucial to maintain relations with Russia. We need their cooperation on preventing the spread of dangerous materials and addressing the situation with Iran. I remember Putin's proposal to supply enriched uranium to Iran's Bushehr plant, which I found helpful. Regarding missile defense in Europe, we must strive for mutual understanding. I hope my successor can build a working relationship with Russia, even amidst disagreements. It is in our country's best interest.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, regarding Prime Minister Maliki's recent visit to Iran and the reports suggesting he expressed appreciation for Iran's 'positive and constructive stance,' do you share the same perspective as your Iraqi counterparts on Iran? Furthermore, what message do these warm images send to our allies and Americans who are concerned about Prime Minister Maliki's role? [SEP] Well, I haven't had a chance to thoroughly review those specific reports or images yet. I'd prefer to get a detailed briefing from our embassy staff, who will undoubtedly be in contact with the Prime Minister, before offering a definitive assessment. It would be irresponsible of me to speculate without having all the facts. Generally speaking, diplomatic interactions often involve a degree of cordiality, so I wouldn't necessarily read too much into a friendly photo.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. President Trump, what specific steps are you taking to reverse the annexation of Crimea? [SEP] Look, it's a process, okay? If I knew the answer, I wouldn't tell you, because that would give us away. But we're working on it. Crimea was a bad hand that I was dealt, just like North Korea. But we're doing great with North Korea. No nuclear testing, no missile launches, no rocket launches. We got our hostages back. A lot of good things are happening. So, we'll see what happens with Crimea. It's a longer process than anyone would like, but I'm used to long processes.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: But Mr. President, without a formal signature, isn't there a risk that future administrations could simply disregard this agreement? [SEP] We believe that the importance of this agreement is so clear and the benefits are so significant that any future administration would be foolish to abandon it. We're confident that this agreement will stand the test of time.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Are you going to be? [SEP] Most likely, yes. Most likely.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, can you elaborate on the nature of your relationship with Mr. McCarthy, specifically addressing the frequency of your interactions and your overall assessment of his leadership? [SEP] I think he's the Republican leader, and I haven't had much of occasion to talk to him. But I will be talking to him. I think I'm talking to him later today.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Mr. President, regarding your recent remarks about President Xi and the broader issues of human rights in India, could you please reiterate the second part of my question concerning the treatment of religious minorities in India? [SEP] The short answer to the first part is no. Look, when we engage with allies like India, I'm not about to censor myself or sugarcoat the facts regarding our relationship with China. The hysteria surrounding China is overblown. We had a minor hiccup, but Secretary Blinken's trip was productive, and I anticipate meeting with President Xi soon. Now, remind me of the second part of your question?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Is there any definitive information available yet regarding that detail? [SEP] That remains to be seen.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: President Lee, considering the existing sanctions on North Korea, how do you envision this pipeline project moving forward without providing them with substantial financial benefits? [SEP] Thank you. I'm not sure if I should be answering this question here, but I will try. We've been discussing importing Russian gas into South Korea for some time. We're now discussing with North Korea the possibility of Russian gas, which is quite affordable, passing through North Korea for use in South Korea. This is beneficial for Russia because they can sell their natural resources, for North Korea because they could use this natural resource, and also for South Korea. However, South Korea, North Korea, and Russia haven't yet discussed this in detail. While economically beneficial, this issue also involves security matters, which we will consider closely. Also, this project will not be implemented soon. We are mindful of progress on the North Korean nuclear issue as well.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Hi, Mr. President. So Americans have been self-quarantining for several months now, social distancing, yet we're still seeing about 20,000 new cases a day, 1- to 2,000 deaths. Is there anything else the administration is planning to do to get these new cases under control? Because we seem to be on a plateau. Or is this just a fact of life? [SEP] Well, excuse me. There are 20,000—the numbers are way down from what they were two weeks ago. I mean, the numbers are really coming down, and very substantially. And this weekend was one of the lowest we've had. This is—you know, the numbers are coming down very rapidly all throughout the country, by the way. There may be one exception. But all throughout the country, the numbers are coming down rapidly. I think you see that, Admiral.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, with respect to Senator Obama's comments on Iraq, do you believe they reflect a lack of awareness or insight? [SEP] Senator Obama should concentrate on his primary against Senator Clinton. Neither of them has secured their party's nomination. My party's nomination hasn't been decided either. There will be plenty of time to discuss the positions of whoever their candidate is. Nice try, Sheryl. Another question?
label: Dodging

sentence: Given your previous statements, were you aware that your former advisor was planning to leave their position, regardless of the timing of the announcement? [SEP] To be perfectly clear, I had no prior knowledge of their departure at that specific moment in time.
label: Implicit

sentence: Sir, will the United States formally acknowledge that? [SEP] I would encourage you to examine the Ahtisaari plan. The primary obstacle to deploying additional peacekeepers to Darfur has been the absence of a status of forces agreement between the UN and the Sudanese government. Now that this agreement has been finalized, the path forward is clear. We are actively soliciting more volunteers as required. We have pledged to contribute one battalion and remain prepared to offer a second if necessary.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, given Mayor Bloomberg's endorsement based on your climate change commitment, particularly post-Hurricane Sandy, what specific climate change policies will you champion in a second term? And do you believe there's enough political will in Washington to pass a carbon tax? [SEP] Mark, we can't say for sure that any one storm is because of climate change. But the world is getting hotter faster than we thought, and the ice in the Arctic is melting really fast too. We're seeing more and more crazy weather. I really believe that climate change is happening and that we're making it worse. We owe it to our kids and grandkids to do something about it. We doubled how good cars are on gas and made more clean energy, which helps. But we need to do more. I'm going to talk to scientists, engineers, and politicians to figure out how to cut carbon now and have a big talk with the country about what we can do for the long haul. I don't know what the Democrats or Republicans will do, since people in different places see things differently. It's going to take some tough choices to deal with climate change. People are worried about jobs and the economy, so we can't forget about those. If we can create jobs, grow the economy, and fight climate change at the same time, people will be behind it. I'll have more to say about this soon.
label: General

sentence: So, are you considering relocating the convention to Charlotte? [SEP] We're exploring all our options, folks. Stay tuned for an announcement soon.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, the intelligence community claims Russia is interfering to damage Biden, and China is considering interfering to damage you. Do you concur with this assessment, and what measures will be taken? [SEP] Could be. I mean, it's possible – very much so. I think the last person Russia wants in office is Donald Trump, because nobody has been tougher on Russia than I have, ever.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, the evidence surrounding the Khashoggi murder seems to point towards Saudi involvement. Why the hesitation to directly condemn the Crown Prince, and what message does that send to authoritarian regimes worldwide? [SEP] Look, we're taking this very seriously. We're getting all the facts. We're working with Congress, we're working with Turkey, we're working with Saudi Arabia. We want to get to the bottom of it. It's a terrible thing that happened.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. Yesterday DHS came to an agreement with the Governor of Oregon to remove Federal officers, and Oregon State troopers took over. Mayor Ted Wheeler was noticeably absent from that agreement. Are you confident, sir, that the State of Oregon will be able to quell the protests in Portland? And if the violence does continue, would you consider redeploying Federal troops? [SEP] So our people have done—Homeland Security have done a fantastic job. They went to Oregon a little more than a week ago. The place was a mess. The city, Portland, was just a disaster. You see it, and a lot of people weren't reporting it right. They tried to pretend it was a protest, as opposed to anarchists and agitators. You understand what I'm saying. It's a mess.They went there a short while ago, and they saved a Federal courthouse that costs hundreds of millions of dollars. And they put a ring around the courthouse, and they saved it. But the group that's there is basically meant to save buildings, and they were very strong, very powerful. And they didn't come out too often out of this cocoon that they built in order to save these very expensive, valuable, and psychologically important buildings—right?—like courthouses.The Governor and the mayor, we've been dealing with them, and we think they don't know what they're doing, because this should not have been going on for 60 days. It's not our job unless, in case of emergency—which I consider now to be an emergency—it's not our job to go in and clean out the cities. That's supposed to be done by local law enforcement.Yesterday the Governor worked a deal where they'll do it; we'll stand by, they'll do it—and that's good. That was very good, but she didn't report it that way. What she reported was totally different. She said, I think Trump wants to take over the country. It's crazy.So what happened is, our people are staying there to see whether or not they can do it today and tomorrow. And if they don't do it, we will send in the National Guard and we'll take care of it. And we're telling, right now, these protesters—and many should be arrested, because these are professional agitators, these are professional anarchists; these are people that hate our country. We're telling them, right now, that we're coming in very soon, the National Guard. A lot of people. A lot of very tough people. And these are not people that just have to guard the courthouse and save it. These are people that are allowed to go forward and do what they have to do. And I think that makes the Governor's job and the mayor's job a lot easier. So they're working today and probably tomorrow to clean out this beehive of terrorists. And if they do it, I'm going to be very happy. And then, slowly, we can start to leave the city. If they don't do it, we'll be sending in the National Guard.Please.
label: Explicit

sentence: Sir, considering the Speaker's current political predicament, do you have full faith in his capacity to marshal the necessary votes within his caucus to enact any agreed-upon legislation? [SEP] That's a matter for the Speaker to address, not myself. My dealings with John Boehner have been constructive. I believe he is a man of good character who genuinely desires to serve the country. However, the political dynamics that elevated him to the Speakership are now presenting challenges to effective governance. It is imperative that the Republican caucus recognizes that American democracy functions optimally when individuals engage in respectful dialogue, extend the benefit of the doubt, and embrace compromise to resolve complex issues.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Sir, to be precise, do you believe the U.S. made the right call in 1945 regarding Hiroshima and Nagasaki? [SEP] Now, you presented a few questions, didn't you? Could you remind me of the first one?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Yes, but as President of the United States, are you concerned about the access that people are having to voting? [SEP] I heard it was very efficient in Georgia. I heard it was very efficient. But again, you'd have to ask the State governments, because—just one of those things you're going to have to ask them.Yes, go ahead. Please. Please, go ahead.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, is his job on the line? [SEP] I consider firing everybody. It's just a matter of time. Jennifer, you're working so hard.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, if releasing five Iranians held in Iraq could secure the release of the British sailors, would the U.S. consider it? [SEP] I've stated that the seizure of the sailors by the Iranians is indefensible. I support the Blair Government's efforts to resolve this peacefully. We're consulting closely with the British Government. I also support the Prime Minister's stance that there should be no quid pro quos in this situation.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. So, just to be absolutely clear, are you referring to one specific aspect or multiple facets of this issue? [Laughter] [SEP] Why not consider both? Now, what's your point?
label: Clarification

sentence: President, can you confirm whether you and President Bolsonaro discussed the establishment of a U.S. military base in Brazil to support efforts related to Venezuela? [SEP] We covered a range of topics, including Brazil's potential enhanced alliance status and our shared commitment to resolving the Venezuelan crisis. We are exploring all possible avenues to provide humanitarian assistance and support a return to democracy in that country.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Would you consider an Executive order on this? Is that appropriate? [SEP] Well, I have the right to do it. We haven't gotten there yet, but we'll see what happens. We will be suing in Nevada, and that's already been taken care of. We'll probably file something tomorrow.I do want to say that we're going to be introducing a tremendous health care plan sometime prior—hopefully, prior to the end of the month. It's just completed now.In addition, next month, we'll be doing the immigration plan. So we'll be doing that in September. We'll be doing, sometime during this month, the health care plan. And I think that will be before the end of the month. And I think it will be very impressive to a lot of people.Thank you very much. Thank you.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Mr. President, with all due respect, why should Americans care about this global competition when they are facing daily losses and rising case numbers here at home? [SEP] The losses are, sadly, a global phenomenon. Perhaps the more pertinent inquiry should be directed towards China. I suggest you pose that question to them. You might find their response... illuminating. Yes, next question, please.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Sir, with the benefit of hindsight, do you believe the initial goals and expectations for political progress in Iraq were realistic, given the complex sectarian divisions and historical grievances? [SEP] Looking back, it's clear that the challenges in Iraq were even greater than we initially anticipated. The legacy of decades of authoritarian rule, coupled with deep-seated sectarian tensions, created a very difficult environment for political reconciliation. However, we remain committed to supporting the Iraqi people as they work to build a more stable and democratic society. We've learned valuable lessons from our experience in Iraq, and we're applying those lessons to our approach in other parts of the world.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Sure.Pandemic Adviser Atlas. ——in sometime no later than January. I mean, of course, it depends on when things are approved and the emergency use is given. Q. But what about—I'm talking though about the low-priority people.Pandemic Adviser Atlas. I understand. Yes. I can finish. Q. Yes.Pandemic Adviser Atlas. And then, it is anticipated there will be 700 million doses by end of Q1. That's 700 million doses. Q. So by the end of March?Pandemic Adviser Atlas. That's end of Q1. Q. Dr. Atlas, do you mind if I ask you a question? [SEP] 1, he said.

sentence: Can you confirm whether the Syrian situation was addressed during the talks? [SEP] The talks covered a range of geopolitical issues.

sentence: Q. Mr. President, in light of its increasing prominence, what's your perspective on the QAnon movement and its potential impact? [SEP] To be honest, I haven't delved into the specifics of that particular group. My priority is addressing the challenges facing the American people, and that's where my attention is focused.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Sometime next year? [SEP] Sometime early next year. Yes.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. And what was the response? [SEP] I asked him what was happening and he was telling me that—I think he said 13 but could be more—and I think he said more in the works—that there are large numbers of people being prosecuted. He's very angry about it. He's very unhappy about it.And I did mention it to him very strongly and he answered very strongly. But they're prosecuting large numbers of people. That was a bad event.Okay.

sentence: Mr. President, with respect to Mayor Bowser's order in DC, even though it doesn't apply to Federal properties, would you suggest that Federal properties, like the White House, and military bases, should follow the order? What do you think? [SEP] We're mulling over the decision in the coming 24 hours. We'll make sure to inform you all of the decision. Okay?
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Regarding the commutations you've granted, a significant portion involved firearms offenses. How does this align with your stance on gun control? [SEP] Well, each case is unique, right? We look at the individual circumstances, the severity of the crime, and the potential for rehabilitation. It's a complex issue, and we try to be fair.

sentence: But if Russia is talking with the U.S.A. or Guaidó, what can you tell—about us? [SEP] Don't worry about it. Everything's under control. We're fully aware of the situation and very involved. Okay? Thank you.

sentence: Sir, many interpret your words as giving Putin a green light for limited aggression. Can you reassure our allies and the Ukrainian people that the U.S. stands firmly against any Russian incursion, no matter how small? [SEP] We are committed to Ukraine's sovereignty.

sentence: Q. Mr. President, what is your opinion on the rise of the QAnon movement and its increasing popularity? [SEP] To be honest, I'm not familiar with the specifics. I've heard they're very supportive, and I appreciate that. I imagine they're just patriots who want to see America be great again. It's all about making America great again.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. [Inaudible]—if 160,000 people had died on President Obama's watch, do you think you would have called for his resignation? [SEP] No, I wouldn't have done that. I think it's been amazing what we've been able to do. If we didn't close up our country, we would have had 1½ or 2 million people already dead. We've called it right; now we don't have to close it. We understand the disease.Nobody understood it because nobody has ever seen anything like this. The closest thing is, in 1917, they say, right? The great pandemic certainly was a terrible thing, where they lost, anywhere from 50 to 100 million people. Probably ended the Second World War; all the soldiers were sick. That was a terrible situation. And this is highly contagious. This one is highly, highly contagious.No, if I would have listened to a lot of people, we would have kept it open. And by the way, we keep it open now, all the way. We keep it open. But we would have kept it open, and you could be up to a million and a half or 2 million people right now—1½ to 2 million people.Our people have done a fantastic job, our consultants and our doctors. You know, and with disagreements and with a lot of things happening. What we've done with ventilators has been amazing. What we've done with medical equipment has been incredible. We've supplied the Governors. Nobody, not one person in this country that needed a ventilator didn't get it. And you know, at the beginning, there was a big shortage of ventilators. Nobody had stockpiles or anything comparable to what you had to have.So we would have lost—if you think about it, you had mentioned 160,000 people. Multiply that times 10 right now. I think it would have been unsustainable and unacceptable. But that's what would have happened had we kept it open.So no, I think we're a very large country. We are—one person—and I say it all the time; a lot of people like to leave that out—one person is too many. It should have never happened. But they've done a—really, an extraordinary job. They'll never be given the credit—and I'm not talking about me.
