And China has also acknowledged that it needs to transition to a more balanced growth strategy internally, where they're focusing on their enormous domestic market and giving their people the opportunity to buy goods and services and consume, all of which will promote their growth, but also will reduce some of the imbalances around the world.And so what this communique, I think, communicates, not just to China, but to all of us, is letting currencies reflect market fundamentals, allowing your currency to move up and down, depending on the role that you're playing in the international trading system, is the best way to assure that everybody benefits from trade rather than just some. And the communique strongly communicates that principle.My expectation is that China is going to make progress on this issue. President Hu is going to be visiting me in Washington in January, and our hope and expectation is, is that we will continue to see progress on this front.It means some adjustments for China. And so we're--we understand that this is not solved overnight. But it needs to be dealt with, and I'm confident that it can be.Sheryl Stolberg.Oh, I think that what we will naturally see is a whole bunch of talented people rise to the top as they promote good ideas that attract the American people when it comes to jobs and investment and how to grow the economy and how to deal with our challenges. I think Speaker Pelosi has been an outstanding partner for me. I think Harry Reid has been a terrific partner in moving some very difficult legislation forward. And I'm looking forward to working with the entire leadership team to continue to make progress on the issues that are important to the American people.Sheryl [Sheryl Gay Stolberg, New York Times].
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, can we expect a third summit? [SEP] Essentially, their condition was the complete removal of sanctions, which was untenable for us. They expressed willingness to dismantle a significant portion of their nuclear facilities, as we desired, but we couldn't concede on all sanctions in exchange. We remain engaged in ongoing discussions, and we'll observe how things unfold. However, we were compelled to reject that specific proposition.
label: General

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. On Russia, are you planning to go to Moscow next spring, as President Putin invited you? [SEP] Yes.
label: Explicit

sentence: Given the evolving situation in Libya, what specific benchmarks must be met before the U.S. transfers command, and why is NATO the preferred partner for this transition? [SEP] Well, the situation remains fluid, as you know. The timing of any transfer hinges on the assessment of our field commanders regarding the completion of the initial phase, specifically neutralizing Libyan air defenses. This is paramount to ensure the no-fly zone's effectiveness and the safety of coalition aircraft. Humanitarian considerations are also key. While I anticipate this occurring within days, not weeks, the specifics are best left to the Pentagon. NATO's coordinating role is invaluable due to its capabilities. As for this partnership, let's just say it's a two-way street. Chile has much to offer, particularly in clean energy. We're exploring collaborations in education and security, addressing issues like narcotrafficking. This isn't about a developed nation aiding a less developed one; it's a collaboration among equals. Regarding Latin American integration, we lag behind Europe. While the idea of a free trade area from Alaska to Tierra del Fuego was once floated, it never materialized. Latin America needs to fulfill its potential, drawing on shared values and principles with the U.S. We seek a partnership that encompasses democracy, free trade, education, and innovation. We must also address energy and water challenges, as well as transnational threats. The time is ripe for a new international order, one that adapts to the needs of the 21st century. Latin America cannot afford to be late to the knowledge and information revolution.
label: General

sentence: Given your focus on strengthening the U.S.-Japan alliance and promoting a free and open Indo-Pacific, how do you reconcile this with your upcoming visit to China, a nation with a fundamentally different ideology? Won't this inevitably lead to conflict? [SEP] Look, the Prime Minister is doing a fantastic job modernizing Japan's defenses. They're buying a tremendous amount of our equipment, the best in the world, frankly. As for China, President Xi and I have a good relationship, a very good one. We're friends. But the trade imbalance is a disaster. For decades, we've been taken advantage of. We're talking hundreds of billions of dollars. We need fair trade, reciprocal trade. We're going to level the playing field, and you'll see a big difference very soon. We're already putting the legal foundation in place.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Where does the people's right to know this fit into all of that? [SEP] You know, I don't—we're weighing, taking a look, taking consideration, giving it serious consideration. Nice try, though.Olivier [Olivier Knox, Agence France-Presse].
label: Dodging

sentence: Concerning energy, are American oil companies fully utilizing all available resources, including offshore drilling? And regarding Iraq, will you finalize an interim agreement with Prime Minister Maliki regarding American military presence, or will you leave the negotiation of a permanent agreement to the next administration? [SEP] We're currently engaged in discussions with the Iraqi government to establish a strategic framework agreement that encompasses various areas of cooperation, including diplomacy, economics, and the rule of law. A key component of this agreement is a security arrangement. The Iraqi government has expressed its desire for a timeline for transitioning to an 'overwatch' role for US forces, which would involve training, logistical support, and special operations. To ensure the continued presence of our troops in Iraq, we need a clear understanding with the Iraqi government, including the necessary authorities and protections. We are actively negotiating these terms, and we aim to finalize the agreement before the end of the year, unless the UN mandate is extended.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, concerning Venezuela, following the imposition of stringent sanctions and the provision of aid, Maduro's departure seems no closer. Are you growing concerned about a potential loss of momentum, and what is the anticipated duration of this situation? [SEP] Look, I'm not getting any firm timelines here. Between him and the guy before him, they've been there a long time. You'd think things would change eventually. But the truth is, we haven't even hit them with the really tough sanctions yet. We've got those ready to go. All options are on the table, believe me. We've been playing it down the middle, you might say. But we can get a lot tougher if we need to. It's a real shame what's happening there, though. We're just trying to help those people who are starving and dying in the streets. It's a disgrace. This used to be one of the richest countries on Earth, and now it's just... poverty, no food, no water, nothing. The power went out for a long time last week. It's a mess. It's going to break down again, mark my words. It's being held together by a thread. Very sad, Roberta. Very sad.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Could the terror threats be the reason you have skipped Kenya in your visits to Africa? [SEP] Oh, no, no, no. [] The—well, first of all, with respect to journalists in the media, the last session that we had on good governance emphasized that good governance means everybody has a voice, that government is transparent and thereby accountable. And even though leaders don't always like it, the media plays a crucial role in assuring people that they have the proper information to evaluate the policies that their leaders are pursuing.And so we have been very consistent in pushing governments not just in Africa, but around the world, to respect the right of journalists to practice their trade as a critical part of civil society and a critical part of any democratic norm. The specific issue of the Al Jazeera journalists in Egypt, we've been clear both publicly and privately that they should be released. And we have been troubled by some of the laws that have been passed around the world that seem to restrict the ability of journalists to pursue stories or write stories. We've also been disturbed by efforts to control the Internet. Part of what's happened over the last decade or two is that new media, new technology allow people to get information that previously would have never been accessible or only to a few specialists. And now people can punch something up on the Internet and pull up information that's relevant to their own lives and their own societies and communities. So we're going to continue to push back against these efforts.As is true on a whole range of issues—and I've said this in the past—many times, we will work with countries even though they're not perfect on every issue. And we find that in some cases, engaging a country that generally is a good partner, but is not performing optimally when it comes to all of the various categories of human rights, that we can be effective by working with them on certain areas and criticizing them and trying to elicit improvements in other areas. And even among countries that generally have strong human rights records, there are areas where there are problems. That's true of the United States, by the way.And so the good news—and we heard this in the summit—is that more and more countries are recognizing that in the absence of good governance, in the absence of accountability and transparency, that's not only going to have an effect domestically on the legitimacy of a government, it's going to have an effect on economic development and growth. Because ultimately, in an information age, open societies have the capacity to innovate and educate and move faster and be part of the global marketplace more than closed societies do over the long term. I believe that.Now, with respect to terrorism, I think there's uniform concern of terrorist infiltration in many countries throughout Africa. Obviously, this is a concern that we have globally. A lot of the initiatives that we put forward were designed to partner so that countries, first and foremost, can deal with these problems within their own borders or regionally. And the United States doesn't have a desire to expand and create a big footprint inside of Africa. What we do want to make sure we can do is partner with the African Union, with ECOWAS, with individual countries to build up their capacity.And one of the encouraging things in the sessions was a recognition that fighting terrorism also requires security forces that are professional, that are disciplined, that themselves are not engaging in human rights violations; that part of the lesson that we've all learned about terrorism is that it is possible in reaction to terrorism to actually accelerate the disease if the response is one that alienates populations or particular ethnic groups or particular religions. And so the work that we're doing, including the security initiatives that I announced today, I think can make a big difference in that direction.It's not just a matter of us providing better equipment or better training. That's a part of it, but part of it is also making sure that these security forces and the intelligence operations are coordinated and professional and they're not alienating populations. The more we do that, the more effective we can be.Last point I'll make is, on good governance, one of the best inoculators against terrorist infiltration is a society in which everybody feels as if they have a stake in the existing order and they feel that their grievances can be resolved through political means rather than through violence. And so that's just one more reason why good governance has to be part of the recipe that we use for a strong, stable, and prosperous Africa.Last question, Jérôme Cartillier [Agence France-Presse].
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Is this kind of public pressure the only leverage you have, sir? [SEP] Look, we have a democracy. And right now John Boehner is the Speaker of the House and Mitch McConnell is the Republican leader. And all I can do is make the best arguments and mobilize the American people so that they're responsive.So far they haven't been responsive to not just me, but public opinion. We saw that during the debt ceiling vote. But we're just going to keep on making the case. But I guess what I'm saying, though, here, Bill, is--and I said this when I made my speech at the joint session--the election is 13, 14 months away. I would love nothing more than to not have to be out there campaigning because we were seeing constructive action here in Congress. That's my goal. That's what I'm looking for.But I'm also dealing with a Republican majority leader who said that his number-one goal was to beat me, not put Americans back to work, not grow the economy, not help small businesses expand, but to defeat me. And he's been saying that now for a couple of years. So yes, I've got to go out and enlist the American people to see if maybe he'll listen to them if he's not listening to me.Matt Spetalnick [Reuters]. Where's Matt? There we are.
label: Dodging

sentence: President López Obrador, while you celebrate the U.S. administration's decision to grant humanitarian visas, many critics argue that it's a band-aid solution that doesn't address the root causes of migration. What specific actions is Mexico taking to create economic opportunities and improve living conditions in the regions from which migrants are fleeing, and how will you ensure that these efforts are sustainable in the long term? [SEP] As I mentioned, we are working with communities in El Salvador, Honduras, Guatemala, and Belize to promote development and well-being. We are investing in programs that provide opportunities for people to stay in their own communities. We are also working to combat corruption and violence, which are major drivers of migration. We believe that by addressing the root causes of migration, we can create a more sustainable solution.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Mr. President, David Herszenhorn with Politico Europe. Just to come back to Russia for a second. The something that happened that got them kicked out of the G-8 was the invasion and annexation of Crimea. Do you think that Crimea should be recognized as Russian at this point? [SEP] Well, you know, you have to ask President Obama, because he was the one that let Crimea get away. That was during his administration. And he was the one that let Russia go and spend a lot of money on Crimea, because they've spent a lot of money on rebuilding it. I guess they have their submarine port there and such. But Crimea was let go during the Obama administration. And you know, Obama can say all he wants, but he allowed Russia to take Crimea. I may have had a much different attitude. But—so you'd really have to ask that question to President Obama—you know, why did he do that; why did he do that? But with that being said, it's been done a long time.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the Senate proceedings, would you prefer a swift resolution or a thorough examination of the facts? What are your thoughts on the exchange between White House Counsel Pat Cipollone and Jerrold Nadler last night? And are you absolutely opposed to John Bolton testifying? [SEP] Well, you're asking a lot of questions.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. So you're still planning for that deadline? That deadline is still in place, which is now a week from now? [SEP] Oh yes. Unless we do something pretty miraculous. But the Democrats it seems to me they want to have open borders. And for the life of me I cannot figure that out. It's one thing because I want people to come into our country. We need them because we have all these companies coming in. You know we have Foxconn in Wisconsin. We have so many companies coming in. Auto companies. Just today I was with President Abe; he told me another auto company is going to build a big plant. They need people. So I'm all for that.The only problem is that they have to come in through a process. They have to come in legally. It's also very unfair. You have millions of people on line for years trying to get into a country. They take tests. They study. They know a lot about our country. They read. They do—they have to go through a very complicated process. And these people have worked hard. They've been on line for 7 8 9 years and then somebody walks in and they're you know Welcome to the United States. It's really—honestly it's very unfair.But yes we will be removing large numbers of people. People have to understand: Yes the laws are—
label: Explicit

sentence: President, what demonstrable steps will be taken by your administration to assure the public that deficit reduction targets will be achieved, both now and in the future? [SEP] Pardon me? I didn't hear the question clearly.
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, could you outline the practical advantages of economic security for the Korean population? Also, in light of your emphasis on shared values, would the U.S. consider implementing export restrictions against nations that do not adhere to these principles? [SEP] The concept of economic security is vital for the well-being of our citizens. It directly affects their livelihoods. Consider the automotive industry, which depends on semiconductors. Recent water scarcity issues also underscore the critical need for essential resources in both daily life and industrial output. Securing a stable supply chain is paramount for our people and national economy, with implications for national and military security. While the WTO once promoted free trade, the pandemic and the rise of market blocs have created vulnerabilities in the supply chain. The U.S. and Korea, united by democratic values and human rights, must collaborate with like-minded countries to fortify the supply chain. Our National Security Councils are tasked with addressing this. We seek deeper cooperation to resolve any challenges. Furthermore, we stand ready to support each other in the event of financial or foreign exchange market instability, encompassing military and economic security. We also intend to negotiate defense item exports to enhance cooperation in specific sectors. This is not mere rhetoric; it's an active alliance. We are dedicated to strengthening our alliance. While championing democracy, human rights, and freedom, we aim to involve nations with different values in the pursuit of global peace, encouraging them to adopt these universal ideals. Our priority is to foster strong solidarity and cooperation among nations that share our values.
label: General

sentence: Q. Do you have a—— The President. Yes.Economic Stimulus Legislation  Q. Mr. President, I just want to follow up on that, and then a quick question. Just when you said that you've directed Secretary Mnuchin to ready direct payments, are you— speaking about something you're going to do independently or that you're just waiting for the legislative package? [SEP] I'm waiting for the Democrats to approve it. Okay?
label: Explicit

sentence: You think the Republican Party needs to be more inclusive. Who needs to hear that message inside the Republican Party? [SEP] The temptation after a defeat is to narrow our focus and impose litmus tests. This party will rebound, but its message must embrace diverse viewpoints. Take immigration, for example. The initial debate created the impression that Republicans dislike immigrants. If that's the image, others might feel excluded too. Our party must be compassionate and broadminded. I recall the 1964 elections when my father ran for Senate and was swept away by the Johnson landslide. The Republican Party was decimated then, but it rebounded in '66. The same can happen now, but we must ensure our message is inclusive and compassionate, showing we care about people's lives and have a plan to improve them.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, could you elaborate on the substance of your discussion with him? [SEP] The conversation revolved around the key themes of the conference. We touched upon the necessity of stability and facilitating access to development for the Southern Hemisphere. It was a cordial exchange, not at all confrontational. He approached me and made certain remarks. Thank you, everyone. This concludes the press conference.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Chemical weapons, Mr. President? Intel? Response? [SEP] No intel sharing. Response depends on use.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President Obama, The New Yorker has reported that the Red Cross found that the CIA's interrogation program used techniques tantamount to torture. Have you read that report, and what is your reaction? Also, a year ago, you stated your desire to close Guantanamo, yet little progress has been made. Reports suggest resistance from your Vice President, Attorney General, and Homeland Security Secretary. Who's truly in charge on this issue? Are you actively working towards closure, and do you anticipate Guantanamo being open or closed when you leave office? [SEP] Well, as I've said before, closing Guantanamo is an objective we should strive for. The problem, as you know, is finding places for these individuals to go. The Senate vote, nearly unanimous, against bringing these prisoners into the U.S. demonstrates the complexity. It's not as simple as snapping our fingers. We are actively working with other countries to facilitate transfers, which, as you can imagine, is no easy task given the nature of the individuals involved. We're also working to establish trial mechanisms, which is crucial. So, while I can't give you a definitive answer on Guantanamo's future, I can assure you it's a priority, albeit a complex one. And now, about that Red Cross report, could you remind me of the specifics you're asking about?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, concerning the situation in Haiti and Canada's role, are you disappointed that Canada isn't taking a more significant role in the multilateral forces there? What further actions would you like to see Canada undertake, beyond the $100 million pledged today? [SEP] Disappointed? No, not at all. The situation in Haiti is incredibly challenging, with gangs effectively running the country. The Prime Minister's approach makes a lot of sense. The most impactful thing we can do is bolster the capacity of the Haitian police to address the problems they face, which will take time. We're also exploring a larger role for the United Nations. The potential diaspora from Haiti poses a significant concern for the Western Hemisphere. We're collaborating with Canada to enhance the training and methods of the Haitian police and engaging other nations in the hemisphere to contribute. It's a work in progress. We must focus on strengthening the capacity of the Haitian National Police to bring more peace and security and stability. This won't happen overnight. At the same time, we must hold the Haitian elite accountable for the distress facing the Haitian people.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, Israel seems increasingly concerned about Iran's nuclear ambitions. How do you view the possibility of a preemptive strike by Israel, and what assurances can you offer regarding US commitment to preventing Iran from acquiring nuclear weapons? [SEP] Well, let's be clear: nobody wants to see Iran with a nuke, okay? If I were in Israel's shoes, I'd be worried too. We're working on it, believe me. We're exploring all options, and we're going to make sure Iran doesn't get a nuclear weapon. As for climate change, frankly, I think we can get a deal done. It's all about getting the right people at the table.
label: Implicit

sentence: What specific outcomes are you hoping to achieve during your G-7 Presidency? [SEP] We're aiming for something truly special, something that builds on the foundation we've already established. We've made significant progress, and we're moving forward with remarkable unity. In fact, unity was the defining characteristic of our last meeting with these seven crucial nations. Above all, we enjoyed excellent rapport and collaboration.
label: General

sentence: Q. Thank you so much, Mr. President. Dr. Fauci said earlier this week that the lag in testing was, in fact, a failing. Do you take responsibility for that? And when can you guarantee that every single American who needs a test will be able to have a test? What's the date of that? [SEP] Yes, no, I don't take responsibility at all, because we were given a set of circumstances and we were given rules, regulations, and specifications from a different time. It wasn't meant for this kind of an event with the kind of numbers that we're talking about. And what we've done is redesigned it very quickly with the help of the people behind me. And we're now in very, very strong shape.I think we'll be announcing, as I said, Sunday night, and this will start very quickly. And we'll have the ability to do in the millions over a very, very quick period of time. So no.And what we have done—and we are going to be leaving a very indelible print for the future, in case something like this happens again. But it was a—and that's not the fault of anybody. And frankly, the old system worked very well for smaller numbers—much smaller numbers—but not for these kind of numbers.Tony, maybe you'd like to say something?
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, concerning the Red Cross report detailing alleged torture by the CIA, what is your personal assessment of these interrogation methods? And regarding Guantanamo, despite your stated intention to close it, it remains operational. Given reported internal opposition, can you definitively state that Guantanamo will be closed during your presidency? [SEP] My position has been clear: closing Guantanamo is a national objective. The primary obstacle is finding countries willing to repatriate detainees. We need a destination for these individuals. The Senate recently expressed strong opposition to housing these prisoners within the US. So, the practical challenge is: what becomes of these individuals? To suggest no progress has been made is incorrect. We are actively negotiating with other nations for the return of detainees. Many are dangerous, making repatriation difficult. We also insist on humane treatment upon their return. Another priority is holding trials. I am committed to seeing these trials begin. The courts are involved in determining the procedures, and the Defense Department is working to establish the necessary mechanisms. The sooner we can proceed, the better. I cannot guarantee the closure of Guantanamo. It's a multifaceted issue. I've articulated an aspiration. Whether we achieve it remains to be seen. It's more complicated than it appears. Again, consider the Senate vote. There's limited support for closing Guantanamo and accepting prisoners in their home states. What was your second question?
label: General

sentence: Given the ongoing subpoenas, Mr. President, what prevents your administration from pursuing those specific actions? [SEP] I'm sorry? Bipartisanship.
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, critics argue that your business dealings create vulnerabilities to foreign influence. What specific measures have you taken to mitigate these risks and ensure the integrity of your office? [SEP] That's a ridiculous question. Next.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Sir, should the NHS be a topic of discussion? [SEP] Could you repeat that, please?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, the document you signed with North Korea commits them to denuclearization. How do you plan to ensure they take concrete action, rather than just offering empty words, a critique you often direct at your political rivals? [SEP] Look, can anyone truly guarantee anything? Can I guarantee the sun will rise tomorrow? No. What I can tell you is that they are eager to strike a deal. That's what I excel at. Deals are my forte, and I'm exceptionally skilled at them. I possess the innate ability to discern when someone genuinely desires a deal and when they are merely feigning interest. Many politicians lack this skill, but it is my strength. Frankly, this agreement could have been reached much earlier. However, I have a strong intuition – a talent, if you will – that they are committed to making it happen. A deal benefits the entire world, especially China, which undoubtedly harbors concerns about nuclear weapons in close proximity. China has been instrumental in facilitating this process. So, I believe he is serious. Can I offer absolute certainty? No, but the ongoing negotiations will soon reveal the truth. Thank you. Next question.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Do you think there's a risk of a recession? How do you rate that? [SEP] You know, you need to talk to economists. I think I got a B in Econ 101. I got an A, however, in keeping taxes low—[]—and being fiscally responsible with the people's money. We've submitted a plan that will enable this budget to become balanced by 2012 so long as Congress learns to set priorities. And we can balance the budget without raising taxes.Caren [Caren Bohan, Reuters].
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Thank you very much. Mr. President, two questions for you. The first one is on Ronny Jackson. It's been one day since he bowed out. I know it's only been less than 24 hours. Have you had a new nominee for the Secretary for the Department of Veteran Affairs?And my second question is on the U.S. Embassy set to open in Jerusalem in 3 weeks. Have you decided if you do plan to attend? And also, can you confirm if Treasury Secretary Steve Mnuchin is leading a delegation that could include your son-in-law Jared Kushner and Ivanka Trump? [SEP] Ronny Jackson—admiral, doctor—is one of the finest men that I've met over the last long period of time. High quality. High-quality family. I just met them. And I explained what happened. I explained that Washington can be a very mean place. You don't know about that, Chancellor. [] A nasty place.The false accusations that were made about him by Senator Tester, from a great State—I don't think that State is going to put up with it. These were false accusations about a great man, about a man who has a son who is a top student at Annapolis, about a man that's given his life to this country and to the military. A brave man. He would have been a great leader.To say the kind of things that he said—you had President Obama giving him an A-plus report. You had President Bush giving him an A-plus report. You have giving him an A-plus report. And to make statements of things that most people said never happened, never even happened. Calling him names was, to me, a disgrace, an absolute disgrace.And I think it's something we learn from. I called him today. I said, in a certain way—in a very big way, you're an American hero because you've exposed the system for some horrible things. I've had it happen to me with the Russian collusion hoax. It's a hoax.But I came into the job understanding that things happen. He didn't. He's a great doctor. He's a great admiral. He didn't really think a thing like this could happen. And I think it's a disgrace.So I just want to comment on that. And actually, I'm glad you asked the question. I think this man has been treated—he's an American hero, and I think he's been treated very unfairly. Okay?
label: Implicit

sentence: Does the offer remain valid? [SEP] Ultimately, it's the ians' decision. They need to determine their own course of action.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, isn't your reluctance to acknowledge any connection to him a bit disingenuous, considering his legal background? [SEP] Look, he went to law school, fine. I've heard the name floating around for years, sure. Didn't know the guy, never met him. Suddenly, everyone's talking about him for the Supreme Court, calling him brilliant. All I'm saying is, let's hear what the woman has to say, okay? We need to be fair, very fair.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Was it pretty far from the White House? Or was it right in front of that? [SEP] I can only tell you, they're going to going to give you a briefing. It was outside of the premises, near the fence, but outside of the premises.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, just to be clear, are you suggesting that future relations between the U.S. and North Korea could mirror the current U.S.-Vietnam relationship? [SEP] Say it again, please.
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the Senate proceedings, do you prefer a swift resolution or a thorough investigation? What are your thoughts on the exchange between Pat Cipollone and Jerrold Nadler? And are you opposed to John Bolton testifying? [SEP] That's quite a list of questions you've presented.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Mr. President, given John Howard's emphasis on climate change at this APEC meeting, hasn't your scheduling of a separate meeting in Washington undermined his attempt to establish aspirational goals? And to what extent do you consider ratification of Kyoto as being relevant to addressing climate change? [SEP] Let me address the latter question first. As I get older, you may need to remind me of the first part. Kyoto may be suitable for other countries. It may have made sense for certain countries that ratified it; however, it simply didn't make sense for the United States. Therefore, I was honest. And by the way, prior to my arrival in Washington, the United States Senate had the opportunity to express their approval or disapproval of whether or not Kyoto made sense to the United States. There was a 95-to-nothing vote against Kyoto. So, it's not just my opinion; many people thought Kyoto wasn't the way to go. We developed a different approach: energy efficiency standards based upon new technologies. And as I mentioned, we reduced greenhouse gases in America last year, and our economy grew at 3 percent. I don't know if many countries can make that claim, but we can because our strategy of putting new technologies in place is working. I happen to believe that we can do a better job of becoming less dependent on foreign oil. As an energy exporter, that might kind of frighten some of the energy exporters. But we've got to reduce our dependency on oil and therefore have put forth what's called a 20-in-10 program. Over the next 10 years, we will reduce our gasoline consumption by 20 percent by using ethanol and other new technologies. I believe battery technology is coming, so people in Sydney can drive the first 40 miles in their cars on battery without your car looking like a golf cart. In other words, there are new technologies coming to market. The fundamental question is how to get them to market as quickly as possible? Kyoto didn't do that as far as we were concerned. As a matter of fact, if you begin to take an assessment or inventory of countries that are actually meeting the Kyoto targets, I think you'll find that maybe a different approach makes sense. So, the reason we rejected Kyoto is because it wouldn't have allowed us to do what we wanted to do, which is grow our economy, become less dependent on foreign oil, and be good stewards of the environment. John and I have discussed his desire to put climate change at the forefront of APEC, and I was a strong supporter of that. I also reminded him that at the G-8, I took the message that said to our partners there that if you really want to really solve the global climate change issue, let's get everybody to the table. Let's make sure that countries such as China and India are at the table as we discuss the way forward. Otherwise, I suspect, if they feel like nations are going to cram down a solution down their throat and not give them a voice on how to achieve a common objective, they'll walk. And then you can't have effective global climate change if a nation like China is not involved. I thought the Prime Minister did something smart in this protocol. He announced that we need to cut back on tariffs that prohibit the exportation of technologies that will enable China, for example, to burn coal in a cleaner way. In other words, they've protected their environmental industries. And he wants to tear down those tariffs and barriers, and we support him strongly on this, so that technology is more likely to be able to flow from those of us who have it to those who don't. There are fundamental questions: How fast can we get effective technology to the market—coal sequestration technologies, nuclear spent fuel reprocessing technologies to the market? And once to the market, can we help developing nations acquire those technologies? Otherwise, it's an exercise that's not going to be effective. I believe the strategy that we have laid forth is the most effective way to deal with this issue in a serious way. I also appreciate the fact that the Prime Minister is the one that brought the issue to focus and is talking about energy dependency, energy efficiency standards, which is a part of the global climate mix. He shows that leadership on the issue, and I'm proud to be here talking about the issue. Okay. Thank you.
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, looking back, do you regret any of the alleged misinformation you shared with the American people? [SEP] Come again?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Mr. President, your comments on Brexit appear to contradict your earlier statements. You suggested the Prime Minister's plan would jeopardize a trade deal with the UK, despite our so-called 'special relationship.' Is this how a friend treats a friend? And Prime Minister, are you worried that the President's criticisms might be valid, potentially limiting future trade opportunities? [SEP] Let me set the record straight. I wasn't criticizing the Prime Minister. I have great respect for her. The media, as usual, got it wrong. That's why we record these things now. It's called combating fake news. The Prime Minister will decide her own path. I simply ask that we ensure free trade, no restrictions. We want to trade with the UK, and they with us. We're their biggest partner, and we have huge potential to grow. If they choose a different path – and they want independence, which is fine – I just hope they can still trade with the US. Some say it's impossible, but I believe it's absolutely possible after talking with their people. So, trade is a little tricky, but we'll make it work. And she's doing a wonderful job, by the way.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, concerning the impending sanctions deadline, how optimistic are you about reaching a consensus? Furthermore, what assurances can you provide regarding the security of Pakistan's nuclear assets in light of potential terrorist threats? [SEP] Regarding Pakistan, and to reiterate a point already raised, we maintain a level of confidence in the security surrounding their nuclear weapons programs. However, it's crucial to acknowledge that continuous improvement is essential for all nations, ourselves included. We experienced a notable incident involving nuclear-tipped missiles some time ago, prompting Secretary Gates to implement significant changes. Therefore, every nuclear power must enhance its security measures. Pakistan is not exempt, and neither are we. This summit aims to address this very issue. On the matter of sanctions, we have a substantial number of countries on the Security Council who support this course of action. However, these negotiations can be challenging. I intend to advocate vigorously for robust sanctions that will have consequences for Iran's nuclear program, and I aim to achieve this promptly. Beyond that, I won't speculate on the specifics at this time.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, regarding Russia and Ukraine, if Russia commits a 'minor incursion,' as you put it, will the sanctions you threatened still be imposed? Are you effectively signaling to Putin that a small-scale invasion is permissible? [SEP] I appreciate the question.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: President Bush, considering John Howard's focus on climate change at APEC, and your simultaneous meeting in Washington, how do you reconcile these actions? Furthermore, what is your assessment of the Kyoto Protocol's relevance to addressing climate change? [SEP] Okay, let's clarify a few things. First, on Kyoto, it just wasn't the right path for America. The Senate made that clear long before I arrived. It was a 95-to-nothing vote, so it's not just my view. We're pursuing a different strategy, one based on technology and innovation. We've shown that you can reduce emissions and grow the economy at the same time. Now, regarding John's efforts, I'm fully supportive of addressing climate change, but it needs to be a global effort. We need to bring everyone to the table, including China and India. We can't just dictate terms; we need collaboration. And John's idea of cutting tariffs on clean technologies is a good one. We need to get these technologies to developing nations. Our approach is the most effective way to deal with this issue in a serious way. I appreciate John's leadership on this.
label: Clarification

sentence: Regarding Russia, the Democratic candidates seemed to lack knowledge about Dmitry Medvedev. What's your take on him, and how much influence does he truly have with Putin still around? Critics claim you misjudged Putin. What cautionary tale would you share with your successor about Russia and its new leader? [SEP] I'm not particularly well-acquainted with Medvedev either. It'll be revealing to see who represents Russia at gatherings like the G-8. That'll provide some insight into Russia's foreign policy direction after Putin. I can't fully answer that at this point. It's crucial for us to maintain relations with Russia. For example, on proliferation, we must prevent the spread of dangerous materials. We need to work together on Iran. I appreciated Putin's offer to provide enriched uranium to Iran for the Bushehr plant, removing their need to enrich it themselves. That was a constructive gesture. We need to be able to work with Russia on Iran. There are many areas where we need to collaborate. Yesterday, with the Czech Prime Minister, I discussed missile defense in Europe. It's in our interest to help Russia understand the system isn't aimed at them but at genuine 21st-century threats, such as a launch from a violent regime with weapons of mass destruction. So, there are areas where we need to cooperate. I'm going to try to ensure my successor can have a relationship with whoever is steering foreign policy in Russia. It's in the country's best interest. That doesn't mean we'll always agree. We disagreed on Kosovo, and there will be other disagreements. But it's in the country's interest to have a relationship, leader to leader, and beyond.
label: General

sentence: The election of two Muslim women, one veiled, to the House – does that represent a repudiation of your message, in your opinion? [SEP] I'm not sure I understand the connection you're making. Could you clarify?
label: Clarification

sentence: President Biden, should Zelenskyy cede territory for a cease-fire? And should Russia be removed from the G-20? [SEP] On the second point, I think it depends on the G-20. I did raise the possibility that if Indonesia and others do not agree, that we should ask to have both be able to attend the meetings. Now, what was the first question again?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Mr. President, were you made aware of any new COVID-19 infections within the White House staff earlier today? [SEP] Pardon me, the audio is quite poor; could you repeat that?
label: Clarification

sentence: President Obama, regarding Ukraine, with reportedly 30,000 Russian troops near the border, what assurances can you offer to Eastern Ukraine, the Baltic States, Moldova, and others concerning potential Russian annexation? Furthermore, is Crimea a 'done deal,' or do you believe Putin might return it, or is this merely a show of force to prevent further land grabs? [SEP] On Crimea, it's not a done deal in that the international community largely rejects the annexation. Russia controls Crimea, and some residents support this. Forceful removal is unlikely. We're applying legal, diplomatic, political, and economic pressure. However, a simple solution is unlikely. History is unpredictable. The situation's evolution depends on international unity in condemning Russia's actions. Regarding Russian troops on the Ukrainian border, they're on Russian soil. We oppose intimidation, but Russia can legally have troops on its soil. Russia is still calculating. These calculations depend on unity from the US, Europe, and the international community in rejecting 21st-century dispute resolution methods. It's crucial to dismiss claims of threatened Russian speakers in Ukraine justifying Russian action. There's no evidence of threats. Provocateurs have caused scuffles. Comparisons to Kosovo, where thousands were slaughtered, are nonsensical. We must dispel excuses for Russian action. For border states outside NATO, like Ukraine, we're applying international pressure, highlighting the situation, and bolstering their economies. NATO members have Article 5 protection. We're intensifying contingency plans. NATO's ministerial will further develop these plans. NATO members are determined. For non-NATO countries, we're providing support through diplomatic and economic initiatives.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, regarding your demands to Congress concerning immigration, particularly the amnesty for 1.7 million individuals tied to a DACA fix, are you open to any modifications? [SEP] DACA was something we could have done something really good with. We were close to a deal, a very good deal. But a judge ruled that DACA was okay. Once the judge ruled that way, the Democrats didn't want to talk anymore. So, we'll see what happens with the Supreme Court.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Mr. President, you praised Governor Ducey's handling of the epidemic in his State. One of the things that he did was delay the start of public schools opening. Is that a model that governors and States experiencing hotspots should—should do as the beginning of school does approach? [SEP] Well, I'd like to see the schools open. I think many of the schools—most of the schools will be open. I can say that Republican areas want to see them open, and the Democrats probably want to keep them closed until after November 3 because they think it's good for them politically. I actually don't think it's good for them politically.Parents want the schools open. We want them open. We want them open safely. We're going to practice very strong hygiene and all of the other things that I've enumerated many times. But we want to see the schools open.Yes. Please, go ahead.
label: General

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. Heading into Laos, what are the main things you can offer its leaders? And what do you plan to push for in return? On the offering side, for example, I'm wondering how you view U.S. responsibility for unexploded ordnance. On the asking side, what are you pushing for most? Is it human rights? Closer U.S. ties in the face of China? Improving their problems with governance and corruption? What's the priority? [SEP] Well look, symbolically, this is important. I'll be the first U.S. President to visit Laos. And when you think about the history of the United States and Laos, I think it's useful to see what's happened in the evolution of our relationship with Vietnam, a country that I just visited recently.At the outset, as we're trying to build trust, a lot of work can be done around war legacy issues. For the Lao, that involves dealing with unexploded ordnance, which is still plaguing big chunks of the countryside. And since Laos is still a relatively poor country that is developing, their capacity alone to clean that up is hampered by a lack of resources. We should help. And my expectation is, is that in our meetings over the course of several days, that we'll be able to provide some really concrete assistance that ensures that innocent kids who are running through a field or a farmer that's trying to clear a field or a business that's trying to get set up, that they're not endangered by the possibility of an explosion.Likewise, we have deep commitments to accounting for those who were lost during that war. And as was true with Vietnam—to the extent that we're able to find out more about our missing in action and our POWs—that not only provides enormous comfort and meaning for families and is consistent with our traditions, but it also ends up being a show of good faith on the part of the country and a way for us to move into a next phase of a relationship.And so a lot of the conversation, I think, will start there, but it doesn't end there. We've had an initiative, for example, helping all the countries along the Mekong Delta to find ways to harness development and deal with environmental issues. And that's something that we've been doing through ASEAN over the course of several years now. For us to be able to expand some of that work, I think, would be important. Establishing people-to-people exchanges is another area that historically has been important.I do think Laos, seeing the enormous economic progress that Vietnam and China and others have made, are going to be very interested in finding ways in which they can advance into the global economy and help themselves grow, and I think that we can be a useful partner there.So I think there will be a broad-based agenda. But if you think about the visit I made to Ho Chi Minh City and driving through those streets and the enormous wellspring of good will that you saw, that started with some of the same kinds of steps that we're going to be taking with Laos. But I think we can, hopefully, do it faster, make more progress faster than we did over the course of 10, 15 years, because we've learned some things. And I think Laos is very eager to engage with us, and we're eager to engage with them.So I look forward to visiting what I hear is a beautiful country. Christi Parsons [Chicago Tribune].Trans-Pacific Partnership/uarterback Colin Kaepernick of the National Football League's San Francisco 49ers
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, should you deem a troop surge in Iraq essential, would you override your military advisors if they advised against it? [SEP] Look, that's a hypothetical, and I'm not going to play that game. I'm going to listen to everyone – Gates, the military, the diplomats in Iraq, even the Iraqis themselves. Then, and only then, will I make a decision about a surge. So, no comment for now.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, some critics argue that your focus on COVID-19 is a convenient excuse to avoid tackling the more difficult and politically divisive issues. How do you respond to that? [SEP] That's simply not true. COVID-19 is a real and present danger to the American people. It's a crisis that demands our immediate attention. And we will not apologize for putting the health and safety of the American people first.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Mr. President, are you aware of any new confirmed cases of the coronavirus amongst White House personnel as of today? [SEP] Just to be clear, you're asking about today?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. If this drug proves to be effective, would you support fast-tracking its approval in the United States? [SEP] I think it's premature for me to say that because I don't have enough information. I don't have enough data right now to offer an opinion on that.Jon Karl, ABC News.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, considering the soaring gas prices impacting American households, will you directly request Saudi Arabia to increase oil output during your upcoming visit? How will you reconcile seeking assistance from a nation with a questionable human rights record while simultaneously advocating for human rights on the global stage? [SEP] Well, let's be clear, the trip isn't solely about that. I'm beginning in Israel, a critical ally, and their leaders have stressed the significance of this visit. The meeting in Saudi Arabia is with the G-7, which includes Gulf States plus three. It's a broader engagement, not just about Saudi Arabia. I expect to meet with the King and Crown Prince, but it's within the context of a larger meeting. The key objective is to deepen Israel's integration in the region, promoting peace and bolstering Israeli security. That's why Israeli leaders are so supportive of my visit. We're also focused on addressing the tragic situation in Yemen, working to reduce casualties and foster stability. The agenda is comprehensive and goes beyond any single issue related to Saudi Arabia.
label: Deflection

sentence: President Biden, Vladimir Putin has characterized U.S.-Russia relations as being at a nadir. What concrete actions do you foresee emerging from your summit to reverse this decline? [SEP] Look, Putin's assessment isn't far off. The key is whether he's prepared to adhere to international norms. I told him, even before taking office, that I would investigate any meddling. And I did. I responded accordingly. This isn't a game of one-upmanship in front of the cameras; it's about establishing clear expectations for a better relationship. We're not seeking confrontation, but we must address unacceptable behavior. There are areas where cooperation is possible, perhaps even on climate. The most productive approach is a direct and honest conversation. I assure you, I will be forthright.
label: General

sentence: Q. Just to confirm, the essence of my question is your opinion on the U.S. decision to deploy atomic weapons against Hiroshima and Nagasaki, is that a fair summary? [SEP] Wait a minute, didn't you have several questions? You brought up something else about ?
label: Clarification

sentence: Sir, following up on the Putin matter, are you at liberty to share any insights into the substance of your discussion that led to his reported satisfaction? [SEP] The matter is closed. He's content, and frankly, so am I. Dragging it out further benefits no one.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Sir, regarding Prime Minister Maliki, are there specific deadlines for achieving these objectives? Furthermore, in emphasizing the U.S. focus on combating Al Qaida, are you suggesting that addressing sectarian violence is solely the responsibility of the Iraqi government, without U.S. military involvement? And Prime Minister Maliki, could you elaborate on the reasons for the cancellation of last night's meeting? [SEP] Could you please reiterate the initial component of your inquiry?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, Sputnik News is reporting possible inspections to North Korea's nuclear sites. Did you discuss this during negotiations? [SEP] Excuse me? I can't hear you. Where are you from again?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. But can I ask a follow-up on that? [SEP] Please, go ahead.
label: Explicit

sentence: Given the skepticism from climate activists and the concerns about broken promises from past climate conferences, what do you say to those who feel the current efforts are insufficient, particularly with legislative challenges and potential Supreme Court intervention? [SEP] Look, anyone concerned about the environment has every right to be worried. We've made significant strides, but we need to do much more. No one here has questioned my dedication. They're focused on our progress on deforestation and Build Back Better. World leaders are now prioritizing climate considerations in infrastructure projects. There's valid cause for concern, but I'm optimistic because public awareness has shifted dramatically since COP25. People are witnessing unprecedented climate disasters. The younger generation is driving change. The private sector is stepping up, and corporations are factoring in the cost of carbon. Things are evolving, and we need strong leadership to guide us forward.
label: Implicit

sentence: What specific criteria would need to be met before you would consider meeting with President Castro in Havana? And regarding the North Korean hack, while you've indicated that you won't disclose your response, can you confirm whether additional economic or financial sanctions are being considered? Moreover, can you rule out any potential military intervention or a retaliatory cyber operation? [SEP] I'll stand by my earlier statement. We've confirmed North Korea's culpability, and we're assessing various response options. These options will be presented to me, and I'll make a decision based on what I consider to be proportionate and appropriate. As for Cuba, a visit from me or President Castro is not presently in the cards. I'm unsure how the relationship will develop, but I foresee visiting Cuba at some point in my life. However, there are no specific plans for a visit at this time.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. And the U.S. aid to Egypt? [SEP] Well, Jonathan, I have to say that your numbers on U.S. aid to Egypt were a little bit imprecise. We have some regular assistance that we provide Egypt. We have some dollars that have been held up and have to be approved by Congress. But the way we make decisions about assistance to Egypt is based on are they in fact following rule of law and democratic procedures. And we don't make those decisions just by counting the number of heads in a protest march, but we do make decisions based on whether or not a government is listening to the opposition, maintaining a free press, maintaining freedom of assembly, not using violence or intimidation, conducting fair and free elections. And those are the kinds of things that we're examining, and we press the Egyptian Government very hard on those issues. Is 's visit significant? Very significant. Why am I saying so? Africa needs the United States. The United States needs Africa. And the only way you can build this relationship is through exchange of visits, and visits at the highest level speaks volumes about doing that. So I would say the visit of to Africa consolidates existing relations, but also advances them to greater heights for the mutual benefits of our two countries and our two peoples. President Bush and Madam Laura Bush are visiting Tanzania. The George Bush Foundation has programs supporting African First Ladies in the work that they do in their respective countries, particularly supporting women groups and supporting girls with regards to education and empowerment.Were we excited? In this, we have the President and the former President in Tanzania at the same time. It's a blessing to this country.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. When you talked about this in the past, you've minimized the benefits and you've highlighted some of the risks associated with that project. I'm wondering if you could tell us both what you would do when faced with that bill, given the Republican majority that we'll have in both Chambers, and also, what do you see as the benefits? And given the precipitous drop we've seen in oil prices recently, does that change the calculus in terms of how it would contribute to climate change, and whether you think it makes sense to go ahead with that project? [SEP] Well, I don't think I've minimized the benefits, I think I've described the benefits. If—at issue in Keystone is not American oil. It is Canadian oil that is drawn out of tar sands in Canada. That oil currently is being shipped out through rail or trucks, and it would save Canadian oil companies and the Canadian oil industry an enormous amount of money if they could simply pipe it all the way through the United States down to the Gulf. Once that oil gets to the Gulf, it is then entering into the world market, and it would be sold all around the world.So there's no—I won't say no—there is very little impact, nominal impact, on U.S. gas prices, what the average American consumer cares about, by having this pipeline come through. And sometimes, the way this gets sold is, let's get this oil, and it's going to come here. And the implication is, is that's going to oil—lower gas prices here in the United States. It's not. There's a global oil market. It's very good for Canadian oil companies, and it's good for the Canadian oil industry, but it's not going to be a huge benefit to U.S. consumers. It's not even going to be a nominal benefit to U.S. consumers.Now, the construction of the pipeline itself will create probably a couple thousand jobs. Those are temporary jobs until the construction actually happens. There's probably some additional jobs that can be created in the refining process down in the Gulf. Those aren't completely insignificant; if—it's just like any other project. But when you consider what we could be doing if we were rebuilding our roads and bridges around the country, something that Congress could authorize, we could probably create hundreds of thousands of jobs or a million jobs. So if that's the argument, there are a lot of more direct ways to create well-paying American construction jobs.And then, with respect to the costs, all I've said is that I want to make sure that if in fact this project goes forward, that it's not adding to the problem of climate change, which I think is very serious and does impose serious costs on the American people, some of them long term, but significant costs nonetheless. If we've got more flooding, more wildfires, more drought, there are direct economic impacts on that.And as we're now rebuilding after Sandy, for example, we're having to consider, how do we increase preparedness in how we structure infrastructure and housing and so forth along the Jersey Shore? That's an example of the kind of costs that are imposed, and you can put a dollar figure on it. So, in terms of process, you've got a Nebraska judge that's still determining whether or not the new path for this pipeline is appropriate. Once that is resolved, then the State Department will have all the information it needs to make its decision.But I've just tried to give this perspective, because I think that there's been this tendency to really hype this thing as some magic formula and—to what ails the U.S. economy, and it's hard to see on paper where exactly they're getting that information from.In terms of oil prices and how it impacts the decision, I think that it won't have a significant impact except perhaps in the minds of folks. When gas prices are lower, maybe they're more—less susceptible to the argument that this is the answer to lowering gas prices. But it was never going to be the answer to lowering gas prices, because the oil that would be piped through the Keystone pipeline would go into the world market. And that's what determines oil prices, ultimately.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. My name is--[inaudible]--from the Dong-a Daily News. I know that President Lee is talking about a South Korea-North Korea-Russia trilateral gas pipeline project. But North Korea is also under a lot of sanctions from the international community and the United States and other countries. But having said that, if this gas line project proceeds as planned, then we would have to provide or compensate North Korea with a substantial amount of money or other forms of compensation. So in your opinion, President Lee, do you think that the gas line--pipeline project will be able to proceed without resolving the North Korean nuclear issue? [SEP] Yes, thank you. And I don't know if that's a question that I should be answering here in the United States, but since you asked a question I will try to answer that.In the Far East, we have been discussing this issue for quite some time in trying to import Russian gas into the Republic of Korea. Now, we're discussing right now with the North Koreans whether the Russian gas, which is quite affordable, can travel through North Korea and be imported and be used in South Korea.This is beneficial, first of all, for Russia because they can sell their natural resource. For North Korea it is beneficial because they could use this natural resource, and also beneficial for South Korea as well. But let me just remind you that South Korea, North Korea, and Russia haven't yet come together to discuss this issue in any detail. But from an economic standpoint of view, it is beneficial for all parties involved. But I understand that this issue is not just economics alone. This issue inevitably involves security matters, which we will consider very closely.And also, let me remind you that this project will not be implemented anytime soon. Of course, we are mindful of the progress that we are making with regards to the North Korean nuclear issue as well. Jessica Yellin [CNN].
label: Deflection

sentence: President, Vladimir Putin recently stated that U.S.-Russia relations are at a low ebb. What tangible outcomes do you anticipate from your meeting to improve this situation, and why forego a joint press conference to publicly address these issues alongside him? [SEP] He's not wrong about the low point. It all depends on his commitment to international standards, which he hasn't always shown. I told him before I even took office that I'd investigate any election interference. And I did. I responded appropriately. This isn't about scoring points in a press conference; it's about clearly defining the terms for a better relationship. We're not looking for a fight, but we must address actions that violate international norms. There are potential areas of collaboration, perhaps even on strategic doctrine or climate. The best way forward is a direct, candid discussion. I assure you, I'll be very clear about our concerns.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, regarding Iran, what's the game plan? When do we start playing, and will their elections affect our strategy? Are they even interested in talking? [SEP] Look, Iran is a nation with a rich history, but their behavior hasn't exactly been conducive to global peace. Funding groups like Hezbollah and Hamas, threatening Israel, and pursuing nuclear weapons – these actions destabilize the region. We're reviewing our policy, exploring diplomatic avenues, and seeking opportunities for direct engagement. It won't be an overnight fix, given the deep mistrust. We'll be firm on our concerns: no funding of terrorism, no nuclear weapons. But there's potential for mutual respect and progress. Our approach to the Middle East, like George Mitchell's envoy role, shows our desire for change. Now, Iran needs to show they're willing to act differently and embrace their responsibilities as a member of the international community.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, could you clarify why you chose not to attend the hearing? [SEP] Well, you know, it's not that I wouldn't enjoy being there, believe me. I'd honestly relish the opportunity to observe their, shall we say, *unique* perspectives firsthand. But, you know, other things came up.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, considering Prime Minister Netanyahu's pre-election stance against Palestinian statehood, what concrete steps could he take to demonstrate his commitment to peace? Is there still time to repair the relationship during your presidency? Furthermore, are the claims of Israeli espionage during the Iran negotiations substantiated? And President Ghani, could you address the stalled reconciliation talks with the Taliban and the potential role of the U.S.? [SEP] I generally avoid commenting on intelligence matters publicly. We keep Congress, Israel, and our allies informed about the Iran deal. Any agreement will be transparent and verifiable, ensuring security for America, Israel, and the region. Regarding Israeli-Palestinian relations, the key is what the parties believe is achievable. Netanyahu's pre-election statements suggested a Palestinian state was unlikely, and his subsequent conditions were impractical. The question is whether there's a framework offering Palestinians hope for a secure state alongside Israel. Based on Netanyahu's remarks, it's difficult to envision. Our commitment to Israel's security remains firm, but we must re-evaluate our approach to Israeli-Palestinian relations, as the two-state solution appears increasingly distant. This could lead to a dangerous escalation. Our military and intelligence cooperation with Israel is unaffected, but we must be realistic about the situation. This isn't a personal matter; it's a fundamental policy disagreement. We advocate for two states, while Netanyahu holds a different view.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, Shanghai Media Group wants to know: when's the next meeting happening? Any chance it's soon, or are we looking at a significant delay? [SEP] I wish I could give you a straight answer, but I simply don't know. It could be just around the corner, or it could be a long way off. I'm hoping for the former, but I can't make any promises.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, with all due respect, the public is understandably confused about the coronavirus response. Why haven't you made changes at the CDC or other agencies, given the conflicting messages and the drop in public confidence? [SEP] Well, let me tell you, the situation is evolving rapidly, and the scientists are learning new things every day. The messages might seem confusing at times, but that's because the science is constantly changing. As for the CDC, they're doing the best they can with the information they have. This is a brand-new virus, a brand-new phenomenon. We're learning as we go. It's like when we were dealing with polio. The recommendations changed over time as we learned more about the virus. And let's not forget the amazing progress we've made in developing a vaccine in record time. Did we get everything right? Of course not. But we're doing our best to protect the American people. Anyway, I think I've said enough on that.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, reflecting on the Baghdad regional conference, what tangible outcomes were achieved, and what specific expectations do you hold for future sessions? Furthermore, do you genuinely believe Iran and Syria are committed to stabilizing Iraq, and could this pave the way for more formal engagement with these nations? [SEP] We'll see what they do. Actions speak louder than words, as they say. If they're serious about helping Iraq, they know what to do: stop the flow of weapons and suicide bombers. The conference itself was a positive step, bringing regional players together to support Iraq's democracy. It boosted the Iraqi government's confidence, which is crucial for reconciliation. As for future meetings, Secretary Rice will be there, continuing the work we started. It's all about helping Iraq build a stable and democratic future. We're watching closely to see if Iran and Syria back up their words with concrete actions.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, regarding Russia and the new leader Medvedev, what's your take on his power dynamic with Putin, and what advice would you give your successor about dealing with Russia? [SEP] Frankly, I'm still assessing Medvedev myself. The upcoming G-8 summit might offer some clues about Russia's foreign policy direction post-Putin. It's too early to say definitively. Maintaining relations with Russia is vital, especially on issues like non-proliferation and Iran. I've appreciated Putin's past cooperation on Iran's nuclear program. We need to work with Russia on various fronts, including missile defense in Europe, to ensure they understand it's not aimed at them. My goal is to leave my successor with a foundation for a functional relationship with Russia, despite disagreements. It's in our national interest, even if we don't always see eye-to-eye, as evidenced by our differences on Kosovo.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, with anti-LGBTQ+ laws proliferating across the country and instances of violence on the rise, many are questioning the federal government's commitment to protecting this community. What assurances can you offer to LGBTQ+ Americans, particularly families with transgender children, who feel increasingly unsafe, and what concrete actions will you take to counteract these discriminatory state laws? [SEP] Let me start by saying that if you can connect me with that family you mentioned, I want to speak with them directly and assure them of our unwavering support. As president, I was proud to end the ban on transgender individuals serving in our military, and I signed the Respect for Marriage Act, among other things. However, the fight is far from over. We are facing a wave of prejudice and fear-mongering that is simply unacceptable. It is wrong that someone can be married in the morning and fired in the afternoon simply because of who they are. The violence and hate crimes targeting the LGBTQ+ community are abhorrent. The hateful bills targeting transgender children are terrifying families and criminalizing doctors. These are our children, our neighbors, and it is our moral imperative to protect them. I am announcing a series of new initiatives to protect the LGBTQ+ community, including strengthening physical safety, addressing civil rights violations, and expanding mental health resources. Congress must pass the Equality Act and send it to my desk. To all LGBTQ+ Americans, especially our children: you are loved, you are heard, and this administration has your back. Regarding AI, it is clear that it presents both incredible benefits and real risks. We are working with international partners to establish the necessary guardrails. And on climate change, we need that same spirit of urgency to the challenges and opportunities that AI poses. I'd like to call on the BBC for the next question.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: President Bush, North Korea's nuclear declaration lacked information on weapons. Is that acceptable? You're removing them from the terror list despite Japanese abduction concerns. How will we address abductions after removal? Mr. Fukuda, did you urge President Bush to reconsider the delisting? If not, why? What U.S. cooperation will you seek on abductions post-delisting? [SEP] North Korea is still under the heaviest sanctions in the world. They can only get rid of them by proving they're keeping their promises. Taking them off the list doesn't mean the sanctions are gone. They have a lot to do to get rid of them. It's a step-by-step process. They destroyed the cooling tower, which we could see, and that's good. But we still have other worries, like the abductions. Some people think we should ask the U.S. to put them back on the list because of the abductions. But we're in a new stage with the nuclear issue, and we need to make it work because it's good for Japan. At the same time, we need to solve the abduction problem. We shouldn't let the nuclear progress stop us from working on the abductions. We need to talk to North Korea and make progress on both things. It's important for Japan and for North Korea too.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, regarding Putin's invitation, yes or no: will you participate in this video summit? [SEP] I'm not aware of any formal invitation. I'll need to be briefed on the details before I can provide a definitive answer. It's a process.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Sir, to reiterate, will the NHS be included in the discussions? [SEP] I'm sorry, could you repeat the question?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the coronavirus vaccine, who should be prioritized for the initial doses once it's available? Also, what are your thoughts on Russia's approval of their own vaccine, and have you discussed it with Russian officials? [SEP] The medical experts will guide the distribution, focusing on those most vulnerable. As for the Russian vaccine, we're monitoring its progress, but safety and rigorous testing are paramount.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, many legal scholars are debating the possibility of preemptive pardons. Could you clarify your stance on this matter, specifically regarding potential pardons for members of your administration? [SEP] I appreciate the question, but I will not be commenting on any potential pardon actions at this juncture. My focus remains elsewhere.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: So, Charlotte then, Mr. President? [SEP] We're looking at various places. Expect an announcement soon.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, after your discussions with the U.S. President, are you now less concerned about the direction of climate change and Russia policies under his successor? Do you foresee a potential fracturing of the united European front against Russia? And following Mr. Trump's victory, would you consider it necessary to re-announce your candidacy as a matter of protocol? [SEP] Well, I generally avoid commenting on the internal affairs of other nations. However, I must commend Chancellor Merkel for her exceptional partnership. She stands as one of the few remaining leaders from our closest allies who was present when I first took office. Together, we've navigated numerous challenges. While we haven't always agreed on every matter, our shared core values, her unwavering integrity, her commitment to truthfulness, her thoughtful approach, her meticulous preparation, her dedication to prioritizing the interests of the German people while recognizing the importance of global engagement and effective participation in multilateral institutions – all of these qualities make her an outstanding leader. The decision of whether to seek re-election rests solely with her, and ultimately, it will be the German people who determine the future. If I were a German citizen with a vote, I might be inclined to support her. Regarding Russia, my stance has remained consistent throughout my time in office. Russia is a significant nation, a military superpower with considerable influence both regionally and globally. To address many of the world's pressing issues, it is in our best interest to collaborate with Russia and secure their cooperation. We should all aspire to a prosperous Russia, where its citizens are employed, its economy is thriving, and it maintains positive relationships with its neighbors while actively contributing to global challenges such as climate change. I have consistently sought a constructive relationship with Russia, while also acknowledging the significant differences in our worldviews. The values we hold dear – democracy, freedom of speech, international norms, the rule of law, and respect for the sovereignty and territorial integrity of other nations – are non-negotiable. Consequently, we have encountered substantial disagreements on issues such as Ukraine and Syria. My hope is that the incoming President-elect will adopt a similarly constructive approach, identifying areas where our values and interests align, while also standing firm against Russia when they deviate from our values and international norms.
