While I don't anticipate the President-elect adhering precisely to our blueprint, I hope he avoids a purely realpolitik approach that prioritizes short-term deals with Russia at the expense of international norms, the vulnerability of smaller countries, or the creation of long-term problems in regions like Syria. This is something we will learn more about as the President-elect assembles his team. I am encouraged by the President-elect's reaffirmation of the unwavering commitment to NATO. His full support for NATO as the cornerstone of our international security is of paramount importance. Finally, regarding my conversations with President Putin, these occurred before the election. As I have stated, there is clear evidence of their involvement in cyber attacks. This is not a new phenomenon, nor is it unique to Russia. We have observed low-level cyber attacks, industrial espionage, and other unacceptable behavior from various states. I conveyed a clear and forceful message that while we recognize Russia's intelligence gathering activities, even if we disapprove, there is a distinct difference between that and meddling in elections or targeting private organizations or commercial entities. We are closely monitoring the situation and will respond appropriately if and when we witness such actions. I believe that the issue of cyber security requires international cooperation to develop frameworks and norms to prevent a cyber arms race. Many countries possess advanced capabilities, and given the vulnerability of our infrastructure and economies to digital platforms, we must ensure that this does not become a lawless, low-level battlefield. We have begun to establish principles adopted by the G-20, the G-7, and the U.N., but much work remains to be done. Allow me to emphasize my admiration for the smooth transition of power in the United States, which adheres to democratic principles despite a challenging election campaign. This transition, focused on the American people and their destiny, involves the outgoing administration sharing its knowledge and expertise with the incoming administration. This encourages us to continue the strong cooperation between the United States and the Federal Republic of Germany, which is in our mutual interest. We will continue this cooperation with an open mind and a deep conviction with President-elect Donald Trump. Regarding Russia, I can only reiterate what the President said. It is about respecting certain principles. From a European and German perspective, the fact that we have enjoyed peace for over 70 years depends on respecting the territorial integrity and sovereignty of every European country. Disregarding this would be a dangerous step backward, and we must resolutely oppose any such attempts. We remain hopeful for political solutions, which is why we launched the Normandy process in close coordination with the United States. From a German and European perspective, Russia is our neighbor. Considering Poland's perspective, we have an interest in a positive relationship. We share historical ties, but this should not prevent us from addressing serious disagreements through political means and seeking political settlements. This is what I will continue to work on with all my heart. Regarding my candidacy, I will address that at the appropriate time, but not today.
label: General

sentence: Q. Regarding the NHS, Mr. President, is its inclusion in trade negotiations a possibility? [SEP] Excuse me? Could you repeat the question?
label: Clarification

sentence: Concerning the deadline for Kosovo's independence... [SEP] Decline of what are we speaking of?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Mr. President, with the House seemingly poised to disapprove of your Iraq policy, does such a vote embolden our enemies and undermine your strategy? Furthermore, what steps are you taking to prevent Congress from restricting funding for the war? [SEP] Right, a couple of things. First, I recognize Congress will voice their concerns, and the Democrats, along with some Republicans, clearly disagree with my approach. That's fine; they're entitled to their opinions. I considered their viewpoints, but I believe they would hinder the establishment of a self-governing, self-sustaining ally in the fight against terror. Second, I hope this non-binding resolution doesn't morph into a binding policy that ties our troops' hands. It's contradictory to unanimously support General Petraeus and then deny him the resources he needs to implement his strategy, which he detailed before the Senate. I'm going to emphasize to Congress, starting now, the necessity of funding our troops and providing them with the flexibility to succeed. It's also curious that they're criticizing a plan before it's even had a chance to prove itself. Again, I understand their concerns. Now, what was the other part of your question?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Former President Barack Obama famously said that he had a pen and a phone to use executive power on issues like immigration. Do you see yourself using executive power to get some of your immigration agenda done? [SEP] I do. I do. I think that some of it I can use executive power—on some. Not all. But I got—I mean, he certainly used it. He used it on DACA. And when he did it, he said something to the effect that I'm not allowed to do this, it will never hold up, but I'm doing it anyway. And he did it, and they found judges that approved it. We also found judges that didn't approve it, so it's obviously going to be determined in the Supreme Court.And if the Supreme—if the Court rules in favor of what President Obama thinks they should rule—which is what he said—then I will probably have a deal with the Democrats in a very short period of time. We were very close to having a deal until we got that very strange ruling.
label: Explicit

sentence: On the subject of Huawei, Mr. President, could you clarify whether its removal from the entity list is a genuine possibility? What factors are being considered in this decision? [SEP] Look, I'm not going to negotiate in public on this. Huawei is a serious matter, and we're giving it the attention it deserves. We're looking at all the angles, considering all the options. I'm not going to get into specifics right now. We'll have more to say on this down the road.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. My name is Giuliana. President Trump, Nigeria urgently needs the Tucano aircraft to address the problems back home. Would you be willing to release at least two before 2020 to help the country deal with the situation? And when will you be visiting Nigeria? [SEP] I would love to visit Nigeria. It's an incredible country. From what I hear, it's one of the most beautiful countries in the world. So, I'd like to go. As for the first part of your question, I didn't quite catch it. Please repeat it.
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. You're scheduled to meet this week with President Hollande in Washington to talk about stepping up efforts against ISIL even further. Given that Russia would be part of the coalition that France proposes, have you seen any signs in the past couple days of Russia redirecting its military efforts in Syria to actually focus on ISIL? Are you—are there any circumstances that you could see President Asad remaining in power, even if only temporarily, if that's what it took to effectively have a broad alliance directed at ISIL?And finally, as you've said, the U.S. won't work with Russia if their goal is to keep Asad in power. If that's the case, is defeating ISIL or destroying ISIL a realistic goal? [SEP] Well, first of all, destroying ISIL is not only a realistic goal, we're going to get it done, and we're going to pursue it with every aspect of American power and with all the coalition partners that we've assembled. It's going to get done.It will be helpful if Russia directs its focus on ISIL, and I do think that as a consequence of ISIL claiming responsibility for bringing down their plane, there is an increasing awareness on the part of President Putin that ISIL poses a greater threat to them than anything else in the region. The question at this point is whether they can make the strategic adjustment that allows them to be effective partners with us and the other 65 countries who are already part of the counter-ISIL campaign. And we don't know that yet.So far, over the last several weeks, when they started taking strikes in Syria, their principal targets have been the moderate opposition that they felt threatened Asad. Their principal goal appeared to be—if you follow the strikes that they took—to fortify the position of the Asad regime. And that does not add to our efforts against ISIL. In some ways, it strengthens it, because ISIL is also fighting many of those groups that the Russians were hitting.When we were in Turkey, I discussed with President Putin, in a brief pull-aside, his need to recognize that he needs to go after the people who killed Russian citizens. And those aren't the groups that they were currently hitting with strikes. So they're going to have to make an adjustment in terms of what they're prioritizing.More broadly—I've said this before; I said it to President Putin 5 years ago, and I repeated it to him just a few days ago—the issue with Asad is not simply the way that he has treated his people. It's not just a human rights issue. It's not just a question of supporting somebody who has been ruthlessly dropping bombs on his own civilian populations. As a practical matter, it is not conceivable that Mr. Asad can regain legitimacy in a country in which a large majority of that country despises Asad and will not stop fighting so long as he's in power, which means that the civil war perpetuates itself.And so the goal in Vienna is to see if—with all the countries around the table, including Saudi Arabia and Turkey and Iran and Russia, as well as the United States and other countries that have concerns about this—whether we can arrive at a political transition process that recognizes the need for a new government and can quell the fighting, bring about a cease-fire, and allows all of us to refocus our attention on this barbaric organization that is killing so many people.Russia has not officially committed to a transition of Asad moving out, but they did agree to the political transition process. And I think we'll find out over the next several weeks whether or not we can bring about that change of perspective with the Russians.Keep in mind that we all have an interest in maintaining a Syrian state, because we don't want complete chaos. I mean, and there are problems that we've seen in, for example, Lebanon, when the machinery of state entirely breaks down. So there—there's going to be a need for the international community and the United Nations to work in order to maintain a Syria—maintaining a Syrian state and be able to move forward with a political transition that's orderly. And that's going to be difficult, but that's what we have to focus on.In terms of the position of the United States and the other 65 members of the coalition, my view on Asad is, it will not work to keep him in power. We can't stop the fighting. Even if I were to cynically say that my priority is ISIL and not removing Asad regardless of the terrible things that he's done to his people, the United States could not stop the fighting in Syria by those who are opposed to Asad's rule. And so this is a practical issue, not just a matter of conscience. And I think that there are a large number of members of this coalition, including President Hollande, who agree with me on that. Okay?Michael Shear [New York Times].
label: Implicit

sentence: Regarding the executive action, how will you ensure its effectiveness against Republican opposition, particularly concerning funding? Also, are you now considering a figure of two million or more? [SEP] Jeff, when we roll out the executive action, it'll be chock-full of details, believe me. You'll have all the specifics you can handle. And I'm sure there will be a lot of follow-up questions.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, to clarify Vice President Biden's comment about a 30% chance of failure, could you share the subject of that conversation and your views on the probability of success in that area? [SEP] Look, I trust Joe. He's a good man. But I wouldn't get too hung up on the numbers. The important thing is that we're working hard every day to solve these problems. We're going to keep fighting for the American people, and that's all that matters.

sentence: Mr. President, about Georgia, will you be discussing their concerns with President Putin during your meeting? [SEP] Well, they paid us a visit, and I must say, they left a positive impression. The situation in Georgia is indeed challenging. However, they articulated their concerns quite effectively. So, we listened attentively. Next question, please.

sentence: In light of Rick Ledgett's statements regarding Edward Snowden, what is your perspective on the possibility of amnesty or a plea agreement for him? And what is your message to Americans who believe Snowden's actions were justified in exposing surveillance activities? [SEP] Snowden is currently under indictment, so I must exercise caution. This is ultimately a matter for the Attorney General and the courts. I've previously stated that this conversation was necessary. However, the way in which it unfolded damaged U.S. intelligence capabilities. We adhere to the rule of law. These disclosures have allowed countries that actively engage in surveillance to criticize us. It's resulted in unnecessary harm. I'll leave it to the courts to decide.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, despite the allegations against Prime Minister Najib, what specific assurances did you receive from him regarding his commitment to addressing corruption and upholding human rights during your discussions? [SEP] Look, the situation with refugees is complex, especially after the Paris attacks. People are understandably concerned. But we need to remember that refugees undergo rigorous screening. The process is thorough and takes a long time. As for Prime Minister Najib, I can't comment on ongoing investigations. However, I consistently emphasize the importance of transparency, accountability, and rooting out corruption to all leaders. I also stress the importance of civil society and a free press. Countries are at different stages of development, but certain principles are universal. Myanmar's progress is encouraging. We use initiatives like the Open Government Partnership and TPP to promote these values. The goal is a world where people are treated fairly, there's rule of law, and governments are accountable. These are American values, but they're also universal.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, if you acknowledge that this situation is unfair to the country and costing millions, why not simply terminate it? [SEP] Next question, please. I've already addressed this matter.

sentence: So, if I understand correctly, you're not changing your overall position, but you're setting aside, for the time being, the question of whether to use that specific term in the future? [SEP] The priority right now is to support President Gul in these productive negotiations. The United States doesn't want to interfere or influence these discussions while they're progressing positively.

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. You were just criticizing the WHO for praising China as transparent, but you were saying many of the same things about China just a couple of months ago. So, I mean, how do you square, your decision to revoke funding—[inaudible]? [SEP] Well, I did a trade deal with China, where China is supposed to be spending $250 billion in our country. We're going to be watching very much to see. Now, it got a little bit waylaid by the virus.But look, I'd love to have a good relationship with China. But if you look—and we made a phenomenal deal. China has paid—because of me, China has paid us tens of billions of dollars over the course of a very short period of time. Billions of—some of that money has been spent to farmers, where they were targeted by China. We cannot let that happen. We can't let that happen.So we ended up signing a very good trade deal. Now, I want to see if China lives up to it. I know President Xi; I think he will live up to it. If he doesn't live up to it, that will be okay too, because we have very, very good alternatives.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, many families with transgender children feel increasingly vulnerable in the current political climate. Beyond expressing support, what tangible, measurable actions will your administration implement to combat discriminatory legislation and ensure their access to healthcare and equal opportunities? [SEP] Let me tell you, get me that family's number. I want to talk to them. This administration has their back. We ended the ban on transgender troops. We signed the Respect for Marriage Act. But it's not enough. There are some prejudiced people who are pushing fear. It's wrong. These are our kids. We're strengthening safety, addressing civil rights violations, and boosting mental health support. Congress needs to pass the Equality Act. LGBTQ+ Americans, we will protect you.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, regarding chemical weapons, do you have specific intelligence suggesting Putin is preparing to use them? And if he does, what would be the U.S. or NATO's military response? [SEP] I'm not going to share intelligence details with you. However, let me be clear: the use of chemical weapons is unacceptable, and we would respond. The nature of our response would depend on the specifics of the situation. Next question.

sentence: Q. Mr. President, despite the commotion, I must ask: were you informed of any new coronavirus infections within the White House today? [SEP] I can barely hear you. Can you try again?

sentence: Q. Mr. President, where do you plan to find savings in the Defense and Veterans Administrations budgets when so many items that seem destined for the chopping block are politically untenable perhaps? [SEP] I'm sorry, so many?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. And now that you've talked to him, do you believe you can trust him? [SEP] Look, this is not about trust; this is about self-interest and verification of self-interest. That's what it's about. So I—virtually almost—almost anyone that I would work out an agreement with that affected the American people's interests, I don't say: Well, I trust you. No problem. Let's see what happens.You know, as that old expression goes, The proof of the pudding is in the eating. We're going to know shortly.Igor [Igor Sevryugin], Radio Free Europe and Radio Liberty.News Media in /Political Trends in
label: Deflection

sentence: Regarding North Korea's potential nuclear test, what did you discuss with President Xi? How much leverage does China have, and what are the repercussions for US-China relations if they proceed? [SEP] Well, it's hard to say definitively if China can control North Korea. I've told President Xi that they need to try to dissuade them from conducting these tests. If they do proceed, we'll have to take defensive measures to protect ourselves and our allies. These measures wouldn't be directed *at* China, but they would send a clear message to North Korea.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, concerning Judge Kavanaugh, would you support the FBI reopening its background investigation, as some have suggested? [SEP] The FBI doesn't usually do that. They've already done six checks. Kavanaugh is a great guy, smart, a great judge, impeccable. I feel bad for him. This should have come up earlier. Feinstein had the letter for a long time. Why didn't she bring it up? The Democrats obstruct everything. They're lousy on policy. But, we should go through a process, no doubt. Hopefully, the woman will come forward. He will state his case. Then they will vote. He's a great man. I feel terrible for him and his family.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, you mentioned several key areas of potential collaboration with Canada. Could you prioritize which of these areas – stimulus, auto sector, border policy, or carbon market – you see as most critical in the next four years? [SEP] Hold on, hold on. sentence: Concerning these 'provocations' whenever the US extends an olive branch, what's your take on Fidel Castro's involvement in negotiations? Did you mention him to Raul? How's he doing, anyway? And given Republican resistance to your Cuba policy, will you personally lobby them to prevent funding cuts? [SEP] Alright, Lesley, I'm going to have to cut you off there. We're running short on time, and this is taking up a lot of it.

sentence: Mr. President, given your past skepticism towards the intelligence community, what steps are you taking to ensure that you are receiving accurate and unbiased information regarding potential election interference from all sources? [SEP] I have great people, very smart people. They're giving me the best information. We're watching everything very closely. We're not going to let anyone get away with anything. We're going to protect our elections, and we're going to win.

sentence: Given the current situation, Mr. President, do you stand by your earlier assessment of the health crisis as merely 'little fires' being put out? Many would argue that the situation has escalated far beyond that. [SEP] We're monitoring the situation closely. Some states are experiencing challenges, but they have strong governors who are working hard. We're providing them with all the necessary resources. Their hospital capacities are holding up well, and we're confident that they will manage the situation effectively. It's a localized issue, and we're addressing it accordingly.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Mr. President, beyond the stimulus, what tangible solutions do you propose for those in dire economic straits? [SEP] The cornerstone is making the tax cuts permanent. The uncertainty around gasoline prices, possibly reaching $4 a gallon, creates anxiety. Permanent tax cuts provide stability. We also need a realistic energy policy. Renewables are good, but we need to boost domestic oil and gas production. We haven't constructed a refinery in years. My suggestion to build them on old military bases was ignored. Simple supply and demand: less supply, higher prices. Taxing oil companies only exacerbates the problem. We should encourage domestic investment. This stimulus, combined with permanent tax cuts and a pragmatic energy policy, offers hope.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, did your talks with President Bolsonaro include the possibility of a U.S. military base in Brazil to address the Venezuela situation? [SEP] We had a productive discussion about strengthening our alliance, potentially including Brazil's designation as a major non-NATO ally. The focus was on how we can collaboratively address the crisis in Venezuela, ensuring humanitarian aid reaches those in need and working towards a democratic transition.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, how do you view Australia's potential uranium sales to India, and what role did the U.S. play in that decision? Also, what's your stance on a global carbon trading system, especially given Australia's carbon tax? [SEP] Well, regarding India, I don't believe we had any influence on Australia's decision. I think your government is smart enough to recognize the importance of India and the Australia-India relationship. This is your region, and you'll make your own bilateral decisions. The discussions around nuclear energy with India seem compatible with international law and the NPT. This is between India and Australia, not the U.S. On carbon emissions, I agree with your Prime Minister and most scientists that climate change is a real problem caused by human activity. Each country is finding its own way to reduce emissions. Australia has a bold strategy. In the U.S., we've doubled fuel efficiency standards and invested in clean energy research. We believe we can meet our commitments from Copenhagen and Cancun. I hope the U.S. can find further ways to reduce emissions. Advanced economies can't do this alone; emerging economies like China and India need to be part of the solution. We want a mechanism where all countries are making an effort, which will be tough but beneficial in the long term.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Mr. President, can you confirm whether the suspect was armed? [SEP] Well, that's what I've been told. But I don't know for sure. You'll have to ask the people who were there.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, with all due respect, your answer seems to avoid the specific questions about advising protesters and your successor, as well as the urgent situation in Aleppo. Can you clarify your position on these matters? [SEP] I believe that everyone has the right to express their opinions peacefully, and I would never tell anyone to stop protesting. However, I also believe that it's important to engage in constructive dialogue and to work towards solutions. As for my successor, I have offered him my advice and support, but ultimately it's up to him to make his own decisions. And regarding Aleppo, the situation is dire, and we need to do everything we can to alleviate the suffering of the Syrian people.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Will the United States officially recognize that? [SEP] I'd suggest familiarizing yourself with the Ahtisaari plan. Getting more peacekeepers into Darfur has been delayed by the UN and Sudan's disagreement on the status of forces agreement. Now that it's signed, that's cleared the way. We are seeking more volunteers as they are needed. We have volunteered to contribute one battalion. If there is need for another one, we will certainly do that.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Mr. President, your focus on state sovereignty seems at odds with the concept of 'responsibility to protect.' Could you elaborate? [SEP] Reconcile it with responsibility to protect, which was...?
label: Clarification

sentence: Given the focus on your Asia pivot, some suggest your reception in the region has been less than enthusiastic. Furthermore, with only four months remaining in your term and 60 prisoners still held at Guantanamo Bay, will the prison remain open when you leave office? [SEP] Look, as far as I can tell, my reception here has been great. Have you talked to the people in Laos? They seem pretty happy with my visit. Everywhere we've gone, we've had a good reception, like in Vietnam, where millions lined the streets. So, if this theory about my reception and my rebalance policy is based on me using the short stairs in China, I think that's a bit of an overreaction. Anyone reasonable, especially in the region, would be puzzled as to how that became a symbol of our work. If you look at what leaders and ordinary people are saying, and the real work we've done on everything from economic programs to development, to legacy of war issues, to supporting civil society and young people, the worry I've heard isn't that what we've done hasn't been important and successful. The worry is, will it continue? Other leaders are asking if America's interest and presence will be sustained. I hope my successor will keep this going, because there's a lot happening here. You've got countries taking off, one of the youngest populations in the world. This is where the action will be in terms of commerce, trade, and creating U.S. jobs. That's the feedback I've gotten, not just from leaders, but also from local newspapers and people. As for Guantanamo, I'm not ready to say that it might still be open, because we're still working to reduce the number of prisoners. I believe Guantanamo is a recruiting tool for terrorist organizations, it makes counterterrorism cooperation harder, and it's not necessary and costs U.S. taxpayers a fortune. Is there a lot of resistance in Congress? Absolutely. But as we get the population down to 40 or 50 people and keep spending millions to house them, Americans should be asking why we're spending this money when it's not needed for our safety. Because of the politics in Congress, it's tough. But I expect to work hard over the next four and a half months.
label: General

sentence: Q. Thank you. Thank you, Mr. President. I want to ask you about Iran. The Israeli Prime Minister just gave a speech very critical of their nuclear program. I wanted to ask if you have made up your mind to pull out of that deal. And if you do pull out of that deal, do you think—are you worried that it sends the wrong message to North Korea, as you seek to enter nuclear talks with Kim Jong Un? [SEP] No, I think it sends the right message. You know, in 7 years that deal will have expired and Iran is free to go ahead and create nuclear weapons. That's not acceptable. Seven years is tomorrow. That's not acceptable.So no, if anything, it's proven right what Israel has done today with the news conference. And Prime Minister Netanyahu just gave a very—I don't know if everybody has seen it, but I got to see a little bit of it. And that is just not an acceptable situation. And I've been saying that's happening. They're not sitting back idly. They're setting off missiles, which they say are for television purposes. I don't think so.So we'll see what happens. I'm not telling you what I'm doing, but a lot of people think they know. And on or before the 12th, we'll make a decision. That doesn't mean we won't negotiate a real agreement. You know, this is an agreement that wasn't approved by too many people. And it's a horrible agreement for the United States, including the fact, Mr. President, that we gave Iran $150 billion and $1.8 billion in cash—Nigeria would like some of that—$1.8 billion in cash and $150 billion. You know what we got? We got nothing. We got nothing.So that doesn't mean I wouldn't negotiate a new agreement. We'll see what happens. But I think, if anything, what's happening today and what's happened over the last little while and what we've learned, has really shown that I've been 100 percent right.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. But shouldn't you, as the President, meet with them in person? [SEP] Listen to me. Listen to me. My people are doing very good. And my people call me. They're in the office; they call me. They call me. When it's right—nobody knows the deal better than I do. When it's right, I'll meet. But right now it's not right. They want a trillion dollars to bail out badly run States—they're Democrat. They're all—I mean, they're Democrat States. Will something happen? Possibly. But I want to tell you, the country is doing very well right now. We can live very happily with it, without it. But I'd like to do it, because I want to give money to the people. I want to put money into the people's hands. They want to put money into politicians' hands so that the politicians don't look stupid.Okay. Steve [Steve A. Holland, Reuters], please?
label: Explicit

sentence: Sir, regarding budget cuts: where will you find savings in Defense and the VA, given the political challenges? [SEP] So many what now?
label: Clarification

sentence: Sir, isn't it true that your behavior is setting a negative precedent for the nation's youth? [SEP] Look, the idea that my actions are somehow harmful is a politically motivated attack. There are clear distinctions for political activities, and we're operating within those guidelines.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Two years ago, you pledged to invest political capital in the Israeli-Palestinian peace process. Looking back, do you believe you've kept that promise? And how do you see the connection between the Israeli-Palestinian situation and achieving stability in Iraq? [SEP] The most important thing is for people to accept the goal of two states living side by side for peace. We're spending a lot of capital getting people headed in the same direction, which if you look at the history of the Middle East, is a change.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, can you confirm whether all current sanctions will continue to be enforced? [SEP] As it stands, the sanctions remain in place. I've heard some of you suggesting we've made concessions, but that's simply inaccurate. I am optimistic that we will develop a very positive relationship with Chairman Kim and North Korea. I believe they possess significant potential, as I have consistently stated. Time will tell. The core issue was sanctions. They sought their removal, but were unwilling to compromise on the key areas we required. They were prepared to offer certain concessions, but not in the areas we considered essential.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. About the NHS, Mr. President, is it part of the negotiation? [SEP] Pardon? Could you repeat that, please?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, President-elect Trump has indicated he might lift sanctions on Russia in exchange for substantial nuclear stockpile reductions. Given your own arms control efforts, do you see this as a sound strategy? Knowing the demands of the office and Mr. Trump's style, what advice would you give his advisors to ensure effective dealings with Vladimir Putin? Furthermore, considering your recent actions regarding Russia, do you believe those sanctions should be viewed as leverage in future negotiations? [SEP] Well, let's consider a few things. First, it's in the best interest of America and the world to foster a constructive relationship with Russia. That's been my guiding principle throughout my presidency. We've collaborated where our interests aligned. Early in my term, I actively encouraged Russia to become a constructive member of the international community, assisting their government in diversifying and strengthening their economy, and channeling the talents of the Russian people into more productive avenues. However, it's fair to say that after President Putin's return to the presidency, an escalating anti-American sentiment and a global approach seemingly based on the idea that anything America does must be detrimental to Russia, leading them to counteract our efforts, has revived a Cold War-era adversarial spirit, making the relationship more challenging. This was further solidified when Russia intervened in Crimea and parts of Ukraine. The sanctions, as you recall, were not imposed due to nuclear weapons issues. They were a response to the violation of Ukraine's independence and sovereignty through force by Russia. This wasn't just our assessment; it was the consensus of the entire international community. Russia continues to occupy Ukrainian territory, meddle in Ukrainian affairs, and support military proxies who have violated fundamental international law and norms. I've communicated to the Russians that the sanctions will be lifted as soon as they cease these actions. To maintain international norms, it's crucial that we don't conflate the reasons for these sanctions with other unrelated issues. Regarding nuclear matters, we negotiated the START II Treaty during my first term, significantly reducing nuclear stockpiles for both Russia and the United States. I was prepared to go further and conveyed this to President Putin, but they were unwilling to negotiate. If President-elect Trump can restart those talks in a meaningful way, there's still considerable potential for further stockpile reductions. Our success in nonproliferation and nuclear security has been partly due to leading by example. I hope that continues. However, it's essential to remember that the sanctions against Russia are a direct result of their actions in Ukraine. The United States must uphold the fundamental principle that larger countries cannot invade and bully smaller ones. I've stated before that I expect Russia and Ukraine to maintain a strong relationship, given their historical, cultural, and social ties. However, Ukraine is an independent nation. This situation exemplifies the vital role America must continue to play in preserving basic norms and values globally, whether advocating for human rights, women's rights, or freedom of the press. The United States hasn't always been perfect in this regard. At times, we must engage with allies and partners who may not fully meet our desired standards for international rules and norms. However, I can assure you that in every multilateral forum—the United Nations, the G-20, the G-7—the United States has consistently championed these values. It's crucial for us to continue doing so, because if the largest, strongest democracy in the world isn't willing to stand up for these values, then certainly China, Russia, and others will not.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. Does it begin with you, Mr. President? [SEP] But I really believe it begins with the media. If you would cover—and there was a very interesting story written in a very good paper recently that talked about the fact that it isn't good what the media is doing and that I do have the right to fight back, because I'm treated very unfairly.So I do fight back. And I'm fighting back not for me; I'm fighting back for the people of this country.Thank you all very much. Thank you.
label: Implicit

sentence: President Trump, beyond denuclearization, what specific actions do you expect from Kim Jong Un regarding human rights? [SEP] We talked about it. Briefly, sure, but we talked. He wants to do things, believe me. He's a smart guy, a good negotiator. He knows the past failures, all the money wasted. This is different. This is me. I campaigned on this, you know. It's very important. Next question.

sentence: Mr. President, concerning the recent Supreme Court ruling on abortion, what specific executive measures are you contemplating, and will you heed the calls for a public health emergency declaration? [SEP] I'll provide a comprehensive update following my discussion with the Governors on Friday. The fundamental issue is the egregious nature of this ruling and its broad impact on privacy. Our priority is to codify Roe into law through Congressional action. Should the filibuster impede this, we must consider an exception, as we should for voting rights. We'll have further announcements soon.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. I wanted to follow up on your comment on Build Back Better and also ask you a question about the pandemic.You said that you're confident you can pass big chunks of Build Back Better this year. Does that wording mean that you are thinking about—you're looking at breaking the package up into individual portions?And then, on the pandemic: Now that the Supreme Court has blocked the vaccination-or-test rule for larger businesses, are you reconsidering whether to require vaccines for domestic flights as a way to boost vaccination rates? [SEP] No, look, first of all, on the last part of the question: The Supreme Court decision, I think, was a mistake. But you still see thousands and thousands of people who work for major corporations having to be tested as a consequence of the decision made by the corporation and not by the standard I set that is there. I think you'll see that increase, not decrease, number one.What was the first part of your question?
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Will you consider supporting Palestinian statehood at the U.N.? [SEP] We're going to do that evaluation. We're going to partly wait for an actual Israeli Government to form.[.] Peace is our priority. Don't make premature judgments. [] And what we have asked from the United States, and has graciously supported it, is to support an Afghan-led and Afghan-owned peace process. And we are confident that this approach will bear the results in time. Peace is always difficult, and it requires focus, attention, and sacrifice, and that's what we are willing to do to bring it about. Mohmand—[inaudible].
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, given the lack of progress in Venezuela, are you reconsidering your strategy? [SEP] I'm not being told when things will change. They've been in power for a while. Eventually, things will change. We haven't used the really tough sanctions yet. All options are open. We're just trying to help the people who are starving and dying in the streets. It's a disgrace. Venezuela used to be one of the wealthiest countries, and now it's poverty-stricken, with no food, water, or power. It's very sad.
label: Deflection

sentence: Sir, to be absolutely clear, are you saying there was no quid pro quo in your dealings with Ukraine? [SEP] The Democrats and the fake news media are obsessed with this quid pro quo nonsense. They're trying to create a scandal where none exists. My focus is, and always has been, on what's best for the United States. We are dealing with serious issues of national security and global corruption, and I won't be distracted by these petty political games.
label: Deflection

sentence: So, in your view, does this election represent a shift towards greater decency and a break from the intense polarization of recent years? [SEP] I don't think we'll ever get everyone on board, but I believe most Republicans are honorable people. The world is watching us closely, especially after what happened on January 6th. They're wondering if America is still a stable democracy. We need to demonstrate that we're committed to our institutions and the rule of law.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, what are your goals for your African tour, and how will the U.S. contribute to the continent's development? [SEP] I went to Africa early in my term as well. This is my second visit, to emphasize that it's in our interest to combat diseases like malaria and HIV/AIDS, to boost trade, and to support education. Ghana is an ideal place to witness this firsthand. Africa has evolved positively during my presidency, thanks to African leaders. Conflict resolution has advanced, such as in Liberia. The U.S. has been a helpful partner, not dictating terms. Democracy is advancing, with role models like John Kufuor. Our aid program now requires good governance in exchange, like combating corruption and investing in education. I believe in holding African leaders to high standards. I'm confident in the leaders I've met on this trip. It's been a wonderful trip.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Are you worried about that? [SEP] I believe I've addressed that matter sufficiently. Next question, please. Mary Bruce, ABC News.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, what specific steps should individuals take if they wish to boycott companies that suppress political viewpoints? [SEP] Look, I'm not going to tell people how to spend their money. That's their choice. But I will say this: if companies are going to try to silence conservatives, people have a right to push back. How they do that is up to them. I'm just pointing out the problem.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Thank you very much, Mr. President. You've spoken a great deal about what you've characterized as kind of a crude form of nationalism, perhaps, on the rise. I'm wondering if you would advise some of those protestors at home to stop demonstrating against some of the charged rhetoric that has been used by Donald Trump. And I'm wondering, as well, if you've advised your successor to be extra mindful of what you see as some very worrisome trends, particularly when it comes to making his own potentially powerful staff picks.Lastly, sir, in these final weeks of your Presidency, do you believe you have any leverage to stop Bashar al-Asad and Vladimir Putin from continuing to bomb Aleppo?Chancellor Merkel, I'd like to ask you, Bashar al-Asad has described Donald Trump as a natural ally. Your own Foreign Minister has described Donald Trump as a preacher of hate. I'm wondering, would you tell Americans that they now have a perception problem? [SEP] One of the great things about our democracy is, it expresses itself in all sorts of ways, and that includes people protesting. I've been the subject of protests during the course of my 8 years, and I suspect that there's not a President in our history that, at some point, hasn't been subject to these protests. So I would not advise people who feel strongly or are concerned about some of the issues that have been raised during the course of the campaign—I wouldn't advise them to be silent.What I would advise—what I advised before the election and what I will continue to advise after the election—is that elections matter, voting matters, organizing matters, being informed on the issues matter. And what I consistently say to young people—I say it in the United States, but I'll say it here in Germany and across Europe—do not take for granted our systems of government and our way of life.I think there is a tendency—because we have lived in an era that has been largely stable and peaceful, at least in advanced countries, where living standards have generally gone up—there is a tendency, I think, to assume that that's always the case. And it's not. Democracy is hard work.In the United States, if 43 percent of eligible voters do not vote, then democracy is weakened. If we are not serious about facts and what's true and what's not—and particularly in an age of social media where so many people are getting their information in soundbites and snippets off their phones—if we can't discriminate between serious arguments and propaganda, then we have problems. If people, whether they are conservative or liberal, left or right, are unwilling to compromise and engage in the democratic process and are taking absolutist views and demonizing opponents, then democracy will break down.And so I think my most important advice is to understand what are the foundations of a healthy democracy, and how we have to engage in citizenship continuously, not just when something upsets us, not just when there's an election, or when an issue pops up for a few weeks.It's hard work. And the good news is, I think there are a lot of young people, certainly, who were involved in my campaigns and I think continue to be involved in work, not just politically but through nonprofits and other organizations, that can carry this hard work of democracy forward.But I do think sometimes there's complacency. Here in Europe, I think that there are a lot of young people who forget the issues that were at stake during the cold war, who forget what it meant to have a wall. And I'll be honest, there have been times when I listened to the rhetoric in Europe where an easy equivalence somehow between the United States and Russia and between how our governments operate versus other governments operate—where those distinctions aren't made. I've said many times around the world that, like any government, like any country, like any set of human institutions, we have our flaws; we've operated imperfectly. There are times when we've made mistakes. There are times where I've made mistakes or our administration hasn't always aligned ourselves with the values that we need to align ourselves with. It's a work of constant improvement.But I can say to the German people that the United States has been good for Germany, has looked out for Germany, has provided security for Germany, has helped to rebuild Germany and unify Germany. And I can say, across Europe, that many principles that have been taken for granted here around free speech and around civil liberties and an independent judiciary and fighting corruption, those are principles that, not perfectly, but generally, we have tried to apply not just in our own country, but also with respect to our foreign policy.And that should be remembered. Because at an age where there's so much active misinformation—and it's packaged very well, and it looks the same when you see it on a Facebook page or you turn on your television—where some overzealousness on the part of a U.S. official is equated with constant and severe repression elsewhere, if everything seems to be the same and no distinctions are made, then we won't know what to protect. We won't know what to fight for. And you—we can lose so much of what we've gained in terms of the kind of democratic freedoms and market-based economies and prosperity that we've come to take for granted.That was a long answer, wasn't it? I don't remember if I—there was a second part to it. I was—I got all caught up in that one [].
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Well, a couple years ago, Charles Krauthammer, columnist and Harvardtrained psychiatrist, coined a term, Bush derangement syndrome, to talk about your critics who disagreed with you most passionately, not just your policies, but seemed to take an animosity towards you. I'm just wondering, as you look back, why you think you engendered such passionate criticism, animosity, and do you have any message specifically to those—to that particular part of the spectrum of your critics? [SEP] You know, most people I see, you know, when I'm moving around the country, for example, they're not angry. And they're not hostile people. And they— well, they say, you never meet people who disagree; that's just not true. I've met a lot of people who don't agree with the decisions I make. But they have been civil in their discourse.And so I view those who get angry and yell and say bad things and, you know, all that kind of stuff, it's just a very few people in the country. I don't know why they get angry. I don't know why they get hostile. It's not the first time, however, in history that people have expressed themselves in sometimes undignified ways. I've been reading, you know, a lot about Abraham Lincoln during my Presidency, and there was some pretty harsh discord when it came to the 16th President, just like there's been harsh discord for the 30—43d President.You know, Presidents can try to avoid hard decisions, and therefore, avoid controversy. That's just not my nature. I'm the kind of person that, you know, is willing to take on hard tasks, and in times of war people get emotional, I understand that. Never really, you know, spent that much time frankly worrying about the loud voices. I of course hear them, but they didn't affect my policy, nor did they affect how I made decisions.You know, the President-elect Obama will find this too. He'll get in the Oval Office, and there will be a lot of people that are real critical and harsh. And he'll be disappointed at times by the tone of the rhetoric. And he's going to have to do what he thinks is right, Jim. And if you don't, then I don't see how you can live with yourself. I don't see how I can get back home in Texas and look in the mirror and be proud of what I see if I allowed the loud voices, the loud critics, to prevent me from doing what I thought was necessary to protect this country.Mike.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, Prime Minister, did you discuss Canada potentially boosting its stimulus efforts? And for both of you, four years from now, what's the future of the Canada-U.S. relationship? Specifically, the auto sector, border security, and a potential carbon market? [SEP] Alright, alright, slow down. You managed to cram about half a dozen questions into one there. [] Did someone put you up to that? []
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, looking back at the significant advancements in LGBT rights during your time in office – including hate crimes legislation, the repeal of 'Don't Ask, Don't Tell,' nationwide marriage equality, and greater visibility and acceptance for transgender individuals – how do you see LGBT rights fitting into your broader legacy? And how hopeful are you that this progress will endure or even expand under the incoming administration? [SEP] I am incredibly proud of the progress our society has made in the last decade. While I believe we contributed in a meaningful way, the true heroes are the activists, the sons and daughters, and the couples who bravely declared, 'This is who I am, and I'm proud.' Their courage opened hearts and minds, and eventually, the laws followed. But none of this would have been possible without their activism, whether loud and visible or quiet and personal. Our administration's role was to help society move forward in a way that minimized backlash and respected the fact that these issues were often controversial. Take, for example, our approach to 'Don't Ask, Don't Tell.' By being methodical, working with the Joint Chiefs, and demonstrating that it wouldn't impact the effectiveness of our military, we were able to achieve meaningful change. I am proud of the work of Secretary Gates, Chairman Mullen, and the Joint Chiefs who were open to evidence and ultimately did the right thing. But again, this wouldn't have happened without the incredible transformation happening in society. When I awarded Ellen the Presidential Medal of Freedom, I meant every word. Her kindness and likability, projected into living rooms across the country, changed attitudes. That wasn't easy for her, and it's just one example of what was happening in communities nationwide. I'm proud that we were able to provide some support to help the movement advance. I believe this progress is irreversible because American society has changed, especially the attitudes of young people. While there will still be important battles to fight, particularly regarding legal issues and transgender rights, the younger generation, even those who identify as Republican or conservative, often struggle to understand discrimination based on sexual orientation. It's deeply ingrained in them.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Even after all you have seen—ISIS prisoners freed, all the humanitarian disaster—you don't have any regret for giving Erdogan the green light to invade? [SEP] I didn't give him a green light.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. What's going on in the housing market? Is it a correction or a crisis, in your view? Can you assess that? [SEP] Yesterday I did comment upon that, that there was a—I talked about the different scenarios that I had been briefed on about whether or not there would be a precipitous decline in housing or whether it would be what one would call a soft landing. And it appeared at this point that it looks we're headed for a soft landing. And that's what the facts say.Thank you. Mike.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, given the ongoing security concerns in the region, are you satisfied with the level of cooperation from Pakistan in combating terrorism? [SEP] We're working closely with Pakistan to address these challenges. We have a strong partnership, and we're committed to supporting their efforts to combat terrorism. We're also encouraging them to take further steps to address the root causes of extremism in their country.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. How soon will journalists be able to have access to the facilities? We've obviously been allowed to be inside one, but we haven't seen the facilities in which children are packed together to really give the American people a chance to see that. Will you commit to transparency on this issue, Mr. President? [SEP] I will commit to transparency and as soon as I am in a position to be able to implement what we are doing right now.And one of the reasons I haven't gone down—I have all my—my chief folks have gone down—is I don't want to become the issue. I don't want to be, you know, bringing all of the Secret Service and everybody with me to get in the way. So this is being set up, and you'll have full access to everything once we get this thing moving.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, with all due respect, the Shanghai Media Group is looking for some clarity. Can you offer any timeframe, even a broad one, for this upcoming meeting? [SEP] I'd love to give you a straight answer, but I just can't. It's all very fluid, very uncertain. Let's just say it'll happen when it happens. I'm optimistic, but I can't make any promises.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Can I ask you one last quick thing on China? [SEP] Yes go. Please.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. You met today with his successor. Did you have a similar experience, and what was your take? [SEP] I did find him to be trustworthy, and he was trustworthy.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Another round of trade talks with China, Mr. President? [SEP] China is going very well. Talks with China are going very well.Thank you, everybody. Thank you.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. I am Cho Young-min from Channel A. Thank you very much for giving me this opportunity to pose a question. We—this is an extension of the previous question.We talked about how to respond to the evolving nuclear threat of North Korea, that you said that you're going to present an action plan to strengthen the effect of extended deterrence. So, regarding that action plan, I wonder what kind of specific discussions you had today. Did you see eye to eye on this action plan? [SEP] In the past, when it came to extended deterrence, we just talked about a nuclear umbrella. That was what I thought about extended deterrence in the past.But beyond that, there could be many other aspects, including fighters, bombers, and missiles. So, regarding the timely deployment of such strategic assets, we did engage in the discussions today. And going forward, I believe that there will be more concrete discussions between our two sides. That was our agreement, and it will be between our NSCs.And also, as I already stated in the course of answering the question from the U.S. journalist: In order to prepare against a possible nuclear attack, our two countries combined military exercises, I believe, should be stepped up in many aspects. We had that discussion.Thank you.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Hello, Mr. President, I am Park from CBS. And I would like to, first of all, welcome President Trump upon your second visit to the Republic of Korea. At the restricted bilateral meeting this morning, President Moon, you had mentioned that you will be accompanying President Trump to the DMZ, but the focus of the dialogue that will happen at the DMZ will be between President Trump and Chairman Kim. And you said that you are looking forward to much progress being achieved there.So at—once the contact is established between President Trump and Chairman Kim at the DMZ, what kind of progress do you expect in the subsequent negotiations? And is—how about the possibility of a third U.S.-North Korea summit happening before the end of the year?And my third question relates to the written interview that you had given to various agencies recently. And in that interview, you had mentioned that if North Korea, under complete inspection verification from the international community—if North Korea dismantles the nuclear complex in Yongbyon—then the international community could explore the sanctions relief, a partial sanctions relief.So has there been any discussions regarding this issue this morning? And what was the response from the U.S. side? [SEP] Yes. To answer your question, yes, I have been invited to visit Panmunjom with President Trump this afternoon. However, as I had mentioned, the focus of the dialogue today will be the dialogue between the United States and . And of course, President Trump and Chairman Kim will have a reunion and have subsequent dialogue, and I hope that—and I do believe that this is vastly significant for the dialogue that will follow after the meeting today.And also, today there will be a dialogue between the United States and . But as for the inter-Korean dialogue, this will happen at a later time.As for the question regarding the third U.S.- summit, I believe that how the reunion and the dialogue and the meeting turns out this afternoon will have a great say on when and whether the U.S.- summit will happen for the third time. So I do expect some progress there.As for the last question, the—what I had explained was that if goes through the dismantlement in a genuine way—dismantlement of the nuclear complex in Yongbyon—then this will mean that we will be entering—we will be arriving at the entrance of irreversible, substantive denuclearization. So if this indeed is implemented, then the international community will able to discuss a partial sanctions relief. I—my words were in this context.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, what specific conditions would constitute a successful resolution to the conflict, from the perspective of the United States? [SEP] The only acceptable outcome is for him to be gone. He needs to relinquish power and allow the people to determine their own future. We will continue to support the people in their fight for freedom and democracy.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, critics argue that your approach to both Syria and North Korea lacks a clear strategy. How do you respond to those criticisms, and what specific metrics are you using to measure success in these regions? [SEP] Let me tell you, we're doing great. The best. Nobody has ever done it like we're doing it. The media is fake news. They don't understand what's happening. We're making tremendous progress. You'll see. Just wait. We're going to win. Bigly.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, with so many 9/11 plotters still awaiting trial, what message does that send about our justice system? Why are you still pushing for a civilian trial for Khalid Sheikh Mohammed? What's causing the delay? And will Guantanamo remain open? [SEP] We've kept many promises, but closing Guantanamo is one we haven't been able to achieve yet. I wanted it done sooner, but the politics are complicated. I strongly believe the American justice system is capable of convicting those who murdered Americans and committed acts of terror. We can lock them up and make sure they never see the light of day. We've done it before. But there's been a lot of political rhetoric surrounding this, and people are understandably fearful. However, we are a resilient nation and shouldn't be intimidated by a handful of captured terrorists. In some cases, a military tribunal might be more appropriate, such as when it's difficult to assemble a chain of evidence that meets the standards of a regular court. We can reform the military commission system to ensure it meets the highest standards of due process. I'm prepared to collaborate with both parties to establish a sensible system for prosecuting terrorists in either regular courts or military tribunals, and then incarcerate them in secure prisons. The cost of maintaining Guantanamo is significantly higher.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. A question from BFMTV. Both of you today have talked about coordination, cooperation against Daesh. Does it mean that this single coalition—which you mentioned last week, President Hollande—is gone? That it is inconceivable to have the Russians and the Americans to work together under this single command?And then Bashar al-Asad, you said you could not put a date on his departure. Does it mean that his departure is not a preamble or prerequisite for the future of Syria? [SEP] Regarding the coalition of the international community, I believe that the resolution approved by all at the Security Council enabled us to say that now the entire world is committed to fighting against Daesh Then—and this is what I will check when I travel to Moscow—we need one single goal; that is, to tackle terrorism and fight against Daesh militarily And I believe that we can have some further cooperation and coordination militarily to do moreAt the same time, we have to be clear when it comes to the political solution, the one that will enable us to find an outcome for Syria And in this respect, like we've said, and—but we can repeat it, Bashar al-Asad cannot be the future of SyriaIn Vienna, we are already working with all of the countries, even though they do not necessarily—they do not have the same stance: Turkey, Iran, Gulf countries, the United States, France, and of course, all of those who are meant to find a solution But we must work on that transition, a transition where Bashar al-Asad plays no role Because he's been the problem, so he cannot be the solution Just to comment very quickly, we've got a coalition of 65 countries who have been active in pushing back against ISIL for quite some time France has been a central part of that coalition, as have European countries, Arab countries Countries as far flung as Australia and countries in Southeast Asia are part of that coalitionRussia right now is a coalition of two, Iran and Russia, supporting Asad Given Russia's military capabilities and given the influence they have on the Asad regime, them cooperating would be enormously helpful in bringing about a resolution of the civil war in Syria and allow us all to refocus our attention on ISILBut I think it's important for—to remember that you've got a global coalition organized Russia is the outlier We hope that they refocus their attention on what is the most substantial threat and that they serve as a constructive partner And if and when they do, it will make it easier for us to go after ISIL and DaeshAlthough I think it's also important to recognize that the kinds of airstrikes that they're carrying out—just like the kinds of airstrikes that we're carrying out—in and of themselves are not sufficient And the work that we do to bolster local fighting forces, the cutting off of supply lines, financing, oil, reducing the flow of foreign fighters, the intelligence work that needs to be done—all of that is something that we are doing now and that they can supplementBut that's going to be a process that involves hard, methodical work It's not going to be something that happens just because suddenly we take a few more airstrikes And that's the kind of hard work that I know France is prepared to do, the United States is prepared to do, and perhaps, in the future, Russia will be as well Okay?Thank you very much, everybody
label: Implicit

sentence: With respect to the investigation, can you tell us where it is taking place? Also, are you confident in the investigation's ability to be unbiased? [SEP] I am not at liberty to disclose the location of the investigation. I am purposely not getting involved in the investigation, because I am the head of law enforcement in this country. I believe that the Attorney General should handle the matter because he is working with a very respected man, Durham. I cannot give you any further details at this time.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, American companies have been investing in India for a long time. Are you satisfied with the Indian investment climate, particularly regarding multibrand retail and e-commerce, where U.S. firms have significant interest? [SEP] I am very satisfied because they are investing tremendous amounts of money. Look at Mr. Patel, the largest steel person in the world, he is building a billion-dollar plant in Alabama. The press was in there with some of the biggest entrepreneurs in the world. They said it is much better to work in the United States now, in terms of their investment. The steel industry was dead, but now it is vibrant. We need it for defense. Mr. Patel is spending a billion dollars in Alabama because we brought it back. We are very proud of that.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. On the question of ISIS expansion that you've been talking about, because you see them expanding around the world, because you see them trying to inspire attacks, what is your current level of concern about the homeland? You talked about the protection measures, but what is your assessment about the possibility—your own intelligence advisers suggest it's possible—about the direct ISIS threat to Americans? And if I may follow up, somewhat along the same lines, what is your assessment today as you stand here about whether Donald Trump can be trusted with America's nuclear weapons? [SEP] On your second question—and I'll sort of address this to any additional Trump questions—[]—I would ask all of you to just make your own judgment. I've made this point already multiple times. Just listen to what Mr. Trump has to say and make your own judgment with respect to how confident you feel about his ability to manage things like our nuclear triad.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. I'm going to keep the trend and also ask two questions, if that's okay. One on the summit and one domestic question.On the summit, you just said that there would be another round of security assistance for Ukraine. After hearing President Zelenskyy's assessment that the war needs to end before the winter, are you changing your calculation in terms of the pace of the assistance and what kind of assistance you're sending to Ukraine? [SEP] No, I—the war could end tomorrow, by the way, if Russia stops its irrational behavior. So, you know, when the war will end, I hope it ends sooner than later.But for it to end, they have to be in a position where the Ukrainians have all that they can reasonably expect, we can reasonably expect to get to them, in order to provide for their physical security and their defenses.And so one does not relate to the other. They need—we're going to be providing another—well, I guess I'll announce it shortly, but another $800 billion—$800 million in aid for additional weaponry, including—you know, weapons—including air defense system, as well as offensive weapons. I have a whole list I'd be happy to give to you. But that's the next tranche that's going to occur.
label: Explicit

sentence: President, what concrete measures are you implementing to further your pro-life agenda? [SEP] We're continuing to push. I've been pushing hard, and we've seen positive results. But it's a complex issue with deeply held beliefs on both sides.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, a question from the Japanese media outlet? [SEP] Yes, a question from the Japanese media. We are indeed concerned about the events unfolding in Japan.
label: General

sentence: Q. What about this economic development bill that you mentioned, can you give us any of the details of what your plans are? [SEP] I'm going to be proposing an economic development bill in the not-too-distant future. I want to get tax cuts, obviously, done first; maybe even the health care. But I think somewhere in between or shortly thereafter, I'm going to be developing an economic development bill that will put us so far ahead of other countries you will not even believe it. That will be very important.
label: General

sentence: Q. ——May 1 deadline? [SEP] No.
label: Explicit

sentence: Given the current congressional stalemate surrounding the Trans-Pacific Partnership, are you considering alternative strategies to ensure its passage, particularly in light of the recent agreements with Boeing and GE in Vietnam? Furthermore, what are your views on amending the agreement to address concerns regarding currency manipulation? [SEP] Look, I've been around long enough to know that trade deals are always a tough sell. Everyone's looking for a better deal, especially with multiple parties involved. And in an election year, you can bet some folks will try to score political points. That being said, I'm confident we'll get it done because it's the right thing to do. It's good for America, good for the region, good for the world. This is the fastest-growing part of the world, a huge market for the U.S. Most countries here already sell their stuff to us with relatively low tariffs, while our goods face significantly higher tariffs there. So, a deal that eliminates 18,000 taxes on U.S. goods in these markets is a win for American businesses and workers. Historically, trade deals have been criticized for exposing us to countries with lower wages and lax labor and environmental standards. But TPP includes enforceable commitments to raise labor standards and address environmental problems. This allows us to engage with countries like Vietnam on these issues. I haven't seen a credible argument that TPP will make us worse off. We'll demonstrably be better off. American workers and businesses will benefit. The politics will be noisy, like with the Korean, Colombian, and Panamanian free trade agreements I inherited. But we got those done, and we'll get this done too, despite the bumps along the way. As for currency manipulation, TPP includes provisions for transparency and reporting. Some argue for enforceable provisions allowing us to impose tariffs if currency is devalued. But it's hard to determine when currency is being manipulated. Binding other countries on monetary policy would mean binding our Federal Reserve, which we won't do. We've strengthened provisions to put folks on notice if we think they're engaging in competitive devaluations. Finally, regarding the Taliban leader, Mullah Mansur, his death has been confirmed. He targeted U.S. personnel in Afghanistan. This doesn't represent a shift in our approach. We're not re-entering combat operations. Our job is to help Afghanistan secure itself. However, when a high-profile leader consistently targets U.S. personnel and resists peace talks, it's my responsibility to protect our people. That's the message we've sent.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, some observers are drawing parallels between Mr. Lopez Obrador's statements and those of historical figures like Hitler and Mussolini. What is your perspective on these comparisons, and do you believe they contribute to the unity you have consistently promoted among Mexicans, especially in relation to the energy bill debate in our Mexican Congress? [SEP] The only individuals to whom such comparisons can be fairly attributed are those who make them. The Mexican Congress is functioning normally, with a responsible attitude displayed by the majority of political parties represented there. Members from the PRI, PAN, the Green Party, the New Alliance, and other political parties are working diligently. I simply deplore this behavior, which only serves to damage the image of those responsible and further undermine the presence of Mexican parties as significant as the PRD, which, in addition to their own internal challenges, are losing public confidence due to the actions of individuals who simply make them appear foolish. I am hopeful that our institutional life will be strengthened and that we will enhance dialogue and the capacity for communication among ourselves. The issue you mentioned is already under the purview of the authorities, and I am confident that a new electoral authority, such as the IFE, will render a decision based on what it deems appropriate in light of the TV spots you referenced.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, the public is not concerned about the complexity of the issue, but about the lack of clear and consistent guidelines. If the CDC is doing a pretty good job, then why is the public so confused? Why is public confidence declining? Why not make personnel changes to address these issues? [SEP] I think it's important to put things in perspective. The public is always going to be confused when dealing with a novel virus. There's a lot of misinformation out there, and it's hard to know what to believe. But I'm confident that we're on the right track, and that we'll get through this. And as for personnel changes, I'm always evaluating the performance of my team, and I'll make changes if I think they're necessary. But I'm not going to make changes just to appease the media.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Mr. President, would direct talks between the United States and Iran and Syria help stem the violence in Iraq? And would you agree to such a step? [SEP] I think that, first of all, Iraq is a sovereign nation which is conducting its own foreign policy. They're having talks with their neighbors. And if that's what they think they ought to do, that's fine. I hope their talks yield results. One result that Iraq would like to see is for the Iranians to leave them alone. If Iran is going to be involved in their country, they ought to be involved in a constructive way, encouraging peace. That is the message that the Iranians—the Iraqis have delivered to the Iranians. That's the message that Prime Minister Maliki has made clear, that he expects the neighbors to encourage peaceful development of the country.As far as the United States goes, Iran knows how to get to the table with us, and that is to do that which they said they would do, which is verifiably suspend their enrichment programs. One of the concerns that I have about the Iranian regime is their desire to develop a nuclear weapon, and you ought to be concerned about it too. The idea of this regime having a nuclear weapon by which they could blackmail the world is unacceptable to free nations. And that's why we're working through the United Nations to send a clear message that the EU-3 and the United States, Russia, and China do not accept their desires to have a nuclear weapon.There is a better way forward for the Iranian people. And if they would like to be at the table discussing this issue with the United States, I have made it abundantly clear how they can do so, and that is, verifiably suspend the enrichment program. And then we'll be happy to have a dialog with them.But as far as Iraq goes, the Iraqi Government is a sovereign government that is capable of handling its own foreign policies and is in the process of doing so. And they have made it abundantly clear, and I agree with them, that the Iranians and the Syrians should help, not destabilize this young democracy.Thank you. Thank you very much.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. But your Deputy National Security Adviser said that it is not your intention to attack if Congress doesn't approve it. Is he right? [SEP] I don't think that's exactly what he said. But I think I've answered the question.Major Garrett [CBS News].

sentence: So, five years in, what have you learned from this war that'll guide you for the rest of your time in office? [SEP] Gotta look at what didn't work, right? The big problem's been the fighting between the different groups in Baghdad. It's made it tough to help the Iraqi government get on its feet. So, we're figuring out how to help them stop it. There's different parts of the war. Baghdad's a mess, and we're fighting the Sunni guys. We're doing okay there. South's got its own problems. But Baghdad's the real headache. We haven't gotten as far as we wanted in helping them run things themselves. That mosque bombing really stirred things up. To win, we need the military stuff, the politics, and rebuilding to all work together. We need to do the politics and the rebuilding at the same time as the military stuff. We're figuring out what went wrong and what we thought would happen but didn't.
