sentence: On Libya, when do you foresee command being transferred, and is NATO the preferred partner? Also, regarding your "alliance among equals" with the Americas, what specific outcomes are you pursuing after this trip? And President Pinera, what is the substance of this partnership to achieve regional goals? [SEP] Regarding Libya, the situation is constantly evolving on the ground. The speed of the transfer depends on our commanding officers' assessment that the initial mission phase is complete. Our primary goal is neutralizing Libyan air defenses to ensure a no-fly zone's effectiveness and the safety of coalition aircraft. Secondly, we're focused on the humanitarian aspects of the mission. We anticipate this transition within days, not weeks. The Pentagon will keep the public and press informed. NATO will coordinate due to its capabilities. Admiral Mullen can provide specifics on the transfer process. As for the partnership, I don't want to give away my speech's highlights. Chile offers us as much as we offer them. Their clean energy work is impressive, leading to a clean energy partnership. We're strong in alternative energy, but Chile's initiatives might benefit us. On education, we want American students to look outward, hence an exchange program with the Americas. Security cooperation: We can learn from Colombia's success against narcotraffickers and apply those lessons to Central America. Collaboration with Chile and Colombia can enhance security training in Central America. This partnership is a two-way street, not just a developed country helping a poor one. Chile is a rising regional power collaborating with us for peace and prosperity. We lag in the Americas' integration compared to Europe's post-war unity. Latin America needs to fulfill its potential. We share much with the U.S.: territory, hardworking people, and fewer conflicts. We aim for a Partnership 2.0, sharing responsibilities and values. It should encompass democracy, freedom, rule of law, human rights, free trade, education, science, and technology. We can learn from the U.S.'s innovation. This alliance addresses energy, water, organized crime, terrorism, and global warming. It calls for a new international order. The time is right for collaboration, facing challenges and seizing opportunities. Latin America missed the Industrial Revolution; we can't miss the information revolution. No country should be left behind.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Given the promising preliminary results of this experimental drug, would you consider expediting its approval process within the United States? [SEP] Well, that's a hypothetical I'm not prepared to address at this juncture. The data is still preliminary, and I need a more comprehensive understanding before I can offer a considered opinion. It's simply too early to say.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, concerning the Iran deal, some critics are concerned about the specifics of the implementation. Can you assure the American public that the US will not concede on key issues such as immediate lifting of sanctions and inspection of military sites? [SEP] Well, let me address that directly. We have a framework agreement with Iran and the P5+1. Some aspects are very specific, like the reduction of centrifuges at Natanz. Other aspects are more about intent. The details matter. How those details are interpreted will be subject to negotiation. It's inaccurate to suggest that everything is done. This framework, if implemented, will ensure Iran doesn't have a nuclear weapon. The details are important, and there will be tough negotiations. I said this from the beginning. There's no contradiction. Even with the interim agreement, there was back-and-forth. But we achieved something substantial that was effective, even according to critics like the Israelis. They said it worked. Now they are suggesting we stay here. On Cuba, we didn't get into that level of detail. The state sponsor of terrorism recommendation will come to me. I will review it. Congress will have an opportunity to review it as well. The concerns around the Embassy are mostly on the Cuban side. We're confident it can lead to improved dialogue and prospects for the Cuban people. I want to thank the people of Panama. I am very optimistic about this region because of its people. It is a great gift to the United States to have such strong friends and partners.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: If I understand correctly, this is beneficial for both the economy and the environment, but it's not a policy you'd legally require? Is that accurate? [SEP] I'm afraid I didn't quite understand your question. Could you say it again?

sentence: So, Mr. President, what concrete steps are you prepared to take? [SEP] Let's move on.

sentence: Q. Mr. President, there's growing controversy in Iraq over the security agreement. Some officials want a smaller U.S. presence. Does this worry you? [SEP] Well, there's always noise in any system. But we'll get a strategic agreement. Some stories say we want permanent bases there, but that's wrong. We're there at Iraq's invitation. It shows security is improving, which helps democracy and the economy. We're bringing troops home as things improve. Progress is substantial. I love the idea of freedom for everyone.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. You spoke a bit about Iran today and your discussions, and I'm wondering if you could tell us what you think Iran needs to do to reduce some of the tensions. And you've met with the leaders of North Korea and Russia. Are you prepared also—are you willing to meet with President Rouhani? And under what conditions? And have there been any preliminary discussions about something like that? [SEP] I'll meet with anybody. I believe in meeting. The Prime Minister said it better than anybody can say it: Speaking to other people, especially when you're talking about potentials of war and death and famine and lots of other things, you meet. There's nothing wrong with meeting. We met, as you know, with Chairman Kim. And it—you haven't had a missile fired off in 9 months. We got our prisoners back. So many things have happened so positive.But meeting with people—I had a great meeting, in my opinion. Of course, the fake news didn't cover it that way. But I had a great meeting with President Putin of Russia. I think it was a great meeting. In terms of the future, in terms of safety and economic development and protecting Israel and protecting everybody, I thought it was a great meeting.Great meeting with NATO. I just explained NATO. Hundreds of billions of dollars more money will be paid into NATO, the coffers of NATO. And much already has.So I believe in meeting. I would certainly meet with if they wanted to meet. I don't know that they're ready yet. They're having a hard time right now. But I ended the deal; it was a ridiculous deal. I do believe that they will probably end up wanting to meet, and I'm ready to meet any time they want to. And I don't do that from strength or from weakness. I think it's an appropriate thing to do. If we could work something out that's meaningful, not the waste of paper that the other deal was, I would certainly be willing to meet.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Mr. President Trump, with all due respect, Nigeria urgently requires those Tucano aircraft to combat pressing security issues. Is there any possibility of expediting the delivery of at least two aircraft before 2020 to assist in addressing the crisis? And, if I may, when might we anticipate a visit from you to Nigeria? [SEP] Nigeria, a truly remarkable nation. I've heard it said that its natural beauty is unparalleled. A visit would be something. Now, regarding the first part of your question, I didn't quite catch it. Could you repeat it?

sentence: President Lee, North Korea's impending rocket launch is a concern. If they proceed despite warnings, what specific actions will South Korea take, including sanctions and the status of extending South Korea's missile range? [SEP] Let me reiterate: a launch would violate UN resolutions. If proceeds, it defies its commitments. The international community urges them to reconsider. If they proceed, they bear full responsibility, deepening their isolation. The people of will see their leader spending millions on a missile while they suffer. This will reveal the true nature of their leadership. Domestically, they may seek some objective, but they will face a difficult situation. I urge them to act responsibly for the sake of their people. The US and South Korea agree on this. We will remain calm and wise. Regarding missile range, we did not discuss it directly, though officials have. It's part of enhancing our overall defense capabilities.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, when will the public be able to see the specifics of your plan for addressing gun violence, including a potential assault weapons ban? [SEP] We'll be rolling that out in the near future. Details to follow.

sentence: Mr. President, are you considering withholding federal funding from states that are not cooperating with your administration's policies? [SEP] I wouldn't go that far. I believe we can work together constructively. They'll come around. They need our expertise and resources. And frankly, we're in a much stronger position than when I took office. The previous administration... well, let's just say they weren't prepared for this. But these governors, they'll respect the office of the President. It's not about me; it's about the Presidency. We can talk about federalism and the Constitution all day, but the key is to let the governors manage their states and offer assistance when needed. Yes, John.

Very optimistic.

sentence: Mr. President, can you clarify what specific safeguards you believe are necessary to ensure the integrity of mail-in voting in Nevada, beyond signature verification? sentence: Mr. President, with growing concerns about energy independence and environmental sustainability, why haven't you prioritized renewable energy sources over fossil fuels? We're investing in research and development of renewable energy technologies, but we also need to continue to utilize our existing fossil fuel resources. We're working to reduce our dependence on foreign oil and create a more sustainable energy future for our nation.

sentence: Mr. President, you recently met with Prime Minister Najib, who is currently facing allegations of corruption and human rights violations. During your town hall meeting, you stated that you would raise these issues with him privately. Could you elaborate on the specific message you conveyed to Prime Minister Najib regarding the investment funds scandal and the imprisonment of his political opponents? [SEP] With regard to the refugee program, the recent events in Paris, which occurred just a week ago, remain fresh in our minds. Given the rapid pace of news dissemination, it is easy to lose sight of significant events. However, the recent attacks in Paris, coupled with the similarities between Paris and numerous American cities, have understandably heightened public concern, leading to the swift passage of legislation in the House. It is my hope that, with a period of reflection, the public will recognize that refugees seeking entry into the United States undergo the most rigorous and thorough vetting process imaginable. This process, which has been refined over several administrations on a bipartisan basis, is exceptionally comprehensive and typically requires between 18 and 24 months for approval. While the House legislation may appear straightforward on its face, its practical effect could be to paralyze the system and prevent the admission of refugees. The imposition of additional layers of bureaucracy that do not enhance security but merely render processing nearly impossible would effectively terminate the refugee program for those who desperately require it. My reference to a betrayal of our values was specifically directed at commentary suggesting that we might prioritize the admission of Christians over Muslims or expressing the unfounded fear that a four-year-old orphan might pose a threat. Those of you who accompanied me to the refugee center witnessed these children firsthand. If you are a parent and you observed their plight, you would undoubtedly agree that we must find a place for them within the United States. To deny them refuge would be a violation of our fundamental principles. Fortunately, the vast majority of the public, aware of the extensive screening measures already in place, would concur that we must uphold our moral obligation to these children. Turning to the matter of Prime Minister Najib, it is my policy not to comment on ongoing investigations, whether they are conducted within the United States or in foreign jurisdictions. However, I did emphasize to Prime Minister Najib, as I have done with numerous other leaders, the paramount importance of transparency, accountability, and the eradication of corruption, all of which are essential prerequisites for sustainable development. I also underscored the significance of civil society and a free press. While nations exist at varying stages of development, certain fundamental principles are universally applicable. The recent historic election in Myanmar serves as a testament to the potential for progress. While Myanmar may not immediately mirror the democratic practices of Sweden, a profound transformation is underway, and it is our duty to encourage and support this evolution. Our efforts, through initiatives such as the Open Government Partnership and the incorporation of transparency provisions in trade agreements like the TPP, are designed to raise the bar and promote higher standards of governance. While progress may be uneven, the overarching trajectory is towards a world where individuals are treated with fairness, the rule of law is upheld, governments are accountable, and all voices are heard. These values are not merely American values; they are universal values that should be embraced by all nations. Thank you.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: President Biden, concerning the recent announcement about accepting citizens from Venezuela, Haiti, Cuba, and Nicaragua, what is the projected timeframe for implementation? Are there considerations to expand the number of accepted individuals or include other nations in this program? Additionally, what is the overall investment allocated for technological advancements within the United States? President López Obrador, what measures will Mexico undertake to accommodate the migrants being deported from the United States? Could you provide details regarding the purpose and operation of the new migration center in southern Mexico? Following this summit, can we anticipate substantial changes in migration policies and the treatment of migrants? Lastly, President Biden, regarding fentanyl, what specific actions will be implemented to combat its production and distribution? What effect has the arrest of Ovidio Guzmán had on the Cartel of the Pacific, a key fentanyl producer? Furthermore, were the energy sector consultations under the USMCA/T-MEC agreement discussed with Prime Minister Trudeau? [SEP] We're working with our partners in the region to address the challenges of migration. It's a shared responsibility, and we're committed to finding humane and effective solutions. We're providing assistance to countries in need and working to address the root causes of migration. As for fentanyl, we're taking aggressive action to stop the flow of this deadly drug. We're working with our partners to disrupt drug trafficking networks and hold those responsible accountable.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the NHS, is it on the table for discussion during trade talks? [SEP] Excuse me? Could you repeat the question?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. I'd like to ask you a question first, Mr. President. Et ensuite une au President de la Republique.Interpreter. I'm going to question the President of the Republic. Q. President Bush, Iraqi Prime Minister Nuri al-Maliki says that talks on a status of forces agreement are at an impasse, or a dead end—not dead, but in trouble. How do you break this impasse, and are the conditions that the United States have set forward in support so far nonnegotiable?[At this point, the reporter asked a question in French, and it was translated as follows.] Q. And to you, President, is the Franco-American relationship the privilege, the priority number-one relationship in the transatlantic context? [SEP] Olivier, if I were a betting man, we'll reach an agreement with the Iraqis. And it's—you know, of course we're there at their invitation; this is a sovereign nation. And therefore, we're working hard with the elected Government of Iraq about, you know, U.S. presence and coalition presence in a way that the elected Government is comfortable.And it's interesting to be in—working with a democracy where, you know, people are trying to prepare the ground to get something passed through Parliament, for example, or the free press is vibrant. But we're going to work hard to accommodate their desires. It's their country.And at the same time, we believe that a strategic relationship with Iraq is important. It's important for Iraq; it's important for the United States; it's important for the region. And I repeat to you that whatever we agreed to, it will not commit future Presidents to troop levels, nor will it establish permanent bases.Anyway, we'll see how it goes. And thanks for the question in English. [] Well, the Americans and the French have had a privileged relationship for two centuries now. I mean, when the United States of America was born, France made a choice. It was not a European choice, because we chose to side with the Americans or the United States of America as opposed to Britain at the time. And in two World Wars, we've been together. We share the same values.So yes, it is a privileged relationship, but it's not privileged since I came to be elected; it's been privileged for two centuries now. You can't neglect that. Now, through this—throughout that, we have had ups and downs—hiccups—because two peoples— I'm talking about the French and the American peoples—that actually resemble one another. We express our feelings. The American people can be heard, and likewise for the French people. We have to be careful about this. We have to be mindful of this when we talk to one another in our relations.I have always seen American leaders— and thank you to President Bush—for accepting European originality and independence and, of course, French originality and independence. And I've always noted that we can talk very frankly when we had points of disagreement. But we have to do so in—as allies and as friends, and be mindful of not hurting one another. We can agree on an issue, on the substance of issue, but we don't have to say so in an unpleasant manner. It so happens that today we have a lot of areas of convergence. But yes, maybe on such and such an issue, we don't totally agree, but it doesn't in any way undermine the basis of what I have to say, which is that the Americans are our friends and our allies. They know they can count on us.Might I add that it seems to me that the more you trust somebody, the more trust there is on both sides of the Atlantic, the more leeway we have. We don't ask the United States to apologize to us because they have their own vision of their strategic interests, and they don't ask us to apologize for the fact that we are defending our own strategic interests, precisely because the relationship is a strong one; it is a calm one. And when a relationship is that strong, you accept one's divergences or differences. And that is my whole point. You've got to understand, if you're in a strong relationship, then you have more room for freedom, more room for maneuver. That's what this is all about.Perhaps one last question? Oh. [] One more, last.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. On that note, Mr. President, last night, in tweets that were deleted by Twitter, you said that Dr. Fauci misled the country about hydroxychloroquine. How so? [SEP] No, not at all. I think—I don't even know what his stance is on it. I was just—you know, he was at the—he was at the Task Force meeting a little while ago.I have a very good relationship with Dr. Fauci. You know, it's sort of interesting—we've listened to Dr. Fauci. I haven't always agreed with him, and it's, I think, pretty standard. That's okay. He did not want us to ban our—this—this—put up the ban to China, when China was heavily infected—very badly, Wuhan. He didn't want to do that, and I did. And other things. And he told me I was right, and he told me I saved tens of thousands of lives, which was generous, but it's—you know, I think it's fact that I banned—I did the ban on Europe. But I get along with him very well and I agree with a lot of what he's said.So—you know, it's interesting: He's got a very good approval rating, and I like that. I—it's good. Because remember, he's working for this administration. He's working with us, John. We could have gotten other people. We could have gotten somebody else. It didn't have to be Dr. Fauci. He's working with our administration. And, for the most part, we've done pretty much what he and others—Dr. Birx and others, who are terrific—recommended.And he's got this high approval rating, so why don't I have a high approval rating with respect—and the administration, with respect to the virus? We should have a very high, because what we've done in terms of—we're just reading off about the masks and the gowns and the ventilators and numbers that nobody has seen, and the testing at 55 million tests; we tested more than anybody in the world. I have a graph that I'd love to show you—perhaps you've seen it—where we're up here and the rest of the world is down at a level that's just a tiny fraction of what we've done, in terms of testing.So it sort of is curious: A man works for us—with us, very closely, Dr. Fauci, and Dr. Birx also highly thought of. And yet they're highly thought of, but nobody likes me. It can only be my personality. That's all.Go ahead.
label: General

sentence: Q. But can you do it without them? [SEP] We will implement it. There will bewe have a backup Federal exchange. If States aren't cooperating, we set up a Federal exchange so that people can access that Federal exchange.But yes, it puts more of a burden on us. And it's ironic, since all these folks say that they believe in empowering States, that they're going to end up having the Federal Government do something that we'd actually prefer States to do if they were properly cooperating.Let's see how we're doing on time here. Last question, Antonieta Cadiz [El Mercurio]where's Antonieta? There you are. Tell those big guys to get out of your way. []
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Mr. President, dozens of American troops have been killed this month, and sectarian violence appears to be rising again in Iraq. And you yourself just said that you're expecting more casualties in the weeks and months ahead. How much longer do you believe you can sustain your current policy in Iraq without significant progress on the ground? And how confident are you about finding those missing soldiers? [SEP] I'm confident that the military is doing everything it can to find the missing soldiers. I talked to General Petraeus about this subject and Secretary Gates. And General Petraeus informs him that we're using all the intelligence and all the troops we can find—to find them. It's a top priority of our people there in Iraq.Obviously, the loss of life is—it is devastating to families. I fully understand that. But I want to remind you as to why I sent more troops in. It was to help stabilize the capital. You're asking me, How much longer? We have yet to even get all our troops in place. General David Petraeus laid out a plan for the Congress. He talked about a strategy all aiming—all aimed at helping this Iraqi Government secure its capital so that they can do the—some of the political work necessary, the hard work necessary to reconcile.And as I explained in my opening remarks, all the troops won't be there until mid-June. And one reason you're seeing more fighting is because our troops are going into new areas, along with the Iraqis. And so General Petraeus has said, Why don't you give us until September, and let me report back, to not only me but to the United States Congress, about progress?I would like to see us in a different configuration at some point in time in Iraq. However, it's going to require taking control of the capital. And the best way to do that was to follow the recommendations of General Petraeus. As I have constantly made clear, the recommendations of Baker-Hamilton appeal to me, and that is to be embedded and to train and to guard the territorial integrity of the country and to have Special Forces to chase down Al Qaida. But I didn't think we could get there unless we increased the troop levels to secure the capital. I was fearful that violence would spiral out of control in Iraq and that this experience of trying to help this democracy would—couldn't succeed.And so therefore, the decisions I made are all aimed at getting us to a different position; and the timing of which will be decided by the commanders on the ground, not politicians here in Washington.Chen [Edwin Chen, Los Angeles Times]. Ed, excuse me. That's Henry [Ed Henry, Cable News Network]. Chen. Yes, you're coming down there; no, sorry. Work the print people a little bit, see. I've got the strategy: print. Ed, sorry.
label: Explicit

sentence: President Obama, President Dilma, the perception gap: Brazil as global versus regional. How do you reconcile these viewpoints? [SEP] Let me also address the question posed to President Dilma. We view Brazil as a global power, not just regional. The G-20, a key economic platform, has Brazil as a major voice. The Paris climate negotiations need Brazil's leadership. Their renewable energy commitments demonstrate this. Brazil is a major global player. I told President Dilma last night that the U.S., despite its power, can't solve global issues alone. Global health requires Brazil's partnership to prevent pandemics. Climate change, terrorism, poverty – all require Brazil's involvement. They are an indispensable partner.I have an excellent relationship with President Dilma. I trust her completely. She's always been candid about Brazil's interests. She delivers on her promises. The defense cooperation agreements we discussed in Panama? She got them through Congress – a difficult task. This shows her reliability.Our meeting builds on deeper cooperation. Differences will arise, but that's true of all close friends and allies. We share common values, strong people-to-people relations, and similar histories. We should be strong partners for years to come.Part of my answer was already provided by [Obama], and I thank him for that. Countries experience crises. This shouldn't diminish their role. A great country overcomes difficulties. This applies to nations, individuals, and everything in life: the courage to overcome challenges and uphold commitments to one's people and country.It also applies to relations with countries like the U.S. Brazil and the U.S. have much in common. We both fought to overcome slavery. We have large Black populations and multicultural societies. These are major assets.We are also strong democracies. I congratulated [Obama] for overcoming the 2008 crisis. Brazil will overcome its current crisis. We'll do so decisively, with a strong sense of commitment.We will not only resume growth but also ensure the continuity of the gains we have established in the past 12 years. We will build a predominantly middle-class country. Efforts to reduce inequality are a major gain, and we must fight to preserve them.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, can you confirm or deny a possible trip to Charlotte? [SEP] That's a good question. We are looking at a lot of different options. We will let you know as soon as a decision is made.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, this is the first time a U.S. President has visited Benin. Is this visit a genuine shift in relations, or merely a symbolic gesture, a 'diplomatic coup' as some have suggested? [SEP] Well, I'll give you my take, and the President can speak for himself. My presence here signifies America's dedication to improving lives in Africa. We're prioritizing nations that invest in their citizens, fight corruption, and embrace market economies. This visit is a message to future Presidents and Congresses: supporting these nations is both a national and moral imperative. We're moving away from feel-good grants towards initiatives like the Millennium Challenge Account, which rewards countries meeting specific criteria. Benin has met those criteria. This marks a change in our relationship, reflecting Benin's commitment to its people. We're here to support virtuous nations striving for prosperity and good governance.
label: Implicit

sentence: Is it fair to say that you would consider leveraging federal contracts, as you have in the past, to achieve this policy objective? [SEP] I'm not going to get into the specifics right now. We're still reviewing the situation and determining the best course of action. I'll let you know when we have something to announce.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. And you got an MBA? [SEP] The problem is, I called him, and I've known him for a long time.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. Sir, if you do invite him to the White House—or to the United States, would it be here at the White House or at Mar-a-Lago? [SEP] Maybe we'll start with the White House. What do you think? []
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, given the ongoing political turmoil in Israel and the persistent obstacles to peace, what specific steps are you prepared to take to ensure that your administration's peace plan receives broad support from both Israelis and Palestinians, and that it leads to a viable, two-state solution? [SEP] Look, it's a tough situation. A very tough situation. But I'm not afraid of tough situations. I thrive on them. And I believe that we can achieve peace in the Middle East. I really do. But it's going to take leadership. It's going to take courage. And it's going to take a willingness to compromise. And I'm prepared to provide that leadership. I'm prepared to show that courage. And I'm prepared to make those compromises. But both sides have to be willing to do the same. They have to be willing to put aside their differences and come to the table with an open mind. And I believe that they can. I really do. And if they do, then we can achieve peace. A lasting peace. A peace that will benefit everyone. It's going to be great.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Can I ask a question on the vaccine? [SEP] And I just want to again wish you a happy Labor Day.Thank you very much, everybody.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. Do you want to walk back where you did praise China in January for being transparent about the coronavirus? [SEP] I'm always respectful of China.
label: General

sentence: In 2010, you called the result of the midterm election a shellacking. What do you call this? And can you give us an update on your feelings about the immigration Executive order in the result—in the aftermath of this election? Does the election affect your plans to release it? Will it still—is it likely to come out before the lame duck session is over? And have you reduced its scope to just a couple million people? [SEP] As I said earlier, the Republicans had a good night. We'll reach out to Mitch McConnell and John Boehner to discuss their agenda. Hopefully, we can find common ground. The message from this election, and others, is clear: get things done. Focus on the concerns of ordinary Americans. Think about the single mom struggling with childcare costs, the young person worried about college debt, the construction worker who needs a job. If we focus on them, we can make progress. On immigration, I prefer Congress to act on comprehensive reform. We need to strengthen borders, streamline legal immigration, and give undocumented immigrants a chance to earn legal status. The Senate passed a bipartisan bill, which wasn't perfect but would improve our system and economy. I asked John Boehner to pass it in the House, but he couldn't. So, I'll use my executive authority to improve the system, but I'll replace those actions with congressional action if they pass a bill. That's a commitment I made to the American people and to John Boehner. Before the end of the year, I'll take lawful executive actions to improve our immigration system and surge resources to the border. I'll also reach out to Republican and Democratic leaders to discuss how to proceed. If they want to pass a bill, I'm ready to work with them. But I won't wait. I've been patient and tried to work on a bipartisan basis, and I'll continue to do so. But in the meantime, let's improve the system through executive action.
label: Implicit

sentence: President Biden, concerning the G-7's oil price cap intended to address high gas prices, can you confidently state that this will directly benefit American drivers? Furthermore, what's a reasonable timeframe for Americans to bear the financial burden of this war? [SEP] The crux of the matter, as I understand it, is whether this price cap will effectively reduce costs for American families?
label: Clarification

sentence: With governors adopting different stances on mask mandates, some strongly advocating for them while others are less enthusiastic, shouldn't there be a uniform national policy on mask-wearing to effectively address the pandemic? [SEP] The bottom line is, if people feel more comfortable wearing a mask, they should go ahead and wear it. I always keep one handy. I've worn it myself from time to time. In certain situations, like hospitals or when you can't stay far enough apart, I think it's a good idea. I've got mine right here, see? And you know, in some cases, it's really a smart thing to do. Like when you're traveling. It's just a good idea.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, with regards to the vaccine for children under 5, what specific data points are the scientists waiting for, and what recourse do parents have in the meantime, given the ongoing risks of infection? [SEP] Well, they're looking at a whole range of factors, from dosage levels to potential side effects. It's a very complex process. In the meantime, parents should follow the CDC guidelines, practice good hygiene, and consult with their pediatricians. We're doing everything we can to get this vaccine approved as quickly and safely as possible.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, some critics argue that relying on Putin's assurances about Iran's intentions is naive. What safeguards are in place to ensure that Iran is not secretly pursuing a nuclear weapons program? [SEP] We are not relying solely on Putin's assurances. We are conducting our own independent assessments of Iran's nuclear program, and we are working closely with the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) to monitor Iran's activities. We are also maintaining a robust sanctions regime to pressure Iran to comply with international norms. We are taking all necessary steps to ensure that Iran does not acquire a nuclear weapon.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. How serious have your threats been to the Pakistani Government, if they don't hand him over? [SEP] Well, I'm not going to discuss the specific exchanges that we've had. But we've been very firm about this being an important priority. Okay?Ed Henry [CNN].
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. Senator John McCain and Senator Lindsey Graham both said today that they want to have Watergate-style hearings on the attack on the U.S. consulate in Benghazi and said that if you nominate Susan Rice to be Secretary of State, they will do everything in their power to block her nomination. As Senator Graham said, he simply doesn't trust Ambassador Rice after what she said about Benghazi. I'd like your reaction to that. And would those threats deter you from making a nomination like that? [SEP] Well, first of all, I'm not going to comment at this point on various nominations that I'll put forward to fill out my Cabinet for the second term. Those are things that are still being discussed.But let me say specifically about Susan Rice, she has done exemplary work. She has represented the United States and our interests in the United Nations with skill and professionalism and toughness and grace.As I've said before, she made an appearance at the request of the White House in which she gave her best understanding of the intelligence that had been provided to her. If Senator McCain and Senator Graham and others want to go after somebody, they should go after me. And I'm happy to have that discussion with them. But for them to go after the U.N. Ambassador, who had nothing to do with Benghazi and was simply making a presentation based on intelligence that she had received, and to besmirch her reputation is outrageous.And we're after an election now. I think it is important for us to find out exactly what happened in Benghazi, and I'm happy to cooperate in any ways that Congress wants. We have provided every bit of information that we have, and we will continue to provide information. And we've got a full-blown investigation, and all that information will be disgorged to Congress.And I don't think there's any debate in this country that when you have four Americans killed, that's a problem. And we've got to get to the bottom of it, and there needs to be accountability. We've got to bring those who carried it out to justice. They won't get any debate from me on that.But when they go after the U.N. Ambassador, apparently, because they think she's an easy target, then they've got a problem with me. And should I choose, if I think that she would be the best person to serve America in the capacity of the State Department, then I will nominate her. That's not a determination that I've made yet. Okay?Ed Henry [FOX News]
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, with all due respect, after nearly four years in office, do you have any regrets about the inaccuracies you've presented to the American public? [SEP] Excuse me? Could you repeat the premise of your question?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, regarding Libya, are you prepared to use all necessary means to remove Gaddafi from power? If not, why not, considering the apparent shift from a neutral stance in other uprisings? [SEP] We acted swiftly. First, we evacuated our citizens. Then, we implemented the largest financial seizure of assets in history. We imposed sanctions and mobilized the international community through the UN. We're tightening the noose on Gaddafi, isolating him internationally. We've provided humanitarian aid. NATO is discussing options, including 24-hour surveillance, an arms embargo, humanitarian aid, and potential military options like a no-fly zone. Secretary Clinton will meet with the opposition, and we'll assign a representative to assist them. All options are on the table. We've moved quickly to impose sanctions. It's in our interest and the Libyan people's interest for Gaddafi to leave. I'm consulting with my advisors on military options, considering the risks. Maintaining a strong international coalition is crucial.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, after months of promoting your jobs bill, you've achieved little. Are you concerned that you'll face voters in 2012 with high unemployment and no significant legislative accomplishments? [SEP] The real issue is Congress's failure to pass a popular jobs bill. That's why people are unhappy with them. Usually, politicians change course when the public disapproves, but Republicans in Congress seem indifferent to job creation. I'll continue advocating for it. We'll achieve some progress now, and I'll persist until we accomplish everything. Perhaps that takes until November, or a new Congress. We need to cut taxes for the middle class, assist small businesses in hiring veterans, and support teachers. In Hawaii, budget constraints force schools to operate only four days a week. How can we compete globally under those circumstances? The jobs bill would alleviate those pressures. Investing in infrastructure is crucial—world leaders recognize this. Our airports and ports lag behind competitors, hindering trade. And we could create jobs. So, I'll keep pushing. I don't anticipate Republicans suddenly embracing my proposals, but I hope they realize inaction isn't an option. Otherwise, we may see a change in congressional leadership.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. In the past, when you've been asked to address bad poll numbers or your unpopularity, you've said that history will judge that you did the right thing, that you thought you did the right thing. But without getting into your motives or your goals, I think a lot of people, including Republicans, including some members of your own administration, have been disappointed at the execution of some of your ideals, whether Iraq or Katrina or the economy. What would your closing message be to the American people about the execution of these goals? [SEP] Well, first of all, hard things don't happen overnight, Jake. And when the history of Iraq is written, historians will analyze, for example, the decision on the surge. The situation was—looked like it was going fine, and then violence for a period of time began to throw the progress of Iraq into doubt. And rather than accepting the status quo and saying, Oh, it's not worth it, or, The politics makes it difficult, or you know, The party may end up being—you know, not doing well in the elections because of the violence in Iraq, I decided to do something about it and sent 30,000 troops in as opposed to withdrawing.And so that part of history is certain, and the situation did change. Now, the question is, in the long run, will this democracy survive? And that's going to be the challenge for future Presidents.In terms of the economy, look, I inherited a recession; I am ending on a recession. In the meantime there were 52 months of uninterrupted job growth. And I defended tax cuts when I campaigned. I helped implement tax cuts when I was President, and I will defend them after my Presidency as the right course of action. And there's a fundamental philosophical debate about tax cuts. Who best can spend your money, the Government or you? And I have always sided with the people on that issue.Now, obviously, these are very difficult economic times. When people analyze the situation, there will be—this problem started before my Presidency; it obviously took place during my Presidency. The question facing a President is not when the problem started, but what did you do about it when you recognized the problem? And I readily concede I chucked aside some of my free market principles when I was told by chief economic advisers that the situation we were facing could be worse than the Great Depression.So I've told some of my friends who said—you know, who have taken an ideological position on this issue—why did you do what you did? I said, well, if you were sitting there and heard that the depression could be greater than the Great Depression, I hope you would act too, which I did. And we've taken extraordinary measures to deal with the frozen credit markets, which have affected the economy. Credit spreads are beginning to shrink; lending is just beginning to pick up. The actions we have taken, I believe, have helped thaw the credit markets, which is the first step toward recovery.And so yes, look, there's plenty of critics in this business, I understand that. And I thank you for giving me a chance to defend a record that I am going to continue to defend, because I think it's a good, strong record.Jim [Jim Axelrod, CBS News].
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Mr. President, regarding the proposed oil price cap on Russian exports, a measure intended to alleviate the burden of high gasoline prices both here and abroad, can you assure the American people that this cap will indeed lead to lower prices at the pump? Furthermore, what is a reasonable timeframe for American drivers to expect relief from the financial strain caused by this conflict? [SEP] Could you repeat the initial part of your question concerning the price cap's impact?
label: Clarification

sentence: Sir, isn't there a risk that presenting yourself as an equal to Kim Jong Un normalizes his regime on the world stage? [SEP] That's not my perspective. I'm focused on making the world a safer place. If sitting with Chairman Kim can prevent a catastrophe and save millions of lives, I'm willing to do it. I'm willing to travel there with pride. They've already made significant concessions. And don't forget their participation in the Olympics, which helped make it a success. If I can save lives by establishing a relationship with someone who wields such power and controls nuclear weapons, it's my duty to do so.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, you've committed to sending more troops to Afghanistan. Given your 16-month withdrawal timeline from Iraq, what is your projected timeline for troop withdrawal from Afghanistan? Also, will you reverse the Pentagon policy banning media coverage of flag-draped coffins returning from war, a policy Senator Biden once criticized? [SEP] First, let me say that our hearts go out to the families of the fallen. Serving as Commander-in-Chief has been the greatest honor of my life. Regarding the media policy, we are reviewing it. As for Afghanistan, we are conducting a thorough review of our strategy. We must ensure that Afghanistan never again becomes a safe haven for terrorists. I don't have a concrete timeline to share today.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, President Musharraf's government is facing considerable turmoil. Are you concerned this could derail Pakistani counter-terrorism efforts in the border regions? [SEP] I've read the reports about a potential emergency declaration, but I haven't seen concrete proof of that decision. In my conversations with President Musharraf, I've stressed our shared fight against extremists who threaten both our countries. They've even tried to kill him. I've emphasized the importance of intelligence sharing, which I believe is strong. I've also made it clear that the American people expect swift action on actionable intelligence regarding high-value targets within Pakistan. Pakistan is a sovereign nation, and that's important to remember. But it's equally important to understand that President Musharraf shares our concerns about radicals. My focus is on ensuring free and fair elections there, and that's what we're discussing with him. We'll move down the line here.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Is it too late to consider a second one in your administration? [SEP] You know, we—we're always openminded to things, but I—let's see how this stimulus package works, and let us deal with the housing market with good piece of housing legislation and the energy issue with good energy legislation and the trade issue with good trade legislation.People say, Aww, man, you're running out of time; nothing is going to happen. I'll remind people what did happen: We got a good troop funding bill with no strings; got a GI bill; we got FISA. What can we get done? We can get good housing legislation done. We can get good energy legislation done. We can get trade bills done. I mean, there's plenty of time to get action with the United States Congress, and they need to move quickly. We can get judges approved.And so I'm—we'll see what happens up there. I'm confident that if they put their mind to it, we can get good legislation.Let's see here, yes, Mark [Mark Smith, Associated Press].
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Mr. President, can your administration take steps now to build confidence that the U.S. will meet its deficit reduction targets in the medium and long term? [SEP] I'm sorry, could you repeat the question? Please speak a little closer to the microphone.
label: Clarification

sentence: President Obama, the Trans-Pacific Partnership seems fairly stalled in Congress, and other countries are looking to follow the U.S. lead in terms of how they advance their approval of the agreement. With the deals today announced for Boeing and GE and your visit here to Vietnam, are you looking to change your strategy in how you seek approval for the Trans-Pacific Partnership in Congress? And do you think that the agreement should be amended to address currency manipulation?Secondly, President Obama, can you comment on the killing of Taliban leader Mullah Mansur and on Pakistan's concern about that strike happening on its soil? Can you also comment on whether this signals a new offensive in Afghanistan and whether you're concerned that an even more hardline leader might take his place?For President Quang, are you concerned about the lack of enthusiasm for the Trans-Pacific Partnership in the U.S. Congress and what that means for the deal in the end? And how do you respond to China's criticism of the U.S. pursuing what China says is a one-sided, selfish agenda in Asia that risks regional peace? [SEP] Well, first of all, on TPP, Angel, I haven't been around as long as Senators Cooper or Secretary Kerry, but I've spent enough time in the Senate to know that every trade deal is painful, because folks are always seeing if they can get an even better deal. And especially when you have multiple parties involved, folks are going to be scrutinizing it, they're going to be debating it, and in an election year, you can anticipate that some folks are going to try to score political points off it.Having said that, I remain confident we're going to get it done. And the reason I'm confident is because it's the right thing to do. It's good for the country. It's good for America. It's good for the region. It's good for the world.And I know I've sold this to you before, but let me reiterate: This is the fastest growing part of the world. This represents an enormous market for the United States. Most countries here already sell their stuff to the United States, and we have relatively low tariffs. In other words, we put relatively low taxes on goods that are coming into the United States. In contrast, tariffs are significantly higher for U.S. goods being sold here. So a deal that gets rid of 18,000 taxes on U.S. goods into the largest, fastest growing markets of the world, that's a good deal for American businesses and American workers.Number two, one of the biggest complaints about trade deals historically has been that it opens up our markets to countries with lower wages, harsher labor practices, less environmental regulations. Well, if you're signing up for the Trans-Pacific Partnership, you are making commitments that are enforceable to raise labor standards, to ensure that workers have a voice, to attend to environmental problems. And so this gives us the ability to engage with a country like Vietnam and work with them on all those fronts, the precise things that people, in the past, have been concerned about when it comes to trading with other countries.So I have not yet seen a credible argument that once we get TPP in place we're going to be worse off. We are demonstrably better off. American workers and American businesses are better off if we get this deal passed. And I'm confident we will get it passed.Now, the politics of it will be noisy. That was true when I, for example, inherited the Korean free trade agreement or the Colombian and Panamanian free trade agreements when I came into office. But we got them done. And I'm confident that we'll get them done this time, as well, although it will—there will be ups and downs and bumps along the way.With respect to currency manipulation, we have provisions in TPP that advance the transparency and reporting functions that allow us to monitor whether we think that currency manipulation is taking place. One of the debates that took place—and there have been some who argue that we should have enforceable provisions that if you see currency going down too far that we should be able to impose tariffs on that country. The problem is, is that it's very hard to sort out sometimes why currency is going down and whether it's actually being manipulated. And frankly, for us to bind other countries to commitments about their monetary policy would mean we were also binding our Federal Reserve to the claims of other countries in terms of how it implements our monetary policy, and that's not something that we would do. We would not give up sovereignty with respect to our monetary policy in that way. But we have strengthened a number of the provisions that are already contained in TPP that will allow us to put on notice folks who we think are engaging in competitive devaluations.Finally, on the Taliban leader, Mr. Mansur, it has been confirmed that he is dead. And he is an individual who, as head of the Taliban, was specifically targeting U.S. personnel and troops inside of Afghanistan who were there as part of the mission that I've set to be able to maintain a counterterrorism platform and provide assistance and training to the Afghan military forces there. So this does not represent a shift in our approach. We are not reentering the day-to-day combat operations that are currently being conducted by Afghan security forces. Our job is to help Afghanistan secure its own country, not to have our men and women in uniform engage in that fight for them.On the other hand, where we have a high-profile leader who has been consistently part of operations and plans to potentially harm U.S. personnel and who has been resistant to the kinds of peace talks and reconciliation that ultimately could bring an end to decades of war in Afghanistan, then it is my responsibility as Commander in Chief not to stand by, but to make sure that we send a clear signal to the Taliban and others that we're going to protect our people. And that's exactly the message that has been sent. President ung. Let me respond to this question concerning the Trans-Pacific Partnership, TPP. In our view, TPP is a significant trade and economic linkage, contributing to sustaining the dynamics and the role as driver for economic growth in our country, as well as in the Asia-Pacific region. And for Vietnam, TPP and Vietnam's participation in TPP is one step undertaken by the Vietnamese Government in our process of extensive international integration President Ob. Mr. President, sorry to interrupt. We're not getting translation Testing one, two, three. President Ob. For you? Can you hear, Mr. President? President Ob. Oky. Testing one, two, three. President Ob. It's just, I'm sure that he was saying something very wise and important, and we wanted to make sure that we all heard it. President ung. So I would like to add that Vietnam, together with other TPP countries, have been making efforts to narrow differences, to promote cooperation in the spirit of mutual understanding and mutual respect. And we will try to reduce differences in spirit of constructiveness and understanding and paying attention to one another's legitimate interests. And the finalization of TPP is also the successful outcomes of all 12 members of the TPP, rather than any individual effort. And we are prepared to ratify TPP, and we stand ready to implement all the commitments under TPP.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, if Russia's actions don't match their words, what further steps will the United States take to support Ukraine and hold Russia accountable? [SEP] We're prepared to ramp up sanctions, increase military assistance to Ukraine, and work with our allies to isolate Russia further. We're not going to stand by and watch them continue their aggression. We're committed to defending democracy and upholding international law.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, after your meeting with President Zelenskyy, what insights did you gain from the face-to-face interaction that you couldn't have gotten from phone calls? Also, was there any discussion about U.S. intelligence assessments regarding Russia's potential for escalation after the Patriot missile system is delivered? [SEP] Let me start with the first part of your question. You know, they say all politics is local, but I say all politics is personal. There's just no substitute for looking someone in the eye, whether they're a friend or a foe. That's what we did today, and we'll keep doing it. Winter's coming, and Putin's hitting civilian targets – women, children, orphanages. This guy... well, he's going to fail. He's already failed because he'll never take all of Ukraine. The Ukrainian people will never accept him. It was important for everyone to see that Zelenskyy and I stand united. I judge leaders by what they say to me, their consistency, and by looking them in the eye. Zelenskyy is who he says he is, willing to give his life for his country. We'll do everything we can to help him succeed. Thank you. Now, remind me, what was the second part of your question?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. So you rule out that she was fired? [SEP] I'm--come on, Jackie, I don't know. I'm telling you the--I found out about it this morning, so I don't yet know the circumstances, and Ken Salazar's been in testimony on the Hill.With respect to your first question, at MMS, Ken Salazar was in the process of making these reforms. But the point that I'm making is, is that obviously they weren't happening fast enough. If they had been happening fast enough, this might have been caught. Now, it's possible that it might not have been caught. All right? I mean, we could have gone through a whole new process for environmental review; you could have had a bunch of technical folks take a look at BP's plans, and they might have said, this is--meets industry standards, we haven't had an accident like this in 15 years, and we should go ahead.That's what this Commission has to discover, is, was this a systemic breakdown? Is this something that could happen once in a million times? Is it something that could happen once in a thousand times or once every 5,000 times? What exactly are the risks involved?Now, let me make one broader point, though, about energy. The fact that oil companies now have to go a mile underwater and then drill another 3 miles below that in order to hit oil tells us something about the direction of the oil industry. Extraction is more expensive, and it is going to be inherently more risky.And so that's part of the reason you never heard me say, Drill, baby, drill, because we can't drill our way out of the problem. It may be part of the mix as a bridge to a transition to new technologies and new energy sources, but we should be pretty modest in understanding that the easily accessible oil is already been sucked up out of the ground.And as we are moving forward, the technology gets more complicated, the oil sources are more remote, and that means that there's probably going to end up being more risk. And we as a society are going to have to make some very serious determinations in terms of what risks are we willing to accept. And that's part of what the Commission, I think, has to--is going to have to look at.I will tell you, though, that understanding we need to grow--we--we're going to be consuming oil in terms--for our industries and for how people live in this country, we're going to have to start moving on this transition. And that's why when I went to the Republican caucus just this week, I said to them, let's work together. You've got Lieberman and Kerry, who previously were working with Lindsey Graham--even though Lindsey's not on the bill right now--coming up with a framework that has the potential to get bipartisan support and says, yes, we're going to still need oil production, but you know what, we can see what's out there on the horizon, and it's a problem if we don't start changing how we operate. Okay?Macarena Vidal [EFE News]. Not here? Oh, there you are.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the proposed bill granting voting rights to the District of Columbia and an additional congressional seat to Utah, given your commitment to democracy abroad, particularly in Iraq, why not support similar measures domestically? [SEP] To be frank, I'm just learning about this now. I wasn't aware of any plans to introduce it during the lame-duck session.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, it's been suggested that some Democrats facing tough re-election battles have asked you to postpone action on immigration. How have these concerns influenced your decision-making process, and do you see any disadvantages to delaying until after the election? [SEP] My focus this week has been primarily on international matters, specifically Ukraine, ISIS, and strengthening NATO. Regarding immigration, I've received preliminary proposals from Johnson and Holder, which I'll be reviewing. My priority is comprehensive immigration reform, ideally through Congressional action. However, in the absence of that, I intend to take executive action to secure the border, streamline processing, and create pathways to legal status. I'll be considering these options further and making an announcement soon.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. And how can you retaliate against Iran without risking a war? [SEP] What we do know is that the Qods Force was instrumental in providing these deadly IEDs to networks inside of Iraq; we know that. And we also know that the Qods Force is a part of the ian Government; that's a known. What we don't know is whether or not the head leaders of ordered the Qods Force to do what they did.But here's my point: Either they knew or didn't know, and what matters is, is that they're there. What's worse: that the Government knew or that the Government didn't know? But the point I made in my initial speech in the White House about Iraq was, is that we know they're there, and we're going to protect our troops. When we find the networks that are enabling these weapons to end up in Iraq, we will deal with them. If we find agents who are moving these devices into Iraq, we will deal with them. I have put out the command to our troops—I mean, to the people who are commanders that we'll protect the people—the soldiers of the United States and innocent people in Iraq and will continue doing so.Now, let me step back on itself. We have a comprehensive strategy to deal with Iraq []. * There's a variety of issues that we have with Iraq []. * One, of course, is influence inside of Iraq. Another is whether or not they end up with a nuclear weapon. And I believe an with a nuclear weapon would be very dangerous for world peace, and have worked with other nations of like mind. And it turns out, there's a lot of countries in the world that agree with that assessment. After all, we did get a Chapter VII resolution out of the United Nations that included EU-3 as well as Russia and China. That's a positive development.The message to the ian people is, is that your leaders are making decisions that are isolating you in the world, thereby denying you a brighter future. And I believe is a unbelievably vital nation. It's got a great history; it's got wonderful traditions; it's got very capable, smart people. There is—I believe there's also a desire to not be isolated from the world. And our policies are all aimed at convincing the ian people there's a better way forward, and I hope their Government hears that message.Yes, anyway, that's a long answer to a short question, and now you're trying to get to me to another one, aren't you? Gregory [David Gregory, NBC News].
label: General

sentence:
After this meeting, do you honestly believe this person is trustworthy? [SEP] Trust? That's not what this is about. It's about shared goals and making sure those goals are actually being met. When I make a deal for the American people, I don't just take someone's word for it. I need to see results.

Like they say, 'The proof of the pudding is in the eating.' We'll find out soon enough.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, in light of the Inter-Continental Hotel attack, does this not suggest that Afghan security forces are ill-prepared to take the lead, considering their failure to protect such a prominent target in the capital? [SEP] Well, remember the drawdown hasn't started. We understood it's a dangerous place, the Taliban is still active, and events like this will occur. The question is, is Afghan capacity increasing? Kabul, containing a large proportion of the Afghan population, has been largely policed by Afghan forces for quite some time, and they've done a reasonably good job. Kabul is much safer than it was, and Afghan forces in Kabul are much more capable than they were. That doesn't mean these events won't take place, probably for some time. Our work is not done. But as I said, the tide of war is receding. We've shifted to a transition phase. Much like Iraq, where we've drawn down our troops, the remainder coming out by year's end, and Iraq has maintained a democratic government and tamped down violence, we think a similar approach makes sense. Even in Iraq, you still see attacks. These are countries digging themselves out of war, dangerous places. They won't be perfectly safe, even if we were there. But we can improve the chances for the Afghan people to defend themselves. Next question, please.
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. ——to use your favorite expression.After Brexit, who do you think will be your more important relationship: President Macron, France and the EU, or Boris Johnson, Prime Minister of the United Kingdom? [SEP] I think we're going to have just—look, France is a great nation. It's being run. A lot of things are happening. You know, it's not easy what he's doing. He's changing certain ways. It's a very hard thing to do. I won't get into it. I'm going to let him sell his ideas. But a lot of people don't disagree with his ideas.But it's a very hard thing to do if you're a great citizen of France. You love your country, but you want to do the way you've been doing it for a long time. But maybe that's not working. And maybe they have to do what he has to do. I think he's going to do a fantastic job. But it's very tough for him. I know how tough it is for him. He's been having a hard time. And nobody would have any easy time. But I do believe he is doing the right thing.Boris is different. It's a different kind of a deal. Boris has to try and do something with Brexit. It's very tough. I deal with the EU. The EU is—that's a very, very strong group of people. They have their ideas, and they're not easy to deal with, I will tell you.We've very close to making a deal, by the way, with the EU. I have to say this. We made a great deal with Japan. And we're very close to maybe making a deal with the EU. Because they don't want tariffs; it's very simple. They don't want to tax cars. Mercedes Benz, BMW, they don't need a 20-percent or a 25-percent tax. But we're very close. I think we're going to make a deal with the EU without having to go that route. I may have to go that route, but maybe not.We're going to have a deal, a really fair deal. But the EU is another one. We've been losing $180 billion a year for many years. That's a lot of money. How much can you take out of the piggy bank, right?
label: General

sentence: Sir, with another bank bailout on the horizon, will you stipulate that banks must use the funds to expand credit access? If not, how do you sell this to the public after the last bailout's shortcomings? [SEP] Helene, I don't want to steal the thunder from my Treasury Secretary, who has a big announcement tomorrow – be sure to be there; he'll do a fantastic job. But, as I mentioned to Jake, the key is whether credit is reaching those who need it: businesses and consumers. Our package aims to achieve that. Tim will provide more details tomorrow. Major Garrett, are you here?
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, with all due respect, one of Mr. Romney's former advisors published an article in a German journal claiming your administration's advice to Europe, specifically Germany, demonstrates a fundamental misunderstanding of the economic crisis's roots, mirroring the flaws in your own domestic policies. How do you respond to this critique? Furthermore, given Europe's history of short-term fixes, what gives you confidence that the upcoming Brussels meeting will yield a lasting solution? [SEP] Well, regarding Mr. Romney's advisors, I'd suggest directing your inquiries to Mr. Romney himself. It's important to remember that we have one President and one administration at a time, and traditionally, partisan politics stops at the border. Furthermore, that advisor may be misinformed about the specifics of our recommendations to Germany. It's easy to project domestic ideological battles onto the complex situation in Europe. The European situation is multifaceted. Some nations had irresponsible fiscal policies and public debt. Others, like Spain, faced issues stemming from housing speculation and private sector problems unrelated to public debt. All European countries now recognize the need for growth strategies that align with fiscal consolidation. That's precisely what the United States should be considering. My plan from September aimed to boost growth and jobs immediately while providing clarity on how we'll reduce our deficit and debt in the medium and long term. I believe that's the correct approach, not just for us, but universally. Now, what was your second question again?
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the extension of sanctions against Russia, is there a clear consensus among the U.S. and its European allies on the specific next steps if Russia continues to violate the Minsk agreement? And can Russian aggression in Eastern Europe be deterred without a permanent U.S. troop presence? Also, could the legal challenges to your immigration policies extend late into your term? Is there anything more you can do for those affected, and how would you view your term ending without achieving your immigration goals? [SEP] On Ukraine, Russia, and Minsk, there's a strong consensus that we must keep pressing Russia to adhere to the Minsk agreement. We need to continue supporting Ukraine in meeting its obligations under Minsk. Until that's done, sanctions remain. There was discussion about potential additional steps if Russia, through separatists, escalates aggression in Ukraine. These discussions are at a technical level, not yet political, as the immediate goal is rolling over existing sanctions at the upcoming European Council meeting. However, we want to be prepared technically. Our hope is that we won't need further steps because the Minsk agreement is fulfilled. I commend Chancellor Merkel and President Hollande for their extraordinary persistence in trying to make that happen. Ultimately, this rests with Mr. Putin. He must decide: Does he continue to harm his country's economy and isolate Russia by pursuing a misguided desire to recreate the Soviet empire, or does he recognize that Russia's greatness doesn't depend on violating other countries' sovereignty? The Russian people are bearing severe costs. This may not be understood due to state media propaganda, but the truth is that the Russian people would greatly benefit from a different approach. Ironically, Mr. Putin claimed his incursions into Ukraine were to protect Russian speakers, yet they are the ones suffering the most. Their economy has collapsed, their lives are disrupted, many are displaced, and their homes may be destroyed. The best way to end their suffering is full implementation of the Minsk agreement. On immigration, I'm frustrated by the district court ruling currently under appeal. We're aggressively pursuing the appeal and implementing the unchallenged parts of the executive actions. A key provision for me was enabling undocumented individuals to undergo background checks, pay back taxes, and gain legal status. This requires a significant administrative apparatus. I decided it's best not to accept applications until the legal status is clarified. I firmly believe this is within my legal authority, and our lawyers agree. The executive branch has traditional discretion in applying immigration laws. However, the U.S. is a government of laws and separations of power, so we must challenge the ruling, even if it's from a single district court judge. Until we have clarity, I don't want to bring people in and have them jump through hoops only to face further delays. Of course, Congress could solve this by acting, obviating the need for executive actions. Most Americans want this to happen. I suspect it will be a major topic in the next Presidential campaign. We'll continue pushing on all fronts to fix the broken system. Administratively, we'll be prepared if we get the ruling we believe we deserve. But ultimately, this doesn't fully replace the need for Congress to act. My hope is that after addressing current issues, quiet conversations will resume, especially within the Republican Party, about their shortsighted approach to immigration.
label: General

sentence: President Obama, Rick Ledgett suggested considering amnesty for Edward Snowden. What's your stance, particularly given the national conversation about surveillance that Snowden triggered? [SEP] Major, Snowden is facing criminal charges, so my hands are tied. The Attorney General and the courts will handle it. I think the surveillance debate was critical. But the leaks hurt our intelligence and diplomacy. Now, countries that are actually doing the bad things Snowden was worried about are using it to attack us. The debate was good, but the leaks were bad. I'm going to let the courts do their thing.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, does this agreement with North Korea require a formal signing ceremony? [SEP] Well, that's a good question. Since it's not legally binding, I'm not sure if there's a formal signature. I'm not sure what the protocols are, but the commitment from the United States is very important.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the WHO, if Dr. Tedros were to step aside, would the United States consider rejoining and providing financial support? Or do you believe a change in leadership is merely a superficial fix? [SEP] Look, we're conducting a thorough review. I can't say I know the man personally, but there are clearly issues. The WHO hasn't treated the U.S. fairly, much like the WTO, which is finally starting to see things our way. How can they call China a developing nation and let them exploit the system at our expense? Why didn't previous administrations address this? I've been raising this since day one. We're taking a hard look at both the WHO and the WTO. Frankly, I'm not sure which is worse, but we'll get to the bottom of it, believe me.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, considering the potential long-term effects of Brexit on global economic growth, what specific actions will you advocate for at the upcoming G-20 summit to stimulate demand and mitigate the negative consequences? [SEP] We're going to the G-20 to talk about a lot of things, important things. Brexit is one of them. We'll be pushing for policies that benefit American workers, that's my priority. We'll see what the other countries bring to the table.
label: Dodging

sentence: President, did your discussions with President Biden include the recent intelligence leaks indicating U.S. spying on South Korea? Can you confirm whether President Biden offered any assurances regarding this matter? [SEP] Regarding that issue, our nations are in communication, exchanging necessary information. The U.S. is conducting an investigation, and various factors are involved. We must await the investigation's outcome. We intend to continue communication on this. This concludes the questioning.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, following the Boston bombing, are you confident that the intelligence sharing with Russia is now seamless and effective, and what specific measures are in place to ensure Americans' safety at large public gatherings? [SEP] Look, the Russians have stepped up since Boston, no doubt about it. Sure, there's still some Cold War residue, some suspicion. But Putin and I have talked directly, and he's committed to making sure our agencies cooperate fully, not just on this investigation, but on counterterrorism in general. As for Americans, I think Boston set the tone. Nobody's intimidated. People are jogging, going to games. We're resilient. We're going to live our lives. We're going to do everything we can to prevent attacks, but we're not going to let warped individuals scare us. We're going to work, raise our kids, go to ball games. We'll be vigilant, but not naive.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Thank you so much, Mr. President. Were you informed about positive coronavirus cases in the White House today? [SEP] Sorry, I didn't catch that. Could you repeat the question?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Okay. [Laughter] Q. Both? [SEP] Or both. Are you together? Go ahead.
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Are you unwilling to provide more details? [SEP] Excuse me?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Mr. President, I'd like to ask you: Nancy Pelosi has been quite clear about her agenda for the first 100 hours. She mentions things like raising minimum wage, cutting interest rates on student loans, broadening stem cell research, and rolling back tax cuts. Which of those can you support, sir? [SEP] I knew you'd probably try to get me to start negotiating with myself. I haven't even visited with Congresswoman Pelosi yet. She's coming to the Oval Office later this week. I'm going to sit down and talk with her. I believe on a lot of issues we can find common ground, and there's a significant difference between common ground and abandoning principle. She's not going to abandon her principles, and I'm not going to abandon mine. But I do believe we have an opportunity to find some common ground to move forward on.In that very same interview you quoted, one of these three characters asked me about minimum wage. I said, there's an area where I believe we can make some— find common ground. And as we do, I'll be, of course, making sure that our small businesses are—there's compensation for the small businesses in the bill.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Can I follow-up on Jordan's question? [SEP] Go ahead.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Mr. President, you are about to embark on what may be the most important meeting you've ever had in your life. What's in your gut, steel nerves or butterflies? Can you describe how you feel? [SEP] Well, there's always everything. It's really—you know, this has probably rarely been done. It's unknown territory, in the truest sense. But I really feel confident. I feel that Kim Jong Un wants to do something great for his people, and he has that opportunity. And he won't have that opportunity again. It's never going to be there again.So I really believe that he's going to do something very positive for his people, for himself, his family.
