He's got an opportunity, the likes of which I think almost—if you look into history—very few people have ever had. He can take that nation, with those great people, and truly make it great. So it's a one-time—it's a one-time shot. And I think it's going to work out very well.That's why I feel positive, because it makes so much sense. And we will watch over, and we'll protect, and we'll do a lot of things. I can say that South Korea, Japan, China, many countries want to see it happen. And they'll help. They'll all help. So there's a great—there's really—this is a great time. This has not happened in all of the years that they've been separated by a very artificial boundary. This is a great opportunity for peace and lasting peace and prosperity.Yes, ma'am.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Mr. President——TikTok/Committee on Foreign Investment in the U.S. Review  Q. Thank you, Mr. President. Are you prepared to sign off on the Oracle and TikTok deal, even though the Treasury isn't getting paid? And also, does the deal meet your requirements in terms of national security concerns? [SEP] Okay, they're giving me studies on the deal. It has to be a hundred percent as far as national security is concerned. And no, I'm not prepared to sign off on anything. I have to see the deal.We need security, especially after what we've seen with respect to and what's going on. We want security. So I'll let you know. They're going to be reporting to me tomorrow morning, and I will let you know.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the current sanctions, will they remain in effect? [SEP] Let me be clear, the sanctions are currently active. Some have suggested we've conceded ground, but that's simply untrue. I envision a future where we have a strong relationship with Chairman Kim and North Korea, a nation brimming with untapped potential. Sanctions were a point of contention; they sought their removal, but weren't prepared to offer the concessions we deemed essential.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: President Biden, China accuses the U.S. of containment while simultaneously requesting diplomatic talks. How do you respond? Is President Xi sincere about improving relations considering actions like banning Apple in China? [SEP] Look, I'm sincere about getting the relationship right. China's changing the rules of the game, especially on trade. They're considering banning Chinese government officials from using Western cell phones. This trip wasn't about containing China. I want a fair, transparent relationship based on clear rules. We've been working to strengthen alliances globally for stability. This trip was about fostering cooperation with India, Vietnam, etc. It's not isolating China; it's creating a stable Indo-Pacific base. The Quad is about maintaining stability, not isolating China. International rules must be respected. Xi faces economic challenges, and I want China to succeed economically, but they need to play by the rules.
label: General

sentence: Q. Did you make that comment at his son's grave? [SEP] Just so you understand, he was a very—if you look at some of his news conferences, what happened to him: He got eaten alive. He was unable to handle the pressure of this job. This job was a tough job. Mark Meadows is doing a great job, but Kelly was unable to do that.And as far as that day, I mean, we have so much proof as to going to the—I went to Paris and the environs, and I was all set to go. They had a rainstorm the likes of which you've rarely seen. The fog was so great; it was as dense as I've ever seen. And I almost knew that you couldn't use the helicopter. And because they had to drive through, I guess, certain parts of Paris, the Secret Service, who—by the way, we have people here that were on the trip. They're writing a report. Unable to even think about it. And I said: Nope, I want to go. I insist on going. It would have taken us forever.The Paris police said, Please, you can't do this. They'd have to shut down various parts of Paris, and it just was not a possible situation. The helicopter would have been very quick. They had the helicopter all set, but the helicopter could never fly in that kind of weather. So—and that turned out—and that's all documented, by the way. We have all of the information from—and probably will release that information.But I think it's a shame when a second-rate magazine—I don't read it; I know very little about this magazine. But when a second-rate magazine can write things like that about somebody that's done so much for the military, can write things like that and get away with it, where you actually ask questions on it, it's a disgrace, and you ought to be ashamed of yourself.And let me just tell you, I watched the interview with Sleepy Joe Biden, and he didn't ask questions. You didn't ask questions like that. Read the questions you asked. They were, like, meant for a child. Those questions were meant for a child. Smiles on faces of reporters—not like you and you. There were smiles on the reporters. What do you think? Take a look at those questions that they ask him. They were not meant for a grownup; they were meant for a child.
label: General

sentence: Q. What happens if that patience runs out? [SEP] See, that's that hypothetical Keil is trying to get me to answer. Why don't we work to see to it that it doesn't work out—run out? That's the whole objective. That's what positive people do. They say, We're going to put something in place, and we'll work to achieve it.Let's see here, Stephen [Stephen Dinan, Washington Times].
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Can you elaborate? [SEP] Yes, I didn't find him more confrontational or more conciliatory. I found him the way he's always been: direct and straightforward.And do I think he's willing to compromise on various issues? Yes. I think he understands that—look, I think—how can I say this tactfully? I think the election held in the United States was—still leaves a little bit uncertain—has sent a very strong message around the world that the United States is ready to play.The United States is—the Republicans who survived, and along with the Democrats, are of the view that we're going to stay fully engaged in the world and that we, in fact, know what we're about. And so I don't get any sense that there's more or less confrontation.We were very blunt with one another about places where we disagreed or where we were uncertain of each other's position. And we agreed we'd set up—and we did—mechanisms whereby we would meet in detail with our—the key people in each of our administrations to discuss how we could resolve them, or how, if they weren't resolved, on what basis were they not resolved.Sebastian Smith, the AFP.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, regarding your previous statement about President Putin's satisfaction with your remarks about him being a 'killer,' could you elaborate on the specifics of your conversation with him on this matter? [SEP] President Putin is content with the resolution. I see no value in revisiting the subject.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, reports suggest Chinese hackers are targeting vaccine research. Is this a serious concern, and what actions are being taken? [SEP] China, huh? What else is new? They're always up to something. Look, I've made my feelings about China very clear. They should have stopped this virus at the source. Now you're telling me they're hacking our vaccine research? It's just another day with China.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Given these provocative actions whenever the U.S. extends an olive branch, what's your understanding of Fidel Castro's involvement in the talks? Did you discuss him with Raul? And will you personally lobby Congress to prevent them from blocking funding for a new embassy? [SEP] I think we've exhausted this line of questioning. Let's move on.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, about the NHS, will it be on the table in future negotiations? [SEP] Sorry, what was that?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Michael Fischer, DPA. Mr. President, one question to you: The U.S., over the last few years, have exported heavy weapons to Ukraine, and Germany excludes that—has only delivered 5,000 helmets to Ukraine. Don't you think that NATO should act unanimously in this respect and Germany, as the strongest European NATO partner, should also deliver heavy weapons to Ukraine? And Ukraine has asked Germany to do so.And on Nord Stream 2, I would also like to ask: Don't you think, with regard to the threat posed by Russia, Germany should already rethink its position on Nord Stream 2?And the third question, if I may: Over the last few days and weeks, there has been severe criticism from the U.S. media and from Congress as well vis-à-vis Germany about the reliability of Germany as an ally. This has been called into question. Do you understand this criticism? Is Germany a reliable partner, from your point of view?And, Mr. Chancellor, also a question to you: Nord Stream 2—you said all options are on the table. You're not mentioning Nord Stream 2 by name. Don't you think if you were to spell this out, you could win back trust as a strong ally here for the U.S.? [SEP] There's no need to win back trust. He has the complete trust of the United States. Germany is our—one of our most important allies in the world. There is no doubt about Germany's partnership with the United States. None.With regard to helping Ukraine, one of the largest contributors financially to Ukraine has been Germany. Germany has been in the forefront of making sure—providing economic assistance.You also asked the question—you asked so many, I can't remember them all. But in terms of the U.S. media saying Germany is not reliable, Germany is completely reliable—completely, totally, thoroughly reliable. I have no doubt about Germany at all. We are united. And the transatlantic partnership between Germany and the U.S. is one of the permanent pillars of German policy, and it will be relevant in the future as well—just as relevant. And this will be one of our top priorities always.On behalf of NATO, we are the country in continental Europe that is doing—making the largest contribution: financial means and also military power. And we are the country that contributes a great share—we're not fully—we don't fully agree with you as who pays the biggest part of financial support to Ukraine. And so, since 2014, about 2 billion U.S. dollars direct bilateral support and, within the EU, an additional 3.8 billion that is made available. So a substantial financial means to stabilize the Ukrainian economy, and we are willing to continue with that sort of contribution.So this is the very strong and unbreakable friendship between our two countries. Part of this is that with regard to the difficult situation at the Ukrainian border due to the Russian troops, we have made it very clear we will unanimously act in terms of sanctions.
label: Explicit

sentence: President, on the Senate trial: speed or thoroughness? Cipollone-Nadler showdown – your take? And Bolton testifying – yay or nay? [SEP] Whoa, hold on a second. That's a whole bunch of questions at once.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Sir, in light of the ongoing subpoena process, what prevents you from fully cooperating with these inquiries? [SEP] Pardon? Bipartisanship...
label: Clarification

sentence: So, about the retirement age, can you give us any specifics? [SEP] I'm not going to get into the nitty-gritty details right now. We've considered all the options you mentioned. Look, if we're talking about adjustments that might cost seniors a little more each year, or even affect future beneficiaries, then it's only fair that those making a million dollars or more contribute as well. It's about finding a balanced approach where everyone shares the burden.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Given the rise of anti-LGBTQ+ legislation in Republican-led states, what specific federal actions are you prepared to take to protect transgender children and their families who feel unsafe and are considering leaving the country? [SEP] First, let me say, give me that family's number. I want to talk to them. This administration has their back, 100%. Look, we ended the ban on transgender troops, signed the Respect for Marriage Act. But it's not enough. These hysterical, prejudiced people are pushing fear. It's wrong. These are our kids, our neighbors. We're strengthening safety, addressing civil rights violations, and boosting mental health support. Congress needs to pass the Equality Act. LGBTQ+ Americans, especially children, you are loved, you are heard, and we will not relent in protecting you.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, can you comment on the recent intelligence leaks indicating that the U.S. was spying on South Korea, and did President Biden offer any reassurances during your discussions? [SEP] On that matter, our nations are engaged in ongoing communication, exchanging pertinent details. The U.S. is currently conducting an investigation, and as always, numerous complex factors are at play. We must allow time for the U.S. investigation to conclude. We intend to maintain communication on this issue. This concludes our questioning.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Thank you. Thank you, Mr. President. I have two questions: one on the Ahmaud Arbery case and one on the coronavirus. The first on the coronavirus: The Vice President is said to be in some sort of self-isolating—keeping his distance from people. What do you say to Americans who say: How can you keep me safe? How can you reopen the government, if even the Vice President is self-isolating? And why hasn't testing gotten up to the point where every American who wants to test can get a test? [SEP] Well, the Vice President, first of all, has been tested, and he's negative—and was tested yesterday, tested today, and he's negative. He's in very good shape. And I think that that's going to be fine.As far as Americans getting a test, they should all be able to get a test right now. They should be able to get a test. That's the problem with a question like that. We go through a whole announcement saying We're number one in the world by far, by a factor of two, and even three and four depending on where you're looking, and I get a question, When will everybody be able to get tested? If somebody wants to be tested right now, they'll be able to be tested.As far as the incident, I think it's horrible, and it's certainly being looked at by many people. I'm speaking to many people about it. He looked—I saw the picture of him in his tuxedo; it was so beautiful. I mean, he looks like a wonderful, young guy. Would have been a wonderful—I mean, just a wonderful guy. I think it's a horrible thing. I think it's a horrible thing.Now, with that being said, as you know, they're studying the case very carefully. They're interviewing everybody involved, and we'll see what happens. To me, it's a very sad thing.I spoke to a number of people that are very much involved in it. I've been following that one very closely. It breaks your heart to watch it. It breaks your heart. And certainly, the video was a—it was a terrible-looking video to me.But you have a lot of people looking at it, and hopefully, an answer is going to be arrived at very quickly. But it's something that is heartbreaking.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: President Duda, after your conversation with President Trump concerning the prospect of a permanent American military installation in Poland, can you elaborate on his initial response and whether you harbor any anxieties regarding the current state of U.S.-Russia relations? [SEP] Of course, I discussed with Mr. President the implications of a permanent U.S. military presence in Poland. But let me stress this: permanent bases should not be seen as a provocation leading to increased Russian activity and militarization. Russia has been steadily militarizing areas like Kaliningrad for years. From Georgia in 2008 to the illegal annexation of Crimea, their actions speak volumes. The U.S. presence is a security guarantee for our part of Europe, for the free world. We desire both U.S. and NATO forces to protect our interests. The President and his team will weigh all factors, but the arguments for a U.S. presence are strong, given the ongoing violations of international law. Deterrence is key to preventing war. The President also noted Poland's willingness to contribute financially, reflecting his focus on burden-sharing. He believes wealthy nations should contribute to their defense, a point he's made repeatedly within NATO, resulting in increased contributions. We are considering this from a military and cost perspective.
label: Implicit

sentence: Sir, you've been criticized for spending a considerable amount of time on the golf course. Why haven't you scheduled a face-to-face meeting with the families of fallen soldiers? [SEP] Absolutely.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, concerning Venezuela, critics argue that sanctions are hurting the Venezuelan people more than Maduro's regime. How do you respond to those concerns? [SEP] We're aware of those concerns, and we're taking steps to mitigate the impact of sanctions on the Venezuelan people. We're providing humanitarian aid and working with international organizations to ensure that it reaches those who need it most. But we also believe that sanctions are necessary to pressure Maduro's regime and force them to negotiate a peaceful transition to democracy.
label: General

sentence: Q. If you don't get it done, Republicans have said they'll try to use the debt limit as a next pressure point. Would you negotiate with them in that context? [SEP] No. And I've been very clear about this. This is the United States of America, the greatest country on Earth, the world's economic superpower. And the idea that we lurch from crisis to crisis and, every 6 months or every 9 months, that we threaten not to pay our bills on stuff we've already bought and default and ruin the full faith and credit of the United States of America, that's not how you run a great country.So I've put forward a very clear principle: I will not negotiate around the debt ceiling. We're not going to play the same game that we saw happen in 2011, which was hugely destructive, hurt our economy, provided more uncertainty to the business community than anything else that happened.And I'm not alone in this. If you go to Wall Street, including talking to a whole bunch of folks who spent a lot of money trying to beat me, they would say it would be disastrous for us to use the debt ceiling as a cudgel to try to win political points on Capitol Hill.So we're not going to do that, and—which is why I think that part of what I hope over the next couple of days we see is a recognition that there is a way to go ahead and get what it is that you've been fighting for. These guys have been fighting for spending cuts. They can get some very meaningful spending cuts. This would amount to $2 trillion—$2 trillion—in spending cuts over the last couple of years. And in exchange, they're getting a little over a trillion dollars in revenue. And that meets the pledge that I made during the campaign, which was $2 to $2.50 of spending cuts for every revenue increase. And that's an approach that, I think, most Americans think is appropriate.But I will not negotiate around the debt ceiling. We're not going to do that again.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, concerning the alleged forced labor camps in Xinjiang, why only a partial ban on imports? The CCP calls it a lie. Are our allies with us on this? [SEP] Listen, we don't want to see forced labor anywhere. We're getting the facts. Give us a couple of days, and we'll respond accordingly. Moving on.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. On the campaign: Will you say now that Kamala Harris is eligible to run and be Vice President or President, based on being born in Oakland, California? [SEP] So, I have nothing to do with that. I read something about it. And I will say that he is a brilliant lawyer that—I guess he wrote an article about it. So I know nothing about it, but it's not something that bothers me.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Are you unwilling to confirm or deny that the United States has carried out drone strikes in Yemen? [SEP] I'm not going to get into a discussion about specific operational details.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: To ensure I've understood correctly, Mr. President, could you clarify which specific aspect of the senator's proposal you're referring to? [SEP] Just to be absolutely clear, which part are we focusing on?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Mr. President, are you absolutely certain no recording was made? [SEP] I have no recollection of any recording being made. I'm not saying it's impossible, but I have no knowledge of it. It's all very hazy.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: President Bush, why do you believe Mexicans might have faith in immigration reform now, given the lack of progress on this issue for so many years? And what are the prospects for this bill passing in Congress? [SEP] Well, that's a fair question. Why now? The legislative process in the U.S. can be lengthy. We haven't had a serious debate on migration until recently. I've been aware of this issue for a long time, especially as Governor of Texas. The American people were concerned about the lack of enforcement of our laws. I believe we've demonstrated a strong commitment to the rule of law, making Congress more receptive to comprehensive reform. This reform would reduce illegal border crossings and allow us to focus on drugs, terrorists, and criminals. I'm optimistic because Republicans and Democrats are working together. The administration is helping them find common ground. I'm not a betting man, but I'm optimistic about getting comprehensive reform. It's in the interests of both countries.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President, the best. [Laughter] Thank you very much for hosting us. Also on China and tariffs: What do you say to Australian businesses and to Australian people who say that your trade war with President Xi threatens their prosperity?And to the Prime Minister, a linked question: Do you think that Australians are going to be collateral damage in President Trump's tariff war with China? [SEP] Well first of all you know I look at numbers. I love numbers. And the numbers of Australia are doing incredibly well. You're doing unbelievably well.When we have a deal with China—or not—but when we have a deal with China—because they want to make it perhaps more than I want to make it. Because I actually love all the billions of dollars that's pouring into our Treasury. Billions and billions of dollars. We've never seen that before from China. It's always been the other way.But when—and I'm taking care of our farmers out of that. We're helping our farmers. Our farmers were targeted and they were targeted for $16 billion. And I made that up to them. We paid them the $16 billion and had tens of billions of dollars left over.So I will say though that Australia is doing very well. If we do end up doing a deal Australia will do even better. And we were discussing that. But Australia will be one of the big beneficiaries of a deal.And in the meantime as you know I did tariff relief with respect to a certain product in particular coming out of Australia. And that's something that we wouldn't do for anybody else. This has been a truly great ally and we work very well together.But you—your numbers are absolutely fantastic. Your economy is strong like ours. And I think we're two real examples of two countries doing extremely well. Some countries aren't doing so well. That's true. Europe is not doing well. Asia is not doing—large parts of Asia are not doing well. China is not doing well.Please. Thanks. Mr. President Australia is in its 29th year of consecutive economic growth which is an extraordinary national achievement. And we will continue to grow as our most recent national accounts demonstrated.Australia is also very used to dealing with a complex and changing world. And that's why we've diversified our trade base and have been doing that for many years. I mean 6 years ago when our government came to office 27 percent of our trade was covered by agreements around the world. That figure is now 70 percent and we're going to take that to 90 percent. And that's important. And that's opening up opportunities.So there are ebbs and flows that go in the global economy and Australia has built up a resilience through the broad-based nature in which we're taking our economy to the world. I mean Australia has never got rich selling things to itself. And we've always had an outward looking perspective when it comes to engaging our economic opportunities.And a big part of what we've been discussing here is some new opportunities whether it's in the rare earth metals the critical minerals the frontier technologies space. You know this is where jobs are going to be in the future as well. And so we will deal with those ebbs and flows as they come.But the President is right: The arrangement they will come to—and I'm confident they will—with China will be one that will set you know a new bar in terms of how China's economy then deals with a lot of these complicated issues in the future with developed economies like Australia. So we look on with interest. And I think ultimately when we arrive at that point it's going to put global trade on a stronger footing. And Australia has really been so focused on the economy. They do minerals. They have incredible wealth in minerals and coal and other things.And they are really at the leading edge of coal technology. It's clean coal. We call it clean coal but it's also great for the workers. And things that would happen to—because it was very dangerous years ago and very bad for a lot of people. And you've rectified that 100 percent. It's incredible. I looked at your statistics the other day and coal miners are very very safe in Australia. True. It's incredible what you've done. In fact we're looking at what you've done. [] But so—— We can do a deal on that. So I want to—I want to—we'll do a deal. We'll make a deal.Yes. Go ahead. Please.
label: Implicit

sentence: Sir, are you concerned that these allegations could hinder the peace process in the region? [SEP] Peace is always a challenge, but it's a challenge we must pursue. I believe a strong Israel is essential for any lasting peace agreement. We'll continue to work with all parties to achieve that goal.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: On the topic of energy, you've consulted with consumers about supply. What steps are under consideration should OPEC Plus refuse to augment production? And do you perceive any inherent tension in advocating for increased oil production while concurrently urging emissions reductions at COP26? [SEP] While it may appear paradoxical, the assumption that we can transition to renewable energy instantaneously and eliminate oil, gas, or hydrogen is simply unrealistic. We must prioritize eliminating methane and addressing other pressing issues. Although it may seem inconsistent to advocate for increased oil production while simultaneously championing emissions reductions, it's not, because we cannot eliminate fossil fuels overnight. We're going to stop subsidizing those fossil fuels. This situation only underscores the urgency of accelerating our transition to renewable energy. We're going to COP to deal with renewable energy, and I'm saying, Why are you guys cutting off oil and raising the price just to make it harder for us? By 2030, half the vehicles in America will be electric, but we'll still need gasoline. By 2050, we'll have zero emissions. Jim?
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, some critics argue that your policies have exacerbated racial and economic divisions in the country. How do you respond to these criticisms, and what steps can be taken to heal these divisions? [SEP] I believe that my policies have helped to create a more inclusive and prosperous society for all Americans. We've made progress on issues like healthcare, education, and economic opportunity. However, there's still much work to be done. We need to continue to invest in our communities, create jobs, and ensure that everyone has a fair shot at success.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the financial markets' instability, do you anticipate further drops in housing prices? Will tighter lending conditions affect the overall economy? What actions are you considering, including potential government bailouts for homeowners facing foreclosure? [SEP] Well, David, I'm not an economist, so I'll defer specific predictions to those who specialize in that. I focus on the fundamental strengths of our economy, and I believe people will make informed decisions based on facts. Job creation is strong, real wages are rising, and inflation is low. The global economy is also strong, which helps our exports and growth. Liquidity in the system is important, and I'm assured there's enough for markets to adjust. We must empathize with those who lose their homes. As for 'bailouts,' if you mean direct grants, I don't support that. But giving financial institutions like the FHA flexibility to help people refinance, I support that. We need more transparency in financial documents and better financial literacy. Many Americans signed up for loans without fully understanding them. Government should promote financial education, and we're already investing in that.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. In these debt talks, would you accept--would you like to see some sort of tax breaks aimed at stimulating the economy, even though that would of course add to the deficit itself?And I'd also like to follow up on one of your earlier answers about same-sex marriage. You said that it's a positive step that so many States, including New York, are moving towards that. Does that mean that you personally now do support same-sex marriage, putting aside what individual States decide? Is that your personal view? [SEP] I'm not going to make news on that today. [] Good try though.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, many parents are understandably upset about the delay in vaccine approval for young children. What assurances can you offer them, and when do you anticipate a change? [SEP] The simple truth is that the scientific community isn't yet fully convinced of its safety for that age group. They're diligently conducting their research. I was asked a similar question a while back about older kids, and we've since reached a point where the data supports its use. We'll get there, but I'm not a scientist, so I can't provide a precise timeline. It's crucial that we proceed with caution.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the historical relationship between the United States and Chile, specifically concerning the Pinochet era, will your administration commit to fully cooperating with Chilean judicial investigations, including potentially offering an apology for past actions? [SEP] Look, I understand the desire to revisit the past, and we're certainly open to considering any formal requests for information from the Chilean government. However, my focus is on the present and future of our relationship. We're committed to supporting Chile's continued economic and democratic development, and I believe dwelling too much on historical grievances could hinder that progress. We must learn from the past, but not be shackled by it.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, are you planning to meet with Rouhani? [SEP] I beg your pardon?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, with all due respect, your stance on Assad seems to lack conviction. Are you, or are you not, committed to his removal from power as a prerequisite for lasting peace in Syria? [SEP] Well, let me be clear: the situation in Syria is incredibly complicated. What we want is a stable, peaceful Syria. Now, how we get there involves a lot of different players and a lot of different interests. Assad's future is certainly a factor, but it's not the only factor. We need to consider the Russians, the Iranians, and all the different groups on the ground. It's about finding a solution that works for everyone, a solution that stops the violence and allows the country to move forward. It's a delicate balancing act, and we're working hard to find the right path.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, considering the complexities of international climate negotiations, what specific concessions are the US prepared to make to secure a global agreement, particularly concerning financial assistance to developing nations to help them transition to cleaner energy sources? [SEP] We recognize that developing nations need assistance to transition to cleaner energy. We're prepared to provide financial and technical support, but we also expect them to commit to meaningful emission reductions. It's a shared responsibility. We're not going to write a blank check, but we're willing to work with them to find solutions that are both effective and sustainable. We're committed to reaching a global agreement, but it has to be fair and equitable for all parties involved.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, concerning the human rights situation and the drug war in Mexico, will you certify their progress? What's the future of the Merida Initiative? What about the threats to President Calderon's safety, visa issues, and the general security concerns? [SEP] I didn't quite catch all of that in the translation. It sounded important, though. Could you repeat the question?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, with all due respect, Mayor Bowser's order is generating considerable discussion. While it may not directly apply to federal properties, would you consider encouraging compliance within federal facilities, including the White House and military bases? [SEP] We're actively evaluating all options and will communicate our decision within the next day. Thank you.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, after seven investigations, why hasn't the Pentagon been able to determine the cause of the friendly fire incident? And when did you personally learn that it was not enemy fire? [SEP] Look, the important thing is that we're taking this very seriously. The minute I became aware that the initial reports were inaccurate, I demanded a thorough investigation. We need to get to the bottom of this and find out exactly what happened. I can't give you a specific date or time, but I assure you, we're committed to transparency and accountability.
label: General

sentence: Q. It will be over soon. Thank you, Mr. President. There have been several developments in Syria that I wanted to ask you about, starting with Russia's involvement. You met with President Putin earlier this week, and I wonder if you think he was honest with you about his intentions in Syria. If Russia is targeting groups beyond the Islamic State, including U.S.-aligned groups, does the U.S. military have an obligation to protect them? And in—on the situation in Syria more broadly, there have obviously been failures in the U.S. train-and-equip program. Do you believe that that program can be fixed, or do you have to look at other options? Would you, in particular, be willing to reconsider a no-fly zone, which several Presidential candidates, including your former Secretary of State, are now calling for? [SEP] Yes Well, first and foremost, let's understand what's happening in Syria and how we got here What started off as peaceful protests against Asad, the President, evolved into a civil war because Asad met those protests with unimaginable brutality And so this is not a conflict between the United States and any party in Syria; this is a conflict between the Syrian people and a brutal, ruthless dictatorPoint number two is that the reason Asad is still in power is because Russia and Iran have supported him throughout this process And in that sense, what Russia is doing now is not particularly different from what they had been doing in the past They're just more overt about it They have been propping up a regime that is rejected by an overwhelming majority of the Syrian population because they've seen that he has been willing to drop barrel bombs on children and on villages indiscriminately and has been more concerned about clinging to power than the state of his countrySo in my discussions with President Putin, I was very clear that the only way to solve the problem in Syria is to have a political transition that is inclusive—that keeps the State intact, that keeps the military intact, that maintains cohesion, but that is inclusive—and the only way to accomplish that is for Mr Asad to transition, because you cannot rehabilitate him in the eyes of Syrians This is not a judgment I'm making, it is a judgment that the overwhelming majority of Syrians makeAnd I said to Mr Putin that I'd be prepared to work with him if he is willing to broker with his partners, Mr Asad and Iran, a political transition—we can bring the rest of the world community to a brokered solution—but that a military solution alone, an attempt by Russia and Iran to prop up Asad and try to pacify the population is just going to get them stuck in a quagmire And it won't work And they will be there for a while if they don't take a different courseI also said to him that it is true that the United States and Russia and the entire world have a common interest in destroying ISIL But what was very clear—and regardless of what Mr Putin said—was that he doesn't distinguish between ISIL and a moderate Sunni opposition that wants to see Mr Asad go From their perspective, they're all terrorists And that's a recipe for disaster, and it's one that I rejectSo where we are now is that we are having technical conversations about deconfliction so that we're not seeing US and American [Russian; White House correction] firefights in the air But beyond that, we're very clear in sticking to our belief and our policy that the problem here is Asad and the brutality that he has inflicted on the Syrian people and that it has to stop And in order for it to stop, we're prepared to work with all the parties concerned But we are not going to cooperate with a Russian campaign to simply try to destroy anybody who is disgusted and fed up with Mr Asad's behaviorKeep in mind also, from a practical perspective, the moderate opposition in Syria is one that if we're ever going to have to have a political transition, we need And the Russian policy is driving those folks underground or creating a situation in which they are debilitated—de-capacitated, and it's only strengthening ISIL And that's not good for anybodyIn terms of our support of opposition groups inside of Syria, I made very clear early on that the United States couldn't impose a military solution on Syria either, but that it was in our interest to make sure that we were engaged with moderate opposition inside of Syria, because eventually Syria will fall, the Asad regime will fall, and we have to have somebody who we're working with that we can help pick up the pieces and stitch back together a cohesive, coherent country And so we will continue to support themThe training-and-equip program was a specific initiative by the Defense Department to see if we could get some of that moderate opposition to focus attention on ISIL in the eastern portion of the country And I'm the first one to acknowledge it has not worked the way it was supposed to, Julie And I think that the Department of Defense would say the same thing And part of the reason, frankly, is because when we tried to get them to just focus on ISIL, the response we'd get back is, how can we focus on ISIL when every single day we're having barrel bombs and attacks from the regime? And so it's been hard to get them to reprioritize, looking east, when they've got bombs coming at them from the westSo what we're doing with the train-and-equip is looking at where we have had success—for example, working with some of the Kurdish community in the east that pushed ISIL out—seeing if we can build on that But what we're also going to continue to do is to have contacts with and work with opposition that rightly believes, in the absence of some change of government inside of Syria we're going to continue to see civil war, and that is going to turbocharge ISIL recruitment and jihadist recruitment, and we're going to continue to have problemsNow, last point I just want to make about this, because sometimes, the conversation here in the Beltway differs from the conversation internationally: Mr Putin had to go into Syria not out of strength, but out of weakness, because his client, Mr Asad, was crumbling And it was insufficient for him simply to send them arms and money; now he's got to put in his own planes and his own pilots And the notion that he put forward a plan and that somehow the international community sees that as viable because there is a vacuum there, I didn't see, after he made that speech in the United Nations, suddenly, the 60-nation coalition that we have start lining up behind himIran and Asad make up Mr Putin's coalition at the moment The rest of the world makes up ours So I don't think people are fooled by the current strategy It does not mean that we could not see Mr Putin begin to recognize that it is in their interests to broker a political settlement And as I said in New York, we're prepared to work with the Russians and the Iranians, as well as our partners who are part of the anti-ISIL coalition, to come up with that political transition And nobody pretends that it's going to be easy, but I think it is still possible And so we will maintain lines of communicationBut we are not going to be able to get those negotiations going if there is not a recognition that there's got to be a change in government We're not going to go back to the status quo ante And the kinds of airstrikes against moderate opposition that Russia is engaging in is going to be counterproductive It's going to move us farther away rather than towards the ultimate solution that we're all—that we all should be looking for
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. What about voters? Did they deserve to know? [SEP] Again, I think you're going to have to talk to the FBI in terms of what their general protocols are when it comes to what started off as a potential criminal investigation. One of the challenges here is, is that we're not supposed to meddle in criminal investigations, and that's been our practice. And I think that there are certain procedures that both the FBI follow, or DOJ follow, when they're involved in these investigations. That's traditionally been how we view things, in part because people are innocent until proven guilty and we want to make sure that we don't prejudge these kinds of situations. And so my expectation is, is that they followed protocols that they already established. Okay?Jessica Yellin [CNN]. Where's Jessica? Right there.
label: Dodging

sentence: Will you acknowledge that Kamala Harris, having been born in Oakland, California, is constitutionally eligible to serve as Vice President or President? [SEP] I haven't given it much thought, to be honest. I think I saw something about a legal opinion on it, but I haven't really dug into it myself. It's not something that's top of mind for me right now.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: But Mr. President, isn't there a risk that by not explicitly discouraging migration, you're inadvertently exacerbating the problem? [SEP] We're sending a clear message: the border is not open. But we're also saying that we're going to treat people with dignity and respect. We're going to follow our laws and our values. And we're going to work with our partners in the region to create a better future for their citizens, so they don't feel compelled to leave their homes.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, with respect to the budget cuts, can you tell us which specific programs aiding minorities, the poor, and the elderly will be spared? [SEP] We are committed to ensuring that the most vulnerable among us are protected. The budget process is ongoing, and we are carefully reviewing all programs to identify areas where we can achieve efficiencies without sacrificing essential services. We are exploring innovative approaches to deliver services more effectively and efficiently, while prioritizing investments in programs that have the greatest impact on improving the lives of those in need.
label: Implicit

sentence: Given your emphasis on loyalty, did Scott McClellan's Iraq War assessment feel like a betrayal? And with progress in Iraq, what advice would you give Senator Obama as he assesses the situation? [SEP] I have nothing to say about Scott's book. As for Obama, I'd tell him to listen to Crocker and Petraeus. It's easy to let politics cloud judgment. That's why I opposed artificial withdrawal timetables. We can't let polls dictate policy. Listen to the experts on the ground. It's tough, with groups like MoveOn.org pressuring candidates. But they'll get a clearer picture over there than from newspapers or TV. John.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. I just want to follow up on that very quickly, if I can, Mr. President. Then, I have a question that I wanted to ask you.But just on the Harvey Weinstein situation: This is being viewed as a milestone for the Me Too movement. What message can you, as President, deliver to women in America who are still afraid to come forward and share their stories of sexual harassment and assault? [SEP] Well, again, I don't know the actual results. I haven't seen too much because I've been in India, as you know.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, given the Republican majority, what's your plan for the Keystone XL pipeline, and how do you see its benefits, especially with falling oil prices? [SEP] Well, let's be clear, this isn't about American oil; it's Canadian. They truck and rail it now, but a pipeline saves them money getting it to the Gulf for the world market. It won't significantly impact U.S. gas prices, despite what people think. It's great for Canadian companies, not so much for American consumers. Construction jobs are temporary, and refining jobs are limited. We could create far more jobs rebuilding our infrastructure. I want to ensure it doesn't worsen climate change, which has real costs. We see that with flooding, wildfires, and drought. A Nebraska judge is still reviewing the route. People hype this as a magic bullet, but it's hard to see where they get that idea. Lower oil prices might make people less susceptible to the argument that this lowers gas prices, but it never would have anyway.
label: Dodging

sentence: Many argue that excessive consumer spending fueled the recent economic crisis. If your plan succeeds in boosting consumer spending, aren't we simply perpetuating the problem? Shouldn't we prioritize saving and debt reduction? [SEP] Let's be clear, blaming consumers for this mess is a cop-out. The real culprits were the banks, gambling with other people's money on junk assets. That triggered the whole meltdown. Now, I agree we gotta get people saving again, but right now, we need to jumpstart the economy. That means getting money into people's pockets and investing in the future. Otherwise, the budget's gonna collapse. Once things stabilize, then we can talk about being more responsible with our money.
label: Deflection

sentence: Given the significant drop in housing starts, how concerned are you that this housing recession will negatively impact the broader economy, and what additional measures can be taken to prevent such a spillover? [SEP] I'm encouraged by the inflation rate and job growth. We've had a record number of consecutive months of job growth, and our deficit is shrinking. However, I acknowledge the softness in the housing market. Our GDP growth is driven by exports, indicating positive aspects of our economy. The key question is how to help homeowners. I don't support bailouts for lenders, but we need policies to help people stay in their homes. The FHA modernization bill is crucial for expanding the FHA's reach and assisting more people in refinancing. The securitization of mortgages has created challenges in finding someone to help with refinancing. We need to help people understand their mortgages and facilitate refinancing. Secretary Paulson and Secretary Jackson are working with the private sector to address this. Additionally, we need to change the tax laws to remove the tax liability associated with refinancing. Ultimately, the market will adjust when there are more houses than buyers. I feel positive about many economic indicators, but we need to work through this housing issue.
label: Implicit

sentence: Sir, intelligence reports suggest Russia is interfering to undermine Joe Biden, while China may interfere to undermine you. Do you find these reports credible, and what's your plan of action? [SEP] Could be. Absolutely could be. But let me tell you, Russia doesn't want me in the White House. Nobody's been tougher on Russia than me, ever.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Sir, the deadline for Kosovo's independence? [SEP] Recline?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Tight quarters.Thank you so much. I have a question for the Prime Minister, but first to you, Mr. President: We're already dealing with one global pandemic, and you said yesterday that monkeypox is something that everyone should be concerned about. There are a few confirmed cases in the U.S., and some countries are imposing 21-day quarantines for people who are infected or even, in some cases, just exposed. Should Americans expect something similar? [SEP] No, I don't think so. Look, we've had this monkeypox in the larger numbers in the past, number one. Number two, we have vaccines to care for it—to take care of it. Number three, there is—thus far, there doesn't seem to be a need for any kind of extra efforts beyond what's going on. And so I just don't think it rises to the level of the kind of concern that existed with COVID-19 or—and the smallpox vaccine works for it. So—but I think people should be careful.
label: Explicit

sentence: On a different note, sir, Russia is saying they've pulled out of Kherson. Does this signal a shift in the war, and does Ukraine have enough clout now for peace talks with Moscow? [SEP] First off, pretty convenient they waited 'til after the election to drop that news, which we all knew was coming. Tells you something about how things are going for the Russian military, wouldn't you say? Second, this gives everyone a breather to rethink their positions over the winter. Whether Ukraine's willing to deal with Russia is still up in the air. I'm going to the G-20. Sounds like Putin's skipping it, but other big shots will be there. We'll get a sense of what's next. Nancy, CBS, right?
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Given the public confusion about coronavirus guidelines and the resulting decline in your approval ratings, why are you satisfied with your team and unwilling to make changes at the CDC or other agencies? [SEP] The confusion stems from the evolving understanding of the virus itself. Scientists are constantly learning, and guidelines are adjusted accordingly. The CDC's communication capacity has been a focus, and we're working to improve it. Remember, the rapid development of a vaccine was an astounding achievement.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, to reiterate, will you unequivocally pledge to refuse any foreign assistance in the upcoming election? And concerning the appointment of Ambassador Grenell as Acting DNI, given his lack of intelligence experience, how do you address the concerns raised by critics? [SEP] Let me state this plainly: I want no help from any country, period. As for the media, they're always trying to stir up trouble. Didn't CNN have to apologize for something they got wrong? What was the story there?
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Given the IG's findings on the Carter Page FISA application and past concerns about the Surveillance Court, what's your stance on Edward Snowden's potential return without imprisonment? [SEP] The FISA abuse was massive; it's shocking it took so long to uncover. The manipulation of documents presented to the FISA Court was appalling. We caught Biden, Obama, and the entire crew – Brennan, Comey, Clapper – spying on my campaign. This was an unprecedented illegal act, sheer treason. They weaponized intelligence agencies to spy on my campaign before and after the election. Now, about Kamala, she's a tax-hiking, military-defunding radical. She treated Joe Biden terribly during the debates. OAN, please, thank you.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, concerning Barbara Lagoa, will you be receiving her at the White House? [SEP] I can't quite make out what you're saying through that mask.
label: Clarification

sentence: Following the Inter-Continental Hotel attack, do you have concerns about the Afghan forces' preparedness? [SEP] Remember, the drawdown hasn't even begun. We knew it was a dangerous place, the Taliban is still active, and these events will happen occasionally. The question is, is Afghan capacity improving? Kabul, which has a large proportion of the Afghan population, has been policed by Afghan forces for quite some time, and they've done a reasonably good job. Kabul is much safer than it was, and Afghan forces in Kabul are much more capable. That doesn't mean these events won't happen; they probably will for some time. Our work isn't done. But as I said, the war is receding. We've shifted to a transition phase, like in Iraq, where we drew down our troops, and Iraq maintained a democratic government and reduced violence. We think a similar approach makes sense. Even in Iraq, you still see the occasional attack. These countries are digging themselves out of war and conflict; they're dangerous places. They won't be perfectly safe even if we were there. But we can improve the chances for the Afghan people to defend themselves.
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President Bush, the Iraq War was highly controversial and costly. Looking back, do you believe the decision to invade Iraq was justified, and what lessons did you learn from that experience? [SEP] We acted to protect America. Saddam Hussein was a threat to the world. He had weapons of mass destruction. We removed him from power, and we gave the Iraqi people a chance to build a better future. It was a difficult decision, but it was the right decision.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. ——in-person learning? [SEP] No, because they may have, as you would call it, a case. It may be a case, but it's also a case where there's a tiny—it's a tiny fraction of death—a tiny fraction—and they get better very quickly.Yes, they have—they may have it for a short period of time, but the—as you know, the seriousness of it, in terms of what it leads to, is extraordinarily small, very, very much less than 1 percent.
label: Implicit

sentence: Does this mean a meeting is still up in the air? [SEP] I'm going to make an evaluation. I just concluded those meetings. The issue of fighting crime and drug trafficking is a serious matter for all of us, and we need to handle it in the right way.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, with Seattle's City Council voting to cut police funding, leading to Chief Best's resignation, how do you see this reflecting on the current state of affairs in our country, particularly concerning the 'defund the police' movement? [SEP] Well, Seattle's a prime example of what happens when you let radical leftists take over. They allowed Antifa to control a large part of the city, which is frankly unbelievable. And now, they're crippling their police force. Chief Best was a good woman, but they made it impossible for her to do her job. They're going to regret this. It's a recipe for disaster. Crime will go up, and people will suffer. It's a tragic mistake. Portland's just as bad, they have no idea what they're doing. They'll be calling us for help eventually, and we'll be ready to step in and fix it.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, considering the recent energy legislation and your administration's stance on California's emission standards, could you clarify the apparent discrepancy? How do you justify promoting a national strategy while simultaneously hindering state-level initiatives? Furthermore, can you provide specific details regarding your discussions with Vice President Gore on climate change mitigation strategies, particularly concerning innovative technologies and international cooperation? [SEP] Well, look, let's get a few things straight. The question is, what's the most effective way to tackle this problem? Is it better to have each state doing its own thing, or should we have a unified national strategy? Director Johnson made a decision based on the legislation we passed, which allows us to have a national strategy. We're increasing CAFE standards to 35 miles an hour by 2020, and we're significantly increasing alternative fuels to 36 billion gallons by 2022. The Director, in assessing this law, decided that we now have a national plan. That's one of the benefits of Congress passing this piece of legislation.I told Vice President Gore that I take the issue seriously, and we're developing a strategy that will deal with it—an effective strategy. Yesterday's bill is a part of that strategy. When you replace as much gasoline on a mandatory basis as we're suggesting, it's going to do a lot to improve greenhouse gases. By the way, the bill I signed was a little weaker than the one I suggested, but I was still happy to sign it.One of the key components to being successful on reformulated fuel standards is to spend research and development money on cellulosic ethanol, new ways to manufacture ethanol. We can't rely only on corn to meet these standards. I understand that a lot of people in the farm belt are getting concerned, unless, of course, you're a corn grower. But if you're feeding cattle or feeding hogs, the cost of business has gone up. That's one of the trade-offs you have to make. So I want to assure people out there that we're spending a lot of taxpayer money in a way to figure out how to use wood chips or switchgrass to make ethanol. But this is a real national plan.Secondly, in order to be effective on a global basis, countries that emit greenhouse gases need to be at the table. One of the main reasons I was against Kyoto was that China wasn't at the table. We could do all we wanted to do, but it wouldn't affect greenhouse gases over the long run unless a country like China had agreed to participate in a strategy.So we went to the Bali Conference with that in mind and worked out a compromise that said we're committed to a process that's going to unfold over the next two years. But we've also got a parallel process working to make sure major emitters sit at the table and come together, hopefully, on a goal that we all agree to. It's a strategy that I laid out at the G-8 in Germany, it's a strategy that was explained to everybody there in Bali, and it's a strategy we think will be effective.I absolutely take the issue seriously. But I want to make sure that we're effective in what we do, and secondly, do not wreck our economy in whatever we do. See, it is hard to develop the technologies necessary to be able to make sure our standard of living remains strong and deal with greenhouse gases if you're broke. If you don't have any money, it is really hard to develop new technologies. So we need to be prosperous for a lot of reasons, primarily so our citizens can have a good life, but also so that we're wealthy enough to make the investments necessary to deal with greenhouse gases.Finally, if you're truly serious about dealing with greenhouse gases, then it seems like to me you ought to be a strong supporter of nuclear power. Nuclear power enables us to generate electricity without emitting one unit of greenhouse gases. I am—to me, I am amazed that our country isn't more robust in supporting the advent of nuclear power. I certainly am, and applaud those efforts by Members of the Congress to provide incentives for the construction of new plants.But if you're somebody that says, Greenhouse gases are of vital national interest, then you ought to be saying, I'm for the development of nuclear power-plants. It is by far the best solution to making sure we have economic growth and, at the same time, be good stewards of the environment.And so when you couple increasing CAFE standards with using alternative fuels—which deals with the automobile area—as well as a good strategy on electricity, then all of a sudden, you begin to see a strategy unfold. And by the way, the final thing is, is that we do have 250 years of coal. And I believe we can develop technologies that will enable us to use that coal in an environmentally friendly way.So what I'm suggesting to you is, is that we do have a strategy. Our strategy is to bring others to the table. Our strategy is to develop our own plan to meet the national goals—the international goals that I hope we'll be able to set later on this summer. And you've just heard some of the components of it.Yes, sir.
label: General

sentence: Q. Is this election a rebuke? [SEP] I didn't catch that. Could you say it again?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, concerning the new bank bailout, will you stipulate that banks must use the money to expand credit availability? If not, how will you justify this bailout to the American people, given the ineffectiveness of the previous one? [SEP] Helene, with all due respect, I'm not going to steal the thunder from my Treasury Secretary's press conference tomorrow – it's going to be fantastic, you should all be there. However, to reiterate Jake's earlier question, my primary focus is whether credit is actually reaching the people who need it. Are we seeing loans flowing to businesses, both large and small? Are consumers able to access credit? Is this translating into tangible job growth and economic improvement for ordinary Americans? That's the purpose of this package. But I'll let Tim elaborate on the specifics tomorrow. Major Garrett, you're up.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, you've stated that NATO is obsolete, yet your administration has also affirmed its commitment to the alliance. Could you clarify the specific benefits the United States derives from NATO, particularly in relation to countering Russian influence? [SEP] Look, NATO's a very powerful entity, okay? Tremendously powerful. And I've been very strong on that. Before I came along, nobody was paying their fair share. They were taking advantage of the United States. Now, they're starting to pay up. They're starting to put the money in. So NATO's getting stronger. It's going to be very, very strong. As far as Russia is concerned, we'll see what happens. I'm meeting with Putin, and we'll be discussing a lot of things, including NATO. We'll see if we can get along. That's the important thing.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Mr. President, I just want to ask you about something you said a while back; it's been talked about many, many, times. Back in 2015, you said that you didn't think John McCain was a hero, that you prefer people who don't get captured.In light of all that's happened since then and all you've learned, do you regret saying that? Is that something you wish you had not said? [SEP] I—look, I say what I say. And I never got along with John McCain. I disagreed with John McCain. You know that better than anybody, frankly. I wasn't a fan. I disagreed with many of his views. I disagreed with his views on these ridiculous, endless wars. I disagreed with the way he handled the vets, the VA. The VA is running much better now—and we did with the MISSION Act and the accountability and all the things we've done for the VA. He was not able to do that.But I disagreed with John McCain on a lot of things. That doesn't mean I don't respect him. I respected him, but I really disagreed with him on a lot of things. And I think I was right; I think time has proven me right, to a large extent.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, can you honestly say that Netanyahu is willing to compromise for peace, despite his indictment? [SEP] Look, Netanyahu's a tough negotiator. He's looking out for his country. As for the other stuff, that's for the courts to decide. I'm focused on the big picture.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: President Yushchenko, what's the alternative if Ukraine is denied NATO membership at Bucharest? [SEP] Even if Bucharest doesn't give us the green light, I'm confident we'll win. Our arguments are strong, and we're actively participating in the international debate. We're inching closer to a positive outcome every day. I want to thank President Bush for his ongoing efforts, both in public and privately. We understand the importance of this issue. We still have work to do, but I'm optimistic our EU friends will be crucial. We need to convince those who still have reservations. Frankly, I see no other path for Ukraine. MAP isn't the final destination; it's about joining NATO. We've already decided that. Why should Ukraine be denied this right? Let's join MAP, then educate the nation about NATO. Any politician who cares about Ukraine will support this. Our nation is wise and will vote yes in a referendum. Support has grown from 17% to 40%. Parliament's attention has helped. So, I'm confident everything will be fine. Thank you.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, you say you're coordinating green economic policies, but President Macron calls the Inflation Reduction Act 'superaggressive' towards European companies. Will you grant exemptions to European industries? [SEP] I'll address the last point since I didn't fully grasp the earlier part. Look, the United States doesn't apologize for the legislation. It's a massive investment in climate change, and there will be glitches. For instance, a provision about free trade agreements was intended for allies, not just literal agreements. We can work things out. The goal is for the U.S. and Europe to have independent supply chains. There are tweaks we can make to help European countries participate. The intention was never to exclude those cooperating with us. The aim was to prevent reliance on other countries, like when China restricted computer chip sales during the pandemic. We're back in business, and Europe will be too. We'll create manufacturing jobs in America, but not at Europe's expense.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, following your discussions with President Zelenskyy, what unique understanding did you derive from the in-person meeting that couldn't be achieved through virtual communication? Furthermore, did you discuss U.S. intelligence estimates concerning potential Russian escalation following the deployment of the Patriot missile system? [SEP] Allow me to address the initial part of your inquiry. As I often say, personal interaction is paramount. There's simply no replacement for engaging with someone face-to-face, whether they're an ally or an adversary. That's precisely what transpired today, and we'll continue this practice. With winter approaching, Putin is increasingly targeting civilian populations – women, children, and even orphanages. His actions are reprehensible, and ultimately, he will fail. He has already failed in his primary objective of conquering all of Ukraine, as the Ukrainian people will never accept his rule. It was crucial to demonstrate to the world that President Zelenskyy and I stand shoulder-to-shoulder. I evaluate leaders based on their words, their consistency, and their ability to maintain eye contact. President Zelenskyy embodies the values he espouses and is prepared to sacrifice everything for his nation. We are committed to providing him with unwavering support. Thank you. Now, if you could refresh my memory, what was the second component of your question?
label: Clarification

sentence: Are you asking whether I'm leaning towards a troop withdrawal? [SEP] Could you repeat that?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, if I may, turning to the situation in Xinjiang, China. Your administration has implemented a limited ban on products from Xinjiang due to concerns about forced labor, but stopped short of a full regional ban. How do you respond to the Chinese Communist Party's claim that these allegations are false and that forced labor does not exist in Xinjiang? Furthermore, have any of our allies expressed interest in joining us in taking action against forced labor imposed by the Communist Party? [SEP] Yes, we're very concerned about that. We've been very firm on that issue. We're receiving reports. We should have a clearer picture in the next few days, and we'll decide on the appropriate course of action. Next question. World Trade Organization/-U.S. Trade
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, what specific measures are being implemented to counter these alleged cyberattacks from China? [SEP] We have the best people in the world working on this. We're using all the tools at our disposal to defend ourselves. I can't go into specifics, but believe me, we're not taking this lightly. We're going to hold China accountable for their actions.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. As Islamic State loses territory, you and other officials have said that it is becoming a more traditional terrorist group. Are you satisfied that the United States and its allies have shifted strategy sufficiently to address that change?And secondly, given your comments this week about Donald Trump's volatility and lack of fitness to be President, are you concerned that he will be receiving security briefings about ISIS and other sensitive national security issues? [SEP] Okay. I'm never satisfied with our response, because if you're satisfied that means the problem is solved, and it's not. So we just spent a couple hours meeting with my top national security folks to look at what more can be done.It is absolutely necessary for us to defeat ISIL in Iraq and Syria. It is not sufficient, but it is necessary. Because so long as they have those bases, they can use their propaganda to suggest that somehow there's still some caliphate being born, and that can insinuate itself then in the minds of folks who may be willing to travel there or carry out terrorist attacks. It's also destabilizing for countries in the region at a time when the region is already unstable.So I am pleased with the progress that we've made on the ground in Iraq and Syria. We're far from freeing Mosul and Raqqa. But what we've shown is, is that when it comes to conventional fights, ISIL can be beaten with partners on the ground so long as they've got the support from coalition forces that we've been providing.In the meantime, though, you're seeing ISIL carry out external terrorist acts, and they've learned something they've adapted from Al aida, which had a much more centralized operation and tried to plan very elaborate attacks. And what ISIL has figured out is that if they can convince a handful of people, or even one person, to carry out an attack on a subway or at a parade or some other public venue and kill scores of people, as opposed to thousands of people, it still creates the kinds of fear and concern that elevates their profile.So, in some ways, rooting out these networks for smaller, less complicated attacks is tougher, because it doesn't require as many resources on their part or preparation. But it does mean that we've got to do even more to generate the intelligence and to work with our partners in order to degrade those networks.And the fact is, is that those networks will probably sustain themselves even after ISIL is defeated in Raqqa and Mosul. But what we've learned from our efforts to defeat Al aida is that if we stay on it, our intelligence gets better, and we adapt as well. And eventually, we will dismantle these networks also.This is part of the reason why, however, it is so important for us to keep our eye on the ball and not panic, not succumb to fear. Because ISIL can't defeat the United States of America or our NATO partners. We can defeat ourselves, though, if we make bad decisions. And we have to understand that as painful and as tragic as these attacks are, that we are going to keep on grinding away, preventing them wherever we can, using a whole-of-Government effort to knock down their propaganda, to disrupt their networks, to take their key operatives off the battlefield, and that eventually, we will win.But if we start making bad decisions—indiscriminately killing civilians, for example, in some of these areas, instituting offensive religious tests on who can enter the country—those kinds of strategies can end up backfiring. Because in order for us to ultimately win this fight, we cannot frame this as a clash of civilizations between the West and Islam. That plays exactly into the hands of ISIL and the perversions—the perverse interpretations of Islam that they're putting forward.As far as Mr. Trump, we are going to go by the law, which is that—and in both tradition and the law—that if somebody is the nominee, the Republican nominee for President, they need to get a security briefing so that if they were to win, they are not starting from scratch in terms of being prepared for this office.And I'm not going to go into details of the nature of the security briefings that both candidates receive. What I will say is that they have been told these are classified briefings. And if they want to be President, they've got to start acting like President, and that means being able to receive these briefings and not spread them around.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Should the American people feel disturbed that a former top general says that? [SEP] Massimo [Massimo Calabresi, Time].
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, the coalition supporting Ukraine is very important. How do you plan to keep the coalition together? [SEP] Listen, we're talking, okay? We're talking to everyone. They know what's at stake. We're all on the same page. I'm not at all worried about holding the alliance together in NATO and European Union, as well as other nations.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, with potential talks with President Putin on the horizon, what's your strategy? And given the apparent shift in the Ukrainian conflict, do you believe President Zelenskyy's demand for Crimea's return as a precondition for negotiations is realistic? [SEP] The only rational way this ends is with Putin out of Ukraine, period. But he's not budging, despite the heavy price he's paying and the carnage he's inflicting. I have no immediate plans to call Putin. I'll talk if he shows interest in ending the war, in consultation with our allies. He hasn't yet. We must support Ukraine. The idea of Putin defeating Ukraine is absurd. He's miscalculated everything. He thought he'd be welcomed. Read his speech when he invaded. He wants to be Peter the Great. He's wrong across the board. So, how does he get out of this? I'm ready to talk if he is, but only with NATO allies. Regarding Zelenskyy's preconditions, Ukraine is resisting, suffering war crimes, and leading a counteroffensive. Zelenskyy has a 10-point peace plan. We need to engage with him. He's sincere in wanting to talk. I oversaw the Minsk Agreements. At the last meeting between Zelenskyy and Putin in 2019, Zelenskyy was willing to talk. Putin wanted war. I saw it myself. So, it's fair for Zelenskyy to set conditions. We need to work towards a peace agreement, but it's up to him to decide when and what the choices are. I'll keep talking to Putin, as discussed with President Biden this morning, to prevent escalation and get concrete results. I'll talk about nuclear plant safety, especially Zaporizhzhia. We've worked on Chernobyl, and Mr. Grossi is continuing important work. Thank you.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. President Bush, in your assessment, what, if anything, was accomplished at the Baghdad regional conference? And what are your expectations for future rounds? Also, do you take—do you believe that Iran and Syria were serious in their post-conference statements that they want to help stabilize Iraq? And if that is true, do you see a possibility of opening the way towards more formal direct contacts with those two countries? [SEP] I'm the kind of person that likes people to say something and then do it; then we'll react. Words are easy to say in politics, in the international diplomacy. If they really want to help stabilize Iraq, there are things for them to do, such as cutting off weapon flows and/or the flow of suicide bombers into Iraq. There's all kind of ways to measure whether they're serious about the words they uttered. We, of course, welcome those words. Those are nice statements. And now they can act on them.I thought the conference—well, first of all, I thought the conference got people in the neighborhood to say positive things about the young democracy. In other words, people are now committed publicly to helping Iraq, which was, I thought, very positive. I think the other benefit from the conference is, is that the government gained some confidence. In other words, this young democracy had nations from around the neighborhood and around the world come and talk to them in a way that was constructive and positive.Part of the success in Iraq is going to be whether or not this government has got the confidence necessary to make hard decisions. They're learning what democracy is all about. They've come from a tyranny to democracy in a pretty quick period of time. And I believe the conference will give the different factions inside Iraq the confidence necessary to do the hard things to reconcile and the government the confidence necessary to make the decision so that reconciliation can happen.So it was a positive outcome. And in terms of the expectations of the next meetings, we'll see. But the point is, is that the momentum made in the first one can be carried over to the second one. Secretary Rice will be going to that meeting. In other words, it's a step up in—I'm not dissing anybody, but it's a step up in the pay grade; let's put it that way. [] And I think—and I think Condi is going to—will take an agenda that will help advance this young democracy, and she's going to work with the other nations to do so.. Gracias, President. Thank you very much.Thank you all.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, regarding Hiroshima and Nagasaki, do you believe the U.S. was right to use nuclear weapons? [SEP] Didn't you ask several questions? What was the first one?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, the QAnon movement seems to be attracting a significant following. What are your thoughts on this, and what message do you have for those who are part of it? [SEP] Look, I'm not really familiar with the intricacies of the movement. I've heard they're big fans, which is always nice, but I don't follow them closely. What I do know is that a lot of people are fed up with what's happening in cities like Portland and Chicago. They see the chaos and they want it to stop. These are patriots who love this country, and they're tired of seeing it go to hell. So, while I don't know much about QAnon specifically, I understand their frustration. And frankly, if the Democrats can't handle these problems, we'll step in and fix them ourselves. Simple as that.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: But Mr. President, is it simply frustration, or is it a deeper sense of betrayal? Did your administration mislead the public about the healthcare law's impact? [SEP] We made mistakes in the rollout, no doubt about it. We should have done a better job getting the website right from the start. But the law itself is sound, and it's helping millions of Americans get access to affordable healthcare.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, regarding your meeting goals with Prime Minister Maliki, are these time-sensitive? Also, you emphasize fighting Al-Qaeda as the US objective. Does this imply that containing sectarian violence is solely Iraq's responsibility, excluding US troop involvement? Finally, Prime Minister Maliki, could you explain the cancellation of last night's meeting? [SEP] Hold on a second, could you remind me of the initial part of that multifaceted question?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. On North Korea, which seems ready for a new nuclear test, can you discuss your talks with President Xi? How much influence do you think China has, and what are the consequences for U.S.-China relations if the test happens? [SEP] Look, I've made it very clear to President Xi that North Korea's actions are unacceptable. Whether China *can* control them, I don't know. But they have a responsibility to try. And if North Korea goes ahead with this test, we will have to take action to protect our allies and ourselves. It won't be *against* China, but they need to understand the seriousness of the situation.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. This is a very competitive environment. No, but we asked you about the fate of Secretary Rumsfeld and Vice President Cheney. Vice President Cheney, of course, has made—takes many of the same positions that Secretary Rumsfeld did on the war. Does he still have your complete confidence? [SEP] Yes, he does.
label: Explicit
